en: I Night
vi: I – Night
tr: I Night
es: I THE NIGHT
CHAPTER 1

en: We slept in what had once been the gymnasium.
vi: We slept in what used to be the gymnasium.
tr: We used to sleep in a place that was once a gymnasium.
es: We slept in what had once been the gymnasium.

en: The floor was of varnished wood, with stripes and circles painted on it, for the games that were formerly played there; the hoops for the basketball nets were still in place, though the nets were gone.
vi: The floor was made of varnished wood, painted with circles and lines for games of the past; the basketball hoops were still there, though the nets were gone.
tr: The floor was polished parquet, bearing the lines and circles drawn for games played in the past; the hoops of the basketball nets were still in place, but the nets were gone.
es: The floor, made of varnished wood, had lines and circles painted on it for various sports. The basketball hoops were still there, but the nets had disappeared.

en: A balcony ran around the room, for the spectators, and I thought I could smell, faintly like an afterimage, the pungent scent of sweat, shot through with the sweet taint of chewing gum and perfume from the watching girls, felt-skirted as I knew from pictures, later in miniskirts, then pants, then in one earring, spiky green-streaked hair.
vi: A long balcony ran along the four walls, meant for spectators, and I could almost smell, faintly like a lingering echo, the pungent scent of sweat, mixed with hints of chewing gum and perfume from the girls watching, dressed in wool skirts – I saw it in movies – then over time to mini skirts, pants, and finally with one ear pierced, hair streaked with blue and spiked with gel.
tr: A balcony surrounded the hall, for spectators, and from what I know from pictures, I imagined I could smell the sharp scent of sweat mingling with the pleasant aroma of gum and perfume from the girls in felt skirts at first, then mini-skirts, later pants, and finally with earrings in one ear and stiff hair with green streaks, like a fleeting afterimage.
es: The room was surrounded by a gallery for the audience; and I had the impression that I could perceive, like in a vague mirage, the acrid smell of sweat mixed with that sweet touch of chewing gum and the perfume of the girls who were among the audience, dressed in felt skirts — that's how I had seen them in the photos —, later in miniskirts, then in pants, finally with a single earring and styled with crests of green stripes.

en: Dances would have been held there; themusic lingered, a palimpsest of unheard sound, style upon style, an undercurrent of drums, a forlorn wail, garlands made of tissue-paper flowers, cardboard devils, a revolving ball of mirrors, powdering the dancers with a snow of light.
vi: Perhaps dances were also held here: the music still lingers, layers of sound overlapping without listeners, one tune covering another, the drumbeats blending, the mournful wails, garlands made of crepe paper, cardboard devil masks, the glass ball on the ceiling slowly turning, scattering clusters of light over the dancing couples.
tr: Balls were also held there; the music would be dying: like a parchment of unheard sound, layer upon layer, with drum sounds coming from underneath, a desperate cry; garlands made of thin paper flowers; cardboard devil masks; a rotating glass ball sprinkling a snow of light over the dancers.
es: Dances had been held here; the music persisted, a palimpsest of sounds that no one listened to, one style after another, a background of drums, a melancholic wail, garlands of flowers made of tissue paper, cardboard demons, a rotating mirror ball that sprinkled the dancers with flakes of light.

en: There was old sex in the room and loneliness, and expectation, of something without a shape or name.
vi: At that time, the room was filled with the scent of old intimacy and loneliness, and a longing, waiting for something without shape or name.
tr: There was a sexuality left in the past in the room, and loneliness and expectation, of something without form or name.
es: In the room, there were reminiscences of sex and loneliness and expectation, the expectation of something without form or name.

en: I remember that yearning, for something that was always about to happen and was never the same as the hands that were on us there and then, in the small of the back, or out back, in the parking lot, or in the television room with the sound turned down and only the pictures flickering over lifting flesh.
vi: I still remember that longing, yearning for something always just ahead and always new, like the hands that had been placed on me there, at that moment, on the small of my back, or further away, in the parking lot, or in the room with the TV turned down low, only flickering images casting shadows on the moving flesh.
tr: I remember the longing we felt for something always changing and about to happen, like the hands on us there and then, in the parking lot or on the bodies moving up and down, in the silent TV room where only the images flickered, on the narrowest part of the back or outside.
es: I remember that sensation, the longing for something that was always about to happen and was never the same, just as the hands that, without wasting time, caressed our lumbar region were not the same, or slipped between our clothes when we crouched in the parking lot or in the television room with the device muted and the images flickering over our exalted flesh.

en: We yearned for the future.
vi: We long for the future.
tr: We also longed for the future.
es: We sighed for the future.

en: How did we learn it, that talent for insatiability?
vi: Where does that talent come from, that never-satisfied desire?
tr: How did we acquire this ability, this insatiability?
es: Where did we get that talent for insatiability?

en: It was in the air; and it was still in the air, an after-thought, as we tried to sleep, in the army cots that had been set
vi: It hovers in the air; and it remains in the air, like a late thought, when we try to lull ourselves to sleep, on the military folding beds arranged in rows, spaced apart to prevent any intention of conversation.
tr: It was in the air; it was still in the air as we tried to sleep on military-issue portable beds lined up at intervals that made conversation impossible; like a belated thought.
es: It floated in the air; and it was still breathed in, like a late idea, when we tried to sleep on the army cots arranged in a row and separated from each other so we couldn't talk.

en: up in rows, with spaces between so we could not talk.
vi: It hovers in the air; and it remains in the air, like a late thought, when we try to lull ourselves to sleep, on the military folding beds arranged in rows, spaced apart to prevent any intention of conversation.
tr: It was in the air; it was still in the air as we tried to sleep on military-issue portable beds lined up at intervals that made conversation impossible; like a belated thought.
es: It floated in the air; and it was still breathed in, like a late idea, when we tried to sleep on the army cots arranged in a row and separated from each other so we couldn't talk.

en: We had flannelette sheets, like children's, and army-issue blankets, old ones that still said U. S.
vi: The beds are made with faux flannel sheets, like children's, and the blankets are also military issue, old blankets still bearing the U.S. mark.
tr: We had flannel sheets, similar to those of children, and still old military-issue blankets with "US" written on them.
es: We had cotton flannel sheets, like the ones children use, and army blankets, so old they still bore the initials U. S.

en: We folded our clothes neatly and laid them on the stools at the ends of the beds.
vi: Clothes are neatly folded and placed on the stool at the foot of the bed.
tr: We would neatly fold our clothes and place them on the stools at the foot of the beds.
es: We folded our clothes very neatly and left them on the stool at the foot of the bed.

en: The lights were turned down but not out.
vi: The lights are dim but not completely off.
tr: The lights were not turned off but dimmed.
es: The lights would dim immediately but were never turned off.

en: Aunt Sara and Aunt Elizabeth patrolled; they had electric cattle prods slung on thongs from their leather belts.
vi: Aunt Sara and Aunt Elizabeth hover around supervising, cattle prods dangling from their leather belts.
tr: Aunt Sara and Aunt Elizabeth would patrol; they had electric prods hanging from the straps on their leather belts.
es: Aunt Sara and Aunt Elizabeth made the rounds; on their leather belts they carried electric prods like the ones used for cattle.

en: No guns though, even they could not be trustedwith guns.
vi: But not the guns; even they couldn't put guns in our hands.
tr: Still, they had no weapons; they were too untrustworthy to be given weapons.
es: However, they did not carry weapons; not even those would have been entrusted to them.

en: Guns were for the guards, specially picked from the Angels.
vi: The guns were reserved for the guards, the Angels carefully chosen.
tr: The weapons were especially for the Guardians chosen from among the Angels.
es: Their use was reserved for the Guardians, who were specially chosen from among the Angels.

en: The guards weren't allowed inside the building except when called, and we weren't allowed out, except for our walks, twice daily, two by two around the football field, which was enclosed now by a chain-link fence topped with barbed wire.
vi: The guards were not allowed inside the school unless summoned, and we were not allowed out, except for the twice-daily walks, in pairs, around the football field, fenced with wire mesh and barbed wire.
tr: The Guardians were not allowed to enter the building unless summoned, and we were not allowed to go outside, except for our walks; twice a day, in pairs, around the football field now surrounded by barbed wire.
es: The presence of Guardians inside the building was not allowed, except when they were called; and we were not allowed to go out, except for our walks, twice a day and in pairs, around the football field that was now fenced with a chain-link fence topped with barbed wire.

en: The Angels stood outside it with their backs to us.
vi: Outside, the Angels stood with their backs turned.
tr: The Angels would stand outside this fence with their backs turned to us.
es: The Angels remained outside, turning their backs to us.

en: They were objects of fear to us, but of something else as well.
vi: They instilled fear, and kindled other feelings within us.
tr: They were objects of fear for us, but they were also something else.
es: For us, they were a source of fear, and also something more.

en: If only they would look.
vi: If only they would turn and look.
tr: Oh, if only they would look!
es: If only they would look at us, if we could talk to them...

en: If only we could talk to them.
vi: If only we could speak to them.
tr: If only we could talk to them.
es: If only they would look at us, if we could talk to them...

en: Something could be exchanged,we thought, some deal made, some tradeoff, we still had our bodies.
vi: We imagined we could exchange something, establish a deal, a barter; we still had our bodies.
tr: We thought something could be exchanged, a deal, a trade, we still had our bodies.
es: We believed that we could exchange something, make a deal, reach an agreement, we still had our bodies...

en: That was our fantasy.
vi: Such were our dreams.
tr: This was our fantasy.
es: This was our fantasy.

en: We learned to whisper almost without sound.
vi: We learned to whisper almost inaudibly.
tr: We almost learned to whisper silently.
es: We learned to whisper almost without making a sound.

en: In the semi-darkness we could stretch out our arms, when the Aunts weren't looking, and touch each other's hands across space.
vi: In the dim light, we could reach out, when the aunts weren't paying attention, and touch each other through the gaps between the beds.
tr: In the semi-darkness, we could reach out our arms, and when the Aunts weren't looking, we could cross the void and touch each other's hands.
es: In the semi-darkness, when the Aunts weren't looking, we would stretch out our arms and touch each other's hands.

en: We learned to lip-read, our heads flat on the beds, turned sideways, watching each other's mouths.
vi: We learned to read each other's lips, cheek pressed against the bed, lying on our sides, watching each other's mouths move.
tr: We also learned to read lips, our heads pressed against the pillow, turned sideways, watching each other's lips.
es: We learned to read the movement of the lips: with our heads pressed against the bed, lying on our sides, we watched each other's mouths.

en: In this way we exchanged names, from bed to bed: Alma.
vi: In this way, names were passed along, from bed to bed. Alma.
tr: We communicated our names this way, from bed to bed: Alma.
es: Thus, from one bed to another, we communicated the names: Alma, Janine, Dolores, Moira, June.

en: Janine.
vi: Janine.
tr: Janine.
es: Thus, from one bed to another, we communicated the names: Alma, Janine, Dolores, Moira, June.

en: Dolores.
vi: Dolores.
tr: Dolores.
es: Thus, from one bed to another, we communicated the names: Alma, Janine, Dolores, Moira, June.

en: Moira.
vi: Moira.
tr: Moira.
es: Thus, from one bed to another, we communicated the names: Alma, Janine, Dolores, Moira, June.

en: June.
vi: June.
tr: June.
es: Thus, from one bed to another, we communicated the names: Alma, Janine, Dolores, Moira, June.

en: II Shopping
vi: II – Shopping
tr: II
es: II

vi: II – Shopping
tr: Shopping
es: THE PURCHASE
CHAPTER 2

en: A chair, a table, a lamp.
vi: One chair, one table, one lamp.
tr: A chair, a table, a lamp.
es: A chair, a table, a lamp.

en: Above, on the white ceiling, a relief ornament in the shape of a wreath, and in the center of it a blank space, plastered over, like the place in a face where the eye has been taken out.
vi: High up on the whitewashed ceiling, a wreath in relief, with a gaping hole of plaster in the center, like an empty socket where an eye had been removed.
tr: A relief decoration in the shape of a wreath on the white ceiling and in the middle a plastered empty area resembling a hole in a face with one eye removed.
es: Above, on the white ceiling, a relief ornament in the shape of a garland, and in the center of it a blank space covered with plaster, like a face from which the eyes have been gouged out.

en: There must have been a chandelier, once.
vi: There must have once hung a chandelier here.
tr: There must have been a chandelier hanging there once.
es: There must have once been a chandelier there.

en: They've removed anything you could tie a rope to.
vi: They had taken away everything that could be used to tie a rope to.
tr: They have removed everything that could be hung.
es: But they have removed all the objects to which a rope could be tied.

en: A window, two white curtains.
vi: A window, two white curtains.
tr: A window, two white curtains.
es: A window, two white curtains.

en: Under the window, a window seat with a little cushion.
vi: Below is the windowsill with a small cushion placed on it.
tr: Below the curtains, a window seat with a small pillow on it.
es: Under the window, a seat with a small cushion.

en: When the window is partly openit only opens partlythe air can come in and make the curtains move.
vi: When the window is slightly open – never more than that – the wind blows in, making the curtains sway.
tr: When the window is half-opened - it won't open any further anyway - the wind can come in and move the curtains.
es: When the window is partially opened –it only opens partially— air comes in and moves the curtains.

en: I can sit in the chair,or on the window seat, hands folded, and watch this.
vi: I can sit on the chair, or on the windowsill, arms folded, watching this scene.
tr: I can sit on the chair or the window seat, clasp my hands, and watch this.
es: I can sit in the chair, or on the window seat, with my hands crossed, and dedicate myself to contemplating.

en: Sunlight comes in through the window too, ami falls on the floor, which is made of wood, in narrow strips, highly polished.
vi: Sunlight also comes in through the window, falling onto the floor, made of wood, assembled from narrow planks, polished to a shine.
tr: Daylight also enters through the window and reflects on the floor covered with narrow-striped, overly polished parquet.
es: Sunlight also enters through the window and projects onto the narrow, highly waxed wooden floorboards.

en: I can smell the polish.
vi: I can smell the polish.
tr: I can smell the polish.
es: I can smell the wax.

en: There's a rug on the floor, oval, of braided rags.
vi: The floor is covered with a rug, oval-shaped, woven from rags.
tr: On the floor, an oval rug, woven from rags.
es: On the floor, there is an oval rug, made from old braided rags.

en: This is the kind of touch they like: folk art, archaic, made by women, in their spare time, from things that have no further use.
vi: They like that style: folk craftsmanship, somewhat old-fashioned, made by women in their spare time, from discarded materials.
tr: This is what they like: folk art, archaic, made by women, in their spare time, from things that serve no other purpose.
es: This is the kind of detail they like: folk art, archaic, made by women in their spare time with things that are no longer useful.

en: A return to traditional values.
vi: Returning to traditional values.
tr: A return to traditional values.
es: A return to traditional values.

en: Waste not want not.
vi: Waste not, want not.
tr: Waste not, want not.
es: Do not consume, do not desire.

en: I am not being wasted.
vi: I am not being wasted.
tr: I'm not being wasted.
es: Do not consume, do not desire.

en: Why do 1 want?
vi: Why is there still not enough?
tr: Why would I want to be?
es: If I do not consume, why do I still desire?

en: On the wall above the chair, a picture, framed but with no glass: a print of flowers, blue irises, watercolor.
vi: On the wall above the chair, a painting, framed but without glass: it depicts flowers, blue irises, watercolor.
tr: A picture on the wall above the chair, framed but without glass: a flower print, blue irises, watercolor.
es: On the wall, above the chair, a painting with a frame but without glass: it is a watercolor of flowers, of blue irises.

en: Flowers are still allowed, Does each of us have the same print, the same chair, the same while curtains, I wonder?
vi: Flowers are still allowed. Do we all have the same paintings, the same chairs, the same white curtains?
tr: The flower is still allowed. Do we each have the same picture, the same chair, the same white curtains?
es: Flowers are still allowed. I wonder if the others also have a painting, a chair, some white curtains.

en: Government issue?
vi: Standard issue?
tr: Government property?
es: Are these items distributed by the government?

en: Think of it as being in the army, said Aunt Lydia.
vi: Just consider it like being in the military, Aunt Lydia said.
tr: Imagine that you are in the army, Aunt Lydia would say.
es: "Act as if you were in the army," said Aunt Lydia.

en: A bed.
vi: There is a bed.
tr: A bed.
es: A bed.

en: Single, mattress medium-hard, covered with a flocked white spread.
vi: A single bed, medium-firm mattress, white sheets stuffed with recycled cotton.
tr: Single, with a medium-firm mattress, covered with a woolly white blanket.
es: Single, with a semi-firm mattress covered by a white quilt filled with batting.

en: Nothing takes place in the bed but sleep; or no sleep.
vi: The bed is for nothing other than sleeping – or not sleeping.
tr: Nothing happens in the bed except sleeping; or not being able to sleep.
es: In the bed, nothing is done except sleep... or not sleep.

en: I try not to think too much.
vi: I try not to think too much.
tr: I try not to think too much.
es: I try not to think too much.

en: Like other things now, thought must be rationed.
vi: Like everything right now, even thinking has to be rationed.
tr: Like other things, now thoughts should also be rationed.
es: Like everything else, thought has to be rationed.

en: There's a lot that doesn't bear thinking about.
vi: There are many things not worth the effort of thinking about.
tr: There are many things that are unbearable to think about.
es: There are many who cannot bear to think.

en: Thinking can hurt your chances, and I intend to last.
vi: Thinking too much can affect your chances, and I want to survive.
tr: Thinking can push one's luck, but my goal is to endure.
es: Thinking can harm your chances, and I intend to resist.

en: I know why there is no glass, in front of the watercolor picture of blue irises, and why the window opens only partly and why the glass in it is shatterproof.
vi: I know why there is no glass, why the watercolor painting of irises is covered, and why the window is only slightly open, using unbreakable glass.
tr: I know why the watercolor painting of blue irises is without glass, why the window is only half-open, and why the glass is unbreakable.
es: I know why the painting of the blue lilies has no glass, and why the window only opens partially, and why the window glass is shatterproof.

en: It isn't running away they're afraid of.
vi: It's not that they fear escape.
tr: What they fear is not our escape.
es: What they fear is not that we might escape –after all, we wouldn't get very far— but those other exits, the ones you can open within yourself if you have a sharp mind.

en: Wewouldn't get far.
vi: We wouldn't get far anyway.
tr: We can't go too far anyway.
es: What they fear is not that we might escape –after all, we wouldn't get very far— but those other exits, the ones you can open within yourself if you have a sharp mind.

en: It's those other escapes, the ones you can open in yourself, given a cutting edge.
vi: But they fear that other escape, the one we could open within ourselves, with just something sharp-edged.
tr: It's the other escapes you can make with something sharp within yourself that they fear.
es: What they fear is not that we might escape –after all, we wouldn't get very far— but those other exits, the ones you can open within yourself if you have a sharp mind.

en: So.
vi: That's it.
tr: That's how it is.
es: So, apart from these details, this could be the guest room of a school, but the room for the less distinguished visitors; or a room in a guesthouse like the ones from before, suitable for ladies of limited means.

en: Apart from these details, this could be a college guest room, for the less distinguished visitors; or a room in a rooming house, of former times, for ladies in reduced circumstances.
vi: Besides those points, this is also like a living room at a university, meant for the most ordinary guests; or a boarding room, in the old days, for ladies in reduced circumstances.
tr: Aside from these details, this could be a college guest room, for less distinguished visitors; or a boarding house room, from old times, for ladies with limited means.
es: So, apart from these details, this could be the guest room of a school, but the room for the less distinguished visitors; or a room in a guesthouse like the ones from before, suitable for ladies of limited means.

en: That is what we are now.
vi: Just like us now.
tr: This is who we are.
es: This is where we are now.

en: The circumstances have been reduced; for those of us who still have circumstances.
vi: All in reduced circumstances, that is, for those who still have circumstances.
tr: Limited means for those of us who still have means.
es: The possibilities have been reduced... for those of us who still have possibilities.

en: But a chair, sunlight, flowers: these are not to be dismissed.
vi: But chairs, sunlight, and flowers: should not be denied.
tr: However, the chair, daylight, flowers: These cannot be removed.
es: But the chair, the sunlight, the flowers... should not be despised.

en: I am
vi: I am still alive, I live, I breathe, I stretch my hand, spread wide, reaching into the sunlight.
tr: I am alive, I am living, I am breathing, I extend my hand into the daylight without breaking it.
es: I am alive, I live, I breathe, I extend my open hand to the sunlight.

en: alive, I live, I breathe, I put my hand out, unfolded, into the sunlight.
vi: I am still alive, I live, I breathe, I stretch my hand, spread wide, reaching into the sunlight.
tr: I am alive, I am living, I am breathing, I extend my hand into the daylight without breaking it.
es: I am alive, I live, I breathe, I extend my open hand to the sunlight.

en: Where I am is not a prison but a privilege, as Aunt Lydia said, who was in love with either/or.
vi: Where I live is not a prison, but a privilege, Aunt Lydia said so, faithful to her either-or formula.
tr: The place I am in is not a prison, on the contrary, it is a privilege, as Aunt Lydia, who loves 'either/or' phrases, would say.
es: The place where I am is not a prison but a privilege, as Aunt Lydia used to say, who loved extremes.

en: The bell that measures time is ringing.
vi: The hour bell is ringing.
tr: The bell that measures time is ringing.
es: The bell that marks the time is ringing.

en: Time here is measured by bells, as once in nunneries.
vi: Here, the time is announced by bells, like in old monasteries.
tr: As it used to be in monasteries, time here is also measured by bells.
es: Here, time is marked by bells, as it used to be in nunneries.

en: As in a nunnery too, there are few mirrors.
vi: Also like monasteries, there are hardly any mirrors.
tr: Again, like in a monastery, there are very few mirrors here.
es: And, also like in a convent, there are few mirrors.

en: I get up out of the chair, advance my feet into the sunlight, in their red shoes, flat-heeled to save the spine and not for dancing.
vi: I stood up from the chair, stepped into the sunlight, in red shoes with flat soles, to protect my spine, not for dancing.
tr: I get up from my chair, stretching my feet in red shoes with flat heels designed not for dancing but for protecting the spine into the daylight.
es: I get up from the chair, take a step towards the sunlight with the red low-heeled shoes, designed to protect the spine but not for dancing.

en: The red gloves are lying on the bed.
vi: The red gloves lay on the bed.
tr: The red gloves are on the bed.
es: The red gloves are on the bed.

en: I pick them up, pull them onto my hands, finger by finger.
vi: I picked them up, put them on my hands, one finger at a time.
tr: I pick them up and put them on, sliding each finger into place one by one.
es: I pick them up and put them on, finger by finger.

en: Everything except the wings around my face is red: the color of blood, which defines us.
vi: Everything except the wings on either side of my face was red: the color of blood, our sign.
tr: Everything is red, except for the wings on either side of my face: the color of the blood that defines us.
es: Except for the headdress that surrounds my face, everything is red, the color of blood, which is what defines us.

en: The skirt is ankle-length, full, gathered to a flat yoke that extends over the breasts, the sleeves are full.
vi: A flared dress reaching the ankles, a flat corset up to the chest, long sleeves covering completely.
tr: The dress extends down to the ankles, loose, gathered with a wide band around the chest, and the sleeves are loose as well.
es: The skirt is long down to the ankles and wide, gathered in a smooth yoke that covers the chest, and the sleeves are wide.

en: The white wings too are prescribed issue; they are to keep us from seeing, but also from being seen.
vi: Even the white wings were special items: so we couldn't see, but also wouldn't be seen.
tr: The white wings are also by command; to prevent us from seeing, and of course, from being seen.
es: The white headdress is mandatory; its purpose is to prevent us from seeing, and also from being seen.

en: I never looked good in red, it's not my color.
vi: I didn't look good in red clothes, they didn't suit me at all.
tr: Red has never suited me, it is not my color.
es: Red never suited me well, it's not my color.

en: I pick up the shopping basket, put it over my arm.
vi: I picked up the shopping basket, slung it over my arm.
tr: I take the shopping basket and hang it on my arm.
es: I grab the shopping basket and hang it on my arm.

en: The door of the roomnot my room, I refuse to say myis not locked.
vi: The door of this room – not my room, I'm not talking about my room – is not locked.
tr: The door of the room -not my room, I refuse to call it mine- is not locked.
es: The door of the room – not my room, I refuse to acknowledge it as mine

en: In fact it doesn't shut properly.
vi: To be precise, it cannot be closed.
tr: In fact, it doesn't even close properly.
es: — it is not locked. In fact, it cannot even be adjusted.

en: I go out into the polished hallway,which has a runner down the center, dusty pink.
vi: I step out into the polished hallway, with a long carpet in the middle, pink mixed with gray.
tr: I step out into the polished corridor with a dirty pink runner in the middle.
es: I step out into the hallway, waxed and covered with a central carpet of ashen pink color.

en: Like a path through the forest, like a carpet for royalty, it shows me the way.
vi: Like a trail through the forest, like a velvet carpet for dignitaries, it guides my way.
tr: Like a path in the forest, a royal carpet shows me the way.
es: Like a path in the forest, like a carpet for royalty, it shows me the way.

en: The carpet bends and goes down the front staircase and I go with it, one hand on the banister, once a tree, turned in another century, rubbed to a warm gloss.
vi: The carpet turned the corner and went down the stairs ahead, and I followed, sliding my hand along the banister, which was once a tree, felled in a century long past, worn to a glossy shine.
tr: After a bend, the carpet goes down the front stairs, and I follow it, one hand on the banister, which was once a tree, made in another century and polished until it took on a warm glow.
es: The carpet traces a curve and descends the stairs; I follow it, resting one hand on the banister that was once a tree, crafted in another century, polished to make it shine.

en: Late Victorian, the house is, a family house, built for a large rich family.
vi: Late Victorian, a house for a whole family, a large, wealthy family.
tr: A late Victorian-style family house, built for a large and wealthy family.
es: The house is of late Victorian style and was built for a wealthy and large family.

en: There's a grandfather clock in the hallway, which doles out time, and then the door to the motherly front sitting room, with its flesh tones and hints.
vi: The hall had a grandfather clock, measuring out time bit by bit, followed by a door leading to the main lounge, with a motherly appearance, tinged with flesh tones.
tr: In the hall, there is an aged wall clock that kindly shows the time and a door that opens to the matronly sitting room at the front, with its beige tones and hints, a sitting room where I never sat, only stood or knelt.
es: In the hallway, there is a pendulum clock that languidly marks the time, and then a door that leads to the maternal living room, populated with shadows.

en: A sitting room in which I never sit, but stand or kneel only.
vi: A lounge where I had never sat or lain down to rest, only knelt or stood.
tr: In the hall, there is an aged wall clock that kindly shows the time and a door that opens to the matronly sitting room at the front, with its beige tones and hints, a sitting room where I never sat, only stood or knelt.
es: A room in which I never sit, I only stand or kneel.

en: At the end of the hallway, above the front door, is a fanlight of colored glass: flowers, red and blue.
vi: At the other end of the hall, above the main door, a half-moon stained glass window: floral patterns, red and blue.
tr: At the end of the hall, above the front door, there is a stained glass window: flowers, red and blue.
es: At the end of the hallway, above the front door, there is a fanlight with colored glass forming red and blue flowers.

en: There remains a mirror, on the hall wall.
vi: There is still a mirror on the wall in the hall.
tr: Only the mirror on the hall wall remains.
es: On the wall of the living room, there is still a mirror.

en: If I turn my head so that the white wings framing my face direct my vision towards it, I can see it as I go down the stairs, round, convex, a pier glass, like the eye of a
vi: If you turn your head so that the two wings limit the rotation field to look straight into it, you will see it when going down the stairs, round, convex, as long as a person, like a fish's eye, seeing myself in it as a distorted shadow, not knowing what to mock – a fairy tale character wearing a red scarf, gradually descending to a moment of carelessness as equal to danger.
tr: As I descend the stairs, if I turn my head in such a way that the white wings on either side of my face direct my view towards the mirror, I see the round, convex, fish-eye-like glass mirror and myself reflected in it; a distorted shadow, a parody of something, like a fairy tale character in a red cloak descending towards a momentary carelessness equivalent to danger.
es: If I turn my head – in such a way that the white cap framing my face directs my vision towards it – I can see it while descending the stairs: a round, convex, full-body mirror, like a fish's eye, and my image reflected in it like a distorted shadow, a parody of something, like the figure from a fairy tale covered with a red cloak, descending towards a moment of indifference that is equal to danger.

en: fish, and myself in it like a distorted shadow, a parody of something, some fairy-tale figure in a red cloak, descending towards a moment of carelessness that is the same as danger.
vi: If you turn your head so that the two wings limit the rotation field to look straight into it, you will see it when going down the stairs, round, convex, as long as a person, like a fish's eye, seeing myself in it as a distorted shadow, not knowing what to mock – a fairy tale character wearing a red scarf, gradually descending to a moment of carelessness as equal to danger.
tr: As I descend the stairs, if I turn my head in such a way that the white wings on either side of my face direct my view towards the mirror, I see the round, convex, fish-eye-like glass mirror and myself reflected in it; a distorted shadow, a parody of something, like a fairy tale character in a red cloak descending towards a momentary carelessness equivalent to danger.
es: If I turn my head – in such a way that the white cap framing my face directs my vision towards it – I can see it while descending the stairs: a round, convex, full-body mirror, like a fish's eye, and my image reflected in it like a distorted shadow, a parody of something, like the figure from a fairy tale covered with a red cloak, descending towards a moment of indifference that is equal to danger.

en: A Sister, dipped in blood.
vi: A Nun, dipped in blood.
tr: A nun, stained with blood.
es: A sister, bathed in blood.

en: At the bottom of the stairs there's a hat-and-umbrella stand, the bentwood kind, long rounded rungs of wood curving gently up into hooks shaped like the opening fronds of a fern.
vi: At the end of the stairs, there was a hat and umbrella stand made of bent wood, with long round rods gently coiled into hooks that looked like young fern leaves unfurling.
tr: At the end of the stairs, there is a hat-and-umbrella stand with long, round wooden arms that gently curve towards hooks shaped like the unfurling fronds of a twisted fern.
es: At the foot of the staircase, there is a coat rack for hats and umbrellas; it has long, rounded wooden bars that gently curve to form hooks, imitating the leaves of a fern.

en: There are several umbrellas in it: black, for the Commander, blue, for the Commander's Wife, and the one assigned to me, which is red.
vi: A few umbrellas were left there: a black one, belonging to the Commander, a blue one, belonging to the Commander's Wife, and one meant for me, which was red.
tr: Inside it, there are a few umbrellas: a black one assigned to the Commander, a blue one to the Commander's Wife, and a red one to me.
es: Several umbrellas hang from it: a black one for the Commander, a blue one for the Commander's Wife, and the one assigned to me, which is red.

en: I leave the red umbrella where it is, because I know from the window that the day is sunny.
vi: I left the red umbrella alone, as I saw through the door that it was sunny today.
tr: I leave the red umbrella where it is, having seen from the window that the day was sunny.
es: I leave the red umbrella in its place: through the window, I see the sun shining.

en: I wonder whether or notthe Commander's Wile-is in the sitting room.
vi: I wondered if the Commander's Wife was in the lounge.
tr: I wonder if the Commander's Wife is in the sitting room.
es: I wonder if the Commander's Wife is in the living room.

en: She doesn't always sit.
vi: She wasn't always resting.
tr: She doesn't always sit there.
es: She is not always sitting there.

en: Sometimes 1 can hear her pacing back and forth, a heavy step and then a light one, anil the soft tap of her cane on the dusty-rose carpet.
vi: Occasionally, I would hear her walking back and forth, one heavy step followed by a light step, and the faint sound of her cane tapping on the peach-pinkish gray carpet.
tr: Sometimes, I can hear her pacing back and forth, one heavy and then one light footstep, and the soft taps of her cane on the dirty rose-colored carpet.
es: Sometimes I hear her pacing back and forth, one strong step and then a soft one, and the dull tap of her cane on the ash-pink carpet.

en: I walk along the hallway, past the sitting room door and the door that leads into the dining room, and open the door at the end of the hall and go through into the kitchen.
vi: I walked along the hallway, past the door to the lounge and the door leading to the dining room, and opened the door at the end of the hallway to enter the kitchen.
tr: Walking through the hallway, I pass the living room door and the door leading to the dining room, then open the door at the end of the hallway and enter the kitchen.
es: I walk down the hallway, pass by the living room door and the one that leads to the dining room; I open the one at the end and enter the kitchen.

en: Here the smell is no longer of furniture polish.
vi: The smell of wood polish was no longer there.
tr: This place no longer smells of furniture polish.
es: It doesn't smell like waxed wood here.

en: Rita is in here, standing at the kitchen table, which has a top of chipped white enamel.
vi: Rita was there, standing by the kitchen table, its white enamel surface chipped at the edges.
tr: Rita is standing next to the kitchen table, which is covered with white enamel.
es: I find Rita standing by the table painted with white enamel.

en: She's in her usual Martha's dress, which is dull green, like a surgeon's gown of the time before.
vi: She was wearing Martha's usual outfit, a dull green, like an old-fashioned surgical gown.
tr: She is wearing a familiar Martha dress, a dull green color reminiscent of an old operator's uniform.
es: She is wearing her usual Martha dress, of a dull green color, like a surgeon's gown from times past.

en: The dress is much like mine in shape, long and concealing, but with a bib apron over it and without the white wings and the veil.
vi: It was similar to my dress, long and fully covered, but with an apron and without the white wings or veil.
tr: This dress is very similar to mine in terms of shape, length, and concealment, but it has an apron, no white wings, and no veil.
es: The cut of her dress is very similar to mine, long and modest, but on top she wears an apron with a bib and has no cap or veil.

en: She puts on the veilto go outside, but nobody much cares who sees the face of a Martha.
vi: She only wore the veil when going outside, but it didn't matter if anyone saw the faces of the Marthas.
tr: She wears the veil when she goes outside, but no one really cares about seeing a Martha's face.
es: She only wears the veil when going out, but no one cares too much who sees a Martha's face.

en: Her sleeves are rolled in the elbow, showing her brown arms.
vi: Her sleeves were rolled up to the elbows, revealing her brown arms.
tr: The sleeves of her dress are rolled up to her elbows, revealing the brownness of her arms.
es: Her dress is rolled up to her elbows, revealing her dark arms.

en: She's making bread, thowing the loaves for the final brief kneading and then the shaping.
vi: She was making bread, tossing each loaf for a final knead before putting it into the mold.
tr: She is busy making bread, throwing the loaves onto the table for the final kneading and shaping.
es: She is making bread, spreading the dough for the brief final kneading and to shape it.

en: Rita sees me and nods, whether in greeting or in simple acknowl edgment of my presence it's hard to say, and wipes her floury hands on her apron and rummages in the kitchen drawer for the token book.
vi: Seeing me, Rita nodded, it was hard to tell if she was greeting me or just acknowledging my presence, and wiped her flour-covered hands on her apron to rummage through the kitchen drawer for the ration book.
tr: Rita sees me and nods her head; it's hard to tell if it's to greet me or simply to acknowledge my presence. She wipes her floury hands on her apron and starts searching for the report card in the kitchen drawer.
es: Rita sees me and moves her head –it's hard to tell whether as a greeting or just becoming aware of my presence—; she wipes her flour-covered hands on her apron and rummages through the drawer in search of the voucher book.

en: Frowning, she tears out three tokens and hands them to me.
vi: Her brows furrowed, she tore out three sheets and handed them to me.
tr: With a frown, she tears off three report cards and hands them to me.
es: He frowns, tears off three vouchers, and hands them to me.

en: Her face might be kindly if she would smile.
vi: If she smiled, her face would probably look kind.
tr: If she smiled, her face could look kind.
es: If he smiled, his face might appear kind.

en: But the frown isn't personal: it's the red dress she disapproves of, and what it stands for.
vi: But the frown wasn't directed at me personally: she was annoyed by the red dress and its implications.
tr: However, her frown is not personal: it's about the red dress she disapproves of and what it represents.
es: But his expression is not directed personally at me: he dislikes the red dress and what it represents.

en: She thinks I may be catching, like a disease or any form of bad luck.
vi: She thought I could be contagious, like a disease or a bad omen.
tr: She thinks I could be contagious, like a disease or bad luck.
es: He thinks I might be contagious, like a disease or some kind of misfortune.

en: Sometimes I listen outside closed doors, a thing I never would have done in the time before.
vi: Occasionally, I eavesdrop outside the closed door, something I would never have done in the past.
tr: Sometimes I stand in front of closed doors and eavesdrop, something I would never have done before.
es: Sometimes I listen behind doors, something I would never have done before.

en: I don't listen long, because I don't want to be caught doing it.
vi: I don't listen for long because I don't want to get caught.
tr: I don't listen for too long, because I don't want to get caught doing it.
es: I don't listen for too long because I don't want to get caught.

en: Once, though, I heard Rita say to Cora I hat she wouldn't debase herself like that.
vi: However, once I heard Rita telling Cora that she would not allow herself to stoop to such a level.
tr: Still, once, I heard Rita telling Cora that she wouldn't demean herself to that extent.
es: However, once I heard Rita telling Cora that she wouldn't lower herself in that way.

en: Nobody asking you, Cora said.
vi: Who asked you? Cora said.
tr: Nobody is asking this of you, said Cora.
es: Nobody is asking you to, replied Cora.

en: Anyways, what could you do, supposing?
vi: And besides, what would you do in that case?
tr: Anyway, what could you do if they did?
es: Anyway, what would you do if you could?

en: Go to the Colonies, Rita said.
vi: Arriving at the Expatriate area, Rita said.
tr: I would go to the colonies, said Rita.
es: Going to the Colonies, stated Rita.

en: They have the choice.
vi: They have the right to choose.
tr: They have a choice.
es: They have an alternative.

en: With the Unwomen, and starve to death and Lord knows what all?
vi: With the group of useless women, to starve to death and God knows what else?
tr: To the place where the Non-Women are? To that place where starvation and God knows what else await you?
es: With the No Women, starving to death and God knows what else?, asked Cora.

en: said Cora.
vi: Cora said.
tr: said Cora.
es: With the No Women, starving to death and God knows what else?, asked Cora.

en: Catch you.
vi: Please, I beg you.
tr: Don't be ridiculous.
es: You are crazy.

en: They were shelling peas; even through the almost-closed door I could hear the light clink of the hard peas falling into the metal howl.
vi: They are shelling beans; through the nearly closed door, I can still hear the hard beans clinking into the metal bowl.
tr: They were shelling peas, and even through the closed door, I could hear the soft clatter of the hard peas falling into the pot.
es: They were shelling peas; even through the half-closed door, I could hear the clinking sound the peas made as they fell into the metal bowl.

en: I heard Rita, a grunt or a sigh, of protest or agreement.
vi: I hear Rita's voice, grumbling or sighing, in protest or agreement.
tr: I could hear Rita grumbling or sighing as a sign of either disapproval or agreement.
es: I heard Rita grunt or sigh, I don't know if in protest or approval.

en: Anyways, they're doing it for us all, said Cora, or so they say.
vi: Anyway, they do it just for us, Cora said, or at least that's what they claim.
tr: Anyway, they do this for all of us, they say the same to Cora.
es: Anyway, they do it for us, or so they say, continued Cora.

en: If I hadn't of got my tubes tied, it could of been me, say I was ten years younger.
vi: If I hadn't tied it already, who knows, it might have been my turn, that is if I were ten years younger.
tr: If my tubes hadn't been tied, I could have been one of them, if I were ten years younger, for instance.
es: If I didn't have my tubes tied, it could be me, if I were ten years younger.

en: It's not that bad.
vi: It's not that bad.
tr: It's not that bad.
es: It's not that bad.

en: It's not what you'd call hard work.
vi: At least there's nothing you could call strenuous.
tr: Besides, you can't call this hard work.
es: It's not what you would call hard work.

en: Better her than me, Rita said, and I opened the door.
vi: It's better it than me, Rita said, and I pushed the door open.
tr: Rita said, "It's better for her to be in my place," as I opened the door.
es: She is better than me, said Rita, and at that moment I opened the door.

en: Their faces were the way women's faces are when they've been talking about you behind your back and they think you've heard: embarrassed, but also a little defiant, as if it were their right.
vi: On their faces appeared the same look as all women caught gossiping, thinking the subject had overheard: embarrassed, but also somewhat defensive, it was their right after all.
tr: Their faces were like those of women who talk behind your back and think they are not heard: surprised, a bit arrogant as if it were their right to speak that way.
es: They had the expression that women have when you catch them talking about you behind your back and they think you’ve heard them: an expression of discomfort and at the same time defiance, as if they were within their rights.

en: That day, Cora was more pleasant to me than usual, Rita more surly.
vi: That day, Cora was kinder to me, and Rita was more irritable than usual.
tr: That day, Cora had been more pleasant than usual to me, and Rita had been more irritable.
es: That day, Cora was kinder to me than usual and Rita more surly.

en: Today, despite Rita's closed face and pressed lips, I would like to stay here, in the kitchen.
vi: Today, despite Rita's tightly closed face and pursed lips, I still want to stay here, in this kitchen.
tr: Today, despite Rita's sullen face and tense lips, I would have liked to stay here, in the kitchen.
es: Today, despite Rita's impenetrable face and her tight lips, I would like to stay in the kitchen.

en: Cora might come in, from somewhere else in the house, carrying her bottle of lemon oil and her duster, and Rita would make coffeein the houses of the Commanders there is still real coffeeand we would sit at Rita's kitchen table, which is not Rita's any more than my table is mine, and we would talk, about aches and pains, illnesses, our feet, our backs, all the different kinds of mischief that our bodies, like unruly children, can get into.
vi: Cora might come in from some corner of the house, bringing a bottle of lemon oil and a rag, and Rita will make coffee – in the Commanders' houses, there is still real coffee, and we will sit around Rita's kitchen table, which isn't really Rita's, just like my table isn't really mine, and we will talk about aches and pains, illnesses, feet, backs, all the mischievous things the body likes to come up with, like naughty children.
tr: From another part of the house, Cora would come in with a bottle of lemon oil and a dust cloth, and Rita would make coffee -there is still real coffee in the Commanders' houses- and we would chat at Rita's kitchen table -just as my table wasn't mine, this table wasn't Rita's anymore- talking about aches, pains, and illnesses, that is, all those different ailments our feet, backs, and bodies could acquire like mischievous children.
es: Cora would come from somewhere else in the house with her bottle of lemon oil and her duster, and Rita would make coffee—in the Commanders' houses there is still real coffee—and we would sit around Rita's table—which belongs to her no more than mine belongs to me—and we would chat about ailments, illnesses, our feet, our backs, the different kinds of mischief that our bodies—as unruly creatures— they are capable of committing.

en: We would nod our heads as punctuation to each other's voices, signaling that yes, we know all about it.
vi: We will nod our heads in rhythm to the words of the others, showing that yes, we have been through all of that too.
tr: We would nod our heads to punctuate each other's words, meaning yes, we know all of this.
es: We would nod our heads, as if each nod punctuated the other's sentence, indicating that yes, we already know what it's about.

en: We would exchange remedies and try to outdo each
vi: We will share remedies and compete to tell of our physical miseries; we will complain softly, in a minor key, mournful like pigeons on the eaves.
tr: We would suggest remedies to each other and try to outdo one another while describing our physical sufferings; we would complain politely, our voices soft and low-pitched, and as mournful as pigeons in the rain gutters.
es: We would exchange remedies and try to outdo each other in the recital of our physical miseries; we would lament quietly, in a low and sad voice, in a minor tone like the pigeons nesting in the gutters of buildings.

en: other in the recital of our physical miseries; gently we would complain, our voices soft and minor key and mournful as pigeons in the eaves troughs.
vi: We will share remedies and compete to tell of our physical miseries; we will complain softly, in a minor key, mournful like pigeons on the eaves.
tr: We would suggest remedies to each other and try to outdo one another while describing our physical sufferings; we would complain politely, our voices soft and low-pitched, and as mournful as pigeons in the rain gutters.
es: We would exchange remedies and try to outdo each other in the recital of our physical miseries; we would lament quietly, in a low and sad voice, in a minor tone like the pigeons nesting in the gutters of buildings.

en: / know what you mean, we'd say.
vi: I understand you so well, we will say.
tr: We understand what you mean, we would say.
es: I know what you mean, we would affirm.

en: Or, a quaint expression you sometimes hear, still, from older people: / hear where you're coming from, as if the voice itself were a traveler, arriving from a distant place.
vi: Or sometimes, a peculiar phrase occasionally heard from the elderly: I hear where you're coming from, as if the voice itself were a traveler, coming from a distant place.
tr: Or, from time to time, we would utter that strange phrase we still hear from old people: I heard where you're coming from.
es: Or, using an expression still heard from the mouths of older people: I hear where you're coming from, as if the voice itself were a traveler arriving from some distant place.

en: Which it would be, which it is.
vi: And it will be like that, and today it truly is.
tr: As if the voice were a traveler coming from afar; actually, it was, and it is.
es: Which it could be, which it is.

en: How I used to despise such talk.
vi: Before, I despised such conversations so much.
tr: I used to hate these kinds of conversations so much.
es: I used to disdain this type of conversation.

en: Now I long for it.
vi: Now I long for them.
tr: Now I miss them.
es: Now I desire it ardently.

en: At least it was talk.
vi: At least it's a conversation.
tr: At least it was a conversation.
es: At least it is a conversation, a way to exchange something.

en: An exchange, of sorts.
vi: It's a form of exchange, after all.
tr: A kind of exchange.
es: At least it is a conversation, a way to exchange something.

en: Or we would gossip.
vi: Or we trade gossip.
tr: Or we would gossip.
es: Or we would dedicate ourselves to gossiping.

en: The Marthas know things, they talk among themselves, passing the unofficial news from house to house.
vi: The Marthas know everything, thanks to the stories they share with each other, the unofficial news transmitted from house to house.
tr: The Marthas always know something, they talk among themselves, spreading unofficial news from house to house.
es: The Marthas know things, they talk among themselves and pass unofficial news from house to house.

en: Like me, they listen at doors, no doubt, and see things even with their eyes averted.
vi: Just like me, they eavesdrop at doors, of course, and see everything even if their eyes are looking elsewhere.
tr: They eavesdrop like me, undoubtedly, and can see what's happening even when their eyes are looking elsewhere.
es: There is no doubt that they listen behind doors, like me, and see things despite those averted eyes.

en: I've heard them at it sometimes, caught whiffs of their private conversations.
vi: Sometimes I overhear, catching snippets of their private conversations.
tr: Sometimes I would overhear them, catching sentences from their private conversations.
es: I have sometimes heard them, I have caught snippets of their private conversations.

en: Stillborn, it was.
vi: Miscarriage, really.
tr: Stillborn.
es: It was stillborn.

en: Or, Stabbed her with a knitting needle, right in the belly.
vi: Or, Stabbed her with a knitting needle, right in the belly.
tr: Or, She stabbed him, right in the stomach.
es: Or: She stuck a knitting needle right into her belly.

en: Jealousy, it must have been, eating her up.
vi: Jealousy, what else, has consumed her.
tr: It must have been jealousy eating her up.
es: It must have been jealousy, which was devouring her.

en: Or, tantalizingly,
vi: Or, so provocative, Couldn't stand it, Used toilet cleaner, really.
tr: Or, The thing the girl used was toilet cleaner.
es: Or, in a tormenting tone: What she used was a cleaning product.

en: It was toilet cleaner she used.
vi: Or, so provocative, Couldn't stand it, Used toilet cleaner, really.
tr: Or, The thing the girl used was toilet cleaner.
es: Or, in a tormenting tone: What she used was a cleaning product.

en: Worked like a charm, though you'd think he'd of tasted it.
vi: Worked like a charm, though everyone thought he must have tasted it already.
tr: You'd think a person would taste it, but it worked just the same.
es: It worked like a charm, although anyone would say that he had tested it.

en: Must've been that drunk; but they found her out all right.
vi: Must have been really drunk; but they will track her down soon enough.
tr: So he was that drunk; they only figured out what the girl did later.
es: It must have been that drunkard; but they found her right away.

en: Or I would help Rita make the bread, sinking my hands into that soft resistant warmth which is so much like flesh.
vi: Or I will help Rita make bread, immersing my hands in the warm, soft, doughy substance that feels very much like flesh.
tr: Or, I would help Rita make bread, plunging my hands into that soft, resilient warmth that resembles meat.
es: Or I would help Rita make the bread, sinking my hands into that soft and resilient warmth that resembles Flesh so much.

en: I hunger to touch something, other than cloth or wood.
vi: I crave touch so intensely, anything that isn't fabric or wood.
tr: I am craving to touch something, something other than fabric or wood.
es: I'm dying to touch something, something that isn't fabric or wood.

en: I hunger to commit the act of touch.
vi: I long to commit the act of touching.
tr: I am craving the act of touching.
es: I'm dying to commit the act of touching.

en: But even if I were to ask, even if I were to violate decorum to that extent, Rita would not allow it.
vi: But even if I open my mouth to ask, even if I break the rules to that extent, Rita will not agree.
tr: However, even if I could ask, even if I could violate etiquette to this extent, Rita would not allow it.
es: But even if they asked me, even if I breached decorum to that extent, Rita would not allow it.

en: She would he too alr?d.
vi: Her fear is too great.
tr: She would be terrified.
es: She would be too worried.

en: T Marthas are not supposed to fraternize with us.
vi: The Marthas are not allowed to be friendly with us.
tr: It is unthinkable for the Marthas to fraternize with us.
es: The Marthas are not supposed to fraternize with us.

en: Fraternize means to behave like a brother.
vi: Huynh hảo, fraternize, means to behave like brothers with each other.
tr: To fraternize means to behave like a brother.
es: To fraternize means to behave like a brother.

en: Luke told me that.
vi: It was Luke who told me that.
tr: Luke told me this.
es: Luke told me that.

en: He said there was no corresponding word thathat meant to behave like a sister.
vi: He also said there is no corresponding term to describe behaving like sisters with each other.
tr: He said there was no suitable word that means to behave like a sister.
es: He said there was no equivalent for behaving like a sister.

en: Sororize, it would have to be, he said.
vi: Sororize, if it exists, would be it, he said.
tr: It should be sororize, he said.
es: According to him, it had to be sororize, from Latin.

en: From the Latin.
vi: Latin root.
tr: From Latin.
es: According to him, it had to be sororize, from Latin.

en: He liked knowing about such details.
vi: He likes to explore such meticulous details.
tr: Luke used to enjoy knowing these kinds of details.
es: He liked knowing those kinds of details, the origins of words and their less common uses.

en: The derivations of words, curious usages.
vi: The process of word derivation, specific usages.
tr: The origins of words, their strange usages.
es: He liked knowing those kinds of details, the origins of words and their less common uses.

en: I used to tease him about being pedantic,
vi: I often tease him for that pedantic habit.
tr: I used to tease him by calling him a know-it-all.
es: I used to tease him for his pedantry.

en: I take the tokens from Rita's outstretched hand.
vi: I took the tickets from Rita's outstretched hand.
tr: I'm taking the report cards from Rita's hand.
es: I take the vouchers that Rita hands me.

en: They have pictures on them, of the things they can be exchanged for tweleve eggs, a piece
vi: On the tickets were drawings indicating their value: a dozen eggs, a piece of cheese, something brown understood to be roast meat.
tr: There are pictures on them of things that can be traded: twelve eggs, a piece of cheese, something brown that is supposed to be meat.
es: They have drawings of the foods they can be exchanged for: a dozen eggs, a piece of cheese, a brown thing that is supposed to be a steak.

en: of cheese, a brown thing that's supposed to be a steak.
vi: On the tickets were drawings indicating their value: a dozen eggs, a piece of cheese, something brown understood to be roast meat.
tr: There are pictures on them of things that can be traded: twelve eggs, a piece of cheese, something brown that is supposed to be meat.
es: They have drawings of the foods they can be exchanged for: a dozen eggs, a piece of cheese, a brown thing that is supposed to be a steak.

en: I place them in the zippered pocket in my sleeve, where 1 keep my pass.
vi: I put them all into the zippered pocket on my sleeve, along with the pass.
tr: I place them in the zippered wallet where I keep my transit pass, inside the sleeve of my dress.
es: I put them in the zippered pocket of my sleeve, where I keep the pass.

en: "Tell them fresh, for the eggs," she any.
vi: “Make sure to get the fresh kind, those eggs,” she said.
tr: “Tell them to give fresh eggs,” says Rita.
es: —Tell them the eggs should be fresh —she warns me—.

en: "Not like the last time.
vi: “Not like last time.
tr: “Not like last time.
es: Not like last time.

en: And a chicken, tell them, not a hen.
vi: And remember, it should be young chicken meat, tell them that, not hen meat.
tr: And a chick, tell them that, not a chicken.
es: And make sure they give you a chicken, not a hen.

en: Tell them who It's for and then they won't mess around."
vi: Just tell them it's for someone and they won't dare to ignore it.”
tr: Tell them who it’s for, so they don’t mess around.”
es: Tell them who it's for and you'll see they won't mess it up.

en: "All right," I say.
vi: "I remember," I said.
tr: "Alright," I say.
es: —Agreed —I respond.

en: I don't smile.
vi: I did not smile.
tr: I don't smile.
es: I don't smile.

en: Why tempt her to friendship?
vi: Why tempt her with friendship?
tr: Why should I entice him into friendship?
es: Why tempt her with a friendly attitude?
CHAPTER 3

en: I go out by the back door, into the garden, which is large and tidy: a lawn in the middle, a willow, weeping catkins; around the edges, the flower borders, in which the daffodils are now fading and the tulips are opening their cups, spilling out color.
vi: I went out through the back door, into the garden, which was spacious and clean: a lawn in the center, a willow tree, and a sorrowful cluster of foxtail plants; around the edges of the garden were flower beds, with yellow daffodils wilting, tulips just beginning to bud, their colors spreading outward.
tr: I am exiting through the back door, into the wide and orderly garden: in the middle, a grassy area, a willow tree, the drooping flowers of the willow tree; on the edges, flower beds, within them, daffodils that are wilting and tulips that are blooming, spreading color all around.
es: I go out through the back door to the garden, large and well-kept: in the middle, there is grass, a willow tree, and candlesticks; at the edges, flower beds: daffodils that are beginning to wither and tulips that are opening in a torrent of color.

en: The tulips are red, a darker crimson towards the stem, as if they have been cut and are beginning to heal there.
vi: The red flowers, darker at the base of the petals, looked like cuts that were starting to heal.
tr: The tulips are red; closer to their stems, they are darker, as if they have been cut and are starting to heal from there.
es: The tulips are red, and a darker crimson color near the stem, as if they had been wounded and were beginning to heal.

en: This garden is the domain of the Commander's Wife.
vi: This garden is the domain of the Commander’s Wife.
tr: This garden is under the dominion of the Commander's Wife.
es: This garden is the realm of the Commander's Wife.

en: Looking out through my shatterproof window I've often seen her in it, her knees on a cushion, a light blue veil thrown over her wide gardening hat, a basket at her side with shears in it and pieces of string for lying the flowers into place.
vi: From my unbroken window, I often see her there, kneeling on a cushion, a bright blue veil draped over her wide-brimmed gardening hat, beside her a large basket containing pruning shears and strings to tie the flowers into place.
tr: While looking outside from my unbreakable window, I had often seen her in the garden, a cushion under her knees, a light blue veil thrown over her wide garden hat, and beside her, a basket containing scissors and pieces of string to tie the flowers in place.
es: Often, when I look out from my shatterproof glass window, I see her here, kneeling on a cushion, with a light blue veil over her large hat and beside her a basket with some scissors and pieces of thread to tie the flowers.

en: A Guardian detailed to the Commander does the heavy digging; the Commander's Wife directs, pointing with her stick.
vi: A Guardian assigned specifically to this Commander handles the digging, while the Commander’s Wife directs, holding a long cane to point things out.
tr: One of the Guardians assigned to the Commander does the heavy digging work; the Commander's Wife directs him, pointing with her cane.
es: The Guardian assigned. to the Commander is the one who performs the heavy task of digging the soil. The Commander's Wife directs the operation, pointing with her cane.

en: Many of the Wives have such gardens, it's something for them to order and maintain and care for.
vi: Many Wives have such garden plots, which they arrange, tend, and oversee.
tr: Most of the Wives have such gardens, something for them to arrange, maintain, and cherish.
es: Many Commanders' wives have gardens like this; that way they can give orders and keep themselves busy.

en: 1 once had a garden.
vi: I once had a garden.
tr: Once upon a time, I also had a garden.
es: Once I had a garden.

en: I can remember the smell of the turned earth, the plump shapes of bulbs held in the hands, fullness, the dry rustle of seeds through the fingers.
vi: I still remember the smell of freshly turned soil, the plump flower bulbs in my cupped hands, the heavy feeling, the seeds rustling as they poured through my fingers.
tr: I can remember the smell of the dug-up soil, the stout shapes of the flower bulbs held in hand, their fullness, the dry rustle made by the seeds flowing through fingers.
es: I remember the smell of the turned earth, the rounded shape of the opened bulbs, the dry crunch of the seeds between my fingers.

en: Time could pass more swiftly thai way.
vi: Time seemed to pass faster that way.
tr: Time could pass more quickly this way.
es: That way, time passed more quickly.

en: Sometimes the Commander's Wife has a chair brought out, and just sits in it, in her garden.
vi: Sometimes, the Commander's Lady would have a chair brought out, and she would just sit there, in her garden.
tr: Sometimes, the Commander's Wife would have a chair brought and just sit in her garden.
es: Sometimes the Commander's Wife takes a chair out to her garden and sits there.

en: From a distance it looks like peace.
vi: From a distance, it looked like peace.
tr: From a distance, this scene evokes tranquility.
es: From a certain distance, she radiates a halo of peace.

en: She isn't here now, and I start to wonder where she is: I don't like to come upon the Commander's Wife unexpectedly.
vi: Now she is not here, and I start to wonder where she might be: I don't fancy suddenly running into her.
tr: She's not here right now; I'm starting to wonder where she is: I don't like running into the Commander's Wife unexpectedly.
es: Now she is not here, and I start to wonder where she might be: I don't like running into her by surprise.

en: Perhaps she's sewing, in the sitting room, with her left foot on the footstool, because of her arthritis.
vi: She could be sewing, in the sitting room, with her left leg propped up on a stool, due to chronic rheumatism.
tr: Maybe she's knitting, in the sitting room, with her left foot on a stool because of her arthritis.
es: Perhaps she is sewing in the living room, with her arthritic left foot on the footstool.

en: Or knitting scarves, for the Angels at the front lines.
vi: Or she could be knitting scarves, for the Angels on the front lines.
tr: Or she's knitting a scarf, for the Angels on the front line.
es: Or knitting scarves for the Angels who are on the front lines.

en: I can hardly believe the Angels have a need for such
vi: I find it hard to believe that the Angels would need those scarves; besides, the scarves made by the Commander's Wife are too elaborate.
tr: I don't think the Angels really need such scarves; still, the Commander's Wife's work is very meticulous.
es: I find it hard to believe that the Angels need to wear those scarves; in any case, the Commander's Wife's scarves are very elaborate.

en: scarves; anyway, the ones made by the Commander's Wife are too elaborate.
vi: I find it hard to believe that the Angels would need those scarves; besides, the scarves made by the Commander's Wife are too elaborate.
tr: I don't think the Angels really need such scarves; still, the Commander's Wife's work is very meticulous.
es: I find it hard to believe that the Angels need to wear those scarves; in any case, the Commander's Wife's scarves are very elaborate.

en: She doesn't bother with the cross-and-star pattern used by many of the other Wives, it's not a challenge.
vi: She doesn't care for cross and star patterns like most other Ladies, as she finds them unworthy of her skill.
tr: She doesn't pay much attention to the cross-and-star pattern used by the other Wives, it doesn't challenge her.
es: She is not satisfied with the pattern of crosses and stars, like the other Wives, because it does not represent a challenge.

en: Fir trees march across the ends of her scarves, or eagles, or stiff humanoid figures, boy and girl, boy and girl.
vi: Along the two ends of the scarves she knits rows of fig trees, or eagles, or tiny stiff figures, boys and girls, girls and boys.
tr: At the ends of her scarves, pine trees appear, or eagles, or motionless human figures standing side by side, a boy and a girl, a boy and a girl.
es: At the ends of her scarves, fir trees, or eagles, or rigid humanoid figures parade: a boy, a girl, a boy, a girl.

en: They aren't scarves for grown men but for children.
vi: Not scarves for adults but for the little ones.
tr: These are not for adult men, but for children.
es: They are not scarves for adults but for children.

en: Sometimes I think these scarves aren't sent to the Angels at all, but unraveled and turned back into balls of yarn, to be knitted again in their turn.
vi: Sometimes I think that scarf isn't meant to be sent to the Angel, but will be unraveled and returned to the skeins of yarn, waiting to be re-knit from the beginning.
tr: Sometimes, I think that these scarves are never sent to the Angels, but are unraveled and sent back as balls of yarn, to be knitted again when the time comes.
es: Sometimes I think that they are not sent to the Angels, but rather they are unraveled and turned back into balls of yarn to be woven again.

en: Maybe it's just something to keep the Wives busy, to give them a sense of purpose.
vi: Maybe just to give the Ladies something to keep busy with, a purpose for the days and months.
tr: Maybe it's to keep the Wives busy, to give them a sense of purpose.
es: Maybe it's only to keep them busy, to give meaning to their lives; but I envy the weaving of the Commander's Wife.

en: But I envy the Commander's Wife her knitting.
vi: But I am envious of the knitting of the Commander's Wife.
tr: Still, I envy the Commander's Wife's knitting.
es: Maybe it's only to keep them busy, to give meaning to their lives; but I envy the weaving of the Commander's Wife.

en: It's good to have small goals that can be easily attained.
vi: Having small, easily achievable goals, how wonderful that would be.
tr: It's good to have small, easily attainable goals.
es: It's good to have small, easily attainable goals.

en: What does she envy me?
vi: What is she jealous of me for?
tr: I wonder what of mine he/she is jealous of?
es: And what does she envy about me?

en: She doesn't speak to me, unless she can't avoid it.
vi: She doesn't talk to me unless absolutely necessary.
tr: He doesn't talk to me unless it's unavoidable.
es: She doesn't speak to me unless she can't avoid it.

en: I am a reproach to her; and a necessity.
vi: I am a living reproach and an essential need for her.
tr: To him, I am a shame; and a necessity.
es: To her, I am a disgrace. And a necessity.

en: We stood face to face for the first time five weeks ago, when I arrived at this posting.
vi: The lady and I faced each other for the first time five weeks ago, when I arrived to take up my post.
tr: We had come face to face for the first time five weeks ago when I arrived at this post.
es: The first time we were face to face was five weeks ago, when I arrived at this detachment.

en: The Guardian from the previous pos?g brought me to the front door.
vi: The guard from the old post brought me to the front door.
tr: The Guardian of the previous post had brought me to the front door.
es: The Guardian of the previous detachment accompanied me to the main door.

en: On first days we are permitted front doors, but after that we're supposed to use the back.
vi: In the early days, we were allowed to use the front door, but later had to use the side door.
tr: In the early days, we are allowed to use the front doors. But after that, we are expected to use the back door.
es: The first few days we are allowed to use the main door, but afterwards we have to use the back ones.

en: Things haven't settled down, it's too soon, everyone is unsure about our exact status.
vi: Things were still not settled, it was still too early, people were still hesitant about determining our status.
tr: Things haven't settled down completely, it's still very early, no one is sure exactly what our status is.
es: Things haven't stabilized, it's still too early and no one is sure of their exact situation.

en: After a while it will be either all from doors or all back.
vi: In a little while, it will be either all back doors, or all front doors.
tr: After a while, we will either always use the front door or always use the back door.
es: In a while, there will be nothing but main doors and back doors.

en: Aunt Lydia said she was lobbying for the front.
vi: Aunt Lydia mentioned that she is lobbying behind the scenes for the front door.
tr: Aunt Lydia had said she was lobbying for the front door.
es: Aunt Lydia told me that she pressured them to let me use the front door.

en: Your in a position of honor, she said.
vi: You ladies are in a position of honor, she said.
tr: She used to say that yours is an honorable position.
es: Yours is a place of honor, he said.

en: The Guardianrang the doorbell for me, but before there was time for someone to hear and walk quickly to answer, the door opened inward.
vi: The Guardian rang the doorbell for me, but before anyone could hear it and come to the door, it had already opened inward.
tr: The guard rang the bell for me, but before enough time had passed for someone to hear the bell and come quickly, the door suddenly opened inward.
es: The Guardian rang the bell for me, and the door opened immediately, in less time than it would take for someone to go and answer.

en: She must have been waiting behind it, I was expecting a Martha, but it was her instead, in her long powder-blue robe, unmistakable.
vi: She must have been waiting, I thought a Martha would come out, but it was her, in the unmistakable long blue dress.
tr: He must have been waiting behind the door. I was expecting a Martha, but it was him who appeared: unmistakably, in his dusty blue outfit.
es: Surely she was on the other side, waiting. I thought a Martha was going to appear, but instead, she came out, dressed in her unmistakable pale blue outfit.

en: So, you're the new one, she said.
vi: So you are the new one, she said.
tr: "So, you're the new arrival," he said.
es: So, you're the new one, she said to me.

en: She didn't step aside to let me in, she just stood there in the doorway, blocking the entrance.
vi: She didn't step aside to let me in but stood there blocking the door.
tr: He didn't step aside to let me in, just stood there in the doorway, blocking the entrance.
es: She didn't even move aside to let me in; she stayed in the doorway, blocking the entrance.

en: She wanted me to feel that I could not come into the house unless she said so.
vi: She wanted me to understand clearly that I was not allowed to enter the house unless she permitted it.
tr: He wanted to make me feel that I couldn't enter the house without his permission.
es: She wanted me to realize that I couldn't enter the house unless she allowed it.

en: There is push and shove, these days, over suchtoeholds.
vi: There are such petty power plays these days over trivial matters like this.
tr: These kinds of encounters have been happening with a lot of pushing and shoving lately.
es: These days, you always have the feeling that you're walking on a tightrope.

en: Yes, I said.
vi: Yes, I replied.
tr: Yes, I said.
es: Yes, I replied.

en: Leave it on the porch.
vi: Just leave it on the porch.
tr: Leave it on the veranda.
es: Leave it on the porch, she told the Guardian, who was carrying my suitcase.

en: She said this to the Guardian, who was carrying my bag.
vi: She told the guard, who was carrying my bag.
tr: She had said this to the Guard who was carrying my bag.
es: Leave it on the porch, she told the Guardian, who was carrying my suitcase.

en: The bag was red vinyl and not large.
vi: A red vinyl bag, not big.
tr: The bag was made of red vinyl and wasn't too big.
es: It was made of red vinyl and not very large.

en: There was another bag, with the winter cloak and heavier dresses, but that would be coming later.
vi: There was another bag, containing winter clothes and thick items, but it would come later.
tr: There was another bag containing my winter cloak and thicker clothes, but that would come later.
es: I had another suitcase with my winter coat and thicker dresses, but they would bring it later.

en: The Guardian set down the bag and saluted her.
vi: The Guard put the bag down and bowed to her.
tr: The guard dropped the bag and saluted him.
es: The Guardian dropped the suitcase and greeted the Commander's Wife.

en: Then I could hear his footsteps behind me, going back down the walk, and the click of the front gate, and I felt as if a protective arm were being withdrawn.
