vi: Then I heard footsteps echoing behind me, back towards the entrance, the front gate clanking shut, and felt as if the covering force had just been ordered to retreat.
tr: Then, behind me, I could hear the footsteps of the returning guard, the front door closing with a click, and I felt as if a protective arm had been withdrawn.
es: Then I perceived his steps retracing the path, heard the click of the gate, and had the sensation of being stripped of a protective hand.

en: The threshold of a new house is a lonely place.
vi: The threshold of a new house is always a lonely place.
tr: The threshold of a new house is filled with loneliness.
es: The threshold of a new house is a desolate place.

en: She waited until the car started up and pulled away.
vi: She waited until the car roared away.
tr: He waited for the car to start and drive away.
es: She waited for the car to start and drive away.

en: I wasn't looking at her face, but at the part of her I could see with my head lowered: her blue waist, thickened, her left hand on the ivory head of her cane, the large diamonds on the ring finger, which must once have beenfine and was still finely kept, the fingernail at the end of the knuckly finger filed to a gentle curving point.
vi: I did not look at her face, but at the part of her body still visible when her head was bowed: the blue waist, tightly bound; the left hand placed on the ivory cane; the large diamonds on the ring finger, surely once very beautiful and still well-preserved; on the finger with protruding joints, the nail filed into a gently curved shape.
tr: I was looking at the parts of her I could see with my head bowed: her thickened waist under the blue dress, her left hand on the ivory handle of her cane, the large diamonds on her ring finger, which must have been beautiful once and still well-maintained, the slightly curved, filed nail at the tip of her bony finger.
es: I didn't look at her face; I only looked at what I could perceive with my head down: her thick blue waist and her left hand on the ivory handle of her cane, the huge diamonds on the ring, which must have once been fine and still preserved well, the nail of a knobby finger filed into a smooth curve.

en: It was like an ironic smile, on that finger; like something mocking her.
vi: It looked like a mocking smile, lying on the finger; as if something was mocking her.
tr: The curve on her finger was like an ironic smile, as if mocking her.
es: It was as if that finger bore an ironic smile, as if it mocked her.

en: You might as well come in, she said.
vi: You may come in, she said.
tr: You can come in now, he said.
es: "You'd better come in," he said.

en: She turned her back on me and limped down the hall.
vi: She turned her back and limped into the hall.
tr: He turned his back to me and limped down the hall.
es: He turned, giving me his back, and limped into the hallway.

en: Shut the door behind you.
vi: Remember to close the door when you come in.
tr: Close the door behind you.
es: "And close the door."

en: I lifted my red bag inside, as she'd no doubt intended, then closed the door.
vi: I put the red bag inside, clearly it was her intention, then closed the door.
tr: I carried the red bag inside, there was no doubt that was the intention, then I closed the door.
es: I carried the red suitcase inside, as she surely wanted, and closed the door.

en: I didn't say anything to her.
vi: I didn't say anything to her.
tr: I didn't say anything to her.
es: I didn't say anything to her.

en: Aunt Lydia said it was best not to speak unless they asked you a direct question.
vi: Aunt Lydia said it's best not to open your mouth unless you're asked directly.
tr: It's best not to speak unless they ask you something directly, Aunt Lydia used to say.
es: Aunt Lydia said it was better not to speak unless you were asked a direct question.

en: Try to think of it from their point of view, she said, her hands clasped and wrung together, her nervous pleading smile.
vi: Try to put yourself in their position, she said, wringing her hands together, a tense pleading smile.
tr: Try to think from their perspective, she would say, with her hands clasped tightly together, her nervous, defensive smile.
es: Try to put yourself in her place, she said, squeezing my hands and smiling with a nervous and pleading expression.

en: It isn't easy for them.
vi: It's not easy for them.
tr: It's not easy for them either.
es: It's not easy for them.

en: In here, said the Commander's Wife.
vi: Here, the Lady Commander spoke.
tr: "Come in," said the Commander's Wife.
es: Here, said the Commander's Wife.

en: When I went into the sitting room she was already in her chair, her left foot on the footstool, with its petit point cushion, roses in a basket.
vi: When I entered the lounge, she was already seated, her left leg resting on a stool, on a small-stitched embroidered cushion with roses in a basket.
tr: When I entered the living room, she was already seated in her chair, with her left foot extended onto a cushioned stool embroidered with a rose basket.
es: When I entered the living room, she was already in her chair, her left foot on the footstool with its petit-point cushion embroidered with a basket of roses.

en: Her knitting was on the floor beside the chair, the needles stuck through it.
vi: The knitting items were on the floor next to the chair, with the knitting needles pointing upwards.
tr: Her knitting was on the floor, beside the chair. With the needles stuck into it.
es: She had the knitting on the floor, next to the chair, and the needles stuck into it.

en: I stood in front of her, hands folded.
vi: I stood before her, arms crossed.
tr: I stood with my hands clasped in front of me.
es: I stood in front of her, with my hands crossed.

en: So, she said.
vi: So there, she said.
tr: So, that's how it is, she said.
es: All right, she said.

en: She had a cigarette, and she put it between her lips and gripped it there while she lit it.
vi: She was holding a cigarette and placed it on her lips, clamping down as she lit it.
tr: She placed a cigarette between her lips and clenched it tightly as she lit it.
es: She took a cigarette and placed it between her lips to light it.

en: Her lips were thin, held that way, with the small vertical lines around them you used to see in advertisements for lip cosmetics.
vi: Her lips were pressed so thin, the outline of her lips forming the fine vertical lines often seen in lipstick advertisements.
tr: Her lips were thin, and with the small vertical lines around them, they resembled the lips seen in old lipstick advertisements.
es: While holding it, her lips looked thin, framed by those vertical lines you see on the lips in cosmetic ads.

en: The lighter was ivory-colored.
vi: An ivory-colored lighter.
tr: The lighter was ivory-colored.
es: The lighter was ivory-colored.

en: The cigarettes must have come from the black
vi: The cigarette was probably bought on the black market, I thought, and began to hope.
tr: The cigarettes must be from the black market, I thought, and this gave me hope.
es: The cigarettes must have been from the black market, I thought, which gave me hope.

en: market, I thought, and this gave me hope.
vi: The cigarette was probably bought on the black market, I thought, and began to hope.
tr: The cigarettes must be from the black market, I thought, and this gave me hope.
es: The cigarettes must have been from the black market, I thought, which gave me hope.

en: Even now that there is no real money anymore, there's still a black market.
vi: Even if there was no more cash, at least there was still the black market.
tr: Even now, in a time when real money is no longer available, there is still a black market.
es: Even now that there's no real money, there is a black market.

en: There's always a black market, there's always something that can be exchanged.
vi: There is always a black market, always something to trade.
tr: There is always a black market, always something that can be traded.
es: There is always a black market, there is always something that can be traded.

en: She then was a woman who might bend the rules.
vi: So she was someone capable of bending the rules.
tr: So, she was a woman who could bend the rules.
es: She was a woman who could bend the rules.

en: But what did I have, to trade?
vi: But what do I have to trade?
tr: But what did I have that I could trade?
es: But what did I have to trade?

en: I looked at the cigarette with longing.
vi: I look at the cigarette with unease.
tr: I was looking at the cigarette with longing.
es: I looked at the cigarette with longing.

en: For me, like liquor and coffee, they are forbidden.
vi: For me, like alcohol and coffee, this is forbidden.
tr: Like liqueur and coffee, cigarettes are also forbidden to me.
es: For me, like alcoholic drinks and coffee, cigarettes are forbidden.

en: So old what's-his-face didn't work out, she said.
vi: Old to the point that it doesn't work anymore, she said.
tr: So, the old "nesi-var" game didn't work, he said.
es: So that old fellow didn't work out, he said.

en: No, ma'am, I said.
vi: Yes, madam, I said.
tr: No, Sir, I said.
es: No, ma'am, I replied.

en: She gave what might have been a laugh, then coughed.
vi: She let out a sound that seemed like a laugh, then coughed.
tr: He made a sound that could be called a laugh, then coughed.
es: He let out something like a laugh and then coughed.

en: Tough luck on him, she said.
vi: Unfortunate for you, she said.
tr: Poor man, he said.
es: Bad luck for you, he said.

en: This is your second, isn't it?
vi: It's the second time for you, isn't it?
tr: This is your second job, isn't it?
es: It's the second one, isn't it?

en: Third, ma'am, I said.
vi: Tuesday, madam, I said.
tr: Third, Sir, I said.
es: The third one, ma'am, I said.

en: Not so good for you either, she said.
vi: Unlucky for you too, she said.
tr: "It's not very good for you either," he said.
es: And yours, he added.

en: There was another coughing laugh.
vi: Another burst of laughter accompanied by coughing.
tr: He laughed again, mixed with a cough.
es: Another laugh and he coughed again.

en: You can sit down.
vi: Have a seat.
tr: "You can sit down."
es: You can sit down.

en: I don't make a practice of it, but just this time.
vi: I don't usually do this, but this time is an exception.
tr: "I don't want this to become a habit, just this once."
es: Don't make it a habit, it's just this once.

en: I did sit, on the edge of one of the stiff-backed chairs.
vi: I sat down for real, perched on the edge of the straight-backed chair.
tr: I perched on the edge of one of the straight-backed chairs.
es: I sat on the edge of one of the straight-backed chairs.

en: I didn't want to stare around the room, I didn't want to appear inattentive to her; so the marble mantelpiece to my right and the mirror over it and the bunches of flowers were just shadows, then, at the edges of my eyes.
vi: I didn't want to stare around the room, didn't want to appear inattentive in front of her; the marble fireplace immediately to the right along with the mirror above and the bunches of flowers thus only flickered in the corner of my eye.
tr: I didn't want to stare around the room, nor did I want to appear indifferent to him; at that moment, the marble fireplace mantle to my right, the mirror above it, and the bouquets of flowers were just shadows, seen out of the corner of my eye.
es: I didn't want to keep my gaze fixed or give the impression that I was distracted; so the marble shelf to my right, the mirror above it, and the bouquets of flowers were just shadows I caught out of the corner of my eye.

en: Later I would have more than enough time to take them in.
vi: Later, I would have plenty of time to look around.
tr: Later, I would have plenty of time to examine them.
es: Later on, I would have plenty of time to look at them.

en: Now her face was on a level with mine.
vi: Now her face was at eye level with mine.
tr: Now her face was at the same level as mine.
es: Now her face was at the same height as mine.

en: I thought I recognized her; or at least there was something familiar about her.
vi: I felt like I recognized her, or at least there was something very familiar about her.
tr: It seemed like I knew her from somewhere; or at least there was something familiar about her.
es: She seemed familiar to me, or at least I saw something familiar in her.

en: A little of her hair was showing, from under her veil.
vi: I could see part of her hair, peeking out from under the headscarf.
tr: A strand of hair was visible from under her veil.
es: A bit of her hair could be seen beneath the veil.

en: It was still blond.
vi: It was still blonde.
tr: She was still blonde.
es: It was still blonde.

en: I thought then that maybe she bleached it, that hair dye was something else she could get through the black market, but I know now that it really is blond.
vi: At that moment, I thought she might have dyed it blonde, thinking hair dye was another item obtained from the black market, but now I know it's naturally blonde.
tr: At that time, I thought maybe she dyed her hair, and that the hair dye was another thing she obtained from the black market, but now I know she was truly blonde.
es: Then I thought that maybe she dyed it, that hair dye could be another one of the things she got on the black market, but now I know it's truly blonde.

en: Her eyebrows were plucked into thin arched lines, which gave her a permanent look of surprise, or outrage, or inquisitiveness, such as you might see on a startled child, but below them her eyelids were tired-looking.
vi: Her eyebrows were shaped into two thin arches, giving her face a constant look of surprise, indignation, or inquiry, like a startled child, but the lashes below looked weary.
tr: Her eyebrows were shaped into thin, curved lines, giving her a constant look of surprise, anger, or curiosity that you might see in a bewildered child; but the eyelids beneath her eyebrows looked tired.
es: She had her eyebrows plucked into thin arched lines, which gave her a look of permanent surprise, or grievance, or inquisitiveness, like that of a frightened child, but her eyelids had a tired expression.

en: Not so her eyes, which were the flat hostile blue of a midsummer sky in bright sunlight, a blue that shuts you out.
vi: Her eyes, however, were not like that, a hostile, unyielding blue like the summer sky under harsh sunlight, a color that blocked any deeper penetration.
tr: However, not her eyes, they were the hostile blue of a summer sky under a scorching sun, a blue that excluded you.
es: Not so her eyes, a hostile blue like a midsummer sky in which the sun shines, an implacable blue.

en: Her nose must once have been what was called cute but now was too
vi: Her nose must have once been delicate, but now it seemed too small for her face.
tr: Her nose must have been considered cute once, but now it was too small for her face.
es: At one time, her nose must have been pretty, but now it was too small in relation to her face, which wasn't fat but was large.

en: small for her face.
vi: Her nose must have once been delicate, but now it seemed too small for her face.
tr: Her nose must have been considered cute once, but now it was too small for her face.
es: At one time, her nose must have been pretty, but now it was too small in relation to her face, which wasn't fat but was large.

en: Her face was not fat but it was large.
vi: Her face wasn't fat, but it was broad.
tr: Her face was not full, but it was wide.
es: At one time, her nose must have been pretty, but now it was too small in relation to her face, which wasn't fat but was large.

en: Two lines led downward from the corners of her mouth; between them was her chin, clenched like a fist.
vi: Two lines drooped from the corners of her mouth, meeting at a chin clenched like a fist.
tr: Two lines ran down from the corners of her mouth; between them was her chin, like a clenched fist.
es: From the corners of her lips, two descending lines emerged, and between them, her chin protruded, clenched as if it were a fist.

en: I want to see as little of you as possible, she said.
vi: I want to see you as little as possible, she said.
tr: I want to see you as little as possible, he said.
es: I want to see you as little as possible, he said.

en: 1 expect you feel the same way about me.
vi: I hope you feel the same way about me.
tr: I expect you to think the same way.
es: I hope you feel the same way about me.

en: I didn't answer, as a yes would have been insulting, a no contradictory.
vi: I did not answer, because saying yes would be an insult, while saying no would be against their wishes.
tr: I didn't respond, because saying yes would be to belittle, and saying no would be to oppose.
es: I didn't respond: a yes could have been insulting, and a no, defiant.

en: I know you aren't stupid, she went on.
vi: I know you are not stupid, she continued.
tr: I know you're not stupid, he continued.
es: I know you're not stupid, he continued.

en: She inhaled, blew out the smoke.
vi: She inhaled and exhaled smoke.
tr: He took a drag from his cigarette and blew out the smoke.
es: He took a drag and exhaled a puff of smoke.

en: I've read your file.
vi: I have read the file.
tr: I've read your file.
es: I have read your file.

en: As far as I'm concerned, this is like a business transaction.
vi: To me, this is entirely a transaction.
tr: In my opinion, this looks like a business deal.
es: As far as I am concerned, this is like a business transaction.

en: But if I get trouble, I'll give trouble back.
vi: But if there is trouble, I will return everything.
tr: But if you cause me trouble, I'll cause you trouble too.
es: But if you cause me trouble, the problem will be yours.

en: You understand?
vi: Do you understand?
tr: Do you understand?
es: Understood?

en: Yes, ma'am, I said.
vi: Yes, madam, I said.
tr: Yes, Sir, I said.
es: Yes, ma'am, I said.

en: Don't call me ma'am, she said irritably.
vi: "Don't call me madam," she snapped.
tr: Don't call me Sir, he said angrily.
es: And don't call me ma'am, she warned me irritably.

en: You're not a Martha.
vi: "You are not Martha."
tr: You are not a Martha.
es: You're not a Martha.

en: I didn't ask what I was supposed to cull her, because I could see that she hoped I would never have the- occasion to call her anvthing at all.
vi: I didn't ask what to call her, because it was clear that she hoped I wouldn't have the chance to address her again.
tr: I didn't ask how I should address her, because I could understand that she hoped such an event would never occur.
es: I didn't ask her how I was supposed to call her, because I realized that she trusted I wouldn't have the occasion to call her in any way.

en: I was disappointed.
vi: I was troubled.
tr: I was disappointed.
es: I felt disappointed.

en: I wanted, then, to turn her into an older sister, a motherly figure, someone who would understand and protect me.
vi: At that time, I wanted her to become a sister, a mother figure, someone who would understand and protect me.
tr: At that moment, I wanted to turn her into a sister, a mother figure, someone who would understand and protect me.
es: I had wished that she would become my older sister, a maternal figure, someone who would understand and protect me.

en: The Wife in my posting before this had spent most of her time in her bedroom; the Marthas said she drank.
vi: The lady at the previous post almost always stayed in her room; the Marthas said she was an alcoholic.
tr: The Wife at my previous posting had spent most of her time in the bedroom; the Marthas said she was drinking.
es: The Wife of the detachment from which I came spent most of her time in her room; the Marthas said she drank.

en: I wanted this one to bedifferent.
vi: I wanted this time to be different.
tr: I wanted this one to be different.
es: I wanted this one to be different.

en: I wanted to think I would have liked her, in another time and place, another life.
vi: I wanted to imagine that I could love her, assuming it was in another time and space, another life.
tr: I wanted to think that I could have loved her in another time and place, in another life.
es: I wanted to believe that she had liked me, in another time and place, in another life.

en: But I could see already that I wouldn't have liked her, nor she me.
vi: But I had foreseen that I wouldn't love her, just as she wouldn't love me.
tr: But I could already see that I couldn't love her, and she couldn't love me.
es: But I soon realized that she didn't like me, nor did I like her.

en: She put her cigarette out, half smoked, in a little scrolled ashtray on the lamp table beside her.
vi: She stubbed out the cigarette, which was only half-smoked, in an intricately carved ashtray on the table beside the lamp.
tr: He extinguished his half-smoked cigarette in the small round ashtray on the side table next to him.
es: He put out the cigarette, without finishing it, in a small ashtray with scrolls on a little table that was beside him.

en: She did this decisively, one jab and one grind, not the series of genteel taps favored by many of the Wives.
vi: The gesture was very decisive, pressing down firmly, not the dainty tapping like most ladies.
tr: He did this decisively, pressing it down in one go, not with the polite and gentle taps that most Spouses preferred.
es: He did it with a resolute attitude, giving it a sharp tap and then crushing it, instead of putting it out with a series of delicate taps, as almost all the other Wives were accustomed to doing.

en: As for my husband, she said, he's just that.
vi: As for my husband, she said, he is just that.
tr: When it comes to my husband, she said, he is what he is.
es: As for my husband, she said, that's exactly what he is: my husband.

en: My husband.
vi: My husband.
tr: He is my husband, after all.
es: As for my husband, she said, that's exactly what he is: my husband.

en: I want that to be perfectly clear.
vi: I want this to be absolutely clear.
tr: I want this to be fully understood.
es: I want this to be absolutely clear.

en: Till death do us part.
vi: Only death separates us.
tr: Until death do us part.
es: Until death do us part.

en: It's final.
vi: Period.
tr: This is what's certain.
es: And that's it.

en: Yes, ma'am, I said again, forgetting.
vi: Yes, madam, I repeat, forget about what happened earlier.
tr: Yes, Sir, I said again, forgetting.
es: Yes, ma'am, I said again, forgetting her previous warning.

en: They used to have dolls, for little girls, that would talk if you pulled a string at the back; I thought I was sounding like that, voice of a monotone, voice of a doll.
vi: In the past, there was something called a doll, for little girls, that would speak when you pulled the string on its back; I think my voice is like that, a mechanical voice, a doll's voice.
tr: In the past, there were dolls for little girls that would speak when you pulled the string on their back; I thought my voice came out like that, monotonous, like a doll's voice.
es: In the past, little girls had dolls that talked when a string on their back was pulled; I had the impression that she spoke like one of them, with a monotonous voice, a doll's voice.

en: She probably longed to slap my face.
vi: You must really want to slap me.
tr: Surely, he must have wanted to slap me.
es: Surely she fervently wished to slap me.

en: They can hit us, there's Scriptural precedent.
vi: They can hit us, there is precedent written in the holy books.
tr: They can hit us, there are examples in the Bible that respond to this.
es: They can punish us, there is a biblical precedent.

en: But not with any implement.
vi: But they can't use anything.
tr: Not with any tool.
es: But they cannot use any instruments; only their hands.

en: Only with their hands.
vi: Only their hands.
tr: They can only use their hands.
es: But they cannot use any instruments; only their hands.

en: It's one of the things we fought for, said the Commander's Wife, and suddenly she wasn't looking at me, she was looking down at her knuckled, diamond-studded hands, and I knew where I'd seen her before.
vi: That is one of the achievements of our struggle, the Lady Commander said, and suddenly she no longer looked at me, but looked down at her knotted, diamond-encrusted hand, and I knew where I had seen her before.
tr: This is one of the things we fight for, said the Commander's Wife, suddenly stopping looking at me and starting to look at her bony, diamond-adorned hands, I realized where I had seen her before.
es: This is one of the things we fight for, said the Commander's Wife, and I noticed that she was not looking at me but at her knobby, diamond-laden hands; then I understood where I had seen her before.

en: The first time was on television, when I was eight or nine.
vi: The first time was on TV, when I was about eight or nine years old.
tr: I first saw her on television when I was eight or nine years old.
es: The first time was on television, when I was eight or nine years old.

en: It was when my mother was sleeping in, on Sunday mornings, and I would get up early and go to the television set in my mother's study and flip through the channels, looking for cartoons.
vi: That was the time when my mother usually slept in, every Sunday morning, while I would wake up early and run to the TV in her study, switching from channel to channel looking for cartoons.
tr: On Sunday mornings, while my mother slept, I would get up early, go to the television in the study, and scan the channels looking for cartoons.
es: On Sunday mornings, my mother would stay in bed sleeping, and I would get up early and sit in front of the television set in her study, clumsily switching from one channel to another, looking for cartoons.

en: Sometimes when I couldn't find any I would watch the Growing Souls Gospel Hour, where they would tell Bible stories for children and sing hymns.
vi: Sometimes there were none, so I watched the Gospel program "Growing Souls," which had Bible stories for children and hymns.
tr: Sometimes, when I couldn't find any cartoons, I would watch the Bible Hour for Growing Souls, where they told Bible stories for children and sang hymns.
es: Sometimes, if I couldn't find them, I would watch The Hour of the Gospel for Innocent Souls, where they told biblical stories for children and sang hymns.

en: One of the women was called Serena Joy.
vi: Among the women on that show, there was one named Serena Joy.
tr: One of the women was named Serena Joy.
es: One of the women was named Serena Joy.

en: She was the lead so-prano.
vi: She led the soprano section.
tr: She was the lead soprano.
es: She was the soprano and main character, a petite woman with ash-blonde hair, a turned-up nose, and blue eyes that always looked up at the sky during the hymns.

en: She was ash blond, petite, with a snub nose and huge blue eyes which she'd turn upwards during hymns.
vi: Ash blonde hair, petite, upturned nose, big blue eyes that looked up to the sky whenever she sang.
tr: She was blonde and delicate, with a small, upturned nose and large blue eyes that she lifted upwards while singing hymns.
es: She was the soprano and main character, a petite woman with ash-blonde hair, a turned-up nose, and blue eyes that always looked up at the sky during the hymns.

en: She could smile and cry at the same time, one tear or two sliding gracefully down her cheek, as if on cue, as her voice lifted through its highest notes, tremulous, effortless.
vi: She could cry and laugh at the same time, with one or two delicate tears rolling down her cheeks, seemingly on cue, while her voice soared to the highest notes, trembling, as if effortlessly.
tr: She could both smile and cry at the same time, and as her voice climbed effortlessly to the highest notes, a few tears would gracefully trickle down her cheek, as if queued up.
es: She was capable of laughing and crying at the same time, gracefully letting one or two tears slide down her cheeks, as if it were something rehearsed, while her voice rose with the highest notes, trembling, without any effort.

en: It was after that she went on to other things.
vi: It was only later that she switched to pursuing something else.
tr: Her involvement in other matters came after this.
es: It was later that she dedicated herself to other things.

en: The woman sitting in front of me was Serena Joy.
vi: The person sitting in front of me is Serena Joy.
tr: The woman sitting in front of me was Serena Joy.
es: The woman who was sitting in front of me was Serena Joy.

en: Or had been, once.
vi: At least, she used to be.
tr: Or at least she used to be.
es: Or she had been once.

en: So it was worse than I thought.
vi: So things are worse than I thought.
tr: This was worse than I thought, it seemed.
es: This was worse than I thought.
CHAPTER 4

en: I walk along the gravel path that divides the back lawn, neatly, like a hair parting.
vi: I walked along the gravel path that split the backyard lawn neatly, like a part in hair.
tr: I'm walking on the gravel path that divides the backyard lawn as straight as a parting line in hair.
es: I walk along the gravel path that cleanly divides the lawn as if it were a part in the hair.

en: It has rained during the night; the grass to either side is damp, the air humid.
vi: It rained last night; the grass on both sides was soggy, and the air was damp.
tr: It rained all night: the grass on both sides of the path is wet, the air is humid.
es: It rained last night: the grass is wet and the air is humid.

en: Here and there are worms, evidence of the fertility of the soil, caught by the sun, half dead; flexible and pink, like lips.
vi: Here and there, earthworms had surfaced, evidence of very fertile soil, caught by the sun, half-dead; limp and pinkish, like lips.
tr: Here and there are worms, evidence of the soil's fertility, half-dead worms hunted by the sun; flexible and pink, like lips.
es: Everywhere there are worms —evidence of the soil's fertility— that have been caught by the sun, half-dead, flexible and pink, like lips.

en: I open the white picket gate and continue, past the front lawn and towards the front gate.
vi: I pushed the white picket gate and continued, across the front lawn straight to the door.
tr: After opening the white wooden gate and crossing the lawn, I continue towards the front door.
es: I open the white picket gate, walk past the front lawn, and head towards the main entrance.

en: In the driveway, one of the Guardians assigned to our household is washing the car.
vi: On the driveway, one of the Guardians assigned to the household was washing a car.
tr: In the driveway, a Guardian assigned to our house is washing the car.
es: One of the Guardians assigned to our house is washing the car in the driveway.

en: That must mean the Commander is in the house, in his own quarters, past the dining room and beyond, where he seems to stay most of the time.
vi: That means the Commander is home, in his office, behind the dining room, where he seems to sit all day.
tr: This must mean that the Commander is at home, in his own quarters where he seems to spend most of his time, beyond the dining room.
es: That means the Commander is in the house, in his rooms on the other side of the dining room, where he seems to spend most of his time.

en: The car is a very expensive one, a Whirlwind; better than the Chariot,
vi: The car is extremely expensive, a whirlwind; much better than a horse-drawn carriage, far surpassing the sturdy, squat buffalo.
tr: This is a very expensive car, a Whirlwind; better than the Chariot, and much better than the stubby, practical Behemoth.
es: It's a very expensive car, a Whirlwind; better than a Chariot, much better than the heavy and practical Behemoth.

en: much better than the chunky, practical Behemoth.
vi: The car is extremely expensive, a whirlwind; much better than a horse-drawn carriage, far surpassing the sturdy, squat buffalo.
tr: This is a very expensive car, a Whirlwind; better than the Chariot, and much better than the stubby, practical Behemoth.
es: It's a very expensive car, a Whirlwind; better than a Chariot, much better than the heavy and practical Behemoth.

en: It's black, of course, the color of prestige or a hearse, and long and sleek.
vi: The car is black, of course, a color that signifies privilege or mourning, long and shiny.
tr: Of course, its color is black too, the color of power or a hearse, and it is also long and shiny.
es: It's black, of course the color of prestige —and of hearses— and long and elegant.

en: The driver is going over it with a chamois, lovingly.
vi: The driver gently glides a piece of leather across the entire body of the car, lovingly.
tr: The driver, with a piece of chamois in his hand, is lovingly wiping the car.
es: The driver lovingly rubs it with a chamois.

en: This ;it least hasn't changed, the way men caress good cars.
vi: At least that hasn't changed, the way men meticulously care for fine cars.
tr: At least this hasn't changed, the way men love good cars.
es: At least one thing hasn't changed: the way men take care of good cars.

en: He's wearing the uniform of the Guardians, but his cap is tilted at a jaunty angle and his sleeves are rolled to the dhow, showing his forearms, tanned but with a stipple of dark hairs, He has a cigarette stuck in the corner of his mouth, which shows that he too has something he can trade on the black market.
vi: The talented man wore the same Guard uniform, but his hat was tilted mischievously to one side and his sleeves were rolled up to the elbows, revealing his tanned arm with a light dusting of black hair. A cigarette was tucked in the corner of his mouth, indicating that he too had some dealings in the black market.
tr: He is wearing a guard's uniform, but he has pushed his hat back in a flamboyant manner and rolled up his shirt to his elbows, exposing his sunburned, dark-haired arms. There is a cigarette in the corner of his mouth, indicating that he also has something he can trade on the black market.
es: He is wearing the Guardians' uniform, but he has the cap tilted jauntily and the shirt rolled up to the elbows, exposing his tanned forearms shaded by dark hair. He has a cigarette hooked in the corner of his lips, which shows that he also has something he can trade in the black market.

en: I know this man's name: Nick.
vi: I know your name: Nick.
tr: I know this man's name: Nick.
es: I know his name is Nick.

en: I know this because I've heard
vi: I know because I heard Rita and Cora mention you, and once I heard the Commander say to you:
tr: I know because I heard Rita and Cora talking about him, and once I heard the Commander call out to him:
es: I know because I heard Rita and Cora talking about him, and once I heard the Commander say to him:

en: Rita and Cora talking about him, and once I heard the Commander speaking to him:
vi: I know because I heard Rita and Cora mention you, and once I heard the Commander say to you:
tr: I know because I heard Rita and Cora talking about him, and once I heard the Commander call out to him:
es: I know because I heard Rita and Cora talking about him, and once I heard the Commander say to him:

en: Nick, I won't be needing the car.
vi: Nick, I won't be using the car today.
tr: Nick, I won't need the car.
es: Nick, I won't need the car.

en: He lives here, in the household, over the garage.
vi: He lives right here, in the house, by the garage.
tr: Here, at home, he stays above the garage.
es: He lives here, in the house, above the garage.

en: Low status: he hasn't been issued a woman, not even one.
vi: Low status: he hasn't been assigned a woman, not even one.
tr: Low status: He hasn't been assigned a woman, not even one.
es: He belongs to a lower social class; he hasn't been assigned a woman, not even one.

en: He doesn't rate: some defect, lack of connections.
vi: He's not ranked: some deficiency, lacking connections.
tr: No value: This must be some kind of flaw, a lack of relationship.
es: He doesn't meet the conditions: some defect, or lack of connections.

en: But he acts as if he doesn't know this, or care, He's too casual, he's not servile enough.
vi: But he acts like he doesn't know, or doesn't care. He behaves so casually, he doesn't show enough obedience.
tr: But he acts as if he doesn't know or doesn't care. Extremely indifferent, but not very proud.
es: But he acts as if he doesn't know or doesn't care. He is very carefree and not servile enough.

en: It may be stupid-ity, but I don't think so.
vi: Maybe he's stupid, but I don't think so.
tr: It could be stupidity, but I don't think so.
es: It could be due to stupidity, but I don't think so.

en: Smells fishy, they used to say; or, I smell a rat Misfit as odor.
vi: Different face, different heart, as they say, I smell a rat. Outcasts signal through scent.
tr: They used to say he smells like stale fish; or I smell a rat. A strange smell.
es: They used to say that his behavior smelled fishy, or that it was suspicious.

en: Despite myself, I think of how he might smell.
vi: Unintentionally, I suddenly think he might have a smell.
tr: I can't help thinking about how I might smell.
es: He is not well regarded because he is a misfit.

en: Not fish or decaying rat; tanned skin, moist in the sun, filmed with smoke.
vi: Not the smell of rot or a decaying rat; tanned skin, damp from the sun, faint in the smoke.
tr: Neither fish nor rotting rat, but a sun-sweated, smoke-covered burnt skin.
es: Despite myself, I imagine how he must smell: not fishy, but like tanned skin, damp under the sun and infused with cigarette smoke.

en: I sigh, inhaling.
vi: I sigh, take a deep breath.
tr: I take a deep breath and sigh.
es: I sigh just thinking about it.

en: He looks at me, and sees me looking.
vi: He looked at me, seeing that I was looking at him.
tr: He looks at me and sees that I am looking at him.
es: He looks at me and sees that I look at him.

en: He has a French face, lean, whimsical, all planes and angles, with creases around the mouth where he smiles.
vi: He had a French-style face, thin, quirky, all angles and edges, with wrinkled lips when he smiled.
tr: The face of a Frenchman: thin, frivolous, flat and angular, the lines that appear around his mouth when he smiles.
es: He has a Latino face, thin, angular, and wrinkles around his mouth from so much smiling.

en: He takes a final puff of the cigarette, lets it drop to the driveway, and steps on it.
vi: He took one last drag of his cigarette, dropped it to the ground, and stomped on it.
tr: He takes one last puff from his cigarette, throws it on the ground and steps on it, starts playing the click.
es: He takes one last drag on the cigarette, drops it to the ground, and steps on it.

en: He begins to whistle.
vi: He started to whistle.
tr: He takes one last puff from his cigarette, throws it on the ground and steps on it, starts playing the click.
es: He starts to whistle and winks at me.

en: Then he winks.
vi: Then he winked.
tr: Then he winks.
es: He starts to whistle and winks at me.

en: I drop my head and turn so that the white wings hide my face, and keep walking.
vi: I bowed my head and turned so that the white wings covered my face, continuing to walk.
tr: I lower my head and turn it so that the white wings cover my face, and I keep walking.
es: I lower my head, turn in such a way that the white hood hides my face, and start walking.

en: He's just taken a risk, but for what?
vi: He just took a risk, but for what?
tr: He put himself in danger, but why?
es: He has taken the risk, but for what?

en: What if I were to report him?
vi: What if I report it?
tr: Well, what if I had reported him?
es: And if I tried to betray him?

en: Perhaps he was merely being friendly.
vi: Maybe he was just being friendly.
tr: Maybe he was just being friendly.
es: Maybe he just wanted to appear friendly.

en: Perhaps he saw the look on my face and mistook it for something else.
vi: Maybe he saw my expression and misunderstood the reason.
tr: Maybe he saw the look on my face and misinterpreted it.
es: Maybe he saw my expression and misunderstood it.

en: Really what I wanted was the cigarette.
vi: In fact, I just craved a cigarette.
tr: Actually, what I wanted was a cigarette.
es: Actually, what I wanted was the cigarette.

en: I'erhaps it was a test, to see what I would do.
vi: It could be a test, to see how I respond.
tr: Maybe this was a test, to see what I would do.
es: Maybe he did it to test, to see my reaction.

en: i I'erhaps he is an Eye.
vi: He might be an Eye.
tr: Maybe it is an Eye.
es: Maybe it's a spy.

en: I open the front gate and close it behind me, looking down but not back.
vi: ~ I pushed the gate and then closed it behind me, looking down without turning back.
tr: With my head bowed, I open the front door without looking back and close it behind me.
es: I open the main gate and close it behind me. I look down, but not back.

en: The sidewalk is red brick.
vi: The red brick sidewalk.
tr: The sidewalk is paved with red bricks.
es: The sidewalk is made of red bricks.

en: That is the landscape I focus on, a held of oblongs, gently undulating where the earth beneath has buckled, from decade after decade of winter frost.
vi: That was the scene I focused on, a field of diamond-shaped tiles, slightly sagging where the ground underneath had sunken after many decades of winter frost.
tr: This is the scene I focus my attention on: A rectangular area that gently undulates where the soil beneath has warped over centuries due to winter frost.
es: I fix my gaze on the ground, a field of rectangles that form gentle waves where the earth, after decades and decades of winter frosts, has become warped.

en: The color of the bricks is old, yet fresh and clear.
vi: The bricks had faded in color, but looked fresh and clean.
tr: The color of the bricks is faded, but still vibrant and clear.
es: The color of the bricks is old, but fresh and clean.

en: Sidewalks are kept much cleaner tan they used to be.
vi: The sidewalk was swept more thoroughly than before.
tr: The sidewalks are being cleaned better than before.
es: The sidewalks are kept cleaner than they used to be in the past.

en: I walk to the corner and wait.
vi: I went to the corner of the street to wait.
tr: I walk to the corner and wait.
es: I walk to the corner and wait.

en: Iused to be bad at waiting.
vi: Before, I wasn't good at waiting.
tr: I used to be bad at waiting.
es: I couldn't stand waiting before.

en: They also serve who only stand and wait, said Aunt Lydia.
vi: Even those who just stand and wait, they also serve Him, Aunt Lydia said so.
tr: They even serve those who just stand and wait, Aunt Lydia used to say.
es: You can also serve simply by waiting, Aunt Lydia used to say.

en: She made us memorize it.
vi: She made us memorize it.
tr: She had made us memorize this.
es: She made us memorize it.

en: She also said, Not all of you will make it through.
vi: She also said, Not all of you will be able to do it.
tr: And, some of you won't be able to endure it, she would also say.
es: He also said: Not all of you will overcome it.

en: Some of you will fall on dry ground or thorns.
vi: Some of you will fall on barren ground or among thorns.
tr: Some of you will fall on hard ground or onto thorns.
es: Some of you will fail or encounter obstacles.

en: Some of you are shallow-rooted.
vi: Some of you will only take shallow roots.
tr: Some of you have weak roots.
es: Some of you are weak.

en: She had a moleon her chin that went up and down while she talked.
vi: On her chin, there was a mole that moved up and down as she spoke.
tr: She had a mole above her chin that moved up and down when she spoke.
es: He had a mole on his chin that moved up and down as he spoke.

en: She said, Think of yourselves as seeds, and right then her voice was wheedling, conspiratorial, like the voices of those women who used to teach ballet classes to children, and who would say, Arms up inthe air now; let's pretend we're trees.
vi: She said, Consider yourselves as seeds, and then her voice was conspiratorial, like those of ballet teachers for children in the old days, when they said, Raise your arms, pretend to be a tree.
tr: Consider yourselves seeds, she would say, and at that moment her voice would turn deceptive, conspiratorial; just like the voices of women teaching ballet to children and saying, let's imagine we are trees, with arms raised.
es: He said: Imagine you are seeds, and immediately adopted a fawning and conspiratorial tone, like ballet teachers when they said to the children: Now let's raise our arms... let's imagine that we are trees.

en: I stand on the corner, pretending I am a tree.
vi: I stand at the corner of the street, pretending to be a tree.
tr: I'm standing in the corner, assuming that I am a tree.
es: I am standing on the corner, pretending to be a tree.

en: A shape, red with white wings around the face, a shape like mine, a nondescript woman in red carrying a basket, comes along the brick sidewalk towards me.
vi: ~ A figure, dressed in red, face hidden behind white wings, a figure resembling me, a woman without expression wearing a red dress and carrying a basket, walking along the brick sidewalk towards me.
tr: A figure; a red figure resembling me, with white wings surrounding its face, carrying a basket, in red, an indescribable woman is coming towards me from the sidewalk.
es: A red figure with a face framed by a white bonnet, a figure like mine, an unremarkable woman, with a basket, walking towards me on the red brick sidewalk.

en: She reaches meand we peer at each other's faces, looking down the white tunnels of cloth that enclose us.
vi: She came to my spot and we both stared intently at each other's faces, glancing towards the end of the tunnel wrapped in white fabric.
tr: She reaches me and we glance at each other's faces, looking through the tunnels of white fabric that surround us.
es: She stops beside me and we look at each other's faces through the white tunnel that serves as our frame.

en: She is the right one.
vi: It was indeed her.
tr: The right person.
es: She is the one I was waiting for.

en: "Blessed be the fruit," she says to me, the accepted greeting among us.
vi: “Blessed be the fruit,” she said to me, the prescribed greeting among those like me.
tr: "May God bless the fruit," he says to me, this is the approved greeting word between us.
es: —Blessed be the fruit —she says to me, pronouncing the accepted greeting among us.

en: "May the Lord open," I answer, the accepted response.
vi: “Pray for the Lord to grant us offspring,” I replied, the prescribed answer.
tr: “May God clear your way,” I reply, the approved response.
es: —May the Lord allow it to mature —I recite the accepted response.

en: We turn and walk together past the large houses, towards the central part of town.
vi: We turned and walked side by side through the large building complex, towards the city center.
tr: We turn and walk together towards the city center, passing the large houses.
es: We turn and pass by the houses, heading towards the city center.

en: We aren't allowed to go there except in twos.
vi: We were only allowed to go there in pairs.
tr: We are not allowed to go there except in pairs.
es: We are not allowed to go there, except in pairs.

en: This is supposed to be for our protection, though the notion is absurd: we are well protected already.
vi: They said it was to protect us, though this explanation was absurd: we were already very well protected.
tr: It is thought that this is done for our protection, but that is a ridiculous notion, we are already well protected.
es: It is supposed to be for our protection, although it is an absurd idea: we are already well protected.

en: The truth is that she is my spy, as I am hers.
vi: In reality, she was meant to spy on me, and I on her.
tr: The truth is, he is my spy, and I am his.
es: The reality is that she is my spy, and I am hers.

en: If either of us slips through the net because of something that happens on one of our daily walks, the other will be accountable.
vi: If one of us slipped up because of something that happened during the outing, there would still be the other to hold accountable.
tr: If one of us slips out of the cage due to an incident during one of our daily walks, the other will be held responsible.
es: If either of us makes a slip during one of our daily walks, the other bears the responsibility.

en: This woman has been my partner for two weeks.
vi: This person has been with me for the past two weeks.
tr: This woman has been my walking companion for two weeks.
es: This woman has been my companion for the past two weeks.

en: I don't know what
vi: I don't know what happened to her before.
tr: I don't know what happened to the one before her.
es: I don't know what happened to the previous one.

en: happened to the one before.
vi: I don't know what happened to her before.
tr: I don't know what happened to the one before her.
es: I don't know what happened to the previous one.

en: On a certain day she simply wasn't there anymore, and this one was there in her place.
vi: One day she didn't come anymore, this person took her place, that's all there is to it.
tr: One day, she just wasn't there anymore, and this woman had come in her place.
es: One day she simply didn't show up, and this one was in her place.

en: It isn't the sort of thing you ask questions about, because the answers are not usually answers you want to know.
vi: These kinds of things shouldn't be questioned, because you usually don't get the answer you want to hear.
tr: This is not an event you can ask questions about, because the answers are usually not the ones you want to hear.
es: You don't ask questions about these kinds of things, because the answers are usually unpleasant.

en: Anyway there wouldn't be an answer.
vi: In general, you don't get any answer at all.
tr: Anyway, there couldn't have been an answer.
es: Anyway, there wouldn't be an answer either.

en: This one is a little plumper than I am.
vi: She is a little fatter than me.
tr: This woman is a bit chubbier than me.
es: This one is a little chubbier than me.

en: Her eyes are brown.
vi: Brown eyes.
tr: Her eyes are brown.
es: She has brown eyes.

en: Her name is Ofglen, and that's about all I know about her.
vi: Her name is Ofglen, that's all I know about her.
tr: Her name is Gleninki, that's all I know about her.
es: Her name is Deglen, and those are the two or three things I know about her.

en: She walks demurely, head down, red-gloved hands clasped in from, with short little steps like a trained pig's, onits hind legs.
vi: She walks with a proper posture, head bowed, red-gloved hands clasped tightly together in front of her chest, taking short steps like a pet pig on its hind legs.
tr: With dignity, head bowed, hands clasped in front with red gloves, she walks in short, small steps like a trained pig walking on its hind legs.
es: She walks demurely, with her head down, her hands in red gloves crossed in front, and with short steps, like those a pig trained to walk on its hind legs would take.

en: During these walks she has never said anything that was not strictly orthodox, but then, neither have I.
vi: During our walks, she has never said anything beyond the strict orthodox boundaries, but in fact, neither have I.
tr: In these walks, she never said anything completely against beliefs, but on the other hand, neither did I.
es: During the walks, she has never said anything that is not strictly orthodox, so neither have I.

en: She may be a real believer, a Handmaid in more than name.
vi: She could be a true believer, a Handmaid not just in name.
tr: She could be a true believer, a Handmaid beyond her name.
es: She must be a true believer; in her case, being a Handmaid must be more than just a name.

en: I can't take the risk.
vi: I must not take risks.
tr: I cannot take this risk.
es: So I can't take the risk.

en: "The war is going well, I hear," she says.
vi: “The war is picking up, or so they say,” she said.
tr: “I heard the war is going well,” he says.
es: —I have heard that the war is going well —he comments.

en: "Praise be," I reply.
vi: “Glory,” I replied.
tr: “Thank goodness,” I reply.
es: —Praise be —I respond.

en: "We've been sent good weather."
vi: “We have been blessed with beautiful weather.”
tr: “God has sent us beautiful weather.”
es: —We've had good weather.

en: "Which I receive with joy."
vi: “I am immensely grateful.”
tr: “I welcome it with happiness.”
es: —Which fills me with joy.

en: "They've defeated more of the rebels, since yesterday."
vi: “Have defeated more rebels since yesterday.”
tr: “They have dealt with a few more of the rebels since yesterday.”
es: —Since yesterday, they have defeated more groups of rebels.

en: "Praise be," I say.
vi: “Glory be,” I said.
tr: “Thank goodness,” I say.
es: —Praise be —I say.

en: I don't ask her how she knows, "What were they?"
vi: I didn’t ask how she knew. “Which ones?”
tr: I don't ask how he learned this. “Who are they?”
es: I don't ask how you know—. What were they?

en: "Baptists.
vi: "The Purification Sect.
tr: “The Baptists.
es: —Baptists.

en: They had a stronghold in the Blue Hills.
vi: They have a base in the Green Hills.
tr: They are based in the Blue Mountains.
es: They had a fortress in the Blue Mountains.

en: They smoked them out."
vi: We smoke them out and force them to flee."
tr: They have been driven out of their dens.”
es: But they were forced to evacuate it with smoke bombs.

en: "Praise be."
vi: “Glory be.”
tr: “Thank goodness.”
es: —Praise be.

en: Sometimes I wish she would just shut up and let me walk in peace.
vi: Sometimes I wish she would shut up so I could have some peace and leave.
tr: Sometimes I just want it to be quiet and let me walk in peace.
es: Sometimes I wish he would shut up and let me walk in peace.

en: But I'm ravenous for news, any kind of news; even if it's false news, it must mean something.
vi: But I crave news, any news; even if it's fake news, it must have some meaning.
tr: But I am hungry for news, all kinds of news; even if they are lies, they must have some meaning too.
es: But I am hungry for news, any kind of news; even if they were false, they would still mean something.

en: We reach the first barrier, which is like the barriers blocking off roadworks, or dug-up sewers: a wooden crisscross painted in yellow and black stripes, a red hexagon which means Stop.
vi: We reached the first barrier, similar to those at road construction sites or water pipe installations: a wooden beam painted yellow and black in stripes, and a red octagonal "Stop" sign.
tr: We reached the first barrier, resembling those set up during hurdle races or infrastructure excavations: yellow and black striped cross planks, a red hexagon meaning Stop.
es: We arrived at the first barrier, which is like the ones used to block the way when doing construction work, or to lift manhole covers: a wooden cross painted with yellow and black stripes and a red hexagon that means Stop.

en: Near the gateway there are some lanterns, not lit because it isn't night.
vi: Near the alleyway, there were several lanterns, unlit because it was not yet dark.
tr: At the gate, there are a few lanterns that are not yet lit because it is not night.
es: Near the door, there are some lanterns that are off because it hasn't gotten dark yet.

en: Above us, I know, there are floodlights, attached to the telephone poles, for use in emergencies, and there are men with machine guns in the pillboxes on either side of the road.
vi: Up high, I knew, there were spotlights attached to telephone poles for emergencies, and there were people holding machine guns in guard posts on either side of the road.
tr: Above us, I know there are spotlights mounted on telephone poles used in emergencies, and on both sides of the road, there are men with machine guns in the huts.
es: I know that above our heads there are lights attached to the telephone poles, which are used in emergencies; and that in the bunkers on both sides of the road, there are men stationed with machine guns.

en: I don't see the floodlights and the pillboxes, because of the wings around my face.
vi: I couldn't see the spotlights and guard posts because they were obscured.
tr: I don't see the spotlights and huts because the wings beside my face obstruct me.
es: The headscarf that surrounds my face prevents me from seeing the lights and the bunkers.

en: I just know they are
vi: I only knew they were there.
tr: I just know they are there.
es: But I know they are there.

en: there.
vi: I only knew they were there.
tr: I just know they are there.
es: But I know they are there.

en: Behind the barrier, waiting for us at the narrow gateway, there are two men, in the green uniforms of the Guardians of the Faith, with the crests on their shoulders and berets: two swords, crossed, above a white triangle.
vi: Behind the barrier, near the narrow passage, waiting for us, there were two people, wearing the blue uniforms of the Guardians of the Faith, with shoulder straps and hats bearing insignia: two crossed swords, below which was a white triangle.
tr: Behind the barrier, in the narrow passage, there are two men waiting for us, wearing the green uniforms of the Guardians of Faith, with the insignia on their shoulders and their berets: two swords crossed on a white triangle.
es: Behind the barrier, next to the narrow entrance, two men dressed in the green uniform of the Guardians of the Faith await us, with plumes on their epaulettes and a beret that features two crossed swords above a white triangle.

en: The Guardians aren't real soldiers.
vi: The Guardians are not combat soldiers.
tr: The Guardians are not real soldiers.
es: The Guardians are not real soldiers.

en: They're used for routine policing and other menial functions, digging up the Commander's Wife's garden, for instance, and they're either stupid or older or disabled or very young, apart from the ones that are Eyes incognito.
vi: They perform patrol duties and other miscellaneous tasks, such as gardening for the Commander's Wife, and if they are not dull-witted, they are either old, crippled, or too young, except for those who are hidden Eyes.
tr: They are used for routine policing and other menial tasks, such as digging the Commander's Wife's garden; they are either fools or old, or crippled or very young, except for the Eyes who roam in disguise.
es: They are assigned guard duties and other menial tasks, such as digging the soil in the Commander's Wife's garden, and they are either stupid, old, invalid, or very young; and then there are the undercover Spies.

en: These two are very young: one mustache is still sparse, one face is still blotchy.
vi: These two people are like fledglings: one with a sparse beard, the other with a still rough face.
tr: These two are very young: one hasn't even started to grow a mustache, and the other's face is still covered in pimples.
es: These two are very young: one of them still has a sparse mustache and the other a red face.

en: Their youth is touching, but I know I can't be deceived by it.
vi: Their youthful appearance easily evokes sympathy, but I know I must not be deceived.
tr: Their youth is touching, but I am aware that this cannot deceive me.
es: Their youth is touching, but I know I must not deceive myself.

en: The young ones are often the most dangerous, the most fanatical, the jumpiest with their guns.
vi: Youths are often the most dangerous, the most fanatical, the most prone to fiddling with guns.
tr: Young Guards are usually the most dangerous, the most fanatical, and the quickest to draw their weapons.
es: Youths are often the most dangerous, the most fanatical, and the ones who get the most agitated when they have a weapon in their hands.

en: They haven't yet learned about existence through time.
vi: They have not yet learned what it means to survive over time.
tr: They have not yet learned how to exist over time.
es: They do not yet possess experience.

en: You have to go slowly with them.
vi: One must be cautious with them.
tr: One must approach them with caution.
es: One must be very tactful with them.

en: Last week they shot a woman, right about here.
vi: Last week, they shot a woman, right near here.
tr: Last week, they shot a woman, right here.
es: Last week, right here, they shot a woman.

en: She was a Martha.
vi: A Martha.
tr: She was a Martha.
es: She was a Martha.

en: She was fumbling in her robe, for her pass, and they thought she was hunting for a bomb.
vi: She fumbled in her robe, looking for her pass, and they thought she was reaching for a bomb.
tr: She was searching for her pass in her dress, they thought she was reaching for a bomb.
es: He was rummaging through his suit, looking for the pass, and they thought he was going to pull out a bomb.

en: They thought she was a man in disguise.
vi: They thought she was a man in disguise.
tr: They thought it was a man dressed as a woman.
es: They took her for a man in disguise.

en: There have been such incidents.
vi: There had been such cases before.
tr: These kinds of incidents have always happened.
es: There have been several incidents of this kind.

en: Rita and Cora knew the woman.
vi: Rita and Cora know her.
tr: Rita and Cora knew the woman.
es: Rita and Cora knew that woman.

en: I heard them talking about it, in the kitchen.
vi: I heard them talking about it, in the kitchen.
tr: I had heard them talking about this event in the kitchen.
es: I heard them talking about her in the kitchen.

en: Doing their job, said Cora.
vi: We just have to do what needs to be done, Cora said.
tr: They are doing their jobs, said Cora.
es: They fulfilled their obligation, said Cora.

en: Keeping us safe.
vi: Protect the safety of our own.
tr: They are protecting us.
es: To ensure our safety.

en: Nothing safer than dead, said Rita, angrily.
vi: Only death is the safest, Rita hissed.
tr: There is no one more trustworthy than a dead person, said Rita angrily.
es: There is nothing more certain than death, said Rita angrily.

en: She was minding her own business.
vi: She only minds her own business.
tr: That woman was minding her own business.
es: She didn't bother anyone.

en: No call to shoot her.
vi: No need to shoot.
tr: There was no reason to shoot her.
es: There was no reason to shoot her.

en: It was an accident, said Cora.
vi: It was an accident, Cora said.
tr: It was an accident, said Cora.
es: It was an accident, replied Cora.

en: No such thing, said Rita.
vi: Forget that sentence, Rita said.
tr: That can't happen, said Rita.
es: None of that, protested Rita.

en: Everything is meant.
vi: Everything is calculated.
tr: Everything was arranged beforehand.
es: All of this is unpleasant.

en: I could hear her thumping the pots around, in the sink.
vi: I heard her banging pots and pans clanging, in the sink.
tr: I could hear the sounds she made while dealing with the dishes in the sink.
es: I could hear her moving the pots in the sink.

en: Well, someone'll think twice before blowing up this house, any ways, said Cora.
vi: Well, anyway, people have to think carefully before blowing up this house, Cora said.
tr: Yes, at the very least, someone will think twice before blowing up this house, said Cora.
es: Well, anyway, they would think twice before blowing up this house, Cora stated.

en: All the same, said Rita.
vi: It's all the same, Rita said.
tr: No matter what, said Rita.
es: It doesn't matter, replied Rita.

en: She worked hard.
vi: She was very diligent.
tr: She was working very hard.
es: She was very hardworking.

en: That was a bad death.
vi: It's terrible to die like that.
tr: She did not deserve such a terrible death.
es: She didn't deserve to die like that.

en: I can think of worse, said Cora.
vi: There are many things much worse, Cora said.
tr: There is something worse, said Cora.
es: There are worse deaths, commented Cora.

en: At least it was quick.
vi: At least it's quick and clean.
tr: At least it was a quick death.
es: At least this one was quick.

en: You can say that, said Rita.
vi: "That's just your opinion," Rita said.
tr: Yes, that can be said, said Rita.
es: You can say it, concluded Rita.

en: I'd choose to have some time, before, like.
vi: "I would rather have more time, maybe a little earlier."
tr: I would like to have a little time.
es: I would prefer to have a little time.

en: To set things right.
vi: "Everything is already arranged."
tr: To get things in order.
es: To fix things.

en: The two young Guardians salute us, raising three fingers to the rims of their berets.
vi: ~ Two young Guards greeted us, touching the brim of their hats with three fingers.
tr: Two young Guards salute us by touching the edges of their berets with three fingers.
es: The two young Guardians greet us by bringing three fingers to the edge of their berets.

en: Such tokens are accorded to us.
vi: We were given this ceremony.
tr: We have such privileges.
es: That is the signal for us.

en: They are supposed to show respect, because of the nature of our service.
vi: They must show respect for our mission.
tr: Due to the nature of our service, they are required to show us respect.
es: They are supposed to show us respect, due to the nature of our mission.

en: We produce our passes, from the zippered pockets in our wide sleeves, and they are inspected and stamped.
vi: We presented our travel documents, taken from the zippered pocket in the wide sleeve, the documents were checked and stamped.
tr: We take out our transit documents from the zippered wallets located in the wide sleeves of our robes, they inspect and stamp them.
es: We take our passes out of the zippered pockets of our wide sleeves; they inspect and stamp them.

en: One man goes into the right-hand pillbox, to punch our numbers into the Compuchek.
vi: A person entered the right guard post, inputting our code into the computer check machine.
tr: One of the men enters the booth on the right to input our numbers into the Compüçek.
es: One of the young men enters the fort on the right to punch the numbers on our passes with the Compuchec.

en: In returning my pass, the one with the peach-colored mustache bends his head to try to get a look at my face.
vi: When returning the paper, the peach-fuzz-mustached boy tilted his head, trying to look at my face.
tr: While returning my document, he tilts his head to look at me, with his peach-colored mustache.
es: When he returns my pass, the man with the peach-colored mustache tilts his head, trying to get a look at my face.

en: I raise my head a little, to help him, and he sees my eyes and I see his, and he blushes.
vi: I lifted my head slightly to help, and he looked into my eyes just as I looked into his, and his cheeks turned red.
tr: To help him, I lift my head a little and he sees my eyes, and I see his, he blushes.
es: I lift my head a bit to help him; he looks into my eyes, I look into his, and he blushes.

en: His face is long and mournful, like a sheep's, but with the large full eyes of a dog, spaniel not terrier.
vi: His face was long and melancholic, like a sheep, but his eyes were big and round like a dog’s, resembling a floppy-eared spaniel rather than a terrier.
tr: His face is as long and sad as a sheep's, but his eyes are like those of a terrier, no, a spaniel's, wide open and large.
es: His face is long and sad, like that of a lamb, and he has large, deep eyes, like those of a dog... a spaniel, not a terrier.

en: His skin is pale and looks un-wholesomely tender, like the skin under a scab.
vi: His skin was pale and fragile-looking, almost sickly, like the new skin of a healing scar.
tr: His skin has a pale and unhealthy delicate appearance, just like the skin under a wound.
es: His skin is white and seems unhealthily fragile, like the skin beneath a scab.

en: Nevertheless, I think of placing my hand on it, this exposed face.
vi: Yet I still imagined placing my hand on it, on that bare face.
tr: Yet I want to put my hand on it, this defenseless face.
es: However, I imagine placing my hand on this exposed face.

en: He is the one who turns away.
vi: He turned away first.
tr: He is the one who looks away.
es: He is the one who pulls away.

en: It's an event, a small defiance of rule, so small as to be undetect-able, but such moments are the rewards I hold out for myself, like the candy I hoarded, as a child, at the back of a drawer.
vi: That event, that tiny violation, too small for anyone to notice, but moments like that are the rewards I keep for myself, like candies once hidden, when I was little, at the bottom of the drawer.
tr: This is an event, a small defiance of the rules, so small it won't be noticed, but such moments are rewards I keep for myself; like hidden candies, when I was a child, at the back of a drawer.
es: This is an event, a small challenge to the norms, so brief that it may go unnoticed; but these moments are a reward that I reserve for myself, like the candy that, as a child, I hid in the back of a drawer.

en: Such moments are possibilities, tiny peepholes.
vi: They are opportunities, tiny keyholes peeking out.
tr: These kinds of moments are opportunities, tiny peepholes.
es: Moments like this are an opportunity that opens up, like a tiny peephole.

en: What if I were to come at night, when he's on duty alonethough he would never be allowed such solitudeand permit him beyond my white wings?
vi: If I come at night, when you are on duty alone – though you will never enjoy that solitude – and allow you inside the white wings?
tr: What if I came to this young man at night while he was alone on duty - even though such solitude would not be granted to him - and left him under my white wings?
es: And what if he came at night, when he is alone —although they would never allow him to be so alone—, and let him go beyond my veil?

en: What if I were to peel off my red shroud and show myself to him, to them, by the uncertain light of the lanterns?
vi: If I shed this red shroud and expose myself to you, to them, in the flickering lantern light?
tr: What if I took off my red shroud and showed myself to him, to them, in the uncertain light of the lanterns?
es: And what if I took off my red veil and exhibited myself before him, before them, under the uncertain light of the street lamps?

en: This is what they must think about sometimes, as they stand endlessly beside this barrier, past which nobody ever comes except the Commanders of the Faithful in their long black murmurous cars, or their blue Wives and white-veiled daughters on their dutiful way to Salvagings or Prayvaganzas, or their dumpy green Marthas, or the occasional Birthmobile', or their read Hand-maids, on foot.
vi: Surely, at times, they must think about this, during their eternal watch behind the bars, where no one ever passes except for the Commanders of the Faithful in their long black cars, the blue-clad Wives and their veiled white daughters diligently on their way to Redemption or Prayer, or the short green Marthas, or the occasional Birthmobiles, or the red Handmaids, all walking.
tr: This must be what they think about as they stand forever beside this barrier, where no one passes except for the Commanders of the Faithful with their long, black, humming cars, the blue Wives and white-veiled girls for the Salvation and Prayer Ceremonies, the stout green Marthas, and occasionally the Birthmobile or the red Handmaids walking on foot.
es: This is what they must sometimes think, as they spend the dead hours behind this barrier that no one ever crosses except the Commanders of the Faith in their long, purring black cars, or their blue Wives, and their daughters with their white veils on their devout journey to Salvation or Prayvaganzas, or their plump green Marthas, or an occasional Birthmobile, or their red Handmaids, on foot.

en: Or sometimes a black-painted van, with the winged
vi: Or sometimes a black-painted van, with the white-winged Eye painted on its side.
tr: Although sometimes a van painted black, with a white-winged eye on one side, passes by.
es: Or, sometimes, a van painted black, with the white eye on the side.

en: Eye in white on the side.
vi: Or sometimes a black-painted van, with the white-winged Eye painted on its side.
tr: Although sometimes a van painted black, with a white-winged eye on one side, passes by.
es: Or, sometimes, a van painted black, with the white eye on the side.

en: The windows of the vans are dark-tinted, and the men in the front seats wear dark glasses: a double obscurity.
vi: The windows of the vehicle are frosted, and the people in the front seats wear dark glasses: doubly obscured.
tr: The windows of the vans are dark-tinted, and the men sitting in the front seats wear dark glasses: double uncertainty.
es: The windows of the vans are dark, and the men in the front seat wear dark glasses: one darkness over another.

en: The vans are surely more silent than the other cars.
vi: The truck was certainly quieter than the other vehicles.
tr: Minibuses are definitely quieter than other cars.
es: By the way, the vans are quieter than the rest of the cars.

en: When they pass, we avert our eyes.
vi: When they passed by, we looked away.
tr: When they pass by, we turn our eyes in another direction.
es: When they pass by, we look away.

en: If there are sounds coming from inside, we try not to hear them.
vi: If there was any noise from the truck, we pretended not to hear it.
tr: If there are sounds coming from inside, we try not to hear them.
es: If any sound comes from inside, we try not to hear it.

en: Nobody's heart is perfect.
vi: Whose heart is ever perfect?
tr: No one's heart is perfect.
es: Out of sight, out of mind.

en: When the black vans reach a checkpoint, they're waved through without a pause.
vi: When a black van arrived at the checkpoint, people waved it through.
tr: When the black vans arrive at a checkpoint, they are waved through without stopping.
es: When the vans arrive at a checkpoint, they are signaled to pass without stopping.

en: The Guardians would not want to take the risk of looking inside, searching, doubting their authority.
vi: The Guards did not want to risk looking inside, searching, or doubting its authority.
tr: The guards do not want to risk looking inside, searching, or questioning their authority.
es: The Guardians do not want to risk inspecting the interior and questioning their authority.

en: Whatever they think.
vi: It didn't matter what they thought.
tr: No matter what their thoughts may be.
es: Regardless of what they think.

en: If they do think; you can't tell by looking at them.
vi: If they are thinking; you can't tell by looking at them.
tr: If they are thinking He, you cannot understand this by looking at their faces.
es: If they think at all, although it's impossible to tell from their expression.

en: But more likely they don't think in terms of clothing discarded on the lawn.
vi: But they are likely not thinking about clothes left on the grass.
tr: But surely they are not thinking in terms of clothes thrown on the grass.
es: The most likely thing is that they don't think about anything promiscuous.

en: If they think of a kiss, they must then think immediately of the floodlights going on, the rifle shots.
vi: If they think about the kiss, they must immediately think about the headlights shining, about the rifle shot.
tr: Even if they think of a kiss, they must immediately think of the burning spotlights and rifle shots afterwards.
es: If they think about a kiss, they must immediately think about the lights turning on and the rifle shots.

en: They think instead of doing their duty and of promotion to the Angels, and of being allowed possibly to marry, and then, if they are able to gain enough power and live to be old enough, of being allotted a Handmaid of their own.
vi: They shift their thoughts to duty and the prospect of ascending to an Angel, and who knows, maybe being allowed to marry, and then, if they gain enough power and live long enough, being granted a Handmaid of their own.
tr: Instead, they are thinking of doing their duties and being promoted to Angelhood, maybe getting marriage leave, and then, if they can gain enough power and live long enough, being assigned a Handmaid.
es: In reality, they think about doing their job, about ascending to the category of Angels, maybe about being allowed to marry and, if they are capable of attaining enough power and reach old age, about being assigned a Handmaid just for them.

en: The one with the mustache opens the small pedestrian gate for us and stands back, well out of the way, and we pass through.
vi: ~ He opened the small pedestrian gate and stepped back, staying far away from it, and we passed through.
tr: The one with the mustache opens the small pedestrian gate for us and stays back, stepping aside quite a bit; we pass through the gate.
es: The man with the mustache opens the small gate for pedestrians, steps back to make room for us, and we pass through.

en: As wewalk away I know they're watching, these two men who aren't yet permitted to touch women.
vi: Their footsteps faded away but I knew they were watching, two young men, not yet allowed to touch women.
tr: I know they are watching us as we move away; these two men who are not yet allowed to touch women.
es: I know that as we move forward, these two men—who are still not allowed to touch women—are watching us.

en: They touch with their eyes instead and I move my hips a little, feeling the full red skirt sway around me.
vi: In return, they caressed with their eyes and I swayed my hips a little, feeling the red puffed skirt swirl around my body.
tr: Instead, they touch with their eyes, I sway my hips a little, feeling the long red skirt swaying.
es: However, they touch us with their eyes and I sway my hips a little and feel the swing of my wide skirt.

en: It's like thumbing your nose from behind a fence or teasing a dog with a bone held out of reach, and I'm ashamed of myself for doing it, because none of this is the fault of these men, they're too young.
vi: It was no different from sticking out your tongue behind a barrier or teasing a dog with a bone just out of reach, and I felt ashamed for doing it, because these things weren't the fault of these two, they were still too young.
tr: It's like making a face from behind a fence or teasing a dog with a bone from a distance; I feel ashamed of myself for doing this, because none of this is their fault, they are very young.
es: It's like mocking someone from the other side of the fence, or teasing a dog with a bone by keeping it out of reach, and I immediately feel ashamed of my behavior because none of this is the fault of those men, they are too young.

en: Then I find I'm not ashamed after all.
vi: Then I realized I wasn't embarrassed at all.
tr: Then I realize that I am not ashamed at all.
es: Soon I discover that I am not actually ashamed.

en: I enjoy the power; power of a dog bone, passive but there.
vi: I savored the feeling of power; the power of a bone, passive, but right in front of their noses.
tr: I like power; the power of a dog’s bone, passive but there it is.
es: I enjoy the power: the power of a bone, which does nothing but is there.

en: I hope theyget hard at the sight of us and have to rub themselves against the painted barriers, surreptitiously.
vi: I prayed that just by looking at us, they would get aroused and have to rub against the black and yellow painted barrier, secretly.
tr: I hope they get aroused when they see us and have to secretly rub themselves against the painted barriers.
