es: I harbor the hope that they will have a hard time looking at us and will have to rub against the barriers, surreptitiously. And

en: They will suffer, later, at night, in their regimented beds.
vi: They would have to suffer later, at night, in their individually assigned beds.
tr: They will suffer later, at night, in their beds aligned in perfect order.
es: that later, at night, they suffer on the regiment's cots.

en: They have no outlets now except themselves, and that's a sacrilege.
vi: Now they had no outlet other than themselves, which was blasphemous.
tr: Now they have no means of release other than themselves, and even that is considered a kind of sin.
es: Now they have no relief except their own bodies, and that is a sacrilege.

en: There are no more magazines, no more films, no more substitutes; only me and my shadow, walking away from the two men, who stand at attention, stiffly, by a roadblock, watching our retreating shapes.
vi: No more magazines, no more films, no alternative routes; just me and the shadow, gradually moving away from the two boys standing stiffly at the checkpoint, watching the two figures recede.
tr: There are no magazines, films, or anything else to take their place anymore; just me and my shadow, moving away from those two men who are carefully watching our upright and departing forms at the barrier.
es: There are no more magazines, no movies, no substitutes; only me and my shadow moving away from the two men, who stand rigidly by the barricade while watching our figures.
CHAPTER 5

en: Doubled, I walk the street.
vi: Carrying the version, I walked on the street.
tr: Paired up, I am walking on the road.
es: I walk down the street accompanied by my double.

en: Though we are no longer in the Commanders' compound, there are large houses here also.
vi: Even though I had left the Commanders' residential area, there were still large houses here.
tr: Even though we are now in the Commanders' compound, there are still large houses here.
es: Although we are no longer in the enclosed area of the Commanders, there are also huge houses here.

en: In front of one of them a Guardian is mowing the lawn.
vi: In front of one house, a Guard was pushing a lawn mower.
tr: In front of one of the houses, a Guardian is mowing the lawn.
es: In one of them, a Guardian can be seen mowing the lawn.

en: The lawns are tidy, the facades are gracious, in good repair; they're like the beautiful pictures they used to print in the magazines about homes and gardens and interior decoration.
vi: The lawn was neat, the facade was splendid, regularly maintained; it looked like the magnificent pictures printed in old home-garden-interior magazines.
tr: The lawns are clean, they look cute, well-maintained; they resemble the beautiful pictures once published in magazines about houses, gardens, and interior decoration.
es: The gardens are well-kept, the facades are beautiful and well-preserved; they are like those beautiful pictures that used to appear in house and garden magazines and interior design magazines.

en: There is the same absence of people, the same air of being asleep.
vi: Also with the same absence of people, the same drowsy appearance.
tr: Here too, there is the same absence of people, the same state of dormancy.
es: And the same absence of people, the same feeling that everything is asleep.

en: The street is almost like a museum, or a street in a model town constructed to show the way people used to live.
vi: The streets were almost like a museum, or like a model city built to display how people used to live.
tr: The street is almost like a museum or a street in model towns built to show how people used to live.
es: The street is almost like a museum, as if it were part of a model of a city, made to show how people lived.

en: As in those pictures, those museums, those model towns, there are no children.
vi: Just like those pictures, those museums, those cities, children were not present.
tr: Just like in those pictures, those museums, those model towns, there are no children around.
es: And just like in those photos, those museums and those models, not a single child can be seen.

en: This is the heart of Gilead, where the war cannot intrude except on television.
vi: This is the heart of Gilead, where civil war cannot penetrate, except through television.
tr: This is the heart of Gilead, a place where the war cannot force its way in except on television.
es: We are in the center of Gilead, where the war only reaches us through the television.

en: Where the edges are we aren't sure, they vary, according to the attacks and counterattacks; but this is the center, where nothing moves.
vi: The border is unclear, it often shifts, depending on the attacks and counterattacks; but the center is here, it never moves.
tr: We are not sure where the borders are, they constantly change according to attacks and counterattacks, but this is the center, where nothing moves.
es: We are not sure where the boundaries are; they vary according to the attacks and counterattacks. But this is the center, and here nothing moves.

en: The Republic of Gilead, said Aunt Lydia, knows no bounds.
vi: The Republic of Gilead, Aunt Lydia says, has no borders.
tr: The Republic of Gilead, Aunt Lydia would say, knows no bounds.
es: The Republic of Gilead, Aunt Lydia said, has no borders.

en: Gilead is within you.
vi: Gilead is within us.
tr: Gilead is within you.
es: Gilead is within you.

en: Doctors lived here once, lawyers, university professors.
vi: Doctors used to live here, as well as lawyers and university lecturers.
tr: Doctors used to live here, lawyers, university professors.
es: Once upon a time, doctors, lawyers, and university professors lived here.

en: There are no lawyers anymore, and the university is closed.
vi: Now there are no more lawyers, and the university has also closed down.
tr: Now there are no lawyers and the university is closed.
es: But now there are no more lawyers, and the universities are closed.

en: Luke and I used to walk together, sometimes, along these streets.
vi: Luke and I often walked side by side, sometimes, on these streets.
tr: Luke and I used to walk these streets from time to time.
es: Sometimes, Luke and I would walk together through these streets.

en: We used to talk about buying a house like one of these, an old big house, fixing it up.
vi: We often talked about buying a house like the ones here, a really big old house, and renovating it.
tr: We would talk about buying a house like these, a big old house, and fixing it up.
es: We would say that we would buy a house like this one, a big house, and that we would fix it up.

en: We would have a garden, . swings forthe Children.
vi: There would be a garden, with swings for the children.
tr: We would have a garden, with swings for the children.
es: We would have a garden and swings for the children.

en: We would have children.
vi: We would have children.
tr: We would have children.
es: Because we would have children.

en: Although we knew it wasn't too likely we could ever afford it, it was something to talk about, a game forSundays.
vi: Even though we knew the chances of realizing those luxuries were quite low, we still liked to talk about it, a Sunday pastime.
tr: Even though we knew it was unlikely we could manage it, it was something to talk about. A Sunday game.
es: Even though we knew it was not very likely that we could afford such a luxury, at least it was a topic of conversation, a game for Sundays.

en: Such freedom now seems almost weightless.
vi: That freedom now feels unreal.
tr: Such freedom is now unthinkable.
es: Now, that freedom seems like a chimera.

en: We turn the corner onto a main street, where there's more traffic.
vi: At the corner, we turned onto the main road, where the traffic was denser.
tr: We turn the corner that opens onto a main street, where the traffic is heavier.
es: At the corner, we turn onto the main street, where there is more traffic.

en: Cars go by, black most of them, some gray and brown.
vi: Cars sped by, mostly black, some gray and brown.
tr: Cars are passing by, most of them black, some gray and brown.
es: Cars pass by, most of them black, and some gray or brown.

en: There are other women with baskets, some in red, some in the dull green of the Marthas, some in the striped dresses, red and blue and green and cheap and skimpy, that mark the women of the poorer men.
vi: More women carrying baskets, some red, some Martha's dull green, some wearing striped clothes, red and blue and green and cheap and neatly woven, the style of poor women's clothing.
tr: There are other women with baskets too, some in red, some in the dull green of the Marthas; some are wearing striped dresses, red and blue and green and cheap and tattered, these mark the wives of poorer men.
es: There are other women with baskets, some dressed in red, others in the dull green of the Marthas, others in dresses with red, blue, and green stripes, cheap and modest, proof that they are the wives of the poorest men.

en: Econowives, they're called.
vi: Frugal wives, that's what they're called.
tr: They are called Econowives.
es: They are called econowives.

en: These women are not divided into functions.
vi: These women are not assigned different duties.
tr: These women have no separate functions.
es: These women are not divided according to their functions, they have to do everything, if they can.

en: They have to do everything; if they can.
vi: They have to do everything, if possible.
tr: They have to do everything; if they can.
es: These women are not divided according to their functions, they have to do everything, if they can.

en: Sometimes there is a womanall in black, a widow.
vi: Occasionally, someone dressed entirely in black, a widow.
tr: Sometimes a woman entirely in black passes by, a widow.
es: Occasionally, you see a woman completely dressed in black, which means she is a widow.

en: There used to be more of them, but
vi: There used to be more, but they seem to be gradually disappearing.
tr: There used to be many of them, but they seem to be decreasing in number.
es: There used to be more widows seen, but they seem to be disappearing.

en: they seem to be diminishing.
vi: There used to be more, but they seem to be gradually disappearing.
tr: There used to be many of them, but they seem to be decreasing in number.
es: There used to be more widows seen, but they seem to be disappearing.

en: You don't see the Commanders' Wives on the sidewalks.
vi: No Commander's Wives were seen on the sidewalks.
tr: You cannot see the Commanders' wives on the sidewalk.
es: You don't see Commanders' Wives on the sidewalks: they only ride in cars.

en: Only in cars.
vi: They always sit in the car.
tr: They are only inside cars.
es: You don't see Commanders' Wives on the sidewalks: they only ride in cars.

en: The sidewalks here are cement.
vi: The sidewalk here is made of cement.
tr: The sidewalks here are made of concrete.
es: Here, the sidewalks are made of cement.

en: Like a child, I avoid stepping on the cracks.
vi: Like a child, I avoid stepping on the cracks.
tr: Just like a child, I take care not to step on the cracked spots.
es: I try not to step on the cracks, like children do.

en: I'm remembering my feet on these sidewalks, in the time before, and what I used to wear on them.
vi: I am reminiscing about my feet on the same sidewalk, long ago, remembering the shoes I used to wear.
tr: I remember my feet walking on these sidewalks, in the past, what I was wearing on my feet.
es: I remember when I used to walk on these sidewalks, in different times, and the footwear I used to wear.

en: Sometimes it was shoes for running, with cushioned soles and breathing holes, and stars of fluorescent fabric that reflected light in the darkness.
vi: Sometimes they were running shoes, with cushioned soles and ventilation holes, adorned with reflective threads that glowed at night.
tr: Sometimes running shoes, the kind with cushioned soles and air holes, with stars made of phosphorescent fabric that reflects light in the dark.
es: Sometimes I wore running shoes with padded insides and little holes for the foot to breathe, and fluorescent fabric stars that reflected light in the dark.

en: Though I never ran at night; and in the daytime, only beside well-frequented roads.
vi: Even though I came, I never ran; even during the day, only on familiar paths.
tr: Though I never ran at night, and only during the day on crowded streets.
es: However, I never ran at night, and during the day I only did so on very crowded streets.

en: Women were not protected then.
vi: In those times, women were not protected.
tr: At that time, women were not yet protected.
es: Back then, women were not protected.

en: I remember the rules, rules that were never spelled out but that every woman knew:
vi: I still remember the rule, unwritten but known by all women:
tr: I remember the rules, the rules never spoken but known by every woman: never open your door to a stranger, even if they say they are the police.
es: I remember the rules, rules that were not written, but that any woman knew: do not open the door to a stranger, even if he says he is a policeman; in that case, tell him to pass his identification card under the door.

en: Don't open your door to a stranger, even if he says he is the police.
vi: Do not open the door for strangers, even if they claim to be the police.
tr: I remember the rules, the rules never spoken but known by every woman: never open your door to a stranger, even if they say they are the police.
es: I remember the rules, rules that were not written, but that any woman knew: do not open the door to a stranger, even if he says he is a policeman; in that case, tell him to pass his identification card under the door.

en: Make him slide his ID under the door.
vi: Make them slide their ID under the door.
tr: Ask them to slide their ID card under the door.
es: I remember the rules, rules that were not written, but that any woman knew: do not open the door to a stranger, even if he says he is a policeman; in that case, tell him to pass his identification card under the door.

en: Don't stop on the road to help a motorist pretending to be in trouble.
vi: Do not stop in the middle of the road to help a motorcyclist pretending to be in trouble.
tr: Do not stop on the road to help a motorcyclist claiming to have a problem.
es: Do not stop on the road to help a motorist who seems to have a problem; do not brake and keep going.

en: Keep the locks on and keep going.
vi: Keep your pace and continue walking.
tr: Hold yourself together and keep walking.
es: Do not stop on the road to help a motorist who seems to have a problem; do not brake and keep going.

en: If anyone whistles, don't turn to look.
vi: If someone whistles to call you, do not turn around.
tr: If someone whistles, do not look back.
es: If someone gets in, do not turn around to look.

en: Don't go into a laundromat, by yourself, at night.
vi: Do not go to the laundromat alone at night.
tr: Do not go to a laundromat alone at night.
es: Do not enter a laundromat alone at night.

en: I think about laundromats.
vi: I think again about the laundromats.
tr: I'm thinking about laundromats.
es: I think about the laundromats.

en: What I wore to them: shorts, jeans, jogging pants.
vi: The things I wear to go there: shorts, jeans, workout pants.
tr: What wouldn't I wear when going there: shorts, jeans, running pants.
es: I think about what I used to wear to go: shorts, jeans, or tracksuit.

en: What I put into them: my own clothes, my own soap, my own money, money I had earned myself.
vi: The things I put in there: my clothes, my soap, my money, the money I earned with my own effort.
tr: What wouldn't I put in the machines: my own clothes, my own soap, my own money, the money I earned on my own.
es: And what I put in the washing machine: my own clothes, my own detergent, my own money, the money I had earned.

en: I think about having such control.
vi: I think about the ownership I once had.
tr: I'm thinking about having such control.
es: I remember what it was like to keep track of the money.

en: Now we walk along the same street, in red pairs, and no man shouts obscenities at us, speaks to us, touches us.
vi: Now we walk on the same street, in pairs, and no men shout obscene words behind us, talk to us, touch us.
tr: Now we are walking on the same street, in red pairs, no man catcalls, talks to us, or touches us.
es: Now we walk down the same street, two by two and in red, and no man shouts obscenities at us, nor speaks to us, nor touches us.

en: No one whistles.
vi: No one whistles.
tr: No one whistles.
es: No one whistles at us.

en: There is more than one kind of freedom, said Aunt Lydia.
vi: There is not just one kind of freedom, Aunt Lydia said.
tr: There are multiple types of freedom, Aunt Lydia used to say.
es: There is more than one kind of freedom, Aunt Lydia used to say.

en: Freedom to and freedom from.
vi: There is freedom to act and freedom through liberation.
tr: The freedom to do things and the freedom to refrain from things.
es: Freedom to and freedom from.

en: In the days of anarchy, it was freedom to.
vi: In the time of anarchy, there was freedom to act.
tr: In the days of anarchy, there was the freedom to do things.
es: In the days of anarchy, it was freedom to.

en: Now you are being given freedom from.
vi: Now you are granted freedom through liberation.
tr: Now you are given the freedom to refrain.
es: Now we are given freedom from.

en: Don't underrate it.
vi: Do not underestimate it.
tr: Do not underestimate this.
es: Do not underrate it.

en: In front of us, to the right, is the store where we order dresses.
vi: Right in front, on the right side of the road, is the shop where we place our clothes.
tr: On our right ahead, there is the shop where we ordered the clothes.
es: In front of us, to the right, is the shop where we ordered the dresses.

en: Sonic people call them habits, a good word for them.
vi: Some people call them uniforms, how accurate that is.
tr: Some people call these habits, a fitting phrase.
es: Some people call them habits, a good definition: it's hard to give up habits.

en: Habits are hard to break.
vi: What becomes a habit is hard to break.
tr: It is difficult to break habits.
es: Some people call them habits, a good definition: it's hard to give up habits.

en: The store has a huge wooden sign outside it, in the shape of a golden lily; Lilies of the Field, it's called.
vi: Outside hangs a very large wooden sign, shaped like a yellow lily; Lily of the field, that's the name of the shop.
tr: Outside the shop, there is a large wooden sign hanging, in the shape of a golden lily; it is called the Field Lily.
es: On the store's facade, there is a huge wooden sign in the shape of a lily: it is called Wild Lilies.

en: You can see the place, under the lily, where the lettering was painted out, when they decided that even the names of shops were too much temptation for us.
vi: You can see a blank space, right below the lily, there used to be something but now it's been erased with red paint, following the opinion that even the names of the shops have too much allure for us.
tr: Under the lily, you can see where the letters were covered with paint, at that time they had decided that even shop names were too enticing for us.
es: Below the lily, you can see the spot where the label was painted; but they decided that even the names of the stores were too much temptation for us.

en: Now places are known by their signs alone.
vi: Now shops are only distinguished by their signs.
tr: Now, such places are only known by their signboards without writing.
es: Now the stores are known only by the signs.

en: Lilies used to be a movie theater, before.
vi: The lily used to be a movie theater, back in the day.
tr: Zambaklar used to be a cinema.
es: Before, Azucenas was a cinema.

en: Students went there a lot; every spring they had aHumphrey Bogart festival, with Lauren Bacall or Katharine Hepburn, women on their own, making up their minds.
vi: Students flocked there; every spring there was a festival commemorating Humphrey Bogart, featuring Lauren Bacall or Katharine Hepburn, women who were self-reliant and made their own decisions.
tr: Students would often go there. Every spring, a Humphrey Bogart festival was organized, featuring Lauren Bacall or Katherine Hepburn, women who made their own decisions independently.
es: It was very popular among students; every spring the Humphrey Bogart festival was celebrated, with Lauren Bacall or Katherine Hepburn, independent and determined women.

en: They wore blouses with buttons down the front that suggested the possibilities of the word undone.
vi: They wore blouses buttoned down the front, suggesting the idea of unbuttoning.
tr: They would wear blouses with buttons all the way down, hinting at the possibilities of the word "naked".
es: They wore buttoned blouses that suggested the various possibilities of the word loose.

en: These women could be undone; or not.
vi: Those women could be unbuttoned, or not.
tr: These women could be stripped or not stripped.
es: Those women could be Loose; or not.

en: They seemed to be able to choose.
vi: It seemed they had the right to choose.
tr: Apparently, they had the right to choose.
es: They seemed capable of choosing.

en: We seemed to be able to choose, then.
vi: We also seemed to have the right to choose, back then.
tr: Back then, we also seemed to have the ability to choose.
es: In those times we seemed capable of choosing.

en: We were a society dying, said Aunt Lydia, of too much choice.
vi: We lived in a society that was suffocating, Aunt Lydia said, under too many choices.
tr: We were a society on the brink of death, Aunt Lydia would say, because of too many choices.
es: We are a Society in decline, Aunt Lydia said, with too many choices.

en: I don't know when they stopped having the festival.
vi: I don't know when they will stop organizing parties.
tr: I don't know when they gave up organizing the festival.
es: I don't know when they stopped celebrating the festival.

en: I must have been grown up.
vi: By that time, I will probably have grown up.
tr: I must have grown up.
es: Surely I had already grown up.

en: So I didn't notice.
vi: So I won't be making excuses anymore.
tr: That's why I didn't notice.
es: That's why I didn't find out.

en: We don't go into Lilies, but across the road and along a side street.
vi: We did not enter Hoa Hue, but crossed the street and turned into a side road.
tr: We avoid the lilies and cross the street, turning into a side alley.
es: We didn't enter Azucenas; we crossed the street and walked along the sidewalk.

en: Our first stop is at a store with another wooden sign: three eggs, a bee, a cow.
vi: The first destination was a store with a wooden sign: three eggs, a bee, a cow.
tr: Our first stop is another shop with a wooden sign: three eggs, a moment, a cow.
es: The first place we entered was a store that also had a wooden sign: three eggs, a bee, and a cow.

en: Milk and Honey.
vi: Milk and honey.
tr: Milk and Honey.
es: Milk and honey.

en: There's a line, and we wait our turn, two by two.
vi: There was a long line in front of the door, and we waited our turn, two by two.
tr: There's a line, we wait our turn, two by two.
es: There was a line; we joined it to wait our turn, always two by two.

en: I see they have oranges today.
vi: I saw that today there were oranges.
tr: I notice that oranges have arrived today.
es: I saw that today they had oranges.

en: Ever since Central America was lost to the Libertheos, oranges have been hard to get: sometimes they are there, sometimes not.
vi: Since Central America fell to the Liberal faction, oranges have become hard to find, sometimes available, sometimes not.
tr: Since Central America was lost to the Libertarians, finding oranges has become difficult, sometimes they are available, sometimes not.
es: Since Central America was lost to the Libertos, oranges have been hard to come by: sometimes they have them and sometimes they don't.

en: The war interferes with the oranges from California, and even Florida isn't dependable, when there are roadblocks or when the train tracks have been blown up.
vi: The war has disrupted the supply of oranges from California, and even Florida can no longer be relied upon, with blockades or rail lines being bombed.
tr: The war also interferes with California oranges, and when there are roadblocks or the railways are blown up, even Florida is not reliable.
es: Because of the war, not many oranges come from California either, and you can't count on the ones from Florida because of the barricades and the blowing up of the railroad tracks.

en: I look atthe oranges, longing for one.
vi: I looked at the oranges, longing for one.
tr: I look at the oranges, desiring one.
es: I looked at the oranges and my mouth watered.

en: But I haven't brought any coupons for oranges.
vi: But I did not bring any orange coupons.
tr: But I didn't bring a ration card for oranges.
es: But I hadn't brought any vouchers for oranges.

en: I'll go back and tell Rita about them, I think.
vi: I'll tell Rita about the oranges when I get back, I thought to myself.
tr: I think about going back and telling Rita about this.
es: It occurred to me that I could go back and tell Rita.

en: She'll be pleased.
vi: She will be pleased.
tr: She will be delighted.
es: She would love it.

en: It will be something, a small achievement, to have made oranges happen.
vi: It will be something noteworthy, a small achievement, if I manage to make oranges appear.
tr: Getting an orange would be something, a small success.
es: Showing up with the oranges would be a small triumph.

en: Those who've reached the counter hand their tokens across it, to the two men in Guardian uniforms who stand on the other side.
vi: Those who had made it to the place handed their tickets over the counter to two men in Guardian uniforms standing on the other side.
tr: Those who reach the counter hand their ration cards to the two men in Guardian uniforms standing on the other side.
es: As they reach the counter, the women hand over their vouchers to the two men in Guardian uniforms, who are on the other side.

en: Nobody talks much, though there is a rustling,and the women's heads move furtively from side to side: here, shopping, is where you might see someone you know, someone you've known in the time before, or at the Red Center.
vi: No one talked much, though there was still a murmur, and the women discreetly turned their heads to look this way and that: here, while shopping, one might meet someone familiar, someone known from the past, or an acquaintance from the Red Center.
tr: There is hardly anyone speaking, though there are whispers, and the women are turning their heads slyly from one side to the other: this is a place of commerce, a place where you might see someone you know, from before or from the Red Center.
es: Practically no one speaks, but there is a murmur and the women furtively move their heads, looking from side to side. It is at these moments, while shopping, that you might see someone you know from the old days, or from the Red Center.

en: Just to catch sight of a face like that is an encouragement.
vi: Just seeing a familiar face was a great encouragement.
tr: Even catching a glimpse of a familiar face is encouraging.
es: Just the sight of one of those faces would be exhilarating.

en: If I could see Moira, just see her, know she still exists.
vi: If only I could see Moira, just see her, know that she still existed.
tr: Oh, if only I could see Moira, just see her, know that she still exists.
es: If I could see Moira, just see her, know that she still exists...

en: It's hard to imagine now,having a friend
vi: It's really hard to imagine that now - having a friend?
tr: Now, it is very difficult to even imagine having a friend.
es: Now it is hard to remember what it means to have a friend.

en: But Ofglen, beside me, isn't looking, Maybe she doesnt know anyone
vi: But Ofglen, beside me, does not look around.
tr: But Gleninki, next to me, is not looking around.
es: But Deglen, who is next to me, does not look.

en: anymore.
vi: Maybe she doesn't know anyone anymore.
tr: Maybe he doesn't recognize anyone anymore.
es: Perhaps she no longer knows anyone.

en: Maybe they have all vanish, the women she knew.
vi: Maybe they have all disappeared, all the women she used to know.
tr: Maybe all the women he knew are gone.
es: Maybe all the women she knew have disappeared.

en: Or maybe she doesn't want to be see.
vi: Or maybe she doesn't want to be seen by anyone.
tr: Or maybe he doesn't want to be seen.
es: Maybe she doesn't want to be seen.

en: She stands in silence head down.
vi: She stands silently, head bowed down.
tr: He stands silently, head bowed.
es: Remain silent, with your head down.

en: As we wait in our double line, the door opens and two more women
vi: While standing in a double line like that, the door opened to let in two more people, both dressed in red and white Tùy female attire.
tr: While we are waiting in our double line, the door opens and two more women enter, both dressed in the red dresses and white wings of the Handmaids.
es: While we wait in double file, the door opens and two other women enter, both dressed in red and wearing the white bonnet of the Handmaids.

en: come in, both in the red dresses and white wings of the Handmaids.
vi: While standing in a double line like that, the door opened to let in two more people, both dressed in red and white Tùy female attire.
tr: While we are waiting in our double line, the door opens and two more women enter, both dressed in the red dresses and white wings of the Handmaids.
es: While we wait in double file, the door opens and two other women enter, both dressed in red and wearing the white bonnet of the Handmaids.

en: One of them is vastly pregnant; her belly, under her loose garment, swells triumphantly.
vi: One of the two was heavily pregnant; her belly, under the loose-fitting clothes, proudly protruded.
tr: One of them is heavily pregnant, her belly prominently swollen under her loose dress.
es: One of them is pregnant; her belly, under the loose clothes, protrudes triumphantly.

en: There is a shifting in the room, a murmur, an escape of breath; despite ourselves we turn our heads, blatantly, to see better; our fingersitch to touch her.
vi: The whole room stirred slightly, there were murmurs, and sighs; even though we didn't want to, we all turned around, conspicuously, to get a clearer look; our itchy fingers just waiting to reach out and touch.
tr: There is a stir in the room, a whispering, a collective exhale; involuntarily, we turn our heads, roughly, to see better; our fingers itch to touch her.
es: There is a stir in the room, a whisper is heard, some sighs; much to our dismay, we turn our heads shamelessly to get a better look.

en: She's a magic presence to us, an object of envy and desire, we covet her.
vi: She was truly a marvel, an object of envy and desire, we looked at her longingly.
tr: To us, she is a magical being, an object of envy and desire, we envy her.
es: We feel an enormous desire to touch her. To us, she is a magical presence, an object of envy and desire, of covetousness.

en: She's a flag on a hilltop, showing us what can still be done: we too can be saved.
vi: She was the flag planted on the hilltop, showing everyone the way out: even we could be saved.
tr: She is the flag on the peak, showing us what can still be done: we too can be saved.
es: She is like a flag on the top of a mountain, the proof that something can still be done: we too can save ourselves.

en: The women in the room are whispering, almost talking, so great is their excitement.
vi: All the women in the room were whispering, almost loudly, how excited they were.
tr: The women in the room are whispering, almost talking, their excitement is so great.
es: The excitement is such that the women whisper, almost converse.

en: "Who is it?" I hear behind me.
vi: "Who is that?" I heard a voice behind me.
tr: “Who is it?” I hear being said behind me.
es: —Who is it? —I hear them ask behind me.

en: "Ofwayne.
vi: "Ofwayne.
tr: "Where are you?" "Here."
es: —Dewayne.

en: No. Ofwarren."
vi: But no. Ofwarren."
tr: "Where are you, Warren?""
es: No. Dewarren.

en: "Showoff," a voice hisses, and this is true.
vi: “Show-off,” a hiss sounded, and indeed it was.
tr: “Show-off,” hisses a voice, and it's true.
es: —How she shows off —someone murmurs, and it's true.

en: A woman that pregnant doesn't have to go out, doesn't have to go shopping.
vi: A pregnant woman this month shouldn't go out, shouldn't go shopping anymore.
tr: A woman whose pregnancy is this advanced doesn't need to go out or do shopping.
es: A pregnant woman is not obligated to go out or go shopping.

en: The daily walk is no longer prescribed, to keep her abdominal muscles in working order.
vi: Nor is she required to take daily walks, which were meant to keep her abdominal muscles functioning normally.
tr: Daily walks are no longer necessary for her abdominal muscles to work well.
es: The daily walk is no longer mandatory, to maintain the proper functioning of her abdominal muscles.

en: She needs only the floor exercises, the breathing drill.
vi: She only needs free exercises, breathing exercises.
tr: She only needs floor exercises, breathing exercises.
es: She only needs normal exercises and breathing exercises.

en: She could stay at her house.
vi: She can stay at home.
tr: She could stay at home.
es: She could stay at home.

en: And it's dangerous for her to be out, there must be a Guardian standing outside the door, waiting for her.
vi: Not to mention going out is very dangerous, there must be guards waiting for her out there.
tr: Besides, being outside is dangerous for her; there should be a Guardian waiting outside the door.
es: In reality, it is dangerous for her to go out, and there is always a Guardian waiting for her by the door.

en: Now that she's the carrier of life, she is closer to death, and needs special security.
vi: Now carrying a life within her, she is closer to death, and needs a special security regime.
tr: Now that she is a life carrier, she is closer to death and needs special protection.
es: Now that she is carrying a new life, she is closer to death and needs special protection.

en: Jealousy could get her, it's happened before.
vi: She could be a victim of jealousy, this has happened before.
tr: Jealousy can reach her; it has happened before.
es: She could become jealous, which has happened in other cases.

en: All children are wanted now, but not by everyone.
vi: Every child now is born out of desire, but not everyone's desire.
tr: Now all children are wanted, but not by everyone.
es: Now all children are wanted, but not by everyone.

en: But the walk may be a whim of hers, and they humor whims, when something has gone this far and there's been no miscarriage.
vi: But today's trip might be an unusual whim, and people are easily forgiving of such whims when they have maintained this level without falling.
tr: However, this walk might be one of her whims, they yield to whims when pregnancy is this advanced and there is no miscarriage.
es: But the walk can be a craving, and if there hasn't been a miscarriage and the pregnancy has reached this point, they like to satisfy the cravings.

en: Or perhaps she's one of those, Pile it on, I can take it, a martyr.
vi: Or maybe she belongs to that type. Pour some more, I can handle it, a martyr.
tr: Or maybe she is one of them, Load more, I can carry; a martyr.
es: Or maybe she is one of those who love to say: Make a pile, and I'll take it, in other words, a martyr.

en: I catch a glimpse of her face, as she raises it to look around.
vi: I caught a glimpse of her face when she looked up and around.
tr: When she lifts her head to look around, I see her face for a moment.
es: She looks around and I manage to see her face.

en: The voice behind me was right.
vi: The person standing behind me was right.
tr: The voice behind me was right.
es: The one who was murmuring was right: she has come to show off; she is brimming with health and enjoys every minute.

en: She's come here to display herself.
vi: She came here to show off.
tr: She came to show herself.
es: The one who was murmuring was right: she has come to show off; she is brimming with health and enjoys every minute.

en: She's glowing, rosy, she's enjoying every minute of this.
vi: She was radiant, rosy, savoring every little detail.
tr: She blushes bright pink, enjoying every moment of it.
es: The one who was murmuring was right: she has come to show off; she is brimming with health and enjoys every minute.

en: "Quiet," says one of the Guardians behind the counter, and we hush like schoolgirls.
vi: "Order," a Guard behind the counter said, and we shushed each other like a bunch of schoolchildren.
tr: "Silence," says one of the Guards behind the counter, and we fall silent like schoolgirls.
es: —Silence —says one of the Guardians from behind the counter, and we fall silent like schoolgirls.

en: Ofglen and I have reached the counter.
vi: Ofglen and I arrived at the counter.
tr: Gleninki and I reached the counter.
es: Deglen and I have reached the counter.

en: We hand over our tokens, and one Guardian enters the numbers on them into the Compubite while the other gives us our purchases, the milk, the eggs.
vi: We handed over the vouchers, and a Guardian entered the numbers into the computer while the other handed over the goods: milk, eggs.
tr: We hand over our ration cards and while one Guard gives us the milk and eggs we requested, the other enters the numbers into the Compubite.
es: We hand over the vouchers and one of the Guardians records a number on them with the Compuperfo, while the other gives us our purchase, the milk and the eggs.

en: We put them into our baskets and go out again, past the pregnant woman and her partner, who beside her looks spindly, shrunken; as we all do.
vi: We put everything into the basket and went out again, past the pregnant woman and her companion, standing there tall and gaunt, like everyone else.
tr: We put what we received into our baskets and go back outside, passing by the pregnant woman and her partner, next to the woman who is hunched over like a stork; just like all of us.
es: We put them in our baskets and go back out, passing by the pregnant woman and her companion who, compared to the first, looks scrawny and wrinkled... just like all of us.

en: The pregnant woman's belly is like a huge fruit.
vi: The pregnant belly looked like a giant fruit.
tr: The pregnant woman's belly looks like a very large fruit.
es: The belly of a pregnant woman is like an immense fruit.

en: Humungous,
vi: Huge, a phrase from my childhood.
tr: Humungous, a word from my childhood.
es: Somoflafla, a word from my childhood.

en: word of my childhood.
vi: Huge, a phrase from my childhood.
tr: Humungous, a word from my childhood.
es: Somoflafla, a word from my childhood.

en: Her hands rest on it as if to defend it, or as if they're gathering something from it, warmth and strength.
vi: Her hand rested on her belly as if to protect it, yet also as if to receive from it, warmth and strength.
tr: Her hands rest on her belly, as if she wants to protect it or gather something from it, warmth and strength, perhaps.
es: She rests her hands on him, as if she wanted to defend him, or as if she were seeking warmth and strength within herself.

en: As I pass she looks full at me, into my eyes, and I know who she; is.
vi: When I walked past her, she looked straight at me, right into my eyes, and I recognized her.
tr: As she walks by, she looks directly into my eyes, and I remember who she is.
es: When I pass by, she looks me directly in the eyes, and then I recognize her.

en: She was at the Red Center with me, one of Aunt Lydia's pets.
vi: She was also at the Red Center with me, one of Aunt Lydia's pets.
tr: We were together at the Red Center, she was one of Aunt Lydia's favorites.
es: She was with me in the Red Center, she was one of Aunt Lydia's favorites.

en: I never liked her.
vi: I never liked her.
tr: I never liked her.
es: I never liked her.

en: Her name, in the time before, was Janine.
vi: Her name, back then, was Janine.
tr: In the previous time, her name was Janine.
es: In those times, her name was Janine.

en: Janine looks at me, then, and around the corners of her mouth there is the trace of a smirk.
vi: Janine looked at me, like that, and a sneer flickered at the corner of her mouth.
tr: Janine is looking at me and the lines of a smirk are forming at the corners of her mouth.
es: Janine looks at me and an affected smile appears at the corners of her lips.

en: She glances down to where my own belly lies flat under my red robe, and the wings cover her face.
vi: She slid her eyes down to my flat stomach under the red dress, then the wings obscured her face.
tr: She is looking at the place where my stomach remains flat under the dress and the wings are covering my face.
es: She lowers her gaze to my belly—a board beneath the red suit—and touches it, covering her face.

en: I can see only a little of her forehead, and the pinkish tip of her nose.
vi: I could only see the top of her forehead, and the tip of her pink nose.
tr: I can only see a small part of her forehead and the pinkish tip of her nose.
es: I can only see a small piece of his forehead and the pink tip of his nose.

en: Next we go into All Flesh, which is marked by a large wooden pork chop hanging from two chains.
vi: Next, we entered the Meat Market, signaled by a large wooden slab of ribs hanging down from two chains.
tr: Our next stop is Bilumum Etler, whose sign consists of a large wooden pork chop hanging from two chains.
es: Then we enter All Meat, marked with a huge pork chop hanging from two chains.

en: There isn't so much of a line here: meat is expensive, and even the Commanders don't have it every day.
vi: The line here wasn't too long: meat is always expensive, and even the commanders can't afford to eat it every day.
tr: There isn't such a long queue here; meat is expensive. Even the commanders can't get it every day.
es: There isn't much of a line here: meat is expensive and even Commanders can't eat it every day.

en: Ofglen gets steak, though, and that's the second time this week.
vi: But Ofglen still got some roast meat, and this is the second time this week.
tr: Gleninki is getting steak, though, for the second time this week.
es: However —and this is the second time this week—, Deglen picks up steaks.

en: I'll tell that to the Marthas: it's the kind of thing they enjoy hearing about.
vi: I'll tell the Marthas: they always like to hear such things.
tr: I'll tell the Marthas about this. This is the kind of thing they like to hear.
es: I'll tell the Marthas: this is the kind of comment they love to hear.

en: They are very interested in how other households are run; such bits of petty gossip give them an opportunity for pride or discontent.
vi: They are very eager to find out how other households live; these small bits of gossip give them a chance to feel either proud or offended..
tr: They are very interested in how things are run in other households; these kinds of trivial gossip pieces give them a chance to feel pride or discontent.
es: They are extremely interested in knowing how the other houses manage; these trivial gossip give them the opportunity to feel proud or disgusted.

en: I take the chicken, wrapped in butcher's paper and trussed with string.
vi: I received the chicken, wrapped in parchment paper and tied with string.
tr: I'm taking the chicken wrapped in butcher paper and tied with string.
es: I grab the chicken, wrapped in paraffin paper and tied with a string.

en: Not many things are plastic, anymore.
vi: Plastic items are rarely seen, not seen anymore.
tr: There isn't much left that's plastic anymore.
es: There aren't many plastic things left anymore.

en: I remember those endless white plastic shopping bags, from the supermarket; I hated to wastethem and would stuff them in under the sink, until the day would come when there would be too many and I would open the cupboard door and they would bulge out, sliding over the floor.
vi: I remember the large bottomless white plastic bags used to carry groceries from the supermarket; I never wanted to throw them away, always stuffing them under the sink, until one day when I opened the cabinet door and they spilled out, scattered all over the floor.
tr: I remember the endless white plastic shopping bags from the supermarket; I hated throwing them away and would stuff them under the sink until the days when they multiplied so much that they would burst out and scatter all over the floor when I opened the cabinet door.
es: I remember those white plastic bags they used to give out at supermarkets; how I hated wasting them, I would pile them up under the sink until there came a point when there were so many that when you opened the cabinet door, they would slip to the floor.

en: Luke used to complain about it.
vi: Luke always complained about that.
tr: Luke used to complain about this.
es: Luke used to complain and every now and then he would take them all out and throw them away.

en: Periodically he would take all the bags and throw them out.
vi: He regularly gathered all the bags and threw them away.
tr: He would periodically gather all the bags and throw them out.
es: Luke used to complain and every now and then he would take them all out and throw them away.

en: She could get one of those over her head, he'd say.
vi: He could put one on his head, that's what you'll say.
tr: The girl could take one of these and put it on her head, she would say.
es: She could grab one and put it on her head, she warned me.

en: You know how kids like to play.
vi: You know how kids like to play.
tr: You know how much children love to play.
es: You know the things children do when they play.

en: She never would, I'd say.
vi: No, I say.
tr: She would never do that, I would say.
es: She would never do that, I told her.

en: She's too old.
vi: He's grown up.
tr: She's grown up now.
es: She's grown up now.

en: (Or too smart, or too lucky.)
vi: (Or smart, or very lucky.)
tr: (Or very smart or very lucky.)
es: (Or intelligent, or lucky.)

en: But I would feel a chill of fear, and then guilt for having been so careless.
vi: But I'll get chills down my spine, and blame myself for being careless.
tr: But I would shiver with fear, and then feel guilty for being so careless.
es: But she felt a chill, and then guilt for having been so reckless.

en: Itwas true, I took too much for granted; I trusted fate, back then.
vi: Indeed, I put too much faith in the constants; I even believed in fate, back in the day.
tr: It was true, I used to accept many things as they were; I trusted fate back then.
es: It was true, I took everything for granted, in those days I relied on luck.

en: I'll keep them in a higher cupboard, I'd say.
vi: Then I say, you'll put it on the top shelf.
tr: I will store them in a higher cabinet, I would say.
es: I'll store them in a higher cabinet, she said.

en: Don't keep them at all, he'd say.
vi: Then you say, don't put it away anymore.
tr: Never store them, she would say.
es: Don't store them, Luke repeated.

en: We never use them for anything.
vi: We never use it anyway.
tr: We don't use them for anything.
es: We never used them.

en: Garbage bags, I'd say.
vi: Then I say, here's the trash bag.
tr: Garbage bags, I would say.
es: As garbage bags, I insisted, and he would tell me...

en: He'd say
vi: Then you say...
tr: And she would say...
es: As garbage bags, I insisted, and he would tell me...

en: Not here and now.
vi: Not now, not here.
tr: It cannot be here and now.
es: Not here.

en: Not where people are looking.
vi: Not in the middle of everyone watching.
tr: It cannot be in a place where people are watching.
es: People are watching.

en: I turn, see my silhouette in the plate glass window.
vi: I turned around, seeing my reflection in the window glass.
tr: I turn around, I see my silhouette in the monolithic glass display.
es: I turn around and see my silhouette in the store window.

en: We have come outside, then, we are on the street.
vi: We had made it outside, that's right, we had made it to the street.
tr: So we have gone outside, we are on the street.
es: So we went out, we are on the street...

en: A group of people is coming towards us.
vi: A group of people is heading towards us.
tr: A group of people is coming towards us.
es: A group of people approaches us.

en: They're tourists, from Japan it looks like, a trade delegation perhaps, on a tour of the historic landmarks or out for local color.
vi: A group of foreign tourists, seemingly from Japan, perhaps a trade delegation, touring historical sites or just out to breathe in the local atmosphere.
tr: Tourists, apparently from Japan, perhaps a trade delegation, on a historical sites tour or exploring local life.
es: They are tourists, they seem to be from Japan, perhaps part of a commercial delegation, and they are visiting historical sites or admiring the local color.

en: They're diminutive and neatly turned out; each has his or her camera, his or her smile.
vi: They are petite and well-groomed, each holding their own camera, each wearing their own smile.
tr: They stand out immediately because they are petite; each has their own camera, their own smile.
es: They are small and neatly dressed. Each one carries a camera and a smile.

en: They look around, bright-eyed, cocking their heads to one side like robins, their very cheerfulness aggressive, and I can't help staring.
vi: They look around, eyes bright, heads tilted to the side like a flock of robins; that sheer exuberance was provocative, and I couldn't help but stare.
tr: They are looking around, with bright eyes, lifting their heads like thrushes, with aggressive cheerfulness; I can't help but watch them.
es: They observe everything attentively, tilting their heads to one side, like robins; their joy is aggressive and I can't stand looking at them.

en: It's been a long time since I've seen skirts that short on women.
vi: It's been a long time since I've seen women wearing skirts that short.
tr: It's been a long time since I've seen women wearing such short skirts.
es: It had been a long time since I had seen women with skirts like these.

en: The skirts reach just below the knee and the legs come out from beneath them, nearly naked in their thin stockings, blatant, the high-heeled shoes with their straps attached to the feet like delicate instruments of torture.
vi: The skirts just barely reach past the knees, legs exposed below, stockings so thin they might as well be bare, shameless, wearing high-heeled shoes that cling to their feet like sophisticated torture devices.
tr: The skirt length is just below the knee, revealing their legs at the end, almost bare in thin stockings, daring, with high-heeled shoes tied to their feet like elegant torture devices.
es: They reach exactly below the knees, and beneath the skirts, their almost bare legs can be seen with those fine and striking stockings, and the high-heeled shoes with straps clinging to their feet like delicate instruments of torture.

en: The women teeter on their spiked feet as if on stilts, but off balance; their backs arch at the waist, thrusting the buttocks out.
vi: The women totter on their sharp-pointed feet as if on stilts, but without balance; their backs arch at the waist, causing their hips to jut out behind.
tr: The women are wobbling on their spiked shoes as if on stilts; their backs arched outward at the waist, pushing their hips out.
es: They sway, as if their feet were nailed to uneven stilts; their backs are arched at the waist and their buttocks are prominent.

en: Their heads are uncovered and their hair too is exposed, in all its darkness and sexuality.
vi: Their heads are uncovered and their hair is exposed, jet black and full of sensuality.
tr: The women's heads are uncovered, displaying their hair in all its blackness and sexuality.
es: They wear their heads uncovered and their hair loose in all its darkness and sexuality; their lips painted red, outlining the moist cavities of their mouths like the scribbles on the wall of a public restroom from another time.

en: They wear lipstick, red, outlining the damp cavities of their mouths, like scrawls on a washroom wall, of the time before.
vi: They wear lipstick, bright red, outlining the moist cavity of their mouths, like scribbles on the walls of public restrooms, from the old days.
tr: They have put on red lipstick, defining the moist hollows of their mouths, just like graffiti on a toilet wall from earlier times.
es: They wear their heads uncovered and their hair loose in all its darkness and sexuality; their lips painted red, outlining the moist cavities of their mouths like the scribbles on the wall of a public restroom from another time.

en: I stop walking.
vi: I stopped walking.
tr: I give up on walking.
es: I stop.

en: Ofglen stops beside me and I know that she too cannot take her eyes off these women.
vi: Beside me, Ofglen also stopped, and I knew she couldn't take her eyes off those women either.
tr: Glen's also stops beside me, and I know he can't take his eyes off these women either.
es: Deglen stands next to me, and I understand that she also can't take her eyes off those women.

en: We are fascinated, but also repelled.
vi: We were mesmerized, but also disgusted.
tr: We are mesmerized, but also disgusted.
es: They fascinate us and at the same time repulse us.

en: They seem undressed.
vi: They seemed almost naked.
tr: They are almost naked.
es: It seems as if they were naked.

en: It has taken so little time to change our minds, about things like this.
vi: It didn't take long for our minds to change about such things.
tr: It didn't take long for us to change our minds about these kinds of things.
es: How little time it has taken to change our mentality regarding these kinds of things.

en: Then I think: I used to dress like that.
vi: Then I thought: I used to dress like that too.
tr: Then I think: I used to dress like this too.
es: Then I think: I used to dress like that.

en: That was freedom.
vi: That's called freedom.
tr: This was freedom.
es: That was freedom.

en: Westernized, they used to call it.
vi: That's Westernization, they used to call it that.
tr: They used to call this Westernized in the past.
es: Westernization, they used to call it.

en: The Japanese tourists come towards us, twittering, and we turn our heads away too late: our faces have been seen.
vi: The group of Japanese tourists walked towards us, chatting animatedly, and we turned away but it was too late: our faces had already been seen.
tr: Japanese tourists are chirping as they come towards us, and we are too late to turn our heads in another direction: our faces have already been seen.
es: The Japanese tourists approach us, anxious; we turn our heads, but it is already too late: they have seen our faces.

en: There's an interpreter, in the standard blue suit and red-patterned tie, with the winged-eye tie pin.
vi: There was an interpreter among them, wearing the regulation blue suit with a red background tie, and a brooch shaped like a winged eye.
tr: There is a translator with them, dressed in a standard blue suit and red tie, with a tie pin featuring a winged eye.
es: They are accompanied by an interpreter, dressed in a classic blue suit and a red patterned tie with a wing-shaped pin.

en: He's the one who steps forward, out of the group, in front of us, blocking our way.
vi: He was the one who stepped forward, leaving the group, coming in front of us, blocking the way.
tr: He separates from the group and steps in front of us, blocking our path.
es: He takes a step forward, moving away from the group and blocking our way.

en: The tourists bunch behind him; one of them raises a camera.
vi: The tourists crowded behind, one person raised a camera.
tr: The tourists cluster behind him; one of them raises a camera.
es: The tourists crowd behind him; one of them raises a camera.

en: "Excuse me," he says to both of us, politely enough.
vi: "Excuse me," he said to both of us, quite politely.
tr: “Excuse me,” he says to both of us, politely enough.
es: —Excuse me —he says to us in a courteous tone—.

en: "They're asking if they can take your picture."
vi: "They want to ask if they can take a picture of you two."
tr: “They are asking if they can take a photo of you.”
es: They are asking if they can take a photo of you.

en: I look down at the sidewalk, shake my head for no.
vi: I cast my eyes down to the roadside, shaking my head to indicate refusal.
tr: I'm looking at the sidewalk and shaking my head to mean No.
es: I fix my gaze on the sidewalk and shake my head negatively.

en: What they must see is the white wings only, a scrap of face, my chinand part of my mouth.
vi: They only needed to see the white wings, a glimpse of my face, my chin, and a corner of my mouth.
tr: The only things they should see are the white wings, part of the face, my chin, and part of my mouth.
es: They should only see a fragment of my face, my chin and part of my mouth.

en: Not the eyes.
vi: Avoid eye contact.
tr: Never the eyes.
es: But not my eyes.

en: I know better than to look the interpreter in the face.
vi: I knew better than to look directly at the interpreter's face.
tr: I'm smart enough not to look at the translator's face.
es: I am very careful not to look the interpreter in the face.

en: Most of the interpreters are Eyes, or so it's said.
vi: Most interpreters are the Eyes, or at least that's the rumor.
tr: Most translators are Eyes or so it is said.
es: Most interpreters are Spies, or so the rumor goes.

en: I also know better than to say yes.
vi: I also know that it's wise not to say yes.
tr: I'm smart enough not to say yes.
es: I also take great care to say yes.

en: Modesty is invisibility, said Aunt Lydia.
vi: Humility must be invisible, Aunt Lydia said so.
tr: Aunt Lydia used to say that humility is invisibility.
es: Modesty and invisibility are synonyms, Aunt Lydia used to say.

en: Never forget it.
vi: Never forget.
tr: Never forget this.
es: Never forget it.

en: To be seento be seenis to beher voice trembledpenetrated.
vi: To be seen - to be seen - also means - her voice trembling - to be penetrated.
tr: To be seen - her voice trembled as she said it - is to be reachable.
es: If they see you —if they see you, it is as if they penetrate you, she said with a trembling voice.

en: What you must be, girls, is impenetrable.
vi: Your duty is not to be penetrated, girls.
tr: What you need to be, girls, is unreachable.
es: And you, girls, must be impenetrable.

en: She called us girls.
vi: She called us girls.
tr: She used to call us girls.
es: He called us girls.

en: Beside me, Ofglen is also silent.
vi: Beside me, Ofglen is also silent.
tr: Glen's is also silent beside me.
es: Deglen, who is beside me, also remains silent.

en: She's tucked her red-gloved hands up into her sleeves, to hide them.
vi: She has tucked her red-gloved hands into her sleeves to hide them.
tr: She has tucked her red-gloved hands into the sleeves of her dress to hide them.
es: He has hidden his gloved hands inside his sleeves.

en: The interpreter turns back to the group, chatters at them in stac cato.
vi: The interpreter returned to the group of guests, chatting with them rapidly, separating each syllable.
tr: The translator turns back to the group and chatters in short, broken sentences.
es: The interpreter turns towards the group and speaks haltingly.

en: I know what he'll be saying, I know the line.
vi: I knew what he was going to say, I had memorized the dialogue.
tr: I know what he's going to say, I know his line.
es: I know what he will be telling them, I know the drill.

en: He'll be telling them that the women here have different customs, that to stare at them through the lens of a camera is, for them, an experience of violation.
vi: He would tell them that the women here have different customs, that being looked at through a camera lens, for them, is a form of violation.
tr: He will explain that the women here have different traditions, and that looking at them through the lens of a camera would be considered, according to them, as an act of violation.
es: He will be telling them that the women here have different customs, that being observed through the lens of a camera is, for them, an experience of violation.

en: I'm looking down, at the sidewalk, mesmerized by the women's feet.
vi: I was still looking down, gazing at the roadside, mesmerized by the women's feet.
tr: I'm looking down at the sidewalk, hypnotized by the women's feet.
es: I still have my gaze fixed on the sidewalk, hypnotized by the women's feet.

en: One of them is wearing open-toed sandals, the toenails painted pink.
vi: There was a woman wearing open-toed sandals, her ten toenails painted pink.
tr: One of them is wearing sandals that leave her toes exposed, and her nails are painted pink.
es: One of them is wearing sandals that leave her toes in the open, and her nails are painted pink.

en: I remember the smell of nail polish, the way it wrinkled if you put the second coat on too soon, the satiny brushing of sheer pantyhose against the skin, the way the toes felt, pushed towards the opening in the shoe by the whole weight of the body.
vi: I still remember the smell of nail polish, remember how it would wrinkle if applied too hastily, remember the thin stockings brushing against the skin, glistening, remember the feeling on the toes when slipping into open-toed sandals under the weight of the whole body.
tr: I remember the smell of nail polish, how it wrinkles when you apply the second coat too early, the satiny touch of thin pantyhose, and what toes feel like when they are pushed into the openness of the shoe with the whole weight of the body.
es: I remember the smell of nail polish, and how it would wrinkle if you applied the second coat too soon, the satin texture of sheer stockings in contact with the skin, and the rubbing of toes pushed towards the shoe's opening by the weight of the entire body.

en: The woman with painted toes shifts from one foot to the other.
vi: The woman with painted toenails balanced her weight.
tr: The woman with the nail polish shifts her weight from one foot to the other.
es: The woman with the painted nails shifts her weight from one foot to the other.

en: I can feel her shoes, on my own feet.
vi: I could feel her sandals, right under my feet.
tr: I can feel her shoes on my own feet.
es: I almost feel her shoes on my own feet.

en: The smell of nail polish has made me hungry.
vi: The smell of nail polish made me hungry.
tr: The smell of the nail polish made me hungry.
es: The smell of nail polish has made me hungry.

en: "Excuse me," says the interpreter again, to catch our attention.
vi: “Excuse me,” the interpreter said again, to get our attention.
tr: “Excuse me,” says the translator again, to get our attention.
es: —Excuse me —says the interpreter again to get our attention.

en: I nod,
vi: I nodded, indicating that I heard.
tr: I nod to show that I heard him.
es: I nod, letting him know that I heard him—.

en: to show I've heard him.
vi: I nodded, indicating that I heard.
tr: I nod to show that I heard him.
es: I nod, letting him know that I heard him—.

en: "He asks, are you happy," says the interpreter.
vi: “He asked if you ladies are happy,” the interpreter said.
tr: “This man is asking if you are happy,” says the translator.
es: They ask if you are happy —he continues.

en: I can imagine it, their curiosity:
vi: I can imagine their curiosity: Are these ladies happy?
tr: I can imagine their curiosity: Are they happy?
es: I can imagine the curiosity of these people: Are they happy?

en: Are they happy?
vi: How can they still be happy?
tr: How can they be happy?
es: How can they be happy?

en: How can they be happy?
vi: How can they still be happy?
tr: How can they be happy?
es: How can they be happy?

en: I can feel their bright black eyes on us, the way they lean a little forward to catch our answers, the women especially, but the men too: we are secret, forbidden, we excite them.
vi: I could feel their bright black eyes scrutinizing me, see them leaning slightly forward to catch the answer, the women the most eager, but the men too: we are mysterious, forbidden, we are alluring.
tr: I can feel their dark open eyes on us, how they leaned in just a moment ago to catch our answers, especially the women, but also the men: We are a mystery to them, forbidden, something that excites them.
es: I feel their bright eyes on us, how they lean forward a bit to catch our response, especially the women, although the men too: we are a mystery, something forbidden, we excite them.

en: Ofglen says nothing.
vi: Ofglen said nothing.
tr: Gleninki doesn't say anything.
es: Deglen says nothing.

en: There is a silence.
vi: There was a long silence.
tr: Silence.
es: Silence reigns.

en: But sometimes it's as dangerous not to speak.
vi: But sometimes saying nothing is just as dangerous.
tr: But sometimes not speaking is equally dangerous.
es: But sometimes, not speaking is equally dangerous.

en: "Yes, we are very happy," I murmur.
vi: “Yes, we are very happy,” I said softly.
tr: “Yes, we are very happy,” I murmur.
es: —Yes, we are very happy —I murmur.

en: I have to say something.
vi: I had to say something.
tr: I have to say something.
es: I have to say something.

en: What else can I say?
vi: What else could I say?
tr: What else can I say?
es: What else can I say?
CHAPTER 6

en: A block past All Flesh, Ofglen pauses, as if hesitant about which way to go.
vi: Passing by a block of houses, Ofglen pauses, as if hesitating which way to go.
tr: After a block from Bilumum Etler, Gleninki pauses, as if unsure which way to go.
es: One block away from Todo Carne, Deglen stops, as if he couldn't decide which way to go.

en: We have a choice.
vi: We have two choices.
tr: We have an option.
es: We have two possibilities: go back in a straight line, or take a detour.

en: We could go straight back, or we could walk the long way around.
vi: We can go straight back, or take the longer route.
tr: We can either turn back directly or take the long way around.
es: We have two possibilities: go back in a straight line, or take a detour.

en: We already know which way we will take, because we always take it.
vi: We already know which way we'll go, because we always take that route.
tr: We already know which way we will prefer, because we always go that way.
es: We already know which one we will choose because it's the one we always take.

en: "I'd like to pass by the church," says Ofglen, as if piously.
vi: “I want to go by the church,” Ofglen said, looking very devout.
tr: “I would like to pass through the church,” says Gleninki, as if devout.
es: —I would like to stop by the church —announces Deglen in a pious tone.

en: "All right," I say, though I know as well as she does what she's really after.
vi: “Alright,” I said, even though we both knew exactly what the real reason was.
tr: “Okay,” I say, although I know just as well as he does what he is truly after.
es: —Agreed —I respond, although I know just as well as she does what she intends.

en: We walk, sedately.
vi: We walked in silence.
tr: We are walking, in tranquility.
es: We walked calmly.

en: The sun is out, in the sky there are white fluffy clouds, the kind that look like headless sheep.
vi: The sun had set, and in the sky, the white clouds looked like a flock of headless sheep.
tr: The sun has risen, there are white fluffy clouds in the sky, resembling headless sheep.
es: The sun has already set, and in the sky appear white, fleecy clouds, the kind that look like headless lambs.

en: Given our wings, our blinkers, it's hard to look up, hard to get the full view, of the sky, of anything.
vi: With wings like the blinders on a horse, it was very difficult for us to look up, to see the whole picture, the sky, and everything around us.
tr: With our wings, with our blinders, it is hard to look up, hard to see the sky, or anything completely.
es: With the headgear we wear —the blinkers— it is difficult to look up and have a complete view of the sky, or of anything.

en: But we can do it, a little at a time, a quick move of the head, up and down, to the side and back.
vi: But we still managed, piece by piece: quickly tilting our heads, up or down, to the sides.
tr: But we can do this for a moment, with a quick movement of the head up and down, sideways and backward.
es: But we manage it anyway, a little at a time, with a small movement of the head up and down, to one side and back.

en: We have learned to see the world in gasps.
vi: We had trained ourselves to view the world through many fleeting glimpses.
tr: We have learned to see the world in fleeting moments.
es: We have learned to see the world in fragments.

en: To the right, if you could walk along, there's a street that would take you down towards the river.
vi: On the right, if allowed to go, there is a street leading to the river.
tr: On the right, if you can walk, there is a street that will take you to the river.
es: To the right, a street opens up that goes down to the river.

en: There's a boathouse, where they kept the sculls once, and some bridges; trees, green banks, where you could sit and watch the water, and the young men with their naked arms, their oars lifting into the sunlight as they played at winning.
vi: There is a boathouse, a dock for double-oared racing boats, and in the past, there were even some cranes; trees, green grassy banks, where one could sit and watch the water flow, watch young men with bare arms, oars swinging in the sunlight as they competed for victory.
tr: There is a boathouse where once there were boats and a few bridges; also trees, green boats where you could watch bare-armed men lifting their oars towards the sun to win.
es: There is a shed —where they used to store the rowing boats—, the occasional bridge, trees, green hills where one could sit to watch the water or the young people with bare arms lifting their oars while racing.

en: On the way to the river are the old dormitories, used for something else now, with their fairy-tale turrets, painted white and gold and blue.
vi: The road to the river will pass by the old dormitory buildings, now used for other purposes, with round towers that look like something out of a fairy tale, painted white, yellow, and blue.
tr: On the way to the river, there are old student dormitories, now used for other purposes, with their fairy-tale towers, painted white, gold, and blue.
es: On the way to the river, you find the old dormitories —which are now used for something else—, with their fairy tale towers painted in white, gold, and blue.

en: When we
vi: When thinking about the past, we only choose to remember the beautiful things.
tr: The things we choose to remember from the past are the beautiful ones.
es: When we evoke the past, we choose the beautiful things.

en: think of the past it's the beautiful things we pick out.
vi: When thinking about the past, we only choose to remember the beautiful things.
tr: The things we choose to remember from the past are the beautiful ones.
es: When we evoke the past, we choose the beautiful things.

en: We want to believe it was all like that.
vi: We want to believe that everything was like that in the old days.
tr: We want to believe that everything was like this.
es: We like to believe that everything was like that.

en: The football stadium is that way too, where they hold the Men's
vi: The football field is also on that road, where the Men's Redemption sessions are held.
tr: The stadium where the Male Liberation Ceremonies are held is also there.
es: There is also the football stadium, where the Saviors of Men are hosted and where football matches are still played.

en: Salvagings.
vi: The football field is also on that road, where the Men's Redemption sessions are held.
tr: The stadium where the Male Liberation Ceremonies are held is also there.
es: There is also the football stadium, where the Saviors of Men are hosted and where football matches are still played.

en: As well as the football games.
vi: And also the football matches.
tr: Additionally, football matches are also held here.
es: There is also the football stadium, where the Saviors of Men are hosted and where football matches are still played.

en: They still have those.
vi: There is still football.
tr: They are still continuing these.
es: There is also the football stadium, where the Saviors of Men are hosted and where football matches are still played.

en: I don't go to the river anymore, or over bridges.
vi: I no longer go to the river, nor do I cross the bridge.
tr: I'm no longer going to the river or crossing the bridges.
es: Now I never go to the river nor walk across the bridges.

en: Or on the subway, although there's a station right there.
vi: I don't take the subway, even though there is one right over there.
tr: Or taking the metro, even though there's a station right there.
es: Nor to the subway, even though there is a station right there.

en: We're not allowed on, there are Guardians now, there's no official reason for us to go down those steps, ride on the trains under the river, into the main city.
vi: We are not allowed to board, now the train has guards, and there is no official reason for us to go down those steps, take the train under the river, and go into the city center.
tr: We are not allowed to use them anymore, there are Guards there now, because we have no official reason to descend these steps and take the trains under the river to the main city.
es: We are not allowed entry, now there are Guardians and there is no official reason for us to go down those stairs and travel on those trains, under the river and to the main city.

en: Why would we want to go from here to there?
vi: What would we want to go from here to there for?
tr: Why would we want to go from here to there?
es: Why would we want to go from here to there?

en: We would be up to no good and they would know it.
vi: It must be for a bad purpose, and they would know immediately.
tr: Our intentions couldn't be good, and they would understand that.
es: We could plot something bad, and they would find out.

en: The church is a small one, one of the first erected here, hundreds of years ago.
vi: The church is quite small, one of the first to be built, many hundreds of years ago.
tr: The church is small, one of the first built here, hundreds of years ago.
es: The church is small, one of the first that were erected here, hundreds of years ago.

en: It isn't used anymore, except as a museum.
vi: It no longer holds services, only serves as a museum, with many paintings inside, depicting women in somber long dresses, their hair wrapped in white scarves, and men standing upright, dressed in dark colors, with unsmiling mouths.
tr: It is no longer in use, except as a museum.
es: It is no longer in use, except as a museum.

en: Inside ityou can see paintings, of women in long somber dresses, their hair covered by white caps, and of upright men, darkly clothed and unsmiling.
vi: It no longer holds services, only serves as a museum, with many paintings inside, depicting women in somber long dresses, their hair wrapped in white scarves, and men standing upright, dressed in dark colors, with unsmiling mouths.
tr: Inside, you can see pictures of women dressed in long, somber dresses with their hair covered by white headscarves, and men standing rigidly in dark clothes, not smiling.
es: Inside, you can see paintings of women in long, languid dresses, adorned with white hats, and respectable men with serious faces, dressed in dark suits.

en: Our ancestors.
vi: Those are our ancestors.
tr: Our ancestors.
es: Our ancestors.

en: Admission is free.
vi: Free admission.
tr: Entrance is free.
es: Entrance is free.

en: We don't go in, though, but stand on the path, looking at the churchyard.
vi: But we did not go in, instead, we stood on the pathway, looking at the churchyard.
tr: We do not go inside, still standing on the path, looking at the church cemetery.
es: However, we did not enter; we stayed on the entrance path, contemplating the cemetery.

en: The old gravestones are still there, weathered, eroding, with their skulls and crossed bones, memento mori, their dough-faced angels, their winged hourglasses to remind us of the passing of mortal time, and, from a later century, their urns and willow trees, for mourning.
vi: The old tombstones were still there, dilapidated, eroded, skull and crossbones, memento mori, powdered-faced angels, winged hourglasses reminding us of the fleeting earthly time, and, in the later centuries, urns and weeping willows, serving as places to send grief and mourning.
tr: The old tombstones are still standing there, changed and worn by the weather, with their skulls and crossbones, memento mori, their dough-faced angels, winged hourglasses reminding us that mortal time has passed, and from a later century, urns and willow trees, for mourning.
es: The old tombstones still remain, deteriorated by the passage of time, eroded, with the sign of the skull and crossbones and the inscription "memento mori," with fickle-faced angels and winged hourglasses. —so that we remember how fleeting life is—, and the graves from a century later surrounded by willows as a sign of mourning.

en: They haven't fiddled with the gravestones, or the church either.
vi: They still haven't done anything to the tombstones, and the church as well.
tr: They neither touched the tombstones nor the church.
es: They haven't bothered to touch the tombstones or the church.

en: It's only the more recent history that offends them.
vi: Only the recent era has offended them.
tr: What disturbed them was more recent history.
es: What offends them is the more recent history.

en: Ofglen's head is bowed, as if she's praying.
vi: Ofglen bows her head, as if in prayer.
tr: Gleninki's head is bowed, as if she is praying.
es: Deglen has her head down, as if she were praying.

en: She does this every time.
vi: It's always the same.
tr: She does this every time.
es: She is always like this.

en: Maybe, I think, there's someone, someone in particular gone, for her too; a man, a child.
vi: Perhaps, I think, there is also someone, a special someone lost, in her memory; a man, or a child.
tr: Maybe, I think, there is someone, a special someone who is gone, for her: a man, a child.
es: It occurs to me that maybe she has also lost someone, a specific person, a man, a child.

en: But I can't entirely believe it.
vi: But I can't naively believe it.
tr: But I can't really believe it.
es: But I am not entirely convinced.

en: I think of her as a woman for whom every act is done for show, is acting rather than a real act.
vi: I think she is the type of person whose every move is a performance, every gesture calculated for effect.
tr: I think of her as a woman who does everything for show, acting more than behaving naturally.
es: I think of her as someone who acts to be seen, someone who is performing rather than truly acting.

en: She does such things to look good, I think.
vi: She does it for appearances, I think.
tr: I think she does these kinds of things to look good.
es: I get the impression that she does these things to seem good.

en: She's out to make the best of it.
vi: She is willing to exploit every gesture of hers.
