tr: She tries to make the most of them.
es: She is determined to conform.

en: But that is what I must look like to her, as well.
vi: But surely I am the same in her eyes.
tr: But I must appear this way to him as well.
es: But that must be the impression she has of me.

en: How can it be otherwise?
vi: How could it be any different?
tr: How could it be otherwise?
es: Could it be any different?

en: Now we turn our backs on the church and there is the thing we've in truth come to see: the Wall.
vi: Now we have turned our backs to the church and are facing what we truly came to visit:
tr: Now we turn our backs to the church and here it is, the thing we actually came to see: The Wall.
es: We turn our backs to the church; there is what we have actually come to see: the Wall.

en: The Wall is hundreds of years old too; or over n hundred, at least.
vi: The wall. The wall is also many hundreds of years old; or at least more than a hundred.
tr: The wall is also centuries old; or at least over a century.
es: The Wall is also hundreds of years old, or at least more than a century.

en: Like the sidewalks, it's red brick, and must once have been plain but handsome.
vi: Like the sidewalk, the wall is built of red bricks, and it must have been bare but beautiful in the past.
tr: Like the sidewalks, it is made of red brick, once simple yet beautiful.
es: Like the sidewalks, it is made of red bricks, and it must have once been simple, yet beautiful.

en: Now the gates have sentries and there are ugly new floodlights mounted on metal posts above it, and barbed wire along the bottom and broken glass set in concrete along the lop,
vi: Now the gates have guards and newly installed floodlights, ugly, on high iron posts, barbed wire running along the base of the wall, and broken glass embedded in the cement layer on top.
tr: Now there are guards at the doors and ugly new spotlights have been installed with metal supports on top; barbed wire runs along the wall and broken glass embedded in concrete on top.
es: Now the gates are guarded by sentinels, and above them there are horrible spotlights mounted on metal poles, barbed wire at the bottom, and shards of glass at the top.

en: No one goes through those gates willingly.
vi: No one enters through these gates without permission.
tr: No one enters through these doors willingly.
es: Nobody crosses these doors voluntarily.

en: the precautions are for those trying to get out, though to make it even as far as the Wall, from the inside, past the electronic alarm system, would be next to impossible.
vi: The precautionary measures are to prevent those who want to escape, even though reaching the Wall from the inside, bypassing the electronic alarm system, is almost impossible.
tr: The precautions are for those trying to get out; although, getting past the electronic alarm system and reaching the Wall from the inside is beyond impossible.
es: The precautions exist for those who try to leave, although reaching the Wall from the inside and avoiding the electronic alarm would be almost impossible.

en: Beside the main gateway there are six more bodies hanging, by the necks, their hands tied in front of them, their heads in white bags tipped sideways onto their shoulders.
vi: By the main gate, there are six more bodies swaying, ropes around their necks, hands tied together in front of their bellies, heads wrapped in white bags lolling to the side over their shoulders.
tr: Six more bodies are hanging by their necks next to the main door; their hands tied in front of them, their heads resting on their shoulders inside white bags.
es: Next to the main entrance, there are six other horns hanging from the neck, with their hands tied in front and their heads wrapped in white bags tied above the shoulders.

en: There must have been a Men's Salvaging early this morning.
vi: There must have been a Men's Salvaging this morning.
tr: The Men's Salvation Ceremony must have been held early this morning.
es: Early this morning, they must have performed a Men's Salvage.

en: I didn't hear the bells.
vi: I didn't hear the bells.
tr: I didn't hear the bells.
es: I didn't hear the bells.

en: Perhaps I've become used to them.
vi: Probably because I'm used to it by now.
tr: Maybe I've gotten used to them.
es: Maybe I've already gotten used to them.

en: We stop, together as if on signal, and stand and look at the bodies.
vi: We stopped, all at once, as if on command, and stood still looking up at the bodies.
tr: As if on a signal, we stand together and look at the bodies.
es: We stop at the same time, as if responding to a signal, and we stand looking at the bodies.

en: It doesn't matter if we look.
vi: There's no harm in looking.
tr: There is no harm in looking.
es: It doesn't matter that we look.

en: We're supposed to look: this is what they are there for, hanging on the Wall.
vi: In fact, we need to look: they are hung here, on this Wall, precisely for that reason.
tr: In fact, we are expected to do so: that is why they are there, hanging on the wall.
es: We can do it: that's what they're there for, hanging from the Wall.

en: Sometimes they'll be there for days, until there's a new batch, so as many people as possible will have the chanceto see them.
vi: Sometimes they stay here for several days, until a new batch arrives, so that as many people as possible have the chance to see them.
tr: Sometimes they stay there for days, until a new group arrives, so that as many people as possible have a chance to see them.
es: Sometimes they are there for entire days —until a new batch arrives—, so that as many people as possible can see them.

en: What they are hanging from is hooks.
vi: The bodies hung on hooks.
tr: They are hanging on hooks.
es: They are hung from hooks; the hooks have been forged with the brickwork of the Wall for this purpose.

en: The hooks have been set into the brickwork of the Wall, for this purpose.
vi: Hooks were added to the brick layer of the Wall specifically for this purpose.
tr: The hooks were placed on the bricks of the Wall for this purpose.
es: They are hung from hooks; the hooks have been forged with the brickwork of the Wall for this purpose.

en: Not all of them are occupied.
vi: There are still empty hooks.
tr: Not all of them are full.
es: Not all of them are occupied.

en: The hooks look like appliances for the armless.
vi: The hooks look like aids for amputees.
tr: The hooks resemble prosthetics made for those without arms.
es: They look like grappling hooks, or question marks laid on their side.

en: Or steel question marks, upside-down and sideways.
vi: Or like inverted, horizontal steel question marks.
tr: Or like steel question marks, inverted and tilted.
es: They look like grappling hooks, or question marks laid on their side.

en: It's the bags over the heads that are the worst, worse than the faces themselves would be.
vi: It is the head-wrapping bags that are the most terrifying, even more so than the faces hidden inside.
tr: The worst are the bags over their heads, worse than the shapes their faces could take.
es: The worst of all are the bags that wrap around the heads, even worse than the faces themselves would be.

en: It makes the men like dolls on which the faces have not yet been painted; like scarecrows, which in a way is what they are, since they are meant to scare.
vi: They make these people look like faceless dolls; like scarecrows, which in a way they are, as they are placed here to instill fear.
tr: The men's faces resemble unpainted dolls; like scarecrows, in a way, because their purpose is to frighten.
es: With them, the men look like dolls that haven't had their faces painted yet; or scarecrows, which in a way is what they are, because they are placed to scare away.

en: Or as if their heads are sacks, stuffed with some undifferentiated material, like flour or dough.
vi: Or as if their heads were just bags, stuffed with some soft, fluffy substance, like flour or dough.
tr: Or their heads are like sacks filled with an indistinguishable material, like flour or dough.
es: It's as if their heads were sacks filled with some undifferentiated material, like flour or paste.

en: It's the obvious heaviness of the heads, their vacancy, the way gravity
vi: That's because of the palpable weight of the heads, the emptiness, the weight pulling them down without the life to hold them upright.
tr: The distinct weight, the emptiness of the heads, is created by gravity pulling them down, there is no vital force to keep them upright anymore.
es: It's the obvious heaviness of the heads, their emptiness, the way they hang down due to the force of gravity and the fact that there is no longer life within them to hold them up.

en: pulls them down and there's no life anymore to hold them up.
vi: That's because of the palpable weight of the heads, the emptiness, the weight pulling them down without the life to hold them upright.
tr: The distinct weight, the emptiness of the heads, is created by gravity pulling them down, there is no vital force to keep them upright anymore.
es: It's the obvious heaviness of the heads, their emptiness, the way they hang down due to the force of gravity and the fact that there is no longer life within them to hold them up.

en: The heads are zeros.
vi: These heads are zeros.
tr: These heads are zero.
es: They are like zeros.

en: Though if you look and look, as we are doing, you can see the outlines of the features under the white cloth, like gray shadows.
vi: Even if you look for a long time, as we are doing here, you can still distinguish the faint outlines behind the white cloth, like gray shadows.
tr: If you look repeatedly like we did, you can see the outlines of faces under the white cloth, like gray shadows.
es: However, looking very carefully, like us, you can see the outline of the features under the white cloth, like gray shadows.

en: The heads are the heads of snowmen, with the coal eyes and the carrot noses fallen out.
vi: Their heads are like snowmen's heads, when the coal eyes and carrot nose have fallen off.
tr: The heads are the heads of snowmen with fallen coal eyes and carrot noses.
es: They look like the head of a snowman, with the coal eyes and the carrot nose fallen; and the head is melting.

en: The heads are melting.
vi: These heads are melting.
tr: The heads are melting.
es: They look like the head of a snowman, with the coal eyes and the carrot nose fallen; and the head is melting.

en: But on one bag there's blood, which has seeped through the white cloth, where the mouth must have been.
vi: But on one bag, there was blood, seeping through the white fabric, where the mouth should be.
tr: However, in the place where the mouth should be, there is a bloodstain that has seeped through the white fabric on one of the bags.
es: But in one of the bags, there is blood that has seeped through the white fabric, where the mouth should be.

en: It makes another mouth, a small red one, like the mouths painted with thick brushes by kindergarten children.
vi: It outlined a second mouth, a small red one, as if a group of kindergarten children had used a thick marker to color it in.
tr: It forms another mouth, a small red mouth, like the mouths painted with thick brushes by kindergarten children.
es: The blood forms another mouth, small and red like the one a kindergarten child would paint with a thick brush.

en: A child's idea of a smile.
vi: The concept of a childlike smile.
tr: A child's conception of a smile.
es: The idea a child has of a smile.

en: This smile of blood is what fixes the attention, finally.
vi: This blood-red smiling mouth is what ultimately catches the eye.
tr: In the end, it is this smile made of blood that draws attention.
es: Finally, attention is fixed on this bloody smile.

en: These are not snowmen after all.
vi: After all, it is not a snowman.
tr: These are not snowmen, after all.
es: After all, they are not snowmen.

en: The men wear white coats, like those worn by doctors or scientists.
vi: These people are wearing white coats, like doctors or scientists.
tr: The men are in white coats, just like the kind doctors or scientists wear.
es: The men wear white coats, like those worn by doctors or scientists.

en: Doctors and scientists aren't the only ones, there are others, but they must have had a run on them this morning.
vi: It's not just doctors and scientists, there are others too, but surely there was a purge of them this morning.
tr: It's not just doctors and scientists who are hanged here, there are others too, but they must have caught these ones this morning.
es: They are not always doctors and scientists, there are others too, but they must have taken them out this morning.

en: Each has a placard hung around his neck to show why he has been executed: a drawing of a human fetus.
vi: A sign hangs around each person's neck indicating the crime for which they are being judged: a drawing of a human fetus.
tr: Each one has a placard around their neck showing why they were executed: a drawing of a fetus.
es: Each one has a sign hanging from their neck, explaining why they were executed: the drawing of a fetus.

en: They were doctors, then, in the time before, when such things were legal.
vi: So they are doctors, from the past, back when those things were still legal.
tr: So they were doctors, in the past, when this kind of procedure was legal.
es: They were doctors in those times, when these things were legal.

en: Angel makers, they used to call them; or was that something else?
vi: The creators of Angels, they were called that, or something else?
tr: They were called angel makers: or was it something else?
es: Angel makers, they used to call them, or could it have been something else?

en: They've been turned up now by searchs through hospital records, or, ormore likely, since most hospitals destroyed such records once it became clear what was going to happenby informants: ex-nurses perhaps, or a pair of them, since evidence from a single woman is no longer admissible; or another doctor, hoping to save his own skin; or someone already accused, lashing out at an enemy, or at random, in some desperate bid for safety.
vi: Now they are brought to light thanks to investigations in hospital records, or - more likely, since most hospitals destroyed all such documents as soon as people realized what was about to happen - thanks to informants: a former nurse, for example, or rather two, since now the testimony of a single woman is no longer accepted; or another doctor, trying to save their own life; or someone already convicted, throwing out the name of an old enemy, or randomly naming someone else, desperately bargaining for safety.
tr: Now they've been uncovered during the examination of hospital records or, more accurately, when it was understood what would happen, since most hospitals destroyed these records, by informers: perhaps an old nurse or two nurses, because the testimony of a single woman is no longer accepted; maybe another doctor hoping to save themselves or someone already accused, betraying an enemy or making a desperate attempt for their own safety.
es: They have been discovered now, by checking hospital records, or —which seems more likely since, when it became clear what was going to happen, almost all hospitals destroyed that type of record— by interrogating informants: perhaps a former nurse, or a couple of them, because the testimony of a single woman is no longer accepted; or some other doctor who wanted to save his own skin; or someone who had already been accused, to harm his enemy, or at random, in a desperate attempt to save himself

en: Though informants are not always pardoned.
vi: Although informants are not always granted clemency.
tr: Though informers are not always forgiven.
es: But informants are not always pardoned According to what we have been told, these men are like war criminals.

en: These men, we've been told, are like war criminals.
vi: Those people, we were taught, are like war criminals.
tr: We were told that these men were like war criminals.
es: But informants are not always pardoned According to what we have been told, these men are like war criminals.

en: It's no excuse that what they did was legal at the time: their crimes are retroactive.
vi: It cannot be excused that what they did was legal at the time: this criminal regulation has retroactive effect.
tr: The fact that what they did was legal at the time could not be considered an excuse: their crimes concern both the past and the present.
es: The fact that their actions were legal at that time is no excuse: their crimes have retroactive effect.

en: They have committed atrocities and must be made into examples, for the rest.
vi: They did immoral things and must be made an example of, for the rest.
tr: They did evil and should serve as an example to the rest.
es: They committed atrocities, and they must serve as an example to others.

en: Though this is hardly needed.
vi: Though it's not much needed.
tr: Though this may not be very necessary.
es: Although it is practically unnecessary

en: No woman in her right mind, these days, would seek to prevent a birth, should she be solucky as to conceive.
vi: Women, these days, no one in their right mind would try to avoid childbirth - assuming she is lucky enough to conceive.
tr: Nowadays, no sane woman who has had the chance to conceive would try to prevent a birth.
es: In these times, no woman in her right mind would try to prevent the birth of a child, if she were so fortunate as to conceive one.

en: What we are supposed to feel towards these bodies is hatred and scorn.
vi: In front of those corpses, they wanted us to feel hatred and contempt.
tr: The expected feelings towards these bodies are hatred and anger.
es: We are supposed to feel hatred and contempt for those corpses.

en: This isn't what I feel.
vi: That was not how I felt.
tr: However, I do not feel these.
es: But that is not what I feel.

en: These bodies hanging on the Wall are time travelers, anachronisms.
vi: The corpses on the Wall were those who transcended time, lost from another era.
tr: The bodies hanging on the wall are time travelers, mistakes of history.
es: These bodies hanging from the Wall are time travelers, anachronisms.

en: They've come here from the past.
vi: They came here from the past.
tr: They came here from the past.
es: They come from the past.

en: What I feel towards them is blankness.
vi: My feeling is numbness.
tr: The emptiness I feel towards them.
es: What I feel for them is emptiness.

en: What I feel is that I must not feel.
vi: My feeling is not to have any feeling.
tr: What I feel, something I shouldn't feel.
es: What I feel is that I should not feel.

en: What I feel is partly relief, because none of these men is Luke.
vi: My feeling is also somewhat of relief, because Luke is not among them.
tr: What I feel is partly relief, because none of these men are Luke.
es: What I feel is a certain relief because none of these men is Luke.

en: Luke wasn't a doctor.
vi: Luke was not a doctor in the past.
tr: Luke was not a doctor.
es: Luke was not a doctor.

en: Isn't.
vi: He is not a doctor.
tr: Not.
es: It is not.

en: I look at the one red smile.
vi: I looked at the solitary red smiling mouth.
tr: I'm looking at that red smile.
es: I look at the one with the red smile.

en: The red of the smile is the same as the red of the tulips in Serena Joy's garden, towards the base of the flowers where they are beginning to heal.
vi: That red color is also the color of the tulips in Serena Joy's garden, near the base of the flower where it starts to heal.
tr: The red of the smile is the red of the tulips in Serena Joy's garden, the red at the base of the flowers where they start to heal.
es: The red of the smile is the same as the red of the tulips in Serena Joy's garden, redder near the stem, where they start to heal.

en: The red is the same but there is no connection.
vi: The same red color but no connection, tulips are not made of blood, the red smiling mouth is not a flower, neither explains the other.
tr: The color is the same but there is no connection between them.
es: It's the same red, but there is no relation between the two.

en: The tulips are not tulips of blond, the red smiles are not flowers, neither thing makes a comment or the other.
vi: The same red color but no connection, tulips are not made of blood, the red smiling mouth is not a flower, neither explains the other.
tr: The tulips are not the tulips of blood, the red smiles are not flowers, none of them comment on the other.
es: The tulips are not made of blood and the red smiles are not flowers, and neither of them refers to the other.

en: The tulip is not a reason for disbelief in the hanged man, or vice versa.
vi: One cannot deny the hanged man because of the flower, or vice versa.
tr: The tulip is not the reason for disbelief in the hanged man, nor is the reverse true.
es: The tulip is not a reason to disbelieve in the hanged man, and vice versa.

en: Each thing is valid and really there.
vi: Each thing has its own reason for existence, and they all exist there.
tr: Each is precious and truly there.
es: Each one is valid and is really there.

en: It is through a field of such valid objects that I must pick my way, every day and in every way.
vi: And through a forest full of such rational things, I have to choose my own path, each day, through each path.
tr: I must find my way through this field of precious objects, every day and in every form.
es: It is through a field of valid objects like these that I must choose my path, every day and in every aspect.

en: I put a lot of effort into making such distinctions I need to make them.
vi: I put a lot of effort into those distinctions. I need them.
tr: I make great efforts to make such distinctions. I need to make them.
es: I make a great effort to make such distinctions. I need to make them.

en: I need to be very clear, in my own mind,
vi: I need to be clear, in my mind.
tr: I must be very clear in my own mind.
es: I need to have very clear ideas.

en: I feel a tremor in the woman beside me.
vi: I felt a trembling running through the woman next to me.
tr: I feel the woman next to me trembling.
es: I feel that the woman next to me is trembling.

en: Is she crying?
vi: Was she crying?
tr: Is she crying?
es: Is she crying?

en: In what way could it make her look good?
vi: How could that help her appear in any way?
tr: How can this make her look good?
es: How could this make her seem good?

en: I can't afford to know, My own hands are clenched, I note, tight around the handle of my basket, I won't give anything away.
vi: I couldn't afford to find out. Here I am, gripping the handle of my bag tightly, I see that, I won't reveal anything.
tr: I can't afford to find out. I realize that my hands are tightly gripping the handle of the basket. I won't reveal anything.
es: I can't afford to find out. I realize that I myself have my hands tightly around the handle of my basket. I am not going to reveal anything.

en: Ordinary, said Aunt Lydia, is what you are used to.
vi: Normally, Aunt Lydia said, it is what you are used to seeing happen.
tr: What you are accustomed to, Aunt Lydia would say, is ordinariness.
es: Normally, Aunt Lydia said, it is what is usually done.

en: This may not seem ordinary to you now, but alter a time it will, It will he-come ordinary.
vi: Right now, you may think it is not normal, but after a while, it will be different. It will become normal.
tr: This may not seem ordinary to you now, but after a while, it will appear ordinary. It will become ordinary.
es: It may not seem normal to you now, but after a while it will be. It will become something normal.

en: III
vi: III - Night
tr: III
es: III

en: Night
vi: III - Night
tr: Night
es: THE NIGHT

vi: III - Night
es: CHAPTER 7
CHAPTER 7

en: The night is mine, my own time, to do with as I will, as long as I am quiet.
vi: The night belongs to me, my own time, to do whatever I want, as long as it's quiet.
tr: The night is mine, a time that belongs to me, I can use it as I wish, as long as I remain silent.
es: The night is for me, it belongs to me; I can do whatever I want, as long as I stay quiet.

en: As long as I don't move.
vi: As long as I'm still.
tr: As long as I do not move.
es: As long as I don't move.

en: As long as I lie still.
vi: As long as I lie still.
tr: As long as I lie still.
es: As long as I stretch out and stay still.

en: The difference between lie and lay.
vi: What's the difference between lying down and sleeping.
tr: The difference between lying down and being laid down.
es: There is a difference between stretching out and lying down.

en: Lay is always passive.
vi: Sleeping can still sometimes be intentional.
tr: Being laid down is always passive:
es: Lying down is always something passive.

en: Even men used to say, I'd like to get laid.
vi: Didn't men in the past say, I want to sleep with her.
tr: In the past, even men would say, I would like to be laid down.
es: Men used to say: I would like to stretch out.

en: Though sometimes they said, I'd like to lay her.
vi: Though sometimes they also said, I want her to let me sleep.
tr: Yet sometimes, they would say, I would like to lay the girl down.
es: Although sometimes they said: I would like to lie down with that girl.

en: All this is pure speculation.
vi: All of this is purely speculation.
tr: All of this is purely speculation.
es: All of this is pure speculation.

en: I don't really know what men used to say.
vi: I don't know for sure what men in the past said.
tr: I really don't know what men used to say.
es: The truth is, I don't know what men used to say.

en: I
vi: Whatever they said, that's what I know.
tr: I only have the words.
es: I only know the words they used.

en: had only their words for it.
vi: Whatever they said, that's what I know.
tr: I only have the words.
es: I only know the words they used.

en: I lie, then, inside the room, under the plaster eye in the ceiling, behind the white curtains, between the sheets, neatly as they, and step sideways out of my own time.
vi: So I lay there, in the room, under the plaster eye on the ceiling, behind the white curtains, amidst the bed sheets, absolutely pristine, and stepped aside, out of my own time.
tr: Inside the room, under the plastered eye on the ceiling, behind the white curtains, among the sheets, as flat as they are, I am lying down, therefore, stepping outside my own time.
es: I stretch, then, inside the room, under the plaster eye of the ceiling, behind the white curtains, between the sheets, and I slide into my own time, abandoning the rhythm that they set for us.

en: Out of time.
vi: Out of all systems of time.
tr: Outside of time.
es: Although this is also part of the rhythm, and I am not outside of it.

en: Though this is time, nor am I out of it.
vi: Even though this is time, I did not step out of it.
tr: Yet this is time, and I am not outside of it.
es: Although this is also part of the rhythm, and I am not outside of it.

en: But the night is my time out.
vi: But night is the time for me to go out.
tr: However, night is my time to go out.
es: But the night is for me.

en: Where should 1 go?
vi: Where should I go?
tr: Where should I go?
es: Where could I go?

en: Somewhere good.
vi: Where is beautiful.
tr: To beautiful places.
es: To a pleasant place.

en: Moira, sitting on the edge of my bed, legs crossed, tinkle on kt in her purple overalls, one dangly earring, the- gold fingernail she wore to be eccentric, a cigarette between her stubby yellow-ended fingers.
vi: Moira, sitting on the edge of my bed, her right leg propped up on her left knee, wearing purple overalls, one earring dangling, her nails painted yellow to look different, a cigarette clamped between her chubby fingers, the tips stained yellow.
tr: At the end of my bed, with legs crossed, heel on her knee, in a purple jumpsuit, with a long earring in her ear, with nails painted gold to be quirky, holding a cigarette between her short fingers with yellow tips, Moira.
es: Moira was sitting on the edge of my bed, with her legs crossed in the Indian style, wearing a purple robe, a single earring, and golden nails to look eccentric; between her chubby fingers, she held a cigarette.

en: Let's go for a beer.
vi: Let's go get a beer.
tr: Come on, let's go have a beer.
es: Let's go get a beer.

en: You're getting ashes in my bed, I said.
vi: You're getting ashes all over my bed, I said.
tr: You are dropping ash on my bed, I said.
es: You're going to fill the bed with ash, I protested.

en: If you'd make it you wouldn't have this problem, Mid Moira.
vi: If it had gone smoothly, you wouldn't have encountered this, Moira said.
tr: If you made your bed, there wouldn't be such a problem, said Moira.
es: If you did it, you wouldn't have these problems, he told me.

en: In half an hour, I said.
vi: Half an hour more, I said.
tr: In half an hour, I said.
es: In half an hour, I assured him.

en: I had a paper due the next day it?
vi: I have an assignment due tomorrow. What kind of assignment?
tr: I had an assignment for the next day. What was it?
es: The next day he had an exam. What was it about?

en: Psychology, English, economics.
vi: Psychology, English, economics.
tr: Psychology, English, Economics.
es: Psychology, literature, economics...

en: We studied things like that, then.
vi: We studied those kinds of subjects back then.
tr: We used to read these kinds of things back then.
es: We used to study subjects like those.

en: On the floor of the room there were books, open face down, this way and that, extravagantly.
vi: The floor was covered with books, face down, everywhere, scattered.
tr: In the room, there were books lying face down on the floor, scattered around wastefully.
es: On the floor of the room, there were several books, open and face down, placed haphazardly.

en: Now, said Moira.
vi: Go now, Moira said.
tr: Now, said Moira.

tr: Mayday was a distress signal used a long time ago, in one of those wars we studied in high school.
es: A day in May; Mayday was a distress signal that used to be employed a long time ago in some of the wars we studied in school.

en: a distress signal, a long time ago, in one of those wars we studied in high school.
vi: It used to be a distress signal, from a long time ago, one of those wars we learned about in school.
tr: Mayday was a distress signal used a long time ago, in one of those wars we studied in high school.
es: A day in May; Mayday was a distress signal that used to be employed a long time ago in some of the wars we studied in school.

en: I kept getting them mixed up, but you could tell them apart by the airplanes if you paid attention.
vi: I constantly mix them up, but I can distinguish them by aircraft if I pay close attention.
tr: I always mixed up those wars, but if you paid attention, it was possible to distinguish them by looking at their planes.
es: I still confuse them, but if you paid attention you could distinguish them by the airplanes.

en: It was Luke who told me about mayday, though.
vi: But it was Luke who told me about “mayday.”
tr: It was Luke who told me about Mayday, though.
es: It was Luke who told me about Mayday.

en: Mayday, mayday, for pilots whose planes had been hit, and shipswas it ships too?at sea.
vi: Mayday, mayday, for pilots when their planes were hit, and ships - ships too, right? - at sea.
tr: Mayday, Mayday, for pilots whose planes were shot down and ships - did it apply to ships too? - hit at sea.
es: Mayday was the code used by pilots of planes that had been hit, or ships... did ships use it too?

en: Maybe it was SOS for ships.
vi: It seems like SOS was for ships.
tr: Maybe the signal for ships was SOS.
es: Maybe ships used S.O.S.

en: I wish I could look it up.
vi: I wish I could look that up.
tr: I wish I could look this up somewhere.
es: I would like to find out.

en: And it was something from Beethoven, for the beginning of the victory, in one of those wars.
vi: And a piece of Beethoven’s music, people before knew about victory, in one of those wars.
tr: And for the beginning of victory, in one of those wars, there was something from Beethoven too.
es: And it was something about Beethoven, about the victory in one of those wars.

en: Do you know what it came from?
vi: Do you know where it comes from?
tr: Do you know what the origin of Mayday is?
es: — Do you know where the word Mayday comes from?

en: said Luke.
vi: Luke said.
tr: said Luke.
es: —Luke asked me.

en: Mayday?
vi: "Mayday" that is?
tr: No, I said.
es: —No —I replied—.

en: No, I said.
vi: No, I said.
tr: No, I said.
es: —No —I replied—.

en: It's a strange word to use for that, isn't it?
vi: Using that word here is a bit strange, isn't it?
tr: A strange word to use in such a situation, isn't it?
es: It's strange that they used such a word for that, isn't it?

en: Newspapers and coffee, on Sunday mornings, before she was born.
vi: Morning newspaper and coffee, Sunday mornings, before our child was born.
tr: Newspapers and coffee, on Sunday mornings, before the girl was born.
es: Newspapers and coffee on Sunday mornings, before she was born.

en: There were still newspapers, then.
vi: There were still newspapers back then.
tr: There were still newspapers back then.
es: Back then, newspapers still existed.

en: We used to read them in bed.
vi: We often read them right in bed.
tr: We used to read them in bed.
es: We used to read them in bed.

en: It's French, he said.
vi: That's French, he said.
tr: French, he said.
es: —From French —he explained to me—.

en: From m'aidez.
vi: It transforms into "m'aidez."
tr: It comes from 'M'aidez'.
es: From M’aidez.

en: Help me.
vi: Save me.
tr: Help me.
es: Help me.

en: Coming towards us there's a small procession, a funeral: three women, each with a black transparent veil thrown over her headdress.
vi: A small convoy is approaching us, a funeral: three women, each with a thin black veil draped over the scarf on her head.
tr: A small group is coming towards us, a funeral procession: three women, each with a transparent black veil thrown over their headdresses.
es: A small procession approaches us, it is a funeral cortege: three women, each with a transparent black veil over their headgear.

en: An Econowife and two others, the mourners, also Econo-wives, her friends perhaps.
vi: One is a Frugal Wife and the other two, relatives, are also Frugal Wives, probably her friends.
tr: An Econowife and two other women, mourners, they are also Econowives, perhaps her friends.
es: One of them is an econowife, and the other two are the mourners, also econowives and perhaps her friends.

en: Their striped dresses are worn-looking, as are their faces.
vi: The striped dresses are worn out, and so are the faces.
tr: Their striped dresses, like their faces, look worn out.
es: Their striped dresses seem worn out, just like their faces.

en: Some day, when times improve, says Aunt Lydia, no one will have to be an Econowife.
vi: One day, when times are better, Aunt Lydia says, no one will have to be a Frugal Wife anymore.
tr: One day, as time goes on, says Aunt Lydia, no one will have to be an Econowife.
es: Someday, when things get better, Aunt Lydia used to say, no one will have to be an econowife.

en: The first one is the bereaved, the mother; she carries asmall black jar.
vi: Leading the procession was the mourner, the mother; she held a small black urn.
tr: The mother at the beginning, who has suffered a loss, is carrying a small black jar.
es: The first is the inconsolable mother; she carries a small black vessel.

en: From the size of the jar you can tell how old it was when it foundered, inside her, flowed to its death.
vi: The size of the urn indicated how much it had grown before fading away, inside her, drifting straight to the realm of death.
tr: From the size of the jar, it is possible to understand how many months old the baby was when it perished and passed into death inside it.
es: From the size of the vessel, one can guess the time it was in her womb when death came.

en: Two or three months, too young to tell whether or not it was an Unbaby.
vi: Two or three months, too small to determine if it was a stillborn or not.
tr: Two or three months old, too small to determine if it was a Non-Baby.
es: Two or three months, too little to know whether it was a No Baby or not.

en: The older ones and those that die at birth have boxes.
vi: The older ones, those who died at birth, would be placed in a box.
tr: The larger ones and those who die at birth are placed in boxes.
es: They place the older ones and those who die at birth in boxes.

en: We pause, out of respect, while they go by.
vi: We stopped, showing respect, as they passed by.
tr: We pause respectfully as they pass by us.
es: We stop as a sign of respect while the procession passes.

en: I wonder if Ofglen feels what I do, pain like a stab, in the belly.
vi: I don't know if Ofglen felt the same as I did, a pain like being stabbed, right in the stomach.
tr: I wonder if Gleninki feels the same way I do; a sharp pain, in the stomach.
es: I wonder if Deglen feels the same as I do, a pain in the gut, like a stab wound.

en: We put our hands over our hearts to show these stranger women that we feel with them in their loss.
vi: We placed our hands on our left chests so that those unfamiliar women would understand that we sympathized with their loss.
tr: We place our hands over our hearts to show these foreign women that we share their pain.
es: We place our hands over our chests to express our condolences to these strangers.

en: Beneath her veil the first one scowls at us.
vi: Under the veil, the leading woman glared.
tr: The woman at the front looks at us with a frown from under her veil.
es: From beneath the veil, the first one gives us a threatening look.

en: One of the others turns aside, spits on the sidewalk.
vi: One of the other two turned away and spat on the sidewalk.
tr: One of the others turns aside and spits on the sidewalk.
es: One of the other two steps aside and spits on the sidewalk.

en: The Econowives do not like us.
vi: The frugal Wives did not like us.
tr: The Econowives do not like us.
es: The econowives don't like us.

en: We go past the shops and come to the barrier again, and are passed through.
vi: We passed by the shops and reached the barrier, and were allowed through.
tr: We pass the shops and come back to the barrier, and we are allowed to pass.
es: We passed by the shops, reached the barriers, and went through them.

en: We continue on among the large empty-looking houses, the
vi: We continued walking between large buildings with empty exteriors, and lawns free of weeds.
tr: We pass in front of wide, empty-looking houses and through weedless lawns.
es: We continue walking among the houses with an uninhabited appearance and well-kept lawns.

en: weedless lawns.
vi: We continued walking between large buildings with empty exteriors, and lawns free of weeds.
tr: We pass in front of wide, empty-looking houses and through weedless lawns.
es: We continue walking among the houses with an uninhabited appearance and well-kept lawns.

en: At the corner near the house where I'm posted, Ofglen stops, turns to me.
vi: At the corner near the house where I serve, Ofglen stopped and turned to me.
tr: At the corner near the house I was assigned to, Gleninki stops and turns to me.
es: At the corner, near the house where I am assigned, Deglen stops and turns towards me.

en: "Under His Eye," she says.
vi: “In his eyes,” she said.
tr: “God Bless,” he says.
es: — May His Gaze accompany you —he tells me, according to the proper farewell.

en: The right farewell.
vi: The perfect farewell.
tr: A fitting farewell.
es: — May His Gaze accompany you —he tells me, according to the proper farewell.

en: "Under His Eye," I reply, and she gives a little nod.
vi: “In His eyes,” I replied, and she nodded slightly.
tr: “God bless,” I reply, and he nods slightly, as if he is about to say something else, but then he turns and walks down the street.
es: — May His Gaze accompany you —I respond and she nods with a slight movement.

en: She hesitates, as if to say something more, but then she turns away and walks down the street.
vi: She hesitated, as if intending to say more, but then turned away and walked down the street.
tr: “God bless,” I reply, and he nods slightly, as if he is about to say something else, but then he turns and walks down the street.
es: She hesitates, as if she were about to say something more, but then turns and starts walking down the street.

en: I watch her.
vi: I watched her.
tr: I watch him.
es: I watch her.

en: She's like my own reflection, in a mirror from which I am moving away.
vi: She seemed like a reflection of me, in a mirror I was gradually moving away from.
tr: Just like my own reflection in a mirror, moving away.
es: She is like my own image reflected in a mirror from which I am moving away.

en: In the driveway, Nick is polishing the Whirlwind again.
vi: On the driveway, Nick was scrubbing the Cyclone again.
tr: On the road, Nick is polishing Whirlwind again.
es: On the driveway, I find Nick, who is still polishing the Whirlwind.

en: He's reached the chrome at the back.
vi: He had scrubbed up to the chrome tail section.
tr: He has reached the chrome plating at the back.
es: He has reached the rear chrome part.

en: I put my gloved hand on the latch of the gate, open it, push inward.
vi: I placed my gloved hand on the gate latch, opened it, and pushed in.
tr: I place my gloved hand on the door latch, open it, and push it inward.
es: I place my gloved hand on the gate handle, open it, and push it inward; it closes with a click.

en: The gate clicks behind me.
vi: The gate clicked shut behind me.
tr: The door clicks shut behind me.
es: I place my gloved hand on the gate handle, open it, and push it inward; it closes with a click.

en: The tulips along the border are redder than ever, opening, no longer wine cups but chalices; thrusting themselves up, to what end?
vi: The tulips at the edge of the garden were redder than ever, blooming large, no longer goblets but big cups; stretching themselves up, where do they want to go?
tr: The tulips at the edge of the garden are redder than ever, blooming, no longer like wine glasses but goblets; they push themselves upward, towards what purpose?
es: The tulips are redder than ever, open, now they don't look like cups but chalices; it's as if they were rising on their own, but for what purpose?

en: They are, after all, empty.
vi: After all, they are all wild.
tr: Ultimately, they are empty.
es: After all, they are empty.

en: When they are old they turn themselves inside out, then explode slowly, the petals thrown out like shards.
vi: When they age, they turn outward, then slowly burst open, petals drooping like fragments.
tr: When they wither, their insides turn outwards, then they slowly burst, scattering petals like broken pottery pieces around.
es: When they grow, they turn inside out, slowly burst, and their petals fall off in pieces.

en: Nick looks up and begins to whistle.
vi: Nick looked up and started whistling.
tr: Nick raises his head and starts whistling.
es: Nick looks up and starts to whistle.

en: Then he says, "Nice walk?"
vi: Then he asked, "Did you have fun?"
tr: Then he says, "Was the walk nice?"
es: Then he asks me: —Did the walk go well?

en: I nod, but do not answer with my voice.
vi: I nodded, but did not speak in reply.
tr: I nod my head, but I do not respond with words.
es: I nod my head, but I don't say anything.

en: He isn't supposed to speak to me.
vi: He was not allowed to talk to me.
tr: They should not speak to me.
es: He is not supposed to talk to me.

en: Of course some of them will try, said Aunt Lydia.
vi: Of course, some will try, Aunt Lydia said.
tr: Of course, a few will try, Aunt Lydia would say.
es: Of course, some will try, said Aunt Lydia.

en: All flesh is weak.
vi: Flesh is weak.
tr: All bodies are weak.
es: The flesh is weak.

en: All flesh is grass, I corrected herin my head.
vi: Flesh is grass, I corrected in my mind.
tr: All bodies are grass, I corrected her in my mind.
es: The flesh is ephemeral, I corrected her mentally.

en: They can't help it, she said, God made them that way but He did not make you that way.
vi: They can't help it, she said, God made them that way but God did not make you that way.
tr: It is not in their hands, she would say, God created them this way, but He did not create you this way.
es: They cannot bear it, she said, God made them that way.

en: He made you different.
vi: God made you different.
tr: He created you differently.
es: But He did not make you that way, He made you different.

en: It's up to you to set the boundaries.
vi: Setting boundaries is up to you.
tr: It is up to you to set the boundaries.
es: It is up to you to set the boundaries.

en: Later you will be thanked.
vi: Then you will be thanked later.
tr: Then you will be appreciated.
es: Someday you will be grateful.

en: In the garden behind the house the Commander's Wife is sitting, in the chair she's had brought out.
vi: In the backyard, the Commander's Wife is sitting in a chair that has been brought out.
tr: The Commander's Wife is sitting in the chair she had brought out in the garden behind the house.
es: In the garden behind the house sits the Commander's Wife, seated in a chair she has brought out from inside.

en: Serena Joy, what a stupid name.
vi: Serena Joy, what a stupid name.
tr: Serena Joy, what a stupid name.
es: Serena Joy, what a stupid name.

en: It's like something you'd put on your hair, in the other time, the time before, to straighten it.
vi: "Serene Joy"; sounds like something you would put on your hair, back then, long ago, to win.
tr: In another time, in the previous time, it was like something you put on your hair to make it stand up.
es: As if it were one of those things that used to be put in the hair to straighten it.

en: Serena
vi: Serena
tr: Serena
es: Serena

en: Joy, it would say on the bottle, with a woman's head in cut-paper silhouette on a pink oval background with scalloped gold edges.
vi: Joy, the words on the label, the silhouette of a woman's head on a pink oval background, with wavy gold edges.
tr: Joy, it would say on the bottle, with yellow scalloped edges, a silhouette of a woman's head cut out of paper on a pink oval background.
es: Joy, it must have said on the bottle, which surely had the silhouette of a female head engraved on the label over an oval pink background with gold scalloped edges.

en: With everything to choose from in the way of names, why did she pick that one?
vi: There are all kinds of names in the world to choose from, why choose this one?
tr: With a whole array of other name options, why did she choose this one?
es: With all the names there are, why did she choose that one?

en: Serena
vi: Her real name was never Serena
tr: Serena
es: Because Serena

en: Joy was never her real name, not even then.
vi: Joy, since back then.
tr: Joy was never her real name, even then.
es: Joy was never her real name, not even then.

en: Her real name was Pain.
vi: Her real name was Pam.
tr: Her real name was Pam.
es: Her real name was Pam.

en: I read that in a profile on her, in a news magazine, long after I'd first watched her singing while my mother slept in on Sunday mornings.
vi: I read it in her biography, in a news magazine, long after the first time I saw her sing while my mother slept in on a Sunday morning.
tr: I read this in a biography about her, in a news magazine, long after I first watched her sing while my mother slept on Sunday mornings.
es: I read it in a biographical review in a magazine, long after seeing her sing on Sunday mornings while my mother slept.

en: By that time she was
vi: I read it in her biography, in a news magazine, long after the first time I saw her sing while my mother slept in on a Sunday morning.
tr: At that time, she was important enough to have a biography written about her:
es: In those days, she deserved a biographical review: she must have appeared in Time or Newsweek.

en: worthy of a profile: Time or Newsweekit was, it must have been.
vi: By then, she was significant enough to warrant a biography: The Times or Newsweek, something like that.
tr: It must have been in Time or Newsweek.
es: In those days, she deserved a biographical review: she must have appeared in Time or Newsweek.

en: She wasn't singing anymore by I then, she was making speeches.
vi: By then, she no longer sang but gave speeches.
tr: By then, she was no longer singing, she was giving speeches.
es: Then she no longer sang, she gave speeches.

en: She was good at it.
vi: She was very good at it.
tr: She was good at that too.
es: And she did it well.

en: Het speeches were about the sanctity of the home, about how women should stay home.
vi: She spoke about the sanctity of the family, encouraging women to stay at home.
tr: Her speeches were about the sanctity of the home, how women should stay at home.
es: She spoke about how sacred the home was, and that women should stay at home.

en: Serena
vi: Serena
tr: Serena
es: She spoke about how sacred the home was, and that women should stay at home.

en: Joy didn't do this herself, she made speeches instead, but she presented this failure of hers as a sacrifice shes was limiting lor the good of all.
vi: Joy herself did not stay at home but went around making speeches, though she considered this failure a personal sacrifice for the welfare of all.
tr: Joy herself wasn't doing that, instead, she was giving speeches, but she presented her own failure as a sacrifice made for the good of everyone.
es: She didn't do it, but she said it, and justified this failure of hers by arguing that it was a sacrifice she made for the good of everyone.

en: Around that time, someone tried to shoot her and missed; her secretary, who was standing right behind her, was killed instead.
vi: During that time, someone attempted to shoot her but missed; the secretary, who was standing right behind, died in her place.
tr: At that time, someone tried to shoot him, but missed; instead, they killed the secretary standing right behind him.
es: Approximately around that time, someone tried to shoot her, but missed the target. Instead, they killed her secretary, who was standing directly behind her.

en: Someone else planted a bomb in her ear but it went off loo early.
vi: Another person planted a car bomb for her but it exploded too early.
tr: Additionally, someone else placed a bomb in his car, but the bomb exploded too early.
es: Another person installed a bomb in her car, but it exploded too soon.

en: Though some people said she'd put the bomb in her own car, for sympathy.
vi: There were even people who claimed she planted the car bomb herself to gain sympathy.
tr: However, according to some, he had placed the bomb in his car himself to garner sympathy.
es: Although some people said that she herself had put the bomb in her car to gain the sympathy of the public.

en: That's how hot things were getting.
vi: The situation had become that tense.
tr: This is how things were heating up.
es: This is how things kept getting worse.

en: Luke and I would watch her sometimes on the late-night news.
vi: Luke and I sometimes saw her on the nightly news.
tr: Luke and I would sometimes watch her on the midnight news.
es: Luke and I sometimes watched her on the last news broadcast of the night.

en: Bothrobes, nightcaps.
vi: Bathrobe, nightcap.
tr: Robes, nightcaps.
es: In a bathrobe and nightcap.

en: We'd watch her sprayed hair and her hys-teria, and the tears she could still produce at will, and the mascara blackening her cheeks.
vi: We watched her hair come undone and her frenzy, and the tears she could summon at will, and the mascara running down her cheeks.
tr: We would watch her sprayed hair, her hysteria, the tears she could shed at will, and the mascara that painted her cheeks black.
es: We would gaze at her lacquered hair, her hysteria, the tears she could still summon at will, and the makeup that darkened her cheeks.

en: By that time she was wearing more makeup.
vi: By then, she wore much heavier makeup.
tr: She used to wear more makeup back then.
es: Back then, she wore more makeup.

en: We thought she was funny.
vi: We found her somewhat amusing.
tr: We thought it was funny.
es: We found her amusing.

en: Or Luke thought she was funny.
vi: Or at least Luke found her amusing.
tr: Or at least Luke did.
es: Or rather, Luke found her amusing.

en: I only pretended to think so.
vi: I just pretended to think so.
tr: I just pretended to think so.
es: I only pretended to think so.

en: Really she was a little frightening.
vi: In truth, I found her a bit frightening.
tr: In reality, it was a bit scary.
es: In reality, she was a bit terrifying.

en: She was in earnest.
vi: She was sincere from start to finish.
tr: She took her job too seriously.
es: She really was.

en: She doesn't make speeches anymore.
vi: Now she no longer speaks.
tr: He no longer gives speeches.
es: She no longer gives speeches.

en: She has become speechless.
vi: She has become silent.
tr: He has stopped talking.
es: She has become mute.

en: She stays in her home, but it doesn't seem to agree with her.
vi: She is at home, but it seems that it does not suit her.
tr: He stays at home, but this doesn't seem to suit him.
es: She stays at home, although this doesn't seem to suit her well.

en: How furios she must be, now that she's been taken at her word.
vi: Now how furious she must be, when her mouth wants to open but her jaw is stuck.
tr: Now, he must be furious because they are taking him seriously.
es: How furious she must be, now that they have taken her at her word.

en: She's looking at the tulips.
vi: She is looking at the tulips.
tr: He is looking at the tulips.
es: She is contemplating the tulips.

en: Her cane is beside her, on the grass.
vi: The cane lies beside her, on the grass.
tr: His cane is beside him on the grass.
es: She has the cane on the ground, beside her.

en: Her profile is towards me, I can see that in the quick sideways look I take at her as I gopast.
vi: Half of her face is turned towards me, I noticed this when I cast a quick sideways glance while passing by.
tr: His profile is turned towards me, I can see this with a brief sideways glance as I pass by.
es: She is in profile, I can see her from the quick sideways glance I cast as I pass by.

en: It wouldn't do to stare.
vi: Staring for long does no good.
tr: It wouldn't be right to look directly at him.
es: I would never look at her directly.

en: It's no longer a flawlesss cut-paper profile, her face is sinking in upon itself, and I think of those towns built on underground rivers, where houses iul whole streets disappear overnight, into sudden quagmires, or coal towns collapsing into the mines beneath them.
vi: It is no longer the round, well-defined face; her face is now in the process of hollowing out, and I think of towns built on underground water sources, rows and rows of houses and streets disappearing overnight, turning into a sudden swamp, or mining towns collapsing into the mines beneath them.
tr: It's no longer a perfect profile cut from paper, his face is collapsing inward, I think of those cities built over underground rivers that suddenly emerge as swamps overnight, swallowing houses and entire streets, or the mining towns whose tunnels collapse beneath them.
es: She is no longer a perfect paper silhouette, her face is sinking into itself and makes me think of those cities built over underground rivers, where entire houses and streets disappear overnight into sudden marshes, or coal cities that sink into their own mines.

en: Something like this must have happened to her, once she saw the true shape of tilings to come.
vi: Surely something similar has happened to her, once she saw the true nature of what was coming.
tr: Something similar must have happened to him when he saw the true shape of things to come.
es: Something like that must have happened to her when she saw the turn things were taking.

en: She doesn't turn her head.
vi: She did not turn her head.
tr: He doesn't turn his head.
es: He doesn't turn his head.

en: She doesn't acknowledge my presence in any way, although she knows I'm there.
vi: She did not show any sign of seeing me, even though she knew I was there.
tr: He doesn't acknowledge my presence in any way, despite knowing that I am there.
es: He doesn't acknowledge my presence in the slightest, even though he knows I'm there.

en: I can tell she knows, it's like a
vi: I understood clearly that she knew, it was like that smell, her knowing: a sour smell, like spoiled milk.
tr: I could swear he knows, his knowledge is like a smell; something sour, like stale milk.
es: I know he knows, his awareness is like a smell: something that turns sour, like milk after several days.

en: smell, her knowledge; something gone sour, like old milk.
vi: I understood clearly that she knew, it was like that smell, her knowing: a sour smell, like spoiled milk.
tr: I could swear he knows, his knowledge is like a smell; something sour, like stale milk.
es: I know he knows, his awareness is like a smell: something that turns sour, like milk after several days.

en: It's not the husbands you have to watch out for, said Aunt Lydia, it's

en: You should always try to imagine what they must l팿
vi: You must always try to imagine how they are feeling.
tr: You must always try to imagine how they feel.

en: feeling.
vi: You must always try to imagine how they are feeling.

es: You must always try to imagine what they feel.

en: Of course they will resent you.
vi: Of course, they will kill you.
tr: Of course, they will resent you.
es: Of course they will offend you.

en: It is only natural.
vi: That's only natural.
tr: That is quite natural.
