en: Try
vi: Try to sympathize with them.
tr: Try to feel like them.
es: Try to pity them.

en: In feel for them.
vi: Try to sympathize with them.
tr: Try to feel like them.
es: Try to pity them.

en: Aunt Lydia thought she was very good at feeling lor other people.
vi: Aunt Lydia thought she was very good at sympathizing with others.
tr: Aunt Lydia thought she was good at feeling like other people.
es: Aunt Lydia believed she was very good at pitying others.

en: Try to pity them.
vi: Try to love them.
tr: Try to pity them.
es: Try to have compassion for them.

en: Forgive them, for they know not what they do.
vi: Forgive them, for they know not what they do.
tr: Forgive them, for they know not what they do.
es: Forgive them, for they know not what they do.

en: Again the tremulous smile, of a beggar, the weak-eyed blinking, the gaze upwards, through the round steel-rimmed glasses, towards the back of the classroom, as if the green-painted plaster ceiling were opening and God on a cloud of Pink Pearl face powder were coming down through the wires and sprinkler plumbing.
vi: Once again, the trembling smile, like a beggar, the nearsighted blinking, the eyes looking up, through the steel-rimmed round glasses, towards the back of the classroom, as if the blue-painted plaster ceiling were opening up and God on a pink pearl cloud of face powder were descending through the tangle of wires and fire sprinkler heads.
tr: Again, that timid smile of a beggar, the flicker of a trembling eye, the upward glance, from round steel-framed glasses, towards the back of the classroom as if the green-painted ceiling was opening up and God was descending on a cloud of Pink Pearl face powder, passing through the cables and sprinkler fire system.
es: And she would show that trembling beggar's smile again, raising her gaze—through her round steel-framed glasses—toward the back of the classroom, as if the green-painted ceiling were opening up and God were descending from it, riding a cloud of pearly pink face powder among the wires and pipes.

en: You must realize that theyare defeated women.
vi: You must understand that they are failed women.
tr: You must understand that they are defeated women.
es: You must understand that they are failed women.

en: They have been unable
vi: They are incapable...
tr: They have lost their sexuality...
es: They have been unable to...

en: Here her voice broke off, and there was a pause, during which I could hear a sigh, a collective sigh from those around me.
vi: At this point, Aunt's voice broke, followed by a brief silence, and I heard a collective sigh rising around.
tr: Her voice was cut off here, a sigh, a pause during which I could hear the collective sigh from those around me.
es: At this point, her voice would break, and she would pause, during which I could perceive a sigh around me, a collective sigh.

en: It was a bad idea to rustle or fidget during these pauses: Aunt Lydia might look abstracted but she was aware of every twitch.
vi: Rustling or fidgeting during the silence was unwise: Aunt Lydia seemed absent-minded, but she watched every movement.
tr: During these pauses, it was not a good idea to move or stir: Aunt Lydia might have seemed abstracted, but she would notice even the slightest movement.
es: It was not advisable to whisper or move during these pauses: Aunt Lydia might seem distracted, but she was aware of the slightest movement.

en: So there was only the sigh.
vi: Therefore, there were only sighs.
tr: So, there was only sighing.
es: That's why nothing more than a sigh could be heard.

en: The future is in your hands, she resumed.
vi: The future lies in your hands, aunt summed up.
tr: The future is in your hands, he said, starting anew.
es: The future is in your hands, he summarized.

en: She held her own hands out to us, the ancient gesture that was both an offering and an invitation, to come forward, into an embrace, an acceptance.
vi: Her hand reached out to us, an ancient gesture both offering and inviting, come here, into the embrace, into the welcoming arms.
tr: He extended his hands towards us, this gesture from the past, meaning both an offer and an invitation, to move towards an embrace, an acceptance.
es: He extended his hands towards us, in that ancient gesture that meant both an offering and an invitation to an embrace, an acceptance.

en: In your hands, she said, looking down at her own hands as if they had given her the idea.
vi: In your hands, she said, looking down at her own hands, as if they had suggested it to her.
tr: In your hands, he said, looking at his own hands, as if they had given him this idea.
es: In your hands, he said, looking at his own as if they had given him the idea.

en: But there was nothing in them.
vi: But there was nothing in them.
tr: But there was nothing in his hands.
es: But he saw nothing in them; they were empty.

en: They were empty.
vi: Her hands were empty.
tr: They were empty.
es: But he saw nothing in them; they were empty.

en: It was our hands that were supposed to be full, of the future; which could be held but not seen.
vi: It is our hands that must be full of the future, a future that can be grasped, but not seen.
tr: It was our hands that were expected to be full, with a future that could be held but not seen.
es: It was ours that were supposedly full of the future, a future that we held but could not see.

en: I walk around to the back door, open it, go in, set my basket down on the kitchen table.
vi: I walked around to the back door, opened it, went inside, and placed the basket on the kitchen table.
tr: I walk towards the back door, open it, and go inside, placing my basket on the kitchen table.
es: I walk around to the back door, open it, enter, and leave the basket on the kitchen table.

en: The table has been scrubbed off, cleared of flour; today's bread, freshly baked, is cooling on its rack.
vi: The table had been scrubbed clean, not a trace of flour; today's batch of freshly baked bread was cooling on the rack.
tr: The table has been wiped, the flour cleaned; today's bread, freshly baked, is cooling on the rack.
es: The table has been scrubbed to remove the flour; the day's bread, freshly baked, is cooling on the rack.

en: The kitchen smells of yeast, a nostalgic smell.
vi: The kitchen exuded the smell of yeast, a scent of nostalgia.
tr: The kitchen smells of yeast, a nostalgic scent.
es: The kitchen smells of yeast, a scent filled with nostalgia.

en: It reminds me of other kitchens, kitchens that were mine.
vi: That smell reminded me of other kitchens, my kitchens.
tr: It reminds me of other kitchens, kitchens that were mine.
es: It reminds me of other kitchens, kitchens that were mine.

en: It smells of mothers; although my own mother did not make bread.
vi: It was the smell of my mother; even though my mother never baked.
tr: It smells like mother, like me when I was a mother in the past.
es: It smells like mother, even though my mother didn't bake bread.

en: It smells of me, in former times, when I was a mother.
vi: It was my smell, from before, when I was still a mother.
tr: It smells like mother, like me when I was a mother in the past.
es: It smells like me, a long time ago, when I was a mother.

en: This is a treacherous smell, and I know I must shut it out.
vi: It was a treacherous smell, and I knew I needed to banish it.
tr: This is a dangerous smell, I know I need to keep it outside.
es: It is a treacherous smell and I know I must ignore it.

en: Rita is there, sitting at the table, peeling and slicing carrots.
vi: Rita is there, sitting by the table, peeling and chopping carrots.
tr: Rita is there, sitting at the table, peeling and slicing carrots.
es: Rita is sitting at the table, peeling and cutting carrots.

en: Old carrots they are, thick ones, overwintered, bearded from their time in storage.
vi: The carrots are old, very thick, stored through the winter, and have sprouted roots over time.
tr: These are old carrots, thick, left over from winter, bearded from the time spent in storage.
es: They are old, thick, overripe carrots, and they have grown whiskers from being stored for so long.

en: The new carrots, tender and pale, won't be ready for weeks.
vi: The new carrots, soft and pale, still need a few more weeks.
tr: Fresh carrots, thin and pale in color, won't be ready for weeks.
es: The new, tender, and pale carrots will not be at their peak for a few weeks.

en: The knife she uses is sharp and bright, and tempting.
vi: The knife in her hand is sharp and shiny, very tempting.
tr: The knife Rita is using is sharp and shiny, almost seductive.
es: The knife she uses is sharp and shiny, tempting.

en: I would like to have a knife like that.
vi: I really want to have one too.
tr: I would like to own such a knife.
es: I would like to have one like this.

en: Rita stops chopping the carrots, stands up, takes the parcels out of the basket, almost eagerly.
vi: Rita stopped chopping carrots, stood up, and eagerly lifted the packages out of the basket.
tr: Rita stops chopping the carrots, stands up, and almost impatiently takes the packages out of the basket.
es: Rita stops cutting carrots, stands up, and takes the packages out of the basket, almost anxiously.

en: She looks forward to seeing what I've brought, although she always frowns while opening the parcels.
vi: She was impatient to see what I had brought back, even though she always frowned when unwrapping them.
tr: Even though she always frowns while opening the packages, she is dying to see what I brought; nothing I bring ever fully satisfies her.
es: She waits to see what I have brought, although she always frowns while opening the packages; nothing I bring pleases her.

en: nothing I bring fully pleases her.
vi: Nothing I brought back ever completely satisfied her.
tr: Even though she always frowns while opening the packages, she is dying to see what I brought; nothing I bring ever fully satisfies her.
es: She waits to see what I have brought, although she always frowns while opening the packages; nothing I bring pleases her.

en: She's thinking she could have done better herself.
vi: She thought she could do much better if it were her.
tr: She thinks she could do this job better herself.
es: She thinks she would have done it better.

en: She would rather do the shopping, gel exactly what she wants; she envies me the walk.
vi: If only she could go shopping herself, bringing back exactly what she wanted; she envied my trips.
tr: She would prefer to do the shopping, to get exactly what she wants; she envies me for the walk.
es: She would like to do the shopping, to pick exactly what she wants; she envies my outings.

en: In this house we all envy each other something.
vi: In this house, everyone envies something about someone else.
tr: In this house, we all envy something about each other.
es: In this house, we all envy something about each other.

en: "They've got oranges," I say.
vi: “There are some oranges,” I said.
tr: “Oranges have arrived,” I say, “at Milk and Honey.
es: —They had oranges —I commented—.

en: "At Milk and Honey.
vi: “At the Milk and Honey shop, there are still a few left.”
tr: “Oranges have arrived,” I say, “at Milk and Honey.
es: At Milk and Honey.

en: There are still some left."
vi: “At the Milk and Honey shop, there are still a few left.”
tr: There are still some left.”
es: There are still some left —I tell her as an offering.

en: I hold out this idea to her like an ollering, I wish to ingratiate myself.
vi: I offered this idea to her as a tribute, I wanted to buy some goodwill.
tr: I present this idea to her as a suggestion. I want to make myself liked.
es: I want to ingratiate myself with her.

en: I saw the oranges yesterday, bill I didn't tell Rita; yesterday she was too grumpy.
vi: I saw the oranges yesterday, but I didn't tell Rita; she was too grumpy yesterday.
tr: I had seen the oranges yesterday, but I hadn't told Rita, because she was very irritable yesterday.
es: I saw the oranges yesterday, but I didn't say anything to Rita: she was too grumpy—.

en: "I could get some tomorrow, if you'd give me the tokens for them."
vi: “I'll get them tomorrow if you give me the orange coupons.”
tr: “I can get some tomorrow, if you give me a coupon for them.”
es: If you give me the vouchers, I could get some tomorrow —I hand her the chicken; today she wanted steaks, but there weren't any.

en: I hold on the chicken to her.
vi: I handed her the chicken.
tr: I hand her the chicken.
es: If you give me the vouchers, I could get some tomorrow —I hand her the chicken; today she wanted steaks, but there weren't any.

en: She wanted steak today, but there wasn't any.
vi: Today she wanted roast meat, but it was all gone.
tr: She had asked for steak today, but there wasn't any.
es: If you give me the vouchers, I could get some tomorrow —I hand her the chicken; today she wanted steaks, but there weren't any.

en: Rita grunts, not revealing pleasure or acceptance, She'll think it, the grunt says, in her own sweet time.
vi: Rita grumbled, showing no sign of satisfaction or approval. She would think later, needing to understand that, when she could be alone and at ease.
tr: Rita grumbles without showing excitement or approval. She will think about this, her grumble says, in her good time.
es: Rita growls, but she does not express pleasure or acceptance. The growl means that she will think about it during her leisure time.

en: She undoes the string on the chicken, and the glared paper.
vi: She untied the chicken, removing the wrapping paper.
tr: She unties the string and transparent paper of the chicken.
es: She unties the string from the chicken package and opens the glazed paper.

en: She prods the chicken, flexes a wing, pokes a finger into the cavity, fishes out the giblets.
vi: She pressed on the body, bent one wing, inserted her finger into the belly cavity, and searched for the giblets.
tr: She turns the chicken over and over, bends a wing, inserts a finger into the cavity, and removes the internal organs.
es: She touches the chicken with the tip of her fingers, folds a wing, sticks her finger into the cavity, and takes out the giblets.

en: The- chicken lies there, headless and without feet, goose pimpled as though shivering.
vi: The chicken lay there, headless and footless, with goosebumps as if it were shivering from the cold.
tr: The chicken lies there, headless and footless, its skin puckered as if cold.
es: The chicken remains there, headless and footless, with goosebumps, as if it had chills.

en: "Bath day," Rita says, without looking at me.
vi: “Today is bath day,” Rita said, not looking at me.
tr: “Bath day,” says Rita, without looking at me.
es: —Today is bath day —announces Rita without looking at me.

en: Cora comes into the kitchen, from the pantry at the back, where they keep the mops and brooms.
vi: Cora went into the kitchen from the storage room behind the house, where the brooms and floor brushes were kept.
tr: Cora enters the kitchen from the pantry at the back where they keep the cleaning supplies and brooms.
es: Cora enters, coming from the back pantry where they keep the mops and brooms.

en: "A chicken," she says, almost with delight.
vi: "Look, a chicken," she said, almost joyfully.
tr: “Chicken,” she says, almost joyfully.
es: —A chicken —he says, almost with glee.

en: "Scrawny," says Rita, "but it'll have to do."
vi: “Raise the bone,” Rita said, “but we have to endure it.”
tr: “Weak and dry,” says Rita, “but it has to work.”
es: —Pure bone —states Rita—, but it will have to do.

en: "'I'here wasn't much else," I say.
vi: "Nothing more," I said.
tr: “There wasn't much,” I say.
es: —There weren't many more —I explain, but Rita ignores me.

en: Rita ignores me.
vi: Rita ignored it.
tr: Rita ignores me.
es: —There weren't many more —I explain, but Rita ignores me.

en: "Looks big enough to me," says Cora.
vi: "I think that's big enough," Cora said.
tr: “It looks big enough to me,” says Cora.
es: —It seems quite big to me —Cora responds.

en: Is she standing up for me?
vi: Was she defending me?
tr: Is she supporting me?
es: Is she defending me?

vi: I looked at her, to see if I should smile; but no, she was just thinking about the food.
tr: Is she supporting me?
es: I look at her, to see if she smiles; but no, she was just thinking about the food.

en: look at her, to see if I shouldsmile; but no, it's only the food she's thinking of.
vi: I looked at her, to see if I should smile; but no, she was just thinking about the food.
tr: I look at her, wondering if I should smile; but no, all she is thinking about is the chicken.
es: I look at her, to see if she smiles; but no, she was just thinking about the food.

en: She's younger than Rita; the sunlight, coming slant now through the west window, catches her hair, parted and drawn back.
vi: She was younger than Rita; the sunlight, slanting in through the west window, highlighted her hair parted in the middle and tied back.
tr: She is younger than Rita; the slanting sunlight coming from the west-facing window catches her hair, which is parted in the middle and gathered at the back.
es: She is younger than Rita; the sunlight, now coming through the west window, touches her hair, parted and swept back.

en: She must have been pretty, quite recently.
vi: She used to be beautiful, not long ago.
tr: She must have been beautiful, until very recently.
es: Until not long ago, she must have been pretty.

en: There's a little mark, like a dimple, in each of her ears, where the punctures for earrings have grown over.
vi: There were two small marks, like dimples, on her ears, where the earring holes had healed.
tr: There is a small mark on her ears, like a dimple, where the earring holes have closed up.
es: She has a small mark like a dimple on each ear, where she used to have holes for earrings.

en: "Tall," says Rita, "but bony.
vi: “Big,” Rita said, “but all bones.”
tr: “Big,” says Rita, “but bony.
es: —Big —argues Rita—, but bony.

en: You should speak up," she says to me, looking directly at me for the first time.
vi: “You should have said something,” she said, looking directly at me for the first time.
tr: You should have said it clearly.” For the first time, she speaks looking directly at me.
es: You would have to speak louder — he tells me, looking me in the face for the first time—.

en: "Ain't like you're common."
vi: “You must belong to that mediocre bunch.”
tr: “He’s not ordinary like you.”
es: They are not ordinary, like you —she refers to the Commander's rank; but from the sense she gives to her words, she thinks I am ordinary.

en: She means the Commander's rank.
vi: She meant the status of the Commander.
tr: She means the Commander’s rank.
es: They are not ordinary, like you —she refers to the Commander's rank; but from the sense she gives to her words, she thinks I am ordinary.

en: But in the other sense, her sense, she thinks I am common.
vi: But in another sense, her sense, she thought I belonged to the mediocre type.
tr: But in another sense, she thinks I am ordinary, in her own way.
es: They are not ordinary, like you —she refers to the Commander's rank; but from the sense she gives to her words, she thinks I am ordinary.

en: She is over sixty, her mind's made up.
vi: She was over sixty, all her prejudices firmly entrenched.
tr: Rita is over sixty, her thoughts ossified.
es: She is over sixty years old and her mentality will not change.

en: She goes to the sink, runs her hands briefly under the tap, dries than on the dishtowel.
vi: She went to the sink, waved her hand under the faucet, and dampened the dish towel.
tr: He goes to the sink, holds his hands under the water. He dries them with a hand towel.
es: He goes to the sink, quickly runs his hands under the stream of water, and dries them with the kitchen towel.

en: The dishtowel is white with blue stripes.
vi: The towel was white with blue stripes.
tr: The hand towel is white with blue stripes.
es: It is white with blue stripes.

en: Dishtowels are the same as they always were.
vi: The dish towel was just like before.
tr: The hand towels have never changed.
es: The kitchen towels are the same as always.

en: Sometimes these flashes of normality come at me from the side, like ambushes.
vi: Sometimes those fleeting everyday moments hit me off guard, like an ambush.
tr: Sometimes these kinds of normalcy clashes overwhelm me, like traps.
es: Sometimes these flashes of normality attack me unexpectedly, as if ambushing me.

en: The ordinary, the usual, a reminder, like a kick.
vi: The ordinary, the familiar, something reminiscent, like a punch.
tr: Ordinary, familiar, reminiscent, like a kick.
es: The normal, the usual, a warning, like a kick.

en: I see the dishtowel, out of context, and I catch my breath.
vi: I saw the towel, detached from its context, and held my breath.
tr: I see the hand towel, out of context, I hold my breath.
es: I observe the kitchen towel out of its context and it takes my breath away.

en: For some, in some ways, things haven't changed that much.
vi: For some, in some way, not much has changed.
tr: For some people, in some way, things haven't changed that much.
es: For some, in a certain sense, things haven't changed that much.

en: "Who's doing the bath?" says Rita, to Cora, not to me.
vi: “Who wants to take a bath?” Rita asked Cora, not me.
tr: “Who is taking a bath?” says Rita, not to me, but to Cora.
es: —Who is taking care of the bathroom? —Rita asks Cora, not me—.

en: "I got to tenderize this bird."
vi: “I need to soften this bird first.”
tr: “I need to soften this bird.”
es: I have to tenderize the chicken.

en: "I'll do it later," says Cora, "after the dusting."
vi: “I will do it later,” Cora said, “when I finish dusting.”
tr: “I'll do it later,” says Cora. “After I dust.”
es: —I will do it later —Cora responds—, after dusting.

en: "Just so it gets done," says Rita.
vi: “Why stop when it's done,” Rita said.
tr: “Then someone should do it,” says Rita.
es: —If not, no one will do it —concludes Rita.

en: They're talking about me as though I can't hear.
vi: They talk about me as if I can't hear them.
tr: They talk about me as if I can't hear them.
es: They talk about me as if I couldn't hear them.

en: To them I'm a household chore, one among many.
vi: To them, I am just a household chore, among many other tasks.
tr: To them, I am just a daily chore in the house, one of many tasks.
es: To them, I am just another household chore, one of many.

en: I've been dismissed.
vi: I was dismissed.
tr: I was defeated.
es: They have pushed me aside.

en: I pick up the basket, go through the kitchen door and along the hall towards the grandfather clock.
vi: I picked up the basket, left the kitchen, and walked down the hall towards my grandfather's clock.
tr: I take the basket and pass through the kitchen door, heading towards the old wall clock along the hall.
es: I grab the basket, go out through the kitchen door, and walk down the hallway to the pendulum clock.

en: The sitting room door is closed.
vi: The door to the lounge was closed.
tr: The door of the living room is closed.
es: The living room door is closed.

en: Sun comes through the fanlight, falling in colors across the floor: red and blue, purple.
vi: Sunlight streamed through the semi-circular archway, casting colorful hues on the floor: red, blue, and purple.
tr: Daylight enters through the window above the door, falling to the ground and scattering colors: red and blue, purple.
es: The sun shines through the fanlight, painting the floor with colors: red, blue, purple.

en: I step into it briefly, stretch out my hands; they fill with flowers of light.
vi: I hesitated to step in, spreading my hands wide: my hands were filled with sunlight flowers.
tr: I immediately step into this light, reaching out my hands; they fill with flowers made of light.
es: I step on it and stretch out my hands, which fill with flowers of light.

en: I go up the stairs, my face, distant and white and distorted, framed in the hall mirror, which bulges outward like an eye under pressure.
vi: I went up the stairs: my face, distant, pale, and distorted, trapped within the long mirror, bulging like an eye being pressed.
tr: I go up the stairs, and in the hall mirror, my face appears distant and white and distorted, like an eye under pressure.
es: I go up the stairs and see my face —distant, white, and distorted— framed in the hallway mirror, which protrudes like a flattened eye.

en: I follow the dusty-pink runner down the long upstairs hallway, back to the room.
vi: I followed the pink and gray carpet along the long upstairs hallway, back to my room.
tr: Following the dusty pink runner, I cross the long hall upstairs and return to my room.
es: I walk along the ash-pink carpet of the upstairs hallway, heading towards the bedroom.

en: There's someone standing in the hall, near the door to the room where I stay.
vi: There is someone standing in the hallway, near the door to my room.
tr: Someone is standing in the hallway, near the door of the room I'm staying in.
es: I see someone standing in the hallway, near the room where I am staying.

en: The hall is dusky, this is a man, his back to me; he's looking into the room, dark against its light.
vi: The hallway is dimly lit, this person is a man, his back turned to me; he is looking into the room, the light spilling out making his figure dark.
tr: The hallway is dim, it's a man, his back is turned to me; he's looking into the room, a dark shadow cast by the light.
es: The hallway is dark; but I see a man, with his back to me. He is looking inside, and his silhouette is darkened against the light coming from the room.

en: I can see now, it's the Commander, heisn't supposed to be here.
vi: Now I see, it is the Commander, he shouldn't be here.
tr: Now I can see, it's the Commander, he shouldn't be here.
es: Now I see him: it is the Commander, he is not supposed to be here.

en: He hears me coming, turns, hesitates, walks forward.
vi: He hears me coming, turns around, hesitates, and steps forward, towards me.
tr: He hears me coming, turns, hesitates, walks forward.
es: He hears me coming, turns around, hesitates, and finally moves forward.

en: Towards me.
vi: He hears me coming, turns around, hesitates, and steps forward, towards me.
tr: Toward me.
es: He is coming towards me.

en: He is violating custom, what do I do now?
vi: He is breaking the rules, what should I do?
tr: He's breaking the rule. What should I do now?
es: He is breaking the rules. What do I do now?

en: I stop, he pauses, I can't see his face, he's looking at me, what does he want?
vi: I stopped, he stopped walking, I couldn't see his face, he was looking at me, what did he want?
tr: I am standing, hesitating, I can't see his face, he is looking at me, what does he want?
es: I stop and he stands still; I can't see his face, he's looking at me, what does he want?

en: But then he moves forward again, steps to the side to avoid touching me, inclines his head, is gone.
vi: But then he moved forward, stepped aside to avoid bumping into me, slightly tilted his head, and walked away.
tr: He moves forward again, pulls aside to avoid touching me, lowers his head, and passes by.
es: But finally he returns to advance, moves aside to avoid touching me, bows the head AND disappears.

en: Something has been shown to me, but what is it?
vi: I was shown something, but what was it?
tr: Something was shown to me, but what?
es: Something has been revealed to me, but what?

en: Like the flag of an unknown country, seen for an instant above a curve of hill.
vi: Like the national flag of an unknown country, briefly appearing behind the hill.
tr: Like the banner of an unknown country appearing for a moment on the curve of a hill; it could mean an attack, a meeting, the boundary of something, a region.
es: Like the flag of an unknown country, seen fleetingly at the curve of a hill; it could mean an attack, it could mean the possibility of negotiating, it could mean the end of something, of a territory.

en: It could mean attack, it could mean parley, it could mean the edge of something, a territory.
vi: It could be an attack, it could be a negotiation, it could be a boundary, a strange territory.
tr: Like the banner of an unknown country appearing for a moment on the curve of a hill; it could mean an attack, a meeting, the boundary of something, a region.
es: Like the flag of an unknown country, seen fleetingly at the curve of a hill; it could mean an attack, it could mean the possibility of negotiating, it could mean the end of something, of a territory.

en: The signals animals give one another: lowered blue eyelids, ears laid back, raised hackles.
vi: Signals between animals: blue eyelids lowered, ears pulled back, feathers on the neck raised.
tr: The signals animals give to each other: lowered blue eyelids, ears laid back, bristling fur.
es: The signals that animals give each other: the lowered eyelids, the ears pulled back, the bristling hair.

en: A flash of bared teeth, what in hell does he think he's doing?
vi: Fangs flashed, what the hell does he think he's doing?
tr: A fleeting glimpse of bared teeth, what the hell does it think it's doing?
es: The flash of some teeth... but what the hell was I doing?

en: Nobody else has seen him.
vi: No one saw him.

en: But now it's the rooms themselves I miss as well, even the dreadful paintings that hung on the walls, landscapes with fall foliage or snow melting in hardwoods, or women in period costume, with china-doll faces and bustles and parasols, or sad-eyed clowns, or bowls of fruit, stiff and chalky looking.

tr: But now, in the same way, I miss the rooms themselves, even those terrible pictures hanging on the walls, autumn leaves or snowy forest landscapes, or women with porcelain doll faces in period costumes, with padded hips and sun umbrellas, or sad-eyed clowns, or tense and chalky-looking fruit bowls.
es: But now I also miss the rooms themselves, even the horrible paintings on the walls: landscapes of fallen leaves, or of snow melting on trees, or of women dressed in period costumes with porcelain doll faces and parasols, or of sad-looking clowns, or of bowls with stiff, chalky-looking fruit.

en: The fresh towels ready for spoilage, the wastebaskets gaping their invitations, beckoning in the careless junk.

tr: Clean towels ready to be soiled, trash bins waving in a careless disarray invitingly.

en: Careless.

vi: I divide the room into sections, in my mind, reserving one section for myself each day.
tr: I divided the room into sections in my mind; I allocated one section to myself each day.
es: I mentally divided the room into sectors; I assigned myself one sector per day and examined it with the utmost thoroughness: the irregularity of the plaster beneath the wallpaper, the scratches on the paint of the baseboard and the windowsill, the stains on the mattress... because I even went so far as to lift the blankets and sheets off the bed and turn them over, a little at a time so I could quickly put them back in place if someone came.

en: This one section I would examine with the great-est minuteness: the unevenness of the plaster under the wallpaper, the scratches in the paint of the baseboad and the windowsill, un-der the top coat of paint, the stains on the matress,for I went so far as to lift the blankets and sheets from the bed, folkd them back, a little at a time, so they could be replaced quickly if anyone came.
vi: I will examine that section meticulously: the uneven layer beneath the wallpaper, the scratches on the baseboards and window sills, beneath the top layer of paint, the stains on the mattress, because I also turn over the blanket and sheets, rolling them back, a little at a time, so I can quickly put them back if someone comes.
tr: I would examine this single section with all my attention: the irregularity of the plaster under the wallpaper, the scratches under the top layer of paint on the baseboard and window sill, the stains on the bed, because I went so far as to remove the blanket and sheets from the bed, folding them piece by piece, so that if someone were to come, they could quickly restore it to its original state.
es: I mentally divided the room into sectors; I assigned myself one sector per day and examined it with the utmost thoroughness: the irregularity of the plaster beneath the wallpaper, the scratches on the paint of the baseboard and the windowsill, the stains on the mattress... because I even went so far as to lift the blankets and sheets off the bed and turn them over, a little at a time so I could quickly put them back in place if someone came.

en: Like dried flower petals.
vi: Like dried petals.

es: Like petals of dried flowers

vi: Nothing can be done.
tr: There is nothing to be done.
es: There is nothing to be done.

tr: I know why the glass in the window is unbreakable and why they removed the chandelier.
es: I already know why the window glass is unbreakable. And why they removed the chandelier.

vi: I looked carefully at the door first, inside and out, then the cupboard walls with brass hooks - why did they overlook the hooks?
tr: First, I carefully examined the door, inside and out, then the brass hooks on the walls - how did they miss the brass hooks?
es: First, I carefully looked at the door, inside and out, and then the walls and their brass hooks; why had they overlooked the hooks?

en: Why didn't they remove them?

es: Why hadn't they removed them?

en: Too close to the floor?

vi: But what's the big deal, a long sock, that's all it takes.

en: And the rod with the plastic hangers, my dresses hanging on
vi: And the horizontal rod hanging plastic hangers, my clothes hanging there, the sleeveless red wool cloak for cold weather, the shawl.
tr: And, the rod carrying the plastic hangers on which my clothes, my red wool cape for cold weather, and the shawl were hanging.
es: And the rod with the plastic hangers and my dresses hanging from them, the red wool cape for cold days, the shawl.

en: them, the red woollen cape for cold weather, the shawl.
vi: And the horizontal rod hanging plastic hangers, my clothes hanging there, the sleeveless red wool cloak for cold weather, the shawl.

es: And the rod with the plastic hangers and my dresses hanging from them, the red wool cape for cold days, the shawl.

en: I knelt to examine the floor, and there it was, in tiny writing, quite fresh it seemed, scratched with a pin or maybe just a fingernail, in the corner where the darkest shadow fell: Nolite te bastardes carborun-dorum.
vi: I knelt down to examine the cupboard floor, and there, tiny letters, still quite new, scratched with a needle or maybe just a fingernail, in the corner shrouded in the thickest darkness: Nolite te bastardes carborundorum.
tr: I knelt down to examine the floor and there it was, in small writing, tiny writing, it looked very new, scratched with a needle or maybe just a fingernail, in the corner where the darkest shadow fell: Nolite te bastardes carborundorum.
es: I knelt to examine the floor and there it was, in tiny letters, quite recent from the looks of it, marked with a pin, or perhaps simply with a fingernail, in the darkest corner: Nolite te bastardes carborundorum.

en: I didn't know what it meant, or even what language it was in.
vi: I don't know what it means, I don't even know what language it is.
tr: I didn't even know what it meant or in which language it was written.
es: I didn't know what it meant, nor what language it was.

en: I thought it might be Latin, but I didn't know any Latin.
vi: I guess it could be Latin, but I don't know Latin.
tr: I thought it might be Latin, but I didn't know Latin.
es: I thought it might be Latin, but I didn't know anything about Latin.

en: Still, it was a message, and it was in writing, forbidden by that very fact, and it hadn't yet been discovered.
vi: Anyway, it's still a message, a message in writing, which alone is enough to make it a forbidden object, and until now it hasn't been discovered.
tr: Still, it was a message and it was written, and for that reason alone it was forbidden and yet undiscovered by anyone.
es: However, it was a message, and it was written, an act forbidden in itself, and it had not yet been discovered.

en: Except by me, for whom it was intended.
vi: Except by me, the one it was sent to.
tr: Except for me, the person to whom the message was sent.
es: Except by me, to whom it was addressed.

en: It was intended for whoever came next.
vi: It was sent to anyone who comes after.
tr: The message was sent to whoever would come after.
es: It was addressed to whoever came after.

en: It pleases me to ponder this message.
vi: Thinking about this message secretly amused me.
tr: I enjoy pondering over this message.
es: I like to reflect on this message.

en: It pleases me to think I'm communing with her, this unknown woman.
vi: I was amused to think that I was communicating with her, the secret woman.
tr: Connecting with her, this unknown woman.
es: I like to think that I communicate with her, with this unknown woman.

en: For she is unknown; or if known, she has never been mentioned to me.
vi: For she was indeed a secret, or if known at all, no one had ever mentioned her to me.
tr: Because she is unknown, or even if she is known, she was never mentioned to me.
es: Because she is unknown; and, if she is known, she was never mentioned to me.

en: It pleases me to know that her taboo message made it through, to at least one other person, washed itself up on the wall of my cupboard, was opened and read by me.
vi: I was delighted to know that her forbidden message had passed through, reaching at least one other person, when placed and stuck on my locker door, had been opened and read by me.
tr: I like knowing that the forbidden message could reach, at least to another person, that it could endure on the wall of my locker, that it was opened and read by me.
es: I like knowing that her taboo message has managed to endure at least so that another person could see it and that, although hidden on the wall of my closet, I opened the door and read it.

en: Sometimes I repeat the words to myself.
vi: Sometimes I repeated each word to myself.
tr: Sometimes I repeat the words to myself.
es: Sometimes I repeat the words to myself.

en: They give me a small joy.
vi: They brought a small joy.
tr: They give me a small happiness.
es: They provide me with a small joy.

en: When 1 imagine the woman who wrote them, I think of her as about my age, maybe a little younger.
vi: When imagining the woman who wrote this line, I pictured her around my age, maybe a little younger.
tr: When I imagine the woman who wrote these, I think she is someone my age, maybe a bit younger.
es: When I imagine the woman who wrote them, I think she is approximately my age, perhaps a bit younger.

en: I turn her into Moira, Moira as she was when she was in college, in the room next to mine: quirky, jaunty, athletic, with a bicycle once, and a knapsack for hiking.
vi: I turned her into Moira, Moira from college, in the room next to mine: playful, lively, a former cyclist, and a backpacker who often went hiking.
tr: I transform her into Moira, in her college days, in the room next to mine: lively, carefree, athletic, with a bicycle she once had and a backpack for hitchhiking.
es: I identify her with Moira, just as she was when she went to university and occupied the room next to mine: witty, lively, athletic, riding a bicycle and with a backpack on her back, ready for hiking.

en: Freckles, I think; irreverent, resourceful.
vi: Freckled, I imagined; fond of mocking, full of schemes.
tr: Freckled, I think; irreverent, resourceful.
es: Freckled, I think; disrespectful and clever.

en: I wonder who she was or is, and what's become of her.
vi: I wonder who Miss Tung is, who she is now, and what she has become.
tr: I wonder who or what it is and what happened to it.
es: I wonder who she was or who she is, and what has become of her.

en: I tried that out on Rita, the day I found the message.
vi: I tried to exploit Rita, the day I found the message.
tr: I tried to get information from Rita, the day I found the message.
es: The day I found the message, I gauged Rita's mood.

en: Who was the woman who stayed in that room?
vi: Who was the person who stayed in that room?
tr: Who was the woman who stayed in the room?
es: Who was the woman that was in that room?, I asked him.

en: I said.
vi: I asked.
tr: I asked.
es: Who was the woman that was in that room?, I asked him.

es: None of them were known to us.

en: The news paper stories were like dreams to us, bad dreams dreamt by others.
vi: The stories in the newspapers are like dreams, like someone else's nightmare.
tr: Newspaper stories were like dreams to us, bad dreams that others had.
es: The news stories seemed like dreams to us, nightmares dreamed by others.

en: How awful, we would say, and they were, but they were awful without being believable.
vi: It's horrifying, we say, and it truly is horrifying, but it's a horror that is hard to believe.
tr: How terrible, we would say, and they were, but they were terribly without being believable.
es: How horrible, we said, and it was, but it was horrible without being believable.

en: They were too melodramatic, they had a dimension that was not the dimension of our lives.
vi: They are too much like theater, they belong to a different dimension, not part of our lives.
tr: They were overly melodramatic, belonging to a dimension that was not part of our lives.
es: They were too melodramatic, they had a dimension that was not the dimension of our lives.

en: We were the people who were not in the papers.
vi: We are the people who don't make it to the news.
tr: We were people who never made it to the newspapers.
es: We were the people who didn't appear in the newspapers.

en: We lived in the blank white spaces at the edges of print.
vi: We live on the margins of blank paper.
tr: We lived in the white margins of the print.
es: We lived in the spaces in between, in the margins of each issue.

en: It gave us more freedom.
vi: It's more free that way.
tr: This gave us more freedom.
es: This gave us more freedom.

en: We lived in the gaps between the stories.
vi: We live in the space between stories.
tr: We used to live in the gaps between the stories.
es: We lived between the lines of the news.

en: From below, from the driveway, comes the sound of the car being started.
vi: From below, the driveway, the sound echoed up, the family car was starting.
tr: The sound of a car being started is coming from down the road.
es: From the lower driveway comes the sound of a car starting up.

en: It's quiet in this area, there isn't a lot of traffic, you can hear things like that very clearly: car motors, lawn mowers, the clipping of a hedge, the slam of a door.
vi: This area is quiet, with few vehicles, every sound is heard very clearly: the sound of car engines, the sound of lawnmowers, the sound of hedge trimmers, the sound of doors slamming shut.
tr: This area is quiet, traffic is not heavy, you can clearly hear such things here: car engines, lawn mowers, the trimming of a bush, the slamming of a door.
es: This is a quiet area, there isn't much traffic, you can hear very clearly sounds like car engines, lawnmowers, the snip of pruning shears, a door slamming.

en: You could hear a shout clearly, or a shot, if such noises were ever made here.
vi: Shouts would also be heard clearly, or gunshots, if they ever rang out here.
tr: You could clearly hear a shout or a gunshot, if such sounds were to occur.
es: A scream or a gunshot could be heard clearly, if someone made those noises here.

en: Sometimes there are distant sirens.
vi: Occasionally, in the distance, there is the sound of sirens.
tr: Sometimes, the sounds of sirens coming from a distance can be heard.
es: Sometimes, in the distance, sirens can be heard.

en: I go to the window and sit on the window seat, which is too narrow for comfort.
vi: I sat on the window sill, too cramped to be comfortable.
tr: I go to the window and sit on the narrow window ledge, which is uncomfortable.
es: I go to the window and settle into its seat, which is too narrow to be comfortable.

en: There's a hard little cushion on it, with a petit point cover: FAITH, in square print, surrounded by a wreath of lilies.
vi: There was a small, hard pillow placed there, with a cover embroidered in small stitches: FAITH, in capital letters, surrounded by a wreath of lilies.
tr: There is a small, hard cushion with embroidery on it: FAITH, surrounded by a wreath of lilies, written in angular letters.
es: There is a cushion, hard and small, with a petit-point cover on which —written in block letters and framed by a garland of lilies—

en: FAITH is a faded blue, the leaves of the lilies a dingy green.
vi: The word FAITH was in faded blue, and the lilies were in dull green.
tr: FAITH is in pale blue, and the leaves of the lilies are in dirty green.
es: the word FAITH is read, in a faded blue, and the leaves of the lilies in a dull green.

en: This is a cushion once used elsewhere, worn but not enough to throw out.
vi: This pillow had been used elsewhere before, worn out but not yet worth discarding.
tr: This cushion was once used elsewhere, worn out, but not enough to be thrown away.
es: This cushion was once used somewhere else, and it was worn, but not so much as to throw it away.

en: Somehow it's been overlooked.
vi: I don't understand why people overlooked it.
tr: Somehow, it was overlooked.
es: Somehow, it has been overlooked.

en: I can spend minutes, tens of minutes, running my eyes over the print: FAITH.
vi: I can sit for minutes, tens of minutes, staring at the words: FAITH.
tr: I can let my eyes wander over the word FAITH for minutes, dozens of minutes.
es: I can spend minutes, tens of minutes, scanning the letters with my gaze: FAITH.

en: It's the only thing they've given me to read.
vi: The only thing available for me to read.
tr: The only thing they gave me to read.
es: It's the only thing they've given me to read.

en: If I were caught doing it, would it count?
vi: If I get caught doing this, will it matter?
tr: If I get caught doing this, would it be considered a crime?
es: If they caught me doing it, would they take it into account?

en: I didn't put the cushion here myself.
vi: It's not like I placed the pillow here myself.
tr: I didn't put the pillow here myself.
es: It wasn't me who put the cushion here.

en: The motor turns, and I lean forward, pulling the while curtain across my face, like a veil.
vi: The engine roared, and I leaned forward, pulling the white curtain past my face, like a veil.
tr: The engine is running and I lean forward, pulling the white curtains towards my face like a veil.
es: The engine starts and I lean forward, closing the curtain in front of my face, as if it were a veil.

en: It's semisheer, I can sec through it.
vi: The curtain was almost transparent, allowing visibility through it.
tr: The curtain is semi-transparent, I can see outside.
es: It is semi-transparent, so I can see through it.

en: If I press my forehead against the glass and look down, I can SCT the back half of the Whirlwind.
vi: If I pressed my forehead against the glass and looked down, I could see the rear half of the Cyclone.
tr: If I press my forehead against the glass and look down, I can see the rear half of the Whirlwind.
es: If I press my forehead against the glass and look down, I can see the back half of the Whirlwind.

en: Nobody is there, but ass I watch I see Nick come around to the back door of the car, open it, stand stiffly beside it.
vi: There was no one, but a moment later I saw Nick walking around to the back door, opening it, and standing beside it.
tr: There is no one, but as I watch, I see Nick circling around to the back of the car and opening the door, standing upright beside it.
es: I don't see anyone, but after a moment I notice that Nick walks around to the back door of the car, opens it, and stands stiffly beside it.

en: His
vi: Now his hat was straight, his hands down, carefully buttoning up.
tr: His hat is neat now and his shirt sleeves are adjusted and buttoned.
es: Now he wears the cap properly, and the sleeves are down and buttoned.

en: cap is straight now and his sleeves rolled down and buttoned.
vi: Now his hat was straight, his hands down, carefully buttoning up.
tr: His hat is neat now and his shirt sleeves are adjusted and buttoned.
es: Now he wears the cap properly, and the sleeves are down and buttoned.

en: I can't see his face because I'm looking down on him.
vi: Looking down from above, I couldn't see his face.
tr: I can't see his face because I am looking at him from above.
es: From the angle where I am, I can see his face.

en: Now the Commander is coming out.
vi: The Commander is now leaving the house.
tr: Now the Commander is going outside.
es: Now the Commander appears.

en: I glimpse him only lor an instant, foreshortened, walking to the car.
vi: I only caught a glimpse of him for a moment, briefly, as he was walking towards the car.
tr: I see him only for a moment, as he walks towards the car, as if he has shrunk.
es: I only manage to see him for an instant, in profile, as he walks towards the car.

en: He does't have his hat on, so it's not a formal event he's going to.
vi: He wasn't wearing a hat, so he wasn't attending any official meeting.
tr: He is not wearing his hat, so he is not going on official business.
es: He is not wearing a hat, so he is not going to any official event.

en: His hair is a gray.
vi: His hair had turned gray.
tr: His hair is gray.
es: He has gray hair.

en: Silver, you might call it if you were being kind.
vi: Gray hair, let's call it that to make him seem kind.
tr: Out of politeness, you would call it silvery.
es: Silver, I should say to be polite.

en: I don't feel like being kind.
vi: I'm not in the mood to be kind.
tr: I don't feel polite.
es: But I don't feel like being polite.

en: The one before this was bald, so I suppose he's an improvement
vi: He used to be completely bald, so this could be considered an improvement.
tr: The previous one was bald, so I guess I've made some progress.
es: The previous one was bald, so I suppose this one represents quite a progress.

en: If I could spit, out the window, or throw something, the cushion for instance, I might be able to hit him.
vi: If only I knew how to spit, from the window, or throw something down, like this pillow for instance, maybe it would hit him.
tr: If I could spit, or throw something out the window, for example, the pillow, it’s possible I might hit him.
es: If I could spit, or throw something, for example the cushion, maybe I could hit him.

en: Moira and I, with paper bags filled with water.
vi: Moira and I, bags of paper filled with water.
tr: Moira and I, with paper bags filled with water.
es: Moira and I have paper bags filled with water.

en: Water bombs, they were called.
vi: Water bombs, that's what we called them.
tr: They were called water bombs.
es: They called them water bombs.

en: Leaning out my dorm window, dropping them on the heads of the boys below.
vi: Leaning out of the dorm window, throwing them down on the boys below.
tr: We would lean out of my dormitory window and throw them at the boys below.
es: We peeked out the window of my bedroom and threw the bombs at the boys who were below.

en: It was Moira's idea.
vi: It was Moira's idea.
tr: It was Moira's idea.
es: It was Moira's idea.

en: What were they trying to do?
vi: What were they trying to do?
tr: What were they trying to do?
es: What were they trying to do?

en: Climb a ladder, for something.
vi: Climbing up with a ladder, wanting to steal some things.
tr: Climbing the stairs, for something.
es: Climb up a ladder in search of something.

en: For our underwear.
vi: Our underwear.
tr: For our underwear.
es: Our underwear.

en: That dormitory had once been coeducational, there were still urinals in one of the washrooms on our floor.
vi: The dormitory used to be co-ed, and our floor still had a men's urinal attached to the wall in the bathroom.
tr: Once upon a time, co-education was practiced here, and there were still urinals in one of the bathrooms on our floor.
es: That dormitory had once been mixed; in one of the sinks on our floor, there were still urinals.

en: But by the time I'd got there they'd put things back the way they were.
vi: But by the time I got there, everything had been restored to its original state.
tr: But when I arrived, men and women were no longer together as they used to be.
es: But by the time I arrived, they had already put women and men back in their places.

en: The Commander stoops, gets into the car, disappears, and Nick shuts the door.
vi: The commander bent down, got into the car, disappeared, and Nick closed the door.
tr: The commander bends down, gets into the car, and disappears, and Nick closes the door.
es: The Commander stops, gets into the car, disappears, and Nick closes the door.

en: A moment later the car moves backward, down the driveway and onto the street, and vanishes behind the hedge.
vi: A second later, the car reversed, passed through the gate, went down the road, and disappeared behind the hedge.
tr: A moment later, the car moves backward down the driveway, goes out onto the street, and disappears behind the bushes.
es: A moment later the car reverses, goes down the driveway, and exits onto the street, disappearing behind the hedge.

en: I ought to feel hatred for this man.
vi: I need to hate this person.
tr: I should have hated this man.
es: I have to feel hatred for this man.

en: I know I ought to feel it, but it isn't what I do feel.
vi: I know I need to, but I really don't feel that way.
tr: I know that this is how I should feel, but in reality, this is not what I feel.
es: I know I have to feel it, but it's not what I really feel.

en: What I feel is more complicated than that.
vi: My feelings are much more complicated.
tr: What I feel is something more complicated than that.
es: What I feel is more complicated.

en: I don't know what to call it.
vi: I don't know what to call it.
tr: I don't know what to call it.
es: I don't know what to call it.

en: It isn't love.
vi: It's not love.
tr: It's not love.
es: It's not love.
CHAPTER 11

en: Yesterday morning I went to the doctor.
vi: Yesterday morning I went for a check-up.
tr: I went to the doctor yesterday morning.
es: Yesterday morning I went to the doctor.

en: Was taken, by a Guardian, one of those with the red arm bands who are in charge of such things.
vi: I was taken there by a Guardian, one of those with a red armband who specialize in this kind of task.
tr: I was taken, that is, by a Guardian with a red armband responsible for such matters.
es: Accompanied by a Guardian, one of those who wear a red armband and take care of such matters.

en: We rode in a red car, him in the front, me in the back.
vi: We rode in a red car, he sat in the front seat, I sat in the back.
tr: We went in a red car, he in the front, me in the back.
es: We traveled in a red car, he in the front and I in the back.

en: No twin went with me; on these occasions I'm solitaire.
vi: There was no shadow accompanying me; on these occasions, I am alone.
tr: Without my partner beside me; in such situations, I am alone.
es: My double did not accompany me; on these occasions, I am a solitary.

en: I'm taken to the doctor's once a month, for tests: urine,, hormones, cancer smear, blood test; the same as before, except that now it's obligatory.
vi: I am taken for a check-up once a month, undergoing all sorts of tests: urine, hormones, cancer screening, blood tests; just like before, except now it's mandatory.
tr: I am taken to the doctor once a month for tests: urine, hormone, smear test, blood test; just like before, the only difference is that now it is mandatory.
es: They take me to the doctor once a month to undergo various tests: urine analysis, hormone tests, biopsy to detect if there is cancer, blood tests; just like before, except now it is mandatory.

en: The doctor's office is in a modern office building.
vi: The clinic is located in a modern office building.
tr: The doctor's office is in a modern business building.
es: The doctor's office is in a modern office building.

en: We ride up in the
vi: We took the elevator up, silently, the Guard facing me.
tr: We go up by elevator, silently, the Guardian facing me.
es: We go up in the elevator, silently, and the Guardian and I stand face to face; I see the back of his neck in the smoked mirror of the elevator.

en: elevator, silently, the Guardian facing me.
vi: We took the elevator up, silently, the Guard facing me.
tr: We go up by elevator, silently, the Guardian facing me.
es: We go up in the elevator, silently, and the Guardian and I stand face to face; I see the back of his neck in the smoked mirror of the elevator.

en: In the black-mirror wall of the elevator I can see the back of his head.
vi: Looking at the glossy black elevator walls like a mirror, I could see the back of his neck.
tr: I see the back of his head in the black mirrored wall of the elevator.
es: We go up in the elevator, silently, and the Guardian and I stand face to face; I see the back of his neck in the smoked mirror of the elevator.

en: At the office itself, I go in; he waits, outside in the hall, with thr other Guardi-ans, on one of the chairs placed there for that purpose.
vi: Upon reaching the clinic, I went inside; he waited outside, in the lobby, with the other Guards, on the row of chairs designated for them.
tr: I enter the office; he, on the other hand, waits outside in the hallway on one of the chairs placed there for this purpose, along with the other Guardians.
es: When we arrive at the office, I enter; he waits outside, in the lobby with the other Guardians and sits in one of the chairs installed for that purpose.

en: Inside the waiting room there are other women, three of them, in red: this doctor is a specialist.
vi: In the waiting room, there were a few other women, three in total, all dressed in red: this is a specialized clinic.
tr: There are other women in the waiting room, three of them in red dresses: this doctor is a specialist.
es: In the waiting room, there are other women, three of them dressed in red: this doctor is a specialist.

en: Covertly we regard each other, sizing up each other's bellies: is anyone lucky?
vi: We secretly looked at each other, measuring each other's bellies: is anyone lucky?
tr: We are secretly looking at each other, measuring our bellies: is anyone lucky?
es: We glance furtively at each other, evaluating the size of our respective bellies. Has any of us been lucky?

en: The nurse records our names and the numbers from our passes on the Compudoc, to see if we are who we are supposed to be.
vi: The orderly entered our names and the numbers from our passes into the Italian computer, checking if anyone was falsely claiming an identity.
tr: The male nurse is recording our names and the numbers on our ID cards into the Compudoc, to see if we are who we are supposed to be.
es: The nurse records our names and the numbers of our passes in the Compudoc, to check if we are who we are supposed to be.

en: He's six feet tall, about forty, a diagonal scar across his check; he sits typing, his hands too big for the keyboard, still wearing his pistol in the shoulder holster.
vi: He was six feet tall, around forty, with a scar crossing his cheek; he sat and typed, his hands oversized for the keyboard, a pistol still holstered on his shoulder.
tr: 1. He is 1.80 meters tall, around forty years old, and has a scar running diagonally across his cheek; he is typing, though his hands are too big for the keyboard, and he still carries his gun in a holster under his arm.
es: He is a man of about forty years old, around six feet tall, with a scar running diagonally across his cheek; he is typing and his hands look too large in relation to the keyboard; he still carries the gun in its holster.

en: When I'm called I go through the doorway intothe inner room.
vi: When I heard my name called, I walked through the door into the inner room.
tr: When I am called, I pass through the door and enter the inner room.
es: When they call me, I go into the inner room.

en: It's white, featureless, like the outer one, except for the folding screen.
vi: The room was painted white, sparsely furnished, just like the outer room, except for a folding screen with red fabric stretched over the frame, depicting a golden Eye, with a sword entwined by two snakes standing upright below it, resembling a hilt.
tr: A white room, featureless, just like the outer room, but here there is a folding screen, a red fabric stretched over a frame, with a golden eye on it, and below that, a sword wrapped with a snake, like some kind of handle.
es: It is white, and there is no striking detail in it, just like in the outer one, except for a screen —a piece of red cloth stretched over a frame— with an eye painted in gold and below it a snake coiled around a sword, in a vertical position, like a kind of handle.

en: red cloth stretched on a frame, a gold Eye painted on it, with a snake-twined sword upright beneath it, like a sort of handle.
vi: The room was painted white, sparsely furnished, just like the outer room, except for a folding screen with red fabric stretched over the frame, depicting a golden Eye, with a sword entwined by two snakes standing upright below it, resembling a hilt.
tr: A white room, featureless, just like the outer room, but here there is a folding screen, a red fabric stretched over a frame, with a golden eye on it, and below that, a sword wrapped with a snake, like some kind of handle.
es: It is white, and there is no striking detail in it, just like in the outer one, except for a screen —a piece of red cloth stretched over a frame— with an eye painted in gold and below it a snake coiled around a sword, in a vertical position, like a kind of handle.

en: The snakes and the sword are bits of broken symbolism left over from the time before.
vi: Snakes and sword, remnants of symbolic fragments.
tr: Snakes and swords are remnants of a broken symbolism from a previous time.
es: The snakes and the swords are remnants of the symbolism of past eras.

en: After I've filled the small bottle left ready for me in the little washroom, I take off my clothes, behind the screen, and leave themfolded on the chair.
vi: After placing the small jar ready in the restroom compartment, I took off my clothes behind the screen, folded them neatly, and placed them on the chair.
tr: After filling the small bottle left for me in the small bathroom, I take off my clothes behind the screen and leave them folded on the chair.
es: I fill the jar that they have left prepared for me in the bathroom, I take off my clothes behind the screen and leave them folded on the chair.

en: When I'm naked I lie down on the examining table, on the sheet of chilly crackling disposable paper.
vi: Naked as a jaybird, I lay on the examination table, on the crinkly disposable paper sheet.
tr: When I am naked, I lie down on the examination table, on the cold, crinkling, disposable paper sheet, and pull the second sheet, the fabric one, over my body.
es: When I finish undressing, I lie down on the stretcher, on the disposable paper sheet, cold and crunchy.

en: I pull the second sheet, the cloth one, up over my body.
vi: I pulled the second sheet, made of fabric, over myself.
tr: When I am naked, I lie down on the examination table, on the cold, crinkling, disposable paper sheet, and pull the second sheet, the fabric one, over my body.
es: I stretch the second sheet, the cloth one, over my body.

en: At neck level there's another sheet, suspended from the ceiling.
vi: At neck level, there was another sheet, hanging down from the ceiling.
tr: There is another sheet hanging down from the ceiling at neck level.
es: At the level of my neck, there is a third sheet hanging from the ceiling.

en: It intersects me so that the doctor will never see my face.
vi: It divided my body so the doctor couldn't see my face.
tr: It divides me in two, so that the doctor will never see my face.
es: This one comes between the doctor and me so that he cannot see my face.

en: He deals with a torso only.
vi: He only worked with a body.
tr: He is only interested in a body.
es: He will only have to deal with a torso.

en: When I'm arranged I reach my hand out, fumble for the small lever at the right side of the table, pull it back.
vi: When everything was in place, I reached out, felt for the lever on the right side of the table, and pulled it.
tr: When I am ready, I reach out and pull back the small lever on the right side of the table.
es: Once ready, I stretch out my hand and grope for the small lever that is to the right of the table; I pull it back.

en: Somewhere else a bell rings, unheard by me.
vi: A bell would ring somewhere, but I couldn't hear it.
tr: A bell rings somewhere else, one that I cannot hear.
es: Somewhere else a bell rings, but I do not hear it.

en: After a minute the dooropens, footsteps come in, there is breathing.
vi: A minute later, the door opened, footsteps entered, and there was breathing.
tr: A minute later, the door opens, footsteps enter, and the sound of breathing is heard.
es: A minute later the door opens and the steps and breathing of someone entering can be heard.

en: He isn't supposed to speak to me except when it's absolutely necessary.
vi: He was not supposed to talk to me unless absolutely necessary.
tr: It is not expected to speak to me unless absolutely necessary.
es: He must not speak to me unless it is absolutely necessary.

en: But this doctor is talkative.
vi: But this doctor was quite talkative.
tr: But this doctor is talkative.
es: But this doctor is very talkative.

en: "How are we getting along?" he says, some tic of speech from the other time.
vi: “How are we doing?” he asked, a linguistic habit left over from the old days.
tr: “How are you?” he says, in a manner of speaking from another time.
es: —How are we doing? —he asks, using a speech tic from bygone times.

en: The sheet is lifted from my skin, a draft pimples me.
vi: The sheet was lifted off my skin, the draft making me break out in goosebumps.
tr: The fabric is lifted off my skin, a breeze sends a shiver through me.
es: He pulls back the sheet from my skin and a shiver runs through my body.

en: A
vi: The sheet was lifted off my skin, the draft making me break out in goosebumps.
tr: The fabric is lifted off my skin, a breeze sends a shiver through me.
es: He pulls back the sheet from my skin and a shiver runs through my body.

en: cold finger, rubber-clad and jellied, slides into me, I am poked and prodded.
vi: A finger, encased in rubber cold as jelly, slipped inside me, I was prodded, pressed.
tr: A cold finger, rubber-covered and lubricated, slides inside me, probing and poking.
es: A cold finger, covered in rubber and jelly, slides inside me, probing my interior.

en: The finger retreats, enters otherwise, withdraws.
vi: The finger withdrew, entered another way, then retreated.
tr: The finger withdraws, entering and exiting in a different way.
es: The finger withdraws, enters in a different direction, and then pulls back.

en: "Nothing wrong with you," the doctor says, as if to himself.
vi: “No issues at all,” the doctor said, as if speaking to himself.
tr: “No problem,” says the doctor, as if to himself.
es: —Everything is fine —he comments, as if talking to himself—.

en: "Any pain, honey?"
vi: “Does it hurt anywhere, dear?”
tr: “Do you have any pain, sweetie?”
es: Does anything hurt, darling?

en: He calls me honey.
vi: He called me dear.
tr: He calls me sweetie.
es: —He calls me darling.

en: "No," I say.
vi: "No," I said.
tr: "No," I say.
es: —No —I respond.

en: My breasts are fingered in their turn, a search for ripeness, rot.
vi: My chest was being squeezed and examined to see if it was ripe or rotten.
tr: When the time comes, my breasts are also examined for signs of maturity and deterioration.
es: Now it's the turn of my breasts, which are palpated in search of any abscess.

en: The breathing comes nearer.
vi: The breath came closer.
tr: His breath approaches, I smell stale smoke, aftershave lotion, tobacco dust in his hair.
es: The breathing gets closer, I perceive the smell of smoke, of aftershave lotion.

en: I smell old smoke, aftershave, tobacco dust on hair.
vi: I smelled the scent of smoke, aftershave, and cigarette ash clinging to the hair.
tr: His breath approaches, I smell stale smoke, aftershave lotion, tobacco dust in his hair.
es: The breathing gets closer, I perceive the smell of smoke, of aftershave lotion.

en: Then the voice, very soft, close to my head: that's him, bulging the sheet.
vi: Then a voice, very soft, right near my head: it was him, his head buried in the curtain.
tr: Then the voice, very soft, close to my head: it's him, creating a bulge in the sheet:
es: Then the voice, very soft, close to my face: it is him, who moves the sheet.

en: "I could help you," he says.
vi: "I can help you," he said.
tr: “I can help you,” he says.
es: —I could help you —he says, whispering.

en: Whispers.
vi: Whispered.
tr: He whispers.
es: —I could help you —he says, whispering.

en: "What?" I say.
vi: “What?” I said.
tr: “What?” I say.
es: —What? —I ask.

en: "Shh," he says.
vi: "Shh," he said.
tr: “Shhh,” he says.
es: —Shhh —he warns me—.

en: "I could help you.
vi: "I can help you.
tr: “I can help you.
es: I could help you.

en: I've helped others."
vi: I've helped many people already."
tr: I’ve helped others.”
es: I have helped others.

tr: But he mostly said this when my mother was around.
es: But in general, he said it when my mother was present.

vi: He enjoyed teasing her.
tr: He loved teasing her.

vi: I turned around and the child was disappearing at the end of the aisle, in the hands of a strange woman.
tr: When I turned around, I saw a woman I had never seen before disappearing down the passageway in someone's arms.
es: I turned around and saw that she was disappearing down the hallway, in the arms of a woman I had never seen before.

en: I screamed, and the woman was stoppctl.
vi: I screamed, she was held back.
tr: When I shouted, someone stopped the woman.
es: I shouted and the woman stopped.

en: She must havebeen about thirty-five.
vi: She looked about thirty-five.
tr: She must have been around thirty-five years old.
es: She must have been about thirty-five years old.

en: She was crying and saying it was her baby, the Lord had given it to her, he'd sent her a sign.
vi: She was crying, saying this was her child, God had given it to her, He had given her a sign.
tr: She was crying and saying that it was her own baby, that it was given to her by God, and that God had sent her a sign.
es: She was crying and saying that it was her baby, that the Lord had given it to her, that He had sent her a sign.

en: I felt sorry for her.
vi: I felt sorry for her.
tr: I felt sorry for her.
es: I felt sorry for her.

en: The store manager apologized and they held her until the police came.
vi: The store owner apologized and they held her until the police arrived.
tr: The store manager apologized and they held her until the police arrived.
es: The store manager apologized, and they detained her until the police arrived.

en: She's just crazy, Luke said.
vi: This woman is just crazy, Luke said.
tr: Gone crazy, said Luke.
es: She's simply crazy, said Luke.

en: I thought it was an isolated incident, at the time.
vi: I think it was an isolated incident, back then.
tr: At that time, I thought it was an isolated incident.
es: At that moment, I believed it was an isolated incident.

en: She fades, I can't keep her here with me, she's gone now.
vi: The child fades away, I can't hold on, the child is gone.
tr: She is disappearing, I can't keep her here with me, now she's gone.
es: Her image fades, I can't keep her here with me, she has already disappeared.

en: Maybe I do think of her as a ghost, the ghost of a dead girl, a little girl who died when she was five.
vi: Perhaps it's true that I also see the child as a ghost, the ghost of a little girl who died, a girl who died at the age of five.
tr: Maybe I really think of her as a ghost, the ghost of a dead girl; a little girl who died at the age of five.
es: Maybe I do think of her as a ghost, the ghost of a dead girl, a creature who died when she was five years old.

en: I remember the pictures of us I once had, me holding her,standard poses, mother and baby, locked in a frame, for safety.
vi: I remember the old photographs, I held the child, mother and baby, captured in a frame, to keep safe.
tr: I remember the photographs I once had: holding her in my arms, standard poses, mother and baby, trapped in a frame, for safety.
es: I remember the photos I once had of the two of us, me holding her in my arms, in typical poses, enclosed in a frame and safe.

en: Behind my closed eyes I can see myself as I am now, sitting beside an open drawer, or a trunk, in the cellar, where the baby clothes are folded away, a lock of hair, cut when she was two, inan envelope, white-blond.
vi: With my eyes closed, I see myself now, sitting beside an open drawer, or a chest, in the basement, baby clothes folded and stored there, a lock of hair, cut when the child was two, placed in an envelope, platinum blonde.
tr: Behind my closed eyes, I can see myself as I am now: in the pantry, sitting beside an open drawer or chest where baby clothes are folded and stored, and a lock of light yellow hair cut when she was two years old and placed in an envelope.
es: From behind my closed eyes, I see myself as I am now, sitting next to an open drawer, or next to a trunk in the basement, where I keep the folded baby clothes and an envelope with a lock of hair from when she was two years old, light blonde in color.

en: It got darker later.
vi: It darkened later.
tr: Her hair darkened later.
es: Then it darkened.

en: I don't have those things anymore, the clothes and hair.
vi: I no longer have them, the clothes and the hairpiece.
tr: I no longer have these, the clothes and the hair.
es: I no longer have those things, neither the clothes nor the hair.

en: I wonder what happened to all our things.
vi: I wonder what happened to all my belongings.
tr: I wonder what happened to all our belongings.
es: I wonder what happened to our belongings.

en: Looted, dumped out, carried away.
vi: Stolen, thrown away, taken.
tr: They were looted, emptied, moved.
es: Looted, thrown away, and torn apart.

en: Confiscated.
vi: Confiscated.
tr: They were confiscated.
es: Confiscated.

en: I've learned to do without a lot of things.
vi: I have learned how to live without needing too many possessions.
tr: I learned to live without many things.
es: I have learned to manage without a lot of things.

en: If you have a lot of things, said Aunt Lydia, you get too attached to this material world and you forget about spiritual values.
vi: If you have many possessions, Aunt Lydia said, you will be bound to this material world and forget about spiritual values.
tr: If you have too much, Aunt Lydia used to say, you become overly attached to this material world and forget spiritual values.
es: If you have too many things, Aunt Lydia used to say, you cling too much to the material world and forget spiritual values.

en: You must cultivate poverty of spirit.
vi: You need to nurture a humble soul.
tr: You must nurture spiritual poverty.
es: If you have too many things, Aunt Lydia used to say, you cling too much to the material world and forget spiritual values.

en: Blessed are the meek.
vi: Blessed are the meek.
tr: Those who are patient and meek are blessed.
es: Blessed are the humble.

en: She didn't go on to say anything about inheriting the earth.
vi: She did not say anything more about inheriting the promised land.
tr: She didn't say anything about inheriting the earth, for some reason.
es: She did not add anything about them inheriting the earth.

en: I lie, lapped by the water, beside an open drawer that does not exist, and think about a girl who did not die when she was five; who still does exist, I hope, though not for me.
vi: I lay there, water lapping over me, beside a non-existent open drawer, thinking about a little girl who never died when she was five; a little girl who still exists, I hope, though not because of me.
tr: I'm lying down, surrounded by water, next to a non-existent open drawer, thinking of a girl who didn't die at five years old, hoping she still exists, though not for me.
es: I remain lying down, with the water gently lapping against my body, next to an open drawer that doesn't exist, and I think of a girl who didn't die when she was five years old; who still exists, I hope, although not for me.

en: Do I exist for her?
vi: Do I exist for her?
tr: I wonder if I exist for her?
es: Do I exist for her?

es: Am I an image in the darkness in the deepest part of her mind?

en: That's what they would think of doing.

vi: They would say that to help you adapt more easily.

en: Eight, she must be now.
vi: Eight years old, it must be that long.

es: She must be eight years old now.

es: They were right, it's easier to think that she is dead.

vi: I wouldn't have to hope or make futile efforts.
tr: In this case, I don't have to hope or strive in vain.
es: That way I don't have to harbor hopes, nor make a futile effort.

es: Why bang your head against the wall?, Aunt Lydia used to say.

es: Sometimes she had a very graphic way of saying things.

en: It's true, she hasn't.

en: Such puritan aids are supplied.
vi: There are such puritanical items like that.

en: I am a national resource.

es: It must have been a long time ago, because I can't remember it.

en: I like her for that.

vi: Good for health.

en: Weave, knit, something to do with my hands.
vi: To weave, to knit, anything to keep my hands busy.
tr: Weaving, knitting; something to do with my hands.
es: If only I could embroider, or knit, do something with my hands... I want a cigarette.

en: I want a cigarette.
vi: I crave a cigarette.
tr: I want a cigarette.
es: If only I could embroider, or knit, do something with my hands... I want a cigarette.

en: I remember walking in art galleries, through the nineteenth century: the obsession they had then with harems.
vi: I remember walking through the exhibits, through the nineteenth century: back then people were obsessed with the harem theme.
tr: I remember wandering through art galleries, from the nineteenth century building: their obsession with harems at that time.
es: I remember when I used to visit art galleries, going through the nineteenth century, and their obsession with harems.

en: Dozens of paintings of harems, fat women lolling on divans, turbans on their heads or velvet caps, being fanned with peacock tails, a eunuch in the background standing guard.
vi: Dozens of harem paintings, plump women lounging in Turkish palaces, wearing military caps or velvet caps, fanning themselves with peacock feathers, with an eunuch standing menacingly in the background.
tr: Dozens of harem paintings; fat women lying sprawled on divans, with turbans or velvet caps on their heads, fanning themselves with peacock feathers, a harem guard standing watch in the background.
es: Lots of paintings of harems, fat women lounging on divans, with turbans on their heads or velvet headpieces, fanned with peacock feathers by a eunuch standing guard in the background.

en: Studies of sedentary flesh, painted by men who'd never been there.
vi: Exercises in depicting lazy flesh, by those who had never been there.
tr: Studies on motionless bodies, paintings made by men who had never been there.
