es: Studies of sedentary bodies, painted by men who had never been there.

en: These pictures were supposed to be erotic, and I thought they were, at the time; but I see now what they were really about
vi: Those paintings were considered erotic, and I think they were, at that time; but now I truly understand what they were saying.
tr: These paintings were considered erotic, and I thought so too, back then, but now I understand what they were really about.
es: These paintings were supposed to be erotic, and they seemed so to me back then; but now I understand their true meaning: they depicted interrupted joy, a wait, objects that were not used.

en: They were paintings
vi: Those paintings were considered erotic, and I think they were, at that time; but now I truly understand what they were saying.
tr: These paintings were considered erotic, and I thought so too, back then, but now I understand what they were really about.
es: These paintings were supposed to be erotic, and they seemed so to me back then; but now I understand their true meaning: they depicted interrupted joy, a wait, objects that were not used.

en: about suspended animation; about wailing, about objects not in use.
vi: They depicted interrupted activity; they depicted waiting, unused objects.
tr: They were about the lack of vitality; about waiting, about unused objects.
es: These paintings were supposed to be erotic, and they seemed so to me back then; but now I understand their true meaning: they depicted interrupted joy, a wait, objects that were not used.

en: They were paintings about boredom.
vi: They depicted boredom.
tr: They were about boredom.
es: They were paintings that represented boredom.

en: But maybe boredom is erotic, when women do it, for men.
vi: But perhaps boredom is enticing to men if it is the boredom of women.
tr: But perhaps boredom is erotic, women and men endure it for each other.
es: But perhaps boredom is erotic, at least for men, when it comes from women.

en: I wait, washed, brushed, fed, like a prize pig.
vi: I waited, having been bathed, groomed, and fed, like a prize-winning pig.
tr: I'm waiting, washed, brushed, fed, like a prize pig.
es: I wait, washed, brushed, fed, like a pig that is given as a prize.

en: Sometime in the eighties they invented pig balls, for pigs who were being fattened in pens.
vi: Around the eighties, they came up with pig balls, meant for the friends who were getting fat in the pen.
tr: In the eighties, they had invented pig balls for a while, for the pigs fattened in pens.
es: In the 1980s, they invented balls for pigs, and they gave them to the pigs that were fattened in pigsties.

en: Pig balls were large colored balls; the pigs rolled them around with their snouts.
vi: These were large, colorful balls for the pigs to push around with their snouts.
tr: These were large colorful balls; the pigs were rolling them here and there with their snouts.
es: They were large and colorful balls, and the pigs would roll them around using their snouts.

en: The pig marketers said this improved their muscle tone;the pigs were curious,they liekd to have some-thing to think about.
vi: The pig traders said this would increase muscle tension; the naturally curious pigs would be happy to have something to think about.
tr: Pig sellers claimed that this improved muscle quality; pigs were curious animals, they liked having something to think about.
es: Pork sellers said that this improved muscle tone; the pigs were curious, they liked having something to think about.

en: I read about that in introduction to Psychology; that, and the chapter on caged rats who'd give themselves electric shocks for something to do And the one on the pigeons, trained to peck abutton that made a grain of corn appear.
vi: I read that in the introductory Psychology course; that, along with the chapter about the rats in the cage that self-administer electric shocks just to have something to do. And the chapter about the pigeons, trained to peck a button that would release a grain of corn.
tr: I had read this in the Introduction to Psychology class; this and the section about the rats in the cage given electric shocks to make them perform a task. And also about the pigeons trained to peck a button that produced a corn kernel.
es: I read that in Introduction to Psychology; that, and the chapter about the laboratory rats that administered electric shocks to themselves, just to do something. And the one who spoke of the trained pigeons to peck at a bud that made a grain of corn appear.

en: Three groups of them: the first got one grain per peck, the second one grain every other peck, the third was random.
vi: There were three groups: the first group always got it, the second group got it every other time, and the last group got it randomly.
tr: These pigeons were divided into three groups: the first group received a corn kernel for every peck, the second group for every two pecks, and the third group randomly.
es: They were divided into three groups: the first picked a grain with each peck; the second, one every two pecks, and the third did it haphazardly.

en: When the man in charge cut off the grain, the first group gave up quite soon, the second group alittle later.
vi: When the person in charge stopped giving corn, the first group gave up quite early, the second group took longer.
tr: When the man overseeing the experiment stopped the flow of corn, the first group gave up shortly, the second group a bit later.
es: When the person in charge of the experiment took the grain away, the first group gave up immediately, and the second group a little later.

en: The third group never gave up.
vi: The last group did not give up.
tr: The third group never gave up.
es: The third group never gave up.

en: They'd peck themselves to death, rather than quit.
vi: They would rather peck until they died than stop.
tr: They continued pecking until they died rather than stop.
es: They would have pecked themselves to death before giving up.

en: Who knew what worked?
vi: Who knows which is better?
tr: Who knows what will work?
es: Who knows what the cause was.

en: I wish I had a pig ball.
vi: I wish I had a pig ball.
tr: If only I had a pig ball.
es: I would like to have one of those balls for pigs.

en: I lie down on the braided rug.
vi: I lay down on the braided mat.
tr: I lie down on the woven carpet.
es: I lie down on the braided rug.

en: You can always practice, said Aunt Lydia.
vi: You can practice anytime, Aunt Lydia said.
tr: You can always practice, Aunt Lydia used to say.
es: You can always train yourself, Aunt Lydia used to say.

en: Several sessions a day, fitted into yourdaily routine.
vi: A few times a day, interspersed with other tasks.
tr: Several times a day, according to your daily tasks.
es: Several sessions a day, while you're immersed in your daily routine.

en: Arms at the sides, knees bent, lift the pelvis, roll the backbone down.
vi: Hands on hips, knees bent, lift the hips, spine pressed down.
tr: Arms at your sides, knees bent, lift your pelvis, roll your spine down.
es: Arms at your sides, knees bent, you lift your pelvis and lower your spine.

en: Tuck.
vi: Hug the knees and rock up.
tr: Breathe in.
es: Arms at your sides, knees bent, you lift your pelvis and lower your spine.

en: Again.
vi: Repeat.
tr: Repeat.
es: Now up, and again.

en: Breathe in to the count of five, hold, expel.
vi: Inhale counting to five, hold the breath, exhale.
tr: Breathe in, hold, release, counting to five.
es: You count to five and inhale, hold your breath and release it.

en: We'd do that in what used to be the Domestic Science room, cleared now of sewing machines and washer-dryers;in unison, lying on little Jap-anese mats, a tape playing, Les Sylphides.
vi: We practiced in what used to be the room Housekeeping, the sewing machine and washer-dryer have been cleaned; simultaneously, lying on the narrow tatami mat, the cassette player is on, Les Sylphides.
tr: We used to do this in the room that used to be the Household Management room, where the sewing machines and clothes dryers had been removed; lying on small Japanese-style mats, while a tape played Les Sylphides, in unison.
es: We did it in what used to be the Home Economics room, now free of washing machines and dryers; in unison, lying on small Japanese mats, while a cassette of Les Sylphides played.

en: That's what I hear now, in my head, as I lift, tilt, breathe.
vi: I can still hear it now, in my head, as I rise, bend, inhale, and exhale.
tr: Now, as I lift, lie to the side, and breathe in, this is what I hear inside my head.
es: That's what now echoes in my mind, as I go up, down, and breathe.

en: Behind my closed eyes thin white dancers flit gracefully among the trees, their legs fluttering like the wings of held birds.
vi: Behind closed eyes, the slender white dancers swiftly glide among the trees, gracefully, their legs fluttering like the wings of birds caught in a trap.
tr: Behind my closed eyes, among the trees, thin white dancers move gracefully back and forth, their legs fluttering like the wings of trapped birds.
es: Behind my closed eyes, ethereal dancers gracefully flit among the trees and flutter their legs like the wings of a caged bird.

en: In the afternoons we lay on our beds for an hour in the gymnasium, between three and four.
vi: In the afternoons, we would lie on our beds for about an hour in the gymnasium, from three to four o'clock.
tr: In the afternoons, for an hour, between three and four, we would lie in our beds in the gymnasium.
es: In the afternoons we lay down in our beds, in the gym, for an hour: from three to four.

en: They said it was a period of rest and
vi: They said it was a time for meditative rest.
tr: They would say it was a time for rest and meditation.
es: They said it was a time for rest and meditation.

en: meditation.
vi: They said it was a time for meditative rest.
tr: They would say it was a time for rest and meditation.
es: They said it was a time for rest and meditation.

en: I thought then they did it because they wanted some time off themselves, from teaching us, and I know the Aunts not on duty went off to the teachers' room for a cup of coffee, or whatever they called by that name.
vi: Back then, I thought it was just because they themselves wanted a break from teaching, and I knew the nuns on duty would go to the staff room for a cup of coffee, or something they called coffee.
tr: At the time, I thought they did it to stop training us and give themselves a little break; I knew the Aunts who were off duty would go to the teachers' lounge for a cup of coffee or whatever they called it.
es: Back then I believed they did it because they wanted to get rid of us for a while, to take a break from the classes, and I know that outside of service hours the Aunts would go to the teachers' room to have a cup of coffee, or what they called that, whatever it was.

en: But now I think that the rest also was practice.
vi: But now I think even the rest period was a form of training.
tr: But now I think this rest was also an exercise.
es: But now I think the rest was also a training.

en: They were giving us a chance to get used to blank time.
vi: It gave us a chance to get used to having free time.
tr: They were giving us a chance to get used to having free time.
es: They were giving us the opportunity to get used to the empty hours.

en: A catnap, Aunt Lydia called it, in her coy way.
vi: Nap time, Aunt Lydia called it, shyly as usual.
tr: "A candy," said Aunt Lydia with her coquettish manner.
es: A little nap, Aunt Lydia called it in her prim style.

en: The strange thing is we needed the rest.
vi: Strangely, we needed a break.
tr: The strange thing was that we also needed this rest.
es: The strange thing is that we needed to rest.

en: Many of us went to sleep.
vi: Many people dozed off.
tr: Most of us would sleep.
es: Almost all of us were going to sleep.

en: We were tired there, a lot of the time.
vi: There, we were very tired, almost always exhausted.
tr: We were often tired there.
es: We were tired most of the time Of time.

en: We were on some kind of pill or drug 1 think, they put it in the food, to keep us calm.
vi: We might have been given some kind of pill or liquid medicine, I guess, mixed into the food, to calm us down.
tr: I think we were under the influence of a pill or drug they put in the food to calm us down.
es: I suppose they gave us some kind of pills, or drugs, which they put in the food to keep us calm.

en: But maybe not.
vi: It might not have been that.
tr: But maybe there was no such thing.
es: Or maybe not.

en: Maybe it was the place itself.
vi: It could have been due to this very place.
tr: Maybe that was the reason for that place.
es: Maybe it was the place.

en: After the first shock, after you'd come to terms, it was better to be lethargic.
vi: After the initial shock, after adapting, it was better to remain in a semi-conscious state.
tr: After the initial shock, once we had settled down, it was better to be lethargic.
es: After the first impression, once you had adapted, it was better to remain in a lethargic state.

en: You could tell yourself you were saving up your strength.
vi: One could tell oneself that it was just conserving energy.
tr: You could say you were conserving your strength.
es: You could tell yourself that you were saving strength.

en: I must have been there three weeks when Moira came.
vi: I must have been there for about three weeks when Moira arrived.
tr: When Moira arrived, I must have spent three weeks there.
es: When Moira arrived, I must have been there for three weeks.

en: She was brought into the gymnasium by two of the Aunts, in the usual way, while we were having our nap.
vi: She was brought into the gymnasium by two Aunts, as usual, while we were napping.
tr: She had been brought to the gym by the two Aunts, as usual, while we were taking our nap.
es: She entered the gym accompanied by two of the Aunts, as usual, at nap time.

en: She still had her other clothes on, jeans and a blue sweatshirther hair was short, she'd defied fashion as usualso I recognized her at once.
vi: She was still wearing her old clothes, jeans, a tight green t-shirt - her hair cut short, still defying fashion as always - so I recognized her immediately.
tr: She was still in her clothes, jeans and a blue sweatshirt - her hair was short, as usual she defied fashion - so I recognized her immediately.
es: She was still wearing her clothes —jeans and a blue tracksuit— and had short hair —to defy fashion, as usual—, which is why I recognized her immediately.

en: She saw me too, but she turned away, she already knew what was safe.
vi: She saw me too, but turned away, she had already understood what was safe.
tr: She saw me too, but turned in another direction, she had already learned what was safe as soon as she arrived.
es: She saw me, but turned away: she already knew what was most prudent.

en: There was a bruiseon her left cheek, turning purple.
vi: Her left cheek had a bruise, turning purple.
tr: There was a bruise on her left cheek, starting to turn purple.
es: She had a purple bruise on her left cheek.

en: The Aunts took her to a vacant bed where the red dress was already laid out.
vi: The Aunts took her to a bed that already had a red dress laid out.
tr: The Aunts took her to an empty bed where the red dress had been prepared and placed on it.
es: The Aunts took her to an empty bed, where the red dress was already prepared.

en: She undressed, began to dress again, in silence, the Aunts standing at the end of the bed, the rest of us watching from inside our slitted eyes.
vi: She undressed, started changing, not saying a word, the Aunts stood at the foot of the bed, and we watched through slitted eyes.
tr: While the Aunts stood at the foot of the bed and the rest of us watched through our half-closed eyes, she undressed silently, then began to dress again.
es: She undressed and started dressing again, in silence, while the Aunts stood at one end of the bed and we watched her with barely open eyes.

en: As she bent over I could see the knobs on her spine.
vi: When she bent over, I could see the joints of her spine.
tr: When she bent forward, I could see the bumps on her spine.
es: When she turned, I saw the protrusions of her spine.

en: I couldn't talk to her for several days; we looked only, small glances, like sips.
vi: For several days I couldn't talk to her; we only exchanged glances, very quickly, in small sips.
tr: I couldn't talk to him for a few days; we were just looking at each other with glances as small as sips.
es: I couldn't talk to her for several days; we only exchanged brief glances, as a test.

en: Friendships were suspicious, we knew it, we avoided each other during the mealtime line-ups in the cafeteria and in the halls between classes.
vi: Friendship is suspicious, we knew, and we avoided each other when lining up for lunch in the canteen as well as in the hallway between classes.
tr: Friendships were suspicious, we knew this, we kept our distance from each other in the cafeteria lunch lines and in the hallways between classes.
es: Friendship was suspicious, we knew it, so we avoided each other during meal times, in the cafeteria lines, and in the hallways, between classes.

en: But on the fourth day she was beside me during the walk, two by two around the football field.
vi: But on the fourth day, she lined up next to me during the walk, forming pairs parading around the football field.
tr: But on the fourth day, during our paired walk around the football field, he fell in step beside me.
es: But on the fourth day, she was by my side during the walk we took two by two around the football field.

en: We weren't given the white wings until we graduated, we had only the veils; so we could talk, as long as we did it quietly and didn't turn to look at one another.
vi: We hadn't received our white wings yet because we hadn't graduated, only the veil, so we could talk, as long as it was very quietly and without turning to look at each other.
tr: White wings were not given until graduation, there were only veils; thus, we could talk as long as we didn't raise our voices and didn't turn our heads to look at each other.
es: Until we graduated, we weren't given the white cap, and we only wore the veil, so we could talk, with the precaution of speaking in a low voice and not turning our heads to look at each other.

en: The Aunts walked at the head of the line and at the end, so
vi: The aunts walked at the front and back of the line, so the only risk was the rest of the group.
tr: The Aunts would walk at the front and back of the line, so the only danger could come from the others.
es: The Aunts walked at the beginning and end of the line, so the only danger was the others.

en: the only danger was from the others.
vi: The aunts walked at the front and back of the line, so the only risk was the rest of the group.
tr: The Aunts would walk at the front and back of the line, so the only danger could come from the others.
es: The Aunts walked at the beginning and end of the line, so the only danger was the others.

en: Some were believers and might report us.
vi: Some were very devout, they could report us.
tr: Some were believers and could report us.
es: Some were believers and could report us.

en: This is a loony bin, Moira said.
vi: It really is a crazy camp, Moira said.
tr: This is a madhouse, said Moira.
es: This is a madhouse, stated Moira.

en: I'm so glad to see you, I said.
vi: Seeing you makes me so happy, I said.
tr: I am so happy to see you, I said.
es: I am so happy to see you..., I told him.

en: Where can we talk?
vi: Where can we talk?
tr: Where can we talk?
es: Where can we talk?, he asked me.

en: said Moira.
vi: Moira said.
tr: said Moira.
es: Where can we talk?, he asked me.

en: Washroom, I said.
vi: The restroom, I said.
tr: In the bathroom, I said.
es: In the bathrooms, I replied.

en: Watch the clock.
vi: Remember to look at the clock.
tr: Look at the time.
es: Watch the clock.

en: End stall, two-thirty.
vi: Last stall, two-thirty.
tr: The last stall, at two thirty.
es: The last stall, at two-thirty.

en: That was all we said.
vi: We just said that.
tr: This was all we talked about.
es: It was everything we said.

en: It makes me feel safer, that Moira is here.
vi: I feel safer, Moira is here.
tr: Having Moira here makes me feel safer.
es: The fact that Moira is here makes me feel safer.

en: We can go to the washroom if we put our hands up, though there's a limit to how many times a day, they mark it down on a chart.
vi: We are allowed to go to the restroom, just need to raise our hand, although there is a limit on the number of times we can go each day, and there is a chart to mark it.
tr: If we raise our hands, we can go to the bathroom, although there is a limit of a few times a day because they record it on a card.
es: We can go to the bathroom as long as we raise our hand, because there is a maximum number of times per day, and they record it on a chart.

en: I watch the clock, electric and round, at the front over the green blackboard.
vi: I keep track of the time, a round battery-operated clock, at the top of the class above the green blackboard.
tr: I'm looking at the electric and round clock above the green board at the front, it's two thirty, which coincides with Confession Hour.
es: I look at the clock, electric and round, which is in front, above the green chalkboard.

en: Two-thirty comes during Testifying.
vi: Two-thirty is exactly the middle of Fox hour.
tr: I'm looking at the electric and round clock above the green board at the front, it's two thirty, which coincides with Confession Hour.
es: When it strikes two-thirty, we are in Testimony session.

en: Aunt Helena is here, as well as Aunt Lydia, because Testifying is special.
vi: Aunt Helena is here, along with Aunt Lydia, because Fox hour is a special time.
tr: Aunt Lydia is here along with Aunt Helena, because Confession Hour is special.
es: Aunt Helena is here, in addition to Aunt Lydia, because the Testimony session is something special.

en: Aunt Helena is fat, . she once headed a Weight Watchers' franchise operation in Iowa, She's good at Testifying.
vi: Aunt Helena is quite fat, she used to head the Weight Watchers branch in Iowa. When it comes to Fox hour, she is very proficient.
tr: Aunt Lydia is fat, she used to be in charge of the Regime's agency in Iowa. She is good at getting confessions.
es: Aunt Helena is fat; once, in Iowa, she led a campaign to obtain Weight Watchers licenses. She is good at Testimony sessions.

en: It's Janine, telling about how she was gang-raped at fourteen and had an abortion.
vi: It's Janine again, telling the story of how she was gang-raped at fourteen and had to get an abortion.
tr: Janine, at the age of fourteen, is describing how she was raped by a gang and had an abortion.
es: It's Janine's turn, who recounts how at fourteen she was raped by a gang and had an abortion.

en: She told the same story ast week.
vi: Last week she told the exact same story.
tr: She told the same story last week as well.
es: Last week she told the same story, and she seemed almost proud of it.

en: She seemed almost proud of it, while she was telling.
vi: She almost seemed proud while telling it.
tr: While telling it, she almost seemed to take pride in it.
es: Last week she told the same story, and she seemed almost proud of it.

en: It may not even be true.
vi: That story might not even be true.
tr: It might not even be true.
es: It might not even be true.

en: At Testifying,it's safer to make things upthan to say you have nothing to reveal.
vi: When it comes to Testimony time, it's safer to make something up than to say you have nothing to report.
tr: It's better to make something up than to say you have nothing to reveal during Confession Hour.
es: In Testimony sessions, it's safer to make something up than to say you have nothing to reveal.

en: But since it's Janine, it's probably more or less true.
vi: But with Janine, it could very well be at least somewhat true.
tr: However, since it's Janine we're talking about, what she says is more or less true.
es: Although in Janine's case, it's probably more or less true.

en: But whose fault was it?
vi: But whose fault is it?
tr: But whose fault was this?
es: But whose fault was it?

en: Aunt Helena says, holding up one plump finger.
vi: Aunt Helena asked, raising a chubby finger.
tr: says Aunt Helena, raising her stubby finger.
es: asks Aunt Helena while raising a chubby finger.

en: Her fault, her fault, her fault, we chant in unison.
vi: Because of her, because of her, because of her, we murmured in chorus.
tr: We are all saying in unison, it's his fault, it's his fault, it's his fault.
es: The fault is yours, yours, yours, we sang in unison.

en: Who led them on?
vi: Who encouraged them?
tr: Who encouraged them?
es: Who dragged her into that?

en: Aunt Helena beams, pleased with us.
vi: Aunt Helena beamed, extremely pleased.
tr: Aunt Helena exclaims, pleased with us.
es: Aunt Helena smiles, satisfied with us.

en: She did.
vi: It's you.
tr: He encouraged.
es: It was her, her, her.

en: She did.
vi: It's you.
tr: He encouraged.
es: It was her, her, her.

en: She did.
vi: It's you.
tr: He encouraged.
es: It was her, her, her.

en: Why did God allow such a terrible thing to happen?
vi: Why would God allow such a terrible thing to happen?
tr: Why did God allow such a terrible thing to happen?
es: Why did God allow such an atrocity to happen?

en: Teach her a lesson.
vi: To teach her a lesson. Teach her a lesson.
tr: To teach him a lesson. To teach him a lesson.
es: To teach him a lesson. To teach him a lesson.

en: Teach her a lesson.
vi: Teach her a lesson.
tr: To teach him a lesson.
es: To teach him a lesson.

en: Teach her a lesson.
vi: Teach her a lesson.
tr: To teach him a lesson.
es: To teach him a lesson.

en: Last week, Janine burst into tears.
vi: Last week Janine burst into tears.
tr: Last week, Janine was in tears.
es: Last week, Janine burst into tears.

en: Aunt Helena made her kneel
vi: Aunt Helena made her kneel at the front of the class, hands clasped behind her back, so we could all see clearly, her face flushed, snotty and tear-streaked.
tr: Aunt Helena made her kneel in front of the class, in a way that we could all see her, her red face, and her runny nose.
es: Aunt Helena made her kneel at the front of the class, with her hands behind her back, so that we could all see her red face and her runny nose.

en: Ml the front of the classroom, hands behind her back, where we could alll see her, her red face and dripping nose.
vi: Aunt Helena made her kneel at the front of the class, hands clasped behind her back, so we could all see clearly, her face flushed, snotty and tear-streaked.
tr: Aunt Helena made her kneel in front of the class, in a way that we could all see her, her red face, and her runny nose.
es: Aunt Helena made her kneel at the front of the class, with her hands behind her back, so that we could all see her red face and her runny nose.

en: Her hair dull blond, her eyelashes so light they seemed not there, the lost eye-lashes of someone who's been in a fire.
vi: Her hair was a dull blonde, her eyelashes so sparse they were almost nonexistent, like someone who had just survived a fire.
tr: Her hair was dull blonde, her eyelashes so light-colored that they seemed nonexistent, like the lost eyelashes of someone who had escaped a fire.
es: And her straw-blonde hair, her eyelashes so light it seemed like she didn't have any, as if they had been burned off in a fire.

en: Burned eyes.
vi: Her eyes had burned out.
tr: Burned eyes.
es: Burned eyes.

en: She looked disgusting:
vi: She looked disgusting: weak, writhing, filthy, with pinkish skin, like a newborn rat.
tr: She looked disgusting: thin, misshapen, blotchy, pink, like a newborn rat.
es: She looked upset: weak, annoyed, dirty, and pink like a newborn mouse.

en: weak, squirmy, blotchy, pink, like a newborn mouse.
vi: She looked disgusting: weak, writhing, filthy, with pinkish skin, like a newborn rat.
tr: She looked disgusting: thin, misshapen, blotchy, pink, like a newborn rat.
es: She looked upset: weak, annoyed, dirty, and pink like a newborn mouse.

en: None of us wanted to look like that, ever.
vi: None of us wanted to end up like that, not ever.
tr: None of us wanted to look like that, ever.
es: None of us would ever want to look like that.

en: For a moment, even though we knew what was being done to her, we despised her.
vi: For a moment, even knowing what she was going through, we felt contempt for her.
tr: Even though we knew what had been done to her, for a moment, we hated her.
es: For a moment, even though we knew what they were going to do to her, we despised her.

en: Crybaby.
vi: Crying over spoiled tea, crying over spoiled tea, crying over spoiled tea.
tr: Crybaby. Crybaby.
es: Llorona.

en: Crybaby.
vi: Crying over spoiled tea, crying over spoiled tea, crying over spoiled tea.
tr: Crybaby.
es: Llorona.

en: Crybaby.
vi: Crying over spoiled tea, crying over spoiled tea, crying over spoiled tea.
tr: Crybaby.
es: Llorona.

en: We meant it, which is the bad part.
vi: We really think so, that is the worst thing.
tr: We were serious about this, and that's the bad part.
es: And the worst part is that we meant it.

en: I used to think well of myself.
vi: I used to think very highly of myself.
tr: I used to think good things about myself.
es: I used to have a good opinion of myself.

en: I didn't then.
vi: Not at that time.
tr: I wasn't thinking that way at the time.
es: But at that moment, I didn't.

en: That was last week.
vi: That was last week's story.
tr: That was last week.
es: That happened last week.

en: This week Janine doesn't wait for us to jeer at her.
vi: This week, Janine didn't wait for us to mock her.
tr: This week Janine doesn't expect us to scold her.
es: This week, Janine doesn't wait for us to insult her.

en: It was my fault, she says.
vi: It's because of you, she said.
tr: It was my fault, she says.
es: It was my fault, he says.

en: It was my own fault.
vi: Because of you alone.
tr: It was my own fault.
es: Only mine.

en: I led them on.
vi: You encouraged them.
tr: I encouraged them.
es: I incited them.

en: I deserved the pain.
vi: You deserve the pain.
tr: I deserved that pain.
es: I deserved the suffering.

en: Very good, Janine, says Aunt Lydia.
vi: Very good, Janine, Aunt Lydia said.
tr: Very good, Janine, says Aunt Lydia.
es: Very good, Janine, says Aunt Lydia.

en: You are an example.
vi: You set a very good example.
tr: You are an example.
es: You have set the example.

en: I have to wait until this is over before I put up my hand.
vi: I had to wait until the end of the play to raise my hand.
tr: Before I raise my hand, I need to wait for this to be over.
es: Before raising my hand, I have to wait for this to end.

en: Sometimes, if you ask at the wrong moment, they say no.
vi: Sometimes, if you ask at the wrong time, you will be refused.
tr: Sometimes, if you ask at the wrong time, they say No.
es: Sometimes, if you ask for permission at an inappropriate moment, they say no.

en: If you really have to go that can be crucial.
vi: If there is indeed a need, the situation can turn out very badly.
tr: If you really need to go, you might find yourself in a tough situation.
es: And if you really have to go, it can be terrible.

en: Yesterday Dolores wet the floor.
vi: Yesterday, Dolores peed on the floor.
tr: Yesterday, Dolores wet herself.
es: Yesterday, Dolores wet the floor.

en: Two Aunts hauled her away, a hand under each armpit.
vi: Two aunts grabbed her by the armpits and dragged her outside.
tr: Two Aunts grabbed her by the armpits and dragged her outside.
es: Two Aunts took her away, grabbing her by the armpits.

en: She wasn't there for the afternoon walk, but at night she was back in her usual bed.
vi: In the afternoon walk, she was not seen, but by night she was already in bed.
tr: She wasn't on the afternoon walk, but she was back in her usual bed at night.
es: She didn't appear for the afternoon walk, but at night she got back into her bed.

en: All night we could hear her moaning, off and on.
vi: All night, I heard her sobbing, going silent, and then bursting out again.
tr: We could hear her moaning throughout the night.
es: We heard her complaining all night long.

en: What did they do to her?
vi: What did they do?
tr: What did they do to her?
es: What did they do to him?, was the murmur that ran from bed to bed.

en: we whispered, from bed to bed.
vi: we whispered between the beds.
tr: we whispered, from bed to bed.
es: What did they do to him?, was the murmur that ran from bed to bed.

en: I don't know.
vi: I don't know.
tr: I don't know.
es: I don't know.

en: Not knowing makes it worse.
vi: Not knowing only makes it worse.
tr: Not knowing is even worse.
es: And the fact of not knowing makes it even worse.

en: I raise my hand, Aunt Lydia nods.
vi: I raised my hand, Aunt Lydia nodded.
tr: I raise my hand, Aunt Lydia nods in approval.
es: I raise my hand and Aunt Lydia nods.

en: I stand up and walk out into the hall, as inconspicuously as possible.
vi: I stood up and walked to the hall, trying my best to appear innocent.
tr: I get up and go out into the hall, as inconspicuously as possible.
es: I stand up and walk out into the hallway, trying not to draw attention.

en: Outside the washroom Aunt Elizabeth is standing guard.
vi: Outside the restroom, Aunt Elizabeth was standing guard.
tr: Aunt Elizabeth is standing guard outside the bathroom.
es: Aunt Elizabeth stands guard outside the bathroom.

en: She nods, signaling that I can go in.
vi: She nodded, signaling me to enter.
tr: She nods, indicating that I can go in.
es: She nods, indicating that I can go in.

en: This washroom used to be for boys.
vi: This used to be the men's restroom.
tr: This toilet used to be for men.
es: This washroom was for the boys.

en: The mirrors have been replaced here too by oblongs of dull gray metal, but the urinals are still there, on one wall, white enamel with yellow stains.
vi: The mirrors have all been replaced with dull gray diamond-shaped metal sheets, but the urinals are still there, on one wall, white porcelain with yellow stains.
tr: The mirrors here have also been replaced with dull gray metal rectangles, but the urinals are still there, on one wall, made of white enamel with yellow stains.
es: Here too, they have replaced the mirrors with rectangles of opaque gray metal, but the urinals are still there, against one of the walls, and the white enamel is stained yellow.

en: They look oddly like babies' coffins.
vi: They look as bizarre as infant coffins.
tr: Strangely, they resemble baby coffins.
es: Strangely, they look like baby coffins.

en: I marvel again at the nakedness of men's lives: the showers right out in the open, the body exposed for in
vi: Once again, I am astonished at how men expose themselves so nakedly: the showerheads are not enclosed at all, bodies displayed for scrutinizing and comparing eyes, private parts openly shown.
tr: The nakedness of male life surprises me again: showers are completely out in the open, bodies on display for examination and comparison, the exposure of private lives.
es: I am once again amazed by the nakedness that characterizes men's lives: the open showers, the body exposed to glances and comparisons, the private parts exposed in public.

en: I
vi: Once again, I am astonished at how men expose themselves so nakedly: the showerheads are not enclosed at all, bodies displayed for scrutinizing and comparing eyes, private parts openly shown.
tr: The nakedness of male life surprises me again: showers are completely out in the open, bodies on display for examination and comparison, the exposure of private lives.
es: I am once again amazed by the nakedness that characterizes men's lives: the open showers, the body exposed to glances and comparisons, the private parts exposed in public.

en: spection and comparison, the public display of privates.
vi: Once again, I am astonished at how men expose themselves so nakedly: the showerheads are not enclosed at all, bodies displayed for scrutinizing and comparing eyes, private parts openly shown.
tr: The nakedness of male life surprises me again: showers are completely out in the open, bodies on display for examination and comparison, the exposure of private lives.
es: I am once again amazed by the nakedness that characterizes men's lives: the open showers, the body exposed to glances and comparisons, the private parts exposed in public.

en: What is it for?
vi: For what purpose?
tr: Why do they do this?
es: For what purpose?

en: What purposes of reassurance does it serve?
vi: To reassure what exactly?
tr: What purpose of reassurance does it serve?
es: Does it have some reassuring purpose?

en: The flashing of a badge, look, everyone, all is in order, I belong here.
vi: Shiny badges, look everyone, everything in its place, I belong here.
tr: A momentary flash of a badge, hey everyone, look, everything is in place, I belong here.
es: The ostentation of a common badge among all of them, which makes them think that everything is in order, that they are where they should be.

en: Why don't
vi: Why don't women have to prove to each other that they are indeed women?
tr: Why don't women need to prove to each other that they are women?
es: Why do women not need to prove to each other that they are women?

en: women have to prove to one another that they are women?
vi: Why don't women have to prove to each other that they are indeed women?
tr: Why don't women need to prove to each other that they are women?
es: Why do women not need to prove to each other that they are women?

en: Some form of unbuttoning, some split-crotch routine, just as casual.
vi: A way to unbutton, a split stance, just as unintentional.
tr: Unbuttoning slightly, showing the crotch, as casually as men do.
es: A certain way of unbuttoning, of carelessly opening the crotch.

en: A doglike sniffing.
vi: A dog's sniffing nose.
tr: Dog-like, sniffing the air.
es: A canine attitude.

en: The high school is old, the stalls are wooden, some kind of chipboard.
vi: This school is old, the bathroom stalls have wooden partitions, a type of particle board.
tr: The high school is old, the partitions are made of wood, thin plywood.
es: The school is old, the toilets are made of wood, a type of particleboard.

en: I go into the second one from the end, swing the door to.
vi: I went into the second stall from the inside, blocking the door.
tr: I enter the second to last one, pushing the door to close it.
es: I enter the second one starting from the end, making the door swing.

en: Of course there are no longer any locks.
vi: Of course, there is no longer a lock.
tr: There is no lock or anything anymore, of course.
es: Of course, there are no locks anymore.

en: In the wood there's a small hole, at the back, next to the wall, about waist height, souvenir of some previous vandalism or legacy of an ancient voyeur.
vi: On the wooden partition, there is a small hole, way in the back, near the wall, about waist-high, a relic from an old act of vandalism or the legacy of a peeping Tom from the past.
tr: In the wood, at the back, close to the wall, approximately at waist height, there is a small hole, a memory of a previous savagery or the legacy of an old voyeur.
es: At the back of the wood, near the wall and at waist height, there is a small hole, a reminder of vandalism from other times, or the legacy of a voyeur.

en: Everyone in the Center knows about this hole in the woodwork; everyone except the Aunts.
vi: The entire Center knows about this hole; except for the aunts.
tr: Everyone in the Center knows about this hole; everyone except the Aunts.
es: In the Center, we all know about the existence of this hole; all except the Aunts.

en: I'm afraid I am too late, held up by Janine's Testifying: maybe Moira has been here already, maybe she's had to go back.
vi: I'm just afraid I'll be late, because of Janine's confession: what if Moira has already arrived, what if she had to turn back.
tr: I'm afraid I'm very late, Janine's Confession delayed me: Maybe Moira has already come here, maybe she had to go back.
es: I am afraid I may have arrived too late because of Janine's Testimony: perhaps Moira has already been here, perhaps she had to leave.

en: They don't give you much time.
vi: They don't allow lingering in here.
tr: They don't give people much time.
es: They don't give you much time.

en: I look carefully down, aslant under the stall wall, and there are two red shoes.
vi: I cautiously look down, diagonally across the partition wall, on the other side are the red shoes.
tr: I look down carefully, bending under the partition wall, and I see two red shoes there.
es: I carefully look under the wall of the toilet, and I see a pair of red shoes.

en: But how can I tell who it is?
vi: But how to know whose they are?
tr: But how can I know who it is?
es: But how can I know who they belong to?

en: I put my mouth to the wooden hole.
vi: I pressed my mouth against the hole.
tr: I put my mouth to the wooden hole.
es: I bring my mouth close to the hole.

en: Moira?
vi: Moira?
tr: Moira?
es: Moira?, I whisper.

en: I whisper.
vi: I whispered.
tr: I whisper.
es: Moira?, I whisper.

en: Is that you?
vi: Is that you?
tr: Is it you?
es: Is that you?

en: she says.
vi: she replied.
tr: he says.
es: he asks me.

en: Yes, I say.
vi: Here I am, I said.
tr: Yes, I say.
es: Yes, I tell him.

en: Relief goes through me.
vi: My whole body felt light.
tr: I feel relieved.
es: I feel an enormous relief.

en: God, do I need a cigarette, says Moira.
vi: Oh God, I crave a cigarette so much, Moira said.
tr: God, how much I need a cigarette, says Moira.
es: My God, I need a cigarette, Moira comments.

en: Me too, I say.
vi: Me too, I replied.
tr: Me too, I say.
es: I also respond.

en: I feel ridiculously happy.
vi: I felt a bizarre kind of happiness.
tr: I feel ridiculously happy.
es: I feel ridiculously happy.

en: I sink down into my body as into a swamp, fenland, where only I know the footing.
vi: I dive into my own body like into a swamp, a sinking ground, only I know where the bottom is.
tr: I sink into my body as if sinking into a swamp whose paths only I know.
es: I submerge myself in my body like in a swamp where only I know how to keep my balance.

en: Treacherous ground, my own territory.
vi: An uncertain surface, my own territory.
tr: Dangerous lands, my own territory.
es: It is a shifting terrain, my territory.

en: I become the earth I set my ear against, for rumors of the future.
vi: I become the ground, pressing my ear to it, listening to guess the upcoming future.
tr: I become the ground to which I press my ear to hear the gossip of the future.
es: I become the ground on which I press my ear to listen to the whispers of the future.

en: Each twinge, each murmur of slight pain, ripples of sloughed-off matter, swellings and diminishings of tissue, the droolings of the flesh, these are signs, these are the things I need to know about, Each month I watch for blood, fearfully, for when it comes it means failure.
vi: Every sharp pain, every dull ache, the layers of living matter peeling off, the tissues swelling then deflating, the flesh oozing, are all signs, things I need to grasp. Every month I watch the blood, in fear, because its arrival brings news of failure.
tr: Every torment, every insignificant whisper of pain, waves of waste matter, the swelling and shrinking of tissue, the body's contentment, these are signs, things I need to know. I wait for the blood to come every month, with fear, because its arrival signifies failure.
es: Every twinge, every murmur of slight pain, waves of detached matter, swellings and contractions of the tissue, secretions of the flesh: all these are signs, they are the things I need to know something about. Every month I await the blood with fear, because if it appears it represents a failure.

en: I have failed once again to fulfill the expectations of others, which have become my own.
vi: Once again, I have failed the expectations of others, which have also become my own.
tr: Once again, I have failed to fulfill the expectations of others that I have adopted as my own.
es: Once again I have failed in the attempt to meet the expectations of others, which have become my own.

en: I used to think of my body as an instrument, of pleasure, or a means of transportation, or an implement for the accomplishment of my will.
vi: I used to consider my body as a tool, bringing pleasure, a vehicle for transportation, a means to achieve my desires.
tr: I used to think of my body as a pleasure, a means of transport, or a tool for fulfilling my own desires.
es: I used to think of my body as an instrument of pleasure, or as a means of transportation, or a tool for executing my will.

en: I could use it to run, push buttons of one sort or an other, make
vi: I could ride on it, press various buttons, and accomplish many things.
tr: I would use my body to run, press buttons, make things happen in one way or another.
es: I could use it to run, press buttons of one kind or another, and make things happen.

en: things happen.
vi: I could ride on it, press various buttons, and accomplish many things.
tr: I would use my body to run, press buttons, make things happen in one way or another.
es: I could use it to run, press buttons of one kind or another, and make things happen.

en: There were limits, hut my body was nevertheless lithe, single, solid, one with me.
vi: There are limits, but still, my body is flexible, unified, solid, it is one with me.
tr: There were limitations, but my body was still agile, unique, flesh and blood, one with me.
es: There were limits, but nevertheless my body was agile, loose, solid, it formed a unity with me.

en: Now the flesh arranges itself differently I'm a cloud, congealed around a central object, the shape of a pear, which is hard and more real than I am and glows red within its translucent wrapping.
vi: Now the flesh restructures itself in a different way. I am a cloud, solidifying around the object at the center, pear-shaped, solid and more real than myself, glowing red inside the translucent shell.
tr: Now the body is organizing itself in a different way.
es: Now the body manages itself in a different way. I am a cloud solidified around a central object, pear-shaped, which is evident and more real than I am and shines in all its redness within its translucent envelope.

en: Inside it is a space, huge as the sky at night and dark and curved like that, though black-red rather than black.
vi: In its heart is a void, vast like the night sky and just as dark, round like that, though not exactly black but leaning towards black-red.
tr: I am a cloud, frozen around a central object, in the shape of a pear, harder and more real than I am, glowing red within its semi-transparent wrapping, with a void inside, as vast and dark as the night sky and as agile, more black-red than black.
es: Inside there is an immense space, dark and curved like the night sky, but red instead of black.

en: Pinpoints of light swell, sparkle, burst and shrivel within it, countless as stars.
vi: Clusters of light swell up, twinkle, burst, and then shrink back inside it, thousands like stars.
tr: Countless points of light swell, sparkle, burst, and contract inside it, like stars.
es: Mined with tiny lights that shine, twinkle, and flicker inside.

en: Every month there is a moon, gigantic, round, heavy, an omen.
vi: Each month a moon appears, gigantic, perfectly round, heavy, an omen.
tr: Every month there is a full moon, huge, round, heavy, a prophecy.
es: Every month a gigantic moon appears, round and deep like an omen.

en: It transits, pauses, continues on and passes out of sight, and I see despair coming towards me like famine.
vi: It passes by, pauses, then sets off again until it disappears from sight, and I feel despair rushing in like hunger.
tr: It passes, pauses, continues, and disappears from sight, and I see despair, like hunger, coming towards me.
es: It culminates, stops, continues, and hides from view, and I feel that despair takes hold of me like a ravenous hunger.

en: To feel that empty, again, again.
vi: Must feel the emptiness, this time, this time again.
tr: To feel so empty, again, and again.
es: Feeling that emptiness over and over again.

en: I listen to my heart, wave upon wave, salty and red, continuing on and on, marking time.
vi: I listen to my heart, waves rising upon waves, salty and red, patiently beating on, counting time.
tr: I listen to my heart, wave after wave, salty and red, continuously moving, marking time.
es: I hear my heart, wave after wave, salty and red, incessantly, marking the time.

en: I'm in our first apartment, in the bedroom.
vi: I am in our first apartment, in the bedroom.
tr: I'm in our first apartment, in the bedroom.
es: I am in the bedroom of our first apartment.

en: I'm standing in front of the cupboard, which has folding doors made of wood.
vi: Standing in front of the wardrobe, with foldable wooden doors.
tr: I'm standing in front of the closet with foldable wooden doors.
es: I am standing in front of the wooden folding door closet.

en: Around me I know it's empty, all the furniture is gone, the floors are bare, no carpets even; but despite this the cupboard is full of clothes.
vi: Everything around me is empty, all the furniture has been taken away, the floor is bare, not even a carpet; but the wardrobe is full of clothes.
tr: I know the surroundings are empty, all the furniture is gone, the floors are bare, not even a carpet; but despite this, the closet is full of clothes.
es: I know that everything around me is empty, the furniture is gone, the floors are bare, there isn't even a carpet; but despite this, the closet is full of clothes.

en: I think they're my clothes, but they don't look like mine, I've never seen them before.
vi: I think they are mine, but looking at them, they are not mine, I have never seen them before.
tr: I think these are my clothes, but they don't look like mine, I've never seen them before.
es: I think they are my clothes, although they don't seem like it, I have never seen them.

en: Maybe they're clothes belonging to Luke's wife, whom I've also never seen; only pictures and a voice on the phone, late at night, when she was calling us, before the divorce.
vi: They might belong to Luke's wife, whom I have never met; only seen pictures and heard her voice on the phone, late at night, when she called us, just before the divorce.
tr: Maybe these clothes belong to Luke's wife, whom I've never seen either; just pictures and a voice on the phone, late at night, when she called us, crying, accusing, before the divorce.
es: Maybe they are the clothes of Luke's wife, whom I have also never seen; only some photos and her voice on the phone one night when she called us yelling and accusing us, before the divorce.

en: But no, they're my clothes all right.
vi: But no, they are indeed my clothes.
tr: But no, these are my clothes.
es: But no, they are my clothes.

en: I need a dress, I need something to wear.
vi: I need a shirt, I need something to wear.
tr: I need a dress, something to wear.
es: I need a dress, I need something to wear.

en: I pull out dresses, black, blue, purple, jackets, skirts; none of them will do, none of them even fits, they're too big or too small.
vi: I pull out one outfit after another, black, blue, purple, tight tops, long skirts; none of them fit, not even one, they are all either too loose or too tight.
tr: I'm taking out the clothes, black, blue, purple, jackets, skirts; none of them are useful, none of them even fit, they're either too big or too small.
es: I take out dresses, black, blue, purple, jackets, skirts; none of them work for me, they don't even fit me well, they are either too big or too small.

en: Luke is there, behind me, I turn to see him.
vi: Luke was there, right behind me, I turned around to look.
tr: Luke is there, behind me, I turn around to see him.
es: Luke is behind me and I turn around to look at him.

en: He won't look at me, he looks down at the floor, where the cat is rubbing itself against his legs, mewing and mewing plaintively.
vi: He wouldn't look at me, his eyes were downcast, the cat was rubbing against his legs, meowing plaintively.
tr: He is not looking at me, he is looking at the ground, where the cat is rubbing against his legs, whining and meowing.
es: He doesn't look at me; he looks at the floor, where the cat is cleaning its paws and meowing plaintively over and over again.

en: It wants food, but how can there be any food with the apartment so empty?
vi: It was hungry, but what could I feed it when the apartment was so empty?
tr: The cat wants its food, but in such an empty apartment, where could he find the food?
es: It wants food, but how can there be food in such an empty apartment?

en: Luke, I say.
vi: Luke, I called.
tr: Luke, I say.
es: Luke, I say.

en: He doesn't answer.
vi: He didn't answer.
tr: He doesn't answer.
es: He doesn't respond.

en: Maybe he doesn't hear me.
vi: Maybe he didn't hear me.
tr: Maybe he doesn't hear me.
es: Maybe he doesn't hear me.

en: It occurs to me that he may not be alive.
vi: I suddenly thought maybe he was no longer alive.
tr: The thought that he might not be alive crosses my mind.
es: It occurs to me that perhaps he isn't alive.

en: I'm running, with her, holding her hand, pulling, dragging her through the bracken, she's only half awake because of the pill I gave
vi: I am running, with my child, holding their hand tightly, pulling, dragging through the ferns, their eyes half-open because I gave them medicine, so they wouldn't cry or say anything that would give us away, they don't even know where they are.
tr: I am running, with my daughter, holding her hand, dragging her through the ferns, half-conscious from the pill I gave her, so she won't cry or say anything to give us away, my daughter doesn't know where she is.
es: I'm running with her, holding her hand, pulling her, dragging her through the ferns, she's barely awake because of the pill I gave her so she wouldn't scream or say anything that could give us away, she doesn't know where she is.

en: her, so she wouldn't cry or say anything that would give us away, she doesn't know where she is.
vi: I am running, with my child, holding their hand tightly, pulling, dragging through the ferns, their eyes half-open because I gave them medicine, so they wouldn't cry or say anything that would give us away, they don't even know where they are.
tr: I am running, with my daughter, holding her hand, dragging her through the ferns, half-conscious from the pill I gave her, so she won't cry or say anything to give us away, my daughter doesn't know where she is.
es: I'm running with her, holding her hand, pulling her, dragging her through the ferns, she's barely awake because of the pill I gave her so she wouldn't scream or say anything that could give us away, she doesn't know where she is.

en: The ground is uneven, rocks, deadbranches, the smell of damp earth, old leaves, she can't run fast enough, by myself I could run faster, I'm a good runner.
vi: The ground is uneven, with boulders, dry branches, the smell of damp earth, fallen leaves, they can't keep up, I could run faster alone, I'm good at running.
tr: The ground is not even, stones, dead branches, the smell of damp soil, pale leaves, she can't run fast enough, I could run faster on my own, I am a good runner.
es: The ground is uneven, there are stones, dry branches, the smell of wet earth, old leaves, she can run very fast, I could run faster alone, I'm a good runner.

en: Now she's crying, she's frightened, I want to carry her but she would be too heavy.
vi: Now they are crying again, they are scared, I want to carry them on my shoulders but they are too heavy.
tr: Now she is crying, scared, I want to carry her, but she would be too heavy.
es: Now she's crying, she's scared, I want to carry her but she would be too heavy for me.

en: I have my hiking boots on and I think, when we reach the water I'll have to kick them off, will it be too cold, will she be able to swim that far, what about the current, we weren't expecting this.
vi: I'm wearing trail shoes and I think, when we reach the river I'll have to take them off, will it be cold, will they be able to swim that far, there's the current too, I didn't foresee this.
tr: My walking shoes are on my feet, I think I will have to take them off and throw them away when we reach the water, will it be too cold, can she swim that long, and what about the current, we didn't expect this.
es: I'm wearing hiking boots and I think that when we reach the water I'll have to take them off in one pull, and if it will be too cold, and if she will be able to swim there, and what will happen with the current, we didn't expect this.

en: Quiet, I say to her angrily.
vi: Be quiet, I snap at them.
tr: Be quiet, I say to her angrily.
es: Quiet, I say angrily.

en: I think about her drowning and this thought slows me.
vi: I imagine them drowning and slow down.
tr: I think she will drown and this thought slows me down.
es: I think she might drown, and the mere idea makes me slow down.

en: Then the shots come behind us, not loud, not like firecrackers, but sharp and crisp like a dry branch snapping.
vi: Then the gunshots follow, not loud, not booming like fireworks, but sharp and crisp like breaking dry branches.
tr: Then gunshots come from behind us, not very loud, not like firecrackers, but sharp and definite like the crack of a dry branch.
es: I hear the shots behind us, not very loud, not like firecrackers but sharp and clear like the crack of a dry branch.

en: It sounds wrong, nothing ever sounds the way you think it will, and I hear the voice, Down, is it a real voice or a voice inside my head or my own voice, out loud?
vi: It doesn't sound normal, no sound is as people usually imagine, and I hear a voice, Get down, is it a real voice or just in my head, or am I shouting it myself?
tr: The sound I hear seems wrong to my ears, you never hear anything the way you think it will be and I hear that sound. Down, is it a real sound, a sound in my head, or my own voice expressed outwardly?
es: They sound wrong, things never sound like you think they should, and I hear a voice shouting Get Down, is it a real voice or a voice sounding inside my head, or am I the one saying it out loud?

en: I pull her to the ground and roll on top of her to cover her, shield her.
vi: I pulled the child down to the ground and lay on top of them to shield, to cover.
tr: I pull her down to the ground and cover her to protect her, to shield her.
es: I throw her to the ground and lie on top of her to cover and protect her.

en: Quiet, Isay again, my face is wet, sweat or tears, I feel calm and floating, as if I'm no longer in my body; close to my eyes there's a leaf, red, turned early, I can see every bright vein.
vi: Be quiet, I repeated, my face drenched, was it sweat or tears, I felt peaceful and buoyant, as if I had escaped my body; right near my eyes was a leaf, red in color, early to change, I could see each white vein.
tr: Quiet, I say again, my face wet, whether from sweat or tears, I feel calm and as if floating, as if I am no longer inside my body; there is a leaf right by my eye, red, having changed color early, I can see every bright vein.
es: Silence, I say to her again; my face is wet with sweat or tears, I feel serene and floating, as if I were no longer inside my body; near my eyes, there is a red leaf that has fallen prematurely, and I can see all its bright veins.

en: It's the most beautiful thing I've ever seen.
vi: Never before had I seen anything so beautiful.
tr: The most beautiful thing I have ever seen in my life.
es: It is the most beautiful thing I have ever seen.

en: I ease off, I don't want to smother her, instead I curl myself around her, keeping my hand over her mouth.
vi: I loosened up, afraid of suffocating the child, I changed position, curling up to embrace them, placing my hand over their mouth.
tr: I relax, I don't want to suffocate her, instead I curl around her, covering her mouth with my hand.
es: I lessen the pressure, I don't want to suffocate her; I curl up over her, without taking my hand off her mouth.

en: There's breath and the knocking of my heart, like pounding, at the door of a house at night, where you thought you would be safe.
vi: There were the sounds of breathing and my heartbeat, pounding, like the sound of knocking on a door at night, when one thought they were in a safe place.
tr: There are breaths and the beats of my heart, like knocking on the door of a house where you think you'll be safe at night.
es: I hear the breathing, and the pounding of my heart as if knocking on the door of a house at night, thinking that I would be safe there.

en: It's all right, I'm here, I say, whisper, Please be quiet, but how can she?
vi: It's okay, it's your mother, I whispered, Be good now, but how could it be?
tr: Everything is fine, I am here, I say, I whisper, Please be quiet, but how can she be quiet?
es: Everything is fine, I am here, I whisper to her, Please, stay quiet, but will she manage?

en: She's too young, it's too late, we come apart, my arms are held, and the edges go dark and nothing is left but a little window, a very little window, like the wrong end of a telescope, like the window on a Christmas card, an old one, night and ice outside, and within a candle, a shining tree, a family, I can hear the bells even, sleigh bells, from the radio, old music, but through this window I can see, small but very clear, I can see her, going away from me, through the trees which are already turning, red and yellow, holding out her arms to
vi: The child was too small, it was too late, we were separated, someone grabbed my hand, the outer edge was pitch black, nothing could be seen except for a small window, an incredibly small window, like looking through the wrong end of a telescope, like the window on an old Christmas card, outside was the freezing night, inside were candles, a glittering black tree, a family, I could even hear the bells, sleigh bells, on the radio, an old song, but this window only showed me, small but clear, I saw the child, moving away from me, among the leaves that had already changed color, yellow and red intermingled, small hands reaching towards me, being taken away.
tr: So small, too late; they separate us, my arms are held and everything goes dark and nothing remains except a very small window, like looking through the wrong end of a telescope, like a window in an old Christmas card, night and ice outside, a candle inside, a shining tree, a family; I can even hear the bells, the jingles, the old music coming from the radio, but through this small but very clear window I can see my daughter, being taken away from me, through the trees that have started to turn red and yellow, reaching her arms out to me.
es: She is very small, it is already too late, we separate, they hold me by the arms, everything goes dark and there is nothing left except a small window, very small, like the far end of a telescope, like the little window of an old Christmas postcard, outside all night and ice, inside a candle, a tree with lights, a family, I even hear the chimes, they are the bells of a sleigh and old music on the radio, but through this window I can see her —small but very clear— moving away from me among the trees that have already turned red and yellow, reaching out to me as they take her away.

en: me, being carried away.
vi: The bell woke me up; then came Cora, knocking on the door.
tr: The bells wake me up; then Cora knocks on my door.
es: The chime wakes me up; and then Cora, who knocks on my door.

en: The bell awakens me; and then Cora, knocking at my door.
vi: The bell woke me up; then came Cora, knocking on the door.
tr: The bells wake me up; then Cora knocks on my door.
es: The chime wakes me up; and then Cora, who knocks on my door.

en: I sit up, on the rug, wipe my wet face with my sleeve.
vi: I sat up, on the carpet, wiping my face with my hand.
tr: I sit up straight on the rug, wiping my wet face with the sleeve of my dress.
es: I sit on the carpet and dry my face with my sleeve.

en: Of all the dreams this is the worst.
vi: No dream was ever as frightening as this one.
tr: Of all the dreams, this is the worst one.
es: Of all the dreams I've had, this one is the worst.

en: VI Household
vi: VI - Blessing
tr: VI
es: VI

tr: House People
es: THE FAMILY
CHAPTER 14

en: When the bell has finished I descend the stairs, a brief waif in the eye of glass that hangs on the downstairs wall.
vi: When the bell had stopped, I went down the stairs, momentarily drifting into oblivion through the glass eye on the wall of the lower floor.
tr: When the bell stops, I am descending the stairs, a fleeting image of a lonely person in the eye of the mirror hanging on the wall below.
es: When the bell stops ringing, I go down the stairs: in the glass eye hanging on the wall downstairs, a tiny lost animal descends with me.

en: The clock ticks with its pendulum, keeping time; my feet in their neat red shoes count the way down.
vi: The clock chimed the hour with its pendulum, and the neat feet in red shoes counted the steps down the stairs.
tr: The clock ticks with its pendulum, working time; my feet in clean red shoes step down the stairs.
es: The ticking of the clock sounds in time with the pendulum; my feet, shod in neat red shoes, follow the rhythm down the stairs.

en: The sitting room door is wide open.
vi: The rest room door is wide open.
tr: The living room door is wide open.
es: The door to the living room is wide open.

en: I go in: so far no one else is here.
vi: I enter: so far, no one is here yet.
tr: I enter: she hasn't arrived yet.
es: I enter: for the moment there is no one else.

en: I don't sit, but take my place, kneeling,near the chair with the footstool where Serena Joy will shortly enthrone herself, leaning on her cane while she lowers herself down.
vi: I don't sit, but move into position, kneeling, close to the footstool where Serena Joy will soon place her feet, hand resting on the cane as she bends to sit down.
tr: I'm not sitting, but I take my place, kneeling next to the stool chair where Serena will soon sit as if ascending a throne, leaning on her cane.
es: I do not sit, but I take my place, on my knees, near the chair and the footstool on which Serena Joy will soon be enthroned, leaning on her cane as she sits.

en: Possibly she'll put a hand on my shoulder, to steady herself, as if I'm a pitve of furniture.
vi: She might even place her hand on my shoulder, for support, like a table or chair.
tr: Possibly, she will place one hand on my shoulder to settle herself, as if I were a piece of furniture.
es: She will probably lean on my shoulder to keep her balance, as if I were a piece of furniture.

en: She's done it before.
vi: It has happened once before.
tr: She had done this before.
es: She has done it before.

en: The sitting room would once have been called a drawing room, perhaps; then a living room.
vi: The lounge in the past might have been called the reception room, for instance; then later, the living room.
tr: It used to be called a guest room, probably, and then a parlor.
es: Perhaps in other times, the room was called a parlor, and later a living room.

en: Or maybe it's a parlor, the kind with a spider and flies.
vi: Or the guest hall, the kind meant for spiders and flies.
tr: Or maybe a lobby, the kind with spiders and flies.
es: Or perhaps it is a reception room, one of those that have chandeliers and flies.

en: But now it's officially a sitting room, because that's what is done in it, by some.
vi: But now it is officially called the lounge, because that's what people do in there, some people.
tr: But now it is officially a living room, because that's what is done here, by some people.
es: But now, officially, it is a sitting room because that is what they do here, at least some of them.

en: For others there's standing room only.
vi: Others only know what a serious room is.
tr: For others, it's just a standing room.
es: For others, it is just a standing room.

en: The posture of the body is important, here and now: minor discomforts are instructive.
vi: Individual posture holds great importance here and now: every small inconvenience is enlightening.
tr: The posture of the body is important, here and now: small discomforts are instructive.
es: Body posture is important: minor discomforts are instructive.

en: The sitting room is subdued, symmetrical; it's one of the shapes money takes when it freezes.
vi: The room was somber and symmetrical; one of the forms of pre-frozen money.
tr: The living room is dim and symmetrical; this is one of the forms money takes when it freezes.
es: The room is dim and symmetrical; this is one of the forms that money takes when it freezes.

en: Money has trickled through this room for years and years, as if through an underground cavern, crustling and hardening like stalactites into these found, Mutely the varied, surfaces present themselves: the dusk-rose velvet of the drawn drapes, the gloss of the matching chairs, eighteenth century, the cow's-tongue hush of the tufted Chinese rug on the floor, with its
vi: Money had seeped through this room for years, like flowing through underground caverns, depositing and hardening into various shapes like stalactites.
tr: Money has flowed through this room for years, as if passing through an underground cave, shaping and hardening into these forms like stalactites.
es: Money has flowed through this room for years and years, as if traversing an underground cavern, encrusting and hardening like stalactites.

en: peach-pink peonies, the suave leather of the Commander's chair, the glint of brass on the box beside it.
vi: The various surfaces silently displayed: the rosy velvet on the hanging curtains, the glossy paint of the matching armchair, eighteenth century, the plushness of the Chinese fur carpet on the floor, blooming pink peonies, the tender leather stretched over the arm of the Commander's chair, the glint of brass from the box beside it.
tr: Different surfaces quietly reveal themselves: the dark rose velvet of the drawn curtains, the eighteenth-century sheen of the chairs matching the curtains' color, the cow-tongue flower silence of the fringed Chinese carpet on the floor with large-leaved peach-pink peonies, the pleasant leather of the Commander's chair, the gleam of the brass box beside it.
es: The various surfaces present themselves mutely: the blackish pink velvet of the drawn curtains, the sheen of the matching eighteenth-century chairs, on the floor the cow's tongue peeking out from the Chinese tassel rug with its peach-colored peonies, the soft leather of the Commander's chair, and the glint of the brass box next to it.

en: The rug is authentic.
vi: The carpet is genuine.
tr: The carpet is genuine.
es: The rug is authentic.

en: Some things in this room are authentic, some are not.
vi: In this room, some items are genuine, others are not, such as the two paintings, both depicting women, each on one side of the fireplace.
tr: Some of the items in this room are genuine, some are not.
es: In this room, there are some things that are authentic and others that are not.

en: For instance, two paintings,both of women, one on either side of the fireplace.
vi: In this room, some items are genuine, others are not, such as the two paintings, both depicting women, each on one side of the fireplace.
tr: For example, the two portraits of women hanging on either side of the fireplace, both dressed in dark clothes similar to those of women in old churches, although these belong to a later period.
es: For example, two paintings, the portraits of two women, each on one side of the fireplace.

en: Both wear dark dresses, like the ones in the old church, though of a later date.
vi: Both are dressed in black, as in an old church, although from a later period.
tr: For example, the two portraits of women hanging on either side of the fireplace, both dressed in dark clothes similar to those of women in old churches, although these belong to a later period.
es: Both are wearing dark dresses, like those in the church paintings, although from a later period.

en: The paintings are possibly authentic.
vi: The two paintings might be genuine.
tr: The paintings are possibly real.
es: The paintings are probably authentic.

en: I suspect that when Serena Joy acquired them, after it became obvious to her that she'd have to redirect her energies into something convincingly domestic, she had the intention of passing them off as ancestors.
vi: I suspect that when they were brought in, after realizing that she would have to limit her enthusiasm to purely domestic matters, Serena Joy intended to leave behind a family heirloom.
tr: After realizing that she needed to direct her energy towards something convincingly domestic, I suspect that Serena Joy acquired these with the intention of presenting them as ancestors.
es: I suppose that when Serena Joy acquired them —once it became obvious to her that she had to channel her energies in a convincingly domestic direction— she did so with the intention of pretending they were her ancestors.

en: Or maybe they were in the house when the Commander bought it.
vi: It's also possible that they were already there when the Commander acquired the house.
tr: Or maybe they were in the house when the Commander bought it.
es: Or maybe they were in the house when the Commander bought it.

en: There's no way of knowing such things.
vi: There's no way to know these things.
tr: There is no way of knowing these things.
es: There is no way to know.

en: In any case, there they hang, their backs and mouths stiff, their breasts constricted, their faces pinched, their caps starched, their skin grayish white, guarding the room with their narrowed eyes.
vi: In any case, they still hang there, mouths stiff, chests tightly bound, faces wrinkled, starched caps rigid, pale white skin, their narrowed eyes watching over the room.
tr: Anyway, there they hang, with their backs straight, mouths closed, chests tight, faces tense, starched bonnets, gray-white skin, and narrowed eyes observing the room.
es: In any case, there they are hanging, with their straight backs and rigid mouths, oppressed chests, tense faces, stiff headdresses, grayish skin, watching the room with narrowed eyes.

en: Between them, over the mantel, there's an oval mirror, flanked by two pairs of silver candlesticks, with a white china Cupid centered between them, its arm around the neck of a lamb.
vi: Between them, on the hearth, was an oval mirror, flanked by two pairs of silver candlesticks, with a white porcelain Cupid in the center, its arms around the neck of a lamb.
tr: Among them, on the mantelpiece, there is an oval mirror, with a silver candlestick with two arms on each side, and in the center, a Cupid made of white porcelain with its arm wrapped around a lamb's neck. Serana
es: Between them, on the mantelpiece, there is an oval mirror flanked by two pairs of silver candlesticks, and in the middle of these, a white porcelain Cupid with its arms around the neck of a lamb.

en: The tastes of Serena Joy are a strange blend: hard lust for quality, soft sentimental cravings.
vi: Serena Joy's taste was a strange mixture: reaching the heights of quality and descending to the depths of sentimentality.
tr: Joy's tastes consist of a strange mixture: a fierce appetite for quality alongside soft, sentimental desires.
es: Serena Joy's tastes are a strange mix: exquisite luxury or easy sentimentality.

en: There's a dried flower arrangement on either end of the mantelpiece, and a vase of real daffodils on the polished marquetry end table beside the sofa.
vi: There were two plates of dried flowers on either side of the fireplace, and a vase of fresh yellow daffodils on a small polished wooden table next to the sofa.
tr: On each side of the fireplace, there are arrangements of dried flowers, and on the inlaid, elegant table next to the sofa, there is a vase with real daffodils.
es: At each end of the fireplace, there is an arrangement of dried flowers, and on the polished marquetry table next to the sofa, a vase with natural daffodils.

en: The room smells of lemon oil, heavy cloth, fading daffodils, the leftover smells of cooking that have made their way from the kitchen or the dining room, and of Serena Joy's perfume: Lily of the Valley.
vi: The room smelled of lemon oil, canvas, half-wilted flowers, lingering kitchen odors wafting from the kitchen or dining room, and Serena Joy's perfume: Lily of the Valley.
tr: The room smells of lemon oil, heavy fabric, wilting daffodils, leftover food odors that have found their way from the kitchen or dining room, and Serena Joy's perfume, which smells like Lily of the Valley.
es: The room is permeated with the smell of lemon oil, heavy fabrics, withered daffodils, the odors that linger after cooking —and that have seeped in from the kitchen or dining room— and the perfume of Serena Joy: Lily of the Valley.

en: Perfume is a luxury, she must have some private source.
vi: Perfume is a luxury item; she must have her own private source.
tr: Perfume is a luxury, she must have a special source.
es: The perfume is a luxury, she must have a secret supplier.

en: I breathe it in, thinking 1 should appreciate it.
vi: I inhaled, thinking I should appreciate it more.
tr: I inhale this scent, thinking I should appreciate it.
es: I inhale, thinking I might recognize it.

en: It's the scent of pre-pubescent girls, of the gifts young children used to give their mothers, for Mother's Day;the smell of white cotton socks and white cotton petticoats, of dusting powder, of the innocence of female flesh not yet given over to hairiness and blood.
vi: It was the scent of a prepubescent girl, the kind of gifts children often buy for Mother's Day; the smell of white cotton socks and white cotton slips, baby powder, the skin of a young girl not yet given way to hair and blood.
tr: This is the scent of gifts given by young girls, not yet mature, to their mothers on Mother's Day; the scent of white cotton socks and white cotton petticoats, of dusting powder, of the innocence of a female body not yet given over to hair and blood.
es: It is one of those scents used by girls who have not yet reached adolescence, or that children give to their mothers for Mother's Day; the smell of socks and white cotton petticoats, of cleaning powders, of the innocence of the female body still free of hair and blood.

en: It makes me feel slightly ill, as it I'm in a closed car on a hot muggy day with an older woman wearing
vi: That scent made me feel slightly uneasy, like being in a closed car on a hot day with a woman wearing too much makeup.
tr: It makes me a little sick, as if I were in a closed car with an old woman overly powdered on a hot, stifling day.
es: This makes me feel slightly sick, as if I were locked in a car on a sweltering day with an older woman who used too much face powder.

en: too much face powder.
vi: That scent made me feel slightly uneasy, like being in a closed car on a hot day with a woman wearing too much makeup.
tr: It makes me a little sick, as if I were in a closed car with an old woman overly powdered on a hot, stifling day.
es: This makes me feel slightly sick, as if I were locked in a car on a sweltering day with an older woman who used too much face powder.
