en: This is what the sitting room is like, despite its elegance.
vi: That's what the sitting room was like, despite its elegance.
tr: That's the sitting room, despite its elegance.
es: That is what the living room feels like, despite its elegance.

en: I would like to steal .
vi: I really want to steal something in this room.
tr: I would like to steal something from this room.
es: I would like to steal something from this room.

en: something from this room.
vi: I really want to steal something in this room.
tr: I would like to steal something from this room.
es: I would like to steal something from this room.

en: I would like to take some small thing, the scrolled ashtray, the little silver pillbox from the mantel perhaps, or a dried flower: hide it in the folds of my dress or in my zippered sleeve, keep it there until this evening is over, secrete it in my room, under the bed, or in a shoe, or in a slit in the hard petit point FAITH cushion.
vi: I want to take something small, like the carved ashtray, the small silver snuffbox on the mantelpiece, or a dried flower: hide it in the fold of my coat or sleeve pocket, until the end of the evening, then store it in my room, under the mattress, in my shoe, or in the crevice of the hard pillow embroidered with the word FAITH.
tr: I would like to take a small thing, the curved ashtray, maybe the small silver pillbox on the mantelpiece, or a dried flower: to hide it in the folds of my dress or the sleeve of my zippered dress, to keep it there until the night is over; to hide it in my room, under the bed, inside a tear in a shoe or a stiff FAITH pillow embroidered with canvas.
es: I would like to take some small object —the scrollwork ashtray, maybe the little silver pillbox on the shelf, or a dried flower— and hide it within the folds of my dress or in the pocket of my sleeve, until night, and then hide it in my room, under the bed or in a shoe, or in a tear of the FAITH cushion.

en: Every once in a while I would take it out and look at it.
vi: From time to time, I will take it out to admire.
tr: Occasionally, I would take it out and look at it.
es: From time to time, I would take it out to look at it.

en: It would make me feel that I have power.
vi: It will give me a sense of power.
tr: It would make me feel powerful.
es: It would give me the feeling that I have power.

en: But such a feeling would be an illusion, and too risky.
vi: But that feeling, if it exists, is just an illusion, and reckless too.
tr: However, such a feeling would be an illusion and very risky.
es: But such a sensation would be illusory, and too risky.

en: My hands stay where they are, folded in my lap.
vi: My hands stay where they are, folded in my lap.
tr: My hands remain where they are, clasped together, in my lap.
es: I leave my hands where they are, crossed over my lap.

en: Thighs together, heels tucked underneath me, pressing up against my body.
vi: Thighs closed, heels tucked underneath, pressing into my body.
tr: My legs are together, my heels curled under me, pressing against my body.
es: Thighs together, heels pressed under my body, pressing it.

en: Head lowered.
vi: Head bowed low.
tr: My head is bowed forward.
es: Head bowed.

en: In mymouth there's the taste of toothpaste: fake mint and plaster.
vi: Mouth tasting of toothpaste: fake mint and plaster.
tr: The taste of toothpaste in my mouth: fake mint and plaster.
es: I have the taste of toothpaste in my mouth: a substitute of mint and chalk.

en: I wait, for the household to assemble.
vi: I sit, waiting for the family to be complete.
tr: I am waiting for the household to gather.
es: I wait for the family to gather.

en: Household: that is what we are.
vi: Family: that's how we are.
tr: The household: this is who we are.
es: A family: that is what we are.

en: The Commander is the head of the household.
vi: The leader stands at the head of the family.
tr: The commander is the head of the household.
es: The Commander is the head of the family.

en: The house is what he holds.
vi: The family is protected by him.
tr: The house is something held in hand.
es: He feeds us all, like a nurse would.

en: To have and to hold, till death do us part.
vi: Enjoyment and protection, only death can separate them.
tr: To own and to hold, until death do us part.
es: He feeds us all, like a nurse would.

en: The hold of a ship.
vi: About a boat.
tr: The hold of a ship that keeps its cargo.
es: A mothership.

en: Hollow.
vi: An empty space.
tr: Void.
es: Every man for himself.

en: Cora comes in first, then Rita, wiping her hands on her apron.
vi: Cora came in first, followed by Rita, wiping her hands.
tr: First, Cora comes, then Rita, wiping her hands on her apron.
es: First, Cora enters, followed by Rita, drying her hands on the apron.

en: They too have been summoned by the bell, they resent it, they have other things to do, the dishes for instance.
vi: They too were summoned by the bell, they hated it, they had so many other things to do, like dishes.
tr: The bell called them too, they resent this, they have things to do, like washing dishes.
es: They also come to the bell's call, reluctantly, because they have other things to do, like washing the dishes.

en: But they need to be here, they all need to be here, the Ceremony demands it.
vi: But they needed to be here, everyone needed to be here, the Ceremony demanded it.
tr: But they need to be here, all of them need to be here, the Ceremony requires it.
es: But they have to be here. Everyone has to be here; the Ceremony demands it.

en: We are all obliged to sit through this, one way or another.
vi: We were all required to sit through it, however we managed.
tr: We all have to endure it, in one way or another.
es: We are obligated to stay until the end.

en: Rita scowls at me before slipping in to stand behind me.
vi: Rita glared at me before slipping behind my back.
tr: Before entering to stand behind me, Rita frowns and looks at me.
es: Rita looks at me with a frown and stands behind me.

en: It's my fault, this waste of her time.
vi: It's my fault that she has to waste her time like this.
tr: This is my fault, her time being wasted.
es: That she wastes time is my fault.

en: Not mine, but my body's, if there is a difference.
vi: It's not my fault, it's my body's fault, if that makes any difference.
tr: Not mine, but my body's, if that counts as a difference.
es: Not mine, but my body's, if there is any difference.

en: Even the Commander is subject to its whims.
vi: Even the Commander is subject to its whims.
tr: Even the Commander is subject to her whims.
es: Even the Commander is subject to the whims of his body.

en: Nick walks in, nods to all three of us, looks around the room.
vi: Nick walked in, nodded to greet all three, and looked around the room.
tr: Nick enters, nods at the three of us, and doesn't look around the room.
es: Nick enters, greets the three of us with a nod, and looks around.

en: He too takes his place behind me, standing.
vi: He also came to stand behind me.
tr: He takes his place behind me, standing.
es: He also positions himself behind me, standing.

en: He's so close that the tip of his boot is touching my foot.
vi: So close that the tip of his boot touched my foot, was it intentional?
tr: He's so close that the tip of his boot touches my foot.
es: He is so close that he touches my foot with the tip of his shoe.

en: Is this on purpose?
vi: So close that the tip of his boot touched my foot, was it intentional?
tr: Is he doing this on purpose?
es: Is he doing it on purpose?

en: Whether it is or not we are touching, two shapes of leather.
vi: Anyway, we were touching, two leather-clad figures.
tr: Whether he is or not, we are touching each other, two forms of skin.
es: Whatever the case, we are touching.

en: I feel my shoe soften, blood flows into it, it grows warm, it becomes a skin.
vi: I felt my shoe soften, blood flowed into it, it warmed up, becoming living skin.
tr: I feel my shoe softening, blood flows into it, it warms up, turning into skin.
es: I feel that my shoe softens, that the blood flows inside it, warms up, and transforms into a skin.

en: I move my foot slightly, away.
vi: I gently moved my foot away from there.
tr: I slowly move my foot away from him.
es: I slightly move my foot aside.

en: "Wish he'd hurry up," says Cora.
vi: "Please hurry up," Cora said.
tr: “Hopefully, he will hurry,” says Cora.
es: —I hope he hurries up —comments Cora.

en: "Hurry up and wait," says Nick.
vi: "Hurry up, still waiting," Nick said.
tr: “Hurry up and wait,” says Nick.
es: —Hurry up and wait —jokes Nick and laughs.

en: He laughs, moves his foot so it's touching mine again.
vi: He laughed loudly, shifting his foot to touch me again.
tr: He laughs, moves his foot so it touches mine again.
es: He moves his foot in such a way that it touches mine again.

en: No one can see, beneath the folds of my outspread skirt.
vi: No one saw, the folds of the dress spread wide.
tr: No one can see this, under the folds of my skirt spread around.
es: Nobody can see what is under my spread-out skirt.

en: I shift, it's too warm in here, the smell of stale perfume makes me feel a little sick.
vi: I moved, it was too warm in here, the smell of perfume made me want to vomit.
tr: I move, it's very hot here, the smell of stale perfume makes me a bit nauseous.
es: I move, it's too hot here, the smell of stale perfume makes me feel sick.

en: I move my foot away.
vi: I shifted my foot away.
tr: I pull my foot away.
es: I move my foot away.

en: We hear Serena coming, down the stairs, along the hall, the muffled tap of her cane on the rug, thud of the goodfoot.
vi: We hear Serena coming, down the stairs, along the hallway, the sound of her cane thumping on the carpet, the heavy step of her good leg.
tr: We hear Serena coming, down the stairs, along the hall, the dull thud of her cane on the carpet, the thud of her good foot.
es: We hear Serena's footsteps as she descends the stairs and approaches down the hallway, the sharp tap of her cane on the carpet and the dull thud of her healthy foot.

en: She hobbles through the doorway, glances at us, counting but not seeing.
vi: She limps into the doorway, glances at us, counting but not seeing.
tr: She limps through the doorway, looks at us, counting but not seeing.
es: He limps through the door and gives us a look, as if counting us, but without seeing us.

en: She nods, at Nick, but says nothing.
vi: She nods slightly, to Nick, but says nothing.
tr: She nods at Nick, but says nothing.
es: He nods at Nick, but says nothing.

en: She's in one of her best dresses, sky blue with embroidery in white along the edges of the veil: flowers and fretwork.
vi: She is wearing her best dress, sky blue, with white embroidery along the edges: flowers and geometric shapes.
tr: She is wearing one of her best dresses, sky blue, with white embroidered edges on the veil: flowers and reliefs.
es: He is wearing one of his best dresses, light blue in color, with a white trim on the edges of the veil: flowers and patterns.

en: Even at her age shestill feels the urge to wreathe herself in flowers.
vi: At her age, she still feels the need to cover herself with flowers.
tr: Even at her age, she still feels the urge to adorn herself with flowers.
es: Even at his age, he experiences the desire to adorn himself with flowers.

en: No use for you, I think at her, my face unmov-ing, you cant use them anymore, you're withered.
vi: It's no use, I think to her, my face unchanged, you can't use them anymore, you're withered.
tr: You naughty girl, I think, looking at her, my face motionless, you can't use them anymore, you have withered.
es: It's useless for you to do it, I tell him mentally, without moving a single muscle in my face, you can't use them anymore, you have withered.

en: They're the genital organs of plants.
vi: Flowers are the reproductive organs of plants.
tr: These are the sexual organs of flowers.
es: Flowers are the genital organs of plants; I read it somewhere once.

en: I read that somewhere, once.
vi: I read that somewhere, once.
tr: I read it somewhere, once upon a time.
es: Flowers are the genital organs of plants; I read it somewhere once.

en: She makes her way to her chair and footstool, turns, lowers her-self, lands ungracefully.
vi: She made her way to the chair and the stool, turned around, crouched down, and touched the ground very ungracefully.
tr: He moves towards his chair and stool, turns around, lowers himself, and settles in with an inelegant motion.
es: He advances to the chair and the footstool, turns, lowers himself, and lets his body drop clumsily.

en: She hoists her left foot onto the stool, fumbles in her sleeve pocket.
vi: She lifted her left leg onto the stool and fumbled in her sleeve pocket.
tr: He places his left foot on the stool and rummages through the pocket of his coat sleeve.
es: He lifts his left foot onto the footstool and rummages in the pocket of his sleeve.

en: I can hear the rustling, the click of her lighter, 1 smell the hot singe of the smoke, breathe it in.
vi: I heard the rustling sound, the click of a lighter, smelled the warm, slightly acrid smoke, and took a deep breath.
tr: I can hear the rustling, the click of his lighter, the smoke, the warm burnt smell, I inhale it.
es: I hear the rustle, then the click of his lighter, I perceive the smell of smoke and inhale deeply.

en: "Late as usual," she says.
vi: “Late as always,” she said.
tr: “As usual, she is late,” he says.
es: —Late, as usual —he says.

en: We don't answer.
vi: We did not reply.
tr: We do not respond.
es: We do not respond.

en: There's a clatter as she gropes on the lamp table, then a click, and the television set runs through its warm-up.
vi: We heard the clattering as she fumbled to turn on the table lamp, then a click, and the TV came on.
tr: When he reaches for the lamped table, a clatter is heard, followed by a click, and the television starts to warm up.
es: He fumbles for the table lamp and turns it on; a click is heard and the television starts to work.

en: A male choir, with greenish-yellow skin, the color needs adjusting; they're singing "Come to the Church in the Wildwood."
vi: The male choir, half yellow half green skin - the color not quite right; singing "Come to the chapel by the wild forest".
tr: A men's choir, their skin greenish-yellow, the color needs adjustment, singing the song "Come to the Church in the Forest."
es: A chorus of men with yellowish-green skin —the color needs its adaptation— sings "Come to the Church of the Virgin Forest."

en: Come, come, come, come, sing the basses.
vi: Come, come, come, come, the bass drops.
tr: Come, come, come, come say the basses.
es: Come, come, come, come, sing the basses.

en: Serena clicks the channel changer.
vi: Serena changes the channel.
tr: Serena presses the remote control.
es: Serena presses the channel selector.

en: Waves, colored zigzags, a garble of sound: it's the Montreal satellite station, being blocked.
vi: The image is noisy, full of color bands, the sound distorted: the Montreal satellite station is blocked.
tr: Waves, colorful zigzags, crackles: the blocked Montreal satellite station.
es: Waves, colorful zigzags, and a fading sound: it's the Montreal satellite station, which has been blocked.

en: Then there's a preacher, earnest, with shining dark eyes, leaning towards us across a desk.
vi: Then a priest appears, with a sincere demeanor, bright black eyes, standing behind a table leaning towards us.
tr: Then a preacher, serious, with shining black eyes, leaning towards us from over a table.
es: Then a pastor appears, serious, with bright dark eyes, addressing us from behind a desk.

en: These days they look a lot like businessmen.
vi: Now they look not much different from businessmen.
tr: These days they look a lot like businessmen.
es: These days, pastors look a lot like businessmen.

en: Serena gives him a few seconds, then clicks onward.
vi: Serena allows him to speak for a few seconds, then switches again.
tr: Serena gives him a few seconds, then continues pressing.
es: Serena gives him a few seconds and continues searching.

en: Several blank channels, then the news.
vi: After a few blank channels, the news came on.
tr: A few empty channels, then the news.
es: She flips through several blank channels, and finally, the news comes on.

en: This is what she's been looking for.
vi: It's what she was looking for.
tr: This is what he was looking for.
es: This is what she was looking for.

en: She leans back, inhales deeply.
vi: She leaned back, taking a deep drag on her cigarette.
tr: He leans back and takes a deep drag from his cigarette.
es: She leans back and takes a deep breath.

en: I on the contrary lean
vi: In contrast, I leaned forward, the child allowed to stay up late with the adults.
tr: In contrast, I lean forward, like a child allowed to stay up late with the grown-ups.
es: I, on the other hand, lean forward, like a child who has been allowed to stay up late with the adults.

en: forward, a child being allowed up late with the grown-ups.
vi: In contrast, I leaned forward, the child allowed to stay up late with the adults.
tr: In contrast, I lean forward, like a child allowed to stay up late with the grown-ups.
es: I, on the other hand, lean forward, like a child who has been allowed to stay up late with the adults.

en: This is the one good thing about these evenings, the evenings of the Ceremony: I'm allowed to watch the news.
vi: This was the only thing that mattered on these evenings, these Festival month evenings: I was allowed to watch the news.
tr: One of the good things about these evenings, these Ceremony evenings, is this; we are allowed to watch the news.
es: This is the good thing about these evenings, the Ceremony evenings: they allow me to listen to the news.

en: It seems to be an unspoken rule in this household: we always get here on time, he's always late, Serena always lets uswatch the news.
vi: It had almost become an unspoken rule in the household: we always arrived on time, he was always late, Serena always let us watch the news.
tr: It's like an unspoken rule in this house: We always arrive here on time, he always late, and Serena always lets us watch the news.
es: It's as if there is an unspoken rule in this house: we always arrive on time, he always arrives late, and Serena always lets us watch the news.

en: Such as it is: who knows if any of it is true?
vi: That's all I know: who knows if there's anything trustworthy?
tr: Although it doesn't really matter: who knows if these news are true or not?
es: As things are, who knows if any of this is true?

en: It could be old clips, it could be faked.
vi: The footage could have been pre-recorded, it could be fake.
tr: They could be old records, they could be fake.
es: They could be ancient fragments, or a forgery.

en: But I watch it anyway, hoping to be able to read beneath it.
vi: But I still watch, hoping to read between the lines.
tr: Still, I watch, hoping I can read between the lines.
es: But I listen to them anyway, hoping to read between the lines.

en: Any news, now, is better than none.
vi: Now, any news is better than no news.
tr: Any news, now, is better than none.
es: Now, any news —whatever it may be— is better than none.

en: First, the front lines.
vi: First of all, there is the front line.
tr: First of all, the fronts.
es: First, the front line.

en: They are not lines, really: the war seems to be going on in many places at once.
vi: In reality, it is not exactly a "front": the fighting seems to be happening simultaneously in many places.
tr: These are not really fronts: it seems like the war is continuing in many places at the same time.
es: In reality, there is no front line: the war seems to be unfolding simultaneously in several places.

en: Wooded hills, seen from above, the trees a sickly yellow.
vi: The hilltop has trees, from the sky looking down, the leaves are sickly yellow.
tr: The tree-covered hills, from above, look like trees are sick with epilepsy.
es: Wooded hills seen from above, trees of a sickly yellow.

en: I wish she'd fix the color.
vi: I asked her to adjust the colors.
tr: Serena wishes she could adjust the color.
es: If only she would adjust the color... "The Appalachian Mountains," says the voice off-screen, "where the Fourth Division of the Angels of the Apocalypse is evicting a Baptist guerrilla stronghold with smoke bombs, supported by the Twenty-Third Battalion of the Angels of Light."

en: The Appalachian Highlands, says the voice-over, where the Angels of the Apocalypse, Fourth Division, are smoking out a pocket of Baptist guerillas, with air support from the Twenty-first Battalion of the Angels of Light.
vi: On the Appalachian highlands, the narrator said, the Apocalypse Angel Corps, 4th Division, is smoking out a handful of Purification guerrillas, with air support from the 21st Battalion of the Light Angel Corps.
tr: The Appalachian Mountains, where the Light Angels' Twenty-First Battalion, with air support, and the Revelation Angels' Fourth Company uncovered a Baptist guerrilla group, says the voice on the television.
es: If only she would adjust the color... "The Appalachian Mountains," says the voice off-screen, "where the Fourth Division of the Angels of the Apocalypse is evicting a Baptist guerrilla stronghold with smoke bombs, supported by the Twenty-Third Battalion of the Angels of Light."

en: We are shown two helicopters, black ones with silver wings painted on the sides.
vi: We watched two helicopters, black with silver wings painted on the sides.
tr: We are shown two black helicopters with silver wings painted on their sides.
es: They show us two black helicopters, with silver wings painted on the sides.

en: Below them, a clump of trees explodes.
vi: Below, a patch of trees exploded.
tr: A cluster of trees is flying in the air beneath them.
es: Below them, a group of trees explodes.

en: Now a close shot of a prisoner, with a stubbled and dirty face, flanked by two Angels in their neat black uniforms.
vi: Close-up of a prisoner, face dirty and stubbled with beard, flanked by two Angels in crisp black uniforms.
tr: Now, a close-up shot of a bearded and dirty-faced prisoner between two Angels in clean black uniforms.
es: Now we see a close-up of a bearded and dirty prisoner, escorted by two Angels dressed in their neat black uniforms.

en: The prisoner accepts a cigarette from one of the Angels, puts it awkwardly to his lips with his bound hands.
vi: The prisoner receives a cigarette from one of the Angels, awkwardly placing it to his lips with his bound hands.
tr: The prisoner takes the cigarette held by one of the Angels and clumsily places it to his lips with his bound hands.
es: The prisoner accepts the cigarette offered by one of the Angels, and clumsily puts it in his mouth with his hands tied.

en: He gives a lopsided little grin.
vi: He slightly smirks.
tr: A small crooked grin spreads across his face.
es: A brief crooked smile appears on his face.

en: The announcer is saying something, but I don't hear it: I look into this man's eyes, trying to decide what he's thinking.
vi: The spokesperson is saying something, but I don't hear: I look into the other man's eyes, guessing what he is thinking.
tr: The announcer is saying something, but I can't hear: I'm looking into this man's eyes, trying to understand what he's thinking.
es: The announcer is saying something, but I can't hear it; I am looking into the eyes of that man, trying to decipher what he is thinking.

en: He knows the camera is on him: is the grin a show of defiance, or is it submission?
vi: He knows there is a camera: is that smile provocative, or submissive?
tr: He knows the camera is on him: Is this grin a show of defiance, or surrender?
es: He knows the camera is focusing on him: is the smile a sign of defiance or submission?

en: Is he embarrassed, at having been caught?
vi: Now captured, is he ashamed or not?
tr: Is he surprised to have been caught?
es: Does he feel uncomfortable being captured by the camera?

en: They only show us victories, never defeats.
vi: They only show victories, never failures.
tr: They only show us victories, never defeats.
es: They only show us the victories, never the defeats.

en: Who wants bad news?
vi: Who wants to hear bad news anyway?
tr: Who wants bad news anyway?
es: Who is interested in bad news?

en: Possibly he's an actor.
vi: It could just be an actor.
tr: Maybe he is an actor.
es: He is probably an actor.

en: The anchorman comes on now.
vi: Now we see the spokesperson's face.
tr: Now it's the main anchor's turn.
es: Now the counselor appears.

en: His manner is kindly, fatherly; he gazes out at us from the screen, looking, with his tan and his white hair and candid eyes, wise wrinkles around them, like everybody's ideal grandfather.
vi: His demeanor is extremely gentle and soothing; he looks at us from the screen, tanned skin, silver hair, steadfast eyes, wise wrinkles, the ideal image of a grandfather.
tr: His demeanor is compassionate, fatherly; he looks at us from the screen, with his sunburnt skin and white hair and sincere eyes surrounded by wise wrinkles, he resembles everyone's ideal grandfather.
es: His attitude is kind, paternal; he looks at us intently from the screen; he has tanned skin, white hair, and eyes with a sincere gaze, surrounded by wise wrinkles: the ideal image we all have of a grandfather.

en: What he's telling us, his level smile implies, is for
vi: He tells us these things, that unwavering smile says, it's all just for our own good, everything will be fine soon.
tr: As his measured smile implies, what he tells us is for our own good.
es: His even-tempered smile suggests that what he tells us is for our own good.

en: our own good.
vi: He tells us these things, that unwavering smile says, it's all just for our own good, everything will be fine soon.
tr: As his measured smile implies, what he tells us is for our own good.
es: His even-tempered smile suggests that what he tells us is for our own good.

en: Everything will be all right soon.
vi: He tells us these things, that unwavering smile says, it's all just for our own good, everything will be fine soon.
tr: I promise, everything will be fixed in the lie.
es: Things will get better very soon.

en: I promise.
vi: I promise.
tr: I promise, everything will be fixed in the lie.
es: I promise you.

en: There will be peace.
vi: There will be peace.
tr: There will be peace.
es: We will have peace.

en: You must trust.
vi: You must believe it.
tr: You must trust.
es: You must believe it.

en: You must go to sleep, like good children.
vi: Go to sleep, like all good children.
tr: It's time to sleep, come on to bed, like good children.
es: Now you must go to sleep, like good children.

en: He tells us what we long to believe.
vi: He said the things we wanted to believe.
tr: It tells us the things we desire to believe in.
es: It tells us what we long to hear.

en: He's very convincing.
vi: He was very persuasive.
tr: Very convincing.
es: And it is very convincing.

en: I struggle against him.
vi: I struggled to resist him.
tr: I am struggling with him.
es: I fight against him.

en: He's like an old movie star, I tell myself, with false teeth and a face job.
vi: Just an end-of-season movie star, I told myself, with false teeth and empty talk.
tr: He looks like an old movie star, I tell myself, with false teeth and a fake face.
es: I tell myself that he is like an old movie star, with false teeth and a fictional face.

en: At the same time I sway towards him, like one hypnotized.
vi: At the same time, I wavered towards him, as if hypnotized.
tr: At the same time, I lean towards him as if hypnotized.
es: At the same time, he exerts a certain influence over me, as if he were hypnotizing me.

en: If only it were true.
vi: If only it were real.
tr: If only these were true.
es: If it were true, if I could believe him...

en: If only I could believe.
vi: If only I could believe it.
tr: If only I could believe.
es: If it were true, if I could believe him...

en: Now he's telling us that an underground espionage ring has been cracked by a team of Eyes, working with an inside informant.
vi: Now he is talking about the underground spy ring that was smashed by a group called The Eye, thanks to an internal informant.
tr: Now, it tells us about an underground espionage organization that was dismantled by an Eye team working with an informant inside.
es: Now he is explaining to us that a clandestine espionage network has been dismantled by a team of Eyes that was working with an infiltrated informant.

en: The ring has been smuggling precious national resources over the border into Canada.
vi: This organization was smuggling precious national resources across the border to Canada.
tr: This organization was smuggling valuable national resources to Canada through customs.
es: The network was dedicated to clandestinely smuggling valuable national resources across the Canadian border.

en: "Five members of the heretical sect of Quakers have been arrested,"
vi: “Five followers of the Quaker heretical sect have been arrested,” he said with a faint smile, “and more arrests are expected.”
tr: “Five members of a heretical sect of Quakers have been arrested,” he says with a gentle smile.
es: “Five members of the heretical Quaker sect have been arrested,” he announces, smiling affably, “and more arrests are expected.”

en: he says, smiling blandly, "and more arrests are anticipated."
vi: “Five followers of the Quaker heretical sect have been arrested,” he said with a faint smile, “and more arrests are expected.”
tr: “And more arrests are expected.”
es: “Five members of the heretical Quaker sect have been arrested,” he announces, smiling affably, “and more arrests are expected.”

en: Two of the Quakers appear onscreen, a man and a woman.
vi: Two Quakers appeared on the screen, a man and a woman.
tr: Two Quakers appear on the screen, a man and a woman.
es: Two Quakers, a man and a woman, appear on the screen.

en: They look terrified, but they're trying to preserve some dignity in front of the camera.
vi: They looked terrified, but still tried to maintain their dignity in front of the camera.
tr: They look horrified, but they are trying to maintain some dignity in front of the camera.
es: They seem terrified, but they try to maintain some dignity in front of the camera.

en: The man has a largedark mark on his forehead; the woman's veil has been torn off, and her hair falls in strands over her face.
vi: The man had a large bruise on his forehead; the woman had her clothes torn, her hair hanging in strands around her face.
tr: The man has a dark, long scar on his forehead; the woman's veil is torn to shreds, and her hair falls in strands over her face.
es: The man has a large, dark mark on his forehead; the woman's veil has been torn off, and her hair falls over her face.

en: Both of them are about fifty.
vi: Both were around fifty years old.
tr: Both are in their fifties.
es: Both are around fifty years old.

en: Now we can see a city, again from the air.
vi: Now we see a city, again from a high vantage point looking down.
tr: Now we see a city, again from the air.
es: Now they show us an aerial view of a city.

en: This used to be Detroit.
vi: It used to be Detroit.
tr: This used to be Detroit.
es: It used to be Detroit.

en: Under the voice of the announcer there's the thunk of artillery.
vi: In the background of the narration is the sound of artillery fire.
tr: The rumble of cannons can be heard behind the announcer's voice.
es: Underneath the narrator's voice, the roar of artillery can be heard.

en: From the skyline columns of smoke ascend.
vi: Columns of smoke rise along the horizon.
tr: Columns of smoke rise from the horizon.
es: Columns of smoke are drawn in the sky.

en: "Resettlement of the Children of Ham is continuing on schedule," says the reassuring pink face, back on the screen.
vi: “The resettlement effort for the Ham lineage is still on schedule,” the reassuringly rosy face appeared again.
tr: “The relocation process of Ham's Children is proceeding according to plan,” says the reassuring pink face that appears on the screen again.
es: —The reestablishment of the Ham Boys continues as planned — says the reassuring pink face from the screen—.

en: "Three thousand have arrived this week in National Homeland One, with another two thousand in transit."
vi: “This week, three thousand people have arrived at National Settlement 1, with another two thousand on the way.”
tr: “This week, three thousand people arrived at National Homeland No 1, and two thousand are on the way.”
es: This week, three thousand have arrived at National Homeland One, and there are another two thousand in transit.

en: How are they transporting that many people at once?
vi: How did they manage to transport so many people at once?
tr: I wonder how they transport so many people at once?
es: How do they manage to transport so many people at once?

en: Trains, buses?
vi: By train or by car?
tr: By train, by bus?
es: By trains, by buses?

en: We are not shown any pictures of this.
vi: We didn’t get to see any images at all.
tr: Nothing is shown about this.
es: They don't show us any pictures of this.

en: National Homeland One is in North Dakota.
vi: National Settlement 1 is located in North Dakota.
tr: National Homeland No 1 is in North Dakota.
es: The National Homeland One is in North Dakota.

en: Lord knows what they're supposed to do, once they get there.
vi: God knows what they intend for them to do when they get there.
tr: God knows what is expected of them when they get there.
es: God knows what they are supposed to do once they arrive.

en: Farm, is the theory.
vi: Farming, that’s the rumor.
tr: The theory is farming.
es: Dedicate themselves to farming, theoretically.

en: Serena Joy has had enough of the news.
vi: Serena Joy had heard enough.
tr: Serena Joy must have had enough of the news.
es: Serena Joy is already tired of the news.

en: Impatiently she clicks the button for a station change, comes up with an aging bass baritone, his cheeks like emptied udders.
vi: Impatient, she changed the channel, encountering an aging singer with a baritone voice and sagging cheeks like a cow's udder.
tr: She impatiently presses the button to change the station, and an aging bass-baritone with cheeks resembling deflated cow udders appears.
es: She impatiently presses the button to change the channel, and a deep baritone appears, an old man whose cheeks look like dried udders.

en: "Whispering Hope" is what he's singing.
vi: "Gentle Hope" was the song he was singing.
tr: The song he sings is "Whispering Hope."
es: He is singing "Whisper of Hope." Serena turns off the television.

en: Serena turns him off.
vi: Serena turned him off.
tr: Serena turns it off.
es: He is singing "Whisper of Hope." Serena turns off the television.

en: We wait, the clock in the hall ticks, Serena lights another cigarette, 1 get into the car.
vi: We waited, the clock struck the hour in the hall, Serena lit another cigarette, I got into the car.
tr: We are waiting, the clock in the hall is ticking, Serena lights another cigarette, and I get into the car.
es: We wait. The ticking of the clock in the hallway can be heard, Serena lights another cigarette, I get into the car.

en: It's a Saturday morning, it's a September, we still have a car.
vi: This morning is Saturday, September, we still have a car.
tr: A Saturday morning, a September month, we still have a car.
es: It's a Saturday morning in September, we still have a car.

en: Other people have had to sell theirs.
vi: The others have had to sell everything.
tr: Others had to sell their cars.
es: Other people have had to sell theirs.

en: My name isn't Offred, I have another name, which nobody uses now because it's forbidden.
vi: My name is not Offred, I have another name, now no one calls it because it is forbidden.
tr: My name is not Fred's, I have another name, no one uses it anymore because it's forbidden.
es: My name is not Offred, I have another name, a name that no one mentions now because it is forbidden.

en: I tellmyself it doesn't matter, your name is like your telephone number, useful only to others; but what I tell myself is wrong, it does matter.
vi: I tell myself it doesn't matter, a name is like a phone number, just for others to use; but what I tell myself is not true, it does matter.
tr: I tell myself that it doesn't matter, that a name is like a phone number, only useful to others, but that's not true, it actually matters.
es: I tell myself it doesn't matter, the name is like a phone number, it's only useful to others; but what I tell myself is not correct, and this does matter.

en: I keep the knowledge of this name like something hidden, some treasure I'll come back to dig up, one day.
vi: I keep the awareness of this name like a stored object, a treasure I will come back to dig up, later.
tr: I keep the existence of my name like a secret, a treasure I will dig up and uncover one day.
es: I keep this name as something secret, like a treasure that I will unearth someday.

en: I think ofthis name as buried.
vi: I consider that name buried.
tr: I think this name is buried.
es: I think of him as if he were buried.

en: This name has an aura around it, like an amulet, some charm that's survived from an unimaginably distant past.
vi: The name lies within a surrounding aura, like a protective talisman, a spell that has resisted life from a long-lost time.
tr: This name is surrounded by an aura of mystery, like a talisman, a spell from an unimaginably distant past.
es: He is surrounded by an aura, like an amulet, like a spell that has survived an unimaginably distant past.

en: I lie in my single bed at night, with my eyes closed, and the name floats there behind my eyes, not quite within reach, shining in the dark.
vi: Every night I lie on my single bed, eyes closed, and the name hovers behind my eyelids, not quite within reach, glowing in the dark.
tr: I lie in my single bed at night, eyes closed, and the name glows in the dark, moving behind my eyes, but not close enough to reach.
es: At night I lie down in my single bed, close my eyes, and the name floats exactly there, behind my eyes, out of reach, glowing in the dark.

en: It's a Saturday morning in September, I'm wearing my shining name.
vi: This Saturday morning in September, I still carry my radiant name.
tr: On a Saturday morning in September, I carry my shining name.
es: It is a Saturday morning in September, and I put on my shining name.

en: The little girl who is now dead sits in the back seat, with her two best dolls, her stuffed rabbit, mangy with age and love.
vi: The little girl who is now dead is sitting behind, carrying her two most beloved dolls, along with the stuffed rabbit, worn out from age and kisses.
tr: The little girl who is now dead sits in the back seat, with her two best dolls and a frozen rabbit worn out from years and love.
es: The girl who is now dead sits in the back seat, with her two favorite dolls, her plush rabbit, dirty from years and caresses.

en: I know all the details.
vi: I remember every detail clearly.
tr: I know all the details.
es: I know all the details.

en: They are sentimental details but I can't help that.
vi: These details are extremely sentimental, but I can't help it.
tr: These are emotional details, but there's nothing I can do.
es: They are sentimental details, but I can't help it.

en: I can't think about the rabbit too much though, I can't start to cry, here on the Chinese rug, breathing in the smoke that has been inside Serena's body.
vi: But I can't think too much about the rabbit, can't cry right now, on the Chinese carpet, while inhaling the stale smoke from Serena's breath.
tr: Still, I can't think about the rabbit for too long, as I inhale the smoke that has passed through Serena's body, here on the Chinese rug, I can't start crying.
es: However, I must not think too much about the rabbit because I can't start crying here, on the Chinese mat, breathing the smoke that was in Serena's body.

en: Not here, not now, I can do that later.
vi: Not now, not here, save it for another time.
tr: Not here, not now, I can do that later.
es: Not here, not now, I can do it later.

en: She thought we were going on a picnic, and in fact there is a picnic basket on the back seat, beside her, with real food in it, hard-boiled eggs, thermos and all.
vi: I thought the whole family was going on a picnic, and indeed there was a basket of food in the back, next to me, proper food, boiled eggs, a thermos, and all sorts of other things.
tr: He thought we were going on a picnic, and indeed, there was a picnic basket on the back seat next to him, containing real food, that is, hard-boiled eggs, a thermos, and everything.
es: She believed we were going on an excursion, and in fact, in the back seat next to her, there was a basket with food, hard-boiled eggs, a thermos, and everything.

en: We didn't want her to know where we were really going, we didn't want her to tell, by mistake, reveal anything, if we were stopped.
vi: We didn't want you to know where we were actually going, didn't want you to accidentally say something, to reveal anything, in case we were stopped.
tr: We didn't want him to know where we were really going, to tell if we were stopped, to explain everything unintentionally.
es: We didn't want her to know where we were really going, we didn't want her to, if we were stopped, make the mistake of talking and revealing something.

en: We didn't want to lay upon her the burden of our truth.
vi: We didn't want to place the burden of the truth on you.
tr: We didn't want to burden him with the weight of our reality.
es: We didn't want the burden of our truth to weigh on her.

en: I wore my hiking boots, she had on her sneakers.
vi: I put on my running shoes, my child has sports shoes.
tr: I had put on my hiking boots, and he had put on his rubber shoes.
es: I was wearing hiking boots and she was wearing canvas shoes.

en: The laces of the sneakers had a design of hearts on them, red, purple, pink, and yellow.
vi: The shoelaces of my child's shoes are decorated with hearts, red, pink, yellow, and purple.
tr: There were hearts on the laces of the rubber shoes, red, purple, pink, and yellow.
es: The laces of her shoes had hearts drawn in red, purple, pink, and yellow.

en: It was warm for the time of year, the leaves were turning already, some of them; Luke drove, I sat beside him, the sun shone, the sky was blue, the houses as we passed them looked comforting and ordinary, each house as it was left behind vanishing into past
vi: Compared to this month, the weather is quite warm, the leaves are starting to change color, on a few scattered trees; Luke is driving, I sit beside him, the sun is shining, the sky is blue, the houses along the road look cozy and very ordinary, each house left behind disappears into the past, collapsing in an instant as if they never existed, because I will never see them again; or at least I was convinced of that.
tr: The weather was warm for this time of year, some leaves had already started to change color; Luke was driving the car, and I was sitting next to him, the sun was shining, the sky was blue, the houses looked comfortable and familiar as we passed by them, and as the houses were left behind, they disappeared into the past, crumbling in an instant as if they had never existed, because I thought I would never see them again—or so I thought at the time.
es: It was hot for the time of year we were in, some leaves were already starting to fall.

en: time, crumbling in an instant as if it had never been, because I would never see it again, or so I thought then.
vi: Compared to this month, the weather is quite warm, the leaves are starting to change color, on a few scattered trees; Luke is driving, I sit beside him, the sun is shining, the sky is blue, the houses along the road look cozy and very ordinary, each house left behind disappears into the past, collapsing in an instant as if they never existed, because I will never see them again; or at least I was convinced of that.
tr: The weather was warm for this time of year, some leaves had already started to change color; Luke was driving the car, and I was sitting next to him, the sun was shining, the sky was blue, the houses looked comfortable and familiar as we passed by them, and as the houses were left behind, they disappeared into the past, crumbling in an instant as if they had never existed, because I thought I would never see them again—or so I thought at the time.
es: Luke was driving, I was beside him, the sun was shining, the sky was blue, the houses looked comfortable and normal, and each one faded into the past, crumbled in an instant as if it had never existed, because I would never see them again; at least that's what I thought then.

en: We have almost nothing with us, we don't want to look as if we're going anywhere far or permanent.
vi: We hardly brought anything with us, not wanting to give the impression that we were going on a long or distant trip.
tr: There is almost nothing with us, we don't want to look like we are going far away or going somewhere permanently.
es: We are taking almost nothing with us; we don't want to give the impression that we are going somewhere far or permanently.

en: We have the forged passports, guaranteed, worth the price.
vi: We carried fake passports, very reliable, worth the money.
tr: The fake passports are with us, guaranteed, worth the money we paid.
es: The passports are fake, but they are guaranteed: they are worth what we paid for them.

en: We couldn't pay in money, of course, orput it on the Compucount: we used other things, some jewelry that was my grandmother's, a stamp collection Luke inherited from his uncle.
vi: Of course, we didn't pay with money, nor did we count it as a computer expense: we used another method, a few pieces of jewelry my grandmother left behind, and a stamp collection Luke inherited from his uncle.
tr: We couldn't pay in cash, of course, nor could we give it to Kompükaunt. We used other things, a few of my grandmother's jewels, the stamp collection Luke inherited from his uncle.
es: We couldn't pay for them with money, of course, nor put them on the Compubank account, but we used other things: some of my mother's jewelry, a stamp collection that Luke had inherited from his uncle.

en: Such things can be exchanged, for money, in other countries.
vi: Those items could be exchanged for money abroad.
tr: These kinds of things can be converted into money in other countries.
es: These kinds of things can be exchanged for money in other countries.

en: When we get to the border we'll pretend we're just going over on a day trip; the fake visas are for a day.
vi: When we reached the border, we would pretend to be on a day trip; the fake visa stamps were only effective for a day.
tr: When we get to the border, we will pretend we are just going on a day trip; the fake visas are only for one day.
es: When we reach the border, we will pretend that we are only going on a day trip; the fake visas are only valid for one day.

en: Before that I'll give her a sleeping pill so she'll be asleep when we cross.
vi: Before that, I would give my child sleeping pills so they would sleep while crossing the border.
tr: Before that, I will give him a sleeping pill, so he will be asleep while we cross the border.
es: Before that, I will give her a sleeping pill, so that when we cross, she will already be asleep.

en: That way she won't betray us.
vi: That way, the child wouldn't give us away.
tr: That way, he won't give us away.
es: That way, she won't betray us.

en: You can't expect a child to lie convincingly.
vi: You can't expect children to lie smoothly.
tr: You can't expect a child to lie convincingly.
es: You can't expect a child to be convincing when lying.

en: And I don't want her to feel frightened, to feel thefear that is now tightening my muscles, tensing my spine, pulling me so taut that I'm certain I would break if touched.
vi: And I didn't want my child to be terrified, didn't want them to feel the horror tightening every muscle, straightening my spine, making me so tense that I feared I would shatter if anyone touched me.
tr: Moreover, I don't want him to feel the fear that makes my muscles tense, my spine stiffen, and keeps me so on edge that I'm sure I'll break if touched.
es: I don't want her to get scared, nor to feel the fear that now grips my muscles, tenses my spine, leaves me so tight that I'm sure if someone touches me, I'll break.

en: Every stoplight is an ordeal.
vi: Each stop was a trial by fire.
tr: Every red traffic light is a test of endurance.
es: Every red traffic light is like an agony.

en: We'll spend the night at a motel, or, better, sleeping in the car on a side road so there will be no suspicious questions.
vi: We would sleep at a motel, or better yet, in the car, on a side road to avoid suspicious questions.
tr: We'll spend the night in a motel or, better yet, sleeping in the car on a side road, so there won't be any suspicious questions.
es: We'll spend the night in a motel, or better yet, we'll sleep in the car, on the side of the road, and avoid the suspicious questions.

en: We'll cross in the morning, drive over the bridge, easily, just like driving to the supermarket.
vi: We would cross the border in the morning, over the bridge, very simple, just like driving to the supermarket.
tr: In the morning, we'll cross the border, over the bridge, just like going to the supermarket.
es: We'll cross in the morning, we'll go over the bridge with complete calm, as if we were going to the supermarket.

en: We turn onto the freeway, head north, flowing with not much traffic.
vi: The car turned onto the highway, heading north, the road was deserted, moving smoothly.
tr: We turn onto the bypass road with little traffic, heading north.
es: We entered the toll-free highway, heading north, and drove with little traffic.

en: Since the war started, gas is expensive and in short supply.
vi: Since the onset of the war, gas prices have surged, and it has also become scarce.
tr: Because the war has started, gasoline is expensive and scarce.
es: Since the war started, gasoline is expensive and scarce.

en: Outside thecity we pass the first checkpoint.
vi: Leaving the city meant passing through the first checkpoint.
tr: We pass the first checkpoint outside the city.
es: Once out of the city, we passed the first checkpoint.

en: All they want is a look at the license, Luke does it well.
vi: They only asked to see the driver's license, Luke managed it fine.
tr: All they want is to check the license; Luke handles this well.
es: They only want to see the permit.

en: The license matches the passport: we thought of that.
vi: The driver's license and passport matched: that was accounted for.
tr: The license matches the passport: We had thought of this.
es: Luke passes the test: the permit matches the passport; we had already thought of that.

en: Back on the road, he squeezes my hand, glances over at me.
vi: When we set off again, he squeezed my hand tightly and looked at me.
tr: When we return to the road, Luke squeezes my hand and looks at me.
es: Back on the road again, he grabs my hand tightly and looks at me.

en: You're white as a sheet, he says.
vi: You are as pale as a sheet of paper, he said.
tr: You're as white as a sheet, he says.
es: You're as white as a sheet, he says to me.

en: That is how I feel: white, flat, thin.
vi: And I felt exactly like that: white, flat, paper-thin.
tr: I feel exactly like this: white, flat, thin.
es: This is how I feel: white, crushed, thin.

en: I feel transparent.
vi: I felt transparent.
tr: It feels like I'm transparent.
es: I feel transparent.

en: Surely they will be able to see through me.
vi: Surely they would see right through to my heart and liver.
tr: I'm sure they will understand what goes through me.
es: Surely you can see right through me.

en: Worse, how will 1 be able to hold on to Luke, to her, when I'm so flat, so while?
vi: Worse, how could I hold on to Luke, to the child, if I was this flat, this white?
tr: It's bad; how will I stay loyal to Luke, to my daughter, when I'm so flat, so white?
es: Even worse, how will I be able to support Luke and her if I am so crushed, so pale?

en: I feel as if there's not much left of me; they will slip through my arms, as if I'm made of smoke, as if I'm a mirage, fading before their eyes.
vi: I felt like there was hardly anything left of me; the two of them would slip out of my arms, as if I were made of smoke, a desert mirage, gradually fading before their eyes.
tr: I feel like there's not much left of me; they will slip through my arms, as if I'm made of smoke, as if I'm a mirage, disappearing right before their eyes.
es: I feel like I have no strength left; it will slip through my hands, as if I were made of smoke, or as if I were a mirage that fades before their eyes.

en: Don't think that way, Moira
vi: Don't think like that, Moira would surely say.
tr: Don't think like that, Moira would say.
es: Don't think like that, Moira would say.

en: would say.
vi: Don't think like that, Moira would surely say.
tr: Don't think like that, Moira would say.
es: Don't think like that, Moira would say.

en: Think that way and you'll make it happen.
vi: Thinking like that will make it happen.
tr: As you think, so shall it be.
es: If you think it, you'll make it happen.

en: Cheer up, says Luke.
vi: Smile, Luke said.
tr: Come on, cheer up, says Luke.
es: Cheer up, says Luke.

en: He's driving a little too fast now.
vi: Now you're going a bit fast.
tr: Now he's driving a bit too fast.
es: He is driving too fast.

en: The adrenaline's gone to his head.
vi: The blood has rushed to your head.
tr: The adrenaline has gone to his head.
es: The adrenaline level in his head has dropped.

en: Now he's singing.
vi: Now you're even singing.
tr: Now he's singing.
es: He is singing.

en: Oh what a beautiful morning, he sings.
vi: Life is still beautiful, you hum.
tr: Oh what a beautiful morning, he sings.
es: Oh, what a beautiful day, he sings.

en: Even his singing worries me.
vi: Even that matter worries me.
tr: Even its song makes me anxious.
es: Even their singing worries me.

en: We've been warned not to look too happy.
vi: People have warned not to show too much joy. 15
tr: We were warned not to appear overly happy. 15
es: We were warned that we should not appear too cheerful. CHAPTER 15

en: The Commander knocks at the door.
vi: The Commander knocked on the door.
tr: The Commander is knocking on the door.
es: The Commander knocks on the door.

en: The knock is prescribed: the sitting room is supposed to be Serena Joy's territory, he's supposed to ask permission toenter it.
vi: That was the rule: the sitting room was considered Serena Joy's territory, and he had to ask permission to enter.
tr: That's the rule: The living room is assumed to be Serena Joy's territory, and the Commander needs to ask for permission to enter. Serena
es: The call is mandatory: it is assumed that the room is Serena Joy's territory, and that he must ask for permission to enter.

en: She likes to keep him waiting.
vi: She liked to make him wait.
tr: Joy likes to keep him waiting.
es: She likes to make him wait.

en: It's a little thing, but in this household little things mean a lot.
vi: A small matter, but in this household, every small matter had significance.
tr: It's a small thing, but even small things are very important in this house.
es: It's an insignificant detail, but in this house, insignificant details are very important.

en: Tonight, however, she doesn't even get that, because before Serena Joy can speak he steps forward into the room anyway.
vi: However, tonight, she did not even have that pleasure, because before she could say anything, he had already stepped into the room.
tr: But tonight, she can't savor it, because the Commander enters the room before Serena Joy can even open her mouth.
es: However, tonight she doesn't even have time to do it because, before she can say a word, he has entered.

en: Maybe he's just forgotten the protocol, but maybe it's deliberate.
vi: It could simply be that he forgot the convention, or it could be deliberate.
tr: Maybe he just forgot the protocol, or maybe he did it on purpose.
es: Maybe he simply forgot the protocol, but perhaps he did it deliberately.

en: Who knows what she said to him, over the silver-encrusted dinner table?
vi: Who knows what she had said to him at the glittering silver dinner table?
tr: Who can tell what Serena Joy said to him over the dinner table adorned with silverware?
es: Who knows what she told him while they were dining, sitting at the table inlaid with silver.

en: Or didn't say.
vi: Or perhaps said nothing at all.
tr: Or what she didn't say.
es: Or what she didn't tell him.

en: The Commander has on his black uniform, in which he looks like a museum guard.
vi: The commander wore a black uniform, looking like a museum guard.
tr: On the Commander, there is a black uniform in which he resembles a museum guard.
es: The Commander is wearing a black uniform, which makes him look like a museum guard.

en: A semiretired man, genial but wary, killing time.
vi: Half-retired, courteous but suspicious, sitting idle all day.
tr: A semi-retired man, pleasant but cautious, busy killing time.
es: Or a semi-retired man, cordial but cautious, who spends his time idly.

en: But only at first glance.
vi: But that's just at first glance.
tr: But this impression only comes at first glance.
es: But that is the first impression he gives.

en: After that he looks like a midwestern bank president, with his straight neatly brushed silver hair, his sober posture, shoulders a little stooped.
vi: Upon closer inspection, he resembled a Midwestern banker, with neatly combed silver hair, a dignified demeanor, and slightly hunched shoulders.
tr: After that, with his straight and carefully combed silvery hair, measured posture, and slightly slouched shoulders, he resembles a Midwestern bank president.
es: If you look closely, he resembles a Midwestern bank president, with his smooth, neatly brushed silver hair, his serious demeanor, and his slightly hunched back.

en: And after that there is his mustache, silver also, and after that his chin, which really you can't miss.
vi: Look even closer and you'll see his mustache is also silver, and then there's the chin, which no one could overlook.
tr: Then there's his silvery mustache and, following that, his chin, which you really can't miss.
es: And then there's his mustache, also silver, and his chin, a feature impossible to overlook.

en: When you get down as far as the chin he looks like a vodka ad, in a glossy magazine, of times gone by.
vi: Down to the chin, he looked like a vodka advertisement from a glossy magazine, from a bygone era.
tr: By the time you get this far, you might compare him to models in a vodka advertisement from a bygone era's glossy magazine.
es: If you look further down from his chin, he resembles a vodka advertisement from one of those glossy magazines from the old days.

en: His manner is mild, his hands large, with thick fingers and acquisitive thumbs, his blue eyes uncommunicative, falsely innocuous.
vi: He had a gentle demeanor, large hands, thick fingers, a greedy thumb, blue eyes that were completely closed off, deceptively harmless.
tr: His behaviors are soft, his hands with thick fingers and greedy thumbs have a large, false harmlessness, and his blue eyes are uncommunicative.
es: His manners are gentle, his hands large, with thick fingers and greedy thumbs, his eyes blue and reserved, falsely harmless.

en: He looks us over as if taking inventory.
vi: He looked at us as if taking inventory.
tr: As if taking inventory, he scrutinizes us one by one.
es: He gives us a glance, as if taking inventory: a woman in red kneeling, one in blue sitting, two in green standing, a lone man with a thin face at the back.

en: One kneeling woman in red, one seated woman in blue, two in green, standing, a solitary man, thin-faced, in the background.
vi: A woman in red knelt, a woman in blue sat, two in green stood, and a single man, with a bony face, formed the background.
tr: A woman kneeling in red, another sitting in blue, two in green standing, and a single man with a thin face in the background.
es: He gives us a glance, as if taking inventory: a woman in red kneeling, one in blue sitting, two in green standing, a lone man with a thin face at the back.

en: He manages to appear puzzled, as if he can't quite remember how we all got in here.
vi: He skillfully feigned confusion, as if he couldn't quite remember why all these women were here.
tr: He manages to look surprised, as if he doesn't quite remember how we all got here.
es: He manages to appear puzzled, as if he cannot exactly remember how many of us there are.

en: As ifwe are something he inherited, like a Victorian pump organ, and he hasn't figured out what to do with us.
vi: Like things that had just been picked up by chance, a Victorian foot-pedal piano, he hadn't figured out what to do with us.
tr: As if we are something inherited by him, like a Victorian organ, and he hasn't decided what to do with us yet.
es: As if we were something inherited, for example a Victorian organ, and he didn't know what to do with us.

en: What we are worth.
vi: Or how much we were worth.
tr: What our value is.
es: Nor what we are for.

en: He nods in the general direction of Serena Joy, who does not make a
vi: He nodded vaguely in the direction of Serena Joy, who did not open her mouth.
tr: He nods slightly towards Serena Joy, but she remains silent.
es: She tilts her head in the direction of Serena Joy, who does not make a single sound.

en: sound.
vi: He nodded vaguely in the direction of Serena Joy, who did not open her mouth.
tr: He nods slightly towards Serena Joy, but she remains silent.
es: She tilts her head in the direction of Serena Joy, who does not make a single sound.

en: He crosses to the large leather chair reserved for him, takes the key out of his pocket, fumbles with the ornate brass-bound leather-covered box that stands on the table beside the chair.
vi: He walked across the room to the large leather armchair reserved for him, took a key from his pocket, and fumbled with the intricately brass-bound leather box placed on the side table next to the chair.
tr: He moves towards the large leather chair assigned to him, takes the key out of his pocket, and reaches for the ornate brass-bound, leather-covered box next to the chair.
es: He advances towards the large leather chair reserved for him, takes the key out of his pocket, and fumbles in the copper-plated box with a leather lid that is on the table next to the chair.

en: He inserts the key, opens the box, lifts out the Bible, an ordinary copy, with a black cover and gold-edged pages.
vi: He inserted the key, opened the box, and took out a Bible, a regular edition, black cover, gold-edged pages.
tr: He inserts the key into the lock and opens the box, taking out an ordinary Bible with a black cover and gold-gilded page edges.
es: He inserts the key, opens the box, and takes out a copy of the Bible with black covers and gold-edged pages.

en: The Bibleis kept locked up, the way people once kept tea locked up, so the servants wouldn't steal it.
vi: The Bible was securely locked, like how tea used to be locked up in the past, so that the servants couldn't steal it.
tr: The Bible is kept under lock and key, just as people used to keep tea locked up to prevent servants from stealing it.
es: The Bible is kept under lock and key, as many people used to do with tea to prevent the servants from stealing it.

en: It is an incendiary device: who knows what we'd make of it, if we ever got our hands on it?
vi: A firebomb: who knows what we would do with it, if we could get our hands on it?
tr: This is very cunning: Even if we could touch the Bible, who knows what we would do with it?
es: It's an absurd stratagem: who knows what we would do with it if we ever got our hands on it?

en: We can be read to from it, by him, but we cannot read.
vi: We are read to, thanks to him, but we are not allowed to read.
tr: Something from the Bible can be read to us by the Commander, but we cannot read it on our own.
es: He can read it to us, but we cannot read it ourselves.

en: Our heads turn towards him, we are expectant, here comes our bedtime story.
vi: All heads turned towards him, expectant, the story-telling time had come.
tr: Our heads turn towards him, eagerly waiting; it's time for our bedtime story.
es: We turn our heads in his direction, expectant: we are about to hear a bedtime story.

en: The Commander sits down and crosses his legs, watched by us.
vi: The commander sat down cross-legged, under the gaze of ten eyes.
tr: While being watched by us, the Commander sits down and crosses his legs.
es: The Commander sits down and crosses his legs, while we watch him.

en: The bookmarks are in place.
vi: The bookmarks were all in place.
tr: The bookmarks are in place.
es: The markers are in their place.

en: He opens the book.
vi: He opened the scripture.
tr: He opens the book.
es: He opens the book.

en: He clears his throat a little, as if embarrassed.
vi: He cleared his throat slightly, seemingly embarrassed.
tr: He clears his throat, as if bored.
es: He clears his throat, as if he feels uncomfortable.

en: "Could I have a drink of water?" he says to the air.
vi: “Give me a glass of water,” he said absentmindedly.
tr: "Can I have a glass of water?" he says out loud.
es: —Could I have a little water? —he says, leaving the Question hanging in the air—.

en: "Please," he adds.
vi: “Is that okay?” he added.
tr: "Please," he adds.
es: Please —he adds.

en: Behind me, one of them, Cora or Rita, leaves her space in the tableau and pads off towards the kitchen.
vi: Behind me, one of the two, Cora or Rita, left the scene and waddled towards the kitchen.
tr: Someone behind me, either Cora or Rita, quietly leaves their place at the table and walks towards the kitchen.
es: Behind my back, Rita or Cora—one of the two—leaves her spot in the family portrait and walks silently to the kitchen.

en: The Commander sits, looking down.
vi: The Commander sat there, eyes on the floor.
tr: The Commander sits with his head bowed.
es: The Commander waits, with his eyes downcast.

en: The Commander sighs, takes out a pair of reading glasses from his inside jacket pocket, gold rims, slips them on.
vi: The Commander sighed, pulled a pair of gold-rimmed glasses from his inner pocket, and pushed them up his nose.
tr: He sighs, takes out a pair of gold-framed reading glasses from the inner pocket of his jacket, and puts them on.
es: He sighs; from the inner pocket of his jacket, he takes out a pair of gold-rimmed reading glasses and puts them on.

en: Now he looks like a shoemaker in an old fairy-tale book.
vi: Now he looked like the old shoemaker from a fairy tale.
tr: Now he looks like a cobbler from an old fairy tale.
es: Now he looks like a shoemaker from an old storybook.

en: Is there no end to his disguises, of benevolence?
vi: Did he have an endless reserve of masks, those of human prisoners?
tr: Is there no end to the angel of mercy masks he constantly changes?
es: Will his disguises as a benevolent man never end?

en: We watch him: every inch, every flicker.
vi: We monitored: every centimeter, every startle.
tr: We are watching him: down to the millimeter, even the slightest movement.
es: We observe each of their gestures, each of their features.

en: To be a man, watched by women.
vi: Being a man, among a group of women watching.
tr: To be a man, watched by women.
es: A man observed by several women.

en: It must be entirely strange.
vi: It must be very strange.
tr: It must be entirely strange.
es: He must feel something very strange.

en: To have them watching him all the time.
vi: When you let them, attentively watching you, at all times.
tr: To always make women watch him.
es: They watching him all the time and wondering, what will he do now?

en: To have them wondering, What's he going to do next?
vi: When you let them guess, What will you do next?
tr: To make them wonder, what will he do next.
es: They watching him all the time and wondering, what will he do now?

en: To have them flinch when he moves, even if it's a harmless enough move, to reach for an ashtray perhaps.
vi: Making them flinch at every movement, no matter how harmless, like reaching for an ashtray.
tr: When he moves, even if it's a very harmless movement, like reaching for an ashtray, to startle the women.
es: Backing away every time he moves, even if it's as harmless a movement as reaching for an ashtray.

en: To have them sizing him up.
vi: Letting them measure you.
tr: To make them measure and evaluate every move.
es: Judging him, thinking: he can't do it, he won't be good enough, he'll have to be good enough, and making this last statement as if he were an outdated or poor-quality garment that must be worn anyway because there's nothing else.

en: To have them thinking, Hee can't do it, he won't do, he'll have to do, this last as if he were a garment, out of style or shoddy, which must nevertheless be put on because there's nothing else available.
vi: Letting them think to themselves, No, no way, it has to be this way, the third sentence as if you were some kind of outfit, shabby or second-rate, still having to wear it because otherwise there's nothing else.
tr: To make them think, he can't do this, he won't do this, he will have to do this, like a garment that must be worn out of necessity, outdated and shabby.
es: Judging him, thinking: he can't do it, he won't be good enough, he'll have to be good enough, and making this last statement as if he were an outdated or poor-quality garment that must be worn anyway because there's nothing else.

en: To have them putting him on, trying him on, trying him out, while he himself puts them on, like a sock over a tool, onto the stub of himself,
vi: To let them bring him in, fit him, test him, while he also brings them in, like putting a sock on a foot, wrapping around his stubby tail, the very sensitive extra thumb, the tentacle, the weak stalked eye of a naked snail, knowing how to extend, expand, retract, or curl back inside if touched the wrong way, then enlarge, slightly swell at the tip, move forward as if along a leaf stalk, into them, eager to see.
tr: To have women dress him, inspect him, measure him, while he dresses them as easily as putting on a sock, to touch the protrusion of his body, his overly sensitive big toe, his touch, the fragile stalked eye of a snail, protruding, expanding, recoiling in fear, retracting back into itself when touched by mistake, moving towards them, eager to see, advancing as if on a leaf, revealing a bit at the tip and then growing again.
es: They put it on, try it on, while he, in turn, puts them on as one puts on a sock, fits them onto his own appendage, his sensitive spare thumb, his tentacle, his lurking slug eye that protrudes, expands, retracts, and folds back on itself when touched incorrectly, and grows again, enlarging slightly at the tip, advancing as if delving into the foliage, inside them, eager for visions.

en: his extra, sensitive thumb, his tentacle, his delicate, stalked slug's eye, which extrudes, expands, winces, and shrivels back into himself when touched wrongly, grows big again, bulging a little at the tip, traveling forward as if along a leaf, into them, avid for vision.
vi: To let them bring him in, fit him, test him, while he also brings them in, like putting a sock on a foot, wrapping around his stubby tail, the very sensitive extra thumb, the tentacle, the weak stalked eye of a naked snail, knowing how to extend, expand, retract, or curl back inside if touched the wrong way, then enlarge, slightly swell at the tip, move forward as if along a leaf stalk, into them, eager to see.
tr: To have women dress him, inspect him, measure him, while he dresses them as easily as putting on a sock, to touch the protrusion of his body, his overly sensitive big toe, his touch, the fragile stalked eye of a snail, protruding, expanding, recoiling in fear, retracting back into itself when touched by mistake, moving towards them, eager to see, advancing as if on a leaf, revealing a bit at the tip and then growing again.
es: They put it on, try it on, while he, in turn, puts them on as one puts on a sock, fits them onto his own appendage, his sensitive spare thumb, his tentacle, his lurking slug eye that protrudes, expands, retracts, and folds back on itself when touched incorrectly, and grows again, enlarging slightly at the tip, advancing as if delving into the foliage, inside them, eager for visions.

en: To achieve vision in this way, this journey into a darkness that is composed of women, a woman, who can see in darkness while he himself strains blindly forward.
vi: To see in that way, through a journey into the darkness, the kind of darkness formed by a woman, by a woman who knows how to see in the dark while he here strains forward in blindness.
tr: The idea of obtaining in this way, making this journey towards the darkness formed by a woman, from women who can see in the dark while he blindly lunges forward.
es: To reach the vision in this way, through this journey in the darkness that is composed of women, of a woman who can see in the dark while he blindly hunches forward.

en: She watches him from within.
vi: That person is watching him from the inside.
tr: Serena Joy is watching him from the inside.
es: She watches him from the inside.

en: We're all watching him.
vi: We are all watching him.
tr: We are all watching.
es: We all watch him.

en: It's the one thing we can really do, and it is not for nothing: if he were to falter, fail, or die, what would become of us?
vi: The only thing we are truly allowed to do, which is not meaningless: if he hesitates, loses, if he dies, what will become of us?
tr: It's really the only thing we can do, and it's not for nothing: If he were to stumble, fail, or die, what would become of us?
es: It is something we can really do, and not in vain: what would become of us if he broke down or died?

en: No wonder he's like a boot, hard on the outside, giving shape to a pulp of tenderfoot.
vi: No wonder he is like a boot, with a hard exterior, encasing white feet.
tr: It's not surprising that he is like a boot, hard on the outside, but shaping to a soft foot.
es: It wouldn't surprise me if beneath his tough exterior there was a tender being hidden.

en: That's just a wish.
vi: But this is just a wish.
tr: This is just a wish.
es: But this is only wishful thinking.

en: I've been watching him for some time and he's given no evidence, of softness.
vi: I have observed him for quite a while and have not seen any signs of weakness.
tr: I've been watching him for a while and he hasn't shown any signs of softness.
es: I've been watching him for some time and he hasn't shown any signs of softness.

en: But watch out, Commander, I tell him in my head.
vi: But beware, Commander, I whispered in my head.
tr: But be careful, Commander, I say in my head.
es: But be careful, Commander, I tell him mentally.

en: I've got my eye on you.
vi: I still keep an eye on you.
tr: I'm watching you.
es: I don't lose sight of you.

en: One false move and I'm dead.
vi: A slight move and I'm dead.
tr: One wrong move and I'm dead.
es: One false move and I'm a dead woman.

en: Still, it must be hell, to be a man, like that.
vi: Anyway, it must be really miserable to be a man like that.
tr: Still, it must be like hell to be a man in this way.
es: However, it must seem incredible to be a man like that.

en: It must be just fine.
vi: It should be fine.
tr: It must be quite pleasant.
es: It must be fantastic.

en: It must be hell.
vi: It must be really miserable.
tr: It must be like hell.
es: It must be incredible.

en: It must be very silent.
vi: It must be extremely lonely.
tr: It must be very quiet.
es: It must be very quiet.

en: The water appears, the Commander drinks it.
vi: The water arrived, the Commander drank.
tr: The water came, the Commander is drinking.
es: The water arrives, and the Commander drinks.

en: "Thank you," he says.
vi: "Thank you," he said.
tr: "Thank you," he says.
es: —Thank you —he says.

en: Cora rustles back into place.
vi: Cora shuffled back to her place.
tr: Cora returns to her place with a rustle.
es: Cora returns to her place.

en: The Commander pauses, looking down, scanning the page.
vi: The commander paused, looked down, and scrutinized the page.
tr: With his head bowed, the Commander pauses as he reviews the page.
es: The Commander pauses and lowers his gaze to search for the page.

en: He takes his time, as if unconscious of us.
vi: Very leisurely, as if he didn't remember our presence.
tr: He is not in a hurry, as if he is unaware of our presence.
es: He takes his time, as if unaware of our presence.

en: He's like a man toying with a steak, behind a restaurant window, pretending not to see the eyes watching him from hungry darkness not three feet from his elbow.
vi: Like a diner poking at a steak, behind the restaurant's glass, pretending not to see the hungry eyes watching from the darkness less than a meter away.
tr: He resembles a man playing with his steak, pretending not to see the eyes watching him from the hungry darkness just a meter away behind a restaurant window.
es: It is like someone toying with a steak, sitting by the window of a restaurant, pretending not to see the eyes watching from the hungry darkness less than a meter away.

en: We lean towards him a little, iron filings to his magnet.
vi: We leaned slightly towards him, like iron filings drawn to a magnet.
tr: We lean towards him a bit, like iron filings caught by his magnet.
es: We lean in a bit towards him, like iron filings reacting to his magnetism.

en: He has something we don't have, he has the word.
vi: If he tested us, he would find us lacking, he would have words.
tr: He possesses something we do not have, the power of speech.
es: He has something we do not have, he has the word.

en: How we squandered it, once.
vi: But in the past, we squandered so much.
tr: How we used to squander it, once upon a time.
es: How we used to waste it in other times.

en: The Commander, as if reluctantly, begins to read.
vi: The commander, seemingly reluctant, opened his mouth and read aloud.
tr: How we used to squander it, once upon a time.
es: The Commander starts to read, but it seems like he does it reluctantly.

en: He isn't very good at it.
vi: The reading wasn't very good.
tr: How we used to squander it, once upon a time.
es: He is not very good at reading.

en: Maybe lie's merely bored.
vi: It might have been just out of boredom.
tr: Familiar story, familiar stories.
es: Maybe he is simply bored.

en: It's the usual story, the usual stories.
vi: It's still the same old story, still the same old stories.
tr: Familiar story, familiar stories.
es: It is the usual story, the usual stories.

en: God to Adam, God to Noah.
vi: God told Adam, God told Noah.
tr: God to Adam, God to Noah.
es: God speaking to Adam. God speaking to Noah.

en: lie fruitful, and multiply, and replenish the earth.
vi: Be fruitful and multiply, and fill the earth.
tr: Be fruitful and multiply and fill the earth.
es: Be fruitful and multiply and fill the earth.

en: Then comes the moldy
vi: Then came Rachel and Leah with the musty smell we were stuffed with at the Center.
tr: Then comes that old Rachel and Leah nonsense we were filled with at the Center.
