es: Then comes all that boring nonsense about Rachel and Leah that they drilled into us at the Center.

en: old Rachel anil Leah stuff we had drummed into us at the Center.
vi: Then came Rachel and Leah with the musty smell we were stuffed with at the Center.
tr: Then comes that old Rachel and Leah nonsense we were filled with at the Center.
es: Then comes all that boring nonsense about Rachel and Leah that they drilled into us at the Center.

en: Give me children, or else I die.
vi: Give me children, or else I die.
tr: Give me children, or else I die.
es: Give me children, or I shall die.

en: Am I in God's stead, who hath withheld from thee the fruit of the womb?
vi: Am I in the place of God, who has withheld children from you?
tr: Am I in the place of God, who has withheld the fruit of the womb from you?
es: Am I, instead of God, who prevents you from bearing fruit from your womb?

en: Behold my maid Bilhah.
vi: Here is my maid Bilhah.
tr: Here is my maid Bilhah.
es: Here is my maid Bilhah.

en: She shall bear upon my knees, that I may also have children by her.
vi: She shall bear a child on my knees, so that I too may have children through her.
tr: Let her bear upon my knees, that I may also have children by her.
es: She will bear children on my knees, and I too will have children through her.

en: And so on and so forth.
vi: And so on and so forth.
tr: Et cetera, et cetera.
es: Et cetera, et cetera.

en: We had it read to us every breakfast, as we sat in the high school cafeteria, eating porridge with cream and brown sugar.
vi: We heard it along with breakfast, sitting in the high school cafeteria, eating oatmeal with cream and brown sugar.
tr: This was read to us while we sat in the high school cafeteria eating mush with cream and brown sugar, every breakfast.
es: They read it to us every day during breakfast, when we sat in the school cafeteria eating oatmeal with cream and brown sugar.

en: You're getting the best, you know, said Aunt Lydia.
vi: You are getting the best, you know, Aunt Lydia said.
tr: You know you're getting the best, Aunt Lydia would say.
es: You have everything the best, Aunt Lydia would say.

en: There's a war on, things are rationed.
vi: It's wartime, and all essentials are rationed.
tr: There's a war out there, everything is rationed.
es: We are at war and things are rationed.

en: You are spoiled girls, she twinkled, as if rebuking a kitten.
vi: You girls are spoiled, she blinked, as if scolding a child.
tr: You're bad girls; her eye twitching, like scolding a kitten.
es: You are spoiled girls, she continued, as if scolding a kitten.

en: Naughty puss.
vi: You naughty little thing.
tr: Bad kitty, bad kitty.
es: Naughty kitten.

en: For lunch it was the Beatitudes.
vi: As for lunch, there are Eight Beatitudes.
tr: At lunch, Absolute Bliss3 was read.
es: During lunch, it was the beatitudes.

en: Blessed be this, blessed be that.
vi: Blessed are this, blessed are that.
tr: How happy I am, how happy he/she is.
es: Blessed this, blessed that.

en: They played it from a tape, so not even an Aunt would be guilty of the sin of reading.
vi: Play the tape recording, so that even the nuns do not commit the sin of reading.
tr: They played this from a disc, the voice belonged to a man.
es: They played a record, sung by a man.

en: The voice was a man's.
vi: A man's voice.
tr: They played this from a disc, the voice belonged to a man.
es: They played a record, sung by a man.

en: Blessed be the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.
vi: Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.
tr: Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.
es: Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.

en: Blessed are the merciful.
vi: Blessed are the merciful.
tr: Blessed are the merciful.
es: Blessed are the meek.

en: Blessed be the meek.
vi: Blessed are the meek.
tr: Blessed are the meek.
es: Blessed are the meek.

en: Blessed are the silent.
vi: Blessed are those who keep their mouths shut.
tr: Blessed are the peacemakers.
es: Blessed are the silent ones.

en: I knew they made that up, I knew it was wrong, and they left things out, too, but there was no way of checking.
vi: I know they made this up, I know it's wrong, and they also cut out a lot, but there's no way to verify.
tr: I knew they made these up, I knew it was wrong, and I also knew they skipped some words in between, but there was no way to check it.
es: I knew that they made it up, that it wasn't like that, and also that they omitted words, but there was no way to verify it.

en: Blessed be those that mourn, for they shall be comforted.
vi: Blessed are those who mourn, for they will be comforted.
tr: Blessed are those who mourn; for they shall be comforted.
es: Blessed are those who mourn, for they will be comforted.

en: Nobody said when.
vi: No one knows when.
tr: No one could say when this would happen.
es: Nobody said when.

en: I check the clock, during dessert, canned pears with cinnamon, standard for lunch, and look for Moira in her place, two tables over.
vi: I kept an eye on the clock, during dessert, a pear with cinnamon, the standard lunch, and glanced around to find Moira two tables away.
tr: I'm checking the time while eating the standard lunch of cinnamon canned pears. I look over to where Moira is sitting, two tables away.
es: While we eat dessert —canned pears with cinnamon, the usual for lunch—, I look at the clock and search for Moira, who is sitting two tables away.

en: She's gone already.
vi: She was already gone.
tr: She's already gone.
es: She has already left.

en: I put my hand up, I am excused.
vi: I raised my hand, with permission.
tr: I raise my hand, permission is granted.
es: I raise my hand to ask for permission.

en: We don't do this too often, and always at different times of day.
vi: We didn't go too often, and the timing always changed.
tr: We do this very often, always at different times of the day.
es: We don't do it very often, and we always choose different times of the day.

en: In the washroom I go to the second-last stall, as usual.
vi: When I went to the restroom, I entered the second stall from the inside, as usual.
tr: I enter the second-to-last stall in the restroom, as usual.
es: Once in the bathrooms, I go into the second-to-last stall, as usual.

en: Are you there?
vi: Do you have it?
tr: Are you there, I whisper.
es: Are you there?, I whisper.

en: I whisper.
vi: I whispered.
tr: Are you there, I whisper.
es: Are you there?, I whisper.

en: Large as life and twice as ugly, Moira whispers back.
vi: Present, although the face is quite a mess, Moira whispered in response.
tr: As big as life and twice as ugly, Moira whispers back.
es: Moira answers me in person.

en: What have you heard?
vi: What did you hear?
tr: What did you hear?
es: Have you heard anything?, I ask him.

en: I ask her.
vi: I asked.
tr: I ask him.
es: Have you heard anything?, I ask him.

en: Nothing much.
vi: Not much.
tr: It's not much.
es: Not much.

en: I've got to get out of here, I'm going bats.
vi: I have to get out of here, I'm going crazy.
tr: I need to get out of here, I'm about to go crazy.
es: I have to get out of here, or I'll go crazy.

en: I feel panic.
vi: I'm terrified.
tr: I panic.
es: I feel panic.

en: No, no, Moira, I say, don't try it.
vi: No, Moira, I said, don't risk it.
tr: No, no, Moira, I say, don't try this.
es: No, Moira, I tell her, don't try it.

en: Not on your own.
vi: You can't do it alone.
tr: It won't work on its own.
es: And even less so alone.

en: I'll fake sick.
vi: I'll pretend to be sick.
tr: I will pretend to be a patient.
es: I will pretend to be sick.

en: They send an ambulance, I've seen it.
vi: There will be an ambulance, I saw it already.
tr: They are sending an ambulance, I have seen it before.
es: They send an ambulance, I've already seen it.

en: You'll only get as far as the hospital.
vi: You can only get to the hospital and that's it.
tr: However, you can only reach the hospital.
es: At most, you will reach the hospital.

en: At least it'll be a change.
vi: At least it's a change of scenery.
tr: At least it would be a change.
es: At least it will be a change.

en: I won't have to listen to that old bitch.
vi: I don't have to listen to that nagging woman anymore.
tr: I wouldn't have to listen to that old whore.
es: I won't have to listen to that old witch.

en: They'll find you out.
vi: They will find out.
tr: They will understand what you are doing.
es: They will discover you.

en: Not to worry, I'm good at it.
vi: Don't worry, I'm really good at this.
tr: Don't worry, I can handle this well.
es: Don't worry, I'm really good at it.

en: When I was a kid in high school I cut out vitamin C, I got scurvy.
vi: Back in high school, I stopped taking vitamin C and got scurvy immediately.
tr: When I was in high school, I stopped taking vitamin C and got scurvy.
es: When I was in high school, I stopped taking vitamin C and got scurvy.

en: In the early stages they can't diagnose it.
vi: At first, they couldn't diagnose it right away.
tr: They can't diagnose it in the early stages.
es: At first, they couldn't diagnose it.

en: Then you just start it again and you're fine.
vi: Then I started taking it again and everything was fine.
tr: Then you start taking vitamin C again and you get better.
es: Then you start taking vitamins again, and you get better.

en: I'll hide my vitamin pills.
vi: I'll hide all the vitamin C pills.
tr: I'll hide my vitamin pills.
es: I will hide my vitamins.

en: Moira, don't.
vi: Moira, please.
tr: Moira, don't.
es: Moira, don't do it.

en: I couldn't stand the thought of her not being here, with me.
vi: I can't bear it if you're no longer here, with me.
tr: I couldn't bear the thought of him not staying here with me, for me.
es: I couldn't bear the thought of not having her with me, for myself.

en: For me.
vi: Because of me.
tr: I couldn't bear the thought of him not staying here with me, for me.
es: I couldn't bear the thought of not having her with me, for myself.

en: They send two guys with you, in the ambulance.
vi: There will be two guys going along, in that ambulance.
tr: They are sending two men with you, in the ambulance.
es: They send you with two guys in the ambulance.

en: Think about it.
vi: Think about it.
tr: Just think about it.
es: Think about it carefully.

en: They must be starved for it, shit, they aren't even allowed to put their hands in their pockets, the possibilities are
vi: They must have been dying of hunger for a long time, damn it, they're not even allowed to put their hands in their pockets, the opportunity is quite...
tr: They must be dying for it, damn it, they aren't even allowed to put their hands in their pockets, the possibilities -
es: Those guys are starving, shit, they aren't even allowed to put their hands in their pockets, there's a possibility of...

en: You in there.
vi: The women inside.
tr: You inside.
es: Hey, you, your time is up, said Aunt Elizabeth's voice from the other side of the door.

en: Time's up, said the voice of Aunt Elizabeth, from the doorway.
vi: Time's up. Aunt Elizabeth's voice, outside the door.
tr: Your time is up, said Aunt Elizabeth's voice from the door.
es: Hey, you, your time is up, said Aunt Elizabeth's voice from the other side of the door.

en: I stood up, flushed the toilet.
vi: I stand up, flush the toilet.
tr: I got up, flushed the toilet.
es: I got up and flushed the toilet.

en: Two of Moira's fingers appeared, through the hole in the wall.
vi: Moira's two fingers appear, through the wall hole.
tr: Moira's two fingers appeared in the hole in the wall.
es: Two of Moira's fingers appeared through the hole in the wall.

en: It was only large enough for two fingers.
vi: Just enough space for two fingers.
tr: It was a hole that could only fit two fingers.
es: It was just the right size for two fingers.

en: I touched my own fingers to them, quickly, held on, Let go.
vi: I touch them with my hand, quickly, grasping. Let go.
tr: I touched my fingers to hers, held them quickly. I let go.
es: I brought my fingers close to hers and grabbed them quickly. Then I let them go.

en: "And Leah said, God hath given me my hire, because I have given my maiden to my husband," says the Commander.
vi: “Mrs. Leah said, God has rewarded me because I gave my maidservant to my husband,” the Commander said.
tr: “And Leah said: God has given me my reward, because I gave my maid to my husband,” says the Commander.
es: —And Leah said: God has rewarded me because I have given my servant to my husband —says the Commander.

en: He lets the book fall closed.
vi: He let the folded book fall.
tr: He closes the book.
es: He lets the book fall, which produces a muffled noise, like a padded door closing by itself, at a certain distance: a gust of air.

en: It makes an exhausted sound, likea padded door shutting, by itself, at a distance: a puff of air.
vi: It exhaled a dull sound, like a door closing by itself somewhere far away: a burst of air escaping.
tr: A tired sound emerges, much like the muffled closing of a door from a certain distance: an air current.
es: He lets the book fall, which produces a muffled noise, like a padded door closing by itself, at a certain distance: a gust of air.

en: The sound suggests the softness of the thin oniony pages, how they would feel under the fingers.
vi: The sound was enough to imagine the softness of the pages, thin as silk, to imagine the feeling when touching them with a fingertip.
tr: The sound evokes the softness of the thin onion-skin-like pages, how they would feel between fingers.
es: The sound suggests the softness of the thin onion-skin pages, and the feel against the fingers.

en: Soft and dry, like papier poudre, pink and powdery, from the time before, you'd get it in booklets for taking the shine off your nose, in those stores that sold candles and soap in the shapes of things: seashells, mushrooms.
vi: Soft and dry, like blotting paper, pinkish and smooth, from ancient times, sold in thin stacks to dab sweat off the nose, in stores that also sold candles and soaps of various shapes: mushroom-shaped, shell-shaped.
tr: Soft and dry, like papier poudre, pink and powdery, from a previous time, used to eliminate shine on the nose, found in brochures, in those shops selling candles and soaps shaped in various forms: seashells, like mushrooms.
es: Soft and dry, like papier poudre, worn and dusty, old, the kind they gave you with propaganda pamphlets in the stores where they sold candles and soap of different shapes: seashells, mushrooms.

en: Like cigarette paper.
vi: Like cigarette paper.
tr: Like cigarette paper.
es: Like cigarette paper.

en: Like prints.
vi: Like flower petals.
tr: Like flower petals.
es: Like petals.

en: He has a lot of responsibilities.

en: It isn't the lirst time.

es: She tries not to make noise.

es: The upholstery and the rugs muffle the sound, but despite that, we can hear her clearly.

en: The tension between her lack of control and her attempt to suppress it is horrible.

tr: The tension from her losing control and trying to suppress it is terrible.
es: The tension that exists between her lack of control and her attempt to overcome it is horrible.

en: It's like a fart in church.

es: It's like farting in church.

es: As always, I feel an overwhelming need to burst out laughing, but not because I think it's funny.

en: The
vi: Her crying filled the room with a stench and we pretended not to notice.

en: smell of her crying spreads over us and we pretend to ignore it.
vi: Her crying filled the room with a stench and we pretended not to notice.

es: Let us ask for blessing and success in all our endeavors.

es: I hear behind me the held breath, the almost inaudible gasps, the shudders.

vi: I mouthed to the woman next to me; harmless, such a question, unless it hits a fanatic, that's all.
tr: I quietly asked the woman next to me; a question that could be asked to anyone except a fanatic.
es: I asked the woman next to me in a very low voice; a fairly prudent question for anyone, except for a fanatic.

en: A fever, she formed with her lips.
vi: High fever, those lips responded.

es: Fever, he said, barely moving his lips.

en: Appendicitis, they say.
vi: Appendicitis, that's what they said.

es: Appendicitis, they say.

vi: I was eating, that evening, minced meat with thinly sliced potatoes.

vi: The guard went inside; the vehicle remained there; the Angel stood with his back to us, as trained.
tr: The guard entered the building; the ambulance stayed parked where it was; the Angel's back was turned to us, as they were taught.

es: They took Moira out from inside, dragged her through the entrance and made her climb the steps, holding her by the armpits, one on each side.

en: She was having trouble walking.
vi: She walked with great difficulty.
tr: She was having difficulty walking.
es: She couldn't walk.

vi: I stopped eating, I couldn't eat; now everyone at my table was staring out the window.
tr: I stopped eating, I couldn't eat; meanwhile, everyone on my side of the table was looking out the window.
es: I left the food, I couldn't continue; at that moment, all of us who were sitting on that side of the table were looking out the window.

en: The window was greenish, with that chicken wire mesh they used to put inside glass.
vi: The window was made of dull green glass, with a wire mesh embedded inside.
tr: The window was greenish, because of the chicken wire they had put inside the glass.
es: The window was greenish, the same color as the chicken wire they used to put on the inside of the glass.

en: Aunt Lydia said, Eat your dinner.
vi: Aunt Lydia said, better eat up.
tr: Aunt Lydia said, Eat your dinner.

en: She went over and pulled down the blind.

vi: They brought her into the room that used to be the laboratory.
tr: They took Moira to a room that used to be the Science Laboratory.
es: They took her to a room that doubled as a Scientific Laboratory.

en: It was a room where none of us ever went willingly.
vi: It was also the room that none of us had ever voluntarily entered.
tr: A room none of us wanted to go to willingly.
es: None of us entered there voluntarily.

tr: Afterwards, she couldn't walk for a week, her feet wouldn't fit into her shoes, they were so swollen.
es: After that, she couldn't walk for a week; her feet were so swollen that they didn't fit in her shoes.

en: It was the feet they'd do, for a first offense.
vi: They will do the feet first, for the first offense.
tr: For the first offense, they would do things to your feet.
es: For the first infraction, they focused on your feet.

en: They used steel cables, frayed at the ends.
vi: Using a steel cable whip, with jagged ends.
tr: They used steel cables with frayed ends.
es: They used steel cables with frayed ends.

en: After that the hands.
vi: Then they move on to the hands.
tr: After that, to your hands.
es: Then it was the hands' turn.

en: They didn't care what they did to your feetor your hands, even if it was permanent.
vi: No matter what they do to our hands and feet, it doesn't matter, even if it's permanent injury.
tr: They didn't care what they did to your feet and hands, even if it was permanent.
es: They didn't care what they did to your feet and hands, even if it caused irreversible damage.

en: Remember, said Aunt Lydia.
vi: Remember this well, Aunt Lydia said.
tr: Remember, Aunt Lydia would say.

vi: For our purposes, your hands and feet are not necessary.
tr: Your feet and hands are not important for our purposes.
es: Your feet and hands are not essential for our purposes.

en: Moira lay on her bed, an example.
vi: Moira lay on the bed, setting an example for everyone.
tr: Moira was lying in her bed, an example.
es: Moira lying on the bed to serve as an example.

vi: She shouldn't have tried, especially with the Angels, Alma said from the next bed.
tr: She shouldn't have tried it, at least not with the Angels, said Alma from the next bed.
es: She shouldn't have tried it, especially not with the Angels, said Alma from the next bed.

en: We had to carry her to classes.
vi: We had to carry her to class.
tr: We had to carry her to the classes.
es: We had to take her to the classes.

en: We stole extra paper packets of sugar for her, from the cafeteria at mealtimes, smuggled them to her, at night, handing them from bed to bed.
vi: We stole small packets of sugar for her, every meal in the cafeteria, secretly passing them to her, every night, across the beds.
tr: We stole extra sugar packets from the cafeteria for her during meal times, and we delivered them to her secretly, passing them from bed to bed at night.
es: In the cafeteria, at mealtime, we would steal the extra sugar packets and pass them along at night, bed to bed.

en: Probably she didn't need the sugar but it was the only thing we could find to steal.
vi: Of course, she didn't need the sugar, but it was the only thing we could manage to steal.
tr: She didn't really need the sugar, but it was the only thing we could find to steal.
es: She probably didn't need sugar, but it was the only thing we could steal.

en: To give.
vi: To give away.
tr: To give her.
es: To give it as a gift.

en: I am still praying but what I am seeing is Moira's feet the way they looked after they'd brought her back, Her feet did not look like feet at all.
vi: I am still praying, but all I see before me are Moira's legs, after they brought her back. Her legs do not look like human legs.
tr: I'm still praying, but what I see are Moira's feet, the way they looked when they brought her back. Her feet didn't look like feet at all.
es: I keep praying, but what I see are Moira's feet just as they were when they brought her. They didn't look like feet.

en: They looked like drowned feet, swollen and bone-less, except for the color.
vi: They look like the legs of a drowned corpse, swollen, limp, except for the color.
tr: They looked like drowned feet, swollen and boneless, only their color was different.
es: They were like a pair of drowned feet, swollen and boneless, though by the color anyone would have sworn they were lungs.

en: They looked like lungs.
vi: The color is like that of lungs.
tr: They looked like lungs.
es: They were like a pair of drowned feet, swollen and boneless, though by the color anyone would have sworn they were lungs.

en: Oh God, I pray.
vi: Oh Lord, I pray.
tr: Oh God, I pray.
es: Oh, God, I pray.

en: Nolite te bastardes carborundorum.
vi: Don't let the bastards grind you down.
tr: Don't let the bastards grind you down.
es: Don't let the bastards grind you down.

en: Is this what you had in mind?
vi: Is this truly your intention?
tr: Is this what you were thinking?
es: Was this what you were thinking?

en: The Commander clears his throat.
vi: The commander cleared his throat.
tr: The commander clears his throat.
es: The Commander clears his throat.

en: This is what he does to let us know dial in his opinion it's time we stopped praying.
vi: It meant that according to him, we could start praying.
tr: This is something he does to show us that the time has come to stop praying, according to him.
es: It is what he always does to let us know that, in his opinion, it is time to stop praying.

en: "For the eyes of the Lord run to and fro throughout the wholeearth, to know himself strong in the behalf of them whose heart is perfect towards him," he says.
vi: "For the eyes of the Lord range throughout the earth to strengthen those whose hearts are fully committed to Him," he said.
tr: “For the eyes of the Lord roam throughout the earth to strengthen those whose hearts are fully committed to him,” he says.
es: —May the eyes of the Lord roam the earth far and wide, and may His strength protect all those who give Him their hearts —he concludes.

en: It's the sign-off.
vi: Signal to stop.
tr: This is the sign of the end.
es: It is the farewell phrase.

en: He stands up.
vi: He stood up.
tr: The commander stands up.
es: He gets up.

en: We are dismissed.
vi: We dispersed.
tr: We have been dismissed.
es: We can leave.
CHAPTER 16

en: The Ceremony goes as usual.
vi: The ceremony of the month took place as usual.
tr: The ritual is taking place as usual.
es: The Ceremony proceeds as usual.

en: I lie on my back, fully clothed except for the healthy white cotton underdrawers.
vi: I lie on my back, fully clothed except for the long white cotton sanitary underwear.
tr: Except for my healthy white cotton underwear, I am lying on my back fully clothed.
es: I lie on my back, fully dressed except for the healthy white cotton underwear.

en: What I could see, if I were to open my eyes, would be the large white canopy of Serena Joy's outsized colonial-style
vi: In front of me, if I were to open my eyes, is the wide white curtain stretched over the oversized colonial-style four-poster bed of Serena Joy, hovering like a waterlogged cloud above, a cloud embroidered with tiny silver raindrops, which upon closer inspection reveal themselves to be four-petaled flowers.
tr: If I could open my eyes, what I would see would be the wide white canopy of Serena Joy's huge colonial-style four-poster bed, hanging above us like a cloud adorned with small silver raindrops, which, if you look closely, turn into four-petaled flowers.
es: If I opened my eyes, I would see the enormous white canopy of Serena Joy's bed —colonial style with four posts— suspended above our heads like a curved cloud, a cloud sprinkled with tiny drops of silver rain that, if you look closely, could become four-petaled flowers.

en: four-poster bed, suspended like a sagging cloud above us, a cloud sprigged with tiny drops of silver rain, which, if you looked at them closely, would turn out to be four-petaled flowers.
vi: In front of me, if I were to open my eyes, is the wide white curtain stretched over the oversized colonial-style four-poster bed of Serena Joy, hovering like a waterlogged cloud above, a cloud embroidered with tiny silver raindrops, which upon closer inspection reveal themselves to be four-petaled flowers.
tr: If I could open my eyes, what I would see would be the wide white canopy of Serena Joy's huge colonial-style four-poster bed, hanging above us like a cloud adorned with small silver raindrops, which, if you look closely, turn into four-petaled flowers.
es: If I opened my eyes, I would see the enormous white canopy of Serena Joy's bed —colonial style with four posts— suspended above our heads like a curved cloud, a cloud sprinkled with tiny drops of silver rain that, if you look closely, could become four-petaled flowers.

en: I would not see the carpet, which is white, or the sprigged curtains and skirted dressing table with its silver-backed brush and mirror set; only the canopy, which manages to suggest at one and the same time, by the gauziness of its fabric and its heavy downward curve, both ethereality and matter.
vi: I would not be able to change the carpet, which is white, nor the curtains also embroidered with branches, nor the dressing table draped with cloth and a set of silver-framed mirror and comb; I can only see the curtain, thanks to the thin transparent silk combined with its sagging curve, skillfully evoking both materiality and etherealness at the same time.
tr: I wouldn't see the white carpet or the curtains decorated with thin branches, the covered dressing table with the silver-backed brush and mirror set; all I could see would be the canopy, which, with the fineness of its weave and the heavy drape it makes downward, manages to remind one of both spirituality and materiality at the same time.
es: I would not see the white carpet, nor the adorned curtains, nor the dresser with its set of mirror and silver-backed brush; only the canopy, which with its diaphanous fabric and pronounced downward curve suggests an ethereal yet material quality.

en: Or the sail of a ship.
vi: Or the sail of a ship.
tr: Or the sail of a ship.
es: Or the sail of a ship.

en: Big-bellied sails, they used to say, in poems.
vi: The sail full of wind, as was once said, a poetic way.
tr: In poems, they used to say sails with swollen bellies.
es: The swollen sails, they used to say, like a swollen belly.

en: Bellying.
vi: The belly full and taut.
tr: To belly.
es: As if pushed by a belly.

en: Propelled forward by a swollen belly.
vi: Speeding forward thanks to the round, taut belly.
tr: To be propelled forward by a swollen belly.
es: As if pushed by a belly.

en: A mist of Lily of the Valley surrounds us, chilly, crisp almost.
vi: The mist of Lily flowers in the valley lingered around, cold and icy as well.
tr: Serin, almost sharp Lily of the Valley mist surrounds us.
es: We are engulfed by a mist of Lily of the Valley, cold, almost icy.

en: It's not warm in this room.
vi: This room is not warm.
tr: The room is not very warm.
es: This room is not warm at all.

en: Above me, towards the head of the bed, Serena Joy is arranged, outspread.
vi: Above, near the head of the bed, Serena Joy had taken her position, spread wide.
tr: Above me, towards the head of the bed, Serena Joy has taken her place, sprawled out.
es: Behind me, next to the headboard of the bed, is Serena Joy, stretched out and ready.

en: Her legs are apart, I lie between them, my head on her stomach, her pubic bone under the base of my skull, her thigh on either side of me.
vi: Her legs were spread to either side, I lay in between, my head resting on her belly, her pubic bone supporting the base of my skull, her thighs gripping either side of my body.
tr: Her legs are open, I am lying between them, my head on her stomach, her pubic bone under my head, and her hips on either side of me.
es: Her legs are spread, and between them, I find myself, with my head resting on her belly, the base of my skull on her pubis, and her thighs flanking my body.

en: She too is fully clothed,
vi: She was also fully clothed.
tr: She is also fully dressed.
es: She is also fully dressed.

en: My arms are raised; she holds my hands, each of mine in each of hers.
vi: My two hands are raised; she takes my hands, one hand each.
tr: My arms are raised; my hands are in hers, she is holding my hands.
es: I have my arms raised; she holds both of my hands with hers.

en: This is supposed to signify that we are one flesh, one being.
vi: This is considered to imply that we are of one flesh, one entity.
tr: This signifies that we are a single body, a single entity.
es: It is supposed to mean that we are one flesh and one being.

en: What it really means is that she is in control, of the process and thus of the product.
vi: The real meaning, however, is that she holds control, throughout the entire process, and thus the product of that process as well.
tr: The real meaning is this: Serena is the one in control; she holds the control of the process and thus the product.
es: But the true meaning is that she controls the process and its product, if there is any.

en: If any.
vi: If there is any.
tr: If a product is to be produced, of course.
es: But the true meaning is that she controls the process and its product, if there is any.

en: The rings of her left hand cut into my fingers.
vi: The rings on her left hand cut into my fingers.
tr: The rings on her left hand are digging into my fingers.
es: The rings on her left hand dig into my fingers, which could be revenge, or not.

en: It may or may not be revenge.
vi: It could be revenge, or it might not be.
tr: This may or may not be an act of revenge.
es: The rings on her left hand dig into my fingers, which could be revenge, or not.

en: My red skirt is hitched up to my waist, though no higher.
vi: The red dress was hitched up to my waist, though that was the end of it.
tr: My red skirt is lifted up to my waist, but no higher.
es: I have the red skirt lifted, but only up to the waist.

en: Below it the Commander is fucking.
vi: Beneath it, the Commander was fucking.
tr: Below, the Commander is fucking.
es: Underneath it, the Commander is fucking.

en: What he is fucking is the lower part of my body.
vi: The target was my lower body.
tr: He's fucking the lower part of my body.
es: What he is fucking is the lower part of my body.

en: I do not say making love, because this is not what he's doing.
vi: I don't call it making love, because he wasn't making love.
tr: I'm not saying he's making love, because that's not what he's doing.
es: I don't say making love, because that's not what he's doing.

vi: Copulation isn't accurate either, because that implies both parties are participating, and here it's just one.
tr: It wouldn't be right to say he's mating either, because that would imply the presence of two people, but there's only one person involved in this.
es: Copulating wouldn't be an appropriate expression either, because it implies the participation of two people, and here only one is involved.

en: Nor does rape cover it: nothing is going on here that I haven't signed up for.
vi: Rape isn't appropriate either: everything happening here has my consent.
tr: Nor does it fit the definition of rape: There's nothing happening here that I don't want.
es: But it's not rape either: nothing happens that I haven't accepted.

en: There wasn't a lot of choice but there was some, and this is what I chose.
vi: There weren't many choices, but there were some, and I chose this one.
tr: The options weren't many, but there were a few, and this is the one I chose.
es: There weren't many possibilities, but there were some, and this is the one I chose.

en: Therefore I lie still and picture the unseen canopy over my head.
vi: So I lay still and sketched in my mind the invisible curtain.
tr: Therefore, I lie still and visualize the invisible dome above my head.
es: Therefore, I stay still and imagine the canopy above my head.

en: I remember Queen Victoria's advice to her daughter: Close your eyes and think of England.
vi: I remembered Queen Victoria's advice to her daughter: Just close your eyes and think of England.
tr: I remember the advice Queen Victoria gave to her daughter. Close your eyes and think of England.
es: I remember the advice that Queen Victoria gave to her daughter: Close your eyes and think of England.

en: But this is not England.
vi: But this is not England.
tr: But it's not about England.
es: But this is not England.

en: I wish he would hurry
vi: I wished he would hurry up and get it over with.
tr: I wish they would hurry up a bit.
es: I wish he would hurry.

en: up.
vi: I wished he would hurry up and get it over with.
tr: I wish they would hurry up a bit.
es: I wish he would hurry.

en: Maybe I'm crazy and this is some new kind of therapy.
vi: It is also possible that I am going crazy and this is a new form of therapy.
tr: Maybe I am crazy and this is a new type of therapy.
es: Maybe I'm crazy, and this is a new form of therapy.

en: I wish it were true; then I could get better and this would go away.

es: I do something on my own.

en: The active, is it a tense?
vi: I am doing something, by myself, proactively; is that a grammatical tense?
tr: Active; or was it a time?
es: In the present tense.

en: Tensed.
vi: Excited.
tr: Stretched time.
es: I am present.

en: What I would like to steal is a knife, from the kitchen, but I'm not ready for that.
vi: What I want to steal is the knife, in the kitchen, but today I'm not ready yet.
tr: The thing I want to steal is a knife from the kitchen, but I'm not ready for it.
es: What I would like to steal is a knife from the kitchen, but I am not prepared for that.

en: I reach the sitting room, door's ajar, slip in, leave the door a little open.
vi: I went to the lounge, the door was ajar, slipped in, and opened the door a bit wider.
tr: I reach the living room, the door is ajar, I slip inside and leave the door slightly open.
es: I arrive at the living room; the door is ajar, I enter and leave it slightly open again.

en: A squeak of wood, but who's near enough to hear?
vi: The floorboard creaked, but who nearby would hear?
tr: The wood creaks, but who is close enough to hear that?
es: The wood creaks, and I wonder if anyone heard it.

en: I stand in the room, letting the pupils of my eyes dilute, like a cat's or owl's.
vi: I stood in the middle of the room, waiting for my pupils to dilate, like a cat or an owl.
tr: I stand in the room, letting my pupils dilate, like the eyes of a cat or an owl.
es: I stop and wait for my pupils to dilate, like those of a cat or an owl.

en: Old perfume, cloth dust fill my nostrils.
vi: The smell of old perfume and fabric dust filled the air.
tr: The smell of stale perfume and fabric dust fills my nostrils.
es: I smell old perfume and rags.

en: There'sa slight mist of light, coming through the cracks around the closed drapes, from the searchlight outside, where two men doubtless patrol, I've seen them, fromabove, from behind my curtains, dark shapes, cutouts.
vi: A thin beam of light slipped in through the gap between the drawn curtains, the headlights from outside, I was sure there were two people patrolling out there, I had seen them, from above, from behind my room's curtains, black shapes, like shadow puppets.
tr: There is a faint hazy light, seeping through the gaps in the closed curtains, from the spotlight outside; undoubtedly two men are patrolling, there, I saw them, from above, behind my curtains, dark shadows, silhouettes.
es: Through the gaps in the curtains, the faint glow of the spotlights outside comes in, where surely two men are making their rounds; from above, from behind the curtains, I have seen their silhouetted, dark figures.

en: Now I can see outlines, gleams: from the mirror, the bases of the lumps, the vases, the sofa looming like a cloud at dusk.
vi: Now I could see faint outlines, light shadows: the mirror, the candlestick, some vases, the sofa looming like a cloud at dusk.
tr: Now I can see the outlines of some things, their glimmers, from the mirror; the lamp stands, the vases, the faintly discernible couch like a cloud in the twilight.
es: Now I manage to see the contours of the objects as faint glimmers: the mirror, the feet of the lamps, the vases, the sofa that outlines itself like a cloud in the twilight.

en: What should I take?
vi: What should be taken?
tr: What should I take?
es: What could I take?

en: Something that will not be missed.
vi: An object that no one will know is missing.
tr: Something whose absence won't be noticed.
es: Something that no one would miss.

en: In the wood at midnight, a magic flower.
vi: In the forest at midnight, a magical flower.
tr: A magical flower from the forest at night.
es: A magical flower from a forest shrouded in darkness.

en: A withered daffodil, not one from the dried arrangement.
vi: A wilted daffodil, not from a dry flower arrangement.
tr: Not a withered daffodil from a dried arrangement, though.
es: A withered daffodil, not from the bouquet of dried flowers.

en: The daffodils will soonbe thrown out, they're
vi: The daffodil is about to be thrown away, they already have a smell.
tr: The daffodils will be thrown away soon; they've already started to smell.
es: They will have to throw away these daffodils very soon, because they are starting to smell, just like Serena's smoke and the stench of her fabric.

en: beginning to smell.
vi: Adding to the scent of Serena's lavender perfume, the smell of knitted items.
tr: Along with Serena's stale scents, I can also smell the bad odor of her braid.
es: They will have to throw away these daffodils very soon, because they are starting to smell, just like Serena's smoke and the stench of her fabric.

en: Along with Serena's stale fumes, the stench of her knitting.
vi: Adding to the scent of Serena's lavender perfume, the smell of knitted items.
tr: Along with Serena's stale scents, I can also smell the bad odor of her braid.
es: They will have to throw away these daffodils very soon, because they are starting to smell, just like Serena's smoke and the stench of her fabric.

en: I grope, find an end table, feel.
vi: I groped around, found the small table, and felt it.
tr: I reach out my hand, find a table, and proceed by feeling my way.
es: I advance by feeling my way, I find the edge of a table and touch it.

en: There's a clink, I must have knocked something.
vi: There was a clattering sound, probably something had fallen over.
tr: A clatter, I must have bumped into something.
es: A jingling sound is heard, I must have knocked something over.

en: I find the daffodils, crisp at the edges where they've dried, limp towards the stems, use my fingers to pinch.
vi: I found the daffodil vase, the edges of the petals were dry and brittle, near the stem they were limp, I pinched them with my fingers.
tr: I find the daffodils, they are withered at the tips, weak towards the stems, I use my fingers to hold them.
es: I find the daffodils, which have dry and crunchy edges and soft stems, and I cut one with my fingers.

en: I will press this, somewhere.
vi: I will press this flower, somewhere.
tr: I will dry this, somewhere.
es: I will let it dry somewhere.

en: Under the mattress.
vi: Under the mattress.
tr: Under the mattress.
es: Under the mattress.

en: Leave it there, for the next woman, the one who comes after me, to find.
vi: Leave it there, for the next woman, who will come after me, to find.
tr: I will leave it there for the next woman, the one who will come after me, to find.
es: I will leave it there for the woman who comes after to find it.

en: But there's someone in the room, behind me.
vi: But there is someone in the room, behind me.
tr: There is someone in the room, behind me.
es: There is someone else in the room.

en: I hear the step, quiet as mine, the creaking of the same floorboard.
vi: I hear footsteps, as light as mine, the creaking sound exactly where the floorboard was earlier.
tr: I hear footsteps, mine are silent, the same creak of the floor tile.
es: I hear the footsteps, as stealthy as mine, and the creaking of the wood.

en: The door closes behind me, with a little click, cutting the light.
vi: The door closes behind me with a click, blocking the light.
tr: The door closes behind me with a small click, cutting off the light.
es: The door closes behind me with a slight click, blocking the light.

en: I freeze: white was a mistake.
vi: I stiffen: wearing white was a real mistake.
tr: I freeze; it was a white mistake.
es: I am petrified.

en: I'm snow in moonlight, even in the dark.
vi: I am snow under the moonlight, even in the dark night.
tr: Even in the dark, I am my wife in the moonlight.
es: It was a mistake to come here dressed in white: I am like the snow in the moonlight, even in the darkness.

en: Then a whisper: "Don't scream.
vi: Then a whisper: "Don't scream."
tr: Then a whisper: "Don't shout.
es: At last I hear a whisper: —Don't shout.

en: It's all right."
vi: "It's okay."
tr: Everything is fine."
es: Everything is fine.

en: As if I'd scream, as if it's all right.
vi: As if I were about to scream, as if it were really okay.
tr: There was no need to shout, everything is fine, you say.
es: As if I were going to scream; as if everything were fine.

en: I turn: a shape, that's all, dull glint of cheekbone, devoid of color.
vi: I turned around: a silhouette, just that, cheekbones slightly glowing, colorless.
tr: I turn: a shadow, that's all, a dull glimmer of the cheekbone, devoid of color.
es: I turn around: all I see is a silhouette and the dim reflection of a pale cheek.

en: He steps towards me.
vi: The person walked towards me.
tr: He is stepping towards me.
es: Take a step towards me.

en: Nick.
vi: Nick.
tr: Nick.
es: It's Nick.

en: "What are you doing in here?"
vi: What are you doing here?
tr: “What are you doing here?””
es: —What are you doing here?

en: I don't answer.
vi: I did not answer.
tr: I am not responding.
es: I don't respond.

en: He too is illegal, here, with me, he can't give me away.
vi: He was also illegal, here, with me, he couldn't accuse me.
tr: It is also illegal for him to be here, he cannot betray me.
es: He can't be here either, with me, so he won't turn me in.

en: Nor I him; for the moment we're mirrors.
vi: I couldn't accuse him either; at this moment, we were friends.
tr: Nor can I betray him; for now, we are mirrors of each other.
es: Nor will I turn him in; for now, we're even.

en: He puts his hand on my arm, pulls me against him, his mouth on mine, what else comes from such denial?
vi: He placed his hand on mine, pulled me close, his mouth on mine, what else could this restraint bring?
tr: He puts his hand on my arm, pulls me towards him, his mouth on mine, what else could follow after so much lawlessness?
es: He puts his hand on my arm and pulls me towards him, his mouth against mine, what else could happen?

en: Without a word.
vi: Not a word.
tr: Without saying a single word, we both tremble, how much I would have wanted it.
es: Without uttering a single word.

en: Both of us shaking, how
vi: Both of us trembling, how much I wanted it.
tr: Without saying a single word, we both tremble, how much I would have wanted it.
es: Both of us shaking in Serena's room, with the dried flowers, on the Chinese rug, his thin body touching mine.

en: I'd like to.
vi: Both of us trembling, how much I wanted it.
tr: Without saying a single word, we both tremble, how much I would have wanted it.
es: Both of us shaking in Serena's room, with the dried flowers, on the Chinese rug, his thin body touching mine.

en: In Serena's parlor, with the dried flowers, on the Chinese carpet, his thin body.
vi: In Serena's parlor, among the dried flowers, on the Chinese rug, his slender body.
tr: In Serena's living room, with dried flowers, on the Chinese carpet, with his slender body.
es: Both of us shaking in Serena's room, with the dried flowers, on the Chinese rug, his thin body touching mine.

en: A man entirely unknown.
vi: A complete stranger.
tr: A completely foreign man.
es: A completely unknown man.

en: It would be like shouting, it would be like shooting someone.
vi: It would be like screaming out loud, like pointing a gun at someone.
tr: It would be like screaming, it would be like hitting someone.
es: It would be the same as shouting, like shooting someone.

en: My hand goes down, how about that, I could unbutton, and then.
vi: My hand slipped down, what if I did, I could unbutton, and then.
tr: My hand slides down, what to say about this, I could have unbuttoned and then.
es: I slide my hand down, I could unbutton him, and then...

en: But it's too dangerous, he knows it, we push each other away, not far.
vi: But it was too dangerous, he knew, we pushed each other away, not too far.
tr: But this is too dangerous, he knows it, we push each other away, but not too far.
es: But it's too dangerous, he knows it, and we separate a little.

en: Too much trust, too much risk, too much already.
vi: Too much trust, too much recklessness, this was already too much.
tr: Excessive confidence, excessive danger, we have already gone too far.
es: Too much trust, too much risk, too much haste.

en: "I was coming to find you," he says, breathes, almost into my ear.
vi: “I came here to find you,” he said, whispering, almost right next to my ear.
tr: “I was looking for you,” he says, almost breathing inside my ear.
es: —I came to find you —he tells me, almost whispering in my ear.

en: I want to reach up, taste his skin, he makes me hungry.
vi: I wanted to rise up, taste his skin, he made me hungry.
tr: I want to reach up, taste his skin, it makes me hungry.
es: I would like to stretch out and feel his skin; he awakens my desires.

en: His fingers move, feeling my arm under the nightgown sleeve, as if his hand won't listen to reason.
vi: Those fingers moved, exploring my hand under the sleeve of my nightgown, as if they didn't want to obey reason.
tr: His fingers move, feeling my arm under the nightgown, as if his hand defies reason.
es: His fingers run along my arm under the sleeve of my nightgown, as if his hand didn't heed reason.

en: It's so good, to be touched by someone, to be felt so greedily, to feel so greedy.
vi: How wonderful it is, to be touched by someone else, to be eagerly sought after, to be eagerly sought after.
tr: To be touched by someone, to feel so insatiably, to feel so insatiable, it feels so good.
es: It's so pleasant to be touched by someone, to feel desired, to desire.

en: Luke, you'd know, you'd understand.
vi: Luke, you know, you understand.
tr: Luke, you would know, you would understand.
es: You would understand, Luke, it's you who is here, in someone else's body.

en: It's you here, in another body.
vi: It's you, in another form.
tr: You are the one here, in another body.
es: You would understand, Luke, it's you who is here, in someone else's body.

en: Bullshit.
vi: Damn it.
tr: Nonsense.
es: Shit.

en: "Why?" I say.
vi: “What are you doing?” I said.
tr: “Why?” I say, is his condition so bad that he would risk coming to my room at night?
es: —Why? —I ask.

en: Is it so bad, for him, that he'd take the risk of coming to my room at night?
vi: Could it be that he couldn't stand it, to the point of risking his life to come to my room at night?
tr: “Why?” I say, is his condition so bad that he would risk coming to my room at night?
es: Is it so terrible for him that he risks coming to my room during the night?

en: I think of the hanged men, hooked on the Wall.
vi: I remembered those who were hung on the hooks on the Wall.
tr: I think of the hanged men, the men hooked to the Wall.
es: I think of the hanged men, the ones hanging on the Wall.

en: I can hardly stand up.
vi: I wanted to collapse.
tr: I can barely stand.
es: I can barely stand it.

en: I have to get away, back to the stairs, before I dissolve entirely.
vi: I had to go, back to the stairs, before I completely vanished.
tr: I need to get away, I need to turn to the stairs, before I completely unravel.
es: I have to leave, run up the stairs before I completely disintegrate.

en: His hand's on my shoulder now, held still, heavy, pressing down on me like warm lead.
vi: His hand placed on my shoulder, steady, heavy, pressing down like hot lead.
tr: His hand is now on my shoulder, motionless, heavy, pressing down like hot lead.
es: Now he puts his hand on my shoulder, a hand that presses down on me, heavy as lead.

en: Is this what I would die for?
vi: Is this worth dying for?
tr: Is this something I would risk my life for?
es: Would I die for this?

en: I'm a coward, I hate the thought of pain.
vi: I'm a coward, I hate being in pain.
tr: I am a coward, I hate the thought of pain.
es: I am a coward, I can't bear the idea of pain.

en: "He told me to," Nick says.
vi: “He sent me,” Nick said.
tr: “He sent me,” says Nick.
es: —He told me —Nick explains to me—.

en: "He wants to see you.
vi: “He wants to see you.
tr: “He wants to see you.
es: He wants to see you, in his office.

en: In his office."
vi: In the office.”
tr: In his office.”
es: He wants to see you, in his office.

en: "What do you mean?" I say.
vi: "What did you say?" I said.
tr: “What do you mean?” I say.
es: —What do you mean? —I say to him.

en: The Commander, it must be.
vi: The commander, of course.
tr: This must be the commander.
es: He must be referring to the Commander.

en: See me?
vi: Meet me?
tr: Is he going to see me?
es: See me?

en: What does he mean by see?
vi: What do you mean by meeting someone?
tr: What does he mean by seeing?
es: What does he mean see me?

en: Hasn't he had enough of me?
vi: Isn't he already done with me?
tr: Is he not satisfied with me?
es: Hasn't he had enough?

en: "Tomorrow," he says, just audible.
vi: “Tomorrow,” he said, just loud enough to hear.
tr: “Tomorrow,” he says in a barely audible voice.
es: —Tomorrow —adds Nick in an almost inaudible tone.

en: In the dark parlor we move away from each other, slowly, as if pulled towards each other by a force, current, pulled apart also by hands equally strong.
vi: In the darkness of the lobby, we parted ways, very slowly, as if drawn together by a force, a current, only to be pushed apart by equally strong arms.
tr: In the dark hall, we drift apart, a draft, equally strong hands separating us.
es: In the darkness of the room, we moved apart, slowly, as if a hidden current united us and at the same time separated us with equal force.

en: I find the door, turn the knob, fingers on cool porcelain, open.
vi: I found the door, turned the knob, my fingers touched the cold porcelain and opened it.
tr: I find the door, I turn the handle, fingers on the cool porcelain; I open it.
es: I find the door; I turn the knob feeling the cold porcelain on my fingers, and I open it.

en: It's all
vi: That's all I could do.
tr: This is all I can do.
es: It is all I can do.

en: I can do.
vi: That's all I could do.
tr: This is all I can do.
es: It is all I can do.

en: VII Night
vi: VII - Night
tr: VII
es: VII

vi: VII - Night
tr: Night
es: THE NIGHT
CHAPTER 18

en: I lie in bed, still trembling.
vi: I lay on the bed, still trembling.
tr: I'm lying in bed, still trembling.
es: Still trembling, I lie down on the bed.

en: You can wet the rim of a glass and run your finger around the rim and it will make a sound.
vi: One can wet the rim of a glass and then rub a finger around it, producing a sound.
tr: When you wet the rim of a glass and run your finger along it, a sound will emerge.
es: If you moisten the rim of a glass and run a finger around it, a sound is produced.

en: This is what I feel like: this sound of glass.
vi: I am feeling exactly like that: the sound of glass ringing.
tr: That's exactly how I feel: like that glass sound.
es: That's how I feel: like that sound.

en: I feel like the word shatter.
vi: It feels like shattering.
tr: I feel like the word "broken".
es: I feel shattered.

en: I want to be with someone.
vi: I want to be with someone.
tr: I want to be with someone.
es: I want to be with someone.

en: Lying in bed, with Luke, his hand on my rounded belly.
vi: Lying on the bed, with Luke, his hand placed on my round, bulging belly.
tr: I'm lying in bed, with Luke; his hand is on my swollen belly.
es: Lying in bed with Luke, his hand on my rounded belly.

en: The three of us, in bed, she kicking, turning over within me.
vi: The three of us, on the bed, the baby keeps kicking and turning inside me.
tr: The three of us, in bed, the girl is kicking, turning inside me.
es: The three of us are in bed, she kicking and moving inside me.

en: Thunderstorm outside the window, that's why she's awake, they can hear, they sleep, they can be startled, even there in the soothing of Ilie heart, like waves on the shore around them.
vi: It's stormy, that's why the baby is awake, they can hear it, they sleep, they can get startled, even in there, next to the heart that soothes, like waves pushing against the shore around them.
tr: There is thunder outside the window, that's why she's awake, babies can hear, sleep, even get startled, even in the racing of the heart, like the waves surrounding them on the beach.
es: A storm has broken out outside, that's why she is awake, they can hear, they sleep, they can get scared even in the calm of that interior, like waves licking the shore that surrounds them.

en: A flash of lightning, quite close, Luke's eyes go white for an instant.
vi: Lightning flashes, quite close, Luke's eyes momentarily white and bright.
tr: Lightning strikes, very close, Luke's eyes turn white for a moment.
es: A fairly close lightning bolt makes Luke's eyes turn white for an instant.

en: I'm not frightened.
vi: I'm not afraid.
tr: I'm not afraid.
es: I am not scared.

en: We're wide awake, the rain hits now, we will be slow and careful.
vi: We are all awake, the rain is pouring down, we will proceed slowly and cautiously.
tr: We are fully awake, it's pouring rain now, we will be slow and careful.
es: We are completely awake, now the rain is hitting, we will do it slowly and carefully.

en: If I thought this would never happen again I would die.
vi: If I thought this wouldn't happen again, I would probably be dead.
tr: If I think I will never experience these again, I will die.
es: If I thought this would never happen again, I would die.

en: But this is wrong, nobody dies from lack of sex, It's lack of love we die from.
vi: But that's boring, no one dies from lack of sex. We die from lack of love.
tr: But this is not true; no one dies from the lack of sex. We die from the lack of love.
es: But it is false, no one dies from lack of sex. It is from lack of love that we die.

en: There's nobody here I can love, all the people I could love are dead or elsewhere.
vi: There is no one here for me to love, everyone I could love is either dead or scattered elsewhere.
tr: There is no one here that I can love; all the people I could love are either dead or somewhere else.
es: There is no one here whom I can love, all the people I love are dead, or elsewhere.

en: Who knows where they are or what their names are now?
vi: Who knows where they are now, what names they go by?
tr: Who can know where they are or what their names are now?
es: Who knows where they are or what their names might be now?

en: They might as well be nowhere, as I am for them.
vi: It doesn't matter if they are nowhere, just as I am to them now.
tr: They might not be anywhere, just as I am not anywhere for them.
es: They could also be nowhere, as I must be according to them.

en: I too am a missing person.
vi: I am also a missing person.
tr: I am a lost person too.
es: I am also a missing person.

en: From time to time I can see their faces, against the dark, flickering like the images of saints, in old foreign cathedrals, Inthe light of the drafty candles; candles you would light to pray by, kneeling, your forehead against the wooden railing, hoping for an answer.
vi: Every now and then I see their faces, emerging in the darkness, flickering like images of saints in old foreign churches, through the light of wind-blown candles; people light them to pray, kneeling, their foreheads pressed against the backs of wooden pews, hoping for an answer.
tr: From time to time, I can see their faces, against the darkness, flickering like the images of saints, in the light of candles under a draft in old foreign cathedrals; candles you would light to pray beside, kneeling, your forehead resting on the wooden railing, hoping for an answer.
es: From time to time I glimpse their faces in the darkness, flickering like images of saints in ancient foreign cathedrals, by the light of wavering candles; candles lit to pray on one's knees, with the forehead against the wooden railing, waiting for an answer.

en: I can conjure them but they are mirages only, they don't last.
vi: I can summon them, but they are only illusions, they do not stay.
tr: I can call them, but they are just mirages, not permanent.
es: I can conjure them, but they are only mirages, they do not last.

en: Can I be blamed for wanting a real body, to put my arms around?
vi: Am I despicable for craving a real body, one I can hold in my arms?
tr: Can I be blamed for wanting a real body to embrace me?
es: Can I be censured for desiring a real body to wrap my arms around?

en: Without it I too am disembodied.
vi: Burning it all would be like shedding my own body.
tr: Without it, I am also bodiless.
es: Without it, I too am incorporeal.

en: I can listen to my own heartbeat against the bedsprings, I can stroke myself, under the dry white sheets, in the dark, but I too am dry and white, hard, granular; it's like running my hand over a plateful of dried rice; it's like snow.
vi: I keep listening to my heartbeat against the mattress springs, keep caressing myself, under the dry white blanket, in the darkness, but I too am dry and white, hard, rough; it's no different than running my hand over a plate of dry rice; no different than snow.
tr: I can listen to the beating of my own heart echoing in the bed springs, I can caress myself, under the dry white sheets, in the dark, but I am also dry and white, hard and grainy; it is like running my hand over a plateful of dried rice; like snow.
es: I can hear my own heartbeat against the mattress springs, caress myself under the dry white sheets, in the darkness, but I too am dry, white, stony, grainy; it is as if I were sliding my hand over a plate of rice; like snow.

en: There's something dead about it, something deserted.
vi: All I taste is the flavor of death, the flavor of abandonment.
tr: There is something dead in this, something abandoned.
es: In this, there is a certain dose of death, of abandonment.

en: I am like a room where things once happened and now nothing does, except the pollen of the weeds that grow up outside the window, blowing in as dust across the floor.
vi: I am a room that has witnessed much and now has nothing left, except for the pollen of wild grasses growing by the window, blown in by the wind like dust on the floor.
tr: I am like a room where something once was and now is completely empty, except for the dust of weed pollen accumulating and flying around on the floor from outside the window.
es: I am like a room where things once happened but where nothing happens anymore, except for the pollen from the grasses growing on the other side of the window, which spreads across the floor like dust.

en: Here is what I believe.
vi: This is what I believe.
tr: Here are the things I believe in.
es: This is what I believe.

en: I believe Luke is lying face down in a thicket, a tangle of bracken, the brown fronds from last year under the green ones just unrolled, or ground hemlock perhaps, although it's too early for the red berries.
vi: I believe Luke is lying face down in a bush, a tangled fern grove, last year's dried compound leaves mingling with the newly smoothed-out young leaves, or perhaps even a hemlock grove, though it's not yet the season for red berries.
tr: I believe Luke is lying face down in some bushes, in a fern thicket, under last year's withered leaves that have just sprouted greens, or maybe it's a fir tree, though it's too early for its fruits.
es: I believe that Luke is lying face down in a thicket, a tangle of ferns, last year's branches beneath the barely developed green ones, perhaps of hemlock, although it's too early for the berries.

en: What is left of him: his hair, the bones, the plaid wool shirt, green and black, the leather belt, the work boots.
vi: What remains of him: hair, bones, a green and black plaid sweater, leather belt, boots.
tr: What remains of him: his hair, bones, a plaid wool shirt, green and black, a leather belt, work boots.
es: What's left of him: his hair, his bones, the green and black plaid wool shirt, the leather belt, the boots.

en: I know exactly what he was wearing.
vi: I know exactly what he is wearing.
tr: I know exactly what he was wearing.
es: I know exactly what he was wearing.

en: I can see his clothes in my mind, bright as a lithograph or a full-color advertisement, from an ancient magazine, though not his face, not so well.
vi: I can still see his clothes in my mind, as clear as a lithograph or a color advertisement from an old magazine, even though I can't see his face, not clearly.
tr: I can see his clothes in my mind, as clear as a lithograph illustration from a very old magazine or a full-color advertisement, but I can't see his face, not as well.
es: I see his clothes mentally, bright as a lithograph or a full-color advertisement from an old magazine, but I don't picture his face, not as clearly.

en: His face is beginning to fade, possibly because it wasn't always the same:his face had different expressions, his clothes did not.
vi: His face is fading away, perhaps because it never stays still: it has many different expressions, unlike his clothes.
tr: His face is starting to fade, maybe because it wasn't always the same: His face had different expressions, but his clothes didn't.
es: It starts to fade, probably because it was never the same: his face had different expressions, and his clothes did not.

en: I pray that the hole, or two or three, there was more than one shot, they were close together, I pray that at least one hole is neatly,
vi: I pray for that hole, or two or three of them, not just one gunshot, but successive ones, I pray for at least one hole to neatly, quickly, and thoroughly pierce through his skull, through the place where all images are stored, so that there is only a single flash, whether it be darkness or pain, hopefully just a subtle one, like the word "thud," a flash and then silence.
tr: I pray that the hole -or two or three, because more than one shot was fired, they were consecutive- at least one hole, passed cleanly, swiftly, and ultimately through the skull, from the place where all the pictures are, so that this single clash would occur, a single clash of darkness or pain, which I hope was not sharp, like the word "bang," and then silence.
es: I beg that the hole, or the two or three —because there was more than one shot—

en: quickly, and finally through the skull, through the place whereall the pictures were, so that there would have been only the one flash, of darkness or pain, dull I hope, like the word thud, only the one and then silence.
vi: I pray for that hole, or two or three of them, not just one gunshot, but successive ones, I pray for at least one hole to neatly, quickly, and thoroughly pierce through his skull, through the place where all images are stored, so that there is only a single flash, whether it be darkness or pain, hopefully just a subtle one, like the word "thud," a flash and then silence.
tr: I pray that the hole -or two or three, because more than one shot was fired, they were consecutive- at least one hole, passed cleanly, swiftly, and ultimately through the skull, from the place where all the pictures are, so that this single clash would occur, a single clash of darkness or pain, which I hope was not sharp, like the word "bang," and then silence.
es: if they were very close together, I pray that at least one hole has opened cleanly, quickly, piercing the skull to the place where images are formed, so that there was a single flash of darkness or pain, I hope soft, like a dull noise, just one and then silence.

en: I believe this.
vi: I believe so.
tr: This is what I believe.
es: I believe so.

en: 1 also believe that Luke is sitting up, in a rectangle somewhere, gray cement, ona ledge or the edge of something, a bed or chair.
vi: I also believe that Luke is sitting upright, in a rectangular room somewhere, gray cement, on the edge or rim of something, a chair or a bed.
tr: Also, I believe Luke is sitting somewhere, in a gray cement rectangle, on the edge or protrusion of something, a bed or a chair.
es: I also think that Luke is standing upright on a gray cement rectangle, somewhere, on the ledge or the edge of something, a bed or a chair.

en: God knows what he's wearing, God knows what they've put him in.
vi: What he is wearing, only God knows, whatever they have dressed him in.
tr: God knows what he's wearing. God knows what they've put him into.
es: God knows what he's wearing. God knows what he has been subjected to.

en: God isn't the only one who knows, so maybe there could be some way of finding out.
vi: And it's not just God who knows, so maybe there's a way to find out.
tr: Not only God knows, so maybe there's a way to find out what happened to him.
es: God is not the only one who knows, so maybe there will be a way to find out.

en: He hasn't shaved for a year, though they cut his hair short, whenever they feel like it, for lice they say.
vi: His beard hasn't been shaved for a year, though his hair is cut short, whenever they feel like it, to prevent lice, they say.
tr: He hasn't shaved for a year, though they must be cutting his hair short, saying it's against lice every time they try to cut it.
es: He hasn't shaved in a year, although when they feel like it, they cut your hair, to avoid lice, they say.

en: I'll have to revise that: if they cut the hair for lice, they'd cut the beard too.
vi: This I need to correct: if they cut his hair to prevent lice, they would also cut his beard.
tr: I need to correct this: If they are cutting his hair against lice, they should also cut his beard.
es: I will have to think about it: if they cut his hair to avoid lice, they would also have to cut his beard.

en: You'd think.
vi: Logically.
tr: That's what one would think.
es: It would have to be considered.

en: Anyway, they don't do it well, the hair is ragged, the back of his neck is nicked, that's hardly the worst, helooks ten years older, twenty, he's bent like an old man, his eyes are pouched, small purple veins have burst in his cheeks, there's a scar, no, a wound, it isn't yet healed, the color of tulips, near the stem end, down the left side of his face where the flesh split recently.
vi: Even so, they did it clumsily, hair disheveled, neck scratched all over, even worse, he looked a decade older, twenty years older, his back bent like an old man, eyes sunken, tiny purple blood vessels on his cheeks burst, there was a scar, no, a wound, it still hadn't healed, a bruised purple color, near the base, under his left cheek where the flesh was recently cut.
tr: Anyway, they can't do this well, hair cropped, back of the neck cut, this isn't the worst, looks ten years older, twenty years, hunched like an old man, eyes bagged, small purple veins cracked in his wounds, there's a scar, no, a wound not yet healed, in the color that tulips take at the end of the stem, on the lower left of the face where the flesh was recently torn.
es: Anyway, they don't do it well, the cut is sloppy, the nape is uneven, although that's not the worst; he looks ten years older, hunched over like an old man, bags under his eyes; on his cheeks, he has some burst veins, purple in color, and a scar, no, a wound that is still not healed, the color of tulips near the stem, on the left side of his face, where the flesh has just been torn.

en: The body is so easily damaged, so easily disposed of, water and chemicals is all it is, hardly more to it than a jellyfish, drying on sand.
vi: How vulnerable the human body is, how easily it can be discarded, entirely just water and organic matter, not much more than a jellyfish, dried up on the sandy shore.
tr: The body is so easily injured, so easily disposed of, it's made up of just water and chemicals, not much different from a jellyfish drying in the sand.
es: His body is very injured and battered, it's nothing more than water and chemicals, barely more than a jellyfish drying on the sand.

en: He finds it painful to move his hands, painful to move.
vi: He feels a sharp pain every time he moves his arm, every time he moves.
tr: Moving his hands, moving at all, feels painful to him.
es: It is painful for him to move his hands, it hurts him to move.

en: He doesn't know what he's accused of.
vi: He doesn't know what he's being accused of.
tr: He doesn't know what he's being accused of.
es: He doesn't know what he is being accused of.

en: A problem.
vi: It's going to be difficult.
tr: A problem.
es: It's a problem.

en: There must be something, some accusation.
vi: There must be something, there must be a crime to accuse.
tr: There must be something, an accusation.
es: There has to be something, some accusation.

en: Otherwise why are they keeping him, why isn't he already dead?
vi: If not, why are they detaining him, why isn't he dead yet?
tr: Otherwise, why are they holding him, why hasn't he died yet?
es: Otherwise, why are they holding him, why isn't he dead yet?

en: He must know something they want to know.
vi: He must know something they want to know.
tr: He must know something they want to know.
es: He must know something they want to find out.

en: I can't imagine.
vi: I can't imagine.
tr: I can't think of what it is.
es: I can't imagine it.

en: I can't imagine he hasn't already said whatever it is.
vi: I can't imagine that he still hasn't said that something.
tr: I can't imagine that whatever it is they want, he hasn't said it yet.
es: I can't imagine that he hasn't said it, whatever it is.

en: I would.
vi: If it were me, I would have already said it.
tr: I would have told them.
es: I would have done it.

en: He is surroundedby a smell, his own, the smell of a cooped-up animal in a dirty cage.
vi: He was immersed in a smell, his smell, the smell of a beast trapped in a filthy cage.
tr: Surrounded by a scent, with its own scent, the scent of an animal trapped in a dirty cage.
es: He is surrounded by a smell, his smell, the smell of an animal locked in a dirty cage.

en: I imagine him resting, because I can't bear to imagine him at any other time, just as I can't imagine anything below his collar, above his cuffs.
vi: I imagined him at rest, because I couldn't imagine him doing anything else, just as I couldn't picture anything beneath the collar around his neck, above the handcuffs.
tr: I dream of it while resting, because I can't bear to dream of it at any other time, just like I can't dream of anything between the bottom of its collar and the top of its cuff.
es: I imagine him resting, because I can't bear to imagine him at any other time, just as I can't imagine him having anything under his neck, or on his wrists.

en: I don't want to think what they've doneto his body.
vi: I didn't want to imagine what they had done to his body.
tr: I don't want to think about what they did to its body.
es: I don't even want to think about what they've done to his body.

en: Does he have shoes?
vi: Did he have shoes?
tr: Does it have shoes, I wonder?
es: Does he have shoes?

en: No, and the floor is cold and wet.
vi: No, and the floor was damp and cold.
tr: No, the ground is cold and wet.
es: No, and the floor is cold and damp.

en: Does he know I'm here, alive, that I'm thinking about him?
vi: Did he know I was here, still alive, did he know I was thinking about him?
tr: Does it know that I am here, that I am alive, that I am thinking of it?
es: Does he know that I am here, alive, and that I am thinking about him?

en: I have to believe
vi: I had to believe so.
tr: I must believe that it knows this.
es: I have to believe so.

en: so.
vi: I had to believe so.
tr: I must believe that it knows this.
es: I have to believe so.

en: In reduced circumstances you have to believe all kinds of things.
vi: In desperate circumstances, one must believe in a hundred different things.
tr: Under limited circumstances, you must believe in all sorts of things.
es: When you find yourself in a tight situation, you have to believe all kinds of things.

en: I believe in thought transference now, vibrations in the ether, that sort of junk.
vi: Now I even believed in telepathy, vibrations transmitted through ether, and even more nonsense.
tr: Now I believe in thought transmission, vibrations in the sky, that kind of nonsense.
es: Now I believe in telepathy, in ether vibrations, and in that kind of nonsense.

en: I never used to.
vi: Never before.
tr: I never used to believe in it.
es: I had never believed in them.

en: I also believe that they didn't catch him or catch up with him after all, that he made it, reached the bank, swam the river, crossed the border, dragged himself up on the far shore, an island, teeth chattering; found his way to a nearby farmhouse, was allowed in, with suspicion at first, but then when they understood who he was, they were friendly, not the sort who would turn him in, perhaps they were Quakers, they will smuggle him inland, from house to house, the woman made him some hot coffee and gave him a set of her husband's clothes.
vi: I also believe that in the end, they did not catch or overtake you, that you escaped, reached the shore, swam across the river, crossed the border, drifted to the other side, an island, teeth chattering; found your way to a nearby farm, were let in, initially with suspicion, but then when they understood, they were very kind, not the type to turn you in, perhaps Quakers, who would secretly take you further inland, from house to house, the lady of the house making you hot coffee, giving you her husband's clothes.
tr: Also, I believe the following: They didn't catch him or even reach him, he managed to escape, reached the shore, swam in the river, crossed the border, barely made it to a distant shore or island, with his teeth chattering; he reached a nearby farm, was initially taken in with suspicion, but then when they realized who he was, they treated him kindly, they were not the kind of people to betray him, maybe they were Quakers, they would smuggle him inland from house to house; the woman made him some hot coffee and gave him a suit of her husband's clothes.
es: I also believe that they didn't catch him, that after all they didn't reach him, that he made it, that he got to the shore, swam across the river, crossed the border and crawled to the opposite shore, which was an island, and his teeth were chattering; he managed to reach a nearby farm and they let him in, initially with suspicion but later, when they understood who he was, they became friendly, they weren't the type of people who would turn him in; maybe they were Quakers and they smuggled him into the territory by passing him from house to house, and the woman made him a hot coffee and gave him a change of clothes from her husband.

en: I picture the clothes.
vi: I sketch the clothes.
tr: I picture the clothes in my mind.
es: I imagine the clothes.

en: It comforts me to dress him warmly.
vi: Feeling at ease knowing you are warmly dressed.
tr: Dressing him in something that will keep him warm comforts me.
es: It would comfort me to know that he was warm.

en: He made contact with the others, there must be a resistance, a government in exile.
vi: Contact those people, there must be a resistance force, an exiled government.
tr: He got in touch with the others, there must be a resistance, a government in exile.
es: He came into contact with the others, there must be a resistance, a government in exile.

en: Someone must be out there, takinf care of things.
vi: There must be someone out there, taking care of everything.
tr: There must be someone outside, arranging things.
es: There must be someone out there who takes care of things.

en: I believe in the resistance as I believe there can be no light without shadow; or rather, no shadow unless there is also light.
vi: I believe in the existence of a resistance force as much as I believe there can't be darkness without light; or conversely, there can't be darkness unless there is light.
tr: I believe in the resistance as I believe there can be no light without shadow; or rather, as I believe there can be no shadow without light.
es: I believe in the resistance in the same way that I believe there can't be light without shadow, or rather, there is no shadow unless there is also light.

en: There must be a resistance, or where do all the criminals come from, on the television?
vi: There must be resistance, otherwise, where would all those criminals shown on TV come from?
tr: There must be a resistance, otherwise where are all those criminals shown on TV coming from?
es: There has to be a resistance because otherwise, where do all the criminals that appear on television come from?

en: Any day now there may be a message from him.
vi: Now, there could be news about him any day.
tr: Now, a message from him could come at any moment.
es: Any day now, a message from him could arrive.

en: Itwill come in the most unexpected way, from the least likely person, someone I never would have suspected.
vi: It will come in the most unexpected way, from the person I least expect, someone I never thought of.
tr: In the most unexpected way, from the most unlikely person, from someone I would never expect.
