es: It will come in the most unexpected way, from the person you least imagine, someone you would never have suspected.

en: Under my plate, on the dinner tray?
vi: Placed under a plate, in the food tray?
tr: Maybe under my plate or on the dinner tray?
es: Perhaps it will be under my plate, on the food tray?

en: Slipped into my hand as I reach the tokens across the counter in All Flesh?
vi: Slipped into my hand when passing the ticket over the Meat counter?
tr: Or will it be handed to me when I give the report cards over the counter at Bilumum Etler?
es: Or will it be slipped into my hand while I hand over the vouchers across the counter at Todo Carne?

en: The message will say that I must have patience: sooner or later he will get me out, we will find her, wherever they've put her.
vi: The note will tell me to be patient: sooner or later he will rescue me, we will find our child, no matter where they have taken them.
tr: The message will say that I need to be patient: Sooner or later, it will get me out, we will find the girl, wherever they put her.
es: The message will say that I must be patient: sooner or later he will rescue me, he will find her, wherever they have her.

en: She'll remember us and we will be all three of us together.
vi: The child still remembers their parents and the three of us will be reunited as before.
tr: She will remember us and the three of us will be together.
es: She will remember us, and the three of us will be together.

en: Meanwhile I must endure, keep myself safe for later.
vi: In the meantime, I need to persevere and wait for the right moment.
tr: In the meantime, I must endure, I must take care of myself for later.
es: In the meantime, I must resist, keep myself safe for later.

en: What has happened to me, what's happening to me now, won't make any difference to him, he loves me anyway, he knows it isn't my fault.
vi: What has happened to me, what is happening to me, won't change anything; he still loves me, he knows this isn't my fault.
tr: What happened to me before, what is happening to me now will not matter to her, she still loves me, she knows it's not my fault.
es: What has happened to me, what is happening to me now, will not matter to him, he loves me anyway, he knows it is not my fault.

en: The message will say that also.
vi: The note will say that too.
tr: The message will say this too.
es: The message will also speak of that.

en: It's this message, which may never arrive, that keeps me alive.
vi: This very note, which may never come, has kept me alive.
tr: This is the message that keeps me alive, the one that might never come.
es: It is this message —which may never arrive— that keeps me alive.

en: I believe in the message.
vi: I believe in it.
tr: I believe in this message.
es: I believe in the message.

en: The things I believe can't all be true, though one of them must be.
vi: The things I believe cannot all be true, though at least one of the three must be.
tr: Not everything I believe in can be true, yet one of them must be.
es: The things I believe may not all be true, although some of them must be.

en: But I believe in all of them, all three versions of Luke, at one and the same time.
vi: But I believe in all three, three versions of Luke, at the same time.
tr: Still, I believe in all of them, simultaneously in all three variations regarding Luke's fate.
es: But I believe in all of them, I believe in the three versions of what happened to Luke, in all three at the same time.

en: This contradictory way of believing seems to me, right now, the only way I can believe anything.
vi: This contradictory way of believing, now, to me, is the only way to believe anything.
tr: This way of believing, filled with contradictions, is the only way for me to believe in anything, right now.
es: This contradictory way of believing seems to me, at this moment, the only way I have to believe in something.

en: Whatever the truth is, I will be ready for it.
vi: Whatever the truth may be, I am ready to face it.
tr: Whatever the truth may be, I will be ready for it.
es: Whatever the truth may be, I will be prepared.

en: This also is a belief of mine.
vi: That is another thing I am sure of.
tr: This is my belief.
es: This is also one of my beliefs.

en: This also may be untrue.
vi: This too could be wrong.
tr: This may also not be true.
es: This can also be false.

en: One of the gravestones in the cemetery near the earliest church has an anchor on it and an hourglass, and the words In Hope.
vi: The tombstone in the cemetery near the old church has an engraving of an anchor and an hourglass, along with the word Hope.
tr: On one of the tombstones in the cemetery near the oldest church, there is an anchor and an hourglass, and the following words:
es: One of the tombstones in the cemetery near the church has carved a casket and an hourglass, and the words: With hope.

en: In Hope.
vi: Hope.
tr: In hope. In hope.
es: With hope.

en: Why did they put that above a dead person?
vi: Why do they write that on the head of the dead?
tr: Why did they write this on a dead person's tombstone?
es: Why did they dedicate those words to a dead person?

en: Was it the corpse hoping, or those still alive?
vi: Is the corpse in the grave hoping, or are the living ones?
tr: Was the hopeful one dead, or was it still the living?
es: Was it the corpse that harbored hopes, or those who are still alive?

en: Does Luke hope?
vi: Does Luke hope or not?
tr: Is Luke hoping as well, I wonder?
es: Does Luke have hopes?

en: VIII
vi: VIII - Date of Birth
tr: VIII
es: VIII

en: Birth Day
vi: VIII - Date of Birth
tr: Birthday
es: THE DAY OF BIRTH

vi: VIII - Date of Birth
tr: Birthday
es: THE DAY OF BIRTH
CHAPTER 19

en: Im dreaming that I am awake.
vi: I dream that I am awake.
tr: I see that I am awake in my dream.
es: I am dreaming that I am awake.

en: I dream that I get out of bed and walk across the room, not this room, and go out the door, not this door.
vi: I see myself getting out of bed and walking across the room, not this room, out the door, not this door.
tr: I see myself getting out of bed and crossing the room, but not this room, from one end to the other, and leaving through the door, but not this door, in my dream.
es: I dream that I get out of bed and cross the room, not this room, and go out the door, not this door.

en: I'mat home, one of my homes, and she's running to meet me, in her small green nightgown with the sunflower on the front, her feet bare, and I pick her up and reel her arms and legs go around me and I begin to cry, because I know then that I'm not awake.
vi: I am at home, one of the houses I used to live in, and the child runs to me, wearing a small blue nightgown, with a sunflower printed on the chest, barefoot, and then I pick the child up and feel their limbs wrapping around me and I cry, because at that moment I know I am dreaming.
tr: I am at home, in one of my homes, the girl is running to embrace me, in her small green nightgown with a sunflower on her chest, her feet are bare, I lift her up and feel her arms and legs wrapping around me and I start to cry, because then I realize I am not awake.
es: I'm at home, one of my homes, and she runs to meet me dressed in her little green nightgown with a sunflower on the front, barefoot, and I pick her up and feel her arms and legs wrapping around my body and I start to cry because I realize that I'm not awake.

en: I'mback in this bed, trying to wake up, and I wake up and sit on the edge of the bed, and my mother comes in with a tray and asks me if I'm feeling better.
vi: I see myself back in bed, then waking up, and waking up sitting on the edge of the bed, and my mother brings in a tray and asks if I am feeling better.
tr: I am back in this bed, trying to wake up, I wake up and sit on the edge of the bed, my mother comes in with a tray in her hand and asks if I am feeling better.
es: I'm in this bed again, trying to wake up and I wake up and sit on the edge of the bed, and my mother comes with a tray and asks me if I feel better.

en: When I was sick, as a child, she had to stay home from work, But I'm not awake this time either.
vi: Every time I was sick, when I was little, my mother had to take time off work to stay home. But this time I haven't woken up yet either.
tr: When I was a child and sick, she would have to stay home from work. But this time, I am not awake either.
es: As a child, when I got sick, she had to miss work. But this time I'm not awake either.

en: After these dreams I do awake, and I know I'm really awake because there is the wreath, on the ceiling, and my curtains hanging like drowned white hair.
vi: After these dreams, I woke up completely, and knew I was awake when I saw that wreath again, on the ceiling, both curtains hanging down like the white hair of a drowned person.
tr: After these dreams, I wake up and I know that I am truly awake because I see the garland on the ceiling and my curtains hang like white hair drowned in water.
es: After these dreams, I wake up for real and I know that I am truly awake because I see the garland on the ceiling and my curtains, which hang like a soaked white mane.

en: I feel drugged.
vi: I felt dizzy as if drugged.
tr: I feel drugged.
es: I feel drugged.

en: I consider'this: maybe they're drugging me.
vi: I pondered this possibility: maybe they had drugged me.
tr: I calculate this possibility: Maybe they are giving me medicine.
es: I think that maybe they are drugging me.

en: Maybe the life I think I'm living is a paranoid delusion.
vi: Maybe my life, which I thought was real, is just an illusion.
tr: Maybe this life I think I am living is nothing but a paranoid delusion.
es: Maybe the life I believe I am living is a paranoid illusion.

en: Not a hope.
vi: Zero hope.
tr: There is no hope.
es: Not a chance.

en: I know where I am, and who, and what day it is.
vi: I know where I am, who I am, and what day it is today.
tr: I know where I am, who I am, and what day it is.
es: I know where I am, who I am, and what day it is.

en: These are the tests, and I am sane.
vi: Three questions to check, I am completely sane.
tr: Thus, I test myself, my mind is clear.
es: These are the proofs, and I am healthy.

en: Sanity is a valuable possesion I hoard it
vi: A clear mind is a priceless treasure; I store it like people used to store money.
tr: The mind is a valuable thing to possess; I accumulate it as people once accumulated money.
es: Health is an invaluable asset.

en: the way people once hoarded money.
vi: A clear mind is a priceless treasure; I store it like people used to store money.
tr: The mind is a valuable thing to possess; I accumulate it as people once accumulated money.
es: I treasure it just as people once treasured money.

en: I save it, so I will have enough, when the time comes.
vi: I save it, to have enough when needed, when the time comes.
tr: I keep it, and when the time comes, I will have enough.
es: I keep it, because that way I'll have enough when the time comes.

en: Grayness comes through the curtains, hazy bright, not much sun today.
vi: The gray light filters through the curtains, dimly bright, it's not very sunny today.
tr: Smoke is seeping through the curtains, a misty light, there's not much sun today.
es: A gray reflection enters through the window, a dull shine, there isn't much sun today.

en: I get out of bed, go to the window, kneel on the window seat, the hard little cushion, FAITH, and look out There is nothing to be seen.
vi: I get out of bed, go to the window, kneel on the sill, the small hard pillow, FAITH, looking outside. There's nothing to see.
tr: I get out of bed, go to the window and kneel on the window sill, hard small pillow, FAITH, I look outside There's nothing to see.
es: I get out of bed, go to the window, and kneel on the seat, on the hard cushion of FAITH, and look outside. There is nothing to see.

en: I wonder what has become of the other two cushions.
vi: I wonder where those two went.
tr: I wonder what happened to the other two pillows?
es: I wonder what happened to the other two cushions.

en: There must have been three, once.
vi: It must have been a trio at first.
tr: There should have been three, once upon a time.
es: There must have been three at some point.

en: HOPE and CHARITY where have they been stowed?
vi: HOPE and CHARITY, where have they been sent?
tr: Where did they put HOPE and KINDNESS?
es: HOPE and CHARITY, where could they have stored them?

en: Serena Joy has tidy habits.
vi: Serena Joy is used to neatness.
tr: Serena Joy has regular habits.
es: Serena Joy is a woman of order.

en: She wouldn't throw away anything not quite worn out.
vi: She wouldn't throw away anything that isn't too worn out.
tr: She never throws away something that isn't completely worn out.
es: She wouldn't throw anything away unless it was very worn out.

en: One for Rita, one for Cora?
vi: One for Rita, the other for Cora perhaps?
tr: Did she give one to Rita and the other to Cora?
es: One for Rita and one for Cora?

en: The bell goes, I'm up before it, ahead of time, I dress, not looking down.
vi: The bell rang; I woke up early, before the time. I got dressed, without looking down.
tr: The bell is ringing, I had woken up before the bell, I am ahead of time. I am getting dressed, without looking ahead.
es: The bell rings; I am already up, I got up before time. I get dressed, without looking down.

en: I sit in the chair and think about the word char.
vi: I sit on the chair and think about the word "chair". Chair.
tr: I am sitting in the chair and thinking about the word chair4.
es: I sit in the chair and think about this word: chair.

en: It can also mean the leader of a meeting.
vi: It also means the head of a meeting.
tr: It can also mean the head of a meeting.
es: I sit in the chair and think about this word: chair.

en: It can also mean a mode of execution.
vi: It is also a method of execution.
tr: It can also mean a type of execution method.
es: It also means papal seat, and there is the electric chair.

en: It is the first syllable in chanty.
vi: Pronounced, it is the beginning of "charity," kindness.
tr: It is the first syllable in the word charity5.
es: In English, it is called chair, and chair in French means flesh.

en: It is the French world for flesh.
vi: In French, it means "flesh".
tr: In French, it means body.
es: In English, it is called chair, and chair in French means flesh.

en: None of these facts has any connection with the others.
vi: These things have nothing to do with each other.
tr: None of these facts are related to each other.
es: None of these things are related to the rest.

en: These are the kinds of litanies I use, to compse myself.
vi: This is my daily prayer book, to prepare myself.
tr: These are the types of prayers I use to calm down.
es: This is the kind of litany I resort to in order to calm myself.

en: In front of me is a tray, and on the tray are a glass of apple juice, a vitamin pill, a spoon, a plate with three slice of brown toast on it, a small dish containing honey, and another plate with an eggcup on it, the kind that looks like a woman's torso, in a skirt.
vi: In front of me is a tray, on it a glass of apple juice, a vitamin pill, a spoon, three slices of brown bread on a plate, another small plate holding honey, a third plate supporting an egg cup, shaped like the waist of a woman, wearing a skirt.
tr: In front of me, there is a tray, on the tray there is a glass of apple juice, a vitamin pill, a spoon, a plate with three slices of brown toast, a small bowl containing honey, and another plate resembling the skirted body of a woman, with a second egg underneath the skirt to keep it from getting cold.
es: In front of me, I have a tray, and on the tray, there is a glass of apple juice, a vitamin pill, a spoon, a plate with three slices of toast, a small dish with honey, and another plate with an egg cup — one of those that look like a woman's torso — covered with a lid.

en: Under the skirt is the second egg, being kept warm.
vi: The skirt covers the second egg, keeping it warm.
tr: In front of me, there is a tray, on the tray there is a glass of apple juice, a vitamin pill, a spoon, a plate with three slices of brown toast, a small bowl containing honey, and another plate resembling the skirted body of a woman, with a second egg underneath the skirt to keep it from getting cold.
es: Under the lid, to keep it warm, is the second egg.

en: The eggcup is white china with a blue stripe.
vi: The cup is made of white porcelain with a blue glaze.
tr: The egg cup is made of white porcelain with blue stripes.
es: The egg cup is made of white porcelain with a blue stripe.

en: The first egg is white.
vi: The egg on top is white.
tr: The first egg is white.
es: The first egg is white.

en: I move the eggcup alittle, so it's now in the watery sunlight that comes through the window and falls, brightening, waning, brightening again, on the tray.
vi: I move the cup a bit, so it catches the shimmering sunlight streaming through the window, which lands on the tray, glows, fades, and then glows again.
tr: I push the egg holder a bit, so it enters the weak daylight that comes through the window, illuminating, diminishing, then illuminating again, and falls onto the tray.
es: I move the egg carton a bit so that it is now under the pale sunlight coming through the window, which falls on the tray shining, weakening, and shining again.

en: The shell of the egg is smooth but also grained; small pelbles of calcium are defined by the sunlight, like craters on the mom.
vi: The eggshell is smooth but also slightly gritty; the small calcium deposits are accentuated by the sunlight, like the craters of the moon.
tr: The shell of the egg is smooth but also rough; it is marked by small calcium particles resembling craters on the moon.
es: The eggshell is smooth and at the same time grainy. Under the sunlight, tiny calcium pebbles are drawn, like the craters of the moon.

en: It's a barren landscape, yet perfect; it's the sort of desert the saints went into, so their minds would not be distracted by profusion.
vi: The scene is barren, but perfect; an ideal desert for saints to retreat, keeping their minds undisturbed by the bustling outside world.
tr: A barren land, yet perfect; a kind of desert that saints go to so their minds do not succumb to extremes.
es: It is an arid, yet perfect landscape; it is the kind of desert that saints traversed so that abundance would not scatter their minds.

en: I think that this is what God
vi: I think God must look exactly like this: like an egg.
tr: I think God must look like this: an egg.
es: I think this must be what God looks like: an egg.

en: must look like: an egg.
vi: I think God must look exactly like this: like an egg.
tr: I think God must look like this: an egg.
es: I think this must be what God looks like: an egg.

en: The life of the moon may not be on the surface, but inside.
vi: Who knows, maybe life on the moon doesn't exist on the surface, but within its core.
tr: Life on the moon might be inside rather than on the surface.
es: Perhaps life on the Moon does not take place on the surface but inside.

en: The egg is glowing now, as if it had an energy of its own.
vi: Now the egg is glowing, as if emitting energy on its own.
tr: The egg is now glowing, as if it has its own energy.
es: Now the egg glows, as if it had its own energy.

en: To look at the egg gives me intense pleasure.
vi: Watching it gives me indescribable pleasure.
tr: Looking at the egg gives me great pleasure.
es: Looking at it gives me intense pleasure.

en: The sun goes and the egg fades.
vi: The sun sets, the egg goes out.
tr: The sun is disappearing and the egg is fading.
es: The sun goes away and the egg fades.

en: I pick the egg out of the cup and finger'tfor a moment.
vi: I picked up the egg and fiddled with it for a moment.
tr: I take the egg from the captain and for a moment I turn it around between my fingers.
es: I take the egg out of the egg carton and touch it.

en: It's warm.
vi: Warm.
tr: Warm.
es: It is warm.

en: Women used to carry such eggs betveen their breasts, to incubate them.
vi: In the old days, women would carry these eggs between their breasts, incubating them until they hatched.
tr: In the past, women used to carry these between their breasts to incubate them.
es: Women used to carry eggs like these between their breasts to incubate them.

en: That would have felt good.
vi: It must have felt quite interesting.
tr: They must have felt good.
es: It must have been a pleasant sensation.

en: The minimalist life.
vi: Life is extremely simple.
tr: Minimalist life.
es: The minimal expression of life.

en: Pleasure is an egg.
vi: Happiness = an egg.
tr: Even an egg gives pleasure.
es: Pleasure condensed in an egg.

en: Blessings that can be
vi: Blessings can be counted on one hand.
tr: Blessings that can be counted on the fingers of one hand.
es: Blessings that can be counted on the fingers of one hand.

vi: Blessings can be counted on one hand.
tr: Blessings that can be counted on the fingers of one hand.
es: Blessings that can be counted on the fingers of one hand.

en: counted, on the fingers of one hand.
vi: Blessings can be counted on one hand.
tr: Blessings that can be counted on the fingers of one hand.
es: Blessings that can be counted on the fingers of one hand.

en: But possibly this is how I am expected to react.
vi: But perhaps this is exactly the reaction people expect from me.
tr: But it is expected of me to give up in this way.
es: But that's probably how I'm expected to react.

en: If I have an egg, what more can I want?
vi: I have the egg, what more could I ask for?
tr: If I have an egg, what more could I want?
es: If I have an egg, what more could I want?

en: In reduced circumstances the desire to live attaches itself to strange objects.
vi: In circumstances of declining aspirations, the will to live attaches itself to the strangest objects.
tr: Under limited means, the desire to live attaches itself to strange objects.
es: In a tight situation, the desire to live clings to strange objects.

en: I would like a pet: a bird, say, or a cat.
vi: If only I had some animal: a bird, for instance, or a cat. A pet.
tr: I would like to have a pet: a bird or a cat.
es: I would like to have a pet: let's say a bird, or a cat.

en: A familiar.
vi: An animal that is at least somewhat familiar.
tr: A friend.
es: A friend.

en: Anything at all familiar.
vi: An animal that is at least somewhat familiar.
tr: It could be anything familiar.
es: Anything that seemed familiar to me.

en: A rat would do, in a pinch, but there's no chance of that.
vi: A mouse would do as well, if necessary, but I don't expect to get one.
tr: A rat would do, if necessary, but such a possibility doesn't exist.
es: Even a rat would do, if I ever caught one, but there's no chance: this house is too clean.

en: This house is too clean.
vi: This house is too clean.
tr: This house is too clean.
es: Even a rat would do, if I ever caught one, but there's no chance: this house is too clean.

en: I slice the top off the egg with the spoon, and eat the contents.
vi: I took a spoon, cracked the top of the egg, and ate the inside.
tr: I open the top of the egg with a spoon and eat the inside.
es: I break the top of the egg with the spoon and eat the inside.

en: While I'm eating the second egg, I hear the siren, at a great distance at first, winding its way towards me among the large houses and clipped lawns, a thin sound like the hum of an insect; then nearing, opening out, like a flower of sound opening, into atrumpet.
vi: While eating the second fruit, I heard the sound of a siren, at first very distant, winding through large houses and neatly trimmed lawns, the sound buzzing like an insect; then it came closer, blooming, like a flower of sound bursting into a brass trumpet.
tr: While eating the second egg, I hear the siren, a thin sound like the buzz of an insect, at first from a distance, winding its way through large houses and mowed lawns towards me; then it gets closer, blooming from the sound like a flower and turning into a trumpet.
es: While I eat the second egg, I hear the siren, at first very far away — snaking towards me between the enormous houses with trimmed lawns, a high-pitched sound like the buzz of an insect, then approaching and opening up like the sound that blooms in a trumpet.

en: A proclamation, this siren.
vi: What announcement is this, this siren sound.
tr: This siren is an announcement.
es: This siren is quite a proclamation.

en: I put down my spoon, my heart speeds up, I go to the window again: will it be blue and not for me?
vi: I put down the spoon, my heart leaping, I went to the window again: what if it's blue, not meant for me?
tr: I put down my spoon, my heart rate quickens, I go to the window again: will it be blue, meaning not for me?
es: I put down the spoon; my heart races and I move closer to the window: could it be blue, and not for me?

en: But I see it turn the corner, come along the street, stop in front of the house, still blaring, and it's red.
vi: But I saw it turn in, speeding down the street, stopping right in front of the house, still blaring loudly, and painted red.
tr: I see it turning the corner, advancing along the street, still making noise, stopping in front of the house, and it is red.
es: I see it turn the corner, come down the street, and stop in front of the house without ceasing to sound the siren. It's red.

en: Joy to the world, rare enough these days.
vi: Good news, rarely seen these days.
tr: Happiness in the world, this is something rarely experienced these days.
es: The day dresses up for a celebration, something rare these days.

en: I leave the second egg half eaten, hurry to the closet for my cloak, and already I can hear feet on the stairs and the voices calling.
vi: I left the half-eaten egg, hurriedly went to the closet to get my coat, already hearing footsteps on the stairs and a call.
tr: I leave the second egg half-eaten, run to the closet to get my cloak, I can already hear my footsteps on the stairs and them calling me.
es: I leave the second egg half-eaten and run to the closet to grab my cape; I can already hear the footsteps on the stairs and the voices.

en: "Hurry," says Cora, "won't wait all day," and she helps me on with the cloak, she's actually smiling.
vi: “Hurry up,” said Cora, “no one is going to wait all day,” and she helped me put on my shirt, she even laughed.
tr: “Hurry up,” says Cora. “They won't wait for you all day.” She helps me put on my cloak and is actually smiling.
es: —Hurry up —Cora urges me—, they won't wait for you all day —she helps me put on the cloak; she is smiling.

en: I almost run down the hall, the stairs are like skiing, the front door is wide, today I can go through it, and the Guardian stands there,
vi: I almost ran through the hall, sliding down the stairs like a snow hill, the front door wide open, today I was allowed to pass through, and the Guard stood there, bowing.
tr: I'm almost running through the hall, sliding down the stairs, the front door is wide open, I can use it today, the Guard is standing there, saluting.
es: I advance through the hallway, almost running; the staircase is like a ski slope, the main door is wide, today I can go through it; next to it is the Guardian, who greets me.

en: saluting.
vi: It started to rain, a light drizzle, and the smell of earth and growing grass filled the air.
tr: I'm almost running through the hall, sliding down the stairs, the front door is wide open, I can use it today, the Guard is standing there, saluting.
es: I advance through the hallway, almost running; the staircase is like a ski slope, the main door is wide, today I can go through it; next to it is the Guardian, who greets me.

en: It's started to rain, a drizzle, and the gravid smell of earth and grass fills the air.
vi: It started to rain, a light drizzle, and the smell of earth and growing grass filled the air.
tr: It has started to rain, drizzling, the pregnant scent of soil and grass fills the air.
es: It has started to rain, it's only a drizzle, and the air is filled with the smell of earth and grass.

en: The redBirthmobile is parked in the driveway.
vi: The red-colored Van stopped right at the entrance.
tr: The red Birthmobile is parked on the driveway.
es: The red Birthmobile is parked in the driveway.

en: Its back door is open and I clamber in.
vi: The back door opened, and I clumsily climbed in.
tr: The back door is open, I climb inside.
es: The back door is open and I climb up through it.

en: The carpet on the floor is red, red curtains are drawn over the windows.
vi: The car's floor mat was red, and red curtains were draped over the car windows.
tr: The carpet on the floor is red, and red curtains are drawn on the windows.
es: The carpet is red, just like the curtains on the windows.

en: There are three women in here already, sitting on the benches that run the length of the van on eitherside.
vi: Inside, there were already three women, sitting on two long benches running along both sides.
tr: Three women are already sitting on the benches placed on both sides of the minibus.
es: Inside, there are already three women, sitting on the benches installed along the sides of the van.

en: The Guardian closes and locks the double doors and climbs into the front, beside the driver; through the glassed-ovcr wire grille we can see the backs of their heads'.
vi: The Guard closed the two back doors and locked them, then sat in the front seat next to the driver; through the iron mesh lined with glass, the backs of their heads could be seen.
tr: The guard closes and locks the double doors and sits in the front next to the driver; we can see the backs of their heads through the wire mesh covered with glass.
es: The Guardian closes and locks the double door and jumps into the front seat, next to the driver; through the wire mesh that protects the glass, we can see the backs of their heads.

en: We start with a lurch, while overhead the siren screams:
vi: The car jerked once and then started moving, the siren above still shrieking loudly:
tr: We move with a jolt, a siren wails above us: Make way, make way!
es: We start with a jolt, while above our heads the siren screams:

en: Make way, make way!
vi: Make way, make way!
tr: We move with a jolt, a siren wails above us: Make way, make way!
es: Make way, make way!

en: "Who is it?"
vi: "Who is that?"
tr: "Kim?" I ask the woman next to me; towards her ear or where her ear should be under the white hood.
es: —Who is it?

en: I say to the woman next to me; into her ear, or where her ear must be under the white headress, I almost have to shout, the noise is so loud.
vi: I asked the woman next to me; speaking into her ear, or where her ear might be under the scarf. I almost had to shout, the whistle was too loud.
tr: I almost have to shout, the noise is so loud.
es: —I ask the woman next to me; I have to speak into her ear, or wherever her ear is under the white headdress. There is so much noise that I almost have to shout.

en: "Ofwarren," she shouts back.
vi: “Ofwarren,” she shouted back.
tr: “Warreninki,” he shouts.
es: —Dewarren —she responds to me, shouting.

en: Impulsively she grabs my hand, squeezes it, as we lurch around the corner; she turns to me and I
vi: Instinctively, she grabbed my hand, squeezing it tightly, as the car jerked around the corner; she turned to me and I saw her face, tears rolling down her cheeks, but why?
tr: As we turn the corner shakily, he grabs my hand involuntarily, squeezes it; he turns to me and I see his face, tears are streaming down his cheeks, but what kind of tears are these?
es: As if moved by an impulse, she grabs my hand, squeezes it.

en: see her face, there are tears running down her cheeks, but tears of what?
vi: Instinctively, she grabbed my hand, squeezing it tightly, as the car jerked around the corner; she turned to me and I saw her face, tears rolling down her cheeks, but why?
tr: As we turn the corner shakily, he grabs my hand involuntarily, squeezes it; he turns to me and I see his face, tears are streaming down his cheeks, but what kind of tears are these?
es: As the van turns the corner, it swerves; the woman turns towards me and I can see her face and the tears running down her cheeks. Why is she crying?

en: Envy, disappointment?
vi: Jealousy, disappointment?
tr: Jealousy, disappointment?
es: Is it envy or displeasure?

en: But no, she's laughing, she throws her arms around me, I've never seen her before, she hugs me, she has large breasts, under the red habit, she wipes her sleeve across her lace.
vi: But no, she was laughing, she threw her arms around me, I had never met her before, she hugged me, her large breasts under the red outfit, she wiped her face with her sleeve.
tr: But no, he is laughing, he suddenly wraps his arms around my neck, I had never seen him before, he hugs me, he has large breasts under his red dress, he wipes his face with the sleeve of his dress.
es: But no, she is laughing, she throws her arms around my neck, I don't know her, she hugs me, I feel her large breasts under the red dress; she wipes her face with her sleeve.

en: On this day we can do anything we want.
vi: A day like today we could do whatever we wanted.
tr: On a day like this, we can do anything we want.
es: On a day like this, we can do whatever we want.

en: I revise that: within limits.
vi: Correction needed: within the framework.
tr: I'm correcting: within the limits.
es: I correct myself: within certain limits.

en: Across from us on the other bench, one woman is praying, eyes closed, hands up to her mouth.
vi: Opposite on the other bench, a woman is praying, eyes closed, hand touching her mouth.
tr: In front of us, on the other bench, a woman with her eyes closed, hands on her mouth, is praying.
es: In front of us, on the other bench, a woman prays with her eyes closed and covering her mouth with her hands.

en: Or she may not be praying.
vi: Or maybe not.
tr: Or she might not be praying.
es: Maybe she is not praying, but biting her thumbnail.

en: She nitty be biting her thumbnails.
vi: Maybe she is biting her thumbnail.
tr: Maybe she is biting her nails.
es: Maybe she is not praying, but biting her thumbnail.

en: Possibly she's trying to keep calm.
vi: Perhaps she is calm.
tr: She is possibly trying to stay calm.
es: Perhaps she is trying to calm herself.

en: The third woman is calm already, she sits with her arms folded, Smiling a little.
vi: The third person has already calmed down, arms crossed, mouth slightly smiling.
tr: The third woman has already calmed down. She is sitting with her arms crossed, smiling slightly.
es: The third woman has already calmed down. She is sitting with her arms crossed and smiles slightly.

en: 'I'he siren goes on and on.
vi: The siren is still blaring continuously.
tr: The siren keeps blaring.
es: The siren sounds continuously.

en: That used to be the sound of death, for ambulances or fires.
vi: In the past, this sound signaled death, guiding ambulances or fire trucks.
tr: In the past, this was the sound of death for ambulances or fires.
es: This was the sound of death, the one used by ambulances or firefighters.

en: Possibly it will be the sound of death today also.
vi: Who knows, it might signal death today as well.
tr: It is possibly the sound of death today as well.
es: Probably today it will also be the sound of death.

en: We will soon know.
vi: We'll know soon enough.
tr: We will learn this soon.
es: We will know soon.

en: What will Ofwarren give birth to?
vi: What will Ofwarren give birth to?
tr: What will Warren's give birth to, I wonder?
es: What will Dewarren give birth to?

en: A baby, as we all hope?
vi: A baby, as everyone hopes?
tr: A baby, as we all hope?
es: A baby, as we all hope?

en: Or something else, an Unbaby, with a pinhead or a snout like a dog's, or two bodies, or a hole in its heart or no arms, or webbed hands and feet?
vi: Or not, a defective child, with a flat head or a snout like a dog's, one head with two bodies, a heart with holes or no arms, or webbed fingers?
tr: Or something else, a Non-Baby with a pinhead or a dog nose or two bodies or a hole in the heart or without arms or with webbed hands or feet?
es: Or something else, a Non-Baby, with a very small head, or a snout like a dog's, or two bodies, or a hole in the heart, or without arms, or with the fingers of the hands and feet joined by a membrane?

en: There's no telling.
vi: There's no way to know.
tr: It is not possible to say.
es: It is impossible to know.

en: They could tell once, with
vi: In the past, there were machines to check, but now they are banned.
tr: Once they could tell, but now it is illegal.
es: It used to be detectable with devices, but now that is prohibited.

en: machines, but that is now outlawed.
vi: In the past, there were machines to check, but now they are banned.
tr: Once they could tell, but now it is illegal.
es: It used to be detectable with devices, but now that is prohibited.

en: What would be the point of knowing, anyway?
vi: And what good would it do to know?
tr: And even if it were known, what would it change?
es: Anyway, what would be the point of knowing?

en: You can't have them taken out; whatever it is must be carried to term.
vi: You can't pull them out; whatever it is, it has to be born.
tr: You can't abort it; whatever it is, it must be carried to term.
es: You can't get rid of it; whatever it is, you have to carry it inside until the term is fulfilled.

en: The chances are one in four, we learned that at the Center.
vi: The probability is one-fourth, we were told at the Center.
tr: One in four chance, we learned this at the Center.
es: At the Center, they taught us that there is a one in four chance.

en: The air got too full,once, of chemicals, rays, radiation, the water swarmed with toxic molecules, all of that takes years to clean up, and meanwhile they creep into your body, camp out in your fatty cells.
vi: The air was filled with chemicals, once, then radiation, the water full of toxins, it would take years to purify, and in the meantime, they had infiltrated your bodies, residing in your fat tissues.
tr: Once upon a time, the air was excessively filled with chemicals, rays, radiation, and the water was teeming with toxic molecules; it would take years to clean all this up. Meanwhile, they penetrate your body and settle into your fatty cells.
es: At one time, the air became saturated with chemicals, rays, and radiation, and the water turned into a boiling pot of toxic molecules; it takes years to clean all of this thoroughly, and in the meantime, the pollution gradually enters your body and lodges in your adipose tissue.

en: Who knows, your very flesh may be polluted, dirty as an oily beach, sure death to shore birds and unborn babies.
vi: Who knows, your flesh might already be contaminated, dirty like an oil-slicked beach, ensuring death for seabirds and your future children.
tr: Who knows, your body could be as dirty as a beach covered in oil, a certain death for shorebirds and unborn babies.
es: Who knows, your very flesh might be contaminated like a dirty beach, a sure death for coastal birds or gestating babies.

en: Maybe a vulture would die of eating you.
vi: Who knows, vultures that eat your corpses might also drop dead.
tr: Maybe a vulture would die from eating you.
es: If a vulture were to eat you, it might die.

en: Maybe you light up in the dark, like an old-fashioned watch.
vi: Who knows, you might glow brightly, like an old-fashioned clock, in the night.
tr: Maybe you would glow in the dark like an old-fashioned clock.
es: Perhaps you would glow in the dark like an old clock.

en: Deathwatch.
vi: The night of the death watch.
tr: Death clock6.
es: Like a deathwatch beetle, which is also the name of a beetle that hides in carrion.

en: That's a kind of beetle, it buries carrion.
vi: There is a type of beetle with that name, specialized in burying decaying corpses.
tr: This is a type of insect, a carrion beetle.
es: Like a deathwatch beetle, which is also the name of a beetle that hides in carrion.

en: I can't think of myself, my body, sometimes, without seeing the skeleton: how I must appear to an electron.
vi: Sometimes I cannot think about myself, my body, without sketching out a skeleton: my image before an electron.
tr: Sometimes, without considering the skeleton, I can't think of myself, my body: I wonder how an electron sees me?
es: Sometimes I can't think of myself and see my skeleton in my body: I wonder what I must look like to an electron.

en: A cradle of life, made of bones; and within, hazards, warped proteins, bad crystals jagged as glass.
vi: The cradle of life, woven from bones; and inside, a hundred perils, malformed proteins, crystals jagged like shards of glass.
tr: A cradle of life made of bone; and inside, dangers, corrupted proteins, glass-like notched defective crystals.
es: A framework of life, made with bones; and inside, dangers, deformed proteins, crystals chipped like glass.

en: Women took medicines, pills, men sprayed trees, cows ate grass, all that souped-up piss flowed into the rivers.
vi: Women taking all kinds of medicine, men spraying chemicals on plants, cows eating grass, sources of detoxifying water flowing into the river one after another.
tr: Women took medicines and pills, men sprayed the trees with chemicals, cows ate the grass, and all these additive-filled excrements flowed into the rivers.
es: Women took medications, pills, men sprayed the trees, cows ate grass, and all these urinations seeped into the rivers.

en: Not to mention the exploding atomic power plants, along the San Andreas fault, nobody's fault, during the earthquakes, and the mutant strain of syphilis no mold could touch.
vi: Not to mention a few nuclear plants along the San Andreas fault line that exploded during several earthquakes, caused by nature, not by anyone, and a mutated strain of syphilis that no antibiotic can cure.
tr: During earthquakes, along with the San Andreas fault -actually, it wasn't anyone's fault- there's no need to mention the nuclear power plants that exploded and the mutated syphilis that fit no mold.
es: Not to mention the explosion of nuclear plants on the San Andreas fault, the fault was no one's, during the earthquakes, nor the type of mutant syphilis that broke all molds.

en: Some did it themselves, had themselves tied shut with catgut or scarredwith chemicals.
vi: Some even do it themselves, using catgut to tie it off or chemicals to cause permanent damage.
tr: Some sterilized themselves, some had their tubes tied or damaged their bodies with chemicals.
es: Some managed on their own, closed their wounds with catgut or healed them with chemicals.

en: How could they, said Aunt Lydia, oh how could they have done such a thing?
vi: How can it be, Aunt Lydia said: how can the heavens commit such a colossal act?
tr: How, Aunt Lydia would say, squeezing her hands, oh my God, how could they do these things?
es: How could they?, said Aunt Lydia, oh, How could they do that?

en: lezebels!
vi: The Jezebels!
tr: Shameless!
es: Jezebels!

en: Scorning God's gifts!
vi: Disdaining the gift from God!
tr: Those who scorn God's blessings!
es: Disdaining the gifts of God!

en: Wringing her hands.
vi: Twisted hands.
tr: Those who scorn God's blessings!
es: And she wrung her hands.

en: It's a risk you're taking, said Aunt Lydia, but you are the shock troops, you will march out in advance, into dangerous territory.
vi: You face great dangers, Aunt Lydia said, but as the vanguard, you will march at the forefront, into perilous territory.
tr: You are taking a risk, said Aunt Lydia, but you are shock troops, you will go ahead into dangerous areas.
es: It's a risk you take, Aunt Lydia said, but you are the shock troops, you will march at the forefront through dangerous territories.

en: The greater the risk the greater the glory.
vi: The greater the danger, the greater the glory.
tr: The greater the risk, the greater the victory.
es: The greater the risk, the greater the glory.

en: She clasped her hands, radiant with our phony courage.
vi: She clasped her hands tightly, beaming brightly at our outward display of courage.
tr: She clasped her hands, cheering up with our feigned courage.
es: She clasped her hands, radiant with our false courage.

en: We looked down at the tops of our desks.
vi: We lowered our faces to look at the table.
tr: We were looking down at our tables with our heads bowed.
es: We stared at the desk.

en: To go through all that and give birth to a shredder: it wasn't a fine thought.
vi: After going through everything, ending up as a cutting machine: not a pretty prospect.
tr: Going through all this and ending up giving birth to something rotten: This was not a pleasant thought.
es: Going through all that and giving birth to a rag: it was not a pleasant thought.

en: We didn't know exactly what would happen to the babies that didn't get passed, that were declared Unbabies.
vi: We did not know exactly the fate of the babies who did not make it, those declared as Unbabies.
tr: We didn't know exactly what happened to the babies who didn't pass the test, those designated as Non-Babies.
es: We didn't know exactly what happened to the babies who didn't pass the test and were declared Not Babies.

en: But we knew they were put somewhere, quickly, away.
vi: But we knew they would be discarded, somewhere, completely.
tr: But we knew they were sent somewhere, quickly, far away.
es: But we knew they were taken somewhere and quickly gotten rid of.

en: There was no one cause, says Aunt Lydia.
vi: There isn't just a single cause, Aunt Lydia said.
tr: There wasn't a single reason, says Aunt Lydia.
es: There was no reason, says Aunt Lydia.

en: She stands at the front of the room, in her khaki dress, a pointer in her hand.
vi: She stood in front of the class, in her khaki outfit, holding a pointer.
tr: She stands at the front of the room, in her khaki dress, holding a pointer stick.
es: She is standing in front of the class, with her khaki dress and a pointer in her hand.

en: Pulled down in front of the blackboard, where once there would have been a map, is a graph, showing the birthrate per thousand, for years and years: a slippery slope, down past the zero line of replacement, and down and down.
vi: In front of the blackboard, where a map used to be, there was a drop-down chart showing birth rates, per thousand, over many years: a steeply declining line, plunging below the horizontal axis which represents the population replacement level, lower and lower.
tr: On the blackboard, where there used to be a map, there is now a graph: showing the birth rate per thousand over the years, a sharp decline, below the zero line, down, down, and down.
es: On the blackboard, where there must have once been a map, they have displayed a chart showing the birth rate expressed in thousands, over several years: a marked decline that drops below the zero line and continues descending.

en: Of course, some women believed there would be no future, they thought the world would explode.
vi: Of course, among women, there are those who believe there is no future anymore; they think the world will explode.
tr: Of course, some women believed that there would be no future, that the world would explode and be destroyed.
es: Of course, some women believed there would be no future; they thought the world would explode.

en: That was the excuse they used, says Aunt Lydia.
vi: They use that as an excuse, Aunt Lydia said.
tr: This was the excuse they put forward, says Aunt Lydia.
es: That's the excuse they gave, says Aunt Lydia.

en: They said there was no sense in breeding.
vi: They say that giving birth is meaningless.
tr: There is no point in giving birth, they said.
es: They said there was no point in having offspring.

en: Aunt Lydia's nostrils narrow: such wickedness.
vi: Aunt's nostrils flared: so cruel.
tr: Aunt Lydia's nostrils narrow: what immorality.
es: Aunt Lydia's nostrils flared: such wickedness.

en: They were lazy women, she says.
vi: Those people are lazy, she said.
tr: They were lazy women, she says.
es: They were lazy, he said.

en: They were sluts.
vi: Wretched whores.
tr: They were sluts.
es: Filthy pigs.

en: On the top of my desk there are initials, carved into the wood, and dates.
vi: On the table where I sit, there are initials carved into the wood, accompanied by dates.
tr: Initials and dates are carved on the upper part of my desk.
es: On the surface of my desk, there are some initials and dates engraved.

en: The initials are sometimes in two sets, joined by the word loves.
vi: Sometimes they come in pairs, embraced by the word "love."
tr: Sometimes these are combined in pairs with the word "loves."
es: The initials sometimes come in pairs, connected by the word "loves."

en: J. H. loves B. P. 1954.
vi: J. H. loves B. P. 1954.
tr: J. H., B. loves P. 1954.
es: J. H. loves B. P., 1954; O. R. loves L. T. They remind me of the inscriptions I used to see engraved on the stone walls of caves, or drawn with a mixture of soot and animal fat.

en: O. R. loves L. T. These seem to me like the inscriptions I used to read about, carved on the stone walls of caves, or drawn with a mixture of soot and animal fat.
vi: O. R. loves L. T. I look at them like engravings on cave walls, which I read about in books long ago, or drawings made with soot mixed with animal fat.
tr: O. R., L. loves T. I liken them to the inscriptions I have read about, carved into the stone walls of caves or drawn with a mixture of soot and animal fat.
es: J. H. loves B. P., 1954; O. R. loves L. T. They remind me of the inscriptions I used to see engraved on the stone walls of caves, or drawn with a mixture of soot and animal fat.

en: They seem to me incredibly ancient.
vi: They seem to belong to ancient times.
tr: They seem incredibly old to me.
es: They seem incredibly ancient to me.

en: The desk top is of blond wood; it slants down, and there is an armrest on the right side, to lean on when you were writing, on paper, with a pen.
vi: The tabletop is made of light-colored wood, slightly sloped, with a spot on the right to rest your arm, which you can lean on when writing, on paper, with a pen.
tr: The upper part of the desk is yellow wood; it slopes downward and has an armrest on the right side that you use when writing on paper with a pen.
es: The surface of the desk is made of light wood, slanted, and has an arm on the right side where one can rest to write with paper and pen.

en: Inside the desk you could keep things: books, notebooks.
vi: The desk drawer can store all sorts of things: books, notebooks.
tr: You could put things inside the desk: books, notebooks.
es: Inside the desk, you can store things: books and notebooks.

en: These habits of former times appear to me now lavish, decadent almost; immoral, like the orgies of barbarian regimes.
vi: Those old habits now seem so luxurious to me, almost decadent; as corrupt as wild feasts in a barbaric society.
tr: These habits of the past now seem wasteful to me, almost decadent: like immoral, barbaric orgies.
es: These customs from other times now seem luxurious to me, almost decadent; immoral, like the orgies of barbarian regimes.

en: M. loves G. 1972.
vi: M. loves G. 1972.
tr: M.loves G. 1972.
es: M. loves G., 1972.

en: This carving, done with a pencil dug many-times into the worn varnish ol the desk, has the pathos of all vanished civilizations.
vi: This engraving, repeatedly traced over with pencil on the varnish that has peeled off, contains the sorrow of all fallen civilizations.
tr: This carving, made by repeatedly piercing the worn varnish of the desk with a pen, possesses the melancholic essence of all lost civilizations.
es: This engraving, made by repeatedly pressing a pencil into the worn varnish of the desk, has the pathos of all extinct civilizations.

en: It's like a handprint on stone.
vi: Just like a handprint on stone.
tr: Like a handprint on stone.
es: It's like engraving something by hand on a stone.

en: Whoever made that was once alive.
vi: Its owner, whoever they were, once lived.
tr: Whoever did this once lived.
es: Whoever did it was once alive.

en: There are no dates after the mid-eighties.
vi: There was no day in the latter half of the 80s.
tr: There is no date after the mid-eighties.
es: There are no dates later than the 1980s.

en: Thin must have been one of the schools that was closed down then, for lack of children.
vi: This was probably among the schools that were closed back then, due to a lack of students.
tr: This must be one of the schools that was closed because there were no children.
es: This must have been one of the schools that closed permanently due to a lack of children.

en: They made mistakes, says Aunt Lydia.
vi: They made many mistakes, Aunt Lydia said.
tr: She had her faults, says Aunt Lydia.
es: They made mistakes, says Aunt Lydia.

en: We don't Intend lo repeat them.
vi: We will not repeat them.
tr: We do not intend to repeat them.
es: We don't want to repeat them.

en: Her voice is pious, condescending, the voice of those whose duty it is to tell us unpleasant things lor our owngood.
vi: Her voice was devout, yet condescending, in the manner of someone who feels obligated to tell us unpleasant truths, only for our own good.
tr: Her voice is pious and humble, the voice of someone whose duty is to say unpleasant things for our own good.
es: Her voice is pious, condescending; it is the voice of a person whose function is to tell us unpleasant things for our own good.

en: I
vi: I wanted to strangle her.
tr: I would like to strangle her.
es: I would like to strangle her.

en: would like to strangle her.
vi: I wanted to strangle her.
tr: I would like to strangle her.
es: I would like to strangle her.

en: I shove this thought away almost as soon
vi: I pushed the thought away as soon as it came.
tr: As soon as the thought comes to mind, I dismiss it.
es: I push the idea out of my mind as soon as it occurs to me.

en: as I think it.
vi: I pushed the thought away as soon as it came.
tr: As soon as the thought comes to mind, I dismiss it.
es: I push the idea out of my mind as soon as it occurs to me.

en: A thing is valued, she says, only if it is rare and hard to get.
vi: Objects have value, auntie said, only when they are rare and hard to find.
tr: Something, he says, is only valuable if it is scarce and hard to obtain.
es: Things are valued, he says, only when they are rare and difficult to obtain.

en: We want you to be valued, girls.
vi: We want our girls to have value.
tr: We want you to be valuable, girls.
es: We want to be appreciated girls.

en: She is rich in pauses, which she savors in her mouth.
vi: Auntie is very rich in silences, savored thoroughly in her mouth.
tr: Aunt Lydia is generous in giving pauses that she savors thoroughly.
es: She is fertile in making pauses and savors them slowly.

en: Think of yourselves as pearls.
vi: Consider yourself a pearl.
tr: Think of yourselves as pearls.
es: Imagine that you are pearls.

en: We, sitting in our rows, eyes down, we make her salivate morally.
vi: Here we are, sitting in a row, eyes downcast, we make auntie drool with morality.
tr: We sit in our rows, heads bowed, making our mouths water with moral appetite.
es: We, sitting in a row, with our gaze lowered, make her salivate morally.

en: We are hers to define, we must suffer her adjectives.
vi: We are subject to auntie's definitions, we must endure her adjectives.
tr: We belong to her to be defined, we must endure her characterizations.
es: We are hers and she can define us, we must endure her adjectives.

en: I think about pearls.
vi: I think about pearls.
tr: I am thinking about pearls.
es: I think about the pearls.

en: Pearls are congealed oyster spit.
vi: Pearls are the condensed saliva of oysters.
tr: Pearls are clotted oyster saliva.
es: Pearls are frozen oyster spit.

en: This is whin I
vi: Pearls are the condensed saliva of oysters.
tr: I will tell this to Moira, later; if I can.
es: Pearls are frozen oyster spit.

en: will tell Moira, later; if I can.
vi: I will tell this to Moira later, if possible.
tr: I will tell this to Moira, later; if I can.
es: Later I will tell Moira; if I can.

en: All of us here will lick you into shape, says Aunt Lydia, with satisfied good cheer.
vi: We are here to lick the milk off you girls, Aunt Lydia said, cheerful and satisfied.
tr: All of us here will shape you, says Aunt Lydia, with a satisfactory pride.
es: We are all going to get you up to speed, says Aunt Lydia, with joy and satisfaction.

en: The van stops, the back doors are opened, the Guardian herds us out.
vi: The vehicle stopped, the rear door opened, and the Guards herded us out.
tr: The minibus stops, the rear doors open, and the Guardian herds us outside.
es: The van stops, the rear doors open, and the Guardian makes us get out as if we were a herd.

en: At the front door stands another Guardian, with one of those snubhy machine guns slung over his shoulder.
vi: Right at the main entrance, another Guard stood, a machine gun with a distinctive short barrel slung over his shoulder.
tr: Another Guardian, with one of those disdainful machine guns slung over his shoulder, stands at the front door.
es: Next to the front door there is another Guardian, with one of those recoilless machine guns slung over his shoulder.

en: We file towards the front door, in the drizzle, the Guardians saluting.
vi: We lined up through the main entrance, under the light drizzle, as the Guards bowed.
tr: We line up towards the front door as it drizzles, the Guardians salute.
es: We march in a line towards the front door, under the drizzle, and the Guardians salute us.

en: The big Emerge vim, the one with the machines and the mobile doctors, is parked farther along the circular drive.
vi: The large Emergency vehicle, carrying equipment and mobile doctors, was parked further away at the roundabout.
tr: The Great Birthing Carriage, where the machines and car doctors are, is parked further ahead in the courtyard.
es: The huge emergency van, the one that transports the equipment and the paramedics, is parked a little further away, in the driveway.

en: I see one of the doctors looking out the window of the van.
vi: There was a doctor by the vehicle door looking out.
tr: I see one of the doctors looking out from the minibus window.
es: I see that one of the paramedics is looking out the van window.

en: I wonder what they do in there, waiting.
vi: I wondered what they were doing in there, passing the time.
tr: Inside, while waiting, I wonder what they are doing.
es: I wonder what he is doing in there, waiting.

en: I'lay cards, most likely, or read; some masculine pursuit.
vi: Playing cards, perhaps, or reading books; typical male pastimes.
tr: They are probably playing cards, some kind of masculine pastime.
es: Most likely he is playing cards, or reading; or engaged in some male pastime.

en: Most of the time they aren't needed at all; they're only allowed in if it can't be helped.
vi: Generally, they were seldom needed; they were only allowed in if there was no other option.
tr: Most of the time, they are not needed at all; they are only allowed inside if there is nothing else left to do.
es: Most of the time they are not needed at all; they are only allowed in when their presence is unavoidable.

en: It used to be different, they used to be in charge.
vi: Generally, they were seldom needed; they were only allowed in if there was no other option.
tr: In the past, the situation was different, the responsibility was theirs.
es: Before it was different, they took care of it.

en: A shame it was, said Aunt Lydia.
vi: In the old days, it was very different; they were the ones on the front lines, how shameful it was, Aunt Lydia said.
tr: What a great shame it was, Aunt Lydia would say.
es: It was a shame, Aunt Lydia said.

en: Shameful.
vi: Disgraceful.
tr: It was shameful.
es: Shameful.

en: What she'd just showed us was a film, made in an olden-days hospital: a pregnant woman, wired up to a machine, electrodes coming out of her every which way so that she looked like a broken robot, an intravenous drip feeding into her arm.
vi: She had just shown a film, shot in an old-time hospital: a pregnant woman, connected to some machine, electrodes bristling all over her body like a dead robot, an intravenous tube inserted into the vein in her arm.
tr: The film she had just shown us was shot in a hospital from the old days: a pregnant woman connected to a machine with wires, with so many electrodes coming out of her that she looked like a broken robot, and an IV attached to her arm.
es: The only thing he showed us was a movie shot in an old hospital: a pregnant woman, connected to a device, with electrodes coming out from everywhere, giving her the appearance of a broken robot, and a probe in her arm feeding her intravenously.

en: Some man with a searchlight looking up between her legs, where she's been shaved, a mere beardless girl, a trayful of bright sterilized knives, everyone with masks on.
vi: Someone holding a spotlight peered between her legs, which had been shaved clean, an ordinary smooth young girl, a tray glistening with sterilized knives, everyone wearing masks.
tr: Between her shaved legs, a man looking with a light, a hairless girl alone, a tray full of shiny sterilized knives, everyone masked.
es: A man with a reflector looks between her legs — where they have shaved her, leaving her really like a beardless child—; a tray with bright sterilized scalpels can be seen; everyone has their face covered by a mask.

en: A cooperative patient.
vi: The patient was very cooperative.
tr: A common patient.
es: A cooperative patient.

en: Once they drugged women, induced labor, cut them open, sewed them up.
vi: In the old days, they used to anesthetize women, induce contractions, cut them open, and sew them back up.
tr: Once, they used to drug women, increase their labor pains, cut and sew them up.
es: Once they have drugged her and induced labor, they make an incision and sew her up.

en: No more.
vi: It was over.
tr: Such things no longer exist.
es: That's all.

en: No anesthetics, even.
vi: Even the local anesthetic, over.
tr: There isn't even anesthesia.
es: They don't even use anesthesia.

en: Aunt Elizabeth said it was better for the baby, but also: / will greatly multiply thy sorrow and thy conception; in sorrow thou shalt bring forth children.
vi: Aunt Elizabeth said it was better for the baby, but not only that: I will greatly multiply your pain in childbirth; in pain, you will give birth to children.
tr: Aunt Elizabeth would say it was better for the baby, but also: I will greatly multiply your pain and your conception; in pain, you will give birth to children.
es: Aunt Elizabeth said it was better for the baby, and that: I will greatly increase your pain in childbirth: you will give birth in pain.

en: At lunch we got that, brown bread
vi: A necessary item in the lunch menu, along with brown bread and lettuce sandwiches.
tr: They would give us this along with brown bread and salad sandwiches at lunch.
es: They gave it to us during lunch, in a sandwich of brown bread and lettuce.

en: and lettuce sandwiches.
vi: A necessary item in the lunch menu, along with brown bread and lettuce sandwiches.
tr: They would give us this along with brown bread and salad sandwiches at lunch.
es: They gave it to us during lunch, in a sandwich of brown bread and lettuce.

en: As I'm going up the steps, wide steps with a stone urn on either sideOfwarren's Commander must be higher status than oursI hear another siren.
vi: While climbing the stairs, which were very wide, with two large stone pedestals on either side - the Commander of Ofwarren must have a higher status than our household - I heard another whistle.
tr: As I ascend the wide steps, each flanked by a stone vase - the Commander of Warren's must be of a higher status than ours - I hear another siren.
es: As I climb the staircase, a wide staircase with a stone vase on each side —the Commander of Dewarren must have a higher social position than ours—, I hear another siren.

en: It's the blue Birthmobile, for Wives.
vi: The blue Birthmobile, carrying the Wives.
tr: The blue Birthmobile for the Wives.
es: It's the blue Birthmobile, the one for the Wives.

en: That will be Serena Joy, arriving in state.
vi: That means Serena Joy, arriving with grandeur.
tr: This must be Serena Joy arriving in splendor.
es: This must be Serena Joy, making her triumphant entrance.

en: No benches for them, they get real seats, upholstery.
vi: Not sitting on benches, they have proper seats, upholstered.
tr: They have real, upholstered seats instead of benches.
es: They don't have to sit on benches, but on real, upholstered seats.

en: They face front and are not curtained off.
vi: Looking straight ahead, not obstructed by any screens.
tr: They face forward and the curtains are not drawn.
es: They can look forward and don't have the curtains closed.

en: They know where they're going.
vi: They know exactly where they are going.
tr: They know where they are going.
es: They know where they are going.

en: Probably Serena
vi: Surely Serena
tr: It is possible that Serena Joy had come here, to this house, before, for tea.
es: Serena

en: Joy has been here before, to this house, for tea.
vi: Joy used to come here for tea, in this very house.
tr: It is possible that Serena Joy had come here, to this house, before, for tea.
es: Joy has probably been in this house before, having tea.

en: Probably Ofwarren, formerly that whiny bitch Janine, was paraded out in front of her, her and the other Wives, so they could see her belly, feel it perhaps, and congratulate theWife.
vi: Surely Ofwarren, formerly the coquettish Janine, was paraded before her, her and the other Wives, so they could look at her belly, maybe even touch it, and congratulate the Wife of the house.
tr: It is possible that Warren's wife, the former whining bitch Janine, was paraded in front of him and the other Wives, so they could see her belly, maybe even touch it, and congratulate his Wife.
es: Maybe Dewarren, formerly the crying little whore Janine, paraded in front of her and the other Wives so they could see her belly, maybe touch it, and congratulate the Wife.

en: A strong girl, good muscles.
vi: She's a healthy girl, quite muscular.
tr: A strong girl, good muscles.
es: A strong girl, with good muscles.

en: No Agent Orange in her family, we checked the records, you can never be too careful.
vi: The family doesn't carry Agent Orange, checked the records, better safe than sorry.
tr: No Orange Agent in her family, we checked her records, one can never be too careful.
es: No Agent Orange in her family, we checked the records, no precaution is excessive.

en: And perhaps one of the kinder ones: Would you like a cookie, dear?
vi: And someone kind might say: Would you like a cookie?
tr: And perhaps one of the more polite ones: Would you like a biscuit, dear?
es: And maybe some kind phrase: Would you like a cookie, dear?

en: Oh no, you'll spoil her, too much sugar is bad for them.
vi: Oh, come on, you spoil her too much, it's not good for the girls to have too much sugar.
tr: Ooh, yoo, you will make them sick, too much sugar is not good for them.
es: Oh, no, it would harm them, it's not good for them to eat too much sugar.

en: Surely one won't hurt, just this once, Mildred.
vi: One won't hurt, just this time, Mildred.
tr: Probably nothing will happen from just one, just this once, Mildred.
es: One won't hurt you, just one, Mildred.

en: And sucky Janine:
vi: And Janine whined: Just one, ma'am, please, okay????
tr: And the shameless Janine: Ooh, yes, can I have it, Sir, please?
es: And the brown-noser Janine: Oh, yes, can I have one, ma'am?

en: Oh yes, can I, ma'am, please?
vi: And Janine whined: Just one, ma'am, please, okay????
tr: And the shameless Janine: Ooh, yes, can I have it, Sir, please?
es: Please.

en: Such a, so well behaved, not surly like some of them, do their job and that's that.
vi: Indeed, so well-behaved and skillful, not sullen like many others, once the work is done, that's it.
tr: Oh, and so polite, not sullen like the others, they just do their jobs, that's all.
es: What an exemplary one, so well-behaved, not sullen like some others, she does her job and that's all.

en: More like a daughter to you, as you might say.
vi: Just like your daughter, isn't it? You could say that.
tr: More like your daughter, one could say.
es: Like a daughter to you, as you would say.

en: One of the family.
vi: A member of the family.
tr: Like a member of the family.
es: One of the family.

en: Comfortable matronly chuckles.
vi: Lightly smiling with the confidence of a lady of the house.
tr: Comforting maternal giggles.
es: A matron's stifled giggle.

en: That's all dear, you can go back to your room.
vi: It's done, dear, go back to your room.
tr: That's all, dear, you can go back to your room.
es: That's all, dear, you can go back to your room.

en: And after she's gone: Little whores, all of them, but still, you can't be choosy.
vi: And when she was out: Little whores, all of them, but who can be too picky.
tr: And after he left: Little whores, all of them, but what can you do, you can't choose.
es: And when she has gone: They are all little whores, but at least you can't complain.

en: You take what they hand out, right, girls?
vi: Whatever they give, you just reach out and take it, right, girls?
tr: You take whatever they give you, right, girls!
es: You take what they give you, right, girls?

en: That from the Commander's Wife, mine.
vi: From the mouth of the Lady Commander, mine.
tr: This one is from the Commander's Wife.
es: That's what the Commander's Wife would say.

en: Oh, but you've been so lucky.
vi: Oh, but you were really lucky.
tr: Oh, but you turned out to be very lucky.
es: Oh, but you have been very fortunate.

en: Some of them, why, they aren't even clean.
vi: There are many kids, oh my, who aren't even clean.
tr: Some of them, dear, aren't even clean.
es: Wow, some of them aren't even clean.

en: And won't give you a smile, mope in their rooms, don't wash their hair, the smell.
vi: And they never smile, dragging themselves around the room all day, not washing their hair, oh the smell.
tr: And they don't even show you a smile, they shut themselves in their rooms, don't wash their hair, oh those smells, don't they?
es: And they would never smile at you, they lock themselves in their room, they don't wash their hair, and what a smell.

en: I have to get the Marthas to do it, almost have to hold her down in the bathtub, you practically have to bribe her to get her to take a bath even, you have to threaten her.
vi: I had to make the Marthas barge in, practically dunk them in the tub, had to bribe them to take a bath, had to scare them out of their wits.
tr: I have to make the Marthas do it, they almost have to tie her to the tub, you have to outright bribe her, threaten her to take a bath.
es: I have to send the Marthas to clean, I almost have to drag her to the bathtub, I practically have to bribe her just to get her to take a bath, I have to threaten her.

en: I had to take stern measures with mine, and now she doesn't eat her dinner properly; and as for the other thing, not a nibble, and we've
vi: I had to resort to strong measures with my child, and now he doesn't bother to have a proper dinner anymore; as for that other matter, there's not a trace of it, even though it used to be so frequent at my house.
tr: I had to take strict measures for mine, now he doesn't eat dinner properly, and when it comes to the other thing, there's not even a tiny result, even though we do it so regularly.
es: I had to take severe measures with mine, and now she doesn't eat as she should; and as for the other thing, not a bit, even though we've been very regular.

en: been so regular.
vi: But as for this little one, what an honor for you.
tr: I had to take strict measures for mine, now he doesn't eat dinner properly, and when it comes to the other thing, there's not even a tiny result, even though we do it so regularly.
es: I had to take severe measures with mine, and now she doesn't eat as she should; and as for the other thing, not a bit, even though we've been very regular.

en: But yours, she's a credit to yon.
vi: But as for this little one, what an honor for you.
tr: But yours is your pride and joy.
es: But yours is a complete guarantee for you.

en: And any day now, oh, you must be so excited, she's big as ;i house, I bet you can hardly wait.
vi: Just a day or two left, oh my, you must be so excited, the girl is as big as a house now, I bet you're extremely anxious.
tr: The birth can happen at any moment now, oh you must be so excited, look how swollen you are, I bet waiting is hard for you.
es: And any of these days, oh, you must be so nervous, she's so fat, aren't you impatient?

en: More tea?
vi: Refill?

es: A little more tea?, discreetly changing the subject.

en: Modestly changing the subject.
vi: She politely changed the subject.

es: A little more tea?, discreetly changing the subject.

en: I know the sort of thing that goes on.
vi: I know how the events will unfold.
tr: I know what is happening there.
es: I already know what comes next.

vi: And Janine, in the room upstairs, what is she doing?
tr: Meanwhile, what might Janine be doing in her room upstairs?
es: And what is Janine doing in her room?

en: Sits with the taste of sugar still in her mouth, licking her lips.
vi: Sitting with the taste of sugar still in her mouth, licking her lips.
tr: She might be sitting, licking her lips, with the taste of candy still in her mouth.
es: She must be sitting, with the taste of sugar still in her mouth, licking her lips.

en: Stares out the window.
vi: Staring aimlessly out the door.
tr: She might be looking out the window.
es: Looking out the window.

en: Breathes in and out.
vi: Breathing in and out.
tr: She might be breathing in and out.
es: Inhaling and exhaling.
