CHAPTER 20

en: The central staircase is wider than ours, with a curved banister on cither side.
vi: The main staircase was wider than our house, with two curved handrails on either side.
tr: The main staircase with its curved railings on both sides is wider than ours.
es: The central staircase is wider than ours, and it has a curved railing on each side.

en: From above I can hear the chanting of the women who are already there.
vi: From above, the murmuring prayers of the women who arrived earlier could be heard.
tr: I can hear the songs of the women upstairs.
es: From above, I hear the sing-song of the women who have already arrived.

en: We go up the stairs, single file, being careful not to step on the trailing hems of each other's dresses.
vi: We ascended the staircase, in single file, careful not to step on the trailing hems of the robes in front of us.
tr: In a single file, we ascend the stairs, being careful not to step on each other's trailing skirts.
es: We go up the stairs in single file, very carefully, so as not to step on the hem of the dress of the one in front.

en: To the left, the double doors to the dining room are folded back, and inside I can see the long table, covered with a white cloth and spread with a buffet: ham, cheese, orangesthey have oranges!
vi: To the left, the dining room door was wide open, revealing a long table inside, covered with a white cloth, set for a buffet: bacon with cheese, oranges - this house had oranges!
tr: On the left, the double doors of the dining room are open, I can see the long table inside, covered with a white cloth and an open buffet: ham, cheese, oranges -they have oranges!- and freshly baked breads and pastries.
es: To the left, you can see the double doors of the dining room —which are now folded back—, and inside, the long table covered with a white tablecloth and full of cold dishes: ham, cheese, oranges —they have oranges!—, freshly baked rolls.

en: and fresh-baked breads and cakes.
vi: - and freshly baked bread with pastries.
tr: On the left, the double doors of the dining room are open, I can see the long table inside, covered with a white cloth and an open buffet: ham, cheese, oranges -they have oranges!- and freshly baked breads and pastries.
es: As for us, later they will serve us a tray with milk and sandwiches.

en: As for us, we'll get milk and sandwiches, on a tray, later.
vi: For us, there would be milk and sandwiches, brought on trays, at the end of the hour.
tr: As for us, we will be given a tray with milk and sandwiches later.
es: As for us, later they will serve us a tray with milk and sandwiches.

en: But they have a coffee urn, and bottles of wine, for why shouldn't the Wives get a little drunk on such a triumphant day?
vi: But they had a coffee urn, and a few bottles of wine too; on such a triumphant day, why wouldn't the Ladies indulge a little?
tr: But they have a coffee machine and wine bottles, why shouldn’t the Wives get a little drunk on such a magnificent day?
es: But they have a coffee maker and bottles of wine because, can't the Wives get a little drunk on such a joyous day?

en: First they'll wait for the results, then they'll pig out.
vi: They would wait for the results first, then feast afterwards.
tr: First, they will wait for the result, then they will feast.
es: First, they will wait for the results and then they will gorge themselves like pigs.

en: They're gathered in the sitting room on the other side of the stairway now, cheering on this Commander's Wife, the Wife of Warren.
vi: Right now, they were all gathered in the lounge on the other side of the staircase, encouraging the Lady of the house, Lady Warren.
tr: Now they have gathered in the sitting room on the other side to cheer up this Commander’s Wife, Warren’s Wife.
es: Now they are gathered in the living room, on the other side of the staircase, cheering on the Wife of this Commander, Warren's wife.

en: A small thin woman, she lies on the floor, in a white cotton nightgown, her graying hair spreading like mildew over the rug; they massage her tiny belly, just as if she's really about to give birth herself.
vi: Small and frail, she lay on the floor, in a white cotton nightgown, her graying hair spread out like a frosty mold on the carpet; they massaged her emaciated belly, as if she were about to give birth herself.
tr: A small, thin woman, in her white cotton nightgown, lies on the floor, her hair, starting to gray, spreading out on the carpet like mold; she is being massaged at the waist, as if she were the one actually giving birth.
es: She is a petite woman; she is lying on the floor, dressed in a white cotton nightgown, and her gray hair spread out on the carpet like a damp stain; they are massaging her belly, as if she were really about to give birth.

en: The Commander, of course, is nowhere in sight.
vi: The commander, of course, had disappeared without a trace.
tr: The commander, of course, is nowhere to be seen.
es: The Commander, of course, is not in sight.

en: He's gone wherever men go on such occasions, some hideout.
vi: He had gone to a place reserved for men on such occasions, some secluded spot.
tr: He must have gone to the place where men go in such situations, a kind of escape place.
es: He has gone where men go on these occasions, to some hiding place.

en: Probably he's figuring out when his promotion is likely to be announced, if all goes well.
vi: He was probably guessing when his promotion would be announced, assuming everything went smoothly.
tr: If everything goes well, he is probably calculating when his promotion will likely be announced.
es: He is probably calculating the moment when his presentation will be announced, if all goes well.

en: He's sure to get one, now.
vi: Now, that matter was as certain as nails.
tr: He will definitely get a promotion now.
es: Now he is sure he has succeeded.

en: Ofwarren is in the master bedroom, a good name for it; where this
vi: Ofwarren is in the Commander's bedroom, a very fitting name: the place where the Commander and his Wife lay down every night.
tr: Warren's wife is in the master bedroom, a good name for the room; the place where the Commander and his Wife sleep at night.
es: Dewarren is in the main room, a good way to define it: that is where the Commander and his Wife lie down.

en: Commander and his Wife nightly bed down.
vi: Ofwarren is in the Commander's bedroom, a very fitting name: the place where the Commander and his Wife lay down every night.
tr: Warren's wife is in the master bedroom, a good name for the room; the place where the Commander and his Wife sleep at night.
es: Dewarren is in the main room, a good way to define it: that is where the Commander and his Wife lie down.

en: She's sitting on their
vi: She is sitting on the Commander's bed, leaning against a pile of pillows: Janine, swollen but diminished, her old name has been cut off.
tr: She is sitting on that massive bed, propped up with pillows: Janine, swollen but diminished, her former name clipped and discarded.
es: She is sitting on the huge bed, propped up with cushions: it is Janine, swollen but diminished, stripped of her original name.

en: king-size bed, propped with pillows: Janine, inflated but reduced, shorn of her former name.
vi: She is sitting on the Commander's bed, leaning against a pile of pillows: Janine, swollen but diminished, her old name has been cut off.
tr: She is sitting on that massive bed, propped up with pillows: Janine, swollen but diminished, her former name clipped and discarded.
es: She is sitting on the huge bed, propped up with cushions: it is Janine, swollen but diminished, stripped of her original name.

en: She's wearing a white cotton shift, which is hiked up over her thighs; her long broom-colored hair is pulled back and tied behind her head, to keep it out of the way.
vi: She is wearing a short white cotton dress, rolled up above her thighs; her long broom-colored hair is tied back, out of the way.
tr: She is wearing a white cotton garment gathered around her hips, her long marigold-colored hair brushed back and tied in a bun to keep it out of the way.
es: She is wearing a straight white cotton dress, lifted above her thighs; her long brown hair is combed back and tied at the nape, so it doesn't get in the way.

en: Her eyes are squeezed closed, and this way I can almost like her.
vi: Her eyes are tightly shut, like this I could almost like her.
tr: Her eyes are tightly closed, in this state I could almost love her.
es: Her eyes are squeezed shut; seeing her like this, she almost seems pleasant to me.

en: After all, she's one of us; what did she ever want but to lead her life as agreeably as possible?
vi: After all, she belongs to our group; what else does she want but to live as comfortably as possible?
tr: After all, she is one of us; what has she ever wanted other than to live her life as best as she can?
es: After all, she is one of us, what does she intend, if not to live as pleasantly as possible?

en: What else did any of us want?
vi: Do any of us want anything else?
tr: What else would any of us want?
es: What else does any of us want?

en: It's the possiblethat's the catch.
vi: The trouble is in the timing.
tr: What we seek to grasp is the possible.
es: The drawback lies in what is possible.

en: She's not doing badly, under the circumstances.
vi: She is managing not badly, given her circumstances.
tr: She is managing well under these circumstances, indeed.
es: Considering the circumstances, she is not doing badly.

en: Two women I don't know stand on either side of her, gripping her hands, or she theirs.
vi: Two strange women stood on either side of her, squeezing her hands, or she squeezed theirs.
tr: Two women I don't know are standing on either side of Janine, holding her hand, or Janine is holding theirs.
es: She is flanked by two women I don't know who are holding her hands, or perhaps it is she who is holding the women's hands.

en: A third lifts the nightgown, pours baby oil onto her mound of stomach, rubs downward.
vi: The third woman lifted her shirt, poured baby oil onto her enormous belly, and gradually rubbed it downwards.
tr: A third one is lifting her nightgown, pouring baby oil on the mound of her belly, and rubbing it downward.
es: A third woman lifts her nightgown, applies baby oil to the mound formed by her belly, and rubs it in a downward motion.

en: At her feet stands Aunt Elizabeth, in her khaki dress with the military breast pockets; she was the one who taught Gyn Ed.
vi: By her feet stood Aunt Elizabeth, still in her military-pocketed khaki dress; at the main center, she taught Gynecological Education.
tr: Aunt Elizabeth is standing at the foot of the bed, in her military khaki outfit with breast pockets; she was the one who taught the Gyn Ed7 class.
es: At her feet is Aunt Elizabeth, dressed in the khaki outfit with chest pockets. She was one of those who taught Gynecological Education classes.

en: All I can see of her is the side of her head, her profile, but I know it's her, that jutting nose and handsome chin, severe.
vi: I could only see half of her face, but I knew it was her, with her sharp nose and very defined, strong chin.
tr: All I can see is the side of her head, her profile, but I know it's her; that prominent nose and smooth, firm chin.
es: I can only see one side of her head, her profile, but I know it's her because of her unmistakable prominent nose and her considerable and severe chin.

en: At her side stands the Birthing Stool, with its double seat, the back one raised like a throne behind the other.
vi: Next to her was the Birthing Stool, a double chair with a high backrest that rose up like a throne behind the seat.
tr: Next to her are two Birthing Chairs with two seats, the rear seat elevated like a throne.
es: Next to it, you can see the birthing chair with its double seat, one of them raised like a throne behind the other.

en: They won't put Janine on it before it's time.
vi: Janine had not been placed on it yet, as it was not time.
tr: They won't seat Janine there until it's time.
es: They will not place Janine in the chair until the time comes.

en: The blankets stand ready, the small tub for bathing, the bowl of ice for Janine to suck.
vi: Blankets were ready, a small basin for bathing, and a bowl of ice chips for Janine to suck on.
tr: The sheets, the small tub for the bath, the bowl with the ice Janine will suck on are ready.
es: The sheets are ready, as well as the small bathtub and the bowl with ice cubes for Janine to suck on.

en: The rest of the women sit cross-legged on the rug; there's a crowd of them, everyone in this district is supposed to be here.
vi: The remaining people sat cross-legged on the carpet; quite a large crowd, the entire district needed to be present.
tr: The other women are sitting cross-legged on the carpet; there are many women, everyone in this area must be here.
es: The other women are sitting on the carpet with their legs crossed; they form a crowd, it is supposed that all the women of the district are here.

en: There must be twenty-five, thirty.
vi: There must have been twenty-five, thirty people.
tr: There must be twenty-five, thirty people.
es: There must be twenty-five or thirty.

en: Not every Commander has a Handmaid: some of their Wives have children.
vi: Not every Commander had a Handmaid: some Wives could bear children themselves.
tr: Not every Commander has a Handmaid. Some of the Wives have children.
es: Not all Commanders have a Handmaid: the Wives of some of them have children.

en: From each, says the slogan, according to her ability; to each according to his needs.
vi: She did according to her ability, as per the slogan, he enjoyed according to his needs.
tr: From each according to her ability, to each according to his need, says the slogan.
es: From each according to his abilities; to each according to his needs, says the phrase.

en: We recited that three times, after dessert.
vi: We read that sentence three times, after dessert.
tr: We used to recite this three times after dessert, it was from the Bible or so they said.
es: We recited it three times a day, after dessert.

en: It was from the Bible, or so they said.
vi: They said it was quoted from the Bible.
tr: We used to recite this three times after dessert, it was from the Bible or so they said.
es: It was a phrase from the Bible, or so they said.

en: St. Paul again, in Acts.
vi: Again, Saint Paul, the Acts of the Apostles.
tr: Saint Paul again.
es: Once again Saint Paul, from the Acts.

en: You are a transitional generation, said Aunt Lydia.
vi: You are the transitional generation, Aunt Lydia said.
tr: You are the transitional generation, Aunt Lydia used to say.
es: You are a generation of transition, Aunt Lydia said.

en: It is the hard-est for you.
vi: The greatest difficulties fall upon you.
tr: You are the ones in the most difficult situation.
es: It is the most difficult.

en: We know the sacrifices you are being expected to make.
vi: We know how society expects you to sacrifice.
tr: We are aware of the sacrifices expected from you.
es: We know how many sacrifices you will have to make.

en: It is hard when men revile you.
vi: The hardest part is when people curse you.
tr: It is hard to endure the humiliation from men.
es: It is difficult when men insult you.

en: For the ones who conic after you, it will be easier.
vi: Those who come after will have it easier.
tr: It will be easier for those who come after you.
es: It will be easier for those who come after you.

en: They will accept their duties with willing hearts.
vi: They will willingly fulfill their duties.
tr: They will accept their duties willingly.
es: They will accept their obligation willingly.

en: She did not say: Because they will have no memories, of any other way.
vi: Auntie didn't say: Because they have no memory, that there is another way to go.
tr: What he didn't say was this: Because there will be no other memories.
es: But he did not say: Because they will not have known another way of life.

en: She said: Because they won't want things they can't have.
vi: She said: Because they will not desire the impossible.
tr: What he said is this: Because they will not want things they cannot have.
es: He said: Because they will not want the things they cannot have.

en: Once a week we had movies, after lunch and before our nap.
vi: Once a week we watch a movie, after lunch before taking a nap.
tr: Once a week, after lunch and before naptime, we would watch a movie.
es: Once a week we had movies, after lunch and before the nap.

en: We sat on the floor of the Domestic Science room, on our little gray mats, and waited while Aunt Helena and Aunt Lydia struggled with the projection equipment.
vi: We sit on the floor of the Home Economics room, on a small gray mat, waiting for Aunt Helena and Aunt Lydia to finish wrestling with the projector system.
tr: We would sit on our small gray mats on the floor in the Home Care room and wait while Aunt Helena and Aunt Lydia struggled with the projection equipment.
es: We would sit on the floor of the Domestic Economy room, on our gray mats, while Aunt Helena and Aunt Lydia struggled with the projection equipment.

en: If we were lucky they wouldn't get the film threaded upside-down.
vi: If we're lucky, they won't insert the film reel backward.
tr: If we were lucky, they would set up the film without reversing it.
es: If we were lucky, they wouldn't load the film backwards.

en: What it reminded me of was geography classes, at my own high school thousands of years before, where (hey showed movies of the rest of the world; women in long skirts or cheap printed cotton dresses, carrying bundles of sticks, or baskets,or plastic buckets of water, from some river or other, with babies slung on them in shawls or net slings, looking squint-eyed or afraid out of the screen at us, knowing something was being done to them by a machine with one glass eye but not knowing what,Those movies were comforting and faintly boring.
vi: To me, it recalls geography class at my school a thousand years ago, watching documentaries about the outside world; women in long skirts or cheap floral dresses, carrying bundles of firewood, baskets, or water buckets from some river, with a child slung on their back in a shawl or net carrier, glancing furtively or sideways from the screen at us, aware that the machine with the glass eye is doing something to them but not knowing what. Those kinds of films are comforting and a bit boring.
tr: It reminded me of geography classes at my own high school thousands of years ago, where they showed films about the rest of the world; women in long skirts or cheap printed cotton dresses, carrying bundles of sticks, baskets, plastic buckets filled with water from this or that river, with babies slung on their backs in shawls or net carriers, looking at us from the screen as if they were cross-eyed or scared, sensing that something was being done to them with a single glass-eyed machine but not quite understanding what it was. These films were comforting but a little boring.
es: This reminded me of geography classes, when I went to school, thousands of years ago, and they showed us films from the rest of the world; women dressed in long skirts or cheap printed cotton dresses, carrying bundles of firewood, or baskets, or plastic buckets with water they fetched from some river, and babies hanging from their shawls or net slings. They looked at the camera sideways or with a frightened expression, knowing that something was being done to them with a machine with a single glass eye, but not knowing what. Those films were comforting and terribly boring.

en: They made me feel sleepy, even when men came onto the screen, with naked muscles, hacking away at hard dirt with primitive hoes and shovels, hauling rocks.
vi: They make me sleepy, even when they pan to men, bare muscles, tirelessly digging the barren land with old-fashioned hoes or shovels, pushing carts of stones.
tr: They made me sleepy, even when muscular men appeared on the screen, carrying rocks and digging hard soil with primitive hoes and shovels.
es: They made me feel sleepy, even when men appeared on the screen showing their muscles, breaking the hard ground with rudimentary hoes and shovels, and moving rocks.

en: I preferred movies with dancing in them, singing,ceremonial masks, carved artifacts for making music: feathers, brass buttons, conch shells, drums.
vi: I prefer the films with dancing, singing, witch masks, and carved artifacts that produce music: feathers, bronze knobs, mother-of-pearl shells, drums.
tr: I preferred films that included dance, songs, ceremonial masks, and artworks carved to make music: feathers, brass buttons, spiral mother-of-pearl shells, drums.
es: I preferred the films where you could see dances, songs, ceremonial masks, and carved objects turned into musical instruments: feathers, brass buttons, seashells, drums.

en: I liked watching these people when they were happy, not when they were miserable, starving, emaciated, straining themselves to death over some simple thing,the digging of a well, the irrigation of land, problems the civilized na-tions had long ago solved.
vi: I like seeing these people happy, not suffering, starving, emaciated, working themselves to death for some trivial purpose, a well that needs digging, a field that needs watering, things that civilized nations solved ages ago.
tr: I enjoyed watching these people when they were happy, not when they were miserable, starving, skin and bones, struggling to death for simple things like digging a well or irrigating the land, problems that civilized people had solved long ago.
es: I liked to see these people when they were happy, not when they were miserable and starving, emaciated, or exhausting themselves to death over some trivial task like digging a well or irrigating the land, problems that civilized nations had solved long ago.

en: I thought someone should just give them the technology and let them get on with it.
vi: I think someone just needs to bring them technology and then let them manage on their own.
tr: I used to think someone should give them the technology and let them implement it.
es: I thought it was enough for someone to provide them with the technological means and let them use them.

en: Aunt Lydia didn't show these kinds of movies.
vi: Aunt Lydia does not show those types of movies.
tr: Aunt Lydia would not show these kinds of films.
es: Aunt Lydia didn't show us this type of movies.

vi: Sometimes it's an old pornographic film, from the seventies or eighties.
tr: Sometimes the film shown would be an old pornographic movie from the seventies or eighties.
es: Sometimes he would put on an old pornographic movie for us, from the seventies or eighties.

en: Women kneeling, sucking penises or guns, women tied up or chained or with dog collars around their necks, women hanging from trees, or upside-down, naked, with their legs held apart, women being raped, beaten up, killed.
vi: Women kneeling, sucking on a penis or a gun barrel, women being tied up or chained or wearing a dog collar, women hanging from a tree, or upside down, naked, legs spread wide, women being raped, beaten, killed.
tr: Women kneeling, sucking on a penis or a gun, women tied up or with dog collars around their necks, women hanging from trees or upside down, naked, with their legs spread apart, women being raped, beaten, killed.
es: Women kneeling and sucking penises or guns, women tied up or chained or with dog collars around their necks, women hanging from trees, or upside down, naked, with their legs spread, women being raped or beaten or killed.

en: Once we had to watch a woman being slowly cut into pieces, her fingers and breasts
vi: Once we had to watch a woman being cut into pieces, slowly, fingers and nipples being neatly sliced off, her belly being slit open and her intestines pulled out.
tr: Once, we had to watch a woman being slowly dismembered, her fingers and breasts being cut off with garden shears, her stomach being slit open and her intestines pulled out.
es: Once we had to watch as a woman was dismembered, her fingers and breasts cut off with pruning shears, her stomach opened and her intestines pulled out.

en: snipped off with garden shears, her stomach slit open and her intestines pulled out.

tr: Once, we had to watch a woman being slowly dismembered, her fingers and breasts being cut off with garden shears, her stomach being slit open and her intestines pulled out.
es: Once we had to watch as a woman was dismembered, her fingers and breasts cut off with pruning shears, her stomach opened and her intestines pulled out.

en: Consider the alternatives, said Aunt Lydia.
vi: Just look at the road over there, Aunt Lydia said.
tr: Consider the options, Aunt Lydia used to say.
es: Consider the possibilities, Aunt Lydia used to say.

en: You see what things used to be like?
vi: You see how it was before, right?
tr: Do you see how things used to be?
es: Do you see how things used to be?

en: That was what they thought of women, then.
vi: That's how they treated women, back then.
tr: This is what they thought about women back then.
es: That was what they thought of women back then.

en: Her voice trembled with indignation.
vi: Her voice trembled with indignation.
tr: Her voice was trembling with anger.
es: His voice trembled with indignation.

en: Moira said later that it wasn't real, it was done with models; but it was hard to tell.
vi: Moira said that it wasn't a real scene, it was all mannequins; but it was hard to tell the difference.
tr: Moira later said that this wasn't real, that these were done with models; but it was hard to understand.
es: Later, Moira said it wasn't real, that it was filmed with models; but it was hard to tell.

en: Sometimes, though, the movie would be what Aunt Lydia called an Unwoman documentary.
vi: But sometimes they also showed what Aunt Lydia called documentaries about the Unwomen.
tr: However, sometimes the film would become what Aunt Lydia called the Unwoman documentary.
es: Sometimes, however, the movie was what Aunt Lydia called a documentary about Unwomen.

en: Imagine, said Aunt Lydia, wasting their time like that, when they should have been doing something useful.
vi: Imagine, Aunt Lydia said, wasting time like that, when they could have been doing something useful.
tr: Imagine, Aunt Lydia would say, they are wasting their time in this way when they should be doing something useful.
es: Imagine, Aunt Lydia would say, what it means to waste time in that way, when they should have been doing something useful.

en: Back then, the Unwomen were always wasting time.
vi: Back then, the Unwomen wasted time all day long.
tr: At that time, the Unwomen always wasted their time.
es: Before, Unwomen were always wasting time.

en: They were encouraged to do it.
vi: They were encouraged to do so.
tr: They were encouraged to do so.
es: They were encouraged to do so.

en: The government gave them money to do that very thing.
vi: The government paid them to do it.
tr: The government would pay them to behave this way.
es: The government provided them with money to do exactly that.

en: Mind you, some of their ideas were sound enough, she went on, with the smug authority in her voice of one who is in a position to judge.
vi: Don't forget, many of their ideas were quite solid, she continued, with the authoritative and smug tone of someone in a position to judge.
tr: Look, some of their ideas were quite solid, Aunt Lydia would continue, with the smug authority of someone in a position to judge in her voice.
es: The truth is, they had some pretty good ideas, she continued, with the self-satisfied tone of someone in a position to judge.

en: We would have to condone some of their ideas, even today.
vi: We will have to accommodate some of those ideas, even now.
tr: We had to overlook some of their ideas, even today.
es: Even now, we should allow some of their ideas to continue.

en: Only some, mind you, she said coyly, raising her index finger, waggling it at us.
vi: Just a few, she said coyly, raising her index finger to admonish us.
tr: But only some ideas, she would say coquettishly, raising her index finger and wagging it at us.
es: Only some, really, she would say shyly, raising her index finger and waving it in front of us.

en: But they were Godless, and that can make all the difference, don't you agree?
vi: But they were godless, and that makes them very different, don't you agree?
tr: However, they were godless and that might make all the difference, don't you think?
es: But they were atheists, and there's the big difference, don't you think?

en: I sit on my mat, hands folded, and Aunt Lydia steps to the side, away from the screen, and the lights go out, and I wonder whether I can, in the dark, lean far over to the right without being seen, and whisper, to the woman next to me.
vi: I sit on the mat, hands folded, and Aunt Lydia stands aside, away from the screen, lights off, and I wonder if I could, in the darkness, lean to the right without anyone noticing, and whisper to the person next to me.
tr: I am sitting on my mat with my hands clasped, Aunt Lydia moves away from the screen and steps aside, the lights go out, I wonder if I can reach out to the right without being seen in the dark and whisper to the woman in my memory.
es: I sit on my mat, with my hands crossed; Aunt Lydia steps aside, moving away from the screen; the lights go out and I wonder if in the darkness I could lean to the right without being seen and whisper something to the woman next to me.

en: What will I whisper?
vi: What would I say?
tr: What will I whisper?
es: But what can I whisper to her?

en: I will say, Have you seen Moira.
vi: I would ask, Have you seen Moira?
tr: Have you seen Moira? I will say.
es: I will ask her if she has seen Moira.

en: Because nobody has, she wasn't at breakfast.
vi: Because no one has seen her, she didn't come down for breakfast.
tr: Because no one has seen her, she wasn't at breakfast.
es: Because no one has seen her, she didn't show up at breakfast time.

en: But the room, although dim, isn't dark enough, so I switch my mind into the holding pattern that passes for attention.
vi: But even though the room is dim, it's not completely dark, so I switch to a waiting stance, which can easily be mistaken for attentiveness.
tr: However, the room, despite being dim, is not very dark, I direct my mind to the waiting period given for gathering attention.
es: But the room, although dimly lit, is not dark enough, so I change my attitude, pretending to pay attention.

en: They don't play the soundtrack, on movies like these, though they do on the porno films.
vi: The sound is completely off, in these kinds of films, though they leave it on for pornographic ones.
tr: They play these kinds of films silently, but the pornographic ones with sound.
es: In movies of this type, they don't connect the soundtrack, but they do in the case of porn movies.

en: They want us to hear the screams and grunts and shrieks of what is supposed to be either extreme pain or extreme pleasure or both at once, but they don't want us to hear what the Unwomen are saying.
vi: We need to hear the screams, the panting or the shrieking, considered to be from extreme pain or extreme pleasure or both at the same time, but they never let us hear what the Unwomen say.
tr: They want us to hear the screams, grunts, and cries of what is assumed to be either extreme pain or extreme pleasure or a mixture of both, but not what the Unwomen are saying.
es: They want us to hear the screams, the moans, and the shrieks of what could be extreme pain or extreme pleasure, or both at the same time, but they don't want us to hear what the Unwomen are saying.

en: First come the title and some names, blacked out on the film with a crayon so we can't read them, and then I see my mother.
vi: First, the title appeared with a few names, on the negative film that had been blacked out with wax so we wouldn't read them, then I saw my mother.
tr: First, the title of the movie and a few names appear, but they are covered with a strip so we can't read them, and then I see my mother.
es: First, the title and some names appear —which are crossed out with charcoal so that we cannot read them—, and then I see my mother.

en: My young
vi: My young mother, younger than I even remember, as young as she must have been before I was born.
tr: My young mother, younger than I remember her, as young as she must have been before I was born.
es: My mother when she was young, younger than I remember her, as young as she must have been before I was born.

en: mother, younger than I remember her, as youngas she must have been once before I was born.
vi: My young mother, younger than I even remember, as young as she must have been before I was born.
tr: My young mother, younger than I remember her, as young as she must have been before I was born.
es: My mother when she was young, younger than I remember her, as young as she must have been before I was born.

en: She's wearing the kind of outfit Aunt Lydia told us was typical of Unwomen in those days, overall jeans with a green and mauve plaid shirt underneath and sneakers on her feet; the sort of thing Moira once wore, the sort of thing I can remember wearing, long ago, myself.
vi: She was dressed as Aunt Lydia said was typical of Unwomen of that time, wearing overalls over a half-blue, half-lavender checkered shirt, and sneakers; just like Moira used to wear, just like I remember wearing myself, a long time ago.
tr: In those days, she was wearing the typical clothes of the Unwomen that Aunt Lydia described, a denim overall, a green and lilac plaid shirt underneath, and sneakers on her feet; things that Moira used to wear, things I remember wearing myself a very long time ago.
es: She is wearing the type of clothing that, according to Aunt Lydia, was typical of the Unwomen at that time: a denim jumpsuit, a green and mauve plaid shirt underneath, and canvas shoes; it is the type of clothing that Moira used to wear at one time, the type of clothing I remember wearing myself a long time ago.

en: Her hair is tucked into a mauve kerchief tied behind her head.
vi: Her hair was tied back with a lavender scarf.
tr: Her hair is tucked into a lilac-colored scarf tied at the back of her head.
es: She wears her hair tied at the nape with a mauve-colored scarf.

en: Her face is very young, very serious, even pretty.
vi: Her face was very young, very serious, even beautiful.
tr: Her face is very young, very serious, even beautiful.
es: Her young face is very serious, though beautiful.

en: I've forgotten my mother was once as pretty and as earnest as that.
vi: I had forgotten that my mother was once so beautiful and earnest.
tr: I had forgotten that my mother was once this beautiful and serious.
es: I had forgotten that my mother was once so beautiful and so passionate.

en: She's in a group of other women, dressed in the same fashion; she's holding a stick, no, it's part of a banner, the handle.
vi: She stood among a group of women, dressed in the same style: she was holding up a stick, no, it was a banner, that was the handle.
tr: She is among a group of other women dressed in the same style; she is holding a stick, no, a part of a flag, the handle.
es: She is gathered with other women who are dressed in the same way; she is holding a stick, no, it's the handle of a banner.

en: The camera pans up and we see the writing, in paint, on what must have been a bedsheet: TAKE BACK THE NIGHT.
vi: The frame panned up and we saw the words, painted, on what must have been a bedsheet: TAKE BACK THE NIGHT.
tr: The camera pans up and we see the writing painted on something that was probably once a sheet: TAKE BACK THE NIGHT.
es: The camera takes a panoramic view and we see the inscription, painted on what must have been a sheet: GIVE US BACK THE NIGHT.

en: This hasn't been blacked out, eventhough we aren't supposed to be reading.
vi: This was not blacked out, even though we were not allowed to read written words.
tr: This writing is not blacked out, even though we are not supposed to read it.
es: This one has not been crossed out, but we are supposed not to read it.

en: The women around me breathe in, there's a stirring in the room, like wind over grass.
vi: Everyone around me gasped, the whole room stirred, like wind through grass.
tr: The women around me are sighing, there is a stir in the room, like the wind moving over the grass.
es: The women around me gasp and in the room there is a movement similar to that of grass when it is stirred by the wind.

en: Is this an oversight, have we gotten away with something?
vi: Was this due to negligence, had we glimpsed something we shouldn't have seen?
tr: Was this an unintentional mistake, or had she subtly achieved something?
es: Is it an oversight, and that's why we have escaped punishment?

en: Or is this a thing we're intended to set, lo remind us of the old daysof no safety?
vi: Or was it intentional, to remind us of the absolutely unsafe days of the past?
tr: Or is this something they want us to see, to remind us of those old days when there was no security?
es: Or was it something deliberate, to remind us of the old times when there was no security?

en: Behind this sign there are other signs, and the camera notices them briefly: FREEDOM TO CHOOSE.
vi: After this sign, there are many other banners, the frame glides past: THE RIGHT TO FREEDOM OF CHOICE.
tr: Behind this slogan, there are other slogans, the camera briefly focuses on them: FREEDOM OF CHOICE.
es: Behind this sign, there are others, and the camera briefly captures them: FREEDOM TO CHOOSE.

en: EVERY BABY A WANTED BABY.
vi: EVERY CHILD IS BORN FROM A DESIRE.
tr: EVERY BABY SHOULD BE A WANTED BABY.
es: WE WANT WANTED BABIES LET'S RESCUE OUR

en: RECAPTURE OUR BODIES.
vi: RECLAIM YOUR BODY.
tr: GIVE US BACK OUR BODIES.
es: BODIES.

en: DO YOU BELIEVE A WOMAN'S PLACE IS ON
vi: DO YOU REALLY BELIEVE A WOMAN'S PLACE IS IN THE KITCHEN?
tr: DO YOU BELIEVE A WOMAN'S PLACE IS AT THE KITCHEN TABLE?
es: DO YOU BELIEVE THAT A WOMAN'S PLACE IS IN THE KITCHEN?

en: THE, KItchen TABLE?
vi: DO YOU REALLY BELIEVE A WOMAN'S PLACE IS IN THE KITCHEN?
tr: DO YOU BELIEVE A WOMAN'S PLACE IS AT THE KITCHEN TABLE?
es: DO YOU BELIEVE THAT A WOMAN'S PLACE IS IN THE KITCHEN?

en: Under the last sign there's a line drawing of a woman's body, lying on a table, blood dripping out of it.
vi: Below the last banner, there is a sketch of a woman's body, lying on a table, blood dripping down.
tr: Under the last slogan, a woman is sketched lying on a table, covered in blood.
es: Under the last poster, the body of a woman is drawn on a table, with blood gushing out.

en: Now my mother is moving forward, she's smiling, laughing, they all move forward, and now they're raising their fists in the air.
vi: Now my mother is moving forward, she is smiling, laughing loudly, they are all moving forward, and now all are raising their fists to the sky.
tr: Now my mother is walking forward, smiling, laughing, they all come forward, now they are raising their fists in the air.
es: Now my mother advances, she is smiling, laughing, everyone advances with their fists raised.

en: The camera moves to the sky, where hundreds of balloons rise, trailing their strings: red balloons, with a circle painted on them, a circle with a stem like the stem of an apple, the stem of a cross.
vi: The frame glides up to the sky, where hundreds of balloons are flying up, trailing long strings: red balloons, with circles drawn on them, circles with stems like apple stems, and crosses.
tr: The camera, dragging its cables, turns to the sky where hundreds of balloons are rising: Red balloons, with a circle painted on them, a stem resembling an apple stem in the circle, and the stem is a cross.
es: The camera moves towards the sky, where hundreds of balloons with strings hanging are rising: red balloons that have a circle painted on them, a circle with a tail like that of an apple, but the tail is a cross.

en: Back on the earth, my mother is part of the crowd now, and I can't see her anymore.
vi: Back on the ground, my mother has blended into the crowd, I can't see her anywhere.
tr: We return to the ground, my mother is now part of the crowd and I can no longer see her.
es: The camera descends again; now my mother is part of the crowd and I can no longer see her.

en: 1 had you when I was thirty-seven,my mother said.
vi: My mother gave birth to me in thirty-seven, my mother said.
tr: When I was thirty-seven years old, I gave birth to you, my mother used to say.
es: "I had you when I was thirty-seven years old," my mother told me.

en: It was a risk, you
vi: It was really risky, I could have been deformed or something like that.
tr: It was risky, you could have been disabled or something else.
es: "It was a risk, you could have been born deformed, or something like that."

en: could have been deformed or something.
vi: It was really risky, I could have been deformed or something like that.
tr: It was risky, you could have been disabled or something else.
es: "It was a risk, you could have been born deformed, or something like that."

en: You were a wanted child, all right, and did I get shit from some quarters!
vi: I was born out of desire, that's good, and my mother was cursed by a bunch of people!
tr: You were a wanted child, yes, that's true, and some circles loaded disasters onto me!
es: "You were a wanted baby, that's for sure, and I received criticism from many people."

en: My oldest buddy Tricia accused me of being pronatalist, the bitch.
vi: Tricia, my mother's closest friend, cursed my mother as a reproductive freak, that bitch.
tr: My oldest friend Tricia Foreman accused me of being a protanalist, that bitch.
es: "My old friend Tricia Foreman accused me of being a pronatalist, the bitch."

en: Jealousy, I put that down to.
vi: Just jealousy, my mother thought so.
tr: I attributed this to her jealousy.
es: "I attributed it to jealousy."

en: Some of the others were okay though.
vi: But some others were quite comfortable.
tr: Some others were still good.
es: "Some, however, behaved well."

en: But when I was six months' pregnant, a lot of them started sending me these articles about how the birth-defect rate went zooming up after thirty-five.
vi: But when my mother was six months pregnant, countless people started sending all kinds of articles about the skyrocketing rate of birth defects after thirty-five.
tr: But in the sixth month of my pregnancy, many started sending articles about how the rate of disabled births increases after thirty-five.
es: "But when I was six months pregnant, many of them started sending me those articles about how after thirty-five the risk of having children with congenital defects increases."

en: Just what I needed.
vi: So helpful.
tr: Just what I needed, really.
es: "Exactly what I needed."

en: And stuff about how hard it was to be a single parent.
vi: And the crap about the challenges facing single mothers.
tr: And a lot of nonsense about how hard it is to be a single parent.
es: "And nonsense about how difficult it was to be a single mother."

en: Fuck that shit, I told them, I've started this and I'm going to finish it.
vi: Throw it all away, my mother said, I have started and I will see it through.
tr: Fuck this shit, I told them, I started this and I will finish it.
es: "Take that shit away from here," I told them, "I've started this and I'm going to finish it."

en: At the hospital they wrote down "Aged Pri-mipara" on the chart, I caught them in the act.
vi: At the hospital, they wrote on the chart "Elderly primigravida," caught red-handed by my mother.
tr: They wrote "Advanced Maternal Age Primipara" on my card at the hospital, I caught them doing it.
es: In the hospital chart, they wrote: "Elderly primipara," I caught them while they were noting it down.

en: That's what they call you when it's your first baby over thirty, over thirty for god-sake.
vi: That's a fancy term for someone having their first child after thirty, after thirty, for God's sake.
tr: Over thirty, for god's sake, over thirty, that's the name they give you when you have your first baby.
es: That's what they call women over thirty who are expecting their first baby.

en: Garbage, I told them, biologically I'm twenty-two, I could run rings around you any day.
vi: Damn it, my mother told them, biologically I’m only twenty-two, and if you like, I can kick your asses anytime.
tr: It's nonsense, I told them, biologically I'm twenty-two, I can run circles around you every day.
es: "All that is garbage," I told them, "biologically I am twenty-two years old, I could run circles around all of you."

en: I could have triplets and walk out of here while you were still trying to get up off the bed.
vi: I will give birth to triplets and walk out of here while you are still struggling to get out of bed, just watch.
tr: While you're still trying to get out of bed, I could give birth to triplets and walk out of here.
es: "I could have triplets and walk out of here while you would still be trying to get out of bed."

en: When she said that she'd jut out her chin.
vi: When she mentioned that, Mom tilted her chin up.
tr: When she said this, she would push her chin forward.
es: While she was saying it, her chin was jutting out.

en: I remember her like that, her chin jutted out, a drink in front of her on the kitchen table; not young and earnest and pretty the way she was in the movie, but wiry, spunky, the kind of old woman who won't let anyone butt in front of her in a supermarket line.
vi: I still remember Mom back then, chin tilted up, a glass of wine in front of her on the kitchen table; not youthful, sincere, and beautiful like in the movies, but sinewy, tough, just like the old ladies in the supermarket who would never let anyone cut in line.
tr: I remember her this way, chin thrust forward, at the kitchen table, with a drink in front of her; not young and serious and beautiful like in the movie, but thin, angry, like one of those old women in the supermarket line who wouldn't let anyone cut in front of them.
es: I remember her like that, with her chin jutting out and a glass in front of her, at the kitchen table; not as young, passionate, and pretty as she appeared in the movie, but strong, brave, the kind of old lady who wouldn't let someone cut in front of her in the supermarket line.

en: She liked to come over to my house and have a drink while Luke and I were fixing dinner and tell us what was wrong with her life, which always turned into what was wrong with ours.
vi: Mom liked to drop by my house for a drink while Luke and I were preparing dinner, and tell us where her life went wrong, and it always ended up with her pointing out where we went wrong.
tr: She liked to come to my house, have a drink while Luke and I prepared dinner, and talk about what was wrong in her life - which always turned into what was wrong in our lives.
es: He liked to come to my house for a drink while Luke and I prepared dinner, and tell us what was going wrong in his life, which always turned into what was going wrong in ours.

en: Her hair was gray by that time, of course.
vi: Mom's hair was gray by then, of course.
tr: Her hair was gray at that time, of course.
es: At that time, he had gray hair, of course.

en: She wouldn't dye it.
vi: She didn't plan to dye it.
tr: She didn't dye it.
es: She would never have dyed it.

en: Why pretend, she'd say.
vi: What's the point of pretending, that was her opinion.
tr: Why should I look different than I am? she would say.
es: Why pretend, she said.

en: Anyway what do I need it for, I don't want a man around, what use are they except for ten seconds' worth of half babies.
vi: Anyway, what else did she need to do, she didn't want men bustling around her anymore, what good were they besides spending ten seconds to make half a baby.
tr: Anyway, why would I need to, I don't want men around, what good are they other than making half a baby in ten seconds?
es: Anyway, what do I want it for, I don't want any man by my side, what are they good for, except for the ten seconds they spend making half a baby.

en: A man is just a woman's strategy for making other women.
vi: Men are just a tactic women use to produce more women.
tr: A man is just a tool a woman uses to produce more women.
es: A man is simply a woman's instrument to make other women.

en: Not that your father wasn't a nice guy and all, but he wasn't up to fatherhood.
vi: She didn't say your father wasn't pleasant or anything, but he wasn't fit to be a father.
tr: I'm not saying your father wasn't a nice guy, but he wasn't suitable for fatherhood.
es: I'm not saying your father wasn't a good guy and all that, but he wasn't ready for fatherhood.

en: Not that I expected it of him.
vi: And she didn't expect anything either.
tr: I wasn't expecting that from him anyway.
es: And it's not that I expected that from him.

en: Just do the job, then you can bugger off, I said, I make a decent salary, I can afford daycare.
vi: Do the necessary thing, then get lost, she said, I earn enough, I can afford daycare.
tr: Just do your job, then you can leave, I said, I have a good salary, I can hire a nanny.
es: Just do your job, and then you can disappear, I told him, I have a decent salary and I can take care of her.

en: So he went to the coast and sent Christmas cards.
vi: So he went to the seaside and sent a card at Christmas.
tr: So he went to the Pacific coast and sent Christmas cards.
es: So he went to the coast and sent me Christmas postcards.

en: He had beautifulblue eyes though.
vi: Actually, he had quite beautiful blue eyes.
tr: Still, he had very beautiful blue eyes.
es: He had beautiful blue eyes.

en: But there's something missing in them, even the nice ones.
vi: But they still lack something, even the best ones.
tr: But there was something missing in them, even in the nice ones.
es: But they all lack something, even the handsome ones.

en: It's like they're permanently absent-minded, like they can't
vi: It's like they're perpetually absent-minded, like they never remember who they are.
tr: They seemed constantly distracted, as if they couldn't quite remember who they were.
es: It's like they're permanently distracted, like they can't exactly remember who they are.

en: quite remember who they are.
vi: It's like they're perpetually absent-minded, like they never remember who they are.
tr: They seemed constantly distracted, as if they couldn't quite remember who they were.
es: It's like they're permanently distracted, like they can't exactly remember who they are.

en: They look at the sky too much.
vi: They look up at the clouds for too long.
tr: They look at the sky too much.
es: They look at the sky a lot. And

en: They lose touch with their feet.
vi: They don't feel their feet on the ground.
tr: Their feet don't touch the ground.
es: they lose touch with reality.

en: They aren't a patch on a woman except they're better at fixing cars and playing football, just what we need for the improvement of the human race, right?
vi: They're not even a fraction of a woman except for being a bit better at fixing cars and playing ball, which is so necessary for improving the species, right?
tr: They can't stick to a woman, and despite being better at fixing cars and playing football, they can't even be half as good as women; this is exactly what we need for the advancement of the human race, isn't it?
es: They are not even comparable to women, except that they are better at fixing cars and playing football, which is exactly what we need for the progress of the human race, right?

en: That was the way she talked, even in front of Luke.
vi: That's how mother's tongue is, even in front of Luke.
tr: She would talk like this, even in front of Luke.
es: This is how she spoke, even in front of Luke.

en: He didn't mind, he teased her by pretending to be macho, he'd tell her women were incapable of abstract thought and she'd have another drink and grin at him.
vi: He didn't mind, and would tease her back by pretending to be a hero, saying that women couldn't think abstractly, and then she would pour another glass and laugh at him.
tr: Luke didn't mind, he admired her by acting like a macho, saying that women lacked the ability to think abstractly, and my mother would get another drink and grin at him.
es: He didn't mind and teased her by pretending to be a macho, telling her that women were not capable of abstract thinking, and she would take another drink and give him a mocking smile.

en: Chauvinist pig, she'd say.
vi: The pig is so dirty, mom will say.
tr: Chauvinist pig, my mother used to say.
es: Chauvinist pig, she would say to him.

en: Isn't she quaint, Luke would say to me, and my mother would look sly, furtive almost.
vi: Mom is crazy too, Luke would tell me that, and she would put on a mischievous, even sly look.
tr: "Isn't it antique?" Luke would say to me, and my mother would look cunning, almost sly.
es: Doesn't it seem old-fashioned to you? Luke asked me, and my mother looked at him with a certain malice, almost furtively.

en: I'm entitled, she'd say.
vi: I have the right, mother would say.
tr: I have the right to this, he would say.
es: I have the right, I replied to him.

en: I'm old enough, I've paid my dues, it's time for me to be quaint.
vi: I am old now, my duties are done, now it's time to go crazy.
tr: I've aged enough, I've paid my dues, it's time for me to become an antique.
es: I am old enough, I have paid all my debts, now it's my turn to be old-fashioned.

en: You're still wet behind the ears.
vi: You all are still wet behind the ears.
tr: Your mouth still smells like milk.
es: You still don't know how to wipe your nose.

en: Piglet, I should have said.
vi: Suckling pigs, that's right.
tr: I should have said piglet.
es: I should have called you piglet.

en: As for you, she'd say to me, you're just a backlash.
vi: And you too, my mother turned to me, truly a backward progression.
tr: And as for you, he would say to me, you are just a bundle of reactions.
es: As far as you're concerned, he told me, you're nothing but a game to him.

en: Flash in the pan.
vi: An elephant's head, a mouse's tail.
tr: Empty noise.
es: A flare that quickly dies out.

en: History will absolve me.
vi: History will absolve me.
tr: History will prove me right.
es: Time will prove me right.

en: But she wouldn't say things like that until after the third drink.
vi: But mom will only speak in that tone after the third glass.
tr: But she wouldn't say such things until she had downed her third drink.
es: But he only said these kinds of things after the third drink.

en: You young people don't appreciate things, she'd say.
vi: You young people don't appreciate anything, mother will say.
tr: You young people don't appreciate the value of anything, my mother used to say.
es: You young people do not know how to appreciate things, he continued.

en: You don't know what we had to go through, just to get you where you are.
vi: You don't know what we had to go through to get this day for you.
tr: You have no idea what we went through just to get you to where you are.
es: You do not know what we have had to go through to get you where you are.

en: Look at him, slicing up the carrots.
vi: Just look at that man slicing carrots over there.
tr: Look at this, chopping carrots.
es: Look at him, he is the one peeling the carrots.

en: Don't you know how many women's lives, how many women's bodies, the tanks had to roll over just to get that far?
vi: Do you know how many women lost their lives, crushed under the wheels of tanks, to reach that point?
tr: Do you know how many tanks crushed how many women's lives and bodies just to make this little progress?
es: Do you know how many women's lives, how many women's bodies the tanks have had to crush to reach this situation?

en: Cooking's my hobby, Luke would say.
vi: Cooking is my hobby, Luke would reply.
tr: Cooking is my hobby, Luke would say.
es: The kitchen is my favorite hobby, said Luke.

en: I enjoy it.
vi: I like doing it.
tr: I enjoy it.
es: I enjoy cooking.

en: Hobby, schmobby, my mother would say.
vi: My mother's response to my trivial hobbies.
tr: Hobby schmobbi, my mother would say.
es: A very original hobby, my mother replied.

en: You don't have to make excuses to me.
vi: Don't make excuses to me.
tr: You don't have to make excuses to me.
es: You don't have to explain yourself to me.

en: Once upon a time you wouldn't have been allowed to have such a hobby, they'd have called you queer.
vi: In the past, you weren't even allowed to have such hobbies; you would be called a hypocrite.
tr: There was a time when you wouldn't be allowed to have such a hobby, they would call you henpecked.
es: In other times, they wouldn't have allowed you to have such a hobby; they would have called you a sissy.

en: Now, Mother, I would say.
vi: Alright, mom, let me speak now.
tr: Look, mom, I would say.
es: Let's go, mother, I would say to her.

en: Let's not get into an argument about nothing.
vi: Stop arguing over trivial matters.
tr: Let's not argue over nothing.
es: Let's not argue over silly things.

en: Nothing, she'd say bitterly.
vi: No, mother said bitterly.
tr: Never, he said with pain.
es: Nonsense, he repeated bitterly.

en: You call it nothing.
vi: She said no.
tr: Do you call this nothing?
es: He called them nonsense.

en: You don't un derstand, do you.
vi: She doesn't understand, that's right.
tr: You don't understand, do you?
es: I see that you don't understand.

en: You don't understand at all what I'm talking about.
vi: She doesn't understand anything I say.
tr: You never understand what I'm talking about.
es: You don't understand anything I'm saying.

en: Sometimes she would cry.
vi: Sometimes, mother will cry.
tr: Sometimes he would cry.
es: Sometimes she would burst into tears.

en: I was so lonely, she'd say.
vi: On those days, mother is very lonely, she will say so.
tr: I was so lonely, he would say.
es: She was so lonely..., she would say.

en: You have no idea
vi: You children don't understand how lonely mother is.
tr: You can't imagine how lonely I was.
es: You have no idea how lonely she was.

en: how lonely I was.
vi: You children don't understand how lonely mother is.
tr: You can't imagine how lonely I was.
es: You have no idea how lonely she was.

en: And I had friends, I was a lucky one, but I was lonely anyway.
vi: Even though mother has friends and is relatively fortunate, she is still very lonely.
tr: I had friends, I was lucky, but I was still lonely.
es: And she had friends, she was fortunate, but she was still lonely.

en: I admired my mother in some ways, although things between us were never easy.
vi: There are many times I admire my mother, even though our relationship has never been simple.
tr: I admired my mother in some ways, even though our relationship was not easy at all.
es: In certain aspects, I admired my mother, although things between us were never easy.

en: She expected too much from me, I felt.
vi: My mother demands too much from me, I think.
tr: I felt that she expected a lot from me.
es: I felt that she expected too much from me.

en: She expected me to vindicate her life for her, andthe choices she'd made.
vi: She demands that I be a witness to justify her life, her decisions.
tr: She expected me to justify her life and the choices she made.
es: She expected me to vindicate her life and the choices she had made.

en: I didn't want to live my life on her terms.
vi: I don't want to live my life according to the standards she sets.
tr: I didn't want to live my life according to her terms.
es: I did not want to live my life according to her terms.

en: I didn't want to be the model offspring, the incarnation of her ideas.
vi: I don't want to be the model child, embodying her ideals.
tr: I didn't want to be the embodiment of her ideal child.
es: I did not want to be a model daughter, the embodiment of her ideas.

en: We used to fight about that.
vi: We often argue loudly about this.
tr: We always fought about this.
es: We used to argue about that.

en: 1 am not your justification for existence, I said to her once.
vi: You don't live so that I have a reason to exist, I once said.
tr: I am not the reason for your existence, I told her once.
es: I am not the justification for your existence, I once told him.

en: I want her back.
vi: I want to have my mother back.
tr: I want it back.
es: I want to have her by my side again.

en: I want everything back, the way it was.
vi: I want to have everything back, like it was before.
tr: I want everything back, like it used to be.
es: I want to have everything again, just as it was.

en: But there is no point to it, this wanting.
vi: But nothing comes of it, that desire.
tr: But this, this desire, has no meaning.
es: But this desire makes no sense.
CHAPTER 21

en: It's hot in here, and too noisy.
vi: It's hot here, and also too noisy.
tr: It's hot and very noisy here.
es: It's hot here, and there's a lot of noise.

en: The women's voices rise around me, a soft chant that is still too loud for me, after the days and days of silence.
vi: The voices of the women rise around me, the soft chanting still deafening after days of silence.
tr: The voices of women are rising around me, and even a softly sung song is very loud for me after so many days of silence.
es: The voices of the women rise around me in a soft chant that is still too loud for me, after so many days of silence.

en: In the corner of the room there's a bloodstained sheet, bundled and tossed there, from when the waters broke.
vi: In the corner of the room, there's a blood-stained sheet, rolled up and thrown there since the water broke.
tr: In the corner of the room, there is a blood-stained sheet from a burst water bag, folded and thrown there.
es: In a corner of the room, there's a blood-stained sheet, bundled up and thrown aside, from when Janine's water broke.

en: I hadn't noticed it before.
vi: Earlier, I didn't notice it.
tr: I hadn't noticed it before.
es: I hadn't noticed until now.

en: The room smells too, the air is close, they should open a window.
vi: The room also had a smell, the air was stuffy, they should have opened the door.
tr: There is also a smell in the room, it has become stuffy, the window should be opened.
es: The room also smells, the air is heavy, they should open a window.

en: The smell is of our own flesh, an organic smell, sweat and a tinge of iron, from the blood on the sheet, and another smell, more animal, that's coming, it must be, from Janine: a smell of dens, of inhabited caves, the smell of the plaid blanket on the bed when the cat gave birth on it, once, before she was spayed.
vi: The mixed smell of our flesh, an organic smell, sweat with a hint of iron, from the blood on the sheet, and another smell, more animalistic, emanating directly from Janine: the smell of a den, the smell of inhabited caves, the smell of the checkered blanket on the bed when the cat gave birth there, the only time, before being spayed.
tr: The smell comes from our own bodies, an organic scent with a metallic tinge due to sweat and blood on the sheets; there is another smell, presumably from Janine, more animalistic: the smell of caves, of dens once inhabited by humans, the smell of the plaid blanket on the bed where the cat once gave birth before being spayed.
es: The smell that is felt is that of our own flesh, an organic smell, of sweat with a hint of iron that must come from the blood on the sheet, and another smell, more animalistic, that surely comes from Janine: the smell of a den, an inhabited cave, the smell of the checkered blanket on which the cat once gave birth, before she was sterilized.

en: Smell of matrix.
vi: The smell of the womb.
tr: The smell of the womb.
es: Smell of the womb.

en: "Breathe, breathe," we chant, as we have been taught, "Hold, hold.
vi: “Inhale, inhale,” we chanted softly, as we had learned, “Hold the breath, hold the breath.
tr: “Breathe in, breathe in,” we sing, as we were taught. “Hold, hold.
es: —Breathe in, breathe in —we sing, just as we were taught—. Hold it, hold it.

en: Expel, expel, expel."
vi: Exhale, exhale, exhale.”
tr: Release, release, release.”
es: Expel, expel, expel —we sing until we reach five.

en: We chant to the count of five.
vi: We recited in a rhythm of five.
tr: We sing while counting to five.
es: Five to inhale, five to hold it, and five to exhale.

en: Five in, hold for five, out for five.
vi: In for five, hold for five, exhale for five.
tr: Breathe in for five, hold for five, release for five.
es: Five to inhale, five to hold it, and five to exhale.

en: Janine, her eyes closed, tries to slow her breathing.
vi: Janine, eyes tightly shut, tried to control her breathing.
tr: Janine, with her eyes closed, tries to slow her breathing, and Aunt Elizabeth tries to feel the birth contractions.
es: Janine, with her eyes closed, tries to slow the pace of her breathing.

en: Aunt Elizabeth feels for the contractions.
vi: Aunt Elizabeth checked the dilation of her cervix.
tr: Janine, with her eyes closed, tries to slow her breathing, and Aunt Elizabeth tries to feel the birth contractions.
es: Aunt Elizabeth feels for the contractions.

en: Now Janine is restless, she wants to walk.
vi: Now Janine felt restless, she wanted to walk around.
tr: Now Janine is hesitant, she wants to walk.
es: Now Janine is restless and wants to walk.

en: The two women help her off the bed, support her on either side while she paces.
vi: Two women helped her up from the bed, supporting her on both sides as she took each step.
tr: Two women help her get out of bed, supporting her as she walks.
es: The two women help her get out of bed and support her on each side as she walks.

en: A contraction hits her, she doubles over.
vi: A muscle contraction came, and she bent over, collapsing.
tr: A sudden spasm and Janine doubles over.
es: A contraction comes over her, forcing her to bend over.

en: One of the women kneels and rubs her back.
vi: One of the two women knelt down and stroked her back.
tr: One of the women kneels down and rubs her back.
es: One of the women kneels and rubs her back.

en: We are all good at this, we've had lessons.
vi: Everyone was good at this, having practiced repeatedly.
tr: We are all good at this, we had our training.
es: All of us know how to do it, we have received lessons.

en: I recognize Ofglen, my shopping partner, sitting two away from me.
vi: I recognized Ofglen, my shopping partner, sitting two people away from me.
tr: I notice that Gleninki, my shopping partner, is sitting two people away from me.
es: I recognize Deglen, my shopping partner, two seats away from mine.

en: The soft chanting
vi: The soft chanting surrounded us like a veil.
tr: The softly sung song envelops us like a veil.
es: The soft chant envelops us like a membrane.

en: envelops us like a membrane.
vi: The soft chanting surrounded us like a veil.
tr: The softly sung song envelops us like a veil.
es: The soft chant envelops us like a membrane.

en: A Martha arrives, with a tray: a jug of fruit juice, the kind you make from powder, grape it looks like, and a stack of paper cups.
vi: A woman named Martha came, carrying a tray: a jug of fruit juice, made from powder, probably grape, and a stack of paper cups.
tr: Martha comes in with a tray: powdered fruit juice that looks like grape juice and a stack of paper cups.
es: A Martha arrives with a tray: a pitcher with fruit juice, like the powdered kind, which seems to be grape, and a bunch of cardboard cups.

en: She sets it on the rug in front of the chanting women.
vi: She placed it on the carpet in front of the row of murmuring women.
tr: She places the tray on the carpet in front of the women who are singing.
es: She places it on the carpet, in front of the women who are singing.

en: Ofglen, not missing a beat, pours, and the paper cups pass down the line.
vi: Ofglen, without a moment's delay, poured it out, and the paper cups were passed down the line.
tr: Without missing a word, Gleninki empties the pitcher and passes the paper cups along the row.
es: Without losing the rhythm, Deglen serves the juice and the cups make their way down the row.

en: I receive a cup, lean to the side to pass it, and the woman next to me says, low in my ear, "Are you looking for anyone?"
vi: I received a glass, leaned over to pass it on, and the person sitting next to me whispered in my ear, "Are you looking for someone?"
tr: She takes a glass, I lean to the side to hand it over, and the woman next to me quietly asks in my ear, "Are you looking for someone?"
es: I receive a glass, lean to the side to pass it, and the woman next to me whispers in my ear: —Are you looking for someone?

en: "Moira," I say, just as low.
vi: “Moira,” I said, just as softly.
tr: “Moira,” I say, as quietly as she does, “Dark-haired.
es: —Moira —I say to her, also in a low voice—.

en: "Dark hair, freckles."
vi: “Black hair, with freckles.”
tr: Freckled.”
es: Dark hair and freckles.

en: "No," the woman says.
vi: "I don't know," the other person said.
tr: “No,” says the woman.
es: —No —the woman replies—.

en: I don't know this woman, she wasn't at the Center with me, though I've seen her, shopping.
vi: I don't know you, you are not at the Center, although I have seen you before, while shopping.
tr: I don't know this woman, she wasn't with me at the Center, but I had seen her while shopping.
es: I don't know her, she wasn't with me at the Center, although I've seen her shopping.

en: "But I'll watch for you."
vi: "But I will keep an eye out for you."
tr: “But I'll keep an eye out for you.”
es: But I will look for her for you.

en: "Are you?" I say.
vi: "Really?" I said.
tr: "Your name?" I ask.
es: —Who are you? —I ask him.

en: "Alma," she says.
vi: “Alma,” she said.
tr: “Alma,” he says.
es: —Soul —she responds—.

en: "What's your real name?"
vi: “What is your real name?”
tr: “What is your real name?”
es: What is your real name?

en: I want to tell her there wasan Alma with me at the Center.
vi: I wanted to tell her that there was also an Alma at the Center with me.
tr: I want to tell her that there is an Alma with me at the Center.
es: I want to tell you that there was another Alma in the Center.

en: I want to tell her my name, but Aunt Elizabeth raises her head, staring around the room, she must have heard a break in the chant, so there's no more time.
vi: I wanted to say my name, but Aunt Elizabeth had already looked up, scrutinizing the room, she must have heard the interrupted murmur, it was too late.
tr: I want to say my name, but Aunt Elizabeth lifts her head and scans the room, she must have heard a pause in the song, so there's no time for that anymore.
es: I want to tell you my name, but Aunt Elizabeth lifts her head and scans the room with her gaze; she must have noticed a disruption in the chant, so I don't have time.

en: Sometimes you can find things out, on Birth Days.
vi: Sometimes you can find out something during Birthdays.
tr: You can learn something on Birthdays sometimes.
es: Sometimes, on Birthdays, you find out things.

en: But there would be no point in asking about Luke.
vi: But asking about Luke would be pointless.
tr: There's no point in asking about Luke.
es: But it wouldn't make sense to ask about Luke.

en: He wouldn't be where any of these women would be likely to see him.
vi: He can't be anywhere the women might encounter him.
tr: After all, none of these women have been in a place where they could see him.
es: He must not have been anywhere that any of these women could have seen him.

en: The chanting goes on, it begins to catch me.
vi: The murmuring continued, it had started to infect me.
tr: The song continues, and it is starting to affect me too.
es: The chant continues, and it starts to infect me.

en: It's hard work, you're supposed to concentrate.
vi: This task was quite arduous, requiring concentration.
tr: This is heavy work, you need to concentrate.
es: It's difficult, you have to concentrate.

en: Identify with your body, said Aunt Elizabeth.
vi: Be one with your body, Aunt Elizabeth said.
tr: Identify yourself with your body, Aunt Elizabeth used to say.
es: Identify yourselves with your body, said Aunt Elizabeth.

en: Already I can feel slight pains, in my belly, and my breasts are heavy.
vi: Right now, I could feel a slight pain in my stomach, and a tightness in my chest.
tr: I can already feel slight cramps in my stomach and my breasts have become heavier.
es: I can already feel slight pains in my belly and heaviness in my breasts.

en: Janine screams, a weak scream, partway between a scream and a groan.
vi: Janine screamed, her voice very faint, half scream, half moan.
tr: Janine is screaming, a light scream, something between a scream and a grunt.
es: Janine screams, it is a weak scream, a mix of a scream and a moan.

en: "She's going into transition," says Aunt Elizabeth.
vi: “She has entered the transition phase,” Aunt Elizabeth said.
tr: “She is starting to lose herself,” says Aunt Elizabeth.
es: —She is going into a trance —says Aunt Elizabeth.

en: One of the helpers wipes Janine's forehead with a damp cloth.
vi: One of the two caregivers took a damp cloth and wiped Janine's forehead.
tr: One of the assistants is wiping Janine's forehead with a damp cloth.
es: One of the assistants wipes Janine's forehead with a damp cloth.

en: Janine is sweating now, her hair is escaping in wisps from the elastic band, bits of it stick to her forehead and neck.
vi: Janine was sweating profusely, with strands of hair slipping out of her ponytail, many sticking to her forehead and neck.
tr: Janine is now sweating, her hair slipping out of the rubber band in strands, with a few strands sticking to her forehead and neck.
es: Janine is sweating, some strands of hair come loose from the elastic band and smaller ones stick to her forehead and neck.

en: Her flesh is damp, saturated, lustrous.
vi: Her skin was damp, soaked, and glistening.
tr: Her skin is moist, slippery, and shiny.
es: Her skin is damp, soaked, and shiny.

en: "Pant! pant! pant!" we chant.
vi: "Breathe! Breathe! Breathe!" we murmured.
tr: “Breathe! Breathe! Breathe!” we are singing.
es: —Pant! Pant! Pant! —we sang.

en: "I want to go outside," says Janine.
vi: “I want to go outside,” Janine panted.
tr: “I want to go outside,” says Janine.
es: —I want to go out —says Janine—.

en: "I want to go for a walk.
vi: “I want to take a walk.
tr: “I want to take a walk.
es: I want to take a walk.

en: I feel
vi: I'm fine.
tr: I feel good.
es: I feel good.

en: fine.
vi: I'm fine.
tr: I feel good.
es: I feel good.

en: I have to go to the can."
vi: I need to go to the bathroom.”
tr: I want to go to the bathroom.”
es: I need to go to the restroom.

en: We all know that she's in transition, she doesn't know what she's doing.
vi: We all understand that she is at a transitional stage, she doesn't know what she is doing.
tr: We all know that she is out of it, she doesn't know what she's doing.
es: We all know that she is in a moment of transition, that she doesn't know what she is doing.

en: Which of these statements is true?
vi: Which sentence is correct?
tr: Which of these statements is correct?
es: Which of these statements is true?

en: Probably the last one.
vi: Surely the last one.
tr: Probably the last one.
es: Probably the last one.

en: Aunt Elizabeth signals, two women stand beside the portable toi-let, Janine is lowered gently onto it.
vi: Aunt Elizabeth signaled, and the two women standing by the portable toilet gently placed Janine on it.
tr: Aunt Elizabeth signals, two women are standing next to the portable toilet, and Janine is slowly being placed on it.
es: Aunt Elizabeth makes a signal; two women position themselves next to the portable sink and help Janine to sit on it.

en: There's another smell, added to the others in the room.
vi: Another smell, adding to the ones already present in the room.
tr: Another smell is added to the others in the room.
es: Now another smell is added to those already in the room.

en: Janine groans again, her head bent over so all we can see is her hair.
vi: Janine groaned again, her head drooping so that we could only see her hair.
tr: Janine moans again, her head bowed, all we can see is her hair.
es: Janine groans again and tilts her head in such a way that we can only see her hair.

en: Crouching like that, she's like a doll, an old one that's been pillaged and discarded, in some corner, akimbo.
vi: Her body folded, she looked like a doll, robbed and discarded, in a corner, her arms bent at her sides.
tr: In this squatting position, she looks like a doll, an old doll stripped and thrown into a corner with its hands on its lap.
es: Hunched like that, she looks like a doll with her arms akimbo, an old doll that has been mistreated and abandoned in a corner.

en: Janine is up again and walking.
vi: Janine got up again and walked around.
tr: Janine stands up and walks again.
es: Janine is standing again and walking.

en: "I want to sit down," she says.
vi: “I want to sit down,” she said.
tr: “I want to sit down,” she says.
es: "I want to sit down," she says.

en: How long have we been here?
vi: How long have we been here?
tr: How long have we been here?
es: How long have we been here?

en: Minutes or hours.
vi: Minutes, hours.
tr: For minutes or hours.
es: Minutes or hours.

en: I'm sweating now, my dress under my arms is drenched, I taste salt on my upper lip, the false pains clench at me, the others feel it too, I can tell by the waythey sway.
vi: Now I am also sweating, my armpits are soaked, my upper lip tastes salty, the false labor pains grip me, and the others too, you can tell by the way they sway.
tr: Now I am sweating, my dress is wet under my arms, there is a taste of salt on my upper lip, false pains are gripping me, the others feel the same, I can tell from their swaying.
es: I'm sweating, my dress is soaked under the armpits, my upper lip tastes like salt; false pains come over me, the others feel them too: I know by the way they move.

en: Janine is sucking on an ice cube.
vi: Janine is sucking noisily on a piece of ice.
tr: Janine is sucking on a piece of ice.
es: Janine is sucking on an ice cube.

en: Then, after that, inches away or miles, "No," she screams.
vi: Then, a few steps or a few miles later, “No,” she screamed.
tr: Then, after this, from a centimeter or kilometers away, she screams, “No.” “Oh no, oh no, oh no.”
es: Then, a few steps or kilometers away, she screams—:

en: "Oh no, oh no oh no."
vi: “Oh no, no, oh no no.”
tr: Then, after this, from a centimeter or kilometers away, she screams, “No.” “Oh no, oh no, oh no.”
es: No. Oh no, oh no, oh no —this is her second baby, she had a child, once.

en: It's her second baby, she had another child, once, I know that from the Center, when she used to cry about it at night, like the rest of us only more noisily.
vi: This is her second child, she had another one, a long time ago, I knew back at the Center, she used to cry every night because she missed it, just like all of us, only louder.
tr: This is her second baby; she once had another child, I know this from the Center, she used to cry for it at night, like all of us, only louder.
es: I found out at the Center because she used to call out for him at night, just like the others but louder.

en: So she ought to be able to remember this, what it's like, what's coming.
vi: So she must remember this, remember what it was like, remember what’s coming.
tr: So she must remember this event, what it was like, what awaited her.
