es: So she should be able to remember this, to remember how it is and what will happen.

en: But who can remember pain, once it's over?
vi: But who can remember pain, once it’s over?
tr: But once it's over, who can remember the pain?
es: But who can remember the pain, once it has disappeared?

en: All that remains of it is a shadow, not in the mind even, in the flesh.
vi: All that remains is a shadow, not even in the mind, but in the flesh.
tr: All that remains is a shadow, not even in the mind, just in the body.
es: All that remains of it is a shadow, not even in the mind nor in the flesh.

en: Pain marks you, but too deep to see.
vi: Pain leaves a mark, but too deep to see.
tr: Pain leaves a mark on a person, but too deep to be seen.
es: Pain leaves a mark too deep to be seen, a mark that is beyond the reach of sight and mind.

en: Out of sight, out of mind.
vi: Out of sight, out of mind.
tr: Out of sight, out of mind.
es: Pain leaves a mark too deep to be seen, a mark that is beyond the reach of sight and mind.

en: Someone has spiked the grape juice.
vi: Someone has mixed wine into the grape juice.
tr: Someone has added alcohol to the grape juice.
es: Someone has finished the grape juice and someone has swiped a bottle.

en: Someone has pinched a bottle, from downstairs.
vi: Someone has stolen a bottle from downstairs.
tr: Someone has swiped a bottle from downstairs.
es: Someone has finished the grape juice and someone has swiped a bottle.

en: It won't be the first time at such a gathering; but they'll turn a blind eye.
vi: It's not the first time in gatherings like these, but they will turn a blind eye.
tr: This won't be the first time at such a gathering; but they will ignore it.
es: This is not the first time something like this has happened at a meeting of this kind; but they will turn a blind eye.

en: We too need our orgies.
vi: We also need to revel, don't we?
tr: We also need unregulated and wild parties.
es: We also need our orgies.

en: "Dim the lights," says Aunt Elizabeth.
vi: "Dim the lights," Aunt Elizabeth said.
tr: “Dim the lights,” says Aunt Elizabeth.
es: —Dim the lights —says Aunt Elizabeth—.

en: "Tell her it's time."
vi: "Tell her it's time."
tr: “Tell her that the time has come.”
es: Tell him that the time has come.

en: Someone stands, moves to the wall, the light in the room fades to twilight, our voices dwindle to a chorus of creaks, of husky whispers, like grasshoppers in a field at night.
vi: Someone stood up, went to the wall, the light in the room dimmed to a mere glimmer, our voices lowered into a creaky, hoarse whispering chorus, like crickets in the dark field.
tr: Someone stands up and moves towards the wall, the light in the room turns to twilight, our voices turn into a chorus of creaks and muffled whispers like crickets in a night field.
es: Someone stands up, walks to the wall, and the light becomes dimmer until the room is in semi-darkness; the tone of our voices decreases until it becomes a chorus of creaks, of hoarse murmurs, like grasshoppers in the night.

en: Two leave the room, two others lead Janine to the Birthing Stool,where she sits on the lower of the two seats.
vi: Two people left the room, two others took Janine to the Birthing Stool, to sit her on the low platform.
tr: Two people leave the room, the other two take Janine to the Birthing Chair and place her on the lower of the two seats.
es: Two women leave the room; two others lead Janine to the Birthing Chair, and she sits in the lower seat.

en: She's calmer now, air sucks evenly into her lungs, we lean forward, tensed, the muscles in our backs and bellies hurt from the strain.
vi: Now she had calmed down, the air entering her lungs more evenly, we leaned towards her, tense, our back and abdominal muscles straining painfully.
tr: Now Janine is calmer, drawing air into her lungs in a steady manner, we lean forward, tense, our back and abdominal muscles aching from the strain.
es: Now she is calmer, the air enters her lungs at a steady pace; we lean forward, we are so tense that our back and stomach muscles ache.

en: It's coming, it's coming, like a bugle, a call to arms, like a wall
vi: It was coming, it was coming, like a battle horn, calling for combat, like a collapsing wall, we could feel it as a heavy stone moving down, being dragged down inside us, we thought we were about to explode.
tr: It's coming, it's coming, like a trumpet, a call to arms, like a falling wall, descending, we can feel it like a heavy stone being pushed down inside us, we think we are going to explode.
es: It is coming, it is coming, like the sound of a bugle calling to arms, like a wall collapsing, it gives us the same sensation as a stone descending inside our bodies, and we think we are going to explode.

en: falling, we can feel it like a heavy stone moving down, pulled down inside us, we think we will burst.
vi: It was coming, it was coming, like a battle horn, calling for combat, like a collapsing wall, we could feel it as a heavy stone moving down, being dragged down inside us, we thought we were about to explode.
tr: It's coming, it's coming, like a trumpet, a call to arms, like a falling wall, descending, we can feel it like a heavy stone being pushed down inside us, we think we are going to explode.
es: It is coming, it is coming, like the sound of a bugle calling to arms, like a wall collapsing, it gives us the same sensation as a stone descending inside our bodies, and we think we are going to explode.

en: We grip each other's hands, we are no longer single.
vi: We clung to each other's hands, we were no longer individuals.
tr: We grasp each other's hands, we are no longer alone.
es: We hold hands, we are no longer alone.

en: The Commander's Wife hurries in, in her ridiculous while cotton nightgown, her spindly legs sticking out beneath iti.
vi: The Commander's Wife hurried in, still in her strange white nightgown, with her skinny legs sticking out underneath.
tr: The Commander's Wife rushes in, wearing a ridiculous white cotton nightgown with golden stork legs sticking out from underneath.
es: The Commander's Wife rushes in; she is still wearing the ridiculous white cotton nightgown, under which her lanky legs stick out.

en: Two of the Wives in their blue dresses and veils hold her by the arms, as if she needs it; she has a tight little smile on her face, like a hostess at a party she'd rather not be giving.
vi: Two other Wives, in blue robes, supported her arms, as if she needed it; on her face was a tense smile, like the hostess of a party reluctantly organized.
tr: Two of the Wives in blue dresses and veils hold her by the arms, as if she needed it; her face bears a small tense smile, like a hostess at a party she would prefer not to give.
es: Two Wives, dressed in blue suits and veils, hold her by the arms, as if she needed it. A tense smile is drawn on her face, like that of a hostess during a party she would have preferred not to host.

en: She must know what we think of her.
vi: She must have known what we thought of her.
tr: She must know what we think of her.
es: She must know what we think of her.

en: She scrambles onto the Birthing Stool, sts on theseat behind and above Janine, so that Janine is framed by her her skinny legs come down on either side, like the arms ol an eccentric chair Oddlly enough, she's wearing white cotton socks, and bedroom slippers, blue ones made of fuzzy material, like toilet covers.
vi: She struggled to climb onto the Birthing Stool, sitting on the upper backrest above Janine, enveloping her: her thin legs dangling down, like the armrests of an unusual armchair. Strangely, she wore white cotton socks and blue fuzzy slippers, like toilet seat covers.
tr: She climbs onto the birthing stool and settles on the seat behind and above Janine, so that Janine is enveloped by her: her skinny legs dangle down on either side like the arms of a bizarre chair. Strangely, she is also wearing white cotton socks and blue bedroom slippers made of the fluffy material used for toilet seat covers.
es: She climbs onto the Birthing Stool and sits in the seat that is behind and above Janine, in such a way that she surrounds Janine's body: her skinny legs are placed at the sides, like the arms of an eccentric chair. Strangely enough, she is wearing white cotton socks and blue slippers made of a fuzzy material, like toilet seat covers.

en: Hut we pay no attention to the Wife, we hardly even see her, our eyesi are on Janine.
vi: But we paid no attention to the Wife, almost not even seeing her, our eyes fixed on Janine.
tr: But we are not paying attention to the Woman, we hardly even see her, our eyes are on Janine.
es: But we do not pay attention to the Wife, we barely see her, our eyes are fixed on Janine.

en: In the dim light, in her white gown, she glows like a moon in cloud.
vi: In the dim light, wearing white, she glowed like the moon amidst a halo of clouds.
tr: In the dim light, she glows like the moon among the clouds in her white garment.
es: Under the dim light, dressed in her white outfit, she shines like a moon peeking through the clouds.

en: She's grunting now, with the effort.
vi: Now she is wheezing, making every effort.
tr: Now she is groaning because of the effort she is exerting.
es: Now Janine groans because of the effort.

en: "Push, push, push," we whisper.
vi: “Push, push, push,” we whispered.
tr: “Push, push, push,” we whisper.
es: —Push, push, push —we whisper—.

en: "Relax.
vi: “Relax.
tr: “Relax.
es: Relax.

en: Pant.
vi: Breathe hard.
tr: Breathe.
es: Pant.

en: Push, push, push."
vi: Push, push, push.”
tr: Push, push, push.”
es: Push, push, push —we accompany her, we are one with her, we are drunk.

en: We're with her, we're the same as her, we're drunk.
vi: We were with her, we were also her, we were dizzy with excitement.
tr: We are with her, we are the same as her, we are intoxicated.
es: Push, push, push —we accompany her, we are one with her, we are drunk.

en: Aunt Elizabeth kneels, with an outspread towel to catch the baby, here's the crowning, the glory, the head, purple and smeared with yoghurt, another push and it slithers out, slick with fluid and blood, into our waiting.
vi: Aunt Elizabeth knelt, holding the wide sheet ready to catch the baby, here came the crown, the halo, the head, purple and smeared with cream, one more push and it slipped out swiftly in water and blood, straight into our waiting arms.
tr: Aunt Elizabeth is kneeling, with a towel stretched out to catch the baby; here is the crowning and the triumph, a yogurt-covered purple head; another push and the head slides out, towards our expectation, bright and slippery with fluid and blood.
es: Aunt Elizabeth kneels; in her hands, she holds a towel spread out to catch the baby, here is the crowning of everything, the glory, the purple head stained with yogurt, another push and it will slide out, smeared with fluid and blood, fulfilling our wait.

en: Oh praise.
vi: Blessings.
tr: Thank God.
es: Oh, blessed be.

en: We hold our breath as Aunt Elizabeth inspects it: a girl, poor th?g, but so far so good, at least there's nothing wrong with it, tlhat can be seen, hands, feet, eyes, we silently count, everything is in place.
vi: We held our breath watching Aunt Elizabeth examine her: the girl, poor thing, but for now she was fine, at least nothing was broken, within visible range, arms, legs, eyes, we silently counted, everything in its place.
tr: We hold our breath as Aunt Elizabeth examines her: A girl; poor thing, but for now, she's very good, at least there's no visible disability, hands, feet, eyes, we silently count, everything is in place.
es: While Aunt Elizabeth inspects her, we hold our breath; it's a girl, very small, but for now, she's fine, she has no defects, that's already clear, hands, feet, eyes, we count them in silence, everything is in its place.

en: Aunt Elizabeth, holding the baby, looks up at us and smiles.
vi: Aunt Elizabeth, holding the child, looked up at us and smiled.
tr: Aunt Elizabeth, holding the baby, looks up at us and smiles.
es: With the baby in her arms, Aunt Elizabeth looks at us and smiles.

en: We smile too, we are one smile, tears run down our cheeks, we are so happy.
vi: We also smiled, we shared a common smile, tears rolling down our faces, we were so happy.
tr: We smile too, a single smile, tears stream down our cheeks, we are so happy.
es: We also smile, we are one single smile, tears fall down our cheeks, we are very happy.

en: Our happiness is part memory.
vi: In that joy, there is a part of memory.
tr: Our happiness partly stems from memories.
es: Our happiness is, in part, memory.

en: What I remember is Luke, with me in the hospital, standing beside myhead, holding my hand, in the green gown and white mask they gave him.
vi: I remember remembering Luke, beside me in the hospital, standing at the head of the bed, holding my hand tightly, wearing a blue gown and a white mask provided.
tr: The Luke I remember is standing with me in the hospital, holding my hand, dressed in the green outfit and white mask they gave him.
es: What I remember is Luke when he was with me in the hospital, standing by my head, holding my hand, dressed in the green gown and white mask they had provided him.

en: Oh, he said, oh Jesus, breath coming out in wonder.
vi: Oh, he said, oh Jesus, his breath exhaled in admiration.
tr: Oh, he said, Oh, my God, he was breathing in astonishment.
es: Oh, he exclaimed, oh, Jesus, with a sigh of surprise.

en: That night he couldn't go to sleep at all, he said, he was so high.
vi: That night he couldn't sleep at all, he said, too excited.
tr: He said he couldn't sleep at all that night, he was so excited.
es: He said that night he felt so important that he couldn't sleep a wink.

en: Aunt Elizabeth is gently washing the baby off, it isn't crying much, it stops.
vi: Aunt Elizabeth is gently bathing the baby clean, it doesn't cry much, it's quiet now.
tr: Aunt Elizabeth is gently washing the baby, the baby didn't cry much, and now is quiet.
es: Aunt Elizabeth is carefully washing the baby, who doesn't cry too much.

en: As quietly as possible, so as not to startle it, we rise, crowd around Janine, squeezing her, patting her.
vi: Very softly, to avoid startling it, we stood up, gathered around Janine, hugged her, and comforted her.
tr: To avoid startling the baby, we quietly stand up and gather around Janine, stroking her and lightly tapping her arm.
es: As silently as possible, so as not to startle him, we get up, we huddle around Janine, we hug her, we pat her on the back.

en: She's crying too.
vi: She was crying too.
tr: She is crying too.
es: She is also crying.

en: The two Wives in blue help the third Wife, the Wife of the household, down from the Birthing Stool and over to the bed, where they lay her down and tuck her in.
vi: The two blue-clad Wives helped the third Wife, the house's mistress, down from the Birthing Stool to the bed, laid her down, and tucked her in.
tr: Two Blue Wives help the third Wife, the Wife of the house, down from the Birth Chair and take her to the bed, laying her down and covering her.
es: The two Wives in blue help the third Wife, the Wife of the family, to get down from the Birthing Chair and onto the bed, where they lay her down and tuck her in.

en: The baby, washed now and quiet, is placed ceremoniously in her arms.
vi: The baby, clean and silent, was solemnly placed into her hands.
tr: The now washed and quiet baby is ceremoniously placed in her arms.
es: The baby, now clean and calm, is ceremoniously placed in her arms.

en: The Wives from downstairs are crowding in now, pushing among us, pushing us aside.
vi: The Wives downstairs were now pouring in, jostling past us, pushing us aside.
tr: The Wives from downstairs now crowd in, pushing us aside.
es: The Wives who are downstairs come up in a rush, pushing us aside.

en: They talk too loud, some of them are still carrying their plates, their coffee cups, their wine glasses, some of them are still chewing, they cluster around the bed, the mother and child, cooing and congratulating.
vi: They were so noisy, some carrying plates, cups of coffee, glasses of wine, some still chewing, they crowded around the bed, mother and child, cooing and congratulating.
tr: They are talking very loudly, some still carrying their plates, coffee cups, wine glasses, some with their mouths still full, chirping and congratulating as they gather around the bed, the mother, and the baby.
es: They speak very loudly, some of them still carrying their plates, their coffee cups, their wine glasses, some still chewing, they crowd around the bed, around the mother and the child, congratulating and cooing.

en: Envy radiates from them, I can smell it, faint wisps of acid, mingled with their perfume.
vi: Jealousy emanated from them, I could smell it, a faint acidic scent mixed with perfume.
tr: Jealousy emanates from them, I can smell it, faint acid particles mixed with their perfumes.
es: Envy emanates from them, I can smell it, like faint traces of acid mixed with their perfume.

en: The Commander's Wife looks down at the baby as if it's a bouquet of flowers: something she's won, a tribute.
vi: The Commander’s Wife looked down at the baby as if looking at a bouquet: something she had won, a tribute.
tr: The Commander's Wife looks at the baby as if it were a bouquet of flowers: something she has won, a source of pride.
es: The Commander's Wife looks at the baby as if it were a bouquet of flowers, something she has won, a tribute.

en: The Wives are here to bear witness to the naming.
vi: The Ladies came here to witness the naming ceremony.
tr: The Spouses are here to witness the naming ceremony.
es: The Wives are here as witnesses to the name selection.

en: It's the Wives who do the naming, around here.
vi: The naming is the duty of the Lady in this region.
tr: The Spouses perform the naming ceremony here.
es: They are the ones who choose it.

en: "Angela," says the Commander's Wife.
vi: “Angela,” the General's wife announced.
tr: “Angela,” says the Commander's Wife.
es: —Angela —says the Commander's Wife.

en: "Angela, Angela," the Wives repeat, twittering.
vi: “Angela, Angela,” the ladies repeated, chirping.
tr: “Angela, Angela,” the Wives chirped, repeating.
es: —Angela, Angela —the Wives repeat nervously—.

en: "What a sweet name!
vi: “Such a lovely name!
tr: “What a sweet name!
es: What a sweet name!

en: Oh.
vi: “Such a lovely name!
tr: Oh, perfect!
es: Oh, she is perfect!

en: she's perfect!
vi: The girl is truly perfect!
tr: Oh, perfect!
es: Oh, she is perfect!

en: Oh, she's wonderful!"
vi: The girl is absolutely wonderful!”
tr: Oh, wonderful!”
es: Oh, she is wonderful!

en: We stand between Janine and the bed, so she won't have to see this.
vi: I stood blocking Janine from the bed, so she wouldn't have to witness that scene.
tr: We stand between Janine and the bed, so she doesn't have to see it.
es: We stand between Janine and the bed, so she cannot see him.

en: Someone gives her a drink of grape juice, I hope there's wine in it, she's still having the pains, forthe afterbirth, she's crying helplessly, burnt-out miserable tears.
vi: Someone gave her a sip of grape juice, I hope it was mixed with wine, she was still convulsing, pushing out the placenta, she was crying helplessly, with those damn burning tears.
tr: Someone gives her a glass of grape juice, I hope it has wine in it, she is still in pain, for the placenta to come, crying desperately; burnt, miserable tears.
es: Someone gives her a sip of grape juice, I hope they added wine; she still feels the postpartum pains, crying inconsolably, consumed by tears.

en: Nevertheless we are jubilant, it's a victory, for all of us.
vi: But despite everything, we rejoiced, this was a victory for all of us.
tr: Still, we are very happy, this is a victory, for all of us.
es: However, we feel somewhat touched; this is a victory for all of us.

en: We've done it.
vi: We had done it.
tr: We did this job.
es: We have achieved it.

en: She'll be allowed to nurse the baby, for a few months, they believe in mother's milk.
vi: She will be allowed to take care of the baby, and in the first few months, they encourage the use of breast milk.
tr: They will allow her to feed the baby for a few months because they believe in the benefits of breast milk.
es: They will allow her to feed the baby for a few months. They believe in breast milk.

en: After that she'll be transferred, to see if she can do it again, with someone else who needs a turn.
vi: After that, she will be given a trip to see if she can do it again, with someone else who needs a turn.
tr: Then she will be sent somewhere else to see if she can repeat this with someone in need.
es: Afterwards, Janine will be transferred to see if she can do it again with someone else who needs a change.

en: But she'll never be sent to the Colonies, she'll never be declared Unwoman.
vi: But she will never be sent to the Colonies, nor be declared an Unwoman.
tr: But she will never be sent to the Colonies, never be declared an Unwoman.
es: But she will never be sent to the Colonies, she will never be declared Unwoman.

en: That is her reward.
vi: A reward for her.
tr: That is her reward.
es: That is her reward.

en: The Birthmobile is waiting outside, to deliver us back to our own households.
vi: The Transport vehicle is waiting outside, taking us back to each of our homes.
tr: The birth carriage is waiting outside to take us to our own homes.
es: The Birthmobile is outside, waiting to take us back to our homes.

en: The doctors are still in their van; their faces appear at the window, white blobs, like the faces of sick children confined to
vi: The doctors are still in their car; their faces appear at the window, pale patches, like sick children's faces trapped indoors.
tr: The doctors are still inside their minibus; their faces appear in the window, white spots, like the faces of sick children confined at home.
es: The doctors are still in the van; through the window, we see their faces like white smudges, like the face of a sick child confined to their home.

en: the house.
vi: One person opens the car door towards us.
tr: The doctors are still inside their minibus; their faces appear in the window, white spots, like the faces of sick children confined at home.
es: One of them opens the door and approaches us.

en: One of them opens the door and comes towards us.
vi: One person opens the car door towards us.
tr: One of them opens the door and comes towards us.
es: One of them opens the door and approaches us.

en: "Was it all right?" he asks, anxious.
vi: "Is everything okay?" he asked, worried.
tr: "Did it go well during the birth?" he asks anxiously.
es: —Did everything go well? —he asks anxiously.

en: "Yes," I say.
vi: "It's all right," I said.
tr: “Yes,” I say.
es: —Yes —I respond.

en: By now I'm wrung out, exhausted.
vi: By now, I was exhausted, completely worn out.
tr: I am now in a state of boredom and exhaustion.
es: At this moment, I feel torn, exhausted.

en: My breasts are painful, they're leaking a little.
vi: My chest ached, it was leaking.
tr: My breasts are aching, slightly leaking milk.
es: My breasts hurt, they even leak; it's a substitute for milk, it happens to some of us.

en: Fake milk, it happens this way with some of us.
vi: Fake milk, some of us would experience this.
tr: False milk, some of us are affected this way.
es: My breasts hurt, they even leak; it's a substitute for milk, it happens to some of us.

en: We sit on our benches, facing one another, as we are transported; we're without emotion now, almost without feeling, we might be bundles of red cloth.
vi: We sat on the bench, facing each other, on the way back; now we were devoid of all emotions, almost all sensations, just bundles of red cloth.
tr: As we are taken away, we sit on our benches looking at each other; we are now emotionless, almost numb, we could be a bundle of red cloth.
es: We sit on our benches, facing each other, as we are transported; we are left without emotion, almost without sensations, we must be like bundles of red cloth.

en: We ache.
vi: We were in pain.
tr: We are in pain.
es: Everything hurts.

en: Each of us holds in her lap a phantom, a ghost baby.
vi: Each of us cradled a ghost, a phantom baby.
tr: Each of us holds an imaginary, ghostly baby in her lap.
es: In our laps, we carry a specter, a ghost baby.

en: What confronts us, now the excitement's over, is our own failure.
vi: Facing us, when the excitement had passed, was our own failure.
tr: What we face now, after the excitement has passed, is our own failure.
es: Now that the nervousness has passed, we must face the failure.

en: Mother, I think.
vi: Mother, I thought.
tr: Mother, I think.
es: Mother, I think.

en: Wherever you may be.
vi: Wherever you are.
tr: Wherever you are.
es: Wherever you are, can you hear me?

en: Can you hear me?
vi: Can you hear me?
tr: Can you hear me?
es: Wherever you are, can you hear me?

en: You wanted a women's culture.
vi: You wanted a culture of women.
tr: You wanted a civilization of women.
es: You wanted a culture of women.

en: Well, now there is one.
vi: Now there is one.
tr: Yes, now there is one.
es: Well, here you have it.

en: It isn't what you meant, but it exists.
vi: Not exactly as you imagined, but it exists.
tr: This is not what you meant, but here it is nonetheless.
es: It is not what you intended, but it exists.

en: Be thankful for small mercies.
vi: Be grateful for small blessings.
tr: Be thankful for small mercies.
es: You have something to be thankful for.
CHAPTER 22

en: By the time the Birthmobile arrives in front of the house, it's late afternoon.
vi: By the time Van's car stopped in front of the house, it was late afternoon.
tr: When the birth carriage arrived in front of the house, it was already afternoon.
es: The Birthmobile arrives at the house late in the afternoon.

en: The sun is coming weakly through the clouds, the smell of wet grass warming up is in the air.
vi: The weak sun shone through the clouds, and the smell of wet grass warmed in the air.
tr: The sun was passing wearily through the clouds, and the scent of the warming, damp grass hung in the air.
es: The sun shines faintly through the clouds, and the scent of damp grass beginning to warm up floats in the air.

en: I've been at the Birth all day; you lose track of time.
vi: I had attended the Sinh event all day; it felt like time had completely disappeared.
tr: So, I spent the whole day in Doğum; one loses the sense of time.
es: I've spent the whole day at the Birth ceremony, and I've lost track of time.

en: Cora will have done the shopping today, I'm excused from all duties.
vi: Today, Cora had probably finished shopping, and I was free from all duties.
tr: Cora will do the shopping; today I am relieved of all duties.
es: Today's shopping must have been done by Cora, because I am exempt from all obligations.

en: I go up the stairs, lifting my feet heavily from one step to the next, holding on to the banister.
vi: I went upstairs, my legs heavy as I lifted them from one step to the next, gripping the handrail tightly.
tr: I am climbing the stairs, shifting my weight from one foot to the other weakly and holding onto the banister.
es: I climb the stairs, heavily lifting my feet from one step to the next and holding onto the railing.

en: I feel as if I've been awake for days and running hard;my chest hurts, my muscles cramp as if they're out of sugar.
vi: I felt as if I had been awake for many days and had run a lot; my chest hurt, and my muscles contracted as if lacking sugar.
tr: I feel as if I have been awake for days and running endlessly, my chest hurts; my muscles are cramping as if deprived of sugar.
es: I feel as if I have been on my feet for several days, running all the time; my chest hurts and my muscles cramp as if I were lacking sugar.

en: For once I welcome solitude.
vi: For once, I welcomed the solitude.
tr: This time, I accept the silence with contentment.
es: For once in my life, I long to be alone.

en: I lie on the bed.
vi: I lay down on the bed.
tr: I am in bed.
es: I lie down on the bed.

en: I would like to rest, go to sleep, but I'm too tired, at the same time too excited, my eyes won't close.
vi: I wanted to rest, to sleep, but I was too tired and too agitated to close my eyes.
tr: I would like to rest, to sleep, but I am very tired, and at the same time very excited; my eyes will not close.
es: I would like to rest, fall asleep, but I am too fatigued and at the same time so excited that I couldn't close my eyes.

en: I look up at the ceiling, tracing the foliage of the wreath.
vi: I looked up at the ceiling, tracing the edges of the wreath.
tr: I am looking at the ceiling, watching the leaves of the wreath.
es: I gaze at the flat sky or, following with my eyes the leaves of the garland.

en: Today it makes me think of a hat, the large-brimmed hats women used to wear at some period during the old days: hats like enormous halos, festooned with fruit and flowers, and the feathers of exotic birds; hats like an idea of paradise, floating just above the head, a thought solidified.
vi: Today, I saw it again as a hat, the kind of wide-brimmed hat that women used to wear in a bygone era: a hat like a giant halo, adorned with flowers, fruits, and feathers of tropical birds; a hat like a sketch of paradise, floating right above the head, a concept materialized.
tr: Today it reminds me of a hat, the wide-brimmed hats that women used to wear in a period of the old days: hats that resembled gigantic halos, adorned with fruits and flowers and the feathers of exotic birds; hats that suggested the idea of a paradise floating just above the head, like a thought embodied in flesh and bone.
es: Today it reminds me of a hat, one of those wide-brimmed ones that women used to wear in the past: hats like enormous halos, adorned with fruits and flowers and feathers of exotic birds; hats that represented the idea of paradise floating exactly above the head, a solidified thought.

en: In a minute the wreath will start to color and I will begin seeing things.
vi: In just a moment, the wreath will start to change color and I will see illusions.
tr: Soon the wreath will start to color, and I will begin to see things.
es: In a minute, the garland will start to change color and I will start to see things.

en: That's how tired I am: as when you'd driven all night, into the dawn, for some reason, I won't think about that now, keeping each other awake with stories and taking turns at the wheel, and as the
vi: I am that tired: as if I had been driving all night, until dawn, for some reason, which I will not think about now, helping each other stay awake by telling stories and taking turns driving, and when the sun begins to rise, we will see all sorts of things in the corner of our eyes: purple animals in the bushes by the road, vague human shapes that will disappear if you look directly at them.
tr: That's how tired I am: Like when you drive all night long, keeping each other awake with stories and taking turns at the wheel, for some reason - I can't come up with a reason now - until dawn; as the sun begins to rise, you start to see things at the corners of your eyes: purple animals in the bushes by the road, vague shadows of people that disappear when you look directly at them.
es: This is how exhausted I am: just like when you've been driving all night, in the dark, for some reason, now I must not think about that, telling stories to keep ourselves awake and taking turns driving, and as the sun rises, you start to see things out of the corner of your eye: monstrous animals in the roadside bushes, blurred silhouettes of men that disappear when you look at them directly.

en: sun would begin to come up you'd see things at the sides of your eyes: purple animals, in the bushes beside the road, the vague outlines of men, which would disappear when you looked at them straight.
vi: I am that tired: as if I had been driving all night, until dawn, for some reason, which I will not think about now, helping each other stay awake by telling stories and taking turns driving, and when the sun begins to rise, we will see all sorts of things in the corner of our eyes: purple animals in the bushes by the road, vague human shapes that will disappear if you look directly at them.
tr: That's how tired I am: Like when you drive all night long, keeping each other awake with stories and taking turns at the wheel, for some reason - I can't come up with a reason now - until dawn; as the sun begins to rise, you start to see things at the corners of your eyes: purple animals in the bushes by the road, vague shadows of people that disappear when you look directly at them.
es: This is how exhausted I am: just like when you've been driving all night, in the dark, for some reason, now I must not think about that, telling stories to keep ourselves awake and taking turns driving, and as the sun rises, you start to see things out of the corner of your eye: monstrous animals in the roadside bushes, blurred silhouettes of men that disappear when you look at them directly.

en: I'm too tired to go on with this story.
vi: I am too tired to continue this story.
tr: I am too tired to continue this story.
es: I am too tired to continue with this story.

en: I'm too tired to think about where I am.
vi: I am too tired to even think about where I am.
tr: I am too tired to think about where I am.
es: I am too tired to think about where I am.

en: Here is a different story, a better one.
vi: Well, here is a different story, a better one.
tr: Here is a different, better story for you.
es: Here goes a different story, a better one.

en: This is the story of what happened to Moira.
vi: A story about what happened to Moira.
tr: This is the story of what happened to Moira.
es: This is the story of what happened to Moira.

en: Part of it I can fill in myself, part of it I heard from Alma, who heard it from Dolores, who heard it from Janine.
