es: I could hit you with this, or stab it into your eye.

en: Just remember I didn't, if it ever comes to that.
vi: But remember that I didn't, if it ever comes to that.
tr: Don't ever forget that I didn't do those things, in case things come to that point.
es: Simply, if the occasion ever arises, remember that I didn't do it.

en: Aunt Lydia didn't repeat any of this part to Janine, but I expect Moira said something like it.
vi: Aunt Lydia did not repeat any of it to Janine, but I guess Moira said something similar.
tr: Aunt Lydia never told Janine about this part, but I'm sure Moira said similar things.
es: Aunt Lydia didn't tell this last part to Janine, but I suppose Moira said something like that.

en: In any case she didn't kill or mutilate Aunt Elizabeth, who a few days later, after she'd recovered from her seven hours behind the furnace and presumably from the interrogationfor
vi: Anyway, she did not kill or mutilate Aunt Elizabeth, and a few days later, having recovered after seven hours of being pressed against the stove, and possibly after an interrogation as well - the possibility of collusion cannot be ruled out, whether by the aunts or anyone else - she was seen back at her duties at the Center.
tr: Anyway, Aunt Elizabeth neither killed nor injured anyone, and after recovering from the seven hours she spent behind the boiler and the probable interrogation—because they did not rule out the possibility of collusion between the Aunts and others—she returned to her job at the Center.
es: In any case, she didn't kill or mutilate Aunt Elizabeth who, a few days later, once she recovered from the seven hours spent behind the oven, and probably from the interrogation — because neither the Aunts nor the others had ruled out the possibility of complicity — returned to the Center to work.

en: the possibility of collusion would not have been ruled out, by the
vi: Anyway, she did not kill or mutilate Aunt Elizabeth, and a few days later, having recovered after seven hours of being pressed against the stove, and possibly after an interrogation as well - the possibility of collusion cannot be ruled out, whether by the aunts or anyone else - she was seen back at her duties at the Center.
tr: Anyway, Aunt Elizabeth neither killed nor injured anyone, and after recovering from the seven hours she spent behind the boiler and the probable interrogation—because they did not rule out the possibility of collusion between the Aunts and others—she returned to her job at the Center.
es: In any case, she didn't kill or mutilate Aunt Elizabeth who, a few days later, once she recovered from the seven hours spent behind the oven, and probably from the interrogation — because neither the Aunts nor the others had ruled out the possibility of complicity — returned to the Center to work.

en: Aunts or by anyone elsewas back in operation at the Center.
vi: Anyway, she did not kill or mutilate Aunt Elizabeth, and a few days later, having recovered after seven hours of being pressed against the stove, and possibly after an interrogation as well - the possibility of collusion cannot be ruled out, whether by the aunts or anyone else - she was seen back at her duties at the Center.
tr: Anyway, Aunt Elizabeth neither killed nor injured anyone, and after recovering from the seven hours she spent behind the boiler and the probable interrogation—because they did not rule out the possibility of collusion between the Aunts and others—she returned to her job at the Center.
es: In any case, she didn't kill or mutilate Aunt Elizabeth who, a few days later, once she recovered from the seven hours spent behind the oven, and probably from the interrogation — because neither the Aunts nor the others had ruled out the possibility of complicity — returned to the Center to work.

en: Moira stood up straight and looked firmly ahead.
vi: Moira stood up straight, her eyes resolutely looking forward.
tr: Moira straightened up and looked ahead with determination.
es: Moira stood up and looked resolutely ahead.

en: She drew her shoulders back, pulled up her spine, and compressed her lips.
vi: She squared her shoulders, straightened her back, and pressed her lips together.
tr: She pulled her shoulders back, straightened her back, and pursed her lips.
es: He put his shoulders back, straightened his spine, and pressed his lips together.

en: This was not our usual posture.
vi: It was not our usual posture.
tr: This was not our usual posture.
es: This was not our usual posture.

en: Usually we walked with heads bent down, our eyes on our hands or the ground.
vi: On normal days, we walked with our heads bowed, looking at our hands or just at the ground.
tr: Generally, we walked with our gaze lowered, eyes on our hands or the ground.
es: We generally walked with our heads down, our eyes fixed on our hands or the ground.

en: Moira didn't look much like Aunt Elizabeth, even with the brown wimple in place, but her stiff-backed posture was apparently enough to convince the Angels on guard, who never looked at any ofus very closely, even and perhaps especially the Aunts; because Moira marched straight out the front door, with the bearing of a person who knew where she was going; was saluted, presented Aunt Elizabeth's pass, which they didn't bother to check, becausewho would affront an Aunt in that way.
vi: Moira didn't look much like Aunt Elizabeth, even though she was wearing the brown veil, but that straight-backed posture clearly convinced the Angels standing guard, who had never really looked closely at any of us, especially, or rather most of all, the Aunts; because Moira boldly walked straight to the main door, with the demeanor of someone who knew exactly where she was going; she received their nods, presented Aunt Elizabeth's pass, which they didn't even bother to check, because who would dare be disrespectful to the Aunts like that.
tr: Moira did not much resemble Aunt Elizabeth, even with the brown headscarf, but her upright stance was enough to convince the Angels, who never looked at any of us, not even the Aunts, and perhaps especially not them, because Moira walked out the front door with the demeanor of someone who knew exactly where she was going; she was greeted, showed Aunt Elizabeth's ID, and they didn't bother to check it, because who would dare insult an Aunt in such a manner?
es: Moira didn't look much like Aunt Elizabeth, not even with the brown habit on; but her rigid posture was apparently enough to convince the Angels who were on guard and who had never seen us very closely, not even the Aunts, and perhaps them least of all. So Moira walked straight to the front door, with the bearing of someone who knows where they are going; the Angels greeted her and she presented Aunt Elizabeth's pass, which they didn't bother to examine because no one would insult one of the Aunts in that way.

en: And disappeared.
vi: And she disappeared.
tr: And she disappeared.
es: And she disappeared.

en: Oh, said Janine.
vi: Oh, Janine said.
tr: Oh, said Janine.
es: Oh, said Janine.

en: Who can tell what she felt?
vi: Who knows what she feels?
tr: Who knows what she felt?
es: Who knows what she felt?

en: Maybe she wanted to cheer.
vi: Maybe she wants to cheer.
tr: Maybe she liked it.
es: Maybe she was glad.

en: If so, she kept it well hidden.
vi: If so, she hides it too well.
tr: If so, she did a good job of hiding it.
es: If so, she hid it very well.

en: So, Janine, said Aunt Lydia.
vi: That's it, Janine, Aunt Lydia said.
tr: In this case, Janine, said Aunt Lydia.
es: So, Janine, Aunt Lydia said, this is what I want you to do.

en: Here is what I want you to do.
vi: I want to ask you to do this.
tr: This is what I want you to do.
es: So, Janine, Aunt Lydia said, this is what I want you to do.

en: Janine opened her eyes wide and tried to look innocent and attentive.
vi: Janine opened her eyes wide, trying to appear innocent and attentive.
tr: Janine tried to look innocent and attentive by opening her eyes wide.
es: Janine opened her eyes wide and tried to appear innocent and attentive.

en: I want you to keep your ears open.
vi: I want you to wear the headphones.
tr: I want you to keep your eyes and ears wide open.
es: I want you to open your eyes wide.

en: Maybe one of the others was involved.
vi: There might be someone else involved.
tr: Maybe one of the others is also involved.
es: Maybe one of the others was involved in this.

en: Yes, Aunt Lydia, said Janine.
vi: Yes, Aunt Lydia, Janine said.
tr: Well, Aunt Lydia, said Janine.
es: Yes, Aunt Lydia, said Janine.

en: And come and tell me about it, won't you, dear?
vi: Then come and let me know, okay, little girl?
tr: Then come and tell me, okay, my dear?
es: And if you hear something, come and tell me, will you, dear?

en: If you hear anything.
vi: If you hear anything?
tr: If you hear something.
es: And if you hear something, come and tell me, will you, dear?

en: Yes, Aunt Lydia, said Janine.
vi: Yes, Aunt Lydia, Janine said.
tr: Well, Aunt Lydia, said Janine.
es: Yes, Aunt Lydia, said Janine.

en: She knew she would not have to kneel down anymore, at the front of the classroom, anil listen to all of us shouting at her that it was her fault.
vi: She knew she would no longer have to kneel down, in front of the whole class, listening to all of us scream in her face that it was her fault.
tr: She had realized that she no longer had to kneel in front of the class and listen to all of us shout that it was her own fault.
es: She knew she would never have to kneel at the front of the class again, nor hear all of us shouting that it had been her fault.

en: Now it would be someone else for a while.
vi: Soon, it would be someone else.
tr: Now, for a while, someone else would do that.
es: Now it would be someone else's turn.

en: She was, temporarily, off the hook.
vi: For the time being, she escaped the fate of being hung out to dry.
tr: She had, temporarily, gotten away with it.
es: For the moment, she was off the hook.

en: The fact that she told Dolores all about this encounter in Aunt Lydia's office meant nothing.
vi: It doesn't mean anything if she tells Dolores everything about this meeting.
tr: There was no point in the fact that she told Dolores everything about this encounter in Aunt Lydia's office.
es: The fact that she told Dolores everything about the interview in Aunt Lydia's office meant nothing.

en: It didn't mean she wouldn't testify against us, any of us, if she had the occasion.
vi: It doesn't mean she won't testify against us, any of us, whenever she gets the chance.
tr: This did not mean that she wouldn't betray us, any of us, when she had the chance.
es: It didn't mean that she wouldn't testify against us, against any of us, if given the chance.

en: We knew that.
vi: We understand.
tr: We knew this.
es: We knew that.

en: By this time we were treating her the way people used to treat those with no legs who sold pencils on street corners.
vi: Until now, we have treated her like people used to treat legless individuals selling pencils on the street corner.
tr: At that time, we treated her like people used to treat those who sold pens on street corners, who had no legs.
es: Back then, we treated her the same way people used to treat one of those legless individuals who sell pencils on street corners.

en: We avoided her when we could, were
vi: Avoid as much as possible, compassionate when unavoidable.
tr: If we could, we avoided her; when that wasn't possible, we treated her with compassion.
es: We avoided her whenever we could and were charitable to her when we had no other choice.

en: charitable to her when it couldn't be helped.
vi: Avoid as much as possible, compassionate when unavoidable.
tr: If we could, we avoided her; when that wasn't possible, we treated her with compassion.
es: We avoided her whenever we could and were charitable to her when we had no other choice.

en: She was a danger to us, we knew that.
vi: She is a threat to everyone, we know.
tr: She was a danger to us, we knew this.
es: She represented a danger to us, we knew that.

en: Dolores probably patted her on the back and said she was a good sport to tell us.
vi: Dolores must have praised her, saying that telling it like that was very good.
tr: Dolores likely patted Janine on the back and said that by telling us this, she proved her friendship.
es: Dolores probably patted her on the back and told her she was a good companion when she told us.

en: Where did this exchange take place?
vi: Where did this conversation take place?
tr: Where did this conversation take place?
es: Where did this exchange take place?

en: In the gymnasium, when we were getting ready for bed.
vi: In the gymnasium, when getting ready for bed.
tr: In the gym, while getting ready for bed.
es: In the gym, while we were getting ready for bed.

en: Dolores had the bed next to Janine's.
vi: Dolores lay in the bed right next to Janine.
tr: Dolores' bed was next to Janine's.
es: Dolores's bed was next to Janine's.

en: The story passed among us that night, in the semidarkness, under our breath, from bed to bed.
vi: The story was passed among us that night, in the twilight, in soft breaths, from one bed to another.
tr: The story was told that night, in the semi-darkness, whispered from bed to bed.
es: That night, the tale of what had happened spread among us, in the semi-darkness, in hushed tones, from bed to bed.

en: Moira was out there somewhere.
vi: Moira is somewhere out there.
tr: Moira was there, somewhere outside.
es: Moira was outside, somewhere.

en: She was at large, or dead.
vi: Free, or already dead.
tr: She was either free or dead.
es: She was either free or dead.

en: What would she do?
vi: What does she intend to do?
tr: What was she going to do?
es: What would she do?

en: The thought of what she would do expanded till it filled the room.
vi: The thought of what she intends to do keeps expanding, until it fills the entire room.
tr: The thought of what she was going to do expanded and expanded until it filled the room.
es: The thought of what she would do expanded until it filled the entire room.

en: At any moment there might be a shattering explosion, the glass of the windows would fall inward, the doors would swing openMoira had power now, she'd been set loose, she'd set herself loose.
vi: At any moment, there could be a loud explosion, glass shattering inward, the main doors bursting open...
tr: At any moment, there could be a clattering explosion, window glass could scatter inside, doors could swing wide open.
es: At any moment, an explosion could occur that would destroy everything, the window panes would fall inward, the doors would swing wide open... Now Moira had power, she had been set free, she had set herself free.

en: She was now a loose woman.
vi: Now Moira has power, she has been released, she has freed herself. She is now a liberated woman.
tr: ... The power was now with Moira, she had been set free, she had set herself free. She was now a free woman.
es: Now she was a free woman.

en: I think we found this frightening.
vi: I think at that moment we felt terrified.
tr: I think we had found this scary.
es: I think it seemed awful to us.

en: Moira was like an elevator with open sides.
vi: Moira is like an elevator shaft without walls.
tr: Moira was like an elevator with open sides.
es: Moira was like an elevator with open sides.

en: She made us dizzy.
vi: She makes us dizzy.
tr: It made our heads spin.
es: She made us dizzy.

en: Already we were losing the taste for freedom, already we were finding these walls secure.
vi: By now, we have already lost our desire for freedom, finding security within four walls.
tr: We had already started to lose the taste of freedom and began to find these walls safe.
es: We were already losing our taste for freedom, it already seemed to us that these walls were safe.

en: In the upper reaches of the atmosphere you'd come apart, you'd vaporize, there would be no pressure holding you together.
vi: The high atmospheric layers would make people disappear, evaporate, without enough pressure to keep them intact.
tr: In the upper layers of the atmosphere, you would disintegrate and evaporate; there would be no pressure to hold you together.
es: In the higher layers of the atmosphere you could disintegrate, vaporize, there would be no pressure to keep you together.

en: Nevertheless Moira was our fantasy.
vi: But Moira was still our dream.
tr: Still, Moira was our dream.
es: Anyway, Moira was our fantasy.

en: We hugged her to us, she was with us in secret, a giggle; she was lava beneath the crust of daily life.
vi: We embraced her, she was still here in secret, like a crisp laugh; she was the lava beneath the surface of everyday life.
tr: We had embraced her, she was secretly with us, she was a giggle; the lava beneath the shell of daily life.
es: We hugged her and she was with us in secret, like a stifled giggle. She was like the lava beneath the crust of everyday life.

en: In the light of Moira, the Aunts were less fearsome and more absurd.
vi: With Moira illuminating them, the aunts became less frightening and more ridiculous.
tr: Under Moira's light, the Aunts were less frightening and more ridiculous.
es: In the light of Moira, the Aunts seemed less fearsome and more absurd.

en: Their power had a flaw to it.
vi: Their power also had flaws.
tr: A crack had formed in their power.
es: Their power had cracks.

en: They could be shanghaied in toilets.
vi: They could be intimidated in the bathroom.
tr: They could be dealt with in the toilets.
es: They could be kidnapped in the bathrooms.

en: The audacity was what we liked.
vi: That brazenness delighted us.
tr: It was the audacity that we liked.
es: It was the audacity that we liked.

en: We expected her to be dragged in at any minute, as she had been before.
vi: We are waiting for her to be dragged back at any moment, just like last time.
tr: We were expecting her to be dragged in at any moment, just like before.
es: We supposed that at any moment they would drag her in, as they had done before.

en: We could not imagine what they might do to her this time.
vi: We can't imagine what they might do to her this time.
tr: This time, we couldn't imagine what they might do to her.
es: We couldn't imagine what they would do to her this time.

en: It would be very bad, whatever it was.
vi: Whatever it is, it will surely be very bad.
tr: Whatever it was, it was certain to be very bad.
es: Whatever it was, it would be terrible.

en: But nothing happened.
vi: But there was nothing.
tr: But nothing happened.
es: But nothing happened.

en: Moira didn't reappear.
vi: Moira did not reappear.
tr: Moira did not reappear.
es: Moira did not appear again.

en: She hasn't yet.
vi: Not yet, anyway.
tr: Not yet.
es: For now.
CHAPTER 23

en: This is a reconstruction.
vi: This is a reconstruction.
tr: This is a reenactment.
es: This is a reconstruction.

en: All of it is a reconstruction.
vi: Everything is a reconstruction.
tr: All of this is a reenactment.
es: All of this is a reconstruction.

en: It's a
vi: Everything is a reconstruction.
tr: All of this is a reenactment.
es: All of this is a reconstruction.

en: recon-stfuction now, in my head, as I lie flat on my single bed rehearsing what I should or shouldn't have said, what I should or shouldn't have done, how I should have played it.
vi: It is a reconstruction right now, in my head, lying flat on the bed, reviewing over and over again the things that should have been said or shouldn't have been said, should have been done or shouldn't have been done, should have been handled in such and such a way.
tr: This is a reenactment now, lying flat on my single bed, rehearsing in my mind what to say and what not to say, what to do and what not to do, how to act.
es: It is a reconstruction that is taking place now, in my head, while I am lying on my single bed, reviewing what I should or should not have said, what I should or should not have done, how I should have acted.

en: If I ever get out of here
vi: If I ever get out of here...
tr: If I were to get out of here-
es: If I ever get out of here...

en: Let's stop there.
vi: Stop it right now.
tr: Let's cut it there.
es: Let's stop at this point.

en: I intend to get out of here.
vi: I'm going to get out of here.
tr: My goal is to get out of here.
es: I intend to leave here.

en: It can't last forever.
vi: It can't be like this forever.
tr: This can't last forever.
es: This cannot last a lifetime.

en: Others have thought such things, in bad times before this, and they were always right, they did get out one way or another, and it didn't last forever.
vi: There were people who thought so, in the dark times before this era, and they were always right, they somehow escaped, and things weren't like that forever.
tr: Others had thought about such things, in previous bad times, they were always right, they got out one way or another and it didn't last forever.
es: Others have thought the same before, in bad times, and they were always right, they got out one way or another, and it didn't last a lifetime.

en: Although for them it may have lasted all the forever they had.
vi: Though for them, it might have been like that for the entirety of their forever.
tr: Though it might have lasted as long as all the eternities they knew.
es: Even though for them it lasted their whole life.

en: When I get out of here, if I'm ever able to set this down, in any form,even in the form of one voice to another, it will be a reconstruction then too, at yet another remove.
vi: When I have left this place, if I ever record today, in any form, even if it is words conveyed through speech, it will still be a reconstruction, distanced by another layer.
tr: When I get out of here, if somehow I have the opportunity to record this, even if it is in the form of a voice transmitted from one person to another, it will still be a re-enactment, on yet another plane.
es: When I get out of here, if I am ever able to record this in some way, even by telling it to someone, it will also be a reconstruction and even another version.

en: It's impossible to say a thing exactly the way it was, because what you say can never be exact, you always have to leave something out, there are too many parts, sides, crosscurrents, nuances; too many gestures, which could mean this or that, too many shapes which can never be fully described, too many flavors, in the air or on the tongue, half-colors, too many.
vi: One can never say something exactly as it was, because what is spoken can never be precise; one always has to omit something, there are too many parts, many facets, many counterpoints, many nuances; too many gestures that can be interpreted in various ways, too many shapes that can never be fully described, too many smells in the air, or tastes on the tip of the tongue, too many tones, too many.
tr: It is impossible to describe something exactly as it happened, because what you narrate can never be complete; you always have to omit something. There are a multitude of details, sides, counter-currents, and differences, a multitude of attitudes that could mean this or that, a multitude of forms that can never be fully described, a multitude of tastes in the air or on the tongue, semi-colors, a multitude.
es: It is impossible to tell something exactly as it happened, because what one says can never be exact, something is always left out, there are many parts, aspects, undercurrents, nuances; too many details that could mean this or that, too many forms that cannot be fully described, too many aromas and flavors in the air or on the tongue, too many colors.

en: But if you happen to be a man, sometime inthe future, and you've made it this far, please remember: you will never be subject to the temptation or feeling you must forgive, a man, as a .; woman.
vi: But if by chance you are a man, at some point in the future, and you have followed this far, please remember: you will never have to endure the temptation, or the feeling, that you need to forgive a man, as a woman.
tr: Perhaps you are a man, sometime in the future, and if you have come this far, please remember this: as a woman, you will never be subjected to the temptation of feeling that you need to forgive a man.
es: But if you ever become a man, someday, in the future, if you manage to get that far, please remember this: you will never be as bound as a woman to the temptation of forgiving a man.

en: It's difficult to resist, believe me.
vi: It's very hard to resist, just trust me.
tr: Believe me, it is hard to resist.
es: It is hard to resist, believe me.

en: But remember that for giveness too is a power.
vi: But also remember that forgiveness, in itself, is power.
tr: But remember that forgiveness is also a power.
es: But remember that forgiveness is also a sign of power.

en: To beg for it is a power, and to withhold or bestow it is a power, perhaps the greatest.
vi: Pleading for it is power, and refusing or granting it is also power, perhaps the greatest power.
tr: To beg for it is a power, to hold it or to transfer it is a power, perhaps the greatest one.
es: To implore it is a sign of power, and to deny or grant it is a sign of power, perhaps the greatest.

en: Maybe none of this is about control.
vi: Maybe the issue has nothing to do with ownership.
tr: Maybe this has nothing to do with control.
es: Perhaps none of this can be verified.

en: Maybe it isn't really about who can own whom, who can do what to whom and get away with it, even as far as death.
vi: Maybe it's not necessarily about who possesses whom, who can do what to whom and still get away with it, until death.
tr: Maybe this has nothing to do with who can own whom, who can do what to whom, or even where this can go, even up to death.
es: Perhaps it is not really about who can possess whom, about who can do what to whom, even death, without being punished.

en: Maybe it isn't about who can sit and who has to kneel or stand or lie down, legs spread open.
vi: Maybe it's not about who gets to sit and who has to kneel or stand or lie on their back, legs spread apart.
tr: Maybe it has nothing to do with who can sit and who must kneel, stand, or lie with legs spread.
es: Maybe it's not about who can sit and who has to kneel or stand or lie down with their legs open.

en: Maybe it's about who can do what to whom and be forgiven for it.
vi: Perhaps it's about who can do what to whom and still be forgiven.
tr: Maybe it is about who can do what to whom and be forgiven for it.
es: Maybe it's about who can do what to whom and be forgiven for it.

en: Never tell me it amounts to the same thing.
vi: Don't tell me it's all the same.
tr: Don't say that these all lead to the same conclusion.
es: Don't tell me it means the same thing.

en: I want you to kiss me, said the Commander.
vi: I want you to kiss me, the Commander said.
tr: I want you to kiss me, said the Commander.
es: I want you to kiss me, said the Commander.

en: Well, of course something came before that.
vi: Oh, of course, there was more before that.
tr: Yes, of course, something had happened before this.
es: Well, naturally something happened after that.

en: Such requests never
vi: Such demands don't just fall from the sky.
tr: Such desires never come out of the blue.
es: Such requests never come out of the blue.

en: come flying out of the blue.
vi: Such demands don't just fall from the sky.
tr: Such desires never come out of the blue.
es: Such requests never come out of the blue.

en: I went to sleep after all, and dreamed I was wearing earrings, and one of them was broken; nothing beyond that, just the brain going through its back files, and I was wakened by Cora with the dinner tray, and time was back on track.
vi: Finally, I fell asleep and dreamed that I was wearing earrings, one of which was broken; it had no special meaning, just the brain revisiting old memories, and I woke up when Cora brought in my food tray, and the sense of time returned.
tr: Still, I fell asleep and saw in my dream that I was wearing an earring, one of them was broken; beyond that, there is nothing, just the brain rummaging through old files; and I was awakened by Cora, who came with the dinner tray, time got back on track.
es: After all, I went to sleep, and I dreamed that I was wearing earrings, and one of them was broken; nothing more than that, simply the brain examining its most hidden files, and Cora woke me up by bringing me the dinner tray and time continued its course.

en: "It a good baby?" says Cora as she's setting down the tray.
vi: “Is the baby doing well?” Cora asked as she put down the tray.
tr: “Is the baby okay?” says Cora as she sets down the tray.
es: —Is it a pretty baby? —asks Cora as she sets down the tray.

en: She must know already, they have a kind of word-of-mouth telegraph, from household to household, news gets around; but it gives her pleasure to hear about it, as if my words will make it more real.
vi: Surely she already knew, they had a kind of oral telegraph, from one household to another, spreading news everywhere; but she still enjoyed hearing it again, as if my words would make it more real.
tr: She must already know; they have a kind of word-of-mouth telegraph system that carries news from house to house. But she likes to hear it, as if my words will make it more real.
es: She must already know, they have a sort of oral telegraphy that spreads news from house to house; but it gives her pleasure to hear it, as if my words make it more real.

en: "It's fine," I say.
vi: “Not bad,” I said.
tr: “Very good,” I say.
es: —It's beautiful —I respond—.

en: "A keeper.
vi: “A treasure.
tr: “Healthy.
es: A charm.

en: A girl."
vi: A daughter.”
tr: A girl.”
es: It's a girl.

en: Cora smiles at me, a smile that includes.
vi: Cora smiled at me, a smile full of meaning.
tr: Cora is smiling at me, a knowing smile.
es: Cora smiles at me, hers is an all-encompassing smile.

en: These are the moments that must make what she is doing seem worthwhile to her.
vi: This was one of those moments that made her cherish what she did.
tr: These must be the moments that make what she does seem valuable to her.
es: These are the moments that make her think that what she does is worth it.

en: "That's good," she says.
vi: “Wonderful,” she said.
tr: "Beautiful," he says.
es: —That's very good —she comments.

en: Her voice is almost wistful, and I think: of course.
vi: Her voice was almost wistful, and I thought: of course.
tr: His voice is almost full of longing and I think: of course.
es: Her voice is almost melancholic, and I think: of course.

en: She would have liked to have been there.
vi: She must have really wanted to go there too.
tr: He would have liked to have been there.
es: She would have liked to be there.

en: It's like a party she couldn't go to.
vi: Like a party she couldn't attend.
tr: It's like a party he couldn't attend.
es: It's like a party she couldn't attend.

en: "Maybe we have one, soon," she says, shyly.
vi: “Maybe our house will have it, soon,” she said shyly.
tr: “Maybe we will have one too, soon,” she says, shyly.
es: —Maybe we will have one soon —she says in a timid tone.

en: By we she means me.
vi: Our house means me.
tr: By 'we', she means me.
es: When she says we, she means me.

en: It's up to me to repay the team, justify my food and keep, like a queen ant with eggs.
vi: I have the duty to repay the whole group, worthy of the care and accommodation, like a queen ant holding eggs.
tr: It's up to me to pay for what the team has done, to earn my food and living, like a queen ant with eggs.
es: It is my responsibility to pay the reward, justify the food and care I receive, like a queen ant with the eggs.

en: Rita may disapprove of me, hut Cora does not.
vi: Rita might not be satisfied with me, but Cora is different.
tr: Rita may not approve of me, but Cora is not like that.
es: Rita would disapprove of me, but not Cora.

en: Instead she depends on me.
vi: On the contrary, she clings to me.
tr: Instead, she is dependent on me.
es: On the contrary, she depends on me.

en: She hopes, and I am the vehicle of her hope.
vi: She has hope, I am the means for that hope.
tr: She harbors hope, and I am the agent of her hope.
es: She has hopes, and I am the vehicle of her hopes.

en: Her hope is of the simplest kind.
vi: Her hopes were of the simplest kind.
tr: The simplest kind of hope.
es: What she expects is something very simple.

en: She wants a Birth Day, here, with guests and food and presents, she wants a little child to spoil in the kitchen, to iron clothes for, to slip cookies into when no one's watching.
vi: She wanted to have a Birthday, here, with guests, food, and gifts; she wanted to have a child to bring into the kitchen, to pamper, to iron clothes for, to sneak cookies to when no one was looking.
tr: She wants a Birthday, here, with guests, food, and presents, a little child who will pamper her in the kitchen, iron her clothes, and give her candies when no one is looking.
es: She wants there to be a Birthday, here, with guests, food, and gifts; she wants a child to spoil in the kitchen, to iron their clothes, and to give them cookies when no one is looking.

en: I am to provide these joys for her.
vi: I had the responsibility to provide her with those joys.
tr: I am the one who will provide her with these happinesses.
es: I have to provide her with these joys.

en: I would rather have the disapproval, I feel more worthy of it.
vi: I would rather endure dissatisfaction; that way, I felt more deserving.
tr: I would have preferred not to be approved, I see myself more worthy of this.
es: I would prefer her disapproval; I feel I deserve something better.

en: The dinner is beef stew.
vi: Dinner includes beef stew.
tr: There is beef stew for dinner.
es: The dinner consists of beef stew.

en: I have some trouble finishing it, because halfway through it I remember what the day has erased right out of my head.
vi: I eat with some difficulty, because halfway through I remember something that had slipped my mind during the day.
tr: I am having difficulty finishing it because I am remembering something that the day had completely erased from my mind.
es: I have trouble finishing it, because halfway through I remember what I had completely erased from my mind today.

en: It's true what they say, it's a trance state, giving birth or being there, you lose track of the rest of your life, you focus only on that one instant.
vi: They were right, one would fall into a trance-like state, whether giving birth or attending, causing one to lose a sense of the outside world, focusing solely on the present moment.
tr: What they say is true, it's a state of trance, whether giving birth or just being there, you lose connection with the rest of your life, focusing only on this unique moment.
es: What they say is true, it is a state of trance, both giving birth and being there, you lose track of the rest of your life, you focus only on that moment.

en: But now it comes back to me, and I know I'm not prepared.
vi: But now it has returned, and I know I am not ready.
tr: But now it is coming back to me, and I know I am not ready.
es: But now it comes back to my mind, and I know I'm not prepared.

en: The clock in the hall downstairs strikes nine.
vi: The clock in the hall struck nine.
tr: The clock in the hallway strikes nine.
es: The clock in the downstairs hallway strikes nine.

en: I press my hands
vi: I squeezed my hands against my thighs, took a deep breath, walked out to the hallway, and stepped lightly down the stairs.
tr: I press my hands against my hips, take a breath, and walk slowly down the hall and the stairs.
es: I press my hands against the sides of my thighs, take a breath, walk down the hallway, and descend the stairs silently.

en: against the sides of my thighs, breathe in, set out along the hall and softly down the stairs.
vi: I squeezed my hands against my thighs, took a deep breath, walked out to the hallway, and stepped lightly down the stairs.
tr: I press my hands against my hips, take a breath, and walk slowly down the hall and the stairs.
es: I press my hands against the sides of my thighs, take a breath, walk down the hallway, and descend the stairs silently.

en: Serena
vi: Serena
tr: Serena
es: Serena

en: Joy may still be at the house where the Birth took place; that's lucky, he couldn't have foreseen it.
vi: Joy was probably still at the house where the Birth ceremony had taken place; it was just a stroke of luck, he couldn't have predicted that.
tr: Joy might still be at the house where the Birth is happening; luck, she couldn't have known this beforehand.
es: Joy must still be at the house where the Birth took place; that's called being lucky, because he couldn't have foreseen it.

en: On these days the Wives hang around for hours, helping to open the presents, gossiping, getting drunk.
vi: On these occasions, the Wives gather for hours, helping to open gifts, gossiping, and drinking to their heart's content.
tr: On such days, the Wives spend hours opening gifts, gossiping, and getting drunk.
es: On days like this, the Wives lounge around for hours, helping to open gifts, gossiping, getting drunk.

en: Something has to be done to dispel their envy.
vi: There has to be something to dissolve the jealousy.
tr: Something must be done to disperse their jealousy.
es: They have to do something to dispel their envy.

en: I follow the downstairs corridor back, past the door that leads into the kitchen, along to the next door, his.
vi: I followed the hall downstairs to the back, past the kitchen door, to the next door, his room.
tr: I trace the downstairs corridor back, passing the door to the kitchen and reaching the next door, hers.
es: I back down the hallway on the lower floor, pass by the kitchen door, and walk to the next door, his.

en: I stand outside it, feeling like a child who's been summoned, at school, to the principal's office.
vi: I stood outside, feeling like a student called to the principal's office.
tr: I stand in front of it, feeling like a child summoned to the principal's office at school.
es: I wait outside, feeling like a creature that has been called to the principal's office.

en: What have I done wrong?
vi: What had I done wrong?
tr: What had I done wrong?
es: What have I done wrong?

en: My presence here is illegal.
vi: I am here illegally.
tr: My presence here is illegal.
es: My presence here is illegal.

en: It's forbidden for us to be alone with I he Commanders.
vi: We are forbidden to be alone with the Commanders.
tr: It is forbidden for us to be alone with the commanders.
es: We are forbidden to be alone with the Commanders.

en: We are for breeding purposes: we aren't concubines, geisha girls, courtesans.
vi: We only serve the purpose of reproduction: we are not concubines, prostitutes, or mistresses.
tr: We exist for reproductive purposes: we are not concubines, geishas, or prostitutes.
es: Our mission is to procreate: we are not concubines, nor geishas, nor courtesans.

en: On the contrary: everything possible has been done to remove us from that category.
vi: On the contrary, every measure has been taken to prevent that impression.
tr: On the contrary: everything possible has been done to remove us from that category.
es: On the contrary, they have done everything possible to separate us from that category.

en: There is sup-posed to be nothing entertaining about us, no room is to be permitted lor the flowering of secret lusts; no special favors are to be wheedled, by them or us, there are to be no toeholds for love.
vi: All avenues that might allow us to bring pleasure must be eliminated, leaving no room for secret desires to take hold, no favors to be coquettishly sought, from either their side or ours, no foothold for romance.
tr: There should be nothing entertaining about us, no room for secret passions to flourish; neither they nor we can ingratiate ourselves for special relationships, there should be no basis for love.
es: There should be no fun with respect to us, no room for hidden desires to flourish; no special favors can be obtained, neither from them nor from us, there is no basis on which love can settle.

en: We are two-legged wombs, that's all: sacred vessels, ambulatory chalices.
vi: We are walking wombs, nothing more: sacred vessels, walking chalices.
tr: We are two-legged wombs, that's all: sacred vessels, wandering chalices.
es: We are matrices with two legs, that's all: we are sacred vessels, walking chalices.

en: So why does he want to see me, at night, alone?
vi: So why does he want to meet me, at night, alone?
tr: So, why does he want to see me, at night, alone?
es: So, why would he want to see me, at night and alone?

en: If I'm caught, it's to Serena's tender mercies I'll be delivered.
vi: If I get caught, I will be handed over to the mercy of Serena Joy, who else.
tr: If I get caught, I will be handed over to Serena Joy's merciless hands.
es: If I were caught, I would fall into Serena's ruthless hands.

en: He isn't supposed to meddle in such household discipline, that's women's business.
vi: He has no right to interfere in internal discipline, that is women's business.
tr: The Commander is not expected to interfere in such domestic discipline issues; this is women's work.
es: He must not interfere with the household discipline, that is a matter for the women.

en: After that, reclassification.
vi: After that will be reclassification.
tr: This could end up with reclassification.
es: After this, reclassification would come.

en: I could become an Un woman.
vi: I could become an Unwoman.
tr: I could become an Unwoman.
es: I could become an Unwoman.

en: But to refuse to see him could be worse.
vi: But from the broom meeting the man, it could be worse.
tr: But refusing to see him could have been worse.
es: But if I refused to see it, it could be worse.

en: There's no doubt about who holds the real power.
vi: The real power lies with whom, that is not a question.
tr: There is no doubt about who holds the real power.
es: There is no doubt about who holds the real power.

en: But there must be something he wants, from me.
vi: But there must be something he wants from me.
tr: Still, there must be something he wants from me.
es: There must be something he wants from me.

en: To want is to have a weakness.
vi: Wanting is a weakness.
tr: Wanting is weakness.
es: To desire is to have some weakness.

en: It's this weakness, whatever it is, that entices me.
vi: This very weakness, whatever it is, has drawn me in.
tr: What tempts me, whatever it is, is this weakness.
es: It is this weakness, whatever it may be, that attracts me.

en: It's like a small crack in a wall, before now impenetrable.
vi: Like a small crack on a wall that has always been impenetrable.
tr: Like a small crack in the wall, it is already impossible to grasp.
es: It is like a small crack in an otherwise impenetrable wall.

en: If I press my eye to it, this weakness of his, I may be able to see my way clear.
vi: If I press my eye against it, against this weakness, I can clearly see the way through.
tr: If I adjust my eye well to this crack, perhaps I can clearly see my way through his weakness.
es: If I press my eye to it, to this weakness of his, I may be able to clearly see how I should act.

en: I want to know what he wants.
vi: I want to know what you want.
tr: I want to know what you want.
es: I want to know what they want.

en: I raise my hand, knock, on the door of this forbidden room where I
vi: I raised my hand, knocked, on the forbidden door of the room I had never been to, women never came here.
tr: I raise my hand and knock on the door of this forbidden room, where I have never been, and where women do not enter.
es: I raise my hand and knock on the door of this forbidden room in which I have never been, a room that women do not enter.

en: have never been, where women do not go.
vi: I raised my hand, knocked, on the forbidden door of the room I had never been to, women never came here.
tr: I raise my hand and knock on the door of this forbidden room, where I have never been, and where women do not enter.
es: I raise my hand and knock on the door of this forbidden room in which I have never been, a room that women do not enter.

en: Not even Serena Joy t
vi: Even Serena
tr: Even Serena
es: Not even Serena Joy enters here, and the cleaning is done by the Guardians.

en: comes here, and the cleaning is done by Guardians.
vi: Joy never came here, the cleaning was all done by the Guardians.
tr: Joy does not come here, and the cleaning is done by the Guardians.
es: Not even Serena Joy enters here, and the cleaning is done by the Guardians.

en: What secrets, what male totems are kept in here?
vi: What secrets, what male totems were hidden in there?
tr: What secrets, what masculine totems are hidden here?
es: What secrets, what masculine totems are kept here?

en: I'm told to enter.
vi: I was let in.
tr: I am told to enter.
es: They tell me to come in.

en: I open the door, step in.
vi: I opened the door and stepped inside.
tr: I open the door and step inside.
es: I open the door and enter.

en: What is on the other side is normal life.
vi: On the other side of the door is normal life.
tr: The thing on the other side of the door is normal life.
es: What I find on the other side is something normal.

en: I should say: what is on the other side looks like normal life.
vi: I corrected myself: on the other side of the door looks like normal life.
tr: I should say: The thing on the other side of the door resembles normal life.
es: I should say: what I find on the other side seems something normal.

en: There is a desk, of course, with a Computalk on it, and a black leatherchair behind it.
vi: There is a desk, of course, with a computer phone, next to a leather armchair.
tr: There is a desk, of course, with a Compuspeak on it, and a black leather chair behind it.
es: There is a desk, of course, with a Compucommunicator, and a black leather chair.

en: There's a potted plant on the desk, a pen-holder set, papers.
vi: There is a potted plant on the desk, a pen holder, and papers.
tr: On the desk, there is a plant in a pot, a writing set, and papers.
es: On the desk, there is a pot with a plant, a set of pen holders, and papers.

en: There's an oriental rug on the floor, and a fireplace without a fire in it.
vi: On the floor is an Oriental rug, and an unlit fireplace.
tr: On the floor, there is an oriental rug and a non-functional fireplace.
es: On the floor, an oriental rug; and a fireplace with no fire, a small brown plush sofa, a television set, a table, and a couple of chairs.

en: There's a small sofa, covered in brown plush, a television set, an end table, a couple of chairs.
vi: There is a small sofa, covered in brown velvet, then a TV, a small table, and a few chairs.
tr: A small sofa covered in brown plush, a television, a coffee table, and a pair of chairs.
es: On the floor, an oriental rug; and a fireplace with no fire, a small brown plush sofa, a television set, a table, and a couple of chairs.

en: But all around the walls there are bookcases.
vi: But all around are bookshelves.
tr: All the walls are covered with bookshelves.
es: All the walls are covered with shelves filled with books.

en: They're filled with books.
vi: Every shelf is filled to the brim.
tr: Shelves full of books.
es: And they are full of books.

en: Books and books and books, right out in plain view, no locks, no boxes.
vi: Books and books and books, displayed right before our eyes, not locked, not wrapped in boxes.
tr: Books, books, and books, completely out in the open, neither locked nor boxed.
es: Books, books, and more books perfectly in sight, without locks or drawers.

en: No wonder we can't come in here.
vi: No wonder we are not allowed to come here.
tr: It's not surprising that we can't get in here.
es: It's no wonder we can't enter here.

en: It's an oasis of the forbidden.
vi: This is an oasis of forbidden things.
tr: This is the oasis of the forbidden.
es: This is an oasis of the forbidden.

en: I try not to stare.
vi: I try not to look.
tr: I'm trying not to look around with interest.
es: I try not to fix my gaze on them.

en: The Commander is standing infront of the fireless fireplace, back to it, one elbow on the carved wooden overmantel, other hand in his pocket.
vi: The commander was standing in front of the unlit fireplace, his back to it, one elbow resting on the intricately carved wooden mantel, the other hand in his pocket.
tr: The commander is standing in front of the unlit fireplace, with his back turned to it, one elbow on the carved wooden mantelpiece, and the other hand in his pocket.
es: The Commander is standing in front of the unlit fireplace, with his back to it, one elbow resting on the carved wooden mantel and the other hand in his pocket.

en: It's such a studied pose, something of the country squire, some old come-on from a glossy men's mag.
vi: His pose was meticulously arranged, evoking the style of a rural aristocrat, reminiscent of an old invitation from some glossy men's magazine.
tr: This is a studied pose, something about provincial gentility, that familiar seductiveness stemming from the allure of polished men.
es: It's a studied pose, like a heartthrob, taken from one of those glossy men's magazines.

en: He probably decided ahead of time that he'd be standing like that when I came in.
vi: He had likely decided on this stance beforehand for me to see upon entering.
tr: Perhaps he had decided beforehand to stand like this when I entered.
es: He probably decided beforehand that he would stand like that when I entered.

en: When I knocked he probably rushed over to the fireplace and propped himself up.
vi: When I knocked on the door, he must have rushed to the fireplace to adjust his posture.
tr: He must have rushed to the fireplace and assumed his pose when I knocked on the door.
es: And when I knocked on the door, he surely ran to the fireplace and settled into that position.

en: He should have a black patch, over one eye, a cravat with horseshoes on it.
vi: He is still missing the black cloth, an eye patch, and a tie with a horseshoe pattern.
tr: He should have had a black patch over one eye and also a tie.
es: He would have to have one eye covered with a black patch and a scarf with a horseshoe pattern.

en: It's all very well for me to think these things, quick as staccato, a jittering of the brain.
vi: I can still comfortably assume that these things, fleeting and disjointed, are just a brainwave.
tr: Thinking about all these things is very good for me, as fast as staccato, the brain's wobbling.
es: It does me good to think these things, as quickly as a tapping, a tremor of the mind.

en: An inner jeering.
vi: It's a laugh in the mind.
tr: An inner mockery.
es: Like a mockery to myself.

en: But it's panic.
vi: But that is actually fear.
tr: But at the same time, this is panic.
es: But this is panic.

en: The fact is I'm terrified.
vi: In reality, I am terrified.
tr: The truth is, I am in terror.
es: The truth is that I am terrified.

en: I don't say anything.
vi: I didn't say anything.
tr: I'm not saying anything.
es: I don't say anything.

en: "Close the door behind you," he says, pleasantly enough.
vi: “Remember to close the door when you come in,” he said, quite gently.
tr: “Close the door behind you,” he says, quite kindly.
es: —Close the door —he says to me, in a kind tone.

en: I do it, and turn back.
vi: I closed the door, then turned back.
tr: I close it and turn around.
es: I do as he says, and I turn around—.

en: "Hello," he says.
vi: Hello, miss, he said.
tr: "Hello," he says.
es: Hello —he/she greets me.

en: It's the old form of greeting.
vi: That is the way people used to greet each other in the old days.
tr: Old-fashioned greeting.
es: It is the old way of greeting.

en: I haven't heard it lor a long time, for years.
vi: I haven't heard it for a very long time, for years.
tr: I hadn't heard it for a long time, for years.
es: It had been a long time, years, since I had heard it.

en: Under the circumstances it seems out of place, comical even, a
vi: In this context, it sounds out of place, even bizarre, like a slip back in time, a big leap somewhere.
tr: Under these circumstances, it seems out of place, even funny, a leap back in time, a pause.
es: Given the circumstances, a regression in time, a stagnation, seems out of place, even comical.

en: flip backward in time, a stunt.
vi: In this context, it sounds out of place, even bizarre, like a slip back in time, a big leap somewhere.
tr: Under these circumstances, it seems out of place, even funny, a leap back in time, a pause.
es: Given the circumstances, a regression in time, a stagnation, seems out of place, even comical.

en: 1 can think of nothing appropriate to say in return.
vi: I couldn't think of an appropriate response.
tr: I can't think of anything appropriate in response.
es: Nothing appropriate comes to mind to respond.

en: I think I will cry.
vi: I think I'm about to cry.
tr: I think I will cry.
es: I think I'm going to scream.

en: He must have noticed this, because he looks at me puzzled, gives a little frown I choose to interpret as concern, though it may merely be irritation.
vi: He probably realized it too, so he looked at me, puzzled, slightly furrowing his brows, which I wanted to interpret as concern, though it could just be annoyance.
tr: He must have noticed this, because he is looking at me, surprised, with a slight frown that I choose to interpret as interest, although it could simply be discomfort.
es: He must have noticed it because he looks at me surprised and frowns a little, something I decide to interpret as concern, although it could simply be irritation.

en: "Here," he says.
vi: "Here," he said.
tr: "Here," he says.
es: —Come here —he says—.

en: "You can sit down."
vi: "Have a seat."
tr: "You can sit."
es: You can sit down —he brings a chair and places it in front of his desk.

en: He pulls a chair out for me, sets it in front of his desk.
vi: He pulled out a chair for me, placing it in front of the desk.
tr: He pulls out a chair for me and places it in front of his desk.
es: You can sit down —he brings a chair and places it in front of his desk.

en: Then he goes around behind the desk and sits down, slowlyand it seems to me elaborately.
vi: Then he walked around to the back of the desk and sat down, his movements very slow and, I felt, carefully calculated.
tr: Then he goes behind his desk and sits down, slowly, which seems overly careful to me.
es: Then he walks to another side and sits down slowly and, in my view, in a studied manner.

en: What this act tells me is that he hasn't brought me here to touch me in any way, against my will.
vi: This action was meant to show me that he hadn't brought me here to make any advances, if it was against my will.
tr: From this action, I infer that he will not touch me in any way without my consent.
es: This shows me that he hasn't brought me here to touch me against my will, or anything like that.

en: He smiles.
vi: He smiled.
tr: He smiles.
es: He smiles.

en: The smile is not sinister or predatory.
vi: Not in a malicious or predatory way.
tr: This smile is neither malevolent nor wild.
es: It's not a sinister or predatory smile.

en: It's merely a smile, a formal kind of smile, friendly but a little distant, as if I'm a kitten in a window.
vi: Just a regular smile, a polite, friendly but slightly distant smile, like one would give to a cat behind a glass window.
tr: It's just a smile, a formal smile, friendly but a bit distant, as if I were a kitten in a shop window.
es: It's simply a smile, a formal smile, friendly but a bit distant, as if I were a kitten in a shop window, a cat he looks at but has no intention of buying.

en: One he's looking at but doesn't intend to buy.
vi: He was looking, but not intending to buy.
tr: One that he watches but does not consider buying.
es: It's simply a smile, a formal smile, friendly but a bit distant, as if I were a kitten in a shop window, a cat he looks at but has no intention of buying.

en: I sit up straight on the chair, my hands folded on my lap.
vi: I sit up straight on the chair, hands placed in my lap.
tr: I am sitting upright on the chair, with my hands clasped in my lap.
es: I sit on the chair, upright and with my hands crossed on my lap.

en: I feel as if my feet in their flat red shoes aren't quite touching the floor.
vi: The feeling of my feet in red flat shoes as if not touching the ground.
tr: It feels as if my feet in the red flat shoes are not quite touching the ground.
es: I have the feeling that my feet, shod in low red shoes, do not touch the ground.

en: But of course they are.
vi: But of course, they are.
tr: But of course, that's not true.
es: But they touch it, of course.

en: "You must find this strange," he says.
vi: "You must find it strange," he said.
tr: "This must seem strange to you," he says.
es: —This must seem strange to you —he comments.

en: I simply look at him.
vi: I just looked at him.
tr: I'm just looking at her.
es: I limit myself to looking at him.

en: The understatement of the year, was a phrase my mother uses.
vi: The understatement of the year, as my mother used to say.
tr: The phrase of the year; an expression my mother used.
es: The euphemism of the year, a phrase my mother uses.

en: Used.
vi: Back in the day.
tr: One she had used.
es: He/She/It used to use.

en: I feel like cotton candy: sugar and air.
vi: I thought I was cotton candy mixed with air.
tr: I feel like cotton candy: sugar and air.
es: I feel like a cotton candy: sugar and air.

en: Squeeze me and I'd turn into a small sickly damp wad of weeping pinky-red.
vi: Just mold me, and I will turn into a wet, pinkish-red clump, melting away.
tr: Don't squeeze me, or I'll turn into a small, sickly, and tearful pink-red, damp lump.
es: If I were squeezed, I would turn into a small pink ball, moist and oozing.

en: "I guess it is a little strange," he says, as if I've answered.
vi: “I’m sure this is a bit strange,” he said, as I had replied.
tr: “I guess this is a bit strange,” he says, as if I had responded.
es: —I suppose it is a bit strange —he continues, as if I had responded.

en: I think I should have a hat on, tied with a bow under my chin.
vi: I think I need a hat, tied with a bow under the chin.
tr: I think I should have worn a hat, tied under my chin with a bow.
es: I think I should wear a hat tied with a ribbon under my chin.

en: "I want?
vi: "I want..." he said.
tr: “What I want...” he says.
es: —I want... —he says.

tr: This is the way of nature.
es: It's natural, a resource from God.

en: It's God's device.
vi: God made it so.
tr: God's invention.
es: It's natural, a resource from God.

en: It's the way things are.
vi: Life is like that.
tr: This is how things work.
es: That's how things are.

en: Aunt Lydia did not actually say this, but it was implicit in everything she did say.
vi: Aunt Lydia didn't exactly say that, but it was hidden in everything she said.
tr: Aunt Lydia didn't actually say these things, but they were understood from what she said.
es: In reality, Aunt Lydia did not say this, but it was implied in her words.

en: It hovered over her head, like the golden mottoes over the saints, of the darker ages.
vi: It hovered over her head, like a golden halo over the saints, back when there was still darkness.
tr: They were hovering above her head, just like the golden aphorisms above the saints of darker ages.
es: It floated above her head, like the golden halos worn by saints in the night of times.

en: Like them too, she was angular and without flesh.
vi: Like them, she was all bones, devoid of flesh.
tr: Like them, Aunt Lydia was also bony and fleshless.
es: And like them, it was angular and gaunt.

en: But how to fit the Commander into this, as he exists in his study, with his word games and his desire, for what?
vi: But how to fit the Commander into that formula, a Commander sitting in the study, with the game of arranging letters and a longing, longing for what?
tr: But how should we fit the Commander into this frame, while existing in the study room, with wordplay and desire, who knows for what?
es: But how to fit the Commander into this, as he lives in his office, with his word games and his desires, for what?

en: To be played with, to be gently kissed, as if I meant it.
vi: To have someone to play with, to kiss gently, as I would like.
tr: To accompany his game, to be kissed gently, as if I truly wanted it.
es: So that he can play with him, so that he can kiss him softly, as if he were really doing it.

en: 1 know I need to take it seriously, this desire of his.
vi: I know I need to seriously consider it, this desire.
tr: I know that I need to take this, his desire, seriously.
es: I know I need to seriously consider this desire of his.

en: It could be important, it could be a passport, it could be my downfall.
vi: It could be very important, it could be the ticket out, it could be my dead end.
tr: This could be important, it could be a passport, it could be my downfall.
es: It could be important, it could be a passport, it could be my downfall.

en: I need to be earnest about it, I need to ponder it.
vi: I need to sincerely think about it, need to weigh it.
tr: I need to take this seriously, I need to ponder over it.
es: I must be serious about this, I have to ponder it.

en: But no matter what I do, sitting here in the dark, with the searchlights illuminating the oblong of my window, from outside, through the curtains gauzy as a bridal dress, as ectoplasm, one of my hands holding the other, rocking back and forth a little, no matter what I do there's something hilarious about it.
vi: But no matter how hard I try, sitting here in the dark, the window frame lit up by headlights from outside, through the thin curtains like a bride's dress, like ghostly skin, hand holding hand, body slightly swaying forward, no matter how hard I try, it still seems indescribably humorous.
tr: But no matter what I do, while sitting here in the dark, with the spotlights illuminating the rectangle of my window through the curtains that are as transparent as a wedding dress, as transparent as outer plasma, while one hand holds the other, gently swaying back and forth, no matter what I do, there is something insanely ridiculous about this.
es: But whatever I do, sitting here in the darkness, with the spotlights illuminating the rectangle of my window from outside and through the sheer curtains like a wedding dress, like an ectoplasm, with one of my hands holding the other, rocking slightly back and forth, whatever I do, in all of this there is something funny.

en: He wanted me to play Scrabble with him, and kiss him as if I meant it.
vi: He wants me to play Scrabble with him, and kiss him as if I wanted to.
tr: She wanted me to play Scrabble with her and kiss her as if I really wanted to.
es: He wanted me to play Intelect with him, and to kiss him as if I really meant it.

en: This is one of the most bizarre things that's happened to me, ever.
vi: This is one of the strangest stories I have ever encountered in my entire life.
tr: This is one of the strangest things that has ever happened to me.
es: This is one of the most curious things that has ever happened to me.

en: Context is all.
vi: It's all about the context.
tr: Everything is context.
es: Context is everything.

en: I remember a television program I once saw; a rerun, made years before.
vi: I still remember watching a TV program; a replay, originally from many years ago.
tr: I remember a television program I once watched; a rerun, made years ago.
es: I remember a television program I saw once, a rerun of a show made several years earlier.

en: I must have been seven or eight, too young to understand it.
vi: I was about seven or eight years old, watching without understanding.
tr: I must have been seven or eight years old, too young to understand it.
es: I must have been seven or eight years old, too young to understand it.

en: It was the sort of thing my mother liked to watch: historical, educational.
vi: The program was the type my mother liked: historical storytelling, educational.
tr: It was the kind of thing my mother enjoyed watching: historical, educational.
es: It was the type of program my mother loved to watch: historical, educational.

en: She tried to explain it to me afterwards, to tell me that the things in it had really happened, but to me it was only a story.
vi: Later, my mother tried to explain to me that all those events had happened in real life, but to me, it was still just a story.
tr: She had later tried to explain to me, to tell me that the things in it were real, but to me, it was just a story.
es: Later she tried to explain it to me, telling me that the things shown there had really happened, but to me it was just a story.

en: I thought someone had made it up.
vi: I thought someone had made it up.
tr: I thought someone had made it up.
es: I thought someone had made it up.

en: I suppose all children think that, about any history before their own.
vi: Surely all children think that way about all of history before they were born.
tr: I think all children feel this way about times before their own.
es: I suppose all children think the same about any story from before their own time.

en: If it's only a story, it becomes less frightening.
vi: If it's just a story, it's less scary.
tr: If it's just a story, it's less frightening.
es: If it's just a story, it seems less frightening.

en: The program was a documentary, about one of those wars.
vi: It is a documentary film about an old war.
tr: The program was a documentary about one of those wars.
es: The program consisted of a documentary about one of those wars.

en: They interviewed people and showed clips from films of the time, black and white, and still photos.
vi: They interviewed many people interspersed with contemporary footage, black and white, and photographs.
tr: They were interviewing people and showing clips and photos from the black and white films of that time.
es: They interviewed people and showed clips from movies of the era, in black and white, and photographs.

en: I don't remember much about it, but I remember the quality of the pictures, the way everything in them seemed to be coated with a mixture of sunlight and dust, and how dark the shadows were under people's eyebrows and along their cheekbones.
vi: I don't remember much, but I still recall the quality of the images, everything seemed to be covered with a layer of sun dust, and how dark the shadows under the eyebrows or on the cheekbones were.
tr: I don't remember much, but I do recall the quality of the pictures, how everything in them was covered with a mixture of daylight and dust, and how dark the shadows under people's eyebrows and on their cheekbones were.
es: I don't remember much about the documentary, but I do remember the quality of the images, how everything in them seemed covered with a mix of sunlight and dust, and how dark the shadows were under the eyebrows and cheekbones.

en: The/interviews with people still alive then were in color.
vi: The segments of interviews with living witnesses are all in color.
tr: The interviews conducted with people who were still alive at that time were colorful.
es: The interviews with the people who were still alive were filmed in color.

en: The one I remember best was with a woman who had been the mistress of a man who had supervised one of the camps where they put the Jews, before they killed them.
vi: The person I remember most is the woman who was once the mistress of the manager of a camp for Jews, before they were killed.
tr: The one I remember best was with a woman who had been the mistress of a man who managed one of the camps where Jews were confined before being killed.
es: The one I remember best is the one they did with a woman who had been the lover of a man who supervised one of the camps where they locked up the Jews before killing them.

en: In ovens, my mother said; but there weren't any pictures of the ovens, so I got some confused notion that these deaths had taken place in kitchens.
vi: By cremation, my mother informed me; but the film did not show the ovens, so I mistakenly thought they had died in the kitchen.
tr: They would put them in ovens, my mother said; but there were no pictures of the ovens, so I developed a complicated idea that these deaths occurred in kitchens.
es: In ovens, according to my mother; but there were no images of the ovens, so I formed the idea that these deaths had taken place in the kitchen.

en: There is something especially terrifying to a child in that idea.
vi: That idea is particularly terrifying for children.
tr: There is something particularly frightening about this idea for a child.
es: For a child, this idea holds something especially terrifying.

en: Ovens mean cooking, and cooking comes before eating.
vi: Ovens are for cooking, and cooking is for eating.
tr: An oven means cooking, and cooking comes before eating.
es: Ovens are used for cooking, and cooking is what you do before eating.

en: I thought these people had been eaten.
vi: I thought those people had been eaten.
tr: I thought these people were being eaten.
es: I imagined that those people had been eaten.

en: Which in a way I suppose they had been.
vi: And in some way, I think they were.
tr: And I guess in a way they were.
es: And I suppose that, in a way, that's what happened to them.

en: From what they said, the man had been cruel and brutal.
vi: According to the story, the man was very fierce and brutal.
tr: According to what they said, this man was ruthless and savage.
es: From what they said, that man had been cruel and brutal.

en: The mistressmy mother explained mistress, she did not believe in mystification, I had a pop-up book of sexual organs by the time I was fourthe mistress had once been very beautiful.
vi: The mistress - my mother explained the word mistress, my mother didn't believe it so she told fairy tales to children, I had a pop-up book describing genitalia since I was four - the mistress was once very beautiful.
tr: Mistress - my mother explained what a mistress was, she didn't believe in secrecy, I had a book describing sexual organs when I was four years old - was once very beautiful.
es: His lover —my mother explained the meaning of the word lover to me, she didn't like mysteries; when I was four years old, she bought me a book about sexual organs— had been a very beautiful woman.

en: There was a black-and-white shot of her and another woman, in the two-piece bathing suits and platform shoesand picture hats of the time; they were wearing cat's-eye sunglasses and sitting in deck chairs by a swimming pool.
vi: There is a black and white photo of her and another woman, wearing two-piece swimsuits, platform shoes, and wide-brimmed floral hats, the fashion of those years; they wore cat-eye glasses and sat on deck chairs by the pool.
tr: There was a black and white photo of her and another woman, with the two-piece swimsuits, high heels, and wide-brimmed hats of that time; they were wearing cat-eye sunglasses, sitting on lounge chairs by a swimming pool.
es: There was a black and white photo of her and another woman, dressed in the two-piece swimsuit, platform shoes, and wide-brimmed hat that were used at that time; they were wearing cat-eye sunglasses and were lying on some loungers by the pool.

en: The swimming pool was beside their house, which was near the camp with the ovens.
vi: The pool was next to their house, which means it was very close to the camp with the furnace.
tr: The swimming pool was next to their house, and the house was near the camp where the ovens were located.
es: The pool was next to the house, which was near the field where they had the ovens.

en: The woman said she didn't notice much that she found unusual.
vi: The woman said she didn't notice anything too unusual.
tr: The woman said she didn't notice anything that seemed unusual to her.
es: The woman said she hadn't noticed anything out of the ordinary.

en: She denied knowing about the ovens.
vi: She denied knowing about the furnaces.
tr: She denied knowing about the ovens.
es: She denied being aware of the existence of the ovens.

en: At the time of the interview, forty or fifty years later, she was dying of emphysema.
vi: At the time of the interview, four or five decades later, she was in the final stages of emphysema.
tr: During the interview, forty or fifty years later, he was about to die from emphysema.
es: At the time of the interview, forty or fifty years later, he was dying of emphysema.

en: She coughed a lot, and she was very thin, almost emaciated; but she still took pride in her appearance.
vi: She coughed a lot, and was emaciated, almost skin and bones, but still very proud of her appearance.
tr: He was coughing a lot and was very thin, almost skin and bones; but he was still proud of his appearance.
es: He coughed a lot and looked very thin, almost emaciated. But she still felt proud of her appearance.

en: (Look at that, said my mother, half grudgingly, half admiringly.
vi: (Look at her, my mother said, half grumbling, half admiring.
tr: (Look at him, said my mother, half angry, half admiring.
es: (Look at her, my mother said a bit grudgingly and with a certain tone of admiration.

en: She still takes pride in her appearance.)
vi: She is still proud of her appearance.)
tr: He is still proud of his appearance.)
es: She still feels proud of her appearance.)

en: She was carefully made up, heavy mascara on her
vi: She applied makeup meticulously, thick mascara on her lashes, pink blush on her cheeks, the skin on her face stretched tight like a taut rubber glove.
tr: He had carefully applied makeup, with dark mascara on his eyelashes and blush on his cheekbones, which were as taut as a tightly pulled rubber glove.
es: She was carefully made up, with a lot of mascara on her eyelashes and blush on her cheeks, and her skin was stretched tight like an inflated rubber glove.

en: eyelashes, rouge on the bones of her cheeks, over which the skin was stretched like a rubber glove pulled tight.
vi: She applied makeup meticulously, thick mascara on her lashes, pink blush on her cheeks, the skin on her face stretched tight like a taut rubber glove.
tr: He had carefully applied makeup, with dark mascara on his eyelashes and blush on his cheekbones, which were as taut as a tightly pulled rubber glove.
es: She was carefully made up, with a lot of mascara on her eyelashes and blush on her cheeks, and her skin was stretched tight like an inflated rubber glove.

en: She was wearing pearls.
vi: She wore pearls.
tr: He was wearing pearls.
es: She wore jewelry.

en: He was not a monster, she said.
vi: He is not a demon, she said.
tr: Adam was not a monster, said the woman.
es: He was not a monster, he said.

en: People say he was a monster, but he was not one.
vi: People say he is a demon, but he is not.
tr: People say he was a monster, but he was not.
es: People say that he was a monster, but it is not true.

en: What could she have been thinking about?
vi: Did she ever wonder what she was thinking?
tr: What could he have been thinking?
es: What could she have been thinking about?

en: Not much, I guess; not back then, not at the time.
vi: Not much, I think; not then, not at that time.
tr: Not much, I guess; not at that time and in that moment.
es: I suppose about nothing; not the past, not that moment.

en: She was thinking about how not to think.
vi: She thought about how not to think.
tr: He was thinking about how not to think.
es: She was thinking about how not to think.

en: The times were abnormal.
vi: A grotesque era.
tr: Those times were abnormal.
es: It was an abnormal time.

en: She took pride in her appearance.
vi: She was proud of her appearance.
tr: He was proud of his appearance.
es: She was proud of her appearance.

en: She did not believe he was a monster.
vi: She didn't believe he was a devil.
tr: He didn't believe the man was a monster.
es: She didn't believe he was a monster.

en: Hw was not a monster, to her.
vi: He wasn't a devil, in her eyes.
tr: To him, the man was not a monster.
es: He wasn't, to her.

en: Probably he had some endearing trait: he whistled, offkey, in the shower, he had a yen for truffles, he called his dog Liebchen and made it sit up for little pieces of raw steak.
vi: He had many endearing traits: he often whistled off-key in the bathroom, he constantly nibbled on chocolate candies, he called the dog Liebchen, darling, and made it sit on its hind legs before rewarding it with pieces of raw meat.
tr: Maybe the man had a lovable trait: he would whistle in the shower, loved truffles, and called his dog Liebchen, making it stand on its hind legs for small pieces of raw meat.
es: He probably had some attractive trait: he whistled off-key in the shower, liked truffles, called his dog Liebchen and made it sit to give it pieces of raw meat.

en: How easy it is to invent a humanity, for anyone at all.
vi: It's all too easy to invent humanity for anyone in the world.
tr: How easy it is to find a humane side in anyone.
es: How easy it is to invent anyone's humanity.

en: What an available temptation.
vi: Temptation within reach.
tr: What a useful provocation.
es: What a realizable temptation.

en: A big child, she would have said to herself.
vi: Just a big child, she must have told herself.
tr: She must have thought to herself, big child.
es: A big child, she must have told herself.

en: Her heart would have melted, she'd have smoothed the hair back from his forehead, kissed him on the ear, and not just to get something out of him either.
vi: Her heart softened, she brushed back the hair from his forehead, kissed his ear, not just to extract something from him.
tr: Her heart would soften, she would push back the hair falling on the man's forehead, kiss his ear, and she wouldn't do it just to get something from him.
es: Her heart must have softened, she must have brushed the hair from his forehead and kissed his ear, not precisely to get something from him.

en: The instinct to soothe, to make it better.
vi: The instinct to soothe, to make everything better.
tr: The urge to soothe, to make things better.
es: It was the soothing instinct, the instinct to make things better.

en: There there, she'd say, as he woke from a nightmare.
vi: There, there, she must have said, when he woke from a nightmare.
tr: Come on, come on, she would say when the man woke up from a nightmare.
es: Come on, come on, she would say to him when he woke up from a nightmare.

en: Things are so hard for you.
vi: You've endured so much.
tr: Everything is so hard for you.
es: This is very hard for you.

en: All this she would have believed, because otherwise how could she have kept on living?
vi: She believed all of that, because how else could she go on living?
tr: She must have believed all this, otherwise how could she continue to live?
es: This is what she must have believed because otherwise, how could she have continued living?

en: She was very ordinary, under that beauty.
vi: She was only human, despite her beauty.
tr: So ordinary, beneath that beauty.
es: Beneath that beauty hid a normal woman.

en: She believed 't't in decency, she was nice to the Jewish maid, or nice enough, nicer than she needed to be.
vi: She believed in manners, she was very gentle with the Jewish maid, at least quite gentle, gentler than necessary.
tr: She believed in kindness, she was kind to the Jewish maid or kind enough, kinder than necessary.
es: She believed in decency, was kind to the Jewish maid, or quite kind, or kinder than the maid deserved.
