en: Several days after this interview with her was filmed, she killed herself.
vi: A few days after recording the interview tape, she committed suicide.
tr: A few days after this interview was filmed, he killed himself.
es: A few days after this interview was filmed, he committed suicide.

en: It said that, right on television.
vi: That's what they said, right on television.
tr: They said this directly on television.
es: They said it on television.

en: Nobody asked her whether or not she had loved him.
vi: No one asked her if she had ever loved him.
tr: Nobody asked if anyone liked that man.
es: Nobody asked her if she had loved him or not.

en: What I remember now, most of all, is the make-up.
vi: What I remember most clearly now is the way she did her makeup.
tr: Now, what I remember the most is her makeup.
es: What I now remember, more clearly than anything else, is the makeup.

en: 1 stand up, in the dark, start to unbutton.
vi: I stood up, in the dark, and began to unbutton.
tr: I'm standing up in the dark, starting to unbutton my clothes.
es: I stand up in the darkness and start to unbutton myself.

en: Then I hear something, inside my body.
vi: Then I heard something, within my body.
tr: Then I hear something, somewhere inside my body.
es: Then I hear something inside my body.

en: I've broken, something has cracked, that must be it.
vi: I had broken, something had just cracked, no doubt about it.
tr: I broke something, something cracked, it must be like this.
es: I have broken, something has split inside me, it must be that.

en: Noise is coming up, coming out, of the broken place, in my face.
vi: The sound was rising, escaping, from the place that had just broken, on my face.
tr: The noise rises from the broken place on my face, escaping outside.
es: The noise rises and comes out from the broken place to my face.

en: Without warning: I wasn't thinking about here or there or anything.
vi: Without any warning: I wasn't thinking about here or there or any other place.
tr: Without warning: I wasn't thinking about here, there, or anything.
es: Without warning: I was not thinking about anything.

en: If I let the noise get out into the air it will be laughter, too loud, too much of it, someone is bound to hear, and then there will be hurrying footsteps and commands and who knows?
vi: If I let the sound escape into the air, it would turn into laughter, too loud, too much, surely someone would hear it, and then hurried footsteps and orders and who knows what else.
tr: If I let the noise out, it will turn into laughter, excessively loud, too much, someone will definitely hear, then there will be hurried footsteps and orders and who knows what else!
es: If I let this sound out into the air, it will turn into a laugh too loud, someone might hear and then there would be comings and goings, orders and who knows what else.

en: Judgment: emotion
vi: Judgment: emotions inappropriate to the situation.
tr: Judgment: enthusiasm inappropriate to the situation.
es: Conclusion: emotion inappropriate to the circumstances

en: inappropriate to the occasion.
vi: Judgment: emotions inappropriate to the situation.
tr: Judgment: enthusiasm inappropriate to the situation.
es: Conclusion: emotion inappropriate to the circumstances

en: The wandering womb, they used to think.
vi: A wandering womb, they used to say.
tr: Wandering womb, they used to think.
es: The uterus that rambles they used to think.

en: Hysteria.
vi: Hysteria.
tr: Hysteria.
es: Hysteria.

en: And then a needle, a pill.
vi: And then the injection, the dose.
tr: Then a needle, a pill.
es: And then a needle, a pill.

en: It could be fatal.
vi: It could be fatal.
tr: It could have been fatal.
es: It could be fatal.

en: I cram both hands over my mouth as if I'm about to be sick, drop to my knees, the laughter boiling like lava in my throat.
vi: I covered my mouth with both hands as if about to vomit, collapsed to the floor, and my laughter bubbled like lava in my throat.
tr: I cover my mouth with both hands, feeling like I'm about to vomit, I drop to my knees, laughter bubbling in my throat like lava.
es: I put both hands in front of my mouth, as if I were about to vomit; I fall to my knees, the laughter boils in my throat as if it were lava.

en: I crawl into the cupboard, draw up my knees, I'll choke on it.
vi: I crawled into the closet, curled up, I was going to suffocate.
tr: I crawl towards the closet, pulling my knees up, trying to suppress the laughter.
es: I crawl to the closet and pull my knees up; I'm going to suffocate in here.

en: My ribs hurt with holding back, I shake, I heave, seismic, volcanic, I'll burst.
vi: My ribs ached from holding it in, I shook, I panted, earthquake, volcano, I was about to explode.
tr: My ribs ache from holding it in, I'm shaking, swelling, seismic, volcanic, about to explode.
es: My ribs hurt from holding in the laughter so much. I tremble, I shake, seismic, I'm going to explode like a volcano.

en: Red all over the cupboard, mirth rhymes with birth,oh to die of laughter.
vi: Red splattered all over the closet, joy rhymed with labor pain, oh my, dying from laughter.
tr: The closet has turned completely red, birth rhymes with joint, oh my god, I'm going to die from laughing.
es: The closet turns completely red, laughter rhymes with pregnant, oh, dying of laughter.

en: I stifle it in the folds of the hanging cloak, clench my eyes, from which tears are squeezing.
vi: I tucked it into the folds of the hanging cloak, squeezed my eyes shut to hold back the tears, and tried to compose myself.
tr: I am stifling my laughter among the folds of the hanging cloak, closing my eyes where the tears seep out.
es: I hide my face in the folds of the hanging cloak, tightly close my eyes, and tears begin to well up.

en: Try to compose myself.
vi: I tucked it into the folds of the hanging cloak, squeezed my eyes shut to hold back the tears, and tried to compose myself.
tr: I am trying to pull myself together.
es: I try to calm myself.

en: After a while it passes, like an epileptic fit.
vi: A moment later it stopped, like a seizure.
tr: After a while, it passes, like an epileptic seizure.
es: After a while it passes, as if it were an epileptic seizure.

en: Here I am in the closet.
vi: Leaving me alone in the cupboard.
tr: I'm here, inside the closet.
es: Here I am, inside the closet.

en: Nolite te bastardes carborundorum.
vi: Nolite te bastardes carborundorum.
tr: Nolite te bastardes carborundorum.
es: Nolite te bastardes carborundorum.

en: I can'tsee it in the dark but I trace the tiny scratched writing with the ends of my fingers, as if it's a code in Braille.
vi: In the dark, I couldn't see, but I ran my fingertips over the tiny engraved letters, like Braille.
tr: I can't see in the dark, but I feel the engraved writing with my fingertips as if it were written in Braille.
es: I can't see it in the dark, but I follow the tiny letters with my fingertips, as if it were a Braille code.

en: It sounds in my head now less like a prayer, more like a command; but to do what?
vi: Now that phrase echoes in my head not as a prayer, but as a command; but what to do?
tr: It's no longer a prayer but more like a command in my mind; but for what purpose?
es: Now it resonates in my head, not so much as a prayer but as an order, but to do what?

en: Useless to me in any case, an ancient hieroglyph to which the key's been lost.
vi: Either way, it's useless to me, the ancient hieroglyph has lost its deciphering key.
tr: Whatever it is, it's useless, an old hieroglyph whose key has been lost, for me.
es: In any case, it is useless to me, it is like an ancient hieroglyph whose key has been lost.

en: Why did she write it, why did she bother?
vi: Why did she write it, why go to such trouble?
tr: Why did she write this, why did she bother with this?
es: Why did they write it, why did they bother to do it?

en: There's no way out of here.
vi: There's no way out of here.
tr: There's no way out of here.
es: There is no way out of here.

en: I lie on the floor, breathing too fast, then slower, evening out my breathing, as in the Exercises, for giving birth.
vi: I lay on the floor, panting, then held back, balanced my breathing, like in a Physical Education class, preparing to give birth.
tr: I am lying on the ground, breathing very fast, then slower, correcting my breath, like in the exercises done for childbirth.
es: I remain lying on the floor, breathing rapidly, then more slowly, leveling my breath, like in childbirth exercises.

en: All I can hear now is the sound of my own heart, opening and closing, opening and closing, opening
vi: All I could hear was my own heartbeat, opening then closing, opening then closing, opening.
tr: Now all I hear is the sound of my own heart, opening and closing, opening and closing, opening.
es: The only thing I hear now is the sound of my heart, which opens and closes, opens and closes, opens.

en: X
vi: X - The Soul Book
tr: X
es: X

en: Soul Scrolls
vi: X - The Soul Book
tr: Two Cylinders
es: THE SPIRITUAL SCROLLS

vi: X - The Soul Book
es: THE SPIRITUAL SCROLLS
CHAPTER 25

en: What I heard first the next morning was a scream and a crash.
vi: The sound that greeted me the next morning was a scream followed by a clatter.
tr: The first thing I heard the next morning was a scream followed by a clatter.
es: The first thing I heard the next morning was a scream and a crash.

en: Cora, dropping the breakfast tray.
vi: It was Cora, who had just dropped the tray of food.
tr: It was Cora who had dropped the breakfast tray.
es: It was Cora, who had dropped the breakfast tray.

en: It woke me up.
vi: I woke up with a start.
tr: She woke me up.
es: It woke me up.

en: I was still half in the cupboard, head on the bundled cloak.
vi: I was still half inside the closet, my head buried in a bulky robe.
tr: My head was on the bundled-up cloak, still halfway inside the closet.
es: I still had half my body inside the wardrobe, and my head on the cloak, which was nothing more than a lump.

en: I must have pulled it off the hanger, and gone to sleep there; for a moment I couldn't remember where I was.
vi: I must have pulled it off the hanger and then fallen asleep; it took me a minute to understand where I was.
tr: I must have pulled the cloak from the hanger and fallen asleep there; for a moment, I couldn't remember where I was.
es: Surely I took it off the hanger and fell asleep on top of it. At first, I couldn't remember where I was.

en: Cora was kneeling beside me, I felt her hand touchmy back.
vi: Cora was kneeling beside me, and I felt a hand on my back.
tr: Cora had knelt beside me, I felt her hand touch my back.
es: Cora was kneeling beside me; I felt her touch my back.

en: She screamed again when I moved.
vi: She screamed again when I moved.
tr: When I moved, she screamed again.
es: When I moved, she screamed again.

en: What's wrong?
vi: What is that?
tr: What is the matter?
es: What's happening?, I asked him.

en: I said.
vi: I asked.
tr: I asked.
es: What's happening?, I asked him.

en: I rolled over, pushed myself up.
vi: I turned over and sat up.
tr: I turned and straightened up.
es: I turned around and sat up.

en: Oh, she said.
vi: Oh, she said.
tr: Oh, he said.
es: Oh, he said.

en: I thought.
vi: I thought.
tr: I thought so.
es: I thought...

en: She thought what?
vi: What does she think?
tr: What did they think, I wonder?
es: What did he/she believe?

en: Like?
vi: What does she think?
tr: As if... he said.
es: Like..., I added.

en: she said.
vi: It's just like... she said.
tr: As if... he said.
es: Like..., I added.

en: The eggs had broken on the floor, there was orange juice and shattered glass.
vi: The eggs have shattered, there is orange juice and glass shards on the floor.
tr: The eggs that fell to the ground were broken, there was orange juice and pieces of glass on the floor.
es: The eggs were on the floor, broken, and there was orange juice and shattered glass.

en: I'll have to bring another one, she said.
vi: I will have to bring the new one, she said.
tr: We need to bring another one, he said.
es: I'll have to bring another one, he said.

en: Such a waste.
vi: What a waste.
tr: What a pity.
es: What a waste.

en: What was you doing on the floor like that?
vi: What are you doing lying on the floor?
tr: What were you doing on the ground like this?
es: What were you doing lying on the floor?

en: She was pulling at me, to get me up, respectably onto my feet.
vi: She was grabbing me and pulling, to lift me up, properly, neatly.
tr: He was respectfully extending his hand to lift me up.
es: He grabbed me to help me get up and stand.

en: I didn't want to tell her I'd never been to bed at all.
vi: I don't want to say that I haven't even gone to bed yet.
tr: I didn't want to say that I never got into bed.
es: I didn't want to tell him that I hadn't slept all night.

en: There would be no way of explaining that.
vi: Trying to explain that is impossible.
tr: There could be no explanation for that.
es: I wouldn't have known how to explain it to him.

en: I told her I must have fainted.
vi: I said I must have fainted.
tr: I said that I must have passed out.
es: I told him that I must have fainted.

en: That was almost as bad, because she seized on it.
vi: It was just as bad, because she immediately seized on that statement.
tr: This was almost as bad as the other, because she immediately caught on.
es: It was almost worse because he started drawing his own conclusions.

en: It's one of the early signs, she said, pleased.
vi: That's the initial sign, she said, very pleased.
tr: One of the first signs, he said contentedly.
es: It's one of the first symptoms, he said with a tone of satisfaction.

en: Thai, and throwing up.
vi: That and vomiting too.
tr: This and vomiting.
es: That, and the vomiting.

en: She should have known there hadn't been time enough, but she was very hopeful.
vi: She had to know that it wasn't enough time yet, but she was still very optimistic.
tr: He must have known that not enough time had passed; still, he was very hopeful.
es: He should have realized that not enough time had passed; but he had high hopes.

en: No, it's not that, I said.
vi: No, it's not that, I said.
tr: No, this isn't it, I said.
es: No, that's not it, I told him.

en: I was sitting in the chair.
vi: At this moment, I am sitting on the chair.
tr: I was sitting on the chair.
es: She was sitting in the chair.

en: I'm sure it isn't that.
vi: Definitely not.
tr: I'm sure this isn't it.
es: I'm sure that's not it.

en: I was just dizzy.
vi: I'm just dizzy.
tr: My head was just spinning.
es: I just got dizzy.

en: I was just standing here and things went dark.
vi: I was standing here and then I suddenly blacked out.
tr: While standing here, everything suddenly went dark.
es: I was here, and everything started to get dark.

en: Itmust have been the strain, she said, of yesterday and all.
vi: It's probably due to stress, she said, from yesterday and everything.
tr: It must be the tension of yesterday and everything, he said.
es: It must have been because of yesterday's tension, he said.

en: Takes it out of you.
vi: It made her break down.
tr: The pain is coming out now.
es: Take this off.

en: She meant the Birth, and I said it did.
vi: She mentioned Sinh's party, and I said yes.
tr: He was referring to the birth, and I confirmed it.
es: She was referring to the Nativity, and I told her yes.

en: By this time I was sitting in the chair, and she was kneeling on the floor, picking up the pieces of broken glass and egg, gathering them onto the tray.
vi: Up until now, I was still sitting on the chair, while she was kneeling on the floor, picking up pieces of glass and eggs, and putting them all into the tray.
tr: Meanwhile, I was sitting on the beige chair, and he was bent over, picking up the broken glass and egg pieces and putting them on the tray.
es: At that moment, I was sitting in the chair and she was kneeling beside me, picking up the pieces of egg and the broken glass and gathering them on the tray.

en: She blotted some of the orange juice with the paper napkin.
vi: She absorbed some of the orange juice with a paper towel.
tr: He soaked up some of the orange juice with a paper napkin.
es: She dried part of the orange juice with the paper napkin.

en: I'll have to bring a cloth, she said.
vi: I will have to get a rag, she said.
tr: I should bring a cloth, she said.
es: I'll have to bring a cloth, she commented.

en: They'll want to know why the extra eggs.
vi: Everyone will ask why more eggs are needed.
tr: They will want to know the reason for the extra eggs.
es: They'll want to know why I'm bringing more eggs.

en: Unless you could do without.
vi: Unless you can hold out.
tr: Unless you don't want to, of course.
es: Unless you manage without them.

en: She looked up at me side-ways, slyly, and 1 saw that it would be better if we could both pretend I'd eaten my breakfast after all.
vi: She looked up slyly, and I understood that it was better for both of us to pretend that I had eaten breakfast as usual.
tr: She lifted her head and looked at me sideways and cunningly, and I realized it would be better if we both pretended I had already had my breakfast.
es: She looked at me sideways, furtively, and I understood that it would be better if we both pretended that I had eaten the entire breakfast.

en: If she said she'd found me lying on the floor, there would be too many questions.
vi: If she said she saw me lying unconscious on the floor, there would be a lot of questions asked.
tr: If she said she found me lying on the floor, a barrage of questions would follow.
es: If she said she had found me lying on the floor, there would be too many questions.

en: She'd have to account for the broken glass in any case; but Rita would get surly if she had to cook a second breakfast.
vi: Either way, she would have to explain the broken cup, but Rita would be grumpy if she had to cook another meal.
tr: She would still have to account for the broken glass; however, if she had to prepare a second breakfast, Rita would get cranky.
es: In any case, she would have to explain the broken glass; but Rita would get in a bad mood if she had to prepare breakfast a second time.

en: I'll do without, I said.
vi: I can hold on, I said.
tr: I can manage without breakfast, I said.
es: I will manage without them, I assured him.

en: I'm not that hungry.
vi: I'm not too hungry.
tr: I wasn't that hungry.
es: I'm not very hungry.

en: This was good, it fit in with the dizziness.
vi: That way, it can eat with the child without feeling dizzy.
tr: This was good, it matched the dizziness.
es: It was perfect because it fit with the dizziness.

en: But I could manage the toast, I said.
vi: But I will have a piece of bread, I said.
tr: Still, I can eat the toast, I said.
es: But I will eat the toast, I added.

en: I didn't want
vi: I don't want to have nothing in my stomach.
tr: I didn't want to go without eating anything at all.
es: I didn't want to go completely without eating.

en: to go without breakfast altogether.
vi: I don't want to have nothing in my stomach.
tr: I didn't want to go without eating anything at all.
es: I didn't want to go completely without eating.

en: It's been on the floor, she said.
vi: It has hit the floor already, she said.
tr: He fell down, but he said.
es: It's on the ground, he warned me.

en: I don't mind, I said.
vi: No problem, I said.
tr: Never mind, I said.
es: It doesn't matter, I said to her.

en: I sat there eating the piece of brown toast while she went into the bathroom and flushed the handful of egg, which could not be salvaged, down the toilet.
vi: I sat there chewing a piece of brown toast while she went into the bathroom to wash away the irredeemable eggs.
tr: While she went to the bathroom and threw a handful of now useless eggs into the toilet and flushed them, I sat there and started eating a slice of brown bread.
es: I sat down to eat the toast while she went into the bathroom and threw the handful of egg she couldn't recover into the toilet.

en: Then she came back.
vi: Then she came back out.
tr: She came back a little later.
es: Then he went out again.

en: I'll say I dropped the tray on the way out, she said.
vi: I will pretend to have dropped the tray on the way out, she said.
tr: "I will say that I dropped the tray while going up," he said.
es: I'll say that the tray fell when I was leaving, he announced.

en: It pleased me that she was willing to lie for me, even in such a small thing, even for her own advantage.
vi: I am very happy to see you are willing to lie for me, even over small matters, even for yourself.
tr: It pleased me that he intended to lie to me, even on such a simple matter and for his own benefit.
es: I liked that she was willing to lie for me, even in something so insignificant, even if it was for her own benefit.

en: It was a link between us.
vi: It creates a bond between us.
tr: This was a bond between us.
es: It was a way to be united.

en: I smiled at her.
vi: I smiled at her.
tr: I smiled at her.
es: I smiled at her.

en: I hope nobody heard you, I said.
vi: Hope no one heard you say that, I said.
tr: I hope no one heard you, I said.
es: I hope no one heard you, I said to her.

en: It did give me a turn, she said, as she stood in the doorway with the tray.
vi: I was also scared, she said, standing in the doorway with a tray in her hands.
tr: While standing in the doorway with the tray, she took my breath away, he said.
es: I got quite a scare, he said, stopping at the entrance with the tray in his hand.

en: At first I thought it was just your clothes, like.
vi: At first, I thought it was just your clothes, something like that.
tr: At first, I thought they were just your clothes.
es: At first, I thought it was just your clothes.

en: Then I said to myself, what're they doing there on the floor?
vi: Then I told myself, why are they lying on the floor?
tr: Then I asked myself, what are they doing on the floor?
es: Then I said to myself, what are her clothes doing on the floor?

en: I thought maybe you'd Run off, I said.
vi: I thought maybe you had... Run away, I said.
tr: I thought, maybe you... He/She has escaped..., I said.
es: I thought that maybe you had... Fugitive, I added.

en: Well, but, she said.
vi: Um, but, she said.
tr: Um, but, he said.
es: Well, almost, he admitted.

en: But it was you.
vi: But it was her.
tr: But it was you.
es: But it was you.

en: Yes, I said.
vi: Yes, I said.
tr: Yes, I said.
es: Yes, I affirmed.

en: It was.
vi: It's me.
tr: I bent.
es: It was.

en: And it was, and she went out with the tray and came back with a cloth for the rest of the orange juice, and Rita that afternoon made a grumpy remark about some folks being all thumbs.
vi: And that's how it was, and she took the tray out and then brought a rag back to wipe up the spilled water, and that afternoon Rita grumbled about someone being extremely clumsy.
tr: I bent down; she returned with a piece of cloth to collect the remnants of the orange juice from the tray. That afternoon, Rita made a sarcastic comment about some people's incompetence.
es: And it was, and she went out with the tray and came back with a cloth to clean up the rest of the orange juice, and that afternoon Rita made a grumpy comment about how some people were clumsy.

en: Too much on their minds, don't look where they're going, she said, and we continued on from there as if nothing had happened.
vi: Thinking about everything under the sun, not knowing where I was going anymore, she said, and we continued as if nothing had happened.
tr: They don't look where they're going, their heads in the clouds, she said, as if nothing had happened. We continued from where we left off.
es: They have too many things on their minds, they don't watch where they're going, she complained, and we carried on as if nothing had happened.

en: That was in May.
vi: It was May.
tr: This happened in May.
es: This happened in May.

en: Spring has now been undergone.
vi: Now spring had left its footsteps behind.
tr: We had passed the spring.
es: Now spring has passed, the tulips have stopped blooming and are starting to lose their petals one by one, as if they were teeth.

en: The tulips have had their moment and are done, shedding their petals one by one, like teeth.
vi: The tulip beds had reached their peak of glory and had faded, shedding petals one by one, like losing teeth.
tr: The tulips had lived their days, now they were wilting, shedding their petals one by one like teeth.
es: Now spring has passed, the tulips have stopped blooming and are starting to lose their petals one by one, as if they were teeth.

en: One day I came upon Serena Joy, kneeling on a cushion in the garden, her cane beside her on the grass.
vi: One day I stumbled upon Serena Joy, kneeling on a cushion in the garden, her cane on the grass.
tr: One day, I encountered Serena Joy kneeling on a cushion in the garden, her cane resting on the grass beside her.
es: One day I stumbled upon Serena Joy, who was in the garden, kneeling on a cushion, with her cane beside her on the grass.

en: She was snipping off the seedpods with a pair of shears.
vi: She was using garden shears to trim all the seed pods.
tr: She was cutting seed pods with scissors.
es: She was cutting the buds with a pair of scissors.

en: I watched her sideways as I went past, with my basket of oranges and lamb chops.
vi: I glanced sideways as I walked past her, carrying a basket of oranges and lamb chops.
tr: I watched her from the side as I passed by with my basket containing oranges and lamb chops.
es: I was carrying my basket with oranges and lamb chops, and as I passed by, I glanced at her sideways.

en: She was aiming, positioning the blades of the shears, then cutting with a convulsive jerk of the hands.
vi: She aimed, placed the blades in position, then made a cut, her hand twitching in a very peculiar way.
tr: She was aiming carefully and cutting by pressing her hands firmly, adjusting the blades of the scissors.
es: She was focused, adjusting the blades of the scissors, and when she cut, she did so with a convulsive spasm of her hands.

en: Was it the arthritis, creeping up?
vi: Was this due to arthritis, creeping up on her?
tr: Was her arthritis getting worse?
es: Could it be arthritis taking over her hands?

en: Or some blitzkrieg, some kamikaze, committed on the swelling geni-talia of the flowers?
vi: Or was it a Blitzkrieg, a kamikaze attack, aimed at the swollen reproductive organs of the flowers?
tr: Or was this a kind of kamikaze attack directed at the swollen sexual organs of the flowers?
es: Or a blitzkrieg, a kamikaze launching itself onto the swollen genital organs of the flowers?

en: The fruiting body.
vi: Removing the seed pods is considered a way to help the plant store nutrients in its bulbs.
tr: The fruit-bearing body.
es: The fruiting body.

en: To cut off the seedpods is supposed to make the bulb store energy.
vi: Removing the seed pods is considered a way to help the plant store nutrients in its bulbs.
tr: It is assumed that by cutting the seed pods, the flower bulb is enabled to store energy.
es: By cutting the buds, the bulb accumulates energy.

en: Saint Serena, on her knees, doing penance.
vi: Saint Serena, kneeling, is repenting.
tr: Saint Serena is confessing her sins on her knees.
es: Saint Serena, kneeling, doing penance.

en: I often amused myself this way, with small mean-minded bitter jokes about her; but not for long.
vi: I often entertained myself that way, with petty, bitter jokes about her, but not for long.
tr: I often amused myself by making shallow, bitter jokes about him; but not for too long.
es: I often amuse myself this way, with spiteful and bitter jokes about her; but not for long.

en: It doesn't do to linger, watching Serena Joy, from behind.
vi: Idly watching Serena Joy from behind didn't accomplish anything either.
tr: It's not advisable to waste time watching Serena Joy from behind.
es: It's not convenient to waste time looking at Serena Joy from behind.

en: What I coveted was the shears.
vi: I long for those garden shears.
tr: The thing I envied was the scissors.
es: What I was looking at greedily were the scissors.

en: Well.
vi: Sigh.
tr: Alright.
es: Good.

en: Then we had the irises, rising beautiful and cool on their tall stalks, like blown glass, like pastel water momentarily frozen in a splash, light blue, light mauve, and the darker ones, velvet and purple, black cat's ears in the sun, indigo shadow, and the bleeding hearts, so female in shape it was a surprise they'd not long since been rooted out.
vi: Then we planted irises, rising gracefully and flamboyantly on their lofty stems, as if blown from glass, like pale-colored water frozen in mid-splash, light blue, pale lavender, or darker hues, velvet and purple, black cat ears in the sun, evening indigo, and bleeding heart flowers, so delicately imagined that it’s surprising to remember they were just recently uprooted.
tr: Back then, we had irises in light blue, light lilac, darker shades, velvet and purple colors, with long stems rising beautifully and coolly like shattered glass, frozen in mid-splash like pastel water; cat ears under the sun, indigo shadow, and girl hearts: Their forms were so feminine that it was surprising they hadn't been uprooted yet.
es: Additionally, we had the irises, which grow beautifully and freshly on their long stems, like blown glass, like a watercolor momentarily frozen in a stain, light blue, light mauve, and the darker ones, velvety and purplish, like the ears of a black cat illuminated by the sun, an indigo shadow, and those with a bloody center, of such feminine shapes that it was surprising that once picked they did not last.

en: There is something subversive about this garden of Serena's, a sense of buried things bursting upwards, wordlessly, into the light, as if to point, to say:Whatever is silenced will clamor to be heard, though silently.
vi: Serena's garden had a rebellious quality, with buried things competing to outdo each other, silently reaching for the light, as if to show, to say: What is silenced will clamor to be heard, even without making a sound.
tr: There was something destructive in Serena's garden, an intuition that buried things were throwing themselves into the light without uttering a single word; as if they were saying: The silenced will make a clamor to be heard, even if silently.
es: There is something subversive in Serena's garden, a sense of things buried that burst upwards, silently, under the light, as if pointing and saying: That which is silenced will cry out to be heard, even if silently.

en: A Tennyson garden, heavy with scent, languid; the return of the word swoon.
vi: A Tennyson-like garden, heavy with scent, languid; the resurgence of the word swoon.
tr: A Tennyson garden, heavy and faint with scents; the return of the word "languid."
es: A Tennyson garden, imbued with fragrance, languid; the return of the word fading.

en: Light pours down upon it from the sun, true, but also heat rises, from the flowers themselves, you can feel it: like holding your hand an inch above an arm, a shoulder.
vi: Light poured down from the sky, indeed, but the heat also rose up, from the very flowers themselves, palpably felt: like holding a hand a few inches above an arm, a shoulder.
tr: It's true that sunlight spreads over them, but heat also rises from the flowers, this can be felt: like holding your hand just above an arm, a shoulder.
es: The sunlight pours over it, it's true, but the heat emanates from the flowers themselves, you can feel it: it's like holding your hand a centimeter above an arm or a shoulder.

en: It breathes, in the warmth, breathing itself in.
vi: It breathed, in the warmth, inhaling itself fully.
tr: Breathing in the heat, drawing it into itself.
es: It emits heat, and it also receives it.

en: To walk through it in these days, of peonies, of pinks and carnations, makes my head swim.
vi: Walking through the garden these days, between red peonies, pink and purple carnations, my head swam.
tr: These days, wandering in the garden among peonies, pink and light red carnations makes my head spin.
es: Walking through this garden of peonies, carnations, and pinks on a day like today makes my head spin.

en: The willow is in full plumage and is no help, with its insinuating whispers.
vi: The willow trees are displaying their dense foliage and doing nothing more, as they continuously whisper near and far.
tr: The willow has blossomed and is not at all helpful, with its suggestive whispers.
es: The willow displays abundant foliage and lets its insinuating whisper be heard.

en: Rendezvous, it says, terraces;the sibilants run up my spine, a shiver as if in fever.
vi: Promises, it reminds, stirring, the sound of the wind rustling runs along my spine, I shiver as if with fever.
tr: The terraces speak of appointments, vowels tickle my spine, a shiver comes over me as if I have a fever.
es: Quote, it says, terraces; the whistles run down my spine, like a shiver caused by fever.

en: The summer dress rustles against the flesh of my thighs, the grass grows underfoot, at the edges of my eyes I here are movements, in the branches; feathers,flirtings, grace notes, tree into bird, metamorphosis run wild.
vi: The summer dress rustles against the skin of my thigh, grass grows around my feet, my eyes are full of movement, among the leaves and branches: feathers, branch-hopping, trills, trees turning into birds, transforming into frenzy.
tr: Summer clothes rustle against the flesh of my hips, grass grows under my feet, I notice some movements out of the corner of my eye, on the branches; feathers, flutters, piercing notes, trees turning into birds, metamorphosis running wild.
es: The summer dress brushes the skin of my thighs, the grass grows under my feet and out of the corner of my eye I see something moving in the branches; feathers, a fluttering, graceful sounds, the tree inside the bird, the metamorphosis runs wild.

en: Goddesses are possible now and the air suffuses with desire.
vi: The goddesses descend within reach, the air brimming with sensuality.
tr: Goddesses are now possible and the air is filled with desire.
es: It is possible that goddesses exist, and the air becomes imbued with desire.

en: Even the bricks of the house are softening, becoming tactile; if I leaned against them they'd be warm and yielding.
vi: Even the house bricks soften, inviting touch; if I lean against them, I would feel them warm and comforting.
tr: Even the roof tiles of the house soften, becoming touchable, if I lean on them, they would warm up and give way.
es: Even the bricks of the house soften and become tactile; if I lean against them, they will become warm and flexible.

en: It's amazing what denial can do.
vi: Strange what abstinence can cause.
tr: The things that suppressed desires can do are astonishing.
es: It is surprising what a denial can achieve.

en: Did the sight of my ankle make him lightheaded, faint, at the checkpoint yesterday, when I dropped my pass and let him pick it up for me?
vi: Was it just seeing my ankle that made him dizzy, almost faint, at the checkpoint yesterday, when I dropped my passport and he picked it up for me?
tr: When I dropped my ID at the checkpoint yesterday and allowed him to pick it up for me, did seeing my ankle make his head spin and daze him?
es: Did the fact that he saw my ankle yesterday at the checkpoint, when I dropped my pass for him to pick up, make him dizzy and faint?

en: No handkerchief, no
vi: Without a handkerchief or fan, I used what was available.
tr: Neither handkerchief nor fan, I use what is at hand.
es: No handkerchiefs or fans, I use what I have at hand.

en: fan, I use what's handy.
vi: Without a handkerchief or fan, I used what was available.
tr: Neither handkerchief nor fan, I use what is at hand.
es: No handkerchiefs or fans, I use what I have at hand.

en: Winter is not so dangerous.
vi: Winter is not that dangerous.
tr: Winter is not so dangerous.
es: Winter is not so dangerous.

en: I need hardness, cold, rigidity; not this heaviness, as if I'm a melon on a stem, this liquid ripeness.
vi: I need to be tough, cold, and solid; I don't want to be heavy, like a melon hanging by its stem, I don't want to be overripe and bursting with juice like this.
tr: I need hardness, cold, immobility, as if I were a watermelon on the vine, not this liquid ripeness, this heaviness.
es: I need the insensitivity, the cold, the rigidity; not this heaviness, as if I were a melon on a stem, this liquid maturity.

en: The Commander and I have an arrangement.
vi: The commander and I have settled everything.
tr: There is an agreement between the commander and me.
es: The Commander and I have an agreement.

en: It's not the first such arrangement in history, though the shape it's taken is not the usual one.
vi: It's not the first settlement in history, though it wasn't done in the usual way.
tr: It's not the first agreement of its kind in history, though its form is unusual.
es: It is not the first of its kind in history, although the form it is taking is not usual.

en: I visit the Commander two or three nights a week, always after dinner, but only when I get the signal.
vi: I go to the Commander's room two or three times a week, always after dinner, but only when there is a signal.
tr: I visit the Commander two or three nights a week, always after dinner, but only when I receive the signal.
es: I visit the Commander two or three times a week, always after dinner, but only when I receive the signal.

en: The signal is Nick.
vi: A signal from Nick.
tr: The signal is Nick.
es: And the signal is Nick.

en: If he's polishing the car when I set out for the shopping, or when I come back, and if his hat is on askew or not on at all, then I go.
vi: If he is polishing the car when I go out shopping, or when I return, and his hat is tilted to one side or he is not wearing it, then I go.
tr: If he is polishing the car when I go shopping or when I return, and his hat is tilted on his head or he is not wearing it at all, I go.
es: If when I go out to do the shopping, or when I return, he is polishing the car, and his cap is tilted or not properly worn, then I go to the meeting.

en: If he isn't there or if he has his hat on straight, then I stay in my room in the ordinary way.
vi: If he is absent or wearing his hat normally, I stay in my room as usual.
tr: If he is not there or his hat is properly on, I stay in my room as usual.
es: If he is not there, or his cap is properly worn, I stay in my room, as usual.

en: On Ceremony nights, of course, none of this applies.
vi: Of course, the nights of the Ceremony do not count.
tr: On ceremony nights, of course, none of this applies.
es: Of course, none of this applies during Ceremony nights.

en: The difficulty is the Wife, as always.
vi: The obstacle was Lady, as in all other cases.
tr: The Wife is a problem, as usual.
es: As always, the difficulty is the Wife.

en: After dinner she goes to their bedroom, from where she could conceivably hear me as I sneak along the hall, although I take care to be very quiet.
vi: After dinner, she would return to her bedroom, from where she could completely hear me sneaking down the stairs, even though I always carefully stepped very lightly.
tr: After dinner, despite my efforts to be very quiet, she goes to the bedrooms where she might hear me as I slowly crawl through the hallway.
es: After dinner, she goes to their bedroom, from where she could hear me while I sneak down the hallway, though I am careful not to make any noise.

en: Or she stays in the sitting room, knitting away at her endless Angel scarves, turning out more and more yards of intricate and useless wool people: her form of procreation, it must be.
vi: Sometimes she would sit in the lounge, diligently knitting those endless angelic scarves, adding more yards of exquisitely worthless wool: her own form of reproduction, I suppose.
tr: Or she stays in the living room, creating people out of meters of complicated and useless yarn and continuing to knit endless Angel scarves: This must be her way of producing.
es: Or she stays in the living room, knitting one of her endless scarves for the Angels, crafting meters and meters of intricate and useless woolen people: it must be her way of procreating.

en: The sitting room door is usually left ajar when she's in there, and I don't dare to go past it.
vi: The lounge door was often ajar when she was in there, and I didn't dare to pass by.
tr: When she is inside, the living room door is usually left ajar, and I do not dare to pass through there.
es: Normally, when he is in the living room, the door is left ajar, so I do not dare to pass by it.

en: When I've had the signal but can't make it, down the stairs or along the hall past the sitting room, the Commander understands.
vi: When I was summoned but couldn't go, downstairs or across the hall past the lounge, the Commander always understood.
tr: When I am signaled and cannot comply, when I cannot go down the stairs and pass through the hallway in front of the living room, the Commander understands this.
es: If I have received the signal but cannot go down the stairs or pass by the living room door, the Commander understands.

en: He knows my situation, none better.
vi: He understood my situation better than anyone else.
tr: He knows my situation, at the very least.
es: He, better than anyone, knows my situation.

en: He knows all the rules.
vi: He knew all the rules.
tr: He knows all the rules.
es: He knows all the rules.

en: Sometimes, however, Serena Joy is out, visiting another Commander's Wife, a sick one; that's the only place she could conceivably go, by herself, in the evenings.
vi: However, sometimes Serena Joy is also away from home, visiting another Commander's Wife who is ill; that's the only place I can imagine her going, alone, in the evening.
tr: Still, from time to time, Serena Joy is out, visiting another Commander's Wife, someone who is sick; perhaps the only place she can go on her own in the evenings.
es: However, sometimes Serena Joy is out, visiting a sick Wife; it is the only place she could go alone, at night.

en: She takes food, a cake or pie or loaf of bread baked by Rita, or a jar of jelly, made from the mint leaves that grow in her garden.
vi: She carries food, sweet cakes, savory cakes, or bread baked by Rita, or a jar of homemade mint jelly, made from the mint leaves in her garden.
tr: She takes food with her, a cake or pie baked by Rita, or a loaf of bread, or a jar of marmalade made from mint leaves grown in her garden.
es: She takes food, for example a cake, or a pastry, or a loaf of bread kneaded by Rita, or a jar of jelly made with the mint leaves that grow in her garden.

en: They get sick a lot, these Wives of the Commanders.
vi: As for the Wives, they often fall ill.
tr: The Commanders' Wives tend to be sick quite often.
es: The Commanders' Wives often get sick; this adds interest to their lives.

en: It adds interest to their lives.
vi: It adds a bit of color to their lives.
tr: This gives importance to their lives.
es: The Commanders' Wives often get sick; this adds interest to their lives.

en: As for us, the Handmaids and even the Marthas, we avoid illness.
vi: As for us, the Handmaids and even the Marthas, we avoid illness as much as possible.
tr: As for us, the Handmaids and even the Marthas, we avoid illness.
es: As for us, the Handmaids and even the Marthas, we avoid illness.

en: The Marthas don't want to be forced to retire, because who knows where they go?
vi: The Marthas don't want to be forced into retirement, because who knows where they will go?
tr: The Marthas don't want to be forced into retirement, because who knows where they would go?
es: The Marthas do not want to be forced to retire because who knows where they would go?

en: You don't see that many old women around anymore.
vi: Nowadays, you hardly see any old women in the city.
tr: There aren't many old women around anymore.
es: There are not many old women around anymore.

en: And as for us,
vi: As for us, if we truly fall ill, feel weak, lose weight or appetite, lose hair, or have any gland issues, it would be a death sentence.
tr: As for us, any real illness, anything debilitating, weight or appetite loss, hair loss, malfunctioning glands would be fatal.
es: And

en: any real illness, anything lingering, weakening, a loss of flesh or appetite, a fall of hair, a failure of the glands, would be terminal.
vi: As for us, if we truly fall ill, feel weak, lose weight or appetite, lose hair, or have any gland issues, it would be a death sentence.
tr: As for us, any real illness, anything debilitating, weight or appetite loss, hair loss, malfunctioning glands would be fatal.
es: as for us, any real illness, anything chronic or debilitating, a loss of weight or appetite, hair loss, a gland failure, would be decisive.

en: I remember Cora, earlier in the spring,staggering around even though she had the flu, holding on to the door frames when she thought no one was looking, being careful not to cough.
vi: I still remember Cora, early in the spring, trying to drag herself around the house despite having the flu, clinging to the door when she thought no one would replace her, doing her best to stifle her cough.
tr: I remember Cora, who, despite having the flu in early spring, walked around staggering, holding onto door frames when she thought no one was looking, and taking care not to cough.
es: I remember that at the beginning of spring, Cora was running around the house despite the flu, and she would hold onto the doors when she thought no one was watching, making efforts not to cough.

en: A slight cold, she said when Serena asked her.
vi: Just a mild cold, she replied to Serena's inquiry.
tr: When Serena asked, she said, I just caught a bit of a chill.
es: When Serena asked her what was wrong, she said it was just a slight cold.

en: Serena herself sometimes takes a few days off, tucked up in bed.
vi: Even Serena sometimes takes a few days off, wrapped tightly in a bunch of blankets.
tr: Serena takes a few days off.
es: Serena herself sometimes takes a few days off and stays in bed.

en: Then she's the one to get the company, the Wives rustling up the stairs, clucking and cheerful; she gets the cakes and pies, the jelly, the bouquets of flowers from their gardens.
vi: During those times, it is her turn to entertain friends; the ladies bustle up and down the stairs, cheerfully laughing; she receives sweet and savory pastries, jams, and flowers cut from their gardens.
tr: In this case, she is the one to be accompanied, and the other Wives go up the stairs, clucking and cheerfully, rustling; this time, she is the one receiving the cakes and pastries, the marmalades, and the bouquets of flowers from their gardens.
es: Then it is she who receives visits; the other Wives noisily climb the stairs and chatter cheerfully; she receives the pies and cakes, the jelly and the bouquets of flowers from the gardens of the others.

en: They take turns.
vi: They take turns.
tr: They do this in turns.
es: They take turns.

en: There is some sort of list, invisible, unspoken.
vi: There is some kind of list, invisible, implicitly understood.
tr: There is a kind of list, invisible, unspoken.
es: There is a kind of invisible and tacit list.

en: Each is careful not to hog more than her share of the attention.
vi: Everyone is careful not to take more than their share of attention.
tr: Each one takes care not to attack more than their fair share of attention.
es: Each one is careful not to monopolize attention more than what is appropriate.

en: On the nights when Serena is due to be out, I'm sure to be summoned.
vi: On the nights I knew Serena would leave, I would inevitably be called.
tr: On the nights when Serena has to be out, it is certain that I will be called.
es: On the nights when it is certain that Serena will go out, I am sure that I will be summoned.

en: The first time, I was confused.
vi: The first time I was quite bewildered.
tr: The first time, I was confused.
es: The first time I was confused.

en: His needs were obscure to me, and what I could perceive of them seemed to me ridiculous, laughable, like a fetish for lace-up shoes.
vi: The things he needed from me I couldn't grasp, and in my perception, they seemed absurd, ridiculous, like the fondness for lace-up shoes.
tr: The requirements were unclear to me, and what I could perceive seemed foolish and ridiculous, like a fetish for lace-up shoes.
es: His needs were unknown to me, and what I could receive in return seemed ridiculous, laughable, like a fetish for tying shoes.

en: Also, there had been a letdown of sorts.
vi: At the same time, there was also a bit of disappointment.
tr: On the other hand, I was disappointed.
es: There had also been a kind of disappointment.

en: What had I been expecting, behind that closed door, the first time?
vi: What was I expecting, behind the still-closed door, when I stood there for the first time?
tr: What was I expecting behind that closed door the first time?
es: What was I expecting the first time, behind the closed door?

en: Something unspeakable, down on all fours perhaps, perversions, whips, mutilations?
vi: Something that cannot be named, crawling on all fours perhaps, depraved, whipping, mutilation?
tr: Something indescribable with words: crawling on the ground on all fours, perversions, whips, mutilations?
es: Something indescribable, perhaps positions on all fours, perversions, whippings, mutilations?

en: At the very least some minor sexual manipulation, some bygone peccadillo now denied him, prohibited by law and punishable by amputation.
vi: At the very least, some mild debauchery, an old rebellious habit that had slipped away from him, a serious crime by law, punishable by amputation.
tr: At least some minor sexual coercions, some small crimes left in the past now deprived, things forbidden by law and punishable by the amputation of a limb.
es: At the very least, some minor sexual manipulation, some past sin that was now denied to him, forbidden by law and punishable by amputation.

en: To be asked to play Scrabble, instead, as if we were an old married couple, or two children, seemed kinky in the extreme, a violation in its own way.
vi: Playing Scrabble, instead, like an old married couple, or two kids, could be considered extraordinarily bizarre, a different kind of violation.
tr: Instead of these, being asked to play Scrabble like an old married couple or two children seemed extremely strange to me, like a violation in its own way.
es: Instead, the fact that he asked me to play Intelect, as if we were an elderly couple or a pair of children, seemed extremely strange to me, in its own way also a violation.

en: As a request it was opaque.
vi: A proposal too vague.
tr: It was vague as a request.
es: As a request, it was obtuse.

en: So when I left the room, it still wasn't clear to me what he wanted, or why, or whether I could fulfill any of it for him.
vi: So when I left the room, I still didn't understand what he wanted, why, or whether I could meet any of his demands.
tr: That's why, when I left the room, it was still not clear to me why He wanted what He wanted or whether I could fulfill any of these for Him.
es: So when I left the room, I still wasn't clear on what he wanted, or why, or if I could fulfill any of it.

en: If there's to be a bargain, the terms of exchange must be set forth.
vi: If planning a negotiation, the terms of exchange must be laid out on the table.
tr: If there is going to be a negotiation, the terms of the deal must be laid out.
es: When it comes to business, the terms of the exchange must be stated.

en: This was something he certainly had not done.
vi: Clearly, this had not been done.
tr: It was certain that He had not done this.
es: Certainly, this was something he had not done.

en: I thought he might be toying, some cat-and-mouse routine, but now I think that his motives and desires weren't obvious even to him.
vi: I thought he was baiting me, playing cat and mouse, but now I think perhaps even he wasn't fully aware of his own motives and desires.
tr: I had thought that He might be playing with me like a cat with a mouse, but now I think that His impulses and desires were not even clear to Himself.
es: I thought he was playing cat and mouse, but now I believe that his motives and desires were not obvious even to himself.

en: They had not yet reached the level of
vi: They had not yet reached the level of words.
tr: They had not yet reached the level of words.
es: They had not yet reached the verbal level.

en: words.
vi: They had not yet reached the level of words.
tr: They had not yet reached the level of words.
es: They had not yet reached the verbal level.

en: The second evening began in the same way as the first.
vi: The second evening began just like the previous one.
tr: The second evening began just like the first.
es: The second night started just like the first.

en: I went to the door, which was closed, knocked on it, was told to come in.
vi: I went to the door, still closed, knocked, and was let in.
tr: I went to the closed door, knocked, and was told to come in.
es: I went to his door —which was closed—, knocked, and he told me to come in.

en: Then followed the same two games, with the smooth beige counters.
vi: Then came two games just the same, with smooth, golden pieces.
tr: This was followed by two games of Scrabble played with smooth beige tiles.
es: Then followed the two games with the soft beige-colored pieces.

en: Prolix, quartz, quandary, sylph, rhythm, all the old tricks with consonants I could dream up or remember.
vi: Prolix, quartz, quandary, sylph, rhythm2, all the old consonant tricks I could think of or remember.
tr: Prolix, quartz, quandary, sylph, rhythm11, all those old tricks I could remember with consonants.
es: Neat, quartz, doorjamb, sylph, rhythm, all the old tricks I could imagine or remember to use the consonants.

en: My tongue felt thick with the effort of spelling.
vi: My tongue hurt from trying to pronounce the words.
tr: My tongue was swollen with the effort of spelling.
es: My tongue felt heavy from the effort of spelling.

en: It was like using a language I'd once known but had nearly forgotten, a language having to do with customs that had long before passed out of the world: cafe au lait at an outdoor table, with a brioche, absinthe in a tall glass, orshrimp in a cornucopia of newspaper; things I'd read about once but had never seen.
vi: It was like using a language once learned but almost entirely forgotten, a language tied to customs long gone: café au lait placed on a table outside the door, brioche bread, absinthe beer in tall glasses, lobsters wrapped in newspaper shaped like a horn; things I had read about but never seen with my own eyes.
tr: It was like using a language I once knew but had almost forgotten, a language related to customs long gone from this world. On a balcony table, café au lait, a brioche12 beside it, absinthe in a tall glass or shrimp in a newspaper cone; things I once read about but never saw.
es: It was like using a language I once knew but had almost forgotten, a language related to customs that disappeared long ago: café au lait on a terrace, with a brioche, absinthe served in a tall glass or shrimp in a paper cone; things I had read about but never seen.

en: It was like trying to walk without crutches, like those phony scenes in old TV movies.
vi: It was like trying to walk without crutches, like those fake scenes in old TV shows.
tr: Like the fake scenes in old TV movies, it was like trying to walk without crutches:
es: It was like trying to walk without crutches, like those fake fights in old television movies.

en: You can do it.
vi: You can do it.
tr: You can do it.
es: You can do it.

en: I know you can.
vi: I know you can do it.
tr: I know you can do it.
es: I know you can.

en: That was the way my mind lurched and stumbled, among the sharp R's and T's, sliding over the ovoid vowels as if on pebbles.
vi: My mind kept groping and stumbling around the sharp R's and T's, gliding swiftly over the round vowels like pebbles.
tr: My mind, sliding over the round vowels as if on pebbles, staggering and stumbling among the sharp r's and t's, this is how it was.
es: Thus my mind staggered and stumbled among the angular r's and t's, sliding over the ovoid vowels as if over pebbles.

en: The Commander was patient when I hesitated, or asked him for a correct spelling.
vi: The commander showed patience whenever I hesitated or asked him how to write something correctly.
tr: When I hesitated or consulted him for the correct spelling, the Commander was patient.
es: The Commander was patient when I hesitated or asked him what the correct spelling of a word was.

en: We can always look it up in the dictionary, he said.
vi: You can look it up in the dictionary, he said.
tr: We can always look it up in the dictionary, he would say.
es: We always have time to consult the dictionary, he said.

en: He said we.
vi: Tell me.
tr: We, he would say.
es: He said we can.

en: The first time, I realized, he'd let me win.
vi: For the first time, I realized he had let me win.
tr: For the first time, I realized that he had allowed me to win.
es: I realized that the first time he had let me win.

en: That night I was expecting everything to be the same, including the good-night kiss.
vi: That night I thought everything would be the same, until the goodbye kiss.
tr: That night, I expected everything to be the same, including the goodnight kiss.
es: I hoped that everything would be the same that night, including the goodnight kiss.

en: But when we'd finished the second game, he sat back in his chair.
vi: But after finishing the next game, he leaned back in his chair.
tr: But when we finished the second game, he leaned back in his chair.
es: But when we finished the game, he leaned back in the chair.

en: He placed his elbows on the arms of the chair, the tips of his fingers together, and looked at me.
vi: He placed his hands on the armrests, with his ten fingers pressed together, looking at me.
tr: He placed his elbows on the arms of the chair, joined his fingertips together, and looked at me.
es: He rested his elbows on the arms of the chair, brought the tips of his fingers together, and looked at me.

en: I have a little present for you, he said.
vi: I have a little gift for you, he said.
tr: I have a small gift for you, he said.
es: I have a small gift for you, he announced.

en: He smiled a little.
vi: He smiled slightly.
tr: He smiled slightly.
es: He smiled slightly.

en: Then he pulled open the top drawer of his desk and took something out.
vi: Then he opened the top drawer and took out something.
tr: Then he opened the top drawer of his desk and took something out.
es: Then he opened the top drawer of his desk and took something out.

en: He held it a moment, casually enough, between thumb and finger, as if deciding whether or not to give it to me.
vi: He held it for a minute, rather indifferently, between his thumb and forefinger, as if pondering whether to give it to me or not.
tr: As if deciding whether or not to give it to me, he held it between two fingers, quite indifferently, for a moment.
es: He held it in his hands for a moment, as if deciding whether to give it to me or not.

en: Although it was upside-down from where I was sitting, I recognized it.
vi: Even though I was looking at it from an angle, I still recognized it.
tr: Even though it was upside down from where I was sitting, I recognized it.
es: Although from where I was I saw it upside down, I recognized it immediately.

en: They were once common enough.
vi: In the past, they were everywhere.
tr: They were quite common once.
es: At one time, they had been very common.

en: It was a magazine, a women's magazine it looked like from the picture, a model on glossy paper, hair blown, neck scarfed, mouth lipsticked; the fall fashions.
vi: A magazine, judging by the picture it was probably a women's magazine, with a model printed on glossy paper, hair tousled, scarf around her neck, lips painted; fall fashion.
tr: It was a magazine, judging by the picture, a women's magazine, on glossy paper, with a photo model with flowing hair, a scarf around her neck, and painted lips; fashion mode.
es: It was a magazine, a women's magazine, as I deduced from the photo on the glossy paper: a model with teased hair, a scarf wrapped around her neck, painted lips; fall fashion.

en: I thought such magazines had all been destroyed, but here was one,
vi: I thought this type had been completely destroyed, but here it was, a leftover issue, in the private room of a Commander, where no one would have imagined.
tr: I thought all such magazines had been destroyed, but here was one, in a place where you would never expect to find such a thing, in a Commander's private study.
es: I thought all those magazines had been destroyed, but there was one left and it was here, in the Commander's private office, where you least expected to find something like that.

en: left over, in a Commander's private study, where you'd least expect to find such a thing.
vi: I thought this type had been completely destroyed, but here it was, a leftover issue, in the private room of a Commander, where no one would have imagined.
tr: I thought all such magazines had been destroyed, but here was one, in a place where you would never expect to find such a thing, in a Commander's private study.
es: I thought all those magazines had been destroyed, but there was one left and it was here, in the Commander's private office, where you least expected to find something like that.

en: He looked down at the model, who was right-side-up to him; he was still smiling, that wistful smile of his.
vi: He looked down at the model, in the same direction; the smile still lingered, a characteristic wistful smile.
tr: He looked at the photo model, who was upright from his perspective; he was still smiling, that desirous smile of his.
es: He looked at the model, who was facing him; he was still smiling, with that melancholic smile that characterized him.

en: It was a look you'd give to an almost extinct animal, at the zoo.
vi: That look people often give to near-extinct animals in a zoo.
tr: It was the kind of look you might direct at an almost extinct animal in a zoo.
es: His gaze was the same as one would give to a zoo animal whose species is almost extinct.

en: Staring at the magazine, as he dangled it before me like fish bait, I wanted it.
vi: Eyes glued to the magazine, his hand dangling in front of my nose, I craved it.
tr: I desired this magazine as the commander dangled it in front of me like fish bait.
es: I fixed my gaze on the magazine, while he swung it in front of me as if it were a lure, and I desired it.

en: I wanted it with a force that made the ends of my fingers ache.
vi: I craved it so intensely that my fingertips ached.
tr: I desired it with a force that made my fingertips tingle.
es: I desired it so intensely that I felt pain in my fingertips.

en: At the same time I saw this longing of mine as trivial and absurd, because I'd taken such magazines lightly enough once.
vi: At the same time, I found this craving so trivial and bizarre, because in the past I had despised them so much.
tr: At the same time, I found my desire unnecessary and absurd, because I had once greatly underestimated such magazines.
es: At the same time, my longing seemed frivolous and absurd because in the past I had taken this type of magazine quite lightly.

en: I'd read them in dentists' offices, and sometimes on planes; I'd bought them to take to hotel rooms, a device to fill in empty time while I was waiting for Luke.
vi: I had read them in the dentist's office, sometimes on the plane; I bought them to bring to the hotel, killing time while waiting for Luke to arrive.
tr: I would read them in dentists' waiting rooms, sometimes on planes, and buy them to take to hotel rooms. A tool to fill the empty time while waiting for Luke.
es: I would read them in the dentist's office and sometimes on planes; I would buy them to take to hotel rooms, as a way to fill the free time while waiting for Luke.

en: After I'd leafedthrough them I would throw them away, for they were infinitely discardable, and a day or two later I wouldn't be able to remember what had been in them.
vi: After flipping through the pages, I would toss them into a corner, because these things were so abundant and disposable, and a day or two later I would completely forget what was in them.
tr: After flipping through them, I would throw them away, because they were extremely disposable things and I couldn't remember what was in them a couple of days later.
es: Once I had flipped through them, I would throw them away, because they were absolutely disposable, and one or two days later I was unable to remember what I had read in them.

en: Though I remembered now.
vi: Even now, I still remember.
tr: But now I remembered.
es: However, at that moment I remembered it.

en: What was in them was promise.
vi: There was a promise in it.
tr: What was inside them was a promise.
es: What was in them was a promise.

en: They dealt in transformations; they suggested anendless series of possibilities, extending like the reflections in two mirrors set facing one another, stretching on, replica after replica, to the vanishing point.
vi: Those magazines talked about transformation, presenting endless possibilities, expanding like reflections in two opposing mirrors, multiplying endlessly, one copy after another, triumphing infinitely.
tr: They traded in transformations; like reflections in two mirrors facing each other, expanding, extending image upon image to the point of disappearance, they offered an infinite series of possibilities: Adventure upon adventure, wardrobe upon wardrobe, development upon development, man upon man.
es: They traded in transformation; they suggested an endless series of possibilities extending like an image in two facing mirrors, multiplying, replica after replica until disappearing.

en: They suggested one adventure after another, one wardrobe after another, one improvement after another, one man after another.
vi: After one venture, they presented another venture, after one set of clothes, another set, after one progress, another progress, after one man, another man.
tr: They traded in transformations; like reflections in two mirrors facing each other, expanding, extending image upon image to the point of disappearance, they offered an infinite series of possibilities: Adventure upon adventure, wardrobe upon wardrobe, development upon development, man upon man.
es: They suggested one adventure after another, one wardrobe after another, one reform after another, one man after another.

en: They suggested rejuvenation, pain overcome and transcended, endless love.
vi: They presented rejuvenation, the path to overcoming and conquering pain, eternal love.
tr: What they proposed was rejuvenation, pain overcome and surpassed, and eternal love.
es: They suggested rejuvenation, the defeat and overcoming of pain, infinite love.

en: The real promise in them was immortality.
vi: The promise, in the end, was about immortality.
tr: The true promise they offered was immortality.
es: The true promise they held was immortality.

en: This was what he was holding, without knowing it.
vi: And it was in his hands, but he didn't know.
tr: This was what he was holding without realizing it.
es: This was what he was holding in his hands, without knowing it.

en: He riffled the pages.
vi: He flipped through the pages.
tr: He flipped through the pages.
es: He quickly flipped through the pages, and I noticed that I was leaning forward.

en: I felt myself leaning forward.
vi: I felt myself reaching out.
tr: I felt myself leaning forward.
es: He quickly flipped through the pages, and I noticed that I was leaning forward.

en: It's an old one, he said, a curio of sorts.
vi: This book is old, he said, a kind of curiosity.
tr: An old thing, he said, a rare piece.
es: It's old, he commented, a kind of curiosity.

en: From the seventies, I think.
vi: From the seventies, maybe.
tr: From the seventies, I think.
es: From the seventies, I think.

en: A Vogue.
vi: Vogue.
tr: A Vogue.
es: It's a Vogue, he said like a wine expert dropping a name.

en: This like a wine connoisseur dropping a name.
vi: Like a connoisseur dropping a wine label.
tr: Like a wine expert whose name is renowned.
es: It's a Vogue, he said like a wine expert dropping a name.

en: I thought you might like to look at it.
vi: I thought maybe you would like it.
tr: I thought you might want to take a look.
es: I thought you might like to look at it.

en: I hung back.
vi: I restrained myself.
tr: I hesitated.
es: I leaned back.

en: He might be testing me, to see how deep my indoctrination had really gone.
vi: Maybe he was testing to see how deeply the teachings had truly sunk in.
tr: He might have been testing me to see how deep my doctrinal loyalty went.
es: He could be subjecting me to a test to see how deeply the indoctrination had taken hold in me.

en: It's not permitted, I said.
vi: This is forbidden, I said.
tr: It's forbidden, I said.
es: It is not allowed, I replied.

en: In here, it is, he said quietly.
vi: Here, no, he said quietly.
tr: Not here, he said calmly.
es: Here, yes, he said serenely.

en: I saw the point.
vi: I understand your point.
tr: I grasped the situation.
es: I understood immediately.

en: Having broken the main taboo, why should I hesitate over another one, something minor?
vi: Having already broken the most serious rule, why should I care about something else, something more trivial?
tr: Since I had broken the fundamental taboo, why would I hesitate to go after a smaller one?
es: If the main taboo had been broken, why hesitate before a less important one?

en: Or another, or another; who could tell where it might stop?
vi: Then another thing, and another; who knows where the stopping point is?
tr: Or another one, then another one; who could know where it would stop?
es: And before another, and another. Who could know where they would end?

en: Behind this
vi: Behind this door, all rules vanish.
tr: Behind this particular door, the taboo was unraveling.
es: Behind this door, the taboo was banished.

en: particular door, taboo dissolved.
vi: Behind this door, all rules vanish.
tr: Behind this particular door, the taboo was unraveling.
es: Behind this door, the taboo was banished.

en: I took the magazine from him and turned it the right way round.
vi: I picked up the newspaper and turned it towards myself.
tr: I took the magazine from him and translated it to suit myself.
es: I took the magazine from her hands and turned it over.

en: There they were again, the images of my childhood: bold, striding, confident, their arms flung out as if to claim space, their legs apart, feet planted squarely on the earth.
vi: Here they are again, those childhood images: bold, striding long, confident, arms swinging as if to claim space, legs spread wide, firmly planted on the floor.
tr: There they were again, the images of my childhood: bold, walking with long strides, confident, arms thrown up as if claiming a right, legs apart, feet firmly planted on the ground.
es: Here they were, once again, the images of my childhood: bold, overwhelming, self-assured, with arms open as if demanding space, with legs spread and feet firmly planted on the ground.

en: There was something Renaissance about the pose, but it was princes I thought of, not coiffed and ringleted maidens.
vi: A very Renaissance posture, but I was thinking of princes, not maidens with headscarves and curly locks.
tr: There was a Renaissance air in this pose, yet the princesses that crossed my mind were not women with curly hair.
es: There was something of the Renaissance in the pose, but I thought of princes and not maidens with coifs and curls.

en: Those candid eyes, shadowed with makeup, yes, but like the eyes of cats, fixed for the pounce.
vi: Eyes looking straight ahead, indeed with makeup, but not unlike a cat's eyes, intensely focused, ready to pounce.
tr: Those eyes, shadowed with makeup, are fine but they resemble the eyes of cats turned to stone, ready to pounce on their prey.
es: Those sincere eyes, shaded with makeup, yes, but just like the eyes of cats, fixed and waiting for the moment to pounce.

en: No quailing, no clinging there, not in those capes and rough tweeds, those boots that came to the knee.
vi: No trembling or clinging, in that cloak or rough tweed outfit, in those knee-high boots.
tr: In these capes and coarse tweeds, in those knee-high boots, there is no trace of timidity or insecurity.
es: Without retreating or clinging, not with those layers and those coarse tweed suits and those knee-high boots.

en: Pirates, these women, with their ladylike briefcases for the loot and their horsy acquisitive teeth.
vi: Female bandit leaders, exactly, with a devilish leather bag hiding the spoils, accompanied by greedy horse-like teeth.
tr: These women, with their feminine briefcases used to carry their spoils and their horse-like, greedy teeth, are pirates.
es: Those women were like pirates, with their elegant purses to store the loot and their horse-like, greedy teeth.

en: I felt the Commander watching me as I turned the pages.
vi: I felt the Commander’s eyes following me as I flipped through each page.
tr: As I turned the pages, I could feel the Commander watching me.
es: I noticed that the Commander was watching me while I turned the pages.

en: I knew I was doing something I shouldn't have been doing, and that he found pleasure in seeing me do it.
vi: I knew I was doing something that was supposed to be forbidden, and I also knew he was gleefully watching me do it.
tr: I knew I was doing something I shouldn't be doing, and that he enjoyed watching me.
es: I knew I was doing something I wasn't supposed to be doing, and that it gave him pleasure to watch me do it.

en: I should have felt evil; by Aunt Lydia's lights, I was evil.
vi: By Aunt Lydia’s standards, I should have seen myself as wicked; according to her, I belonged to the wicked side.
tr: I was supposed to feel sinful; according to Aunt Lydia's perception, I was sinful.
es: I should have felt perverse; in Aunt Lydia's eyes, I was a pervert.

en: But I didn't feel evil.
vi: But I didn’t see it that way.
tr: However, I didn't feel that way.
es: But I didn't feel that way.

en: Instead I felt like an j old Edwardian seaside postcard: naughty.
vi: I saw myself like an early 20th-century English seaside postcard: playful.
tr: Instead, I felt like an old Edwards' seaside postcard: immoral.
es: On the contrary, I felt like an old Edwardian seaside postcard: daring.

en: What was he going to give me next?
vi: What would he give me next?
tr: What would he give me next, I wondered?
es: What would he give me next?

en: A girdle?
vi: A corset?
tr: A corset?
es: A corset?

en: Why do you have this?
vi: Why do you have this?
tr: Why are you hiding this, I asked.
es: Why the guard?, I asked him.

en: I asked him.
vi: I asked.
tr: Why are you hiding this, I asked.
es: Why the guard?, I asked him.

en: Some of us, he said, retain an appreciation for the old things.
vi: Among us, he said, there are those who still hold admiration for the ancient times.
tr: Some of us, he said, still value old things.
es: Some of us, he explained, still appreciate old things.

en: But these were supposed to have been burned, I said.
vi: But these should have been burned already, I said.
tr: Still, they should have been burned, I said.
es: But these were supposed to have been burned, I argued.

en: There were house-to-house searches, bonfires
vi: They searched every house, they destroyed...
tr: There were house-to-house searches, bonfires...
es: House-to-house searches were conducted, bonfires...

en: What's dangerous in the hands of the multitudes, he said, with what may or may not have been irony, is safe enough for those whose motives are
vi: What is dangerous when it falls into the hands of the masses, he said, unable to distinguish whether it is sarcasm or not, is safe in the hands of those who have motives...
tr: Things that could be dangerous in the hands of the masses, he said, whether ironically or not, are safe in our hands, the impulses...
es: What represents a danger in the hands of the masses, he continued, something that in some cases has been an irony, and in others not, is safe in the hands of those whose motives are...

en: Beyond reproach, I said.
vi: Beyond reproach, I said.
tr: Those who are perfect, I said.
es: Impeccable, I concluded.

en: He nodded gravely.
vi: He nodded solemnly.
tr: He shook his head with distress.
es: He nodded with a serious expression.

en: Impossible to tell whether or not he meant it.
vi: Unable to guess if he truly thought that way.
tr: It was impossible to say whether he did it sincerely.
es: It was impossible to tell if he was serious or not.

en: But why show it to me?
vi: But why show it to me?
tr: Well, why did you show it to me?
es: But why are you showing it to me?

en: I said, and then felt stupid.
vi: I asked, and immediately felt foolish.
tr: I asked and felt like an idiot.
es: I asked, and immediately felt stupid.

en: What could he possibly say?
vi: What else could he be saying?
tr: What could he say?
es: What could he answer me?

en: That he was amusing himself, at my expense?
vi: That he wants to have fun and is using me as the price?
tr: That he amused himself at the expense of hurting me?
es: That he was having fun at my expense?

en: For he must have known how painful it was to me, to be reminded of the former time.
vi: Because he must know how much it pains me to remember the past.
tr: After all, he should have known how painful it was for me to remember the old times.
es: Because he must have known how painful it was for me to remember the past.

en: I wasn't prepared for what he actually did say.
vi: I couldn't anticipate his answer.
tr: I was truly not at all ready for what he said.
es: I was not prepared for what he actually answered.

en: Who else could I show
vi: Who else can I show it to?
tr: Who else could I show it to?
es: To whom else could I show it?, he said to me, once again showing an expression of sadness.

en: it to?
vi: Who else can I show it to?
tr: Who else could I show it to?
es: To whom else could I show it?, he said to me, once again showing an expression of sadness.

en: he said, and there it was again, that sadness.
vi: He spoke, and the previous sadness echoed again.
tr: he said, the same sad expression settling on his face again.
es: To whom else could I show it?, he said to me, once again showing an expression of sadness.

en: Should I go further?
vi: Should I push further?
tr: Should I go further?
es: What if I went further?, I thought.

en: I thought.
vi: I thought.
tr: I thought.
es: What if I went further?, I thought.

en: I didn't want to push him, too far, too fast.
vi: I don't want to rush him, too fast, too far.
tr: I didn't want to push him too much and too fast.
es: I didn't want to rush him or pressure him.

en: I knew I was dispensable.
vi: I know I'm the type no one fears missing out on.
tr: In the end, I was something that could be given up.
es: I knew I was dispensable.

en: Nevertheless I said, too softly, How about your wife?
vi: But I still said, as softly as a breath, What about your wife?
tr: Still, I couldn't help myself and in a very soft tone, I said, Well, what about your wife?
