es: However, I asked him very softly: And your wife?

en: He seemed to think about that.
vi: He seemed to be thinking.
tr: He seemed to think about it for a while.
es: He seemed to reflect.

en: No, he said.
vi: No, he said.
tr: No, he said afterward.
es: No, he said.

en: She wouldn't understand.
vi: She wouldn't understand.
tr: He wouldn't understand.
es: She wouldn't understand.

en: Anyway, she won't talk to me much anymore.
vi: Anyway, she doesn't talk to me much anymore.
tr: Anyway, he doesn't talk to me much anymore.
es: Anyway, she doesn't talk to me much anymore.

en: We don't seem to have much in common, these days.
vi: It seems we have little in common these days.
tr: These days, we don't seem to have much in common.
es: It seems like we don't have much in common now.

en: So there it was, out in the open: his wife didn't understand him.
vi: So there it is, laid bare: your wife doesn't understand you.
tr: Here it was, out in the open: His wife did not understand him.
es: He had said it, he had revealed what he thought: his wife did not understand him.

en: That's what I was there for, then.
vi: The reason I came here, so that's it.
tr: So, that was the reason for my being there.
es: So I was there for that reason.

en: The same old thing.
vi: Still the same old story.
tr: Again, the same old, familiar thing.
es: The same as always.

en: It was too banal to be true.
vi: So boring it's unbelievable.
tr: It was too banal to be real.
es: Too trivial to be true.

en: On the third night I asked him for some hand lotion, I didn't want to sound begging, but I wanted what I could get.
vi: On the third night, I asked him if he had any lotion. I didn't want to start begging, but I wanted something within my reach.
tr: On the third night, I asked him for some hand lotion. I didn't want to appear as if I were begging, but I wanted the things I could obtain.
es: The third night I asked her for some hand lotion. I didn't want to seem like a beggar, but I needed to know what I could get.

en: Some what?
vi: What milk is that?
tr: A little what?
es: A little bit of what?, he asked me kindly, as usual.

en: he said, courteous as ever.
vi: he asked, still as polite as usual.
tr: he asked, as polite as ever.
es: A little bit of what?, he asked me kindly, as usual.

en: He was across the desk from me.
vi: He sat opposite me on the other side of the table.
tr: He was diagonally across the table from me.
es: He was in front of me, on the other side of the desk.

en: He didn't touch me much, except for that one obligatory kiss.
vi: He hardly touched me, except for the customary single kiss.
tr: Apart from that one obligatory kiss, he hardly touched me.
es: He never touched me much, except for the obligatory kiss.

en: No pawing, no heavy breathing, none of that; it would have been out of place, somehow, for him as well as for me.
vi: No groping, no heavy breathing or anything like that, it felt like such things were out of place here, for both him and me.
tr: No rough groping or heavy breathing, there was none of that; it would somehow be inappropriate for both him and me.
es: No groping, no panting, none of that; it would have been out of place, in a sense, both for him and for me.

en: Hand lotion, I said.
vi: Skin lotion, I said.
tr: The lotion, I said.
es: Hand lotion, I repeated.

en: Or face lotion.
vi: Or face cream.
tr: Or the face lotion.
es: Or for the face.

en: Our skin gets very dry.
vi: Our skin is dry.
tr: Our skin gets very dry.
es: Our skin gets very dry.

en: For some reason I said our instead of my.
vi: Unintentionally, I said "we" instead of "I."
tr: For some reason, I had said our instead of my.
es: For some reason, I said "our" instead of "my".

en: I would have liked to ask also for some bath oil, in those little colored globules you used to be able to get, that were so much like magic to me when they existed in the round glass bowl in my mother's bathroom at home.
vi: I also wanted to ask for bath oil, those small colorful beads that used to be easy to find, appearing like magic before my eyes in a round glass bowl in the corner of my mother's bathroom.
tr: I wished to ask for those little colored balls of bath oil that you could easily get in the past and which seemed magical to me when they existed in a round glass bowl in my mother's bathroom at home.
es: I would have liked to also ask him for some bath salts, the kind you used to get before, that looked like small colored balloons, and that seemed so magical to me when I saw them at home, in the round glass bowl my mother had in the bathroom.

en: But I thought he wouldn't know what they were.
vi: But I thought he probably wouldn't know.
tr: But I thought he wouldn't understand what they were.
es: But I thought he wouldn't know what I was talking about.

en: Anyway, they probably weren't made anymore.
vi: Anyway, no one probably makes bath oil anymore.
tr: Besides, they might not be made anymore.
es: Anyway, they probably didn't make them anymore.

en: Dry?
vi: Dry?
tr: Is it drying up?
es: Does it dry out?, asked the Commander, as if he had never thought about it.

en: the Commander said, as if he'd never thought about that before.
vi: The commander said, as if he had never thought of that.
tr: said the Commander, as if it had never occurred to him before.
es: Does it dry out?, asked the Commander, as if he had never thought about it.

en: What do you do about it?
vi: So, how do you do it?

es: And what are you doing to remedy it?

en: We use butter, I said.
vi: We use butter, I said.
tr: We use butter, I said.
es: We use butter, I explained to him.

en: When we can get it.
vi: When we can get it.
tr: When we can get it.

en: Or margarine.
vi: Or margarine.
tr: Or margarine.
es: Or margarine.

en: A lot of the time it's margarine.
vi: Usually margarine.

es: Most of the time it's margarine.

en: Butter, he said, musing.
vi: Butter, he said thoughtfully.
tr: Butter, he said, thoughtfully.
es: Butter, he repeated in a reflective tone.

en: That's very clever.
vi: Very clever.
tr: Very clever.
es: A very intelligent idea.

en: Butter.
vi: Butter.
tr: Butter.
es: Butter. And

en: He laughed.
vi: He laughed out loud.
tr: He laughed.
es: started laughing.

en: I could have slapped him.
vi: I almost slapped him in the face.
tr: I could have slapped him.
es: I felt the urge to slap him.

en: I think I could get some of that, he said, as if indulging a child's wish for bubble gum.
vi: I think I can make it, he said, in a way to please a child asking for bubble gum.
tr: I think I can get a little, he said, as if turning a blind eye to a child's wish for gum.
es: I think I could get some, he commented, like someone indulging a child asking for bubble gum.

en: But she might smell it on you.
vi: But she can sniff you out.
tr: But my wife might smell it.
es: But she might notice the smell.

en: I wondered if this fear
vi: I suspect this fear might come from old experiences.
tr: I wondered if this fear stemmed from past experiences.
es: I wondered if this fear was based on some past experience.

en: of his came from past experience.
vi: I suspect this fear might come from old experiences.
tr: I wondered if this fear stemmed from past experiences.
es: I wondered if this fear was based on some past experience.

en: Long past: lipstick on the collar, perfume on the cuffs, a scene, late at night, in some kitchen or bedroom.
vi: Old as time: lipstick marks on the neck, perfume on the wrist, someone dancing tango, late at night, in the kitchen or bedroom.
tr: A long past: lipstick stains on the collar of a shirt, the scent of perfume on the cuffs, a scene, late at night, in a kitchen or a bedroom.
es: A long time ago: lipstick on the collar of the shirt, perfume on the cuffs, a scene late at night, in the kitchen or in the bedroom.

en: A man devoid of such experience wouldn't think of that.
vi: A man with no experience at all wouldn't think of it.
tr: A man devoid of such experiences wouldn't think of this.
es: A man who had not lived such an experience would not think of that.

vi: Unless he is more cunning than he appears.

es: Unless he was more astute than he seemed.

es: Besides, she is never that close to me.

en: I looked down.
vi: I look down.
tr: I lowered my gaze.
es: I lowered my gaze.

en: I'd forgotten about that.
vi: I had forgotten about that.
tr: I had forgotten this.
es: I had forgotten.

en: I could feel myself blushing.
vi: I feel myself blushing.
tr: I could feel myself blushing.
es: I felt myself blush.

en: I
vi: I won't use those nights, I said.

vi: I won't use those nights, I said.

es: The fourth night brought me the hand lotion in an unlabelled plastic bottle.

en: It wasn't very good quality; it smelled faintly of vegetableoil.

tr: It wasn't of very good quality; it smelled slightly of vegetable oil.
es: It wasn't of very good quality, it smelled slightly of vegetable oil.

en: No Lily of the Valley for me.
vi: The lilies in the valley were not for me.
tr: He probably wasn't going to give me Lily of the Valley.
es: For me, the Lily of the Valley did not exist.

es: This lotion must have been something they made to use in hospitals, to heal sores.

es: But I thanked him anyway.

tr: The problem, I said, is that I don't have a place to hide this.
es: The problem, I told him, is that I have nowhere to store it.

en: In your room, he said, as if it were obvious.
vi: Her room, he said, as if it were a very simple matter.
tr: "Keep it in Dutch," he said, as if it were something very obvious.
es: In your room, he said, as if it were obvious.

en: They'd find it, I said.
vi: They found out immediately, I said.
tr: They will find it, I said.
es: They would find her, I replied.

en: Someone would find it.
vi: Someone found out immediately.
tr: Someone will find it.
es: Someone would find her.

en: Why?
vi: Why?
tr: Why?
es: "Why?" he asked, as if he really didn't know.

vi: he asked, as if he genuinely didn't know.
tr: he asked, as if he truly didn't know.

en: Maybe he didn't.

es: And maybe he didn't know.

vi: he asked.

CHAPTER 26

en: When the night for the Ceremony came round again, two or three weeks later, I found that things were changed.
vi: When the festival night came again, two or three weeks later, I noticed a change.
tr: Two or three weeks later, when the Night of the Ceremony came again, I saw that something had changed.
es: Two or three weeks later, when the night of the Ceremony arrived, I had the impression that things were different.

en: There was an awkwardness now that there hadn't beenbefore.
vi: An unprecedented awkwardness.
tr: There was a clumsiness that hadn't been there before.
es: There was an uneasiness that had never existed before.

en: Before, I'd treated it as a job, an unpleasant job to be gone through as fast as possible so it could be over with.
vi: Previously, I considered this a task, a tedious task that needed to be done quickly to get it over with as soon as possible.
tr: Previously, I treated it like a task, an unpleasant job that needed to be finished as quickly as possible, but only then could it be overcome.
es: Before, I considered it a job, an unpleasant job that had to be done as quickly as possible to get it over with.

en: Steel yourself, my mother used to say, before examinations I didn't want to take or swims in cold water.
vi: Brace yourself, mother often said that, before hateful exams, or before jumping into the icy cold pool.
tr: Steel yourself, my mother used to say, before exams I didn't want to take or swimming in cold water.
es: Desensitize yourself, my mother used to say before the exams I didn't want to take, or the cold water baths.

en: I never thought much at the time about what the phrase meant, but it had something to do with metal, with armor, and that's what I would do, I would steel myself.
vi: Back then, I never thought carefully about what it meant, but it was associated with metal, with armor, and I would do that, I would forge myself into solid steel.
tr: Back then, I hadn't thought much about the meaning of this phrase, it was probably something related to metals, armors; well, that's what I did, I steeled myself.
es: At that moment, I didn't think much about what the phrase meant, but it had something to do with metal, with armor, and that's what I should do, I should desensitize myself.

en: I would pretend not to be present, not in the flesh.
vi: I would pretend not to be here, not to be flesh and bone.
tr: I pretended as if I wasn't there, as if I wasn't in my body.
es: I will pretend not to be present, that my body is not present.

en: This state of absence, of existing apart from the body, had been true of the Commander too, I knew now.
vi: The state of detachment, existing outside the body, had been applied by the Commander for a long time, now I understand.
tr: This disappearance applied to the Commander existing separately from the body as well, I know this now.
es: I knew that this state of absence, of existing separate from the body, was also true in the case of the Commander.

en: Probably he thought about other things the whole time he was with me; with us, for of course Serena Joy was there on those evenings also.
vi: Surely he was thinking about something else the whole time he was with me; with us, because of course Serena Joy was present, every night.
tr: During all that time he was with me, he was probably always thinking about other things; with us, that is, because undoubtedly Serena Joy would also be there on those nights.
es: He was probably thinking about other things when he was with me; with us, because of course Serena Joy was also there those nights.

en: He might have been thinking about what he did during the day, or about playing golf, or about what he'd had for dinner.
vi: He could have been thinking about the day's events, about the golf game, or about dinner.
tr: He could have been thinking about what he did during the day, playing golf, or what he had for dinner.
es: He must have been thinking about what he had done during the day, or about the golf games, or about what he had eaten for dinner.

en: The sexual act, although he performed it in a perfunctory way, must have been largely unconscious, for him, like scratching himself.
vi: The act of intercourse, though he still performed it perfunctorily, was probably done mostly unconsciously, like scratching himself.
tr: The sexual act, which he performed in a mechanical way, like scratching an itch, must have been largely unconscious for him.
es: The sexual act—although he performed it in a mechanical way—must have been, for him, largely unconscious, like scratching himself.

en: But that night, the first since the beginning of whatever this new arrangement was between usI had no name for itI felt shy of him.
vi: But that night, the first Ceremony since the new arrangement began, whatever you want to call it, I felt embarrassed.
tr: But that night, whatever the name of this new arrangement between us - I couldn't put a name to it - on the first occasion after its inception, I felt ashamed of the Commander.
es: But that night, the first after this new agreement between us — whatever it was, I didn't know what to call it—I felt ashamed of him.

en: I felt, for one thing, that he was actually looking at me, and
vi: First of all, I noticed that he did look at me, and I didn't like it.
tr: In one way, I felt that he was really looking at me and I didn't like it.
es: The first thing I felt was that he was really looking at me, and I didn't like it.

en: I didn't like it.
vi: First of all, I noticed that he did look at me, and I didn't like it.
tr: In one way, I felt that he was really looking at me and I didn't like it.
es: The first thing I felt was that he was really looking at me, and I didn't like it.

en: The lights were on, as usual, since Serena Joy always avoided anything that would have created an aura of romance or eroticism, however slight: overhead lights, harsh despite the canopy.
vi: The lights were glaring, as always, because Serena Joy had carefully removed anything that might create an atmosphere of intimacy or sensuality, no matter how small: the lights directly overhead, harsh and bright, even though there was a filter.
tr: Because Serena Joy avoided anything that might create a romantic or erotic atmosphere, no matter how vague, the lights were on as usual: the strong ceiling lamps despite the canopy.
es: The lights were on as usual—since Serena Joy always nullified anything that could have created an aura of romance or eroticism—but they were dim: lights above our heads, lights that were annoying despite the canopy.

en: It was like being on an operating table, in the full glare; like being on a stage.
vi: It felt like lying on an operating table, with all eyes on me; like being on stage.
tr: It was like lying on an operating table under dazzling light; like being on stage.
es: It was like being on an operating table under a dazzling spotlight; like being on a stage.

en: I was conscious that my legs were hairy, in the straggly way of legs that have once been shaved but have grownback; I was conscious of my armpits too, although of course he couldn't see them.
vi: I was conscious of my legs being hairy and stubbly, the way they grow back after shaving; I was also aware of my armpits, even though he couldn't see them.
tr: I was conscious of my hairy legs, once shaved but now grown back in a messy way; although he couldn't possibly see, I was also conscious of my armpits.
es: I was aware that my legs were covered in hair, with that scattered hair that grows on legs that have already been shaved.

en: I felt uncouth.
vi: I felt crude.
tr: I felt rough and coarse.
es: I was also aware of the hair in my armpits, although of course he couldn't see it.

en: This act of copulation, fertilization perhaps, which
vi: This act of copulation, which you could call insemination, should have been as natural as a bee pollinating a flower, but now it felt indecent to me, breaking the rules in a shameful way, which it hadn't before.
tr: While this mating, perhaps fertilization act, should mean no more than a bee to a flower, it had now become something inappropriate, against the customs, an embarrassing act for me, even though it hadn't been before.
es: The act of copulation, perhaps fertilization—which for me should have been no more than what a bee is to a flower—had become, in my view, something indecorous, an impropriety that I had never felt before.

en: should have been no more to me than a bee is to a flower, had become for me indecorous, an embarrassingbreach of propriety, which it hadn't been before.
vi: This act of copulation, which you could call insemination, should have been as natural as a bee pollinating a flower, but now it felt indecent to me, breaking the rules in a shameful way, which it hadn't before.
tr: While this mating, perhaps fertilization act, should mean no more than a bee to a flower, it had now become something inappropriate, against the customs, an embarrassing act for me, even though it hadn't been before.
es: The act of copulation, perhaps fertilization—which for me should have been no more than what a bee is to a flower—had become, in my view, something indecorous, an impropriety that I had never felt before.

en: He was no longer a thing to me.
vi: He is no longer an object to me.
tr: The commander had ceased to be an inanimate object in my eyes.
es: He was no longer a thing to me.

en: That was the problem.
vi: That's the unfortunate truth.
tr: That was the problem.
es: Therein lay the problem.

en: I realized it that night, and the realization has stayed with me.
vi: That night I realized it, and I couldn't shake it off.
tr: I realized this that night and it took root inside me.
es: I realized it that night, and this understanding has not left me.

en: It complicates.
vi: Everything became complicated.
tr: It became increasingly complicated.
es: Things are getting complicated.

en: Serena Joy had changed for me, too.
vi: Even Serena Joy has changed towards me.
tr: Serena Joy had also changed for me.
es: Serena Joy has also changed for me.

en: Once I'd merely hated her for her part in what was being done to me; and because she hated me too and resented my presence, and because she would be the one to raise my child, should I be able to have one after all.
vi: Previously, I purely hated her because she was involved in what was happening to my body; and because she also hated me and resented my face, and because she would take on the upbringing of my child, if I could bear one.
tr: Because of her role in what was done to me, I used to only hate her; moreover, I hated her because she hated me and was disturbed by my presence, and because she would raise my child and, above all, have a child of her own.
es: Before, I simply hated her for her participation in what they did to me; and because she also hated me and resented my presence, and because she would be the one to raise my child, if I was able to have one.

en: But now, although I still hated her, no more so than when she was grippingmy hands so hard that her rings bit my flesh, pulling my hands back as well, which she must have done on purpose to make me as uncomfortable as she could, the hatred was no longer pure and simple.
vi: But now, although I still hate her, not more than when she tightened the ring to cut my finger, and pulled my arm back, surely intending to cause me as much trouble as possible, that hatred is no longer as simple and pure as before.
tr: However, now, although I still hated her, it was no more than when she gripped my hand so tightly that her rings dug into my skin or when she clung to them in the same way; she must have been doing these things deliberately to disturb me as much as she could, my hatred was no longer pure and simple.
es: But at that moment, although I hated her —no more than when she squeezed my hands so hard that her rings pinched my skin, and at the same time held them, which she must have done on purpose to make me feel as uncomfortable as she did—, I no longer felt a pure and simple hatred for her.

en: Partly I was jealous of her; but how could I be jealous of a woman so obviously dried-up and unhappy?
vi: In some ways, I am jealous of her, but how can one be jealous of a woman who is so obviously exhausted and unhappy?
tr: Partly, I envied her; but how could I envy such an obviously exhausted and unhappy woman?
es: In part, I felt jealous of her; but, how could I be jealous of a woman so obviously withered and miserable?

en: You can only be jealous of someone who has something you think you ought to have yourself.
vi: One only envies someone who possesses something one should have.
tr: One can only envy someone who has something they believe they should have themselves.
es: One can only feel jealous of a person who has something that should belong to oneself.

en: Nevertheless I was jealous.
vi: Yet I still envy her.
tr: Whatever it was, I envied her.
es: Anyway, I was jealous.

en: But I also felt guilty about her.
vi: But I also felt guilty towards her.
tr: On the other hand, I also felt guilty.
es: But I also felt guilty about her.

en: I felt I was an intruder, in a territory that ought to havebeen hers.
vi: As if I were an intruder, in a territory that should have been under her control.
tr: I felt like someone who had entered a space where they didn't belong.
es: I felt like an intruder invading a territory that should have been hers.

en: Now that I was seeing the Commander on the sly, if only to play his games and listen to him talk, our functions were no longer as separate as they should have been in theory, I was taking something away from her, although she didn't know it.
vi: Adding more secret meetings like now, even if it's just playing with typesetting and listening to the Commander talk, our duties are no longer as clear-cut as in theory, I am taking something from her, even though she doesn't know.
tr: Even if it was just to play games and listen to him talk, because we were secretly meeting with the Commander, our functions were no longer as separate as they theoretically should have been. Even if he didn't know, I was taking something from him.
es: Now that I was seeing the Commander in secret, even if it was just to play his games and hear him talk, our roles were no longer as different as they should have been in theory. Even if she didn't know it, I was taking something from her.

en: Iwas filching.
vi: I am stealing it away.
tr: Honestly, I was stealing.
es: I was stealing.

en: Never mind that it was something she apparently didn't want or had no use for, had rejected even; still, it was hers, and if I took it away, this mysterious "it" I couldn't quite definefor the Commander wasn't in love with me, I refused to believe he felt anything for me as extreme as thatwhat would be left for her?
vi: Regardless of whether it is something she clearly doesn't want, or doesn't use, or has rejected, it is still hers, and if I take away "it", this mysterious "it" that I can't even define myself - because the Commander doesn't love me, I would never believe he has such deep feelings for me - then what does she have left?
tr: If I also took this mysterious "thing" that I couldn't fully define, which he definitely didn't want or need but still belonged to him - after all, the Commander wasn't in love with me, I refused to believe he felt something so extreme for me - what would be left for him?
es: It didn't matter that it was something she apparently didn't want or need, or even rejected; it was still hers, and if I took it from her, if I took this mysterious thing that I find impossible to define—because the Commander wasn't in love with me, I refused to believe he felt something so extreme for me—what would she have left?

en: Why should I care?
vi: Why bother?
tr: Why should I care?
es: Why should I worry?, I said to myself.

en: I told myself.
vi: I told myself.
tr: I said to myself.
es: Why should I worry?, I said to myself.

en: She's nothing to me, she dislikes me, she'd have me out of the house in a minute, or worse, if she could think up any excuse at all.
vi: She is nothing to me, she is unpleasant, she will throw me out of the house, or do something worse, as soon as she thinks of a reason.
tr: It means nothing to me; she doesn't like me, if she found an excuse, she would throw me out of the house immediately or do something worse.
es: She means nothing to me, she doesn't like me, if she could come up with some excuse, she would throw me out of this house immediately.

en: If she wereto find out, for instance.
vi: If she finds out, for instance.
tr: If she were to catch us, for example.
es: If she found out, for example.

en: He wouldn't be able to intervene, to save me; the transgressions of
vi: He won't be able to intervene, won't be able to save me; all violations by women in the household, whether Martha or Handmaid, are by law under the Wife's jurisdiction.
tr: The Commander couldn't intervene to save me; whether it's Martha or a Handmaid, the crimes of the women in the house are considered subject only to the judgment of the Wives.
es: He wouldn't be in a position to intervene to save me; the transgressions of the women of the house —whether a Martha or a Handmaid— are solely under the jurisdiction of the Wives.

en: women in the household, whether Martha or Handmaid, are supposed to be under the jurisdiction of the Wives alone.
vi: He won't be able to intervene, won't be able to save me; all violations by women in the household, whether Martha or Handmaid, are by law under the Wife's jurisdiction.
tr: The Commander couldn't intervene to save me; whether it's Martha or a Handmaid, the crimes of the women in the house are considered subject only to the judgment of the Wives.
es: He wouldn't be in a position to intervene to save me; the transgressions of the women of the house —whether a Martha or a Handmaid— are solely under the jurisdiction of the Wives.

en: She was a malicious and vengeful woman, I knew that.
vi: She is malicious and hateful, that much I know.
tr: She was a malicious and vindictive woman, I was aware of that.
es: I knew she was a malicious and vengeful woman.

en: Nevertheless I couldn't shake it, that small compunction towards her.
vi: But I still can't shake off this small regret.
tr: Still, I couldn't rid myself of this small pang of conscience I felt towards her.
es: However, I couldn't rid myself of this small remorse regarding her.

en: Also: I now had power over her, of a kind, although she didn't , know it.
vi: Not only that: now I have power over her, almost like that, even though she doesn't know it.
tr: Moreover: Even if he wasn't aware, I had now established a kind of dominance over him.
es: Moreover, although Serena Joy did not know it, I had a certain power over her.

en: And I enjoyed that.
vi: And I'm thrilled.
tr: And I was enjoying it.
es: And He enjoyed it.

en: Why pretend?
vi: Why pretend?
tr: Why should I lie: I was immensely enjoying it.
es: Why pretend?

en: I enjoyed it a lot.
vi: I'm absolutely thrilled.
tr: Why should I lie: I was immensely enjoying it.
es: He enjoyed it immensely.

en: f
vi: But the Commander could expose me so easily, a look, a gesture, a small slip could reveal to anyone watching that there is something between us now.
tr: But the Commander could easily give me away, with a glance, a gesture, a small mistake that could reveal to someone watching that there was something between us now.
es: But the Commander could have discovered me very easily, with a look, a gesture, some small slip that revealed there was something between us.

en: But the Commander could give me away so easily, bya look, by a gesture, some tiny slip that would reveal to anyone watching that there was something between us now.
vi: But the Commander could expose me so easily, a look, a gesture, a small slip could reveal to anyone watching that there is something between us now.
tr: But the Commander could easily give me away, with a glance, a gesture, a small mistake that could reveal to someone watching that there was something between us now.
es: But the Commander could have discovered me very easily, with a look, a gesture, some small slip that revealed there was something between us.

en: He almost did it the night of the Ceremony.
vi: That almost happened on Ceremony night.
tr: He almost did on the night of the ceremony.
es: He almost did it the night of the Ceremony.

en: He reached his hand up as if to touch my face; I moved my head to the side, to warn him away, hoping Serena Joy hadn't noticed, and he withdrew his hand again, withdrew into himself and his singled-minded journey.
vi: He reached out as if to touch my face; I turned my head to the side, to ward him off, hoping Serena Joy wouldn't notice, and he withdrew his hand, retreating into his own focused journey.
tr: He raised his hand as if to touch my face; I turned my head to warn him, hoping Serena Joy wouldn't notice, and he withdrew his hand, returning to his single-minded journey.
es: He reached out his hand as if to touch my face; I moved my head to one side, hoping that Serena Joy hadn't noticed, and he withdrew his hand and focused on his thoughts and his inner journey.

en: Don't do that again, I said to him the next time we were alone.
vi: Never repeat it, I said as soon as I met him privately.
tr: Don't do this again, I said the next time we were alone.
es: Don't do it again, I told him when we met again alone.

en: Do what?
vi: Repeat what?
tr: What?
es: What to do?, he asked.

en: he said.
vi: he asked.
tr: he asked.
es: What to do?, he asked.

en: Try to touch me like that, when we're?
vi: To touch me like that, while... while she was there.
tr: Don't try to touch me like that, while we are doing... while he is there.
es: Trying to touch me like that when we are... when she is there.

en: when she's there.
vi: To touch me like that, while... while she was there.
tr: Don't try to touch me like that, while we are doing... while he is there.
es: Trying to touch me like that when we are... when she is there.

en: Did I? he said.
vi: Did I do that? he asked.
tr: Did I really do it? he said.
es: Did I do that?, he was astonished.

en: You could get me transferred, I said.
vi: He can have me transferred, I said.
tr: You could have caused me to be sent away, I said.
es: I could arrange to be transferred, I told him.

en: To the Colonies.
vi: To the Colonies.
tr: To the colonies.
es: To the Colonies, you know, or something worse.

en: You know that.
vi: You know that.
tr: You know this.
es: To the Colonies, you know, or something worse.

en: Or worse.
vi: Or worse.
tr: Or it could have been worse.
es: To the Colonies, you know, or something worse.

en: I thought he should continue to act, in public, as if I were a large vase or a window: part of the background, inanimate or transparent.
vi: I think he should continue, in the crowd, treating me like a piece of furniture or a window frame: blending into the background, motionless or transparent.
tr: I thought he had to continue acting in front of others as if I were a large vase or a window; a part of the background, as if I were something inanimate or transparent.
es: I thought that in front of others, he would continue to act as if I were a huge vase, or a window: part of the decor, inanimate or transparent.

en: I'm sorry, he said.
vi: I'm sorry, he said.
tr: I'm sorry, he said.
es: I'm sorry, he apologized.

en: I didn't mean to.
vi: I didn't mean to.
tr: I didn't do it on purpose.
es: It wasn't my intention.

en: But I find it What?
vi: But I saw it... What?
tr: But this to me...
es: But I find it... What?

en: I said, when he didn't go on.
vi: I said, seeing him pause.
tr: "What?" I said, when they didn't continue.
es: I urged him to finish the sentence.

en: Impersonal, he said.
vi: Lacking people, he said.
tr: It feels like something devoid of emotion, he said.
es: Impersonal, he stated.

en: How long did it take you to find that out?
vi: How long did it take for you to realize?
tr: How long did it take you to understand this?
es: And now you discover it?, I asked him.

en: I said.
vi: I said.
tr: I asked.
es: And now you discover it?, I asked him.

en: You can see from the way I was speaking to him that we were already on different terms.
vi: Surely, anyone could tell from the way we spoke that we had moved on to a different stage.
tr: You can already see from the way I interact with him that our relationship has changed.
es: From the way I spoke, you might have noticed that our relationship had already changed.

en: For the generations that comeafter, Aunt Lydia said, it will be so much better.
vi: Aunt Lydia said that future generations would enjoy better things.
tr: Aunt Lydia used to say, for future generations, everything will be much better.
es: For future generations, said Aunt Lydia, everything will be easier.

en: The women will live in harmony together, all in one family; you will be like daughters to them, and when the population level is up to scratch again we'll no longer have to transfer you from one house toanother because there will be enough to go round.
vi: Women will live in harmony with each other, all in one family; they will be like their daughters, and when the population reaches the right level, they will no longer be transferred from house to house because there will be enough people to distribute.
tr: Women will live together in harmony, everyone will be like a family; you will be like the ones left behind for them, when the population level rises again, you won't have to be sent from house to house anymore, because there will be enough to manage.
es: Women will live together and in harmony, forming a single family.

en: There
vi: Women will live in harmony with each other, all in one family; they will be like their daughters, and when the population reaches the right level, they will no longer be transferred from house to house because there will be enough people to distribute.
tr: Women will live together in harmony, everyone will be like a family; you will be like the ones left behind for them, when the population level rises again, you won't have to be sent from house to house anymore, because there will be enough to manage.
es: For them, you will be like daughters, and when the population level has stabilized again, we won't have to move you from one house to another, because you will be sufficient.

en: can be bonds of real affection, she said, blinking at us ingratiatingly, under such conditions.
vi: There will be deep bonds, she said, blinking tenderly at us, born from that life.
tr: Under these conditions, she would say, winking as if she wanted to endear herself, real bonds of love can be established.
es: Under such conditions, true emotional bonds can be created, she said, winking at us slyly.

en: Women united for a common end!
vi: Women united for a common goal!
tr: Women united for a common purpose!
es: The women will be united by a single goal!

en: Helping one another in their daily chores as they walk the path of life together, each performing her appointed task.
vi: Helping each other with daily tasks while holding hands on life's journey, each with her own duty.
tr: Women helping each other in daily tasks, while each one fulfills the duty given to her, traversing the path of life shoulder to shoulder.
es: They will help each other in daily chores while they walk together on the path of life, each fulfilling the task assigned to her.

en: Why expect one woman to carry out all the functions necessary to the serene running of a household?
vi: Why demand a single woman to perform all the duties to keep the household running smoothly?
tr: Why expect all the necessary functions for the proper management of household chores from a single woman?
es: Why let one woman bear all the tasks necessary for the proper management of a household?

en: It isn't reasonable or humane.
vi: It's absurd, it's inhumane.
tr: This is neither rational nor humane.
es: It is neither reasonable nor humane.

en: Your daughters will have greater freedom.
vi: Your daughters will be much freer.
tr: You will have more freedom than your geese.
es: Your daughters will enjoy greater freedom.

en: We are working towards the goal of a little garden for each one, each one of youthe clasped hands again, the breathy voiceand that's just one for instance.
vi: We are advocating for each of you to have a small garden, your own - remember, holding hands tightly, voice as light as a breath - and that's just one example.
tr: We are striving to achieve the goal of a small garden for each one of you -again clasped hands, that breathless voice- this is just one of our current goals.
es: We are fighting to be able to give each one of you a small garden, to each one of you — he would clasp his hands together again and lower his voice—, and that's just one example.

en: The raised finger, wagging at us.
vi: A finger raised to scold us.
tr: That raised finger waving at us.
es: He would raise his finger and wave it in front of our noses.

en: But we can't be greedy pigs and demand too much before it's ready, now can we?
vi: But we must not whine and complain more than the situation allows, right?
tr: Well, we can't demand too much too soon like greedy pigs, can we?
es: But until this can be achieved, we cannot behave like gluttons and ask for too much, don't you think?

en: The fact is that I'm his mistress.
vi: The truth is, I am his mistress.
tr: The truth is, I am his mistress.
es: The reality is that I am his lover.

en: Men at the top have always had mistresses, why should things be any different now?
vi: Wealthy men have always had mistresses, so why should it be different now?
tr: Men at the top have always had mistresses, why should that change now?
es: Men of high society have always had lovers, why would it be different now?

en: The arrangements aren't quite the same, granted.
vi: The terms have changed somewhat, that I admit.
tr: Okay, the arrangements aren't quite the same.
es: The arrangements are not exactly the same, of course.

en: The mistress used to be kept in a minor house or apartment of her own, and now they've amalgamated things.
vi: Mistresses used to be hidden in small houses or separate apartments, but now they are integrated.
tr: In the past, mistresses were kept in a small house or in a separate apartment, but now they have glued everything together.
es: Before, lovers used to live in a smaller house, or in an apartment of their own, but now things have merged.

en: But underneath it's the same.
vi: But other than that, it remains the same, fundamentally.
tr: However, fundamentally, both lead to the same outcome.
es: Although deep down it is the same, more or less.

en: More or less.
vi: But other than that, it remains the same, fundamentally.
tr: One way or another.
es: Although deep down it is the same, more or less.

en: Outside woman, they used to be called, in some countries.
vi: Women on the outside, as they used to be called, in some countries.
tr: In some countries, they used to call them outside women.
es: In some countries, they were called independent women.

en: I am the outside woman.
vi: I am that woman on the outside.
tr: I am an outside woman.
es: I am an independent woman.

en: It's my job to provide what is otherwise lacking.
vi: My duty is to provide what is lacking.
tr: To provide things that would otherwise be missing, even Scrabble.
es: My job consists of providing what, otherwise, is lacking.

en: Even the Scrabble.
vi: Even a game of Scrabble.
tr: To provide things that would otherwise be missing, even Scrabble.
es: Even the Intellect.

en: It's an absurd as well as an ignominious position.
vi: A position both ridiculous and humiliating.
tr: It's a position as despicable as it is absurd.
es: It is an absurd and, at the same time, ignominious situation.

en: Sometimes I think she knows.
vi: Sometimes I think she knows.
tr: Sometimes I think he knows.
es: Sometimes I think she knows.

en: Sometimes I think they're in collusion.
vi: Sometimes I think they are in cahoots with each other.
tr: Sometimes I think they are in collusion.
es: Sometimes it occurs to me that they are in collusion.

en: Sometimes I think she put him up to it, and is laughing at me; as I laugh, from time to time and with irony, at myself.
vi: Sometimes I think she is pulling his strings to make him do it, and now she is mocking me, just as I, at times, full of sarcasm, mock myself.
tr: Sometimes, I imagine that Serena Joy pushed him into this and that he is mocking me; occasionally and mockingly, when I mock myself.
es: Sometimes I believe that she incites him to this, and that she laughs at me; just as I, from time to time, laugh at myself with a certain irony.

en: Let her take the weight, she can say to herself.
vi: Just let it bear the burden, perhaps she has told herself.
tr: He might be saying to himself, let her bear the burden.
es: Let her carry the heaviest load, she must say to herself.

en: Maybe she's withdrawn from him, almost completely; maybe that's her version of freedom.
vi: Maybe she is withdrawing from him, almost completely; maybe that's how she finds her freedom.
tr: Almost, he might have completely withdrawn from her; maybe, this is his understanding of freedom.
es: Perhaps she has almost completely distanced herself from him; perhaps this is her version of freedom.

en: But even so, and stupidly enough, I'm happier than I was before.
vi: But even so - and how stupid this is - I am still happier than before.
tr: But even so, foolishly, I am happier than I was before.
es: But even so, and in a rather stupid way, I am happier than before.

en: It's something to do, for one thing.
vi: At least, there is something to do.
tr: In a way, it's something to do.
es: First of all, it is something that can be done.

en: Something to fill the time, at night, instead of sitting alone in my room.
vi: There is a way to pass the time, at night, not just sitting alone in the room.
tr: Instead of sitting all alone in my room at night, it's something to pass the time.
es: Something to fill the time in the evenings, instead of sitting alone in my room.

en: It's something else to think about.
vi: There is a new topic for me to think about.
tr: Another thing to think about.
es: It is something else to think about.

en: I don't love the Commander or anything like it, but he's of interest to me, he occupies space, he is more than a shadow.
vi: I don't love the Commander or anything, but he makes me curious, he has substance, not just a ghostly figure.
tr: I neither love the Commander nor feel anything similar towards him; yet he is a source of interest for me, he occupies a place in space, no longer just a mere shadow.
es: I don't love the Commander, or anything like that, but he interests me, occupies a space, is something more than a shadow.

en: And I for him.
vi: Just like me with him, to him I am no longer just a useful body.
tr: I am like this for him too.
es: And I to him.

en: To him I'm no longer merely a usable body.
vi: Just like me with him, to him I am no longer just a useful body.
tr: I am no longer just a body to be used for him.
es: To him, I am no longer just a usable body.

en: To him
vi: Just like me with him, to him I am no longer just a useful body.
tr: I am no longer just a body to be used for him.
es: To him, I am no longer just a usable body.

en: I'm not just a boat with no cargo, a chalice with no wine in it, an
vi: No longer just an empty boat without cargo, an empty cup without wine, an oven – crudely speaking – without bread.
tr: A boat without a load, a glass without wine -to put it crudely- a pan without a pastry; I am no longer these things in his eyes.
es: To him, I am not simply an empty vessel, a chalice without wine, an oven —that doesn't bake— missing its loaves.

en: ovento be crudeminus the bun.
vi: No longer just an empty boat without cargo, an empty cup without wine, an oven – crudely speaking – without bread.
tr: A boat without a load, a glass without wine -to put it crudely- a pan without a pastry; I am no longer these things in his eyes.
es: To him, I am not simply an empty vessel, a chalice without wine, an oven —that doesn't bake— missing its loaves.

en: To him I am not merely empty.
vi: To him, I am no longer empty.
tr: I am not just an empty thing for him anymore.
es: To him, I am not simply empty.
CHAPTER 27

en: I walk with Ofglen along the summer street.
vi: I walk down the summer street with Ofglen.
tr: I am walking along Summer Street with Gleninki.
es: I walk down the street with Deglen, under the sun.

en: It's warm, humid; this would have been sundress-and-sandals weather, once.
vi: The weather is warm and pleasant, ideal for sunglasses and flip-flops, like in the old days.
tr: The weather is hot and humid; it used to be summer-dress-and-sandal weather.
es: It's hot and humid. Before, at this time of year, we would have worn a beach suit and sandals.

en: In each of our baskets are strawberriesthe strawberries are in season now, so we'll eat them and eat them until we're sick of themand some wrapped fish.
vi: Both baskets are filled with strawberries - strawberries are in season now, and we eat them until we feel sick - and some grilled fish.
tr: We both have strawberries in our baskets and, since it's strawberry season, we'll eat until we burst, along with a few packaged fish.
es: In our baskets, we carry strawberries —now is the season, so we will eat strawberries and more strawberries until we are full— and canned fish.

en: We got the fish at Loaves and Fishes, with its wooden sign, a fish with a smile and eyelashes.
vi: The fish is from the Bread and Fish shop, with its wooden sign, a smiling fish with a curved tail.
tr: We got the fish from Bread and Fish, with a wooden sign featuring a smiling, eyelashed fish.
es: We bought the fish at Panes y Peces, which also has a wooden sign with the drawing of a smiling fish with eyelashes.

en: It doesn't sell loaves though.
vi: But they don't sell bread.
tr: Though they don't sell bread.
es: However, they don't sell bread.

en: Most households bake their own, though you can get dried-up rolls and wizened doughnuts at Daily Bread, if you run short.
vi: Most households bake their own, though when in need, you can find dry sweet rolls or twisted bagels at the Daily Bread shop.
tr: If necessary, small, dry breads and wilted flatbreads can be bought from Daily Bread, but most households bake their own bread.
es: Most families bake their own bread, although, when they run out, at El Pan de Cada Día you can get dry rolls and stale fritters.

en: Loaves and Fishes is hardly ever open.
vi: The Bread and Fish shop rarely opens.
tr: Bread and Fish is rarely open.
es: Panes y Peces is almost never open.

en: Why bother opening when there's nothing to sell?
vi: Why bother opening when there's nothing to sell?
tr: Why bother opening when there's nothing to sell?
es: Why bother opening if they have nothing to sell?

en: The sea fisheries were defunct several years ago; the few fish they have now are from fish farms, and taste muddy.
vi: The sea fishing industry has been shut down for many years; the few remaining fish are farm-raised, tasting like mud.
tr: The fish fields disappeared years ago, and the few fish species that exist now come from farms and taste like mud.
es: Marine fishing ceased to exist years ago; the little fish that is available now comes from fish farms, and it tastes like mud.

en: The news says the coastal areas are being "rested."
vi: The news says the coastal areas are "taking a break."
tr: The news says the coastal areas are being "rested."
es: The news says that the coastal areas are "at rest."

en: Sole, I remember, and haddock, swordfish, scallops, tuna; lobsters, stuffed and baked, salmon, pink and fat, grilled in steaks.
vi: I still remember halibut, cod, swordfish, clams, tuna; lobsters, wrapped and baked, salmon, rich and pink, cut into steaks and grilled.
tr: I remember sole and haddock, swordfish, scallops, and tuna; stuffed or fried lobsters, pink and plump, fried in slices, my salmon.
es: I remember the flounder, the pollock, the swordfish, the scallops, the tuna; and the baked stuffed lobster, and the salmon, pink and fatty, grilled.

en: Could they all be extinct, like the whales?
vi: Could they all be extinct, along with the whales?
tr: Could they all be extinct, like whales?
es: Is it possible that they have all gone extinct, just like the whales?

en: I've heard that rumor, passed on to me in soundless words, the lips hardly moving, as we stood in line outside, waiting for the store to open, lured by the picture of succulent white fillets in the window.
vi: I heard that news, in whispers, lips barely moving, while standing in line on the street, waiting for the shop to open, all drawn by the pictures of pristine white fish on the window.
tr: While the picture of plump, boneless white meat in the window made our mouths water, I heard this rumor while standing in line outside the shop, waiting for it to open, almost motionless lips, silent words carried it to me.
es: I heard that rumor, it was conveyed to me with silent words, with a barely perceptible movement of the lips, while we were outside in line, waiting for the store to open, in whose window display there was a drawing of some succulent white fish fillets.

en: They put the picture in the window when they have something, take it away when they don't.
vi: They put up the pictures when there is stock, and take them down when it's gone.
tr: They put the picture in the window when they have something and take it down when it's sold out, sign language.
es: When they have something, they put the drawing in the window display; if not, they remove it.

en: Sign language.
vi: The language of signs.
tr: They put the picture in the window when they have something and take it down when it's sold out, sign language.
es: A language of signals.

en: Ofglen and I walk slowly today; we are hot in our long dresses, wet under the arms, tired.
vi: Today, Ofglen and I walked very slowly; the long dress is very stifling, under the armpits is soaking wet, we are tired.
tr: Gleninki and I are walking slowly today; we are suffocating under our long dresses, our armpits are wet, we are tired.
es: Today, Deglen and I walked slowly; we are hot in our long dresses, our armpits are sweating, and we are tired.

en: At least in this heat we don't wear gloves.
vi: At least in this heat, we don't have to wear gloves.
tr: At least we are not wearing gloves in this heat.
es: At least in this heat, we are not wearing gloves.

en: There used to be an ice cream store, somewhere in this block.
vi: There used to be an ice cream shop somewhere in this area.
tr: There used to be an ice cream shop somewhere in this block.
es: At some point on this block, there was an ice cream shop.

en: 1 can't remember the name.
vi: I don't remember the name.
tr: I can't remember its name.
es: I can't remember the name.

en: Things can change so thickly, buildings can be torn down or turned into something else, it's hard to keep them straight in your mind the way they used to be.
vi: Everything changes so quickly, the rows of houses get demolished or transformed into something else, it's hard to keep the image in your mind exactly as it was.
tr: Everything can change very quickly, buildings can be demolished and turned into something else, it’s hard for a person to keep them in mind as they used to be.
es: Things can change so quickly, buildings can be demolished or transformed into something else, and it becomes difficult to remember them as they were.

en: You could get double scoops, and if you wanted they would put chocolate sprinkles on the top.
vi: You could buy a double serving, and if you asked, the seller would sprinkle chocolate chips on top.
tr: You could get two scoops of ice cream, and if you wanted, they would sprinkle chocolate pieces on top.
es: You could get double cones, and if you wanted, they would sprinkle chocolate shavings on top.

en: These had the name of a man.
vi: That dish had a man's name.
tr: They were named after a man, was it Johnnies?
es: They had a man's name, Johnnies?

en: Johnnies?
vi: Johnnie?
tr: They were named after a man, was it Johnnies?
es: They had a man's name, Johnnies?

en: Jackies?
vi: Or Jackie?
tr: Jackies?
es: Jackies?

en: I can't remember.
vi: I don't remember anymore.
tr: I can't remember.
es: I can't remember it.

en: We would go there, when she was little, and I'd hold her up so she
vi: We used to go there often, back when my child was still small.
tr: When my daughter was little, we used to go there, I would lift her up so she could see the ice cream tubs displayed behind the glass counter; they had quite elegant colors, pale orange, pale green, pale pink, I would read out their names so she could choose.
es: We used to go when she was little, and I would lift her up in my arms so she could see over the glass counter, where the tubs of softly colored ice creams were displayed: pale orange, pale green, pale pink, and I would read the names to her so she could choose.

en: could see through the glass side of the counter, where the vats of ice cream were on display, colored so delicately, pale orange, pale green, pale pink, and I'd read the names to her so she could choose.
vi: I would lift them up so they could see clearly through the glass cover of the counter, where the ice cream bowls were displayed, in various eye-catching colors: light orange, light blue, light pink.
tr: When my daughter was little, we used to go there, I would lift her up so she could see the ice cream tubs displayed behind the glass counter; they had quite elegant colors, pale orange, pale green, pale pink, I would read out their names so she could choose.
es: We used to go when she was little, and I would lift her up in my arms so she could see over the glass counter, where the tubs of softly colored ice creams were displayed: pale orange, pale green, pale pink, and I would read the names to her so she could choose.

en: She wouldn't choose by the name, though, but by the color.
vi: I would read the names of each type for them to choose. But they didn't choose by name, but by color.
tr: However, she would choose based on the colors rather than the names.
es: Anyway, she didn't choose them by the name, but by the color.

en: Her dresses and overalls were those colors too.
vi: Their dresses and clothes were also in those same colors.
tr: Her dresses and leggings were also in these colors.
es: Her dresses and smocks were also in those colors.

en: Ice cream pastels.
vi: A palette of light colors like ice cream.
tr: Ice cream pastels.
es: Pastel ice creams.

en: Jimmies, that was the name.
vi: Jimmie, that's right.
tr: Jimmies, this was the name.
es: Jimmies, that's what they were called.

en: Ofglen and I are more comfortable with one another now, we're used to each other.
vi: Ofglen and I are more comfortable now, we have gotten to know each other a little.
tr: Gleninki and I are more comfortable together now, after all, we have gotten used to each other.
es: Now, Deglen and I feel more comfortable, we have gotten used to being together.

en: Siamese twins.
vi: Conjoined twins.
tr: Siamese twins.
es: Like Siamese twins.

en: We don't bother much with the formalities anymore when we greet each other; we smile and move off, in tandem, traveling smoothly along our daily track.
vi: Now we don't bother much with formal greetings, just smile and start walking, one ahead of the other, quietly strolling along our daily route.
tr: We no longer bother with formalities when greeting each other; we smile and set off straight ahead like horses lined up in a row.
es: We no longer bother with the formalities of greeting; we smile and set off, in tandem, serenely following our daily route.

en: Now and again we vary the route; there's nothing against it, as long as we stay within the barriers.
vi: Sometimes we change the route; no one forbids it, as long as we stay within the barriers.
tr: From time to time, we change our course; as long as we stay within the boundaries set by the barricades, there's no harm in it.
es: From time to time we vary the itinerary; there is nothing that prohibits it, as long as we stay within the boundary of the barriers.

en: A rat in a maze is free to go anywhere, as long as it stays inside the maze.
vi: The mouse in the maze is free to run wherever it wants, as long as it stays in the maze.
tr: As long as it stays within the labyrinth, a mouse is free to go wherever it wants.
es: A rat inside a maze is free to go anywhere, as long as it stays within the maze.

en: We've been to the stores already, and the church; now we're at the Wall.
vi: We have finished going through the shops, past the church; now we are at the Wall.
tr: We had already gone to the shops, and to the church; now we were by the Wall.
es: We have already gone to the shops and to the church; now we are in front of the Wall.

en: Nothing on it today, they don't leave the bodies hanging as long in summer as they do in winter, because of the flies and the smell.
vi: Today the wall is completely empty, people don't leave bodies for long like they did in the winter, there would be flies and smell.
tr: There was nothing on it today, they didn't leave the bodies hanging as long as they did in winter because of the flies and the smell.
es: Today there is nothing, in summer they don't leave the corpses hanging as long as in winter, because of the flies and the smell.

en: This was once the land of air sprays, pine and floral, and people retain the taste; especially the Commanders, who preach purity in all things.
vi: In the past, this used to be the domain of spray paint, pine scent, and the smell of flowers, and people still maintain that preference; especially the Commanders, who preach purity in all things.
tr: This place was once the land of sprays. Pine and Floral, people still haven't forgotten the taste; especially the Commanders who always suggested purity in everything.
es: At another time this was the kingdom of air fresheners, Pine and Floral, and people retain their fondness for them; especially the Commanders, who advocate for the purity of all things.

en: "You have everything on your list?"
vi: "Have you bought everything you need?"
tr: "Did you get everything on the list?"
es: —Do you have everything on your list?

en: Ofglen says to me now, though she knows I do.
vi: Ofglen asked me, even though she knew the answer was yes.
tr: Gleninki asks now, though she knows I did.
es: —Deglen asks me, even though he knows I do.

en: Our lists are never long.
vi: The shopping list is rarely long.
tr: Our lists are never long.
es: Our lists are never long.

en: She's given up some of her passivity lately, some of her melancholy.
vi: Recently, she has become less passive, less gloomy.
tr: Lately, she had given up some of her passivity and melancholy.
es: She has abandoned her passivity from the early days, part of her melancholy.

en: Often she speaks to me first.
vi: She often starts conversations with me first.
tr: Most of the time, she is the one who speaks to me first.
es: Often, it is she who initiates the conversation.

en: "Yes," I say.
vi: “Enough,” I said.
tr: "Yes," I say.
es: —Yes —I respond.

en: "Let's go around," she says.
vi: "Let's go that way," she said.
tr: “Let's take a walk,” he says.
es: —Then let's take a walk —he suggests.

en: She means down, towards the river.
vi: She meant to continue, towards the river.
tr: He means the road going down to the river.
es: He means that we should go down to the river.

en: We haven't been that way for a while.
vi: It had been a long time since we last went that way.
tr: We hadn't been there for a while.
es: It's been a while since we went there.

en: "Fine," I say.
vi: “Alright,” I said.
tr: “Good,” I say.
es: —Fantastic —I say.

en: I don't turn at once, though, but remain standing where I am, taking a last look at the Wall.
vi: But I did not turn away immediately; I still stood there, looking at the Wall one last time.
tr: Still, I don't immediately turn back and stay where I am, casting one last glance at the Wall.
es: However, I don't turn around immediately but stay where I am, taking one last look at the Wall.

en: There arc the red bricks, there are the searchlights, there's the barbed wire, there arc the hooks.
vi: Red bricks, floodlights, barbed wire, hooks.
tr: The red bricks are in place, as are the spotlights, barbed wires, and hooks.
es: There are the red bricks, the spotlights, the barbed wire, the hooks.

en: Somehow the Wall is even more foreboding when it's empty like this.
vi: Somehow, the empty Wall seemed even more menacing.
tr: When it's empty like this, the Wall suggests more than ever that something bad is going to happen.
es: In some way, the Wall seems even more ominous when it is empty, like today.

en: When there's someone hanging on it at least you know the worst.
vi: When there were people on it, at least you could see the worst of it.
tr: When someone is hanging on it, at least you know what the worst is.
es: When there is someone hanging, at least you know the worst.

en: But vacant, it is also potential, like a storm approaching.
vi: But when the wall was empty, the potential remained, like a storm approaching.
tr: But when it's empty, it also harbors possibilities, like an approaching storm.
es: But empty, it is also something in potential, like an approaching storm.

en: When I can see
vi: When I saw the bodies, the corpses before my eyes, when I gauged their size and shape and did not see Luke, I could still believe that he was alive.
tr: When I can see the bodies, the real bodies, and can guess from their sizes and shapes that none of them are Luke, I can also believe that he is still alive.
es: When I see the bodies, the real bodies, when I manage to guess by the sizes and shapes that none of them is Luke, I can also think that he is still alive.

en: the bodies, the actual bodies, when I can guess from the sizes and shapes that none of them is Luke, I can believe also that he is still alive.
vi: When I saw the bodies, the corpses before my eyes, when I gauged their size and shape and did not see Luke, I could still believe that he was alive.
tr: When I can see the bodies, the real bodies, and can guess from their sizes and shapes that none of them are Luke, I can also believe that he is still alive.
es: When I see the bodies, the real bodies, when I manage to guess by the sizes and shapes that none of them is Luke, I can also think that he is still alive.

en: I don't know why I expect him to appear on this wall.
vi: I don't know why I thought he would show up here.
tr: I don't know why I expected him to appear on this wall.
es: I don't know why I expect to see him on this wall.

en: There are hundreds of other places they could have killed him.
vi: Maybe he has been killed in hundreds of other places.
tr: There are hundreds of other places where they could have killed him.
es: There are hundreds of different places where they could have killed him.

en: But I can't shake the idea that he's in there, at this moment, behind the blank red bricks.
vi: But I can't shake the thought that he is in there, right now, behind the empty red bricks.
tr: However, I can't shake the idea that right now, he is there, behind the empty, red bricks.
es: But I can't get the idea out of my head that at this moment he is there, behind the empty red bricks.

en: I try to imagine which building he's in.
vi: I try to imagine which house he is in.
tr: I am trying to imagine which building I am inside.
es: I try to imagine which building he is in.

en: I can remember where the buildings are, inside the Wall; we used to be able to walk freely there, when it was a university.
vi: I still remember where the houses are, behind that wall; we used to walk freely inside when this was still a university.
tr: I can remember the locations of the buildings on the other side of the Wall; when it was a university, we could roam freely there.
es: I remember the layout of the buildings, on the other side of the Wall; before, when it was a university, we could walk freely inside.

en: We still go in there once in a while, for Women's Salvagings.
vi: Now sometimes we still go in there, attending the Women's Redemption ceremonies.
tr: We still go there occasionally, for the Women's Liberation Ceremony.
es: We still go in, occasionally, for the Women's Salvations.

en: Most of the buildings are red brick too; some have arched doorways, a Romanesque effect, from the nineteenth century.
vi: Most of the houses are also built with red bricks, some areas have arches, a Romanesque touch, from the nineteenth century.
tr: Most of the buildings are made of red brick; some have arched entrances, a Roman influence from the nineteenth century.
es: Most of the buildings are also made of red bricks; some have arched doors, a nineteenth-century Romanesque effect.

en: We aren't allowed inside the buildings anymore; but who would want to go in?
vi: Now we are not allowed to enter the buildings anymore, but who would want to go in?
tr: We are no longer allowed to enter the buildings; well, who would want to anyway?
es: They no longer allow us to enter the buildings, but who cares about going in?

en: Those buildings belong to the Eyes.
vi: Those houses belong to the Eyes.
tr: These buildings belong to the Eyes.
es: They belong to the Eyes.

en: Maybe he's in the Library.
vi: He might be in the library.
tr: Maybe, Luke is in the library.
es: Maybe it is in the Library.

en: Somewhere in the vaults.
vi: Somewhere in the basement.
tr: Somewhere under the domes.
es: Somewhere in the vaults.

en: The stacks.
vi: In the book storage.
tr: Among the shelves.
es: On the shelves.

en: The Library is like a temple.
vi: The library is like a temple.
tr: The library is like a temple.
es: The Library is like a temple.

en: There's a long flight of white steps, leading to the rank of doors.
vi: A long white staircase leads up to a row of aligned doors.
tr: There is a long, white staircase that leads to rows of doors.
es: There is a long white staircase that leads to the row of doors.

en: Then, inside, another white staircase going up.
vi: Deep inside, there is another white staircase going up.
tr: Then, inside, another white staircase that goes upwards.
es: Inside, another white staircase.

en: To either side of it, on the wall, there are angels.
vi: On the walls on both sides are angels.
tr: On either side, on the wall, there are angels.
es: On both sides of this, on the wall, there are angels.

en: Also there are men fighting, or about to fight, looking clean and noble, not dirty and bloodstained and smelly the way they must have looked.
vi: There are also people engaged in battle, or about to charge, clean and noble, not dirty, bloody, and foul-smelling as they would be in real life.
tr: There are also men, fighting or about to fight, who appear clean and noble as they should, not dirty, blood-stained, and foul-smelling; on one side of the inner hall, Victory encourages them, while on the other side, Death is present.
es: There are also some men fighting, or about to fight, looking clean and noble and not dirty, bloodied, and smelly, as they should have appeared.

en: Victory is on one side of the inner doorway, leading them on, and Death is on the other.
vi: Victory is on one side of the inner door, guiding them forward, on the other side is Death.
tr: There are also men, fighting or about to fight, who appear clean and noble as they should, not dirty, blood-stained, and foul-smelling; on one side of the inner hall, Victory encourages them, while on the other side, Death is present.
es: On one side of the inner door, Victory is seen, guiding them, and on the other side, Death.

en: It's a mural in honor of some war or other.
vi: This mural is meant to honor some war.
tr: This is a mural made in honor of this or that war.
es: It is a mural in honor of some war.

en: The men on the side of Death are still alive.
vi: The people on Death's side are still alive.
tr: The men on the side of Death are still alive.
es: The men who are next to Death are still alive.

en: They're going to heaven.
vi: They are on their way to heaven.
tr: They are going to heaven.
es: They are going to Heaven.

en: Death is a beautiful woman, with wings and one breast almost bare; or is that Victory?
vi: Death is a beautiful woman with wings, one breast almost bare; or is it Victory?
tr: With wings and an almost bare chest, Death is a woman; or was it Victory?
es: Death is a beautiful woman with wings and an almost bare chest. Or is that Victory?

en: I can't remember.
vi: I can't remember.
tr: I can't remember.
es: I don't remember.

en: They won't have destroyed that.
vi: They probably won't destroy that.
tr: They will not have destroyed this.
es: They did not want to destroy this.

en: We turn our backs to the Wall, head left.
vi: We turned away from the Wall, turned left, here there were a few empty shops, soap written in squiggly letters on the glass door.
tr: We turn our backs to the wall and head left.
es: We turned our backs to the Wall and walked to the left.

en: Here there are several empty storefronts, their glass windows scrawled with soap.
vi: We turned away from the Wall, turned left, here there were a few empty shops, soap written in squiggly letters on the glass door.
tr: There are many empty shop windows here, their glass scribbled with soap.
es: Here there are several empty warehouses with the windows of the storefronts scribbled with soap.

en: I try to remember what was sold in them, once.
vi: I tried to remember what they used to sell, back in the day.
tr: I try to remember what used to be sold there.
es: I try to remember what they used to sell in the past.

en: Cosmetics?
vi: Cosmetics?
tr: Cosmetics?
es: Cosmetics?

en: Jewelry?
vi: Jewelry?
tr: Or jewelry?
es: Jewelry?

en: Most of the stores carrying things for men are still open; it's just the ones dealing in what they call vanities that have been shut down.
vi: Most of the shops serving men were still operating normally; only those selling what were called luxury items were closed.
tr: Most of the shops that have something for men are still open; the ones that were closed dealt with what they called trivial matters.
es: Most of the stores that sold men's items are still open; only those that sold what they call vanities have been closed.

en: At the corner is the store known as Soul Scrolls.
vi: At the corner of the street is a store named Soul Book.
tr: There is a shop known as Prayer Cylinders on the corner.
es: On the corner, there is a store called Spiritual Scrolls.

en: It's a franchise: there are Soul Scrolls in every city center, in every suburb, or so they say.
vi: There is an entire chain of stores: Soul Book is present in the center of every city, every suburb, or at least that's what they say.
tr: An agency: in every city center, in every suburb, there are Prayer Cylinders, at least that's what they say.
es: It is a sanctuary: there are Spiritual Scrolls in the center of every city, in every suburb, or so they say.

en: It must make a lot of profit.
vi: It must be making quite a bit of money.
tr: They must be making a lot of profit.
es: They must make substantial profits.

en: The window of Soul Scrolls is shatterproof.
vi: The window is made of unbreakable glass.
tr: The display windows of the Prayer Cylinders are of the unbreakable kind.
es: The display window of Spiritual Scrolls is made of shatterproof glass.

en: Behind it are printout machines, row on row of them; these machines are known as Holy Rollers, but only among us, it's a disrespectful nickname.
vi: Inside are rows of printers; they are called the Rolling Gods, but only we know this very irreverent nickname among ourselves.
tr: Behind the glass, rows upon rows of printing machines; these machines are known as the Sacred Rollers, but only among us, producing prayers in endless rolls.
es: Behind it, rows and rows of printing machines can be seen; these machines are known by the name Sacred Scrolls, but only among us, because it is a disrespectful name, a nickname.

en: What the machines print is prayers, roll upon roll, prayers going out endlessly.
vi: The printed products are prayer scrolls, rolling out endlessly.
tr: Behind the glass, rows upon rows of printing machines; these machines are known as the Sacred Rollers, but only among us, producing prayers in endless rolls.
es: What the machines print are prayers, scrolls and more scrolls that never stop coming out.

en: They're ordered by Compuphone, I've overheard the Commander's Wife doing it.
vi: They are ordered via computer phone, I overheard the Lady Commander making a call.
tr: They are ordered via the Compuphones, I had overheard the Commander's Wife doing it.
es: Orders are placed via Compufone; one day, by chance, I heard the Commander's Wife doing it.

en: Ordering prayers from Soul Scrolls is supposed to be a sign of pietyand faithfulness to the regime, so of course the Commanders'
vi: Ordering from the Soul Scrolls is a sign of devotion and loyalty to the regime, so naturally, the Ladies continuously place orders.
tr: Since ordering prayers from the Prayer Cylinders is considered a sign of piety and loyalty to the regime, the Commanders'
es: The act of ordering prayers from Spiritual Scrolls is a display of piety and loyalty to the regime; so, naturally, the Commanders'

en: Wives do it a lot.
vi: It benefits their husbands' career advancement.
tr: Wives do this frequently, no doubt.
es: Wives do it very often.

en: It helps their husbands' careers.
vi: It benefits their husbands' career advancement.
tr: It helps their husbands' careers.
es: This supports their husbands' careers.

en: There are five different prayers: for health, wealth, a death, a birth, a sin.
vi: There are five different prayer contents: health, wealth, death, childbirth, and forgiveness.
tr: There are five types of prayers: for health and prosperity, for a death, for a birth, and for sins.
es: There are five different types of prayers: for health, wealth, a death, a birth, a sin.

en: You pick the one you want, punch in the number, then punch in your own number so your account will be debited, and punch in the number of times you want the prayer repeated.
vi: Select the one you need, enter the number, then enter your code to charge to your account, and enter the number of times you want to repeat the prayer.
tr: You choose the one you want and enter its number, then your own number so it can be deducted from your account, and finally the number of times you want the prayer to be repeated.
es: You choose the one you want, press your own number so that your account is charged, and press the number of copies you want of the prayer.

en: The machines talk as they print out the prayers; if you like, you can go inside and listen to them, the toneless metallic voices repeating the same thing over and over.
vi: The machines talk to each other while printing; if you want, you can go in and listen, the toneless metallic voice repeating only one thing.
tr: While the prayers are being printed, the machines speak; if you wish, you can go inside and listen to the toneless metallic voices repeating the same thing over and over again.
es: While the prayers are being printed, the machines speak; if you want, you can enter and listen to their expressionless and metallic voices repeating the same chant over and over again.

en: Once the prayers have been printed out and said, the paper rolls back through another slot and is recycled into fresh paper again.
vi: When the prayer is printed and read, the paper is rolled into another slot to be recycled into white paper.
tr: When the reading and printing of the prayers are finished, the paper is rolled back through another slot and clean paper comes again.
es: When the prayers have been spoken and printed, another paper is rolled into the slot and the cycle begins again.

en: There are no people inside the building: the machines run by themselves.
vi: There is no one in here: the machines run automatically.
tr: There are no people inside the building: the machines work on their own.
es: Inside the building, there is no one: the machines operate on their own.

en: You can't hear the voices from outside; only a murmur, a hum, like a devout crowd, on its knees.
vi: Standing outside, you can't hear the voices; they merge into a hum, a murmur, like a devout crowd, kneeling.
tr: You cannot hear their sounds from outside; just a murmur, a buzz, like a heap of a devout person kneeling.
es: From outside, you cannot hear the voices; you only hear a murmur, a hum, like that of a devout kneeling crowd.

en: Each machine has an eye painted in gold on the side, flanked by two small golden wings.
vi: On the side of each machine, a golden eye is drawn, with two small golden wings waving.
tr: On the side of each machine, there are eyes painted in gold and supported by small golden wings on both sides.
es: Each machine has a golden eye painted on its side, flanked by two small golden wings.

en: I try to remember what this place sold when it was a store, before it was turned into Soul Scrolls.
vi: I try to remember what was sold here when there were still goods, before it became the Soul Tome.
tr: Before it was turned into Dua Silindirleri, I try to remember what was sold here when it was a shop.
es: I try to remember what they sold here when this was a store, before it became Spiritual Scrolls.

en: I think it was lingerie.
vi: It seems like it was women's underwear.
