tr: He was still kneeling on the ground.
es: He was still kneeling on the ground.

en: You know I'll always take care of you.
vi: You know I will always take care of you.
tr: You think I will always look after you.
es: You know I will always take care of you.

en: I thought, Already he's starting to patronize me.
vi: I think, He already wants to act like an elder to me.
tr: He has already started to act superior to me, I thought.
es: He's starting to treat me with a protective air, I thought.

en: Then I thought, Already you're starting to get paranoid.
vi: Then I think, You're already getting scared.
tr: Immediately after, I thought, you are already starting to become paranoid.
es: And you're starting to get paranoid, I told myself.

en: I know, I said.
vi: I'm sorry, I said.
tr: I know, I said.
es: I know, I replied.

en: I love you.
vi: I love you.
tr: I love you.
es: I love you.

en: Later, after she was in bed andwe were having supper, and I wasn't feeling so shaky, I told him about the afternoon.
vi: Then, when you had gone to bed and we were having dinner, when I was no longer trembling so much, I recounted the afternoon to him.
tr: Later, after the girl went to bed and we had dinner, I didn't feel so shaken, and I told her what happened in the afternoon.
es: Later, when she was lying down and we were having dinner, and I stopped trembling, I told her what had happened to me that afternoon.

en: I described the director coming in, blurting out his announcement.
vi: I described the director entering the room, blurting out the announcement.
tr: I described the manager's entrance and his sudden explanation.
es: I told her about the appearance of the director and his unexpected announcement.

en: It would have been funny if it wasn't so awful, I said.
vi: If it hadn't been so frightening, it would have been very funny, I said.
tr: If it weren't so terrifying, it would have been ridiculous, I said.
es: If it weren't so frightening, it would have been funny, I commented.

en: I thought he was drunk.
vi: I thought he was drunk.
tr: I thought he was drunk.
es: I thought he was drunk.

en: Maybe he was.
vi: He might actually have been drunk.
tr: Maybe he was.
es: Maybe he was.

en: The army was there, and everything.
vi: There were also the military and all sorts of other things.
tr: The army and everyone else were there.
es: But the army was there.

en: Then I remembered something I'd seen and hadn't noticed, at the time.
vi: Then I remembered something I had seen but not noticed at the time.
tr: Then I remembered something I had seen around that time but hadn't paid attention to.
es: Then I remembered something I had seen but, nevertheless, had not noticed.

en: It wasn't the army.
vi: It wasn't the national army.
tr: It wasn't the army as we know it.
es: It wasn't the army.

en: It was some other army.
vi: It was another army.
tr: It was a different kind of army.
es: It was another army.

en: There were marches, of course, a lot of women and some men.
vi: There were protests, of course, many women with a few men.
tr: There were marches, of course, a bunch of women and a few men.
es: Of course, marches were organized by lots of women and some men.

en: But they were smaller than you might have thought.
vi: But the scale was much smaller than imagined.
tr: However, their numbers were fewer than you might think.
es: But they were less important than anyone might think.

en: I guess people were
vi: Perhaps people were terrified.
tr: I think people were scared.
es: I think people were panicking.

en: scared.
vi: Perhaps people were terrified.
tr: I think people were scared.
es: I think people were panicking.

en: And when it was known that the police, or the army, or whoever they were, would open fire almost as soon as any of the marches even started, the marches stopped.
vi: And when it became clear that the police, or the army, or whatever that group was called, would open fire almost immediately as the crowd began to take to the streets, the protesters gave up.
tr: When it was heard that the police or the army or whoever would open fire as soon as the marches began, the marches stopped.
es: And when it became known that the police, or the army, or whoever, would open fire as soon as a single one of those marches started, they were disrupted.

en: A few things were blown up, post offices, subway stations.
vi: Some places were bombed, the post office, the subway station.
tr: A few bombs were set off, post offices, subway stations.
es: Two or three buildings, post offices, and metro stations were blown up.

en: But you couldn't even be sure who was doing it.
vi: But it was still uncertain who was responsible.
tr: But you couldn't even be sure who did it.
es: But one couldn't even be sure who was doing all that.

en: It could have been the army, to justify the computer searches and the other ones, the door-to-doors.
vi: It could have been the army itself, to have an excuse to search the computers and search beyond the computers, house by house.
tr: It could have been the army, to justify their computer and house-to-house searches.
es: It could have been the army, to justify the computer records and the other door-to-door searches.

en: I didn't go on any of the marches.
vi: I did not participate in any protests.
tr: I did not join any of the marches.
es: I was not part of any of those marches.

en: Luke said it would be futile and I had to think about them, my family, him and her.
vi: Luke said it was a waste of time and that I had to think about everyone, my family, him, and our child.
tr: Luke said it would be in vain and that I should think about them, my family, him, and my daughter.
es: Luke thought it was useless, and that I had to think about them, about my family, about him and her.

en: I did think about my family.
vi: I thought about my family.
tr: So I thought about my family.
es: And I thought about my family.

en: I started doing more housework, more baking.
vi: I started cleaning more, baking more.
tr: I started doing more housework, cooking more meals.
es: I started dedicating myself more to household chores, to cooking.

en: I tried not to cry at mealtimes.
vi: I tried not to cry when mealtime came.
tr: I tried not to cry during meal times.
es: I tried not to cry at mealtime.

en: By this time I'd started to cry, without warning, and to sit beside the bedroom window, staring out.
vi: Lately, I have started crying often, suddenly, and sitting by the bedroom window, staring out aimlessly.
tr: At that time, I had started crying for no reason and sitting at the bedroom window looking outside.
es: But that time I unexpectedly burst into tears and sat by the window of the room, looking outside.

en: I didn't know many of the neighbors, and whenwe met, outside on the street, we were careful to exchange nothing more than the ordinary greetings.
vi: I don't know many neighbors, and when we meet on the street, we are careful not to exchange more than common greetings.
tr: I didn't know many of the neighbors, and when we met on the street, we made an effort not to talk much beyond the usual greetings.
es: I practically didn't know the neighbors, and when we met on the street, we were very careful not to exchange more than the customary greeting.

en: Nobody wanted to be reported, for disloyalty.
vi: No one wants to be reported, accused of disloyalty.
tr: Nobody wanted to be reported on the grounds of betrayal.
es: Nobody wanted to be reported for disloyalty.

en: Remembering this, I remember also my mother, years before.
vi: Remembering this, I also recall my mother, many years ago.
tr: As I remember this, I also remember my mother, years ago.
es: When I recall this time, I also remember my mother, years ago.

en: I must have been fourteen, fifteen, that age when daughters are most embarrassed by their mothers.
vi: It must have been around when I was fourteen or fifteen, the age when girls are most easily embarrassed by their mothers.
tr: I must have been fourteen or fifteen, at the age when girls are most annoyed by their mothers.
es: I must have been fourteen or fifteen years old, the age when daughters have the most conflicts with their mothers.

en: I remember her coming back to one of our many apartments, with a group of other women, part of her ever-changing circle of friends.
vi: I remember my mother returning to some apartment, one of the countless places we had lived, with a group of other women, among the ever-changing faces of her friends.
tr: I remember her coming to one of our constantly changing houses with a group of other women, part of her constantly changing circle of friends.
es: I remember she returned to one of her many apartments with a group of women who were part of her ever-renewing circle of friends.

en: They'd been in a march that day; it was during the time of the porn riots,or was it the abortion riots, they were close together.
vi: That day they had just returned from a protest; it was during the anti-pornography or anti-abortion riots, both of which were closely related.
tr: That day, they had participated in a march; it was the time of anti-pornography uprisings, or was it the abortion uprisings, they were so close to each other.
es: That day they had attended a march; it was the time of the disturbances due to pornography, or due to abortions, they were closely linked.

en: There were a lot of bombings then: clinics, video stores; it was hard to keep track.
vi: Bombings everywhere: clinics, video stores; hard to remember exactly.
tr: There had been many bombings at that time: clinics, video stores; it was hard to keep track.
es: There were a few bombings: clinics, video stores; it was difficult to closely follow the events.

en: My mother had a bruise on her face, and a little blood.
vi: There were bruises and a bit of blood on my mother's face.
tr: There was a bruise and a bit of blood on my mother's face.
es: My mother had a bruise on her face and a bit of blood.

en: You can't stick your hand through a glass window without getting cut, is what she said about it.
vi: You can't stick your hand through the glass without getting cut, my mother remarked curtly.
tr: Those who went to the bathhouse were sweating, that's all he said.
es: You can't go through glass with your hand and not cut yourself, she remarked.

en: Fucking pigs.
vi: Damn those pigs.
tr: Damned pigs.
es: Fucking pigs.

en: Fucking bleeders, one of her friends said.
vi: Oh mother, the bloodsuckers, one of the friends said.
tr: Damn bleeders, said one of his friends.
es: Damn pro-birthers, one of her friends corrected.

en: They called the other side bleeders, after the signs they carried: Let them bleed.
vi: They called the other side the bloodsuckers, because of their banner: Let them bleed.
tr: They called the other side bleeders, according to the slogans they carried: Let them bleed.
es: They called their opponents pro-birthers because of the signs they carried: Let them be born.

en: So it must have been the abortion riots.
vi: So it must be about the abortion issue.
tr: So, there must have been abortion uprisings.
es: So it must have been a disturbance over the abortion issue.

en: I went into my bedroom, to DC out of their way.
vi: I went into the bedroom, avoiding them.
tr: I went to my bedroom to stay out of the way.
es: I went to my bedroom to get away from them.

en: They were talking too much, and too loudly.
vi: They talked too much, too noisily.
tr: They were talking too much and too loudly.
es: They talked too much, and very loudly.

en: They ignored me, and I resented them.
vi: They ignored me, and I hated them.
tr: They were ignoring me, and I was resenting them for it.
es: They ignored me and I got offended.

en: My mother and her rowdy friends.
vi: Both my mother and her rude friends.
tr: My mom and her thug friends.
es: My mother and her rowdy friends.

en: I didn't see why she had to dress that
vi: I really don't understand why my mother has to dress like that, in overalls, as if she's still very young, and why she has to swear all the time.
tr: I didn't understand why she had to dress like that, as if she were young, walking around in overalls; or why she had to swear so much.
es: I didn't understand why she had to dress that way, in overalls, as if she were young; and use those swear words.

en: way, in overalls, as if she were young; or to swear so much.
vi: I really don't understand why my mother has to dress like that, in overalls, as if she's still very young, and why she has to swear all the time.
tr: I didn't understand why she had to dress like that, as if she were young, walking around in overalls; or why she had to swear so much.
es: I didn't understand why she had to dress that way, in overalls, as if she were young; and use those swear words.

en: You're such a prude, she would say to me, in a tone of voice that was on the whole pleased.
vi: You're just like a turtle hiding in its shell, my mother often told me, her tone actually quite satisfied.
tr: "But you are pretending to be virtuous," she would say to me, usually in a pleased tone of voice.
es: You are a prude, he would say to me, generally in a tone of satisfaction.

en: She liked being more outrageous than I was, more rebellious.
vi: My mother liked to appear more daring, more rebellious than I was.
tr: She enjoyed being more unconventional, more rebellious than I was.
es: He liked being more scandalous than me, more rebellious.

en: Adolescents are always such prudes.
vi: Teenagers are always like turtles hiding in their shells.
tr: Young people always pretend to be virtuous like this.
es: Teenagers are always prudes.

en: Part of my disapproval was that, I'm sure: perfunctory, routine.
vi: One reason I am not satisfied with my mother is because of that, I know: formula, habit.
tr: I am sure part of my opposition was based on this: indifference, routine.
es: I am sure that part of my disapproval was due to that: the negligence, the routine.

en: But also I wanted from her a life more ceremonious, less subject to makeshift and decampment.
vi: But besides that, I also hope my mother can give me a more proper life, less temporary and wandering.
tr: Moreover, I wanted a life that was more ceremonial, less dependent on temporary measures and escapes than his.
es: But I also expected from her a more ceremonious life, less subject to improvisation and constant fleeing.

en: You were a wanted child, God knows, she would say at other moments, lingering over the photo albums in which she had me framed; these albums were thick with babies, but my replicas thinned out as I grew older, as if the population of my duplicates had been hit by some plague.
vi: You were born out of desire, witnessed by God, at other times mother would say, lingering through each album page helping her frame me; those albums densely packed with baby pictures, but my copies thinned out as I grew, like the inhabitants of that twin river country who had to endure a plague.
tr: You were a wanted child, God knows, she would say at other times, while lingering on the pages of the photo albums she framed me in; these albums were swollen with baby pictures, but as I grew older, my images dwindled, as if their number had been decimated by some kind of epidemic.
es: God knows you were a wanted child, she assured me at other times, while she amused herself with the photo albums where she kept me stored. Those albums were full of chubby babies, but my replicas became more slender as I grew, as if the population of my doubles had been ravaged by some plague.

en: She would say this a little regretfully, as though I hadn't turned out entirely as she'd expected.
vi: Mother's voice then often had a tinge of regret, as if in the end I turned out not quite as she had hoped.
tr: She would say this with a bit of sadness, as if I hadn't turned out exactly as she had expected.
es: She said it with a certain regret, as if I had not turned out exactly as she expected.

en: No mother is ever, completely, a child's idea of what a mother should be,and I suppose it works the other way around as well.
vi: No mother is exactly, one hundred percent, the child's idea of a mother, and I suppose the reverse is also true.
tr: No mother fully matches the idea of a mother that a child has, and I suppose the reverse is also true.
es: Mothers never completely align with the idea a child has of what a mother should be, and I suppose the same happens in the reverse case.

en: But despite everything, we didn't do badly by one another, we did as well as most.
vi: But despite everything, we lived together not too badly, quite as well as most other pairs.
tr: But despite everything, we were not bad with each other. We were like most people.
es: But despite everything, we didn't get along badly, most of the time we had a good time.

en: I wish she were here, so I could tell her I finally know this.
vi: I wish my mother were here, to tell her that I finally understand it.
tr: I wish he were here so that I could finally tell him that I understand this.
es: I would like you to be here, to tell you that I have finally discovered it.

en: Someone has come out of the house.
vi: Someone has left the house.
tr: Someone came out of the house.
es: Someone has gone out.

en: I hear the distant closing of a door, around at the side, footsteps on the walk.
vi: I heard the door closing in the distance, from the side wall, the sound of footsteps on the entrance path.
tr: From afar, I hear a door closing, footsteps on the walkway somewhere to the side.
es: I hear a door closing in the distance, somewhere on the side of the house, and some footsteps on the path.

en: It's Nick, I can see him now; he's stepped off the path, onto the lawn, to breathe in the humid air which stinks of flowers, of pulpy growth, of pollen thrown into the wind in handfuls, like oysterspawn into the sea.
vi: It's Nick, now I see: he steps off the path, treads on the grass, inhales the damp air reeking of various flowers, the scent of fruit flesh, the pollen scattering in handfuls into the wind, like clam eggs spraying into the ocean.
tr: It's Nick, now I can see him; he stepped off the path onto the grass, inhaling the moist air thick with the scent of flowers, lush growth, and handfuls of pollen thrown into the wind like oysters spilling into the sea.
es: It's Nick, now I see him; he walks down the path to the lawn to breathe the humid air filled with the scent of flowers, lush vegetation, and pollen thrown into the wind in bunches, like oyster eggs in the sea.

en: All this prodigal breeding.
vi: How wildly the seeds are sown.
tr: Always this extravagant reproduction.
es: What a waste of life.

en: He stretches in the sun, I feel the ripple of muscles go along him, like a cat's back arching.
vi: He stretches in the sunlight, I can feel the muscles moving down his body, like a cat arching its back.
tr: Nick stretches in the sun, I can feel his muscles rippling along his body, just like a cat's arched back.
es: He stretches out under the sun, I notice the ripple of his muscles, like a cat arching its back.

en: He's in his shirt sleeves, bare arms sticking shamelessly out from the rolled cloth.
vi: He is wearing only a shirt, his bare arms brazenly emerging from the rolled-up sleeves.
tr: He's wearing a shirt, his bare arms shamelessly emerging from the rolled-up fabric.
es: He's in his shirtsleeves, and his bare arms boldly stick out from under the rolled-up fabric.

en: Where does the tan end?
vi: Where does the tan end?
tr: I wonder where the bronze of his skin ends?
es: Where will his tan end?

en: I haven't spoken to him since that one night, dreamscape in the moon-filled sitting room.
vi: I haven't spoken to him since that one night, the dream-like night in the moonlit rest room.
tr: I haven't spoken to him since that night, since the dreamlike scene in the living room filled with moonlight.
es: Since that dreamy night in the moonlit room, I haven't spoken to him again.

en: He's only my flag, my semaphore.
vi: He is just a flag, a signal to me.
tr: He's just my flag, my semaphore.
es: He is only my flag, my traffic light.

en: Body language.
vi: Body language.
tr: Body language.
es: Ours is a body language.

en: Right now his cap's on sideways.
vi: At this moment, your hat is askew.
tr: The cap is tilted to the side right now.
es: At this moment, he has his cap tilted, which means they are calling for me.

en: Therefore I am sent for.
vi: That means I am being summoned.
tr: That means I'm being summoned.
es: At this moment, he has his cap tilted, which means they are calling for me.

en: What does he get for it, his role as page boy?
vi: What did he get in return for this errand boy job?
tr: What does the errand boy get in return for his role?
es: What does he get out of all this, playing the role of a page?

en: How does he feel, pimping in this ambiguous way for the Commander?
vi: What did he think when he took on this extremely ambiguous role as a go-between for the Leader?
tr: How does he feel while ambiguously pimping for the Commander?
es: What does he feel playing this ambiguous role of the Commander's pimp?

en: Does it fill him
vi: What did he think when he took on this extremely ambiguous role as a go-between for the Leader?
tr: Does it fill him with disgust, or does it make him want me more?
es: Does it disgust him, or does it make him desire something more from me, desire me more?

en: with disgust, or make him want more of me, want me more?
vi: Did he feel disgusted, or did he want more from me, want me more?
tr: Does it fill him with disgust, or does it make him want me more?
es: Does it disgust him, or does it make him desire something more from me, desire me more?

en: Because he has no idea what really goes on in there, among the books.
vi: Because he couldn't know what was really happening there, among the stacks of books.
tr: Because there, among the books, he has no idea what's really going on.
es: Because he has no idea what really happens in there, among the books.

en: Acts of perversion, for all he knows.
vi: Monkey tricks, that's all he could guess.
tr: Perverse actions, considering how little he knows.
es: Acts of perversion, for all he knows.

en: The Commander and me, covering each other with ink, licking it off, or making love on stacks of forbidden newsprint.
vi: The Leader and I, covering each other in ink, licking it all off, or making love on piles of banned newspapers.
tr: The Commander and I, covering each other in ink, then licking it off or making love on piles of forbidden newspapers.
es: The Commander and I covering each other with ink and licking it off with our tongues, or making love on piles of forbidden newspaper pages.

en: Well, he wouldn't be far off at that.
vi: That wouldn't be too far off.
tr: Well, he wasn't entirely wrong about that.
es: Well, he must not be very far off.

en: But depend on it, there's something in it for him.
vi: But think about it, he must gain something.
tr: But believe this, there is something in this relationship for him too.
es: But surely he gets some benefit from it.

en: Everyone's on the take, one way or another.
vi: Everyone is making a profit, one way or another.
tr: In one way or another, everyone has a price.
es: In some way, everyone looks out for themselves.

en: Extra cigarettes?
vi: An extra ration of cigarettes, perhaps?
tr: Is he buying extra cigarettes?
es: Any extra packs of cigarettes?

en: Extra freedoms, not allowed to the general run?
vi: Extra freedom, which is not meant for the ordinary folks?
tr: Extra freedoms that are not given to the majority?
es: Any freedom that is not normally granted?

en: Anyway, what can he prove?
vi: But anyway, what does he prove?
tr: Whatever, what can he prove?
es: Anyway, what can he prove?

en: It's his word against the Commander's, unless he wants to head a posse.
vi: It's just his word against the Commander's, unless he brings in the special forces.
tr: His word against the Commander's, unless he brings a police squad with him.
es: It's his word against the Commander's, unless he intends to show up with a group of people.

en: Kick in the door, and what did I tell you?
vi: Kicking the door open, didn't I tell you?
tr: Kick the door, here's what I told you?
es: A kick to the door, and what did I tell you?

en: Caught in the act, sinfully Scrabbling.
vi: Caught red-handed, playing the sinful Scrabble.
tr: They were caught red-handed, playing Scrabble sinfully.
es: Caught in the middle of a sinful game of Intelect.

en: Quick, eat those words.
vi: Hurry up, swallow all the letters.
tr: Quickly, eat those words.
es: Come on, swallow those words.

en: Maybe he just likes the satisfaction of knowing something secret.
vi: Maybe he was just delighted because he knew a secret.
tr: Maybe he just enjoys the satisfaction of knowing a secret.
es: Maybe it gives him satisfaction just to know something secret.

en: Of having something on me, as they used to say.
vi: He had something on me, as people often say.
tr: Having leverage against me, as they used to say.
es: Or to have some information about me, as they used to say.

en: It's the kind of power you can use only once.
vi: That kind of power can only be used once.
tr: This is the kind of power that can only be used once.
es: It's the kind of power that can only be used once.

en: I would like to think better of him.
vi: I really want to think better of him.
tr: I would like to think better of him.
es: I would like to have a better opinion of him.

en: That night, after I'd lost my job, Luke wanted to make love.
vi: That night, the night I lost my job, Luke wanted us to make love.
tr: That night, after I lost my job, Luke wanted to make love to me.
es: That night, after losing my job, Luke wanted us to make love.

en: Why didn't I want to?
vi: Why did I refuse?
tr: I wondered why I didn't want to?
es: Why didn't I want to do it?

en: Desperation alone should have driven me.
vi: If it were just despair, it would have driven me to do it.
tr: Despair alone should have ignited me.
es: It must have been desperation.

en: But I still felt numbed.
vi: But I felt paralyzed.
tr: But I still felt numb.
es: But I still felt paralyzed.

en: I could hardly even feel his hands on me.
vi: Almost didn't feel his hand on me.
tr: I could barely feel his hands on me.
es: I could barely feel his hands on my body.

en: What's the matter?
vi: How are you?
tr: What is the problem?
es: What's happening?

en: he said.
vi: he asked.
tr: he said.
es: he asked me.

en: I don't know, I said.
vi: I don't know, I said.
tr: I don't know, I said.
es: I don't know, I said.

en: We still have?he said.
vi: We still have... he said.
tr: "We still have something..." he said.
es: We still have...

en: But he didn't go on to say what we still had.
vi: But he didn't finish saying what we still have.
tr: But he didn't say what it was that we still had.
es: But he didn't say what it was that we still had.

en: It occurred to me that he shouldn't be saying we, since nothing that I knew of had been taken away from him.
vi: I suddenly thought that he shouldn't say "we," because as far as I could see, he hadn't lost anything at all.
tr: I thought he shouldn't say "we," because nothing I knew of had been taken from him.
es: It occurred to me that maybe he didn't mean we still have, since, as far as I knew, nothing had been taken from him.

en: We still have each other, I said.
vi: We still have each other, I said.
tr: We still have each other, I said.
es: We still have each other, I concluded.

en: It was true.
vi: And it's true.
tr: This was true.
es: And it was true.

en: Then why did I sound, even to myself, so indifferent?
vi: So why do my words still ring out, even in my own ears, so indifferent?
tr: So why did my voice sound so indifferent, even to myself?
es: So why did he seem, even to my eyes, so indifferent?

en: He kissed me then, as if now I'd said that, things could get back to normal.
vi: Then he kissed me, as if I had said that, everything would be normal again as before.
tr: And he kissed me, as if by saying this now, things could return to normal.
es: He kissed me, as if after I uttered that phrase, things could return to normal.

en: But something had shifted, some balance.
vi: But something had shifted, a balance had tipped.
tr: But something had changed, a balance.
es: But something had changed, the same balance no longer existed.

en: I felt shrunken, so that when he put his arms around me, gathering me up, I was small as a doll.
vi: I felt myself shrinking, and when he wrapped his arms around me, pulling me close, I was as small as a doll.
tr: I felt shrunken, so much so that when he wrapped his arms around me, I was as small as a baby.
es: I felt myself shrinking, so much so that when he wrapped his arms around me, I was as small as a doll.

en: I felt love going forward without me.
vi: I felt love passing by, I stood still.
tr: I felt that love was progressing without me.
es: I felt that love was leaving without me.

en: He doesn't mind this, I thought.
vi: He doesn't mind that, I think.
tr: He doesn't care, I thought.
es: He doesn't care, I thought.

en: He doesn't mind it at all.
vi: Not at all.

vi: Maybe night falls because it is heavy, a thick curtain pulled up to cover the eyes.
tr: Maybe darkness is falling because it is heavy, like a thick curtain drawn over the eyes.
es: Perhaps the night falls because it is heavy, a thick curtain drawn over the eyes.

en: Wool blanket.
vi: A woolen blanket.
tr: Like a cotton blanket.
es: A woolen mantle.

en: I wish I could see in the dark, better than I do.
vi: I wish I could see in the dark, better than I can now.
tr: I wish I could see in the dark, better than I do now.
es: I would like to see in the dark better than I do.

en: Night has fallen, then.
vi: Well, the night had just fallen.
tr: Let the darkness fall, then.
es: The night has fallen, then.

en: I feel it pressing down on me like a stone.
vi: I felt it pressing down on me like a boulder.
tr: I feel it weighing down on me like a stone.
es: I feel it crushing me, like a tombstone.

en: No breeze.
vi: There was no wind.
tr: No breeze.
es: Not a breeze is stirring.

en: I sit by the partly open window, curtains tucked back because there's no one out there, no need for modesty, in my nightgown, long-sleeved even in summer, to keep us from the temptations of our own flesh, to keep us from hugging ourselves, bare-armed.
vi: I sat by the half-open window, the curtain gathered because outside there was no one, no need for decorum, wearing a nightgown, long sleeves covering everything even in summer, protecting us from the temptation of our own flesh, preventing us from wrapping our bare arms tightly around ourselves.
tr: I am sitting by the half-open window, the curtains drawn back since there's no one outside, no need to feign modesty, wearing my nightgown, long-sleeved even in summer, to protect us from seducing our own bodies, from embracing ourselves with our bare arms.
es: I sit by the partially open window, with the curtains drawn back —because there is no one outside, and it is not necessary to act modestly—; I am wearing the nightgown that even in summer has long sleeves to keep us away from the temptations of our own flesh, to avoid caressing our bare arms.

en: Nothing moves in the searchlight moonlight.
vi: Nothing moved under the probing moonlight.
tr: Nothing moves in the spotlighted moonlight.
es: Everything remains still under the moonlight.

en: The scent from the garden rises like heat from a body, there must be night-blooming flowers, it's so strong.
vi: The scent of flowers in the garden rose like body heat, there must be night-blooming flowers, the smell was too strong.
tr: The scent from the garden rises like heat from a body, it must be the night-blooming flowers, so strong is this scent.
es: The scent of the garden rises like the heat emitted by a body, there must be flowers that open at night, that's why it is so strong.

en: I can almost see it, red radiation, wavering upwards like the shimmer above highway tarmac at noon.
vi: I could almost see it, radiating red in all directions, wavering and rising like the air over asphalt on a midday highway.
tr: I can almost see it, the red shimmer rising in waves like the quivering air over the asphalt of the main road at noon.
es: I can almost see it, a red radiation wavering upward like the shimmering glow of tar on the road at midday.

en: Down there on the lawn, someone emerges from the spill of darkness under the willow, steps across the light, his long shadow attached sharply to his heels.
vi: Below, on the grass, a figure emerged from the shadow under the willow tree, stepping into the light, the long shadow closely following their heels.
tr: Down in the grassy area, someone emerges from the fringed darkness of the willow and passes through the light, their long shadow clinging to their heels.
es: Down on the grass, someone emerges from beneath the cloak of darkness cast by the willow, and takes a few steps towards the light, with their long shadow stubbornly clinging to their heels.

en: Is it Nick, or is it someone else, someone of no importance?
vi: Was it Nick, or someone else, someone who didn't matter?
tr: Is this Nick, or someone else, someone insignificant?
es: Is it Nick, or is it someone else, someone unimportant?

en: He stops, looks up at this window, and I can see the white oblong of his face.
vi: The person stopped, looked up at this window, I saw a long, pale face.
tr: They stop and look up at this window, and I can see the white rectangle of their face.
es: He stops, looks at my window, I manage to see the white rectangle of his face.

en: Nick.
vi: Nick.
tr: Nick.
es: Nick.

en: We look at each other.
vi: We looked at each other.
tr: We look at each other.
es: We look at each other.

vi: We looked at each other.
tr: We look at each other.
es: I don't have a rose to throw to him, and he doesn't have a lute.

en: have no rose to toss, he has no lute.
vi: I had no roses to throw, he had no guitar.
tr: I have no smile to give, nor does he have his lute.
es: I don't have a rose to throw to him, and he doesn't have a lute.

en: But it's the same kind of hun-ger.
vi: But the hunger remained the same.
tr: Yet, it's the same hunger.
es: But it's the same kind of longing.

en: Which I can't indulge.
vi: I cannot tolerate it.
tr: I can't let myself succumb to this hunger.
es: Something I cannot allow.

en: I pull the left-hand curtain so that it falls between us, across my face, and after a moment he walks on, into the invisibility around the corner.
vi: I pulled the left curtain down between us, covering my face, and after a moment he continued walking, disappearing from sight around the corner of the house.
tr: I pull the curtain on the left, thus covering my face and stepping between us, and Nick continues walking immediately afterward, turning the corner into invisibility.
es: I pull the curtain on the left and it falls in front of my face, and a moment later he keeps walking and disappears around the corner of the house.

en: What the Commander said is true.
vi: The commander was right.
tr: The Commander is right.
es: What the Commander said is true.

en: One and one and one and one doesn't equal four.
vi: One with one with one with one is not four.
tr: One plus one plus one plus one does not equal four.
es: One plus one plus one plus one is not equal to four.

en: Each one remains unique, there is no way of joining them together.
vi: Each one is still unique, there is no way to merge them together.
tr: Each one remains alone, there is no way to combine them.
es: Each one remains unique, there is no way to unite them.

en: They cannot be exchanged, one for the other.
vi: They cannot be swapped, one replacing the other.
tr: One cannot be exchanged for the other.
es: They cannot be exchanged for one another.

en: They cannot replace each other.
vi: They cannot substitute for each other.
tr: They cannot take each other's place.
es: They cannot be replaced by one another.

en: Nick for Luke or Luke for Nick.
vi: Nick with Luke or Luke with Nick.
tr: Nick cannot take Luke's place, nor can Luke take Nick's place.
es: Nick for Luke, or Luke for Nick.

en: Should does not apply.
vi: It should not be used here.
tr: Necessity does not work here.
es: The conditional does not apply here.

en: You can't help what you feel, Moira once said, but you can help how you behave.
vi: You don't control your emotions, Moira once said, but you do control your actions.
tr: You cannot control your emotions, Moira once said, but you can adjust your behavior.
es: One cannot help feeling what one feels, Moira once said, but one can make amends for their actions.

en: Which is all very well.
vi: It sounds quite good.
tr: It's easy to say, of course.
es: Which is very good.

en: Context is all; or is it ripeness?
vi: It's all about the context - or is it ripe for the picking?
tr: Context is everything; or is it maturity?
es: Context is everything; or was it maturity?

en: One or the other.
vi: One of those two.
tr: One or the other.
es: One or the other.

en: The night before we left the house, that last time, I was walking through the rooms.
vi: The night before leaving home, for the last time, I walked through the rooms.
tr: The night before we left the house, I was wandering through the rooms for the last time.
es: The night before leaving our house for the last time, I was wandering through the rooms.

en: Nothing was packed up, because we weren't taking much with us and we couldn't afford even then to give the least appearance of leaving.
vi: I didn't pack anything, because we weren't taking much and even then we couldn't risk showing any sign that we were about to leave.
tr: Nothing was packed because we weren't taking much with us, and even then, we couldn't risk leaving the impression that we were leaving for good.
es: We didn't pack anything because we weren't going to take many things and even then we couldn't afford to give the slightest impression that we were leaving.

en: So I was just walking through, here and there, looking at things, at the arrangement we had made together, for our life.
vi: So I just walked, stopping here and there, glancing at things, the orderly scene we had arranged together, to live our whole lives.
tr: For this reason, I was just wandering around, here and there, glancing at the items and the arrangements we had made for our shared life.
es: So I was simply wandering back and forth, looking at the things, the order that we had created together in our life.

en: I had some idea that I would be able to remember, afterwards, what it had looked like.
vi: I vaguely thought that I might be able to remember, later on, how it used to look.
tr: I had the thought that I might be able to remember what it looked like later.
es: It occurred to me that later on I would be able to remember how they had been.

en: Luke was in the living room.
vi: Luke is in the living room.
tr: Luke was in the living room.
es: Luke was in the living room.

en: He put his arms around me.
vi: He wraps his arms around me.
tr: He wrapped his arms around me.
es: He took me in his arms.

en: We were both feeling miserable.
vi: We both feel sorrowful and pitiful.
tr: We both felt miserable.
es: We both felt miserable.

en: How were we to know we were happy, even then?
vi: How could we know we were happy, even then?
tr: How else would we know we were happy, even then?
es: How did we know we were happy, even then?

en: Because we at least had that: arms, around.
vi: Because at least we still had that: an embrace.
tr: Because at least we had this: the arms that embraced us.
es: Because at least we had that: our embraces.

en: The cat, is what he said.
vi: The cat, he said so.
tr: Cat; that's what he said.
es: The cat, that's what she said.

en: Cat?
vi: Cat?
tr: Cat; that's what he said.
es: The cat, that's what she said.

en: I said, against the wool of his sweater.
vi: I said, burying myself into his sweater.
tr: "A cat?" I said, towards the wool of her sweater.
es: "The cat?" I asked her, pressed against the wool of her sweater.

en: We can't just leave her here.
vi: I can't just leave it here.
tr: "We can't just leave it here like this."
es: We can't just leave her here.

en: I hadn't thought about the cat.
vi: I had not considered the cat.
tr: I hadn't thought about the cat.
es: I had not thought about the cat.

en: Neither of us had.
vi: Neither had he.
tr: Neither of us had thought about it.
es: Neither of us had thought.

en: Our decision had been sudden, and then there had been the planning to do.
vi: The decision came too suddenly, then we had to make a plan.
tr: Our decision had been sudden, and then planning had been done to carry it out.
es: We had made the decision suddenly, and then we had to plan things.

en: I must have thought she was coming with us.
vi: I probably thought it would come along.
tr: I must have thought the cat would come with us.
es: I must have thought that we would take her with us.

en: But she couldn't, you don't take a cat on a day trip across the border.
vi: But no, no one takes a cat along for a one-day picnic across the border.
tr: But it couldn't come; no one takes a cat along for a day trip across the border.
es: But we couldn't, you don't take the cat when you cross the border for a day, to go for a walk.

en: Why not outside?
vi: What about outside?
tr: Why don't we let it out?
es: Why don't we leave her outside?, I suggested.

en: I said.
vi: I said.
tr: I said.
es: Why don't we leave her outside?, I suggested.

en: We could just leave her.
vi: We could just leave it there.
tr: We can set it free.
es: We could abandon her.

en: She'd hang around and mew at the door.
vi: It will linger by the door and meow.
tr: It would wander around and meow at the door.
es: He would roam around the house and start meowing by the door.

en: Someone would notice we were gone.
vi: Someone will realize that I have gone missing.
tr: Someone would notice that we were gone.
es: Someone might notice that we have left.

en: We could give her away, I said.
vi: It could be given to someone's house.
tr: We can give it to someone, I said.
es: We could give it away, I suggested.

en: One of the neighbors.
vi: For example, the neighbor's house.
tr: To one of the neighbors.
es: To a neighbor.

en: Even as I said this, I saw how foolish that would be.
vi: As soon as I said it, I realized how stupid the idea was.
tr: As soon as I said this, I realized how foolish it would be.
es: As I said it, I realized it would have been a stupid idea.

en: I'll take care of it, Luke said.
vi: I'll take care of that, Luke said.
tr: "I'll take care of it," said Luke.
es: I'll take care of that, decided Luke.

en: And because he said it instead of her, I knew he meant kill.
vi: And because he said "that" and not "it," I knew he meant to kill it.
tr: I understood that by "it" he meant killing.
es: He said that instead of her, and I knew he meant killing her.

en: That is what you have to do before you kill, I thought.
vi: That's what you have to do before killing, I thought.
tr: This is what you have to do before killing, I thought.
es: That's what one has to do before killing, I thought.

en: You have to create an it, where none was before.
vi: First, you have to create a situation where there was nothing.
tr: You will create a "him" where there wasn't one before.
es: One has to create something where there was nothing before.

en: You do that first, in your head, and then you make it real.
vi: Act first in your mind, then carry it out in reality.
tr: You handle it first in your mind, and then you carry it out.
es: First, it's done mentally, and then in reality.

en: So that's how they do it, I thought.
vi: So that's how people do it, I thought.
tr: So, this is how they do it, I thought.
es: So that's how they do it, I thought.

en: I seemed never to have known that before.
vi: It seems I never knew that before.
tr: It felt like I had never known this before.
es: It seemed to me that I had never known that.

en: Luke foundthe cat, who was hiding under our bed.
vi: Luke found the cat, hiding under the bed.
tr: Luke had found the cat hiding under our bed.
es: Luke found the cat, which was hiding under the bed.

en: They always know.
vi: They always know.
tr: They always understand.
es: They always know it.

en: He went into the garage with her.
vi: He took it to the garage.
tr: He went to the garage with it.
es: He took her to the garage.

en: I don't know what he did and I never asked him.
vi: I don't know what he did, never asked.
tr: I don't know what he did and I never asked.
es: I don't know what he did, and I never asked him.

en: I sat in the living room, hands folded in my lap.
vi: I sat in the living room, hands in my lap.
tr: I sat in the living room with my hands in my lap.
es: I stayed seated in the living room, with my hands crossed on my lap.

en: I should have gone out with him, taken that small responsibility.
vi: I should have gone with him, taken that small responsibility.
tr: I should have gone outside with him, I should have shared this small responsibility.
es: I should have gone out with him, taken on that small responsibility.

en: I should at least have asked him about it afterwards, so he didn't have to carry it alone; because that little sacrifice, that snuffing out of love, was done for my sake as well.
vi: At the very least, I should have asked him about it later, so he wouldn't have to bear it alone; because that small sacrifice, that erasure of love, was also for me.
tr: At the very least, I should have asked him afterward, so he wouldn't have to bear this burden alone; because this small sacrifice, the extinguishing of a life for the sake of love, was also done for my sake.
es: At least I should have asked him afterward, so that he wouldn't have to bear the burden alone; because that small sacrifice, that annihilation of love, was also done for me.

en: That's one of the things they do.
vi: One of the things they do is that.
tr: Here, this is one of the things they do.
es: That is one of the things they do.

en: They force you to kill, within yourself.
vi: They make people kill, inside themselves.
tr: They force you to kill yourself, within.
es: They force you to kill inside yourself.

en: Useless, as it turned out.
vi: Also meaningless, as I see it.
tr: It was unnecessary, as it turned out later.
es: Uselessly, as it was demonstrated.

en: I wonder who told them.
vi: I don't know who reported it.
tr: I wonder who told them.
es: I wonder who informed them.

en: It could have been a neighbor, watching our car pull out from the driveway in the morning, acting on a hunch, tipping them off for a gold star on someone's list.
vi: It could have been a neighbor, seeing our car leaving the gate in the morning, intuitively prompted, whispering to them to go find a gold star on some list somewhere.
tr: It could have been a neighbor, watching our car leave the street in the morning, reporting with foresight to get into someone's good graces.
es: It could have been a neighbor who saw us leave in the car in the morning and had a hunch and dropped the information to add a gold star to someone's list.

en: It could even have been the man who got us the passports; why not get paid twice?
vi: It might even have been the person who got us the passport; why not take advantage twice?
tr: It could even have been the man who found our passports; why wouldn't he take money twice?
es: It could even have been the guy who got us the passports; why not get paid twice?

en: Like them, even, to plant the passport forgers themselves, a net for the unwary.
vi: Who knows, maybe they themselves arranged for the passport makers, setting a trap for the naive.
tr: It might even be their job to place those who make fake passports there; a network that catches the careless ones.
es: Even putting the passport forgers themselves, a trap for the unwary.

en: The Eyes of God run over all the earth.
vi: The eye of God roams the entire world.
tr: The Eyes of God reach every corner of the earth.
es: The Eyes of God roam the earth in all its extent.

en: Because they were ready for us, and waiting.
vi: Because they had anticipated our arrival, waiting for us.
tr: Because they were already waiting for us.
es: Because they were prepared to catch us, and waiting for us.

en: The moment of betrayal is the worst, the moment when you know beyond any doubt that you've been betrayed: that some other human being has wished you that much evil.
vi: The moment of betrayal is the worst, the moment when one is absolutely certain that they have been betrayed: that another person has wished so much harm upon them.
tr: The moment of betrayal is the worst, the moment you realize without a doubt that you have been betrayed: that another person has wished so much harm upon you.
es: The moment of betrayal is the worst, the moment when one knows, beyond any doubt, that one has been betrayed: that another human being has wished so many misfortunes upon them.

en: It was like being in an elevator cut loose at the top.
vi: Like in an elevator room with a broken chain anchor above.
tr: It was like being in an elevator whose cable was cut from the top.
es: It was like being in an elevator whose cables have been cut.

en: Falling, falling, and not knowing when you will hit.
vi: Falling, falling endlessly, not knowing when it will hit the ground.
tr: Falling, falling, and not knowing when it would crash.
es: Falling and falling without knowing when it will crash.

en: I try to conjure, to raise my own spirits, from wherever they are.
vi: I tried to call out, to summon the spirits of my own, wherever they might be.
tr: Wherever they are, I try to revive and summon my own ghosts.
es: I try to conjure, to evoke my own spirits, wherever they are.

en: I need to remember what they look like.
vi: I needed to remember what they looked like.
tr: I need to remember what they look like.
es: I need to remember what they looked like.

en: I try to hold them still behind my eyes, their faces, like pictures in an album.
vi: I tried my best to fix them behind my eyelids, their faces, like photos in an album.
tr: I try to keep them still behind my eyes, their faces, like photographs in an album.
es: I try to keep them still behind my eyes, their faces like the photos in an album.

en: But they won't stay still for me, they move, there's a smile and it's gone, their features curl and bendas if the paper's burning, blackness eats them.
vi: But they wouldn't stay still, they kept stretching out, a smile appearing and then vanishing, the lines curving and folding like burning photo paper, swallowed by shadows.
tr: But they won't stay still for me, they move, there's a smile and it's gone, their lines curling and bending like burning paper, darkness swallows them.
es: But they refuse to stay still, they move, a smile and it immediately disappears, their features curve and fold like burning paper, the blackness devours them.

en: A glimpse, a pale shimmer on the air; a glow, aurora, dance of electrons, then a face again, faces.
vi: A flash passed by, a flicker in the air; glowing, radiating, electrons dancing, then back to faces, many faces.
tr: A momentary image, a faint glow in the air; a glimmer, colored lights, the dance of electrons, then again a face, faces.
es: A momentary vision, a pale glow in the air; blush, dawn, dance of electrons, another face, faces.

en: But they fade, though I stretch out my arms towards them, they slip away from me, ghosts at daybreak.
vi: But they faded again, even though I reached out, they slipped away from me, dawn phantoms.
tr: Yet they vanish, despite my reaching out to them, they slip away from me, ghosts of dawn.
es: But they fade away, and although I stretch my arms towards them, they slip away like ghosts at dawn, returning to the place from which they came.

en: Backto wherever they are.
vi: Returning to their usual abode.
tr: Back to where they belong.
es: But they fade away, and although I stretch my arms towards them, they slip away like ghosts at dawn, returning to the place from which they came.

en: Stay with me, I want to say.
vi: Stay, I wanted to say.
tr: Stay with me, I want to say.
es: Stay with me, I feel like saying.

en: But they won't.
vi: But they didn't listen.
tr: But they won't stay.
es: But they don't hear me.

en: It's my fault.
vi: It's my fault.
tr: It's my fault.
es: It's my fault.

en: I am forgetting too much.
vi: I'm forgetting too much.
tr: I forget too much.
es: I'm forgetting too many things.

en: Tonight I will say my prayers.
vi: Tonight I will pray.
tr: I will pray tonight.
es: Tonight I will say my prayers.

en: No longer kneeling at the foot of the bed, knees on the hard wood of the gym floor, Aunt Elizabeth standing by the double doors, arms folded, cattle prod hung on her belt, while Aunt Lydia strides along the rows of kneeling nightgowned women, hitting our backs or feet or bums or arms lightly, just a flick, a tap, with her wooden pointer if we slouch or slacken.
vi: No longer kneeling at the foot of the bed, knees placed on the hard wooden floor of the gymnasium, Aunt Elizabeth stood on the door, arms crossed, a cattle prod hanging at her hip, while Aunt Lydia strode along the rows of women kneeling in nightgowns, lightly whipping our backs, legs, buttocks, or hands, tapping, lightly striking, with a pointer, if we were distracted or sluggish.
tr: Kneeling at the foot of the bed on the hard wooden floor of the gym, Aunt Lydia would hunch our backs or, if we relaxed, she would lightly tap our backs, feet, buttocks, or arms with the wooden prod - just a flick, a touch - as she walked among the rows of kneeling women in nightgowns, while Aunt Elizabeth stood by the double doors, arms crossed, the prod hanging from her belt, no longer.
es: I no longer kneel at the foot of the bed, on the hard wooden floor of the gymnasium, while Aunt Elizabeth stands by the double doors, arms crossed and the cattle prod hanging from her belt, and Aunt Lydia paces along the rows of kneeling women dressed in nightgowns, lightly hitting our backs or feet or buttocks or arms, just a touch, a tap with the wooden pointer if we slackened or relaxed.

en: She wanted our heads bowed just right, our toes together and pointed, our elbows at the proper angle.
vi: Aunt wanted our heads bowed precisely, our toes neatly together, our elbows at the correct angle.
tr: Aunt Lydia wanted us to bow our heads properly, keep our feet together and flat, and our elbows at the right angle.
es: She wanted us to have our heads perfectly bowed, the tips of our feet together, and our elbows forming the correct angle.

en: Part of her interest in this was aesthetic: she liked the look of the thing.
vi: Part of that interest had an aesthetic reason: Aunt liked the appearance of things.
tr: The reason she was so insistent was her passion for aesthetics: She liked this image.
es: Partly, her interest was aesthetic: she liked the appearance of the thing.

en: She wanted us to look like something Anglo-Saxon, carved on a tomb; or Christmas cardangels, regimented in our robes of purity.
vi: Aunt wanted us to look like Anglo-Saxon relics, carved on tombstones, or angels on Christmas cards, straight and stiff in pure white gowns.
tr: She wanted us to look like something carved on an Anglo-Saxon tombstone; or like Christmas card angels, lined up in our garments of chastity.
es: She wanted us to look like something Anglo-Saxon, carved on a tomb; or angels from a Christmas postcard, uniformed in our robes of purity.

en: But she knew too the spiritual value of bodily rigidity, of muscle strain: a little pain cleans out the mind, she'd say.
vi: But Aunt also understood the spiritual value of a rigid body, of muscle tension: physical pain would cleanse the mind, she said.
tr: But she also knew the spiritual value of physical rigidity, of muscle tension: A little pain clears the mind, she would say.
es: But she also knew the value of bodily rigidity, the tautness of muscle: pain clarifies the mind, she said.

en: What we prayed for was emptiness, so we would be worthy to be filled: with grace, with love, with self-denial, semen and babies.
vi: We pray to be empty, worthy to be filled: grace, love, chastity, semen, and babies.
tr: Our prayers were for the void, so that we would be worthy of being filled: With grace, love, sacrifice, sperm, and babies.
es: We prayed for emptiness, to make ourselves worthy of being filled: with grace, with love, with selflessness, with semen and children.

en: Oh God, King of the universe, thank you for not creating me a man.
vi: Oh Lord, king of the entire universe, thank you for not creating me as a man.
tr: Oh God, King of the Universe, thank you for not creating me as a man.
es: Oh God, King of the universe, thank you for not having made me a man.

en: Oh God, obliterate me.
vi: Oh Lord, please rid me.
tr: Oh God, purify me.
es: Oh God, destroy me.

en: Make me fruitful.
vi: Allow me to flourish.
tr: Make me fruitful.
es: Make me fertile.

en: Mortify my flesh, that I may be multiplied.
vi: Torment my body, so that I may thrive.
tr: Dull my desires so that I may flourish.
es: Mortify my flesh so that I may multiply.

en: Let me be fulfilled
vi: Let me be filled...
tr: Make me content...
es: Allow me to fulfill myself...

en: Some of them would get carried away with this.
vi: There are many who will be overly excited.
tr: Some would lose themselves in these.
es: Some became exalted with the prayers.

en: The ecstasy of abasement.
vi: Intoxicated in humiliation.
tr: The ecstasy of humiliation.
es: It was the ecstasy of degradation.

en: Some of them would moan and cry.
vi: There are many who will moan and cry.
tr: Some would moan and cry.
es: Some moaned and cried.

en: There is no point in making a spectacle of yourself, Janine, said Aunt
vi: Making a fool of yourself won't do any good, Janine, Aunt Lydia said.
tr: There's no point in making a fool of yourself, Janine, Aunt Lydia used to say.
es: There is no need for you to put on a show, Janine, said Aunt Lydia.

en: Lydia.
vi: Making a fool of yourself won't do any good, Janine, Aunt Lydia said.
tr: There's no point in making a fool of yourself, Janine, Aunt Lydia used to say.
es: There is no need for you to put on a show, Janine, said Aunt Lydia.

en: I pray where I am, sitting by the window, looking out through the curtain at the empty garden.
vi: I sit still and pray, by the window, looking through the curtain at the deserted garden.
tr: I pray where I am, sitting at the window, looking at the empty garden through the curtain.
es: Now I pray sitting by the window, looking at the garden through the curtain.

en: I don't even close my eyes.
vi: I don't even bother to close my eyes.
tr: I don't even close my eyes.
es: I don't even close my eyes.

en: Out there or inside my head, it's an equal darkness.
vi: Out there or in my head, it's equally dark.
tr: There, outside or inside my head, there is the same darkness.
es: Out there, or inside my head, the same darkness reigns.

en: Or light.
vi: Or equally bright.
tr: Or light.
es: Or the light.

en: My God. Who Art in the Kingdom of.
vi: My Lord.
tr: My God.
es: My God, You who are in the Kingdom of Heaven, which is within.

en: Heaven, which is within.
vi: Currently reigning in the Kingdom of Heaven, which means residing within me.
tr: You who are inside, who are in the Kingdom of Heaven.
es: My God, You who are in the Kingdom of Heaven, which is within.

en: I wish you would tell me Your Name, the real one I mean.
vi: I wish you would tell me your Name, I mean your real name.
tr: I wish you would tell me your name, your real name, I mean.
es: I would like you to tell me Your Name, I mean the real one.

en: But You will do as well as anything.
vi: But it's okay if you don't, it's not a big deal.
tr: But only You can see this. I would like to know what your purpose is.
es: Although You will also do.

en: I wish I knew what You were up to.
vi: I wish I knew what He foresaw.
tr: I would like to know what your purpose is.
es: I would like to know that You are up there.

en: But whatever it is, help me to get through it, please.
vi: But whatever it is, please help me get through it, I beg you.
tr: But no matter what happens, please help me endure this.
es: But wherever You are, help me get through this, please.

en: Though maybe it's not Your doing; I don't believe for an instant that what's going on out there is what You meant.
vi: Even though it may not be His doing; not for a moment do I believe that what is happening out there is His will.
tr: Even if it's not your job; I don't believe for a moment that what's happening out there is something you want.
es: Although maybe it's not Your task; I don't remotely believe that what is happening here is what You wanted.

en: I have enough daily bread, so I won't waste time on that.
vi: I have enough bread for daily consumption, so I won't waste time on that.
tr: I have enough daily sustenance, so I will not spend time on that.
es: I have enough bread every day, so I won't waste time on that.

en: It isn't the main problem.
vi: That's not the main issue; the issue is how to swallow it without choking.
tr: The main problem is not this.
es: It's not the main problem.

en: The problem is getting it down without choking on it.
vi: That's not the main issue; the issue is how to swallow it without choking.
tr: The problem is being able to swallow it without choking.
es: The problem is swallowing it without choking.

en: Now we come to forgiveness.
vi: Now comes the lesson of forgiveness.
tr: Now it's time for forgiveness.
es: Now comes forgiveness.

en: Don't worry about forgiving me right now.
vi: No need to worry about forgiving me at this moment.
tr: Don't bother trying to forgive me now.
es: Don't bother forgiving me right now.

en: There are more important things.
vi: There are more important matters.
tr: There are more important things.
es: There are more important things.

en: For instance: keep the others safe, if they are safe.
vi: For example: keeping the remaining people safe, if they are currently safe.
tr: For example: protect the others, if they are safe.
es: For example: keep others safe, if they are safe.

en: Don't let them suffer too much.
vi: Don't let them suffer too much.
tr: Don't let them suffer too much.
es: Don't let them suffer too much.

en: If they have to die, let it be fast.
vi: If they must die, make it quick.
tr: If they have to die, let their deaths be quick.
es: If they have to die, make sure it's quick.

en: You might even provide a Heaven for them.
vi: Someone who can grant them a Heaven is fine, we must rely on Him for that.
tr: You can even provide a heaven for them.
es: You can even make a Heaven for them.

en: We need You for that.
vi: As for Hell, we are capable of creating it for ourselves.
tr: We need You for that.
es: For that, we need You.

en: Hell we can make for ourselves.
vi: As for Hell, we are capable of creating it for ourselves.
tr: We can create hell on our own.
es: We can make Hell ourselves.

en: I suppose I should say I forgive whoever did this, and whatever they're doing now.
vi: I guess I should say I forgive everyone who caused that, as well as everything they are doing.
tr: I suppose I need to say that I forgive whoever did this and whatever they are doing right now.
es: I suppose I should say that I forgive whoever has done this, whoever they may be, and what they are doing now, whatever it may be.

en: I'll try, but it isn't easy.
vi: I will try, but it's really not easy.
tr: I will try, but it won't be easy.
es: I will try, although it is not easy.

en: Temptation comes next.
vi: Next is the lesson on temptation.
tr: It's time for seduction.
es: Then comes the temptation.

en: At the Center, temptation was anything much more than eating and sleeping.
vi: At the Center, temptation is anything beyond eating and sleeping.
tr: In the Center, seduction went far beyond eating and sleeping.
es: In the Center, temptation meant much more than eating or sleeping.

en: Knowing was a temptation.
vi: Knowing is already a temptation.
tr: To know was to be seduced.
es: In the Center, temptation meant much more than eating or sleeping.

en: What you don't know won't tempt you, Aunt Lydia used to say.
vi: What you don't know won't tempt you, Aunt Lydia often said.
tr: What you don't know can't seduce you, Aunt Lydia used to say.
es: That which you do not know will not tempt you, Aunt Lydia used to say.

en: Maybe I don't really want to know what's going on.
vi: Maybe I don't really want to know what's happening.
tr: Maybe I don't truly want to know what's going on.
es: Maybe I don't really want to know what's happening.

en: Maybe I'd rather not know.
vi: Maybe I'd rather not know.
tr: Maybe I prefer not knowing.
es: Maybe it will be better if I don't know.

en: Maybe I couldn't bear to know.
vi: Maybe I don't have the strength to know.
tr: Maybe I prefer not knowing.
es: Maybe I couldn't bear to know.

en: The Fall was a fall from innocence to knowledge.
vi: The Fall of Man, is a fall from ignorance to knowledge.
tr: Maybe I couldn't bear to know; the Fall of Man was a fall from innocence to knowledge.
es: The Fall was a fall from innocence to knowledge.

en: I think about the chandelier too much, though it's gone now.
vi: I think too much about the chandelier, even though it's gone.
tr: Even though it's no longer there, I think about the chandelier a lot.
es: I think a lot about the spider, although it is no longer there now.

en: But you could use a hook, in the closet.
vi: But I can still use the hook, in the wardrobe.
tr: But a hook in the bathroom can be used.
es: But I could use a hanger from the closet.

en: I've considered the possibilities.
vi: I've considered every possibility.
tr: I examined the possibilities.
es: I have analyzed the possibilities.

en: All you'd have to do, after attaching yourself, would be to lean your weight forward and not fight.
vi: All that needs to be done, after tying myself up, is to lean forward and not struggle.
tr: All that needs to be done is, after attaching yourself to the hook, to shift your weight forward and not struggle.
es: All that would need to be done after tying oneself would be to lean the weight forward and not offer resistance.

en: Deliver us from evil.
vi: Save us from evil.
tr: Deliver us from evil.
es: Deliver us from evil.

en: Then there's Kingdom, power, and glory.
vi: Then there will be the Kingdom of Heaven, power, and glory.
tr: Then next in line are the Kingdom, power, and glory.
es: Then there exists a Kingdom, power, and glory.

en: It takes a lot to believe in
vi: It takes a lot of effort to believe in those things right now.
tr: Right now, it's very hard to believe in these.
es: It is difficult to believe in that now.

en: those right now.
vi: It takes a lot of effort to believe in those things right now.
tr: Right now, it's very hard to believe in these.
es: It is difficult to believe in that now.

en: But I'll try it anyway.
vi: But I will try.
tr: But still, I will try.
es: But I will try anyway.

en: In Hope, as they say on the gravestones.
vi: Hope, like on the tombstones.
tr: With hope, as they say on the tombstones.
es: With hope, as it said on the tombstone.

en: You must feel pretty ripped off.
vi: You must feel exploited.
tr: You must be feeling like you've been robbed.
es: You must feel quite torn.

en: I guess it's not the first time.
vi: I bet it's not the first time.
tr: I guess this isn't the first time.
es: I suppose it's not the first time.

en: If I were You I'd be fed up.
vi: If I were you, I would be sick of it.
tr: If I were you, I would be exhausted.
es: If I were you, I would be fed up.

en: I'd really be sick of it.
vi: I would be fed up.
tr: I would be truly fed up with this.
es: I would really get sick.

en: I guess that's the difference between us.
vi: I think that's where we differ.
tr: I guess that's the difference between us.
es: I suppose that is the difference between us.

en: I feel very unreal, talking to You like this.
vi: I feel so vague, talking to You like this.
tr: I feel very unreal when talking to you like this.
es: I feel unreal talking to you this way.

en: I feel as if I'm talking to a wall.
vi: I feel like I'm talking to a wall.
tr: As if I'm talking to a wall.
es: I feel the same as if I were talking to a wall.

en: I wish You'd answer.
vi: I wish You would respond.
tr: I wish you had responded.
es: I wish you would answer me.

en: I feel so alone.
vi: I feel so lonely.
tr: I feel so lonely.
es: I feel so alone.

en: All alone by the telephone.
vi: Alone by the phone.
tr: All alone next to the phone.
es: Completely alone next to the phone.

en: Except I can't use the telephone.
vi: But now I can't use the phone.
tr: But I can't use the phone.
es: Except that I don't have a phone.

en: And if I
vi: And even if I could, who would I call?
tr: Even if I could use it, who could I call?
es: And if I had one, who could I call?

en: could, who could I call?
vi: And even if I could, who would I call?
tr: Even if I could use it, who could I call?
es: And if I had one, who could I call?

en: Oh God.
vi: Oh God. I'm not calling in jest.
tr: Oh my God.
es: Oh God.

en: It's no joke.
vi: Oh God. I'm not calling in jest.
tr: This is not a joke.
es: This is no joke.

en: Oh God oh God.
vi: Oh God, oh God.
tr: Oh my God, Oh my God.
es: Oh God oh God.

en: How can I keep on living?
vi: How do I continue living?
tr: How can I continue living?
es: How can I keep living?

en: XII
vi: XII - Jezebel's Palace
tr: XII
es: XII

en: Jezebels
vi: XII - Jezebel's Palace
tr: Jezebel's Place
es: JEZEBEL'S

vi: XII - Jezebel's Palace
tr: Jezebel's Place
es: JEZEBEL'S
CHAPTER 31

en: Every night when I go to bed I think,
vi: Every night when I lie down in bed, I think, Tomorrow morning I will wake up in my own home and everything will be back to the way it was before.
tr: Every night when I go to bed, I think that I will wake up in my own home in the morning and everything will return to the way it was.
es: Every night, when I go to sleep, I think: Tomorrow morning I will wake up in my own house and things will be as they were.

en: In the morning I will wake up in my own house and things will be back the way they were.
vi: Every night when I lie down in bed, I think, Tomorrow morning I will wake up in my own home and everything will be back to the way it was before.
tr: Every night when I go to bed, I think that I will wake up in my own home in the morning and everything will return to the way it was.
es: Every night, when I go to sleep, I think: Tomorrow morning I will wake up in my own house and things will be as they were.

en: It hasn't happened this morning, either.
vi: This morning neither.
tr: This morning, it didn't happen again.
es: This morning it hasn't happened either.

en: I put on my clothes, summer clothes, it's still summer; it seems to have stopped at summer.
vi: I put on my clothes, summer clothes - it's still summer, time seems to have stopped in summer.
tr: I am putting on my clothes, my summer clothes, it is still summer, as if the season has stopped in summer.
es: I dress in my summer clothes, we are still in summer; it's as if time has stopped in the summer.

en: July, its breathless days and sauna nights, hard to sleep.
vi: July, the stifling days and sweltering nights, it's hard to sleep.
tr: July, breathless days and nights as hot as a bath, it's hard to sleep.
es: July: during the day you can't breathe and at night it feels like you're in a sauna, it's hard to sleep.

en: I make a point of keeping track.
vi: I pay attention to counting time.
tr: I am careful not to lose my connection with time.
es: I impose upon myself the obligation not to lose track of time.

en: I should scratch marks on the wall, one for each day of the week, and run a line through them when I have seven.
vi: I mark on the wall, one mark per day, adding a cross line when seven days are complete.
tr: I should have made notches on the wall, one for each day of the week, and when I reached seven, a diagonal line over them.
es: I should mark lines on the wall, one for each day of the week, and cross them out with a line when I reach seven.

en: But whatwould be the use, this isn't a jail sentence; there's no time here that can be done and finished with.
vi: But for what purpose, this is not a prison sentence; there is no deadline to pass and settle.
tr: But what good would that do, this is not a prison sentence; there is no set period to be spent here and then finished.
es: But what sense would that make, this isn't a prison sentence; it's not something that ends after a certain amount of time.

en: Anyway, all I have to do is ask, to find out what day it is.
vi: Anyway, I just need to open my mouth and ask to know what day it is today.
tr: Still, all I have to do is ask, to find out what day it is.
es: Anyway, what I have to do is ask, find out what day it is.

en: Yesterday was July the fourth, which used to be Independence Day, before they abolished it.
vi: Yesterday was the fourth of July, once Independence Day, before it was abolished.
tr: Yesterday was July 4th, it used to be Independence Day, before they canceled it.
es: Yesterday was July 4th, which used to be Independence Day, before they abolished it.

en: September first will be Labor Day, they still have that.
vi: Somewhere in May will be Mother's Day, that still remains.
tr: September 1st will be Birth Day18, they celebrate that.
es: September 1st will be Mother's Day, which is still celebrated.

en: Though it didn't used to have anything to do with mothers.
vi: Though before, it wasn't just confined to childbirth.
tr: Even though it didn't used to be about mothers.
es: Although before it had nothing to do with procreation.

en: But I tell time by the moon.
vi: But I count the days according to the moon.
tr: However, I understand the time by looking at the moon.
es: But I know the time by the moon.

en: Lunar, not solar.
vi: Lunar calendar, not solar calendar.
tr: I use the lunar year, not the solar year.
es: Lunar time, not solar.

en: I bend over to do up my red shoes; lighter weight these days, with discreet slits cut in them, though nothing so daring as sandals.
vi: I bent down to put on the red shoes; now lighter, with cautious grooves, though not as daring as sandals.
tr: I bend forward to put on my red shoes; these days they are made lighter, with unobtrusive cuts on them, though they are not as daring as sandals.
es: I bend down to tie my shoes; these days they are lighter, with discreet openings, although not as daring as sandals.

en: It's an effort to stoop; despite the exercises, I can feel my body gradually
vi: Bending over is a real effort: even though I still exercise, I can feel my body gradually going on strike, resisting.
tr: Bending over requires effort; despite the exercises, I can feel my body getting heavier and resisting.
es: Bending down takes effort; despite the exercises, I feel my body gradually stiffening and becoming useless.

en: seizing up, refusing.
vi: Bending over is a real effort: even though I still exercise, I can feel my body gradually going on strike, resisting.
tr: Bending over requires effort; despite the exercises, I can feel my body getting heavier and resisting.
es: Bending down takes effort; despite the exercises, I feel my body gradually stiffening and becoming useless.

en: Being a woman this way is how 1 used to imagine it would be to be very old.
vi: That's exactly how I imagine women when they get old, very old.
tr: Being such a woman is the same as my old idea of what it would be like to be very old.
es: This is how I used to imagine life would be when I got old.

en: I feel I even walk like that: crouched over, my spine constricting to a question mark, my bones leached of calcium and porous as limestone.
vi: I also feel that I walk the same way: my back hunched, my spine curved into a question mark, my bones losing calcium, becoming porous like limestone.
tr: I even feel like I'm walking that way: Bent forward, my spine turned into a question mark, calcium drained and flowed from my bones, and they are porous like limestone.
es: I feel like I even walk like an old woman: hunched over, with my spine bent like a question mark, my bones weakened by lack of calcium and porous like limestone.

en: When I was younger, imagining age, I would think, Maybe you appreciate things more when you don't have much time left.
vi: When I was young, imagining old age, I thought, Maybe you'll learn to appreciate more when you don't have much time left.
tr: When I was young and in the age of dreaming, I used to think that maybe when one has little time left, they understand the value of everything better.
es: When I was young and imagined old age, I thought: Maybe one appreciates things more when they have little time left to live.

en: I forgot to include the loss of energy.
vi: I forgot to account for the decline in strength.
tr: I forgot to account for the loss of energy.
es: But I forgot to include the loss of energy.

en: Some days I do appreciate things more, eggs, flowers, but then I decide I'm only having an attack of sentimentality, my brain going pastel Technicolor, like the beautiful-sunset greeting cards they used to make so many of in California.
vi: There are days when I do appreciate more, eggs, and flowers, but then I laugh at myself for just being sentimental, my mind coated in a dull four-color hue, like those "beautiful sunset" postcards that used to be everywhere in California.
tr: Some days I value certain things, like eggs, flowers, more, but then I decide that I have just been hit by a wave of sentimentality, and my mind turns into pastel Technicolor, like those countless beautiful sunset greeting cards they used to make in California.
es: Sometimes I appreciate things more: the eggs, the flowers, but then I decide that it's just a bout of sentimentality, and that my brain turns into a technicolor movie with pastel tones, like the sunset postcards that used to be abundant in California.

en: High-gloss hearts.
vi: Glossy hearts.
tr: Overly bright hearts.
es: Hearts of tinsel.

en: The danger is gray out.
vi: Gray threat looming.
tr: The danger lies in losing sight.
es: Danger is gray.

en: I'd like to have Luke here, in this bedroom while I'm getting dressed, so I could have a fight with him.
vi: If only Luke were here, in the room while I was dressing, so I could argue with him.
tr: I wish Luke were here, in this bedroom, while I was getting dressed, so I could argue with him.
es: I would like Luke to be here, in this room while I get dressed, and have a fight with him.

en: Absurd, but that's what I want.
vi: It sounds strange, but that's what I want.
tr: It's silly, but that's what I want.
es: It seems absurd, but that's what I want.

en: An argument, about who should put the dishes in the dishwasher, whose turn it is to sort the laundry, clean the toilet; something daily and unimportant in the big scheme of things.
vi: To bicker about who loads the dishes into the dishwasher, whose turn it is to sort the laundry, to scrub the toilet; trivial daily details amidst the grand movements of the universe.
tr: An argument about who will load the dishwasher, whose turn it is to fold the laundry and clean the toilet; usually something mundane and trivial given the course of events.
es: An argument about who puts the dishes in the dishwasher, whose turn it is to sort the dirty laundry, scrub the sink; something everyday and insignificant about the scheduling of things.
