en: We could even have a fight about that, about unimportant, important.
vi: We even used to argue about those things, whether they were trivial or significant.
tr: We could even argue about whether it was important or trivial.
es: We could even argue about that, the important and the insignificant.

en: What a luxury it would be.
vi: Now it feels like such a luxury.
tr: What a great luxury that would be.
es: It would be a real pleasure.

en: Not that we did it much.
vi: Though it wasn't that frequent.
tr: Not that we argued a lot.
es: It's not that we did it very often.

en: These days I script whole fights, in my head, and the reconciliations afterwards too.
vi: These days, I sketch out each chapter of our arguments in my head, including the subsequent reconciliation scene.
tr: These days, I script big fights in my mind, and the subsequent make-ups too.
es: In recent times, I mentally draft the entire argument, and also the subsequent reconciliation.

en: I sit in my chair, the wreath on the ceiling floating above my head, like a frozen halo, a zero.
vi: I sit in the chair, the garland on the ceiling floating high above, a frozen halo, a zero.
tr: I am sitting in my chair, the wreath on the ceiling floats above my head, frozen like a halo, like a zero.
es: I sit in the chair; the crown of the ceiling floats above my head like a frozen halo, like a zero.

en: A hole in space where a star exploded.
vi: A hole in the universe where a star just exploded.
tr: A hole opened where a star exploded in space.
es: A hole in space, where a star exploded.

en: A ring, on water, where a stone's been thrown.
vi: Ripples on the water's surface, the stone just thrown in.
tr: A ring formed where a stone was thrown into the water.
es: A circle in the water, where a stone has fallen.

en: All things white and circular.
vi: All things round and white.
tr: Everything is white and circular.
es: All white and circular things.

en: I wait for the day to unroll, for the earth to turn, according to the round face of the implacable clock.
vi: I wait for the day to unfold, wait for the earth to turn, following the round face of the clock, with a jellyfish heart.
tr: I am waiting for the day to unfold, for the world to turn, according to the round face of the relentless clock.
es: I hope the day unfolds, that the earth turns according to the round face of the relentless clock.

en: The geometrical days, which go around and around, smoothly and oiled.
vi: Geometric days, circling around and around, smooth as if greased.
tr: Smooth and oiled, the geometric days keep turning.
es: Geometric days that turn over and over again, smoothly lubricated.

en: Sweat already on my upper lip, I wait, for the arrival of the inevitable egg, which will be lukewarm like the room and will have a green film on the yolk and will taste faintly of sulphur.
vi: Sweat beads on my lips, I wait, wait for the arrival of the inevitable egg, which will be lukewarm like the room and have a green film on the yolk with a hint of sulfur.
tr: Sweat has already accumulated on my upper lip, as warm as the room's temperature, and a green layer has formed on the yellow, and I am waiting for the inevitable arrival of the egg that will give a slight taste of sulfur.
es: My upper lip drenched in sweat, I await the arrival of the inevitable egg, which will be warm like the room and will have a yolk covered by a green film and will have a horrible sulfur taste.

en: Today, later, with Ofglen, on our shopping walk:
vi: Still today, later, with Ofglen, the usual shopping hour:
tr: Today, later, we are on a shopping walk with Gleninki.
es: Today, later, with Deglen, during our walk to do the shopping:

en: We go to the church, as usual, and look at the graves.
vi: We went to the church, as usual, to look at some graves.
tr: As usual, we go to the church and look at the graves.
es: We go to the church, as usual, and look at the tombstones.

en: Then to the
vi: Then to the Wall.
tr: Then to the Wall.
es: Then we visit the Wall.

en: Wall.
vi: Then to the Wall.
tr: Then to the Wall.
es: Then we visit the Wall.

en: Only two hanging on it today: one Catholic, not a priest though,
vi: Today there were only two people: a Catholic believer, though not a priest, wearing a large inverted cross around his neck, and the other from a denomination I couldn't recognize.
tr: Today there are only two hanged: one is Catholic, but not a priest, labeled with an upside-down cross, the other from a denomination I can't identify.
es: Today there are only two hanged: a Catholic —who is not a priest—, with a cross placed upside down, and another from a sect I do not recognize.

en: placarded with an upside-down cross, and some other sect I don't recognize.
vi: Today there were only two people: a Catholic believer, though not a priest, wearing a large inverted cross around his neck, and the other from a denomination I couldn't recognize.
tr: Today there are only two hanged: one is Catholic, but not a priest, labeled with an upside-down cross, the other from a denomination I can't identify.
es: Today there are only two hanged: a Catholic —who is not a priest—, with a cross placed upside down, and another from a sect I do not recognize.

en: The body is marked only with a J, in red.
vi: The body was only marked with the letter J, in red.
tr: The body is marked only with a red J19.
es: The body is marked only with a red J.

en: It doesn't mean Jewish, those would be yellow stars.
vi: Not Jewish, that would be a yellow star.
tr: Not Jewish, theirs is a yellow star.
es: It does not mean Jew: in that case, they would put yellow stars.

en: Anyway there haven't been many of them.
vi: But anyway, there aren't many Jews left.
tr: Though, there weren't many of them left.
es: Anyway, there had not been many Jews.

en: Becausethey were declared Sons of Jacob and therefore special, they were given a choice.
vi: They have been declared the Descendants of Jacob, they are special, they have the right to choose.
tr: Because they were declared as the sons of Jacob and thus were special, they were given a choice.
es: Since they were declared Sons of Jacob, and therefore something special, they were given an alternative.

en: They could convert, or emigrate to Israel.
vi: They can convert or emigrate to Israel.
tr: They could convert or migrate to Israel.
es: They could convert or emigrate to Israel.

en: A lot of them emigrated, if you can believe the news.
vi: Most have emigrated, if the news can be believed.
tr: Many migrated, if you can believe the news.
es: Most of them emigrated, if you can believe the news.

en: I saw a boatload of them, on the TV, leaning over the railings in their blackcoats and hats and their long beards, trying to look as Jewish as possible, in costumes fished up from the past, the women with shawls over their heads, smiling and waving, a little stiffly it's true, as if they were posing; and another shot, of the richer ones, lining up for the planes.
vi: I saw a ship full of people, on TV, leaning over the side of the ship, dressed in black, black hats and long beards, trying to look as Jewish as possible, in outfits dug out from ancient times, women with their heads wrapped in scarves, smiling and waving, though a bit stiffly, as if showing off; another scene, the wealthier ones, lining up to board a plane.
tr: I saw a shipload of them, on television, leaning over the railings in their black coats and hats and long beards, trying to look as Jewish as possible; in costumes hunted from the past, smiling and waving women with shawls on their heads. True, it seemed a bit forced, as if they were posing; then another shot, the wealthier ones lining up to board planes.
es: I saw them on television, boarding a freighter, leaning on the railings, dressed in their coats and black hats and long beards, trying to look as Jewish as possible, with clothes rescued from the past, the women with their heads covered by shawls, smiling and waving, a bit stiff, as if they were posing. And another image: that of the richest, lining up to catch the plane.

en: Ofglen says some other people got out that way, by pretending to be Jewish, but it wasn't easy because of the tests they gave you and they've tightened up on that now.
vi: Ofglen said some managed to escape that way, pretending to be Jewish, but it wasn't easy because there were many rounds of scrutiny and now the process has tightened up.
tr: Glen's says others also pretended to be Jewish to get out this way, but because of the tests they applied, it wasn't easy, and now they've made it even harder.
es: Deglen says that many people escaped that way, pretending to be Jews; but that it was not easy, because of the tests they were subjected to, and because now they had become stricter.

en: You don't get hanged only for being a Jew though.
vi: However, people are not hanged just for being Jewish.
tr: Still, you are not hanged merely for being Jewish.
es: Anyway, they don't hang anyone just for being Jewish.

en: You get hanged for being a noisy Jew who won't make the choice.
vi: People are hanged for being talkative Jews who refuse to make choices.
tr: You are hanged for being a Jew who makes the wrong choice and causes trouble, or for pretending to have converted.
es: They hang the one who is a noisy Jew, who hasn't made their choice, or who has pretended to convert.

en: Or for pretending to convert.
vi: Or pretend to convert.
tr: You are hanged for being a Jew who makes the wrong choice and causes trouble, or for pretending to have converted.
es: They hang the one who is a noisy Jew, who hasn't made their choice, or who has pretended to convert.

en: That's been on the TV too: raids at night, secret hoards of Jewish things dragged out from under beds, torahs, tal-liths, Magen Davids.
vi: The TV shows everything: midnight raids, Jewish items stored under the bed being dug out, scriptures, prayer shawls, Star of David.
tr: This was also shown on television: night raids, hidden Jewish stocks pulled out from under beds, Torahs, prayer shawls, Stars of David.
es: They've also shown that on television: nighttime raids, secret treasures of Jewish objects taken from under the beds, Torahs, tallits, Stars of David.

en: And the owners of them, sullen faced, unrepentant, pushed by the Eyes against the walls of their bedrooms, while the sorrowful voice of the announcer tells us voice-over about their perfidy and ungratefulness.
vi: Along with the owners, faces swollen, stubborn, being pushed against the bedroom wall by the Eyes, while a sorrowful voiceover recounts their betrayal and ingratitude to us.
tr: And as the announcer's sorrowful voice narrated their betrayals and ingratitude to us, the stern-faced incorrigible owners were plastered on the bedroom walls by the Eyes.
es: And the owners of these things, taciturn, unrepentant, pushed by the Eyes against the walls of their rooms while the somber voice of the announcer speaks to us off-screen about the perfidy and ingratitude of those people.

en: So the J isn't for Jew.
vi: So J is not a descendant of Jacob.
tr: Therefore, J does not mean Jewish.
es: So, the J doesn't mean Jewish.

en: What could it be?
vi: Then what is he?
tr: What could it be?
es: What could it mean?

en: Jehovah's Witness?
vi: A Jehovah's Witness?
tr: Jehovah's Witnesses?
es: Jehovah's Witness?

en: Jesuit?
vi: A Jesuit?
tr: Jesuit?
es: Jesuit?

en: Whatever it meant, he's just as dead.
vi: Whatever he is, he can't die any more than he already has.
tr: Whatever it means, it's just plain dead.
es: Whatever he was, this one is dead.

en: After this ritual viewing we continue on our way, heading as usual for some open space we can cross, so we can talk.
vi: After this ritual of gazing, we continued on, as usual, looking for a spacious place to talk to each other.
tr: After this ceremonial viewing, we continue on our way, as always, towards an open area where we can talk.
es: After this ritual visit, we continued on our way, as usual looking for some open space where we could talk.

en: If you can call it talking, these clipped whispers, projected through the funnels of our white wings.
vi: If it could even be called talking, those snippets of whispered fragments, uttered through the funnel of white wings.
tr: If it can be called talking, of course, these clipped Utterances coming from the channel of our white wings.
es: If you can call conversation these broken whispers, projected through the funnel of our white headdresses.

en: It's more like a telegram, a verbal semaphore.
vi: More accurately, it was like a piece of telegram, semaphore by mouth.
tr: It resembles more of a telegraph, a verbal semaphore.
es: It resembles more a telegram, a verbal semaphore.

en: Amputated speech.
vi: Crippled words.
tr: A pruned conversation.
es: An amputated dialogue.

en: We can never stand long in any one place.
vi: We cannot stand in one place for too long.
tr: We never stay in one place for very long.
es: We can never stay in one place for too long.

en: We don't want to be picked up for loitering.
vi: We don't want to be caught for loitering.
tr: We don't want to get caught for wandering aimlessly.
es: We don't want to get caught for loitering.

en: Today we turn in the opposite direction from Soul Scrolls, to where there's an open park of sorts, with a large old building on it; ornate late Victorian, with stained glass.
vi: Today we took the path opposite Quyển hồn, to a place that seemed like a public garden, in the middle of a very large, old building; late Victorian, meticulously decorated, stained glass.
tr: Today we are turning in the exact opposite direction of the Prayer Cylinders, where there is an open park with a large, old building adorned with stained glass in late Victorian style.
es: Today we turn in the opposite direction of Spiritual Scrolls, towards where there is a kind of open park with an old and enormous building, in late Victorian style with colored glass.

en: It used to be called Memorial Hall, though I never knew what it was a memorial for.
vi: In the past, this was called the Memorial House, though I never knew what it commemorated.
tr: It used to be called Memorial Hall, but I never knew what it was a memorial for.
es: It used to be called Memorial Hall, although I never knew in memory of what.

en: Dead people of some kind.
vi: Some people were stuck there.
tr: For dead people.
es: Of those who died for something.

en: Moira told me once that it used to be where the undergraduates ale, in the earlier days of the university.
vi: Moira said that in the past, university students often ate here, back when the school first opened.
tr: Moira once said that this place was used as the students' cafeteria during the early years of the university.
es: Moira once told me that it was the place where the students ate, in the early days of the university.

en: If a woman went in there, they'd throw buns at her, she said.
vi: If a woman walked in, she would get bread thrown at her, she said.
tr: She said that if a woman entered, they would throw bread at her.
es: If a woman entered, she told me, they would throw buns at her.

en: Why?
vi: For what?
tr: Why?
es: Why?, I asked her.

en: I said.
vi: I said.
tr: I had asked.
es: Why?, I asked her.

en: Moira became, over the years, increasingly versed in such anecdotes.
vi: Moira, over the years, has become increasingly adept at these kinds of anecdotes.
tr: Moira, over the years, was becoming increasingly adept at these kinds of stories.
es: Over time, Moira became increasingly well-versed in anecdotes of this kind.

en: I didn't much like it, this grudge-holding against the past.
vi: I don't really like that kind of past resentment.
tr: I didn't quite like this, harboring such resentment towards the past.
es: I wasn't very enthusiastic about this resentment towards the past.

en: To make her go out, said Moira.
vi: To drive her away, she replied.
tr: To get the woman out, Moira had said.
es: To make her come out, replied Moira.

en: Maybe it was more like throwing peanuts at elephants, I said.
vi: It might be like throwing peanuts to an elephant, I said.
tr: Maybe it was more like throwing peanuts at elephants, I had said.
es: It was more like throwing peanuts to the elephants, I commented.

en: Moira laughed; she could always do that.
vi: Moira laughed; she could always laugh.
tr: Moira had laughed; she could laugh at any moment.
es: Moira burst into laughter; she could always do it.

en: Exotic monsters, she said.
vi: Monsters from afar, she said.
tr: Exotic monsters, she had said.
es: Exotic monsters, she said.

en: We stand looking at this building, which is in shape more or less like a church, a cathedral.
vi: We stood looking at the building for a while, noting its shape was almost like a church, a grand cathedral.
tr: We are standing and looking at this building, which more or less resembles a church, a cathedral in form.
es: We stood staring at this building, whose shape is more or less like that of a church, a cathedral.

en: Ofglen says, "I hear that's where the Eyes hold their banquets."
vi: Ofglen said, "I heard the Eyes have parties here."
tr: Gleninki says, "I heard that this is where the Eyes of Here hold their feasts."
es: Deglen says: —I heard that this is where the Eyes organize their banquets.

en: "Who told you?" I say.
vi: "Who said that?" I asked.
tr: “Who told you this?” I say.
es: —Who told you that? —I ask him.

en: There's no one near, we can speak more freely, but out of habit we keep our voices low.
vi: There was no one around, so we spoke more freely, but out of habit, we still lowered our voices.
tr: There is no one nearby, we can talk more freely, but out of habit, we speak in low voices.
es: There is no one nearby, we can speak more freely, but we do so in a low voice, out of habit.

en: "The grapevine," she says.
vi: “The network,” she said.
tr: “A walking news gazette,” he says.
es: —A means of communication —he replies.

en: She pauses, looks sideways at me, I can sense the blur of white as her wings move.
vi: She paused, glanced sideways, I felt the white streak quiver as the wings fluttered.
tr: He pauses, looks at me from the side, I can perceive the whiteness as the wings move.
es: He pauses, glances at me sideways, I feel a white flash as he moves his cap—.

en: "There's a password," she says.
vi: “There is a password,” she said.
tr: “There is a password,” he says.
es: There is a password —he adds.

en: "A password?" I ask.
vi: "Password?" I asked.
tr: “A password?” I ask.
es: —A password?

en: "What for?"
vi: "For what?"
tr: “For what?”
es: For what?

en: "So you can tell," she says.
vi: "To find out," she said.
tr: "To understand who is with us and who is not," he says.
es: —To know —he explains to me—.

en: "Who is and who isn't."
vi: "Who's in, who's out."
tr: "To understand who is with us and who is not," he says.
es: Who is and who is not.

en: Although I can't see what use it is for me to know, I ask, "What is it then?"
vi: Even though I didn't see clearly if it would be beneficial for me, I still asked, "So what is it?"
tr: Even though I don't understand how knowing this will be useful to me, I ask: "What is it?""
es: Although I don't understand what the point is for me to know it, I ask her: —Which one is it?

en: "Mayday," she says.
vi: “Mayday,” she said.
tr: “Mayday,” he says.
es: —Mayday —he says—.

en: "I tried it on you once."
vi: “I already tried with you once.”
tr: “I tried it on you once.”
es: I tried it with you once.

en: "Mayday," I repeat.
vi: “Mayday,” I repeated.
tr: “Mayday,” I repeat.
es: —Mayday —I repeat—.

en: I remember that day.
vi: I still remember that day.
tr: I remember that day.
es: I remember the day.

en: M'aidez.
vi: M’aidez.
tr: M'aidez.
es: M’aidez.

en: "Don't use it unless you have to," says Ofglen.
vi: "Don't use it unless absolutely necessary," Ofglen said.
tr: "Don't use it unless you have to," says Gleninki.
es: —Don't use it unless it's necessary —Deglen warns me—.

en: "It isn't good for us to know about too many of the others, in the network.
vi: "We shouldn't know each other too well, among the roots.
tr: "It's not good for us to know too many people from the others, that is, those in the network.
es: It's not convenient for us to know too much about the others who form the network.

en: In case you get caught."
vi: In case we get caught."
tr: In case we get caught."
es: In case we get caught.

en: I find it hard to believe in these whisperings, these revelations, though I always do at the time.
vi: I find it hard to believe those whispers, those revelations, even though at the time I believed them.
tr: These whispers, these explanations are hard for me to believe, though I always believe them at the moment.
es: I find it hard to believe in these rumors, in these revelations, although at the same time I believe it.

en: Afterwards, though, they seem improbable, childish even, like something you'd do for fun; like a girls' club, like secrets at school.
vi: But upon returning, they seem unreal, childish even, like a joke for fun; like a group of schoolgirls, with little secrets from high school days.
tr: But later they seem impossible, even childish, like something done for fun; just like a girls' club, like secrets at school.
es: Then they seem improbable to me, even childish, like something one would do for fun; like a girls' club, like secrets in school.

en: Or like the spy novels I used to read, on weekends, when I should have been finishing my homework, or like late-night television.
vi: Or like the spy novels I used to read, every weekend, when I should have been finishing my homework, or late-night TV dramas.
tr: Or like the spy novels I used to read on weekends when I should have been finishing my homework, or the TV shows I watched late at night.
es: Or like the spy novels I used to read on weekends, when I should have been finishing my homework, or like watching TV late at night.

en: Passwords, things that cannot be told, people with secret identities, dark linkages: this does not seem as if it ought to be the true shape of the world.
vi: Passwords, forbidden topics, double lives, secret communications: none of it seems worthy of being the true nature of the real world.
tr: Passwords, things that can't be explained, people with secret identities and dark connections: This doesn't seem like the real shape of the world.
es: Passwords, things that couldn't be told, people with secret identities, shady connections: it doesn't seem like this should be the true nature of the world.

en: But that is my own illusion, a hangover from a version of reality I learned in the former time.
vi: But this is just my own illusion, remnants from a reality that had once been ingrained in me.
tr: But this is my own illusion, something left over from the interpretation of reality I learned in the past.
es: But it is my own illusion, the remnants of a version of reality that I knew in other times.

en: And networks.
vi: And then there are the roots.
tr: And networks.
es: And the networks.

en: Networking, one of my mother's old phrases, musty slang of yesteryear.
vi: Root stringing, another one of mother's favorite terms, a moldy expression from years past.
tr: Networking, one of my mother's old expressions, the outdated slang of last year.
es: Network work, one of my mother's old phrases, an outdated jargon, out of fashion.

en: Even in her sixties she still did something she called that, though as far as I could see all it meant was having lunch with some other woman.
vi: Even at sixty, mother still did what she called root stringing, though to me it seemed like the whole activity was just having lunch with another old lady.
tr: Even at sixty, she still did things she called that, although to me it just meant having lunch with another woman.
es: Even at sixty years old, she did something she called that, although from what I could see, it meant nothing more than having lunch with another woman.

en: I leave Ofglen at the corner.
vi: Ofglen and I parted ways at the corner.
tr: I leave Gleninki at the corner.
es: I say goodbye to Deglen at the corner.

en: "I'll see you later," she says.
vi: "See you later," she said.
tr: “See you later,” he says.
es: —See you soon —he greets me.

en: She glides away along the sidewalk and I go up the walk towards the house.
vi: She glided away on the sidewalk, and I took the path back home.
tr: He slowly walks away on the sidewalk, and I start walking up the road towards home.
es: He walks away on the sidewalk and I go up the path, towards the house.

en: There's Nick, hat askew; today he doesn't even look at me.
vi: There was Nick, his hat askew; today he didn't even bother to look at me.
tr: There’s Nick, his hat askew; he’s not even looking at me today.
es: I see Nick, who is wearing his cap tilted; today he doesn't even look at me.

en: He must have been waiting around for me though, to deliver his silenl message, because as soon as he knows I've seen him he gives the Whirlwind one last swipe with the chamois and walks briskly off towards the garage door.
vi: But he must have lingered, waiting for me, to deliver that silent message, because as soon as he was sure I had seen him, he gave the car one last wipe and then strode towards the garage door.
tr: Still, he must have waited for me to convey his silent message, because as soon as he realizes I’ve seen him, he gives Whirlwind one last wipe with the chamois in his hand and quickly heads towards the garage door.
es: Anyway, he must have been waiting for me to deliver his silent message, because as soon as he realizes that I have seen him, he gives the Whirlwind a final touch with the chamois and briskly walks towards the garage door.

en: I walk along the gravel, between the slabs of ovcrgreen lawn.
vi: I walk on the gravel path, between two excessively green patches of grass.
tr: I'm walking on the gravel path that divides the overly green lawn.
es: I walk along the gravel path, between the grass beds.

en: Serena
vi: Serena
tr: Serena
es: Serena

en: Joy is sitting under the willow tree, in her chair, cane propped at her elbow.
vi: Joy is sitting by the willow tree, on a chair, with her cane resting on her elbow.
tr: Joy is sitting in her chair under the willow tree, her cane hanging from her elbow.
es: Joy is sitting under the willow tree, in her chair, with the cane resting beside her.

en: Her dress is crisp cool cotton.
vi: She is wearing a cool cotton dress.
tr: Her dress is made of cool cotton.
es: She is wearing a cool cotton dress.

en: For her it's blue, wa-tercolor, not this red of mine that sucks in heat and blazes with it at the same time.
vi: Hers is blue, the color of the sea, not the red of my dress, drenched with heat yet simultaneously burning.
tr: Blue, water-colored, not like mine which absorbs heat and is also burning red.
es: The color that corresponds to her is blue, a watercolor shade, not the red that I wear, which absorbs the heat and at the same time burns with it.

en: Her profile's towards me, she's knitting.
vi: I can only see half of her face; she is knitting.
tr: I see her from the side, she is knitting.
es: She is sitting in profile to me, knitting.

en: How can she bear to touch the wool, in this heat?
vi: How can she touch the wool in this heat?
tr: How can she bear to touch the wool in this heat?
es: How can she stand touching the wool in this heat?

en: But possibly her skin's gone numb; possibly she feels nothing, like one formerly scalded.
vi: But perhaps her skin has become numb; perhaps it feels nothing, like a healed scald from boiling water.
tr: But maybe her skin has become insensitive; maybe she feels nothing, like someone who was scalded with boiling water in the past.
es: Maybe her skin has become insensitive, maybe she doesn't feel anything, as if it has been scalded.

en: I lower my eyes to the path, glide by her, hoping to be invisible, knowing I'll be ignored.
vi: I kept my eyes down on the gravel road, gliding past her, hoping to be invisible, knowing I would be ignored.
tr: I lower my gaze to the path, hoping to be invisible, knowing I will be ignored, I slip past.
es: I lower my gaze to the path and walk past her, hoping to be invisible, knowing that she will ignore me.

en: But not this time.
vi: But this time was different.
tr: But this time it doesn't work.
es: But not this time.

en: "Offred," she says.
vi: "Offred," she said.
tr: “Fredinki,” he says.
es: —Offred —he calls me.

en: I pause, uncertain.
vi: I stopped, hesitating.
tr: I am standing, undecided.
es: I stop, uncertain.

en: "Yes, you."
vi: “It’s you.”
tr: “Yes, you.””
es: —Yes, you.

en: I turn towards her my blinkered sight.
vi: I lift my eyes covered by a patch.
tr: I turn my veiled gaze towards him.
es: I turn my fragmented gaze towards her through the veil.

en: "Come over here.
vi: "Come this way." "I need you.""
tr: "Come here.
es: "Come here." "I need you."

en: I want you."
vi: "Come this way." "I need you.""
tr: I want you."
es: "Come here." "I need you."

en: I walk over the grass and stand before her, looking down.
vi: I stepped across the grass to stand in front of her, eyes downcast.
tr: I walk past the lawn and stand in front of it, looking down.
es: I walk across the grass and stop in front of her with my eyes downcast.

en: "You can sit," she says.
vi: “You can sit,” she said.
tr: “You can sit,” he says.
es: —You can sit down —she tells me—.

en: "Here, take the cushion.
vi: “Here, take the pillow.
tr: “Here, take this pillow.
es: Here, on the cushion.

en: I need you to hold this wool."
vi: I need you to hold the yarn.”
tr: I need you to hold the wool.”
es: I need you to hold the yarn for me —she has a cigarette; the ashtray is next to her, on the grass, and she also has a cup of something, tea or coffee—.

en: She's got a cigarette, the ashtray's on the lawn beside her, and a cup of something, tea or coffee.
vi: She was holding a cigarette, flicking ash onto the grass, next to a cup of something, not sure if it was coffee or tea.
tr: He has a cigarette, an ashtray beside him on the grass, and a cup of tea or coffee.
es: I need you to hold the yarn for me —she has a cigarette; the ashtray is next to her, on the grass, and she also has a cup of something, tea or coffee—.

en: "It's too damn close in there.
vi: “It's suffocating in there.
tr: “It’s damn stuffy in there.
es: That room is devilishly closed.

en: You need a little air," she says.
vi: You need some fresh air,” she said.
tr: You need some air,” he says.
es: You need a bit of air —she comments.

en: I sit, putting down my basket, strawberries again, chicken again, and I note the swear word: something new.
vi: I sat down, basket placed on the grass, with strawberries and chicken, noting the curse: a new addition.
tr: I sit down, placing my basket on the ground, which again contains strawberries, again chicken, and I notice the cursing: something new.
es: I sit down, put down the basket (strawberries again, chicken again) and take note of the swear word: something new.

en: She fits the skein of wool over my two outstretched hands, starts winding.
vi: She looped the yarn around my outstretched hands, starting to wind it.
tr: He places the skein of wool on my outstretched arms and starts winding it.
es: She adjusts the skein around my two outstretched hands and starts to wind.

en: I am leashed, it looks like, manacled; cobwebbed, that's closer.
vi: I felt tied up, seemingly chained; caught in a spider web, more accurately.
tr: Apparently, I’m collared, handcuffed; caught in a spider’s web, that’s more accurate.
es: It seems as if I were tied up, handcuffed; rather, covered in cobwebs.

en: The wool is gray and has absorbed moisture from the air, it's like a wetted baby blanket and smells faintly of damp sheep.
vi: The gray yarn was damp from the humidity, like a child's wet blanket, faintly smelling of wet sheep.
tr: The wool is gray and has absorbed the moisture in the air, like a peed-on baby blanket, and it smells faintly of wet sheep.
es: The yarn is gray and has absorbed the moisture from the environment, it's like a baby's wet sheet and smells terribly of wet lamb.

en: At least my hands will get lanolined.
vi: At least my hands were coated with lanolin.
tr: At least my hands will get lanolined.
es: At least my hands will be coated with lanolin.

en: Serena winds, the cigarette held in the corner of her mouth smoldering, sending out tempting smoke.
vi: Serena rolled the yarn, a cigarette at the corner of her mouth smoldering, exhaling waves of temptation.
tr: Serena is winding the wool, while the cigarette at the corner of her mouth sends out a tempting smoke as it burns slowly.
es: Serena keeps winding; she holds the lit cigarette to the side of her mouth, puffing on it and blowing out tempting clouds of smoke.

en: She winds slowly and with difficulty because of her gradually crippling hands, but with determination.
vi: She rolled very slowly and with difficulty because her hands were starting to become impaired, but she was full of determination.
tr: Due to her gradually paralyzing hands, she winds it slowly and with difficulty, but with determination.
es: She winds the yarn slowly and with difficulty —due to the progressive paralysis of her hands— but with determination.

en: Perhaps the knitting, for her, involves a kind of willpower; maybe it even hurts.
vi: Perhaps knitting, for her, also required mustering up willpower, who knows, it might even be painful.
tr: Knitting, for her, perhaps means testing her willpower in some way; it might even be causing her pain.
es: Perhaps for her, knitting represents a kind of exercise of will; perhaps it even causes her pain.

en: Maybe it's been medically prescribed: ten rows a day of plain, ten of purl.
vi: Who knows if the doctor prescribed it: ten rows of knitting up, ten rows of knitting down each day.
tr: Maybe it was recommended for health reasons: ten rows of knit, ten rows of purl per day.
es: Maybe she does it by medical prescription: ten rows of knit and ten of purl daily.

en: Though she must do more than that.
vi: Though surely not just ten.
tr: However, she must be doing more than that.
es: Although she must do more than that.

en: I see those evergreen trees and geometric boys and girlsin a different light: evidence of her stubbornness, and not altogether despicable.
vi: The evergreen trees and the boys and girls, squares and triangles before me took on a different meaning: evidence of her stubbornness, and not entirely detestable.
tr: I see those ever-green trees and geometric boys and girls from a different perspective: proof of her utterly undeniable stubbornness.
es: I see those evergreen trees and the geometric boys and girls from another perspective: as a testament to her stubbornness, as something not entirely despicable.

en: My mother did not knit or anything like that.
vi: My mother never did anything like weaving or knitting.
tr: My mother did not knit or do similar things.
es: My mother didn't knit, or do anything like that.

en: But whenever she would bring things back from the cleaner's, her good blouses, winter coats, she'd save up the safety pins and make them into a chain.
vi: But whenever she brought back the laundry, expensive shirts, winter coats, she would keep the safety pins and string them together.
tr: However, whenever she picked something up from the cleaner, such as precious blouses or winter coats, she would collect the safety pins and make a chain out of them.

en: Radishes made into flowers, roses or tulips, bob in it.
vi: Carved radishes, shaped like roses or tulips, float inside it.
tr: Radishes, transformed into flowers, roses or tulips, are also bobbing up and down in it.
es: Inside, radishes turned into flowers, roses, or tulips are floating.

en: On the chopping board in front of her she's cutting more, with a paring knife, her large hands deft, indifferent.
vi: She is cutting more on the cutting board, using a carving knife, her large hands moving swiftly and indifferently.
tr: She continues to cut on the board in front of her, with a paring knife, her large hands adept and indifferent to the task.
es: She is cutting some more on the cutting board with a paring knife, and her hands appear skillful but indifferent.

en: The rest of her body does not move, nor does her face.
vi: Her whole body is still, and so is her face.
tr: The rest of her body is not moving, nor is her face.
es: The rest of her body is motionless, just like her face.

en: It's as if she's doing it in her sleep, this knife trick.
vi: It's as if she is performing this trick while half-asleep.
tr: It's as if she's doing this knife trick in her sleep.
es: It's as if she were doing it in her sleep.

en: On the white enamel surface is a pile of radishes, washed but uncut.
vi: On the white enamel table is a pile of radishes, washed but not yet sliced.
tr: On the white enamel surface, there is a pile of washed but uncut radishes.
es: On the white enamel surface, there is a pile of washed but uncut radishes.

en: Little Aztec hearts.
vi: Tiny Aztec hearts.
tr: Little Aztec hearts.
es: Like Aztec hearts.

en: She hardly bothers to look up as I enter.
vi: She didn't bother to look up at me.
tr: When I enter, he doesn't bother to lift his head and look.
es: When I enter, he barely bothers to look up.

en: "You got it all, huh," is what she says, as I take the parcels out for her inspection.
vi: "You got everything, huh," she said just that, as she checked each package I took out.
tr: "You got everything, huh," he says, while taking out the packages to inspect them.
es: —You must have brought everything, I suppose —she says while I take out the packages for her to examine.

en: "Could I have a match?" I ask her.
vi: "Can I have a match?" I asked her.
tr: "Can I have a match?" I ask.
es: —Can you give me a match? —I ask him.

en: Surprising how much like a small, begging child she makes me feel, simply by her scowl, her stolidity; how importunate and whiny.
vi: It was strange to see how she made me feel small and demanding, just by frowning, just by being indifferent; I felt myself pleading and whining.
tr: It's surprising how just a frown, with its indifference, makes me feel like a little beggar child; a persistent and whining child.
es: It's surprising, but his unperturbed expression and furrowed brow make me feel like a small, begging creature, annoying and whiny.

en: "Matches?" she says.
vi: “Matches?” she said.
tr: “A match?” he says.
es: —Matches? —he asks—.

en: "What do you want matches for?"
vi: “What do you need matches for?”
tr: “What are you going to do with a match?”
es: What do you need matches for?

en: "She said I could have one," I say, not wanting to admit to the cigarette.
vi: "She told me to give her a stick," I said, not wanting to admit about the cigar.
tr: “He said I could take one,” I say, not wanting to reveal that I took a cigarette.
es: —She said she could take one —I respond, without admitting that it's for the cigarette.

en: "Who said?"
vi: “Who said that?”
tr: “Who is that?”
es: —Who said that?

en: She continues with the radishes, her rhythm unbroken.
vi: She continued cutting the radish, her rhythm unchanged.
tr: She continues peeling the turnips, without breaking her rhythm.
es: —she continues slicing radishes, without breaking the rhythm—.

en: "No call for you to have matches.
vi: “You don't need matches for anything.
tr: “You have no right to buy matches.
es: There is no reason for you to have matches.

en: Burn the house down."
vi: Going to burn the house down or what.”
tr: You will burn the house down.”
es: You could burn the house down.

en: "You can go and ask her if you like," I say.
vi: "You can go ask her if needed," I said.
tr: "If you want, you can go and ask him," I say.
es: —If you want, you can ask him —I suggest—.

en: "She's out on the lawn."
vi: "She is still out on the lawn."
tr: "Outside on the lawn."
es: He is in the garden.

en: Rita rolls her eyes to the ceiling, as if consulting silently some deity there.
vi: Rita rolled her eyes at the ceiling, as if silently praying to some deity up there.
tr: Rita raises her eyes to the ceiling, as if silently consulting a god up there.
es: She rolls her eyes and looks at the ceiling, as if silently consulting some deity.

en: Then she sighs, rises heavily, and wipes her hands with ostentation on her apron, to show me how much trouble I am.
vi: Then she sighed, heavily stood up, and noisily wiped her hands on her apron, showing how much I was bothering her.
tr: Then she sighs and slowly gets up, wiping her hands on her apron in a showy manner, aiming to demonstrate what a big problem I am.
es: Then she sighs, gets up heavily, and wipes her hands on the apron with ostentatious movements, to show me how annoying I am.

en: She goes to the cupboard over the sink, taking her time, locates her key bunch in her pocket, unlocks the cupboard door.
vi: She went to the cupboard above the sink, moving sluggishly, rummaged for the bunch of keys in her pocket, and opened the cupboard door.
tr: Without hurrying, she walks towards the cabinet above the sink, reaches into her pocket for the key ring, and opens the cabinet door.
es: She slowly approaches the cupboard above the sink, searches for the bunch of keys in her pocket, and opens the door.

en: "Keep 'em in here, summer," she says as if to herself.
vi: “Put it in here, during the summer,” she seemed to be talking to herself.
tr: “I keep them here, in the summer,” she says as if to herself.
es: —In summer we store them here —she says, as if talking to herself—.

en: "No call for a fire in this weather."
vi: “No need to light a fire in this heat.”
tr: “There's no point in inviting a fire in this kind of weather.”
es: With this weather, there's no need to light the fire —I remember that in April, when the weather is colder, Cora lights the fires in the living room and the dining room.

en: I remember from April that it's Cora who lights the fires, in the sitting room and the dining room, in cooler weather.
vi: I still remember back in April when Cora was busy lighting the fireplace, both in the living room and the kitchen, when it was colder.
tr: As far as I remember from April, it is Cora who lights the fires in the sitting and dining rooms during cool weather.
es: With this weather, there's no need to light the fire —I remember that in April, when the weather is colder, Cora lights the fires in the living room and the dining room.

en: The matches are wooden ones, in a cardboard sliding-top box, the kind I used to covet in order to make dolls' drawers out of them.
vi: Wooden matches, in a sliding lid cardboard box, the kind I used to longingly want to steal to make a wardrobe for my dolls.
tr: The matches are in a wooden box with a sliding lid, the kind I used to envy for making baby drawers.
es: The matches are made of wood and come in a cardboard box with a sliding lid, like the ones I used to keep and turn into drawers for the dolls.

en: She opens the box, peers into it, as if deciding which one she'll let me have.
vi: She opened the lid, peered inside, as if considering which stick was worthy of giving to me.
tr: He opens the box, looks inside, as if thinking about which one he will allow me to take.
es: Rita opens the box and inspects it, as if deciding which one she will let me take.

en: "Her own business," she mutters.
vi: “Her own business,” she muttered.
tr: “That's his problem,” he mutters.
es: —It's her business —he grumbles—.

en: "No way you can tell her a
vi: “Don't even think about telling her anything.”
tr: “There's no way to explain anything to him.”
es: —It's her business —he grumbles—.

en: thing."
vi: “Don't even think about telling her anything.”
tr: “There's no way to explain anything to him.”
es: —It's her business —he grumbles—.

en: She plunges her big hand down, selects a match, hands it over to me.
vi: She plunged her large hand in, picked one out, and handed it to me.
tr: He plunges his big hand inside, selects a match, and gives it to me.
es: There's no point in telling her anything —he puts his enormous hand in the box, picks out a match, and hands it to me—.

en: "Now don't you go setting fire to nothing," she says.
vi: “Now don't go around burning anything,” she said.
tr: “Now, don't even think about setting something on fire,” he says.
es: Now don't set anything on fire —he warns me—.

en: "Not them curtains in your room.
vi: “Especially the curtains in the room.
tr: “Be careful with the curtains in your room.
es: Not even the curtains in your room.

en: Too hot the way it is."
vi: The room is hot enough already.”
tr: The weather is already hot enough.”
es: It's already too hot as it is.

en: "I won't," I say.
vi: "No," I said.
tr: “I will not burn it,” I say.
es: —I won't do it —I reassure her—.

en: "That's not what it's for."
vi: "I will do something else."
tr: “I am not taking this for that reason.”
es: It's not for that.

en: She does not deign to ask me what it is for.
vi: She did not bother to ask what the matter was.
tr: He doesn't bother to ask what it's for.
es: He doesn't even bother to ask me what it's for.

en: "Don't care if you eat it, or what," she says.
vi: "Even if you chew it, it doesn't matter," she said.
tr: "Whether you eat it or do something else with it, I don't care," he says.
es: —I don't care if you eat it, or do something else —he states—.

en: "She said you could have one, so I give you one, is all."
vi: "She told me to give you one, so I gave you one, that's all."
tr: "He said you could have one, so I'm giving you one, that's all."
es: She said you could have one, so I'm giving it to you, that's all.

en: She turns away from me and sits again at the table.
vi: She turned away and sat back at the table.
tr: He moves away from me and sits back at the table.
es: She moves away from me and sits back down at the table.

en: Then she picks an ice cube out of the bowl and pops it into her mouth.
vi: Then she picked up a stone and popped it into her mouth.
tr: Then the captain takes a piece of ice and puts it in his mouth.
es: Then she takes an ice cube from the bowl and puts it in her mouth.

en: This is an unusual thing for her to do.
vi: A rather strange gesture from her.
tr: This is unusual behavior for him.
es: This is something unusual for her.

en: I've never seen her nibble while working.
vi: I had never seen her so silent while working.
tr: I had never seen him munching on something while working.
es: I never saw her snacking while she works.

en: "You can have one of them too," she says.
vi: “You can have one too,” she said.
tr: “You can have one too,” he says.
es: —You can take one too —he suggests—.

en: "A shame, making you wear all them pillowcases on your head, in this weather."
vi: “Damn it, having to wear those pillowcases on our heads, in this weather.”
tr: “It's embarrassing to have you carry all these pillowcases on your head, in this weather.”
es: It's a shame they make you wear all those covers on your head in this heat.

en: I am surprised: she doesn't usually offer me anything.
vi: I was astonished: she never had the habit of inviting me to anything, perhaps she thought that if I had been promoted enough to be given a matchstick, she could also make a nice gesture.
tr: I'm surprised: Usually, he doesn't offer me anything.
es: I am surprised: she almost never offers me things.

en: Maybe she feels that if I've risen in status enough to be given a match, she can afford her own small gesture.
vi: I was astonished: she never had the habit of inviting me to anything, perhaps she thought that if I had been promoted enough to be given a matchstick, she could also make a nice gesture.
tr: Maybe he felt that he could make a small gesture since I had made enough progress to deserve a match.
es: Maybe she feels that, if I have been promoted to a category sufficient to be given a match, she can afford the luxury of having a detail with me.

en: Have I become, suddenly, one of those who must be appeased?
vi: Is it true that, all of a sudden, I have joined the ranks of those who need flattery?
tr: Had I suddenly become someone who needed to be kept happy?
es: Have I suddenly become one of those people who need to be appeased?

en: "Thank you," I say.
vi: “Thank you,” I said.
tr: “Thank you,” I say.
es: —Thank you —I reply.

en: I transfer the match carefully to my zip-pered sleeve where the cigarette is, so it won't get wet, and take an ice cube.
vi: I carefully moved the matchstick into the sleeve with a zipper next to the cigar, to keep it from getting wet, and took one.
tr: I carefully place the match in the zippered pocket of my sleeve where the cigarette is, so it won't get wet; I take a piece of ice.
es: I carefully put the match in the sleeve pocket where I have the cigarette, so it doesn't get wet, and I take a cube—.

en: "Those radishes are pretty," I say, in return for the gift she's made me, of her own free will.
vi: “Nice radish,” I said, in response to her gift, which she had given of her own accord.
tr: “These radishes are very nice,” I say, as a reciprocation for the gift he spontaneously gave me.
es: These radishes are lovely —I say in gratitude for the gift he has given me so spontaneously.

en: "I like to do things right, is all," she says, grumpy again.
vi: “I like things to be clear-cut, that's it,” she said, frowning as usual.
tr: “I like doing things right, that's all,” he says, grumpily again.
es: —I like to do things right, period —he states, once again in a grumpy tone—.

en: "No sense otherwise."
vi: “Anything else wouldn't make sense.”
tr: “Otherwise, it loses its meaning.”
es: Otherwise, it wouldn't make sense.

en: I go along the passage, up the stairs, hurrying.
vi: I went out to the hall, up the stairs, my feet hurrying.
tr: I walk hurriedly up the stairs along the corridor.
es: I walk hurriedly down the hallway and climb the stairs.

en: In the curved hallway mirror I flit past, a red shape at the edge of my own field of vision, a wraith of red smoke.
vi: In the convex standing mirror I passed by, I saw the red shadow at the edge of the school, a ghost made of red smoke.
tr: I pass by the curved hall mirror, a red shape, a ghost of red smoke, at the corner of my field of vision.
es: I pass silently by the curved mirror in the foyer, a red shadow at the edge of my own field of vision, a red smoke specter.

en: I have smoke on my mind all fight, already I can feel it in my mouth, drawn down into the lungs, filling me in a long rich dirty cinnamon sigh, and then the rush as the nicotine hits the bloodstream.
vi: My head also became dizzy from the smoke, I could already taste it in my mouth, it sank into my lungs, making my whole body immersed in the coarse, intense breath of cinnamon, followed by the shock when the nicotine hit my bloodstream.
tr: The smoke, long, full, and dirty, with a cinnamon-like inhale filling my lungs, has already formed in my mind; I can already feel it in my mouth, followed by the rush when nicotine hits the blood.
es: The smoke is in my mind, but I can already feel it in my mouth, descending into my lungs and filling me with a prolonged and lascivious sigh of cinnamon, and then the rush as the nicotine hits my bloodstream.

en: After all this time it could make me sick.
vi: After all those years, I could throw up.
tr: After all this time, it could make me nauseous.
es: After so much time, it could hurt me.

en: I wouldn't be surprised.
vi: It's not surprising.
tr: I wouldn't be surprised by it.
es: It wouldn't surprise me.

en: But even that thought is welcome.
vi: But even so, I still welcome it eagerly.
tr: However, even this thought pleases me.
es: But even that idea appeals to me.

en: Along the corridor I go, where should I do it?
vi: I walked down the hallway, where am I now?
tr: I walk along the corridor, where should I drink?
es: As I walk down the hallway, I wonder where I could do it.

en: In the bathroom,
vi: In the bathroom, turning on the water to wash away the smell, in the bedroom, exhaling towards the window?
tr: In the bathroom while running the water to clean the air, or in the bedroom blowing out with a wheeze through the open window?
es: In the bathroom, letting the water run to clear the air, or in the bedroom, letting the puffs escape through the open window?

en: running the water to clear the air, in the bedroom, wheezy puffs out the open window?
vi: In the bathroom, turning on the water to wash away the smell, in the bedroom, exhaling towards the window?
tr: In the bathroom while running the water to clean the air, or in the bedroom blowing out with a wheeze through the open window?
es: In the bathroom, letting the water run to clear the air, or in the bedroom, letting the puffs escape through the open window?

en: Who's to catch me at it?
vi: Who will catch me doing this?
tr: Who will catch me?
es: Will someone discover me?

en: Who knows?
vi: Who knows?
tr: Who knows?
es: Who knows?

en: Even as I luxuriate in the future this way, rolling anticipation around in my mouth, I think of something else.
vi: Right in the midst of savoring such pleasures as before, tasting the imaginations in my mouth, I thought of something else.
tr: Even while savoring the anticipation in my mouth and enjoying the future in this way, I am thinking about something else.
es: While I delight in this way thinking about what is going to happen, anticipating the taste in my mouth, I think of something else.

en: I don't need to smoke this cigarette.
vi: I don't necessarily have to smoke this cigarette.
tr: I don't need to smoke this cigarette.
es: I don't need to smoke this cigarette.

en: I could shred it up and flush it down the toilet.
vi: I can tear it into small pieces and flush it down the toilet.
tr: I can tear it apart and flush it down the toilet, or I can eat it and lose myself in this way too, this might work, one piece at a time, saving the rest.
es: I could undo it and throw it in the toilet, or eat it and get high that way, that could also work, a little at a time, and save the rest.

en: Or I could eat it and get the high that way, that can work too, a little at a time, save up the rest.
vi: Or I can eat it for pleasure, bit by bit, saving the rest for later.
tr: I can tear it apart and flush it down the toilet, or I can eat it and lose myself in this way too, this might work, one piece at a time, saving the rest.
es: I could undo it and throw it in the toilet, or eat it and get high that way, that could also work, a little at a time, and save the rest.

en: That way I could keep the match.
vi: That way, the matchstick will be preserved.
tr: Thus, I won't waste the match.
es: That way I could keep the match.

en: I could make a small hole, in the mattress, slide it carefully in.
vi: You can poke a small hole in the mattress, carefully tuck it in.
tr: I can make a small hole in the mattress and carefully place the match inside.
es: I could make a small hole in the mattress and slide it inside carefully.

en: Such a thin thing would never be noticed.
vi: So small that no one will notice.
tr: Something so thin would never attract attention.
es: No one would ever notice such a small thing.

en: There it would be, at night, under me while I'm in bed.
vi: It will be there, every night, right under me when I lie down.
tr: At night, it would stay there, beneath me while I'm in bed, sleeping on top of it.
es: And at night, when I go to bed, it would be underneath me.

en: Sleeping on it.
vi: Sleeping above it.
tr: At night, it would stay there, beneath me while I'm in bed, sleeping on top of it.
es: I would sleep on top of it.

en: I could burn the house down.
vi: I can go burn down the house.
tr: I can burn the house down.
es: I could set the house on fire.

en: Such a fine thought, it makes me shiver.
vi: What a wonderful idea, it makes me tremble.
tr: It's such a beautiful thought, it makes me shiver.
es: It's a good idea, it makes me tremble.

en: An escape, quick and narrow.
vi: An escape, swift, by a hair's breadth.
tr: An escape, swift and by a hair's breadth.
es: And I would barely escape.

en: I lie on my bed, pretending to nap.
vi: I lay on the bed, pretending to nap.
tr: The commander is looking at me while I sit, rubbing my hands with oily lotion, fingers together, last night.
es: I lie down on the bed and pretend to doze off.

en: The Commander, last night, fingers together, looking at me as I sat rubbing oily lotion into my hands.
vi: Commander, last night, our fingers touched, and you watched me rub that greasy lotion all over my hands.
tr: The commander is looking at me while I sit, rubbing my hands with oily lotion, fingers together, last night.
es: Last night the Commander, with his fingers together, was watching me while I rubbed my hands with lotion.

en: Odd, I thought about asking him for a cigarette, but decided against it.
vi: It was quite amusing, I thought about asking for a cigarette, but then I dismissed the idea.
tr: How strange, I had thought of asking him for a cigarette, but then I changed my mind.
es: The strange thing is that I thought about asking him for a cigarette and then decided not to.

en: I know enough not to ask for too much at once.
vi: I'm smart enough not to demand too much at once.
tr: I know that one should not ask for too much at once.
es: I know I shouldn't ask for too many things at the same time.

en: I don't want him to think I'm using him.
vi: I don't want you to think I'm taking advantage.
tr: I don't want him to think I'm using him.
es: I don't want him to think I'm using him.

en: Also I don't want to interrupt him.
vi: Moreover, I also don't want to interrupt you.
tr: Also, I don't want to interfere.
es: I also don't want him to get tired.

en: Last night he had a drink, Scotch and water.
vi: Last night he drank whiskey, Scotch with water.
tr: Last night he had been drinking, Scotch and water.
es: Last night, he poured himself a glass of Scotch whisky with water.

en: He's taken to drinking in my presence, to unwind after the day, he says.
vi: Now he is used to drinking in front of me, to relax at the end of the day, he says.
tr: He says he enjoys drinking beside me to unwind from the day's fatigue.
es: He has gotten used to drinking in my presence, to relax from the day's tension, he says.

en: I'm to gather he is under pressure.
vi: I need to infer that he is under a lot of pressure.
tr: I should conclude that he is under pressure.
es: I deduce that he is under pressure.

en: He never offers me any, though, and I don't ask: we both know what my body is for.
vi: But he never offers, and I don't ask: we both know what this body is tasked with.
tr: Still, he never offers me any, and I don't want it either: We both know what my body is for.
es: In any case, he never offers me a drink, nor do I ask for one: we both know what my body is for.

en: When I kiss him goodnight, as if I mean it, his breath smells of alcohol, and I breathe it in like smoke.
vi: When I kiss him goodbye, as if I wanted to, his breath full of alcohol, I inhale it like smoke.
tr: When I give him a goodnight kiss, as if I really want to, I smell his alcohol-laden breath and inhale it like smoke.
es: When I give him a goodnight kiss, as if I were doing it for real, his breath smells of alcohol, and I inhale it as if it were smoke.

en: I admit I relish it, this lick of dissipation.
vi: I must admit I devour it, this stolen pleasure.
tr: I admit that it gives me pleasure, this kiss of debauchery.
es: I admit that I enjoy this touch of dissipation.

en: Sometimes after a few drinks he becomes silly, and cheats at Scrabble.
vi: Sometimes after a few drinks he becomes silly, and cheats when playing Scrabble.
tr: Occasionally, after a few drinks, he gets silly and cheats at Scrabble.
es: Sometimes, after a few drinks, he gets silly and cheats at Intelect.

en: He encourages me to do it too, and we take extra letters and make words with them that don't exist, words like smurt and crup, giggling over them.
vi: He even encourages me to do the same, and we both take extra tiles to make up non-existent words like smurt and crup, laughing hysterically.
tr: He encourages me too; he takes extra letters and makes up non-existent words like smurt and crup, and we laugh at them.
es: It encourages me to do it too, and then we pick some more letters and form words that don't exist, like chucrete and sucundún, and we laugh with them.

en: Sometimes he turns on his short-wave
vi: Sometimes he turns on the shortwave radio, showing me a minute or two of Radio Free America, just to prove he can do it.
tr: Sometimes he turns on the shortwave radio, and for a minute or two, to show he can do it, he plays Radio Free America in front of me.
es: Sometimes he turns on his shortwave radio and makes me listen to one or two minutes of Radio América Libre, to show me that he can do it.

en: radio, displaying before me a minute or two of Radio Free America, to show me he can.
vi: Sometimes he turns on the shortwave radio, showing me a minute or two of Radio Free America, just to prove he can do it.
tr: Sometimes he turns on the shortwave radio, and for a minute or two, to show he can do it, he plays Radio Free America in front of me.
es: Sometimes he turns on his shortwave radio and makes me listen to one or two minutes of Radio América Libre, to show me that he can do it.

en: Then he turns it off again.
vi: Then he turns it off again.
tr: Then he turns it off again.
es: Then he turns it off.

en: Damn Cubans, he says.
vi: Those damn Cubans, he says.
tr: “Damn Cubans,” he says.
es: Damned Cubans, he protests.

en: All that filth about universal daycare.
vi: Talking nonsense about universal daycare.
tr: “All this crap about universal childcare.”
es: And all that universal daily filth.

en: Sometimes, after the games, he sits on the floor beside my chair, holding my hand.
vi: Sometimes, after playing, he would sit on the floor next to my chair, holding my hand.
tr: Sometimes, after the games, he sits on the floor next to my chair, holding my hand.
es: Sometimes, after the games, she sits on the floor next to my chair and takes my hand.

en: His head is a little below mine, so that when he looks up at me it's at a juvenile angle.
vi: His head was slightly lower than mine, so he could look up at me from an angle like a child looking up.
tr: His head is slightly below mine, so when he looks at me, he appears like a child.
es: Her head is a little below mine, so when she looks at me, she shows a youthful angle.

en: It must amuse him, this fake subservience.
vi: Surely, he found joy in that act of feigned submission.
tr: It must amuse him, this fake submission.
es: This false subordination must amuse her.

en: He's way up there, says Ofglen.
vi: He is way up high, Ofglen said.
tr: Oh, up there, says Gleninki.
es: He is above, says Deglen.

en: He's at the top, and I mean the very top.
vi: He is at the top, the very top.
tr: At the top, I mean the very top.
es: He is at the top, and I mean the very top.

en: At such times it's hard to imagine it.
vi: It's hard to imagine that these days.
tr: It's hard to think about this at times like these.
es: In moments like that, it is difficult to imagine it.

en: Occasionally I try to put myself in his position.
vi: Occasionally, I try to put myself in his position.
tr: From time to time, I try to put myself in his place.
es: From time to time, I try to put myself in his place.

en: I do this as a tactic, to guess in advance how he may be moved to behave towards me.
vi: It is a proactive tactic, to anticipate how he might be influenced to behave towards me.
tr: I do this as a tactic, to predict in advance how his behavior towards me might be directed.
es: I do it as a tactic, to guess in advance how he feels inclined to treat me.

en: It's difficult for me to believe I have power over him, of any sort, but I do; although it's of an equivocal kind.
vi: It is hard to believe that I have any power over him, in any way, but it is true; though it is a very ambiguous kind of power.
tr: It is hard for me to believe that I have any kind of power over him, but I do; despite it being ambiguous.
es: I find it hard to believe that I have some kind of power over him, but I do. However, it is somewhat ambiguous.

en: Once in a while I think I can see myself, though blurrily, as he may see me.
vi: Sometimes I think I can see myself, though quite vaguely, through the eyes he might see me with.
tr: Every now and then, even if it's blurry, I think I can see myself as he sees me.
es: From time to time, I think I can see myself, though blurry, just as he sees me.

en: There are things he wants to prove to me, gifts he wants to bestow, services he wants to render, tendernesses he wants to inspire.
vi: There are things he wants to prove, gifts he wants to bestow, services he wants to offer, affections he wants to awaken.
tr: There are things he wants to prove to me, gifts he wants to give, services he wants to perform, and states of compassion he wants to inspire.
es: There are things he wants to show me, gifts he wants to give me, favors he wants to do for me, tenderness he wants to inspire.

en: He wants, all right.
vi: He wants it, that's it.
tr: He wants it, very well.
es: He wants to, very well.

en: Especially after a few drinks.
vi: Especially after a few drinks.
tr: Especially after a few glasses of alcohol.
es: Especially after a few drinks.

en: Sometimes he becomes querulous, at other times philosophical; or he wishes to explain things, justify himself.
vi: Sometimes he became grumpy, other times he preferred to philosophize; wanting to explain the situation, justify himself, when things got too complicated, for example.
tr: Sometimes he gets grumpy, other times he turns into a philosopher; or he wants to explain something, to justify himself.
es: At times he becomes whiny, and at other moments philosophical; or he wants to explain things, to justify himself.

en: As last night.
vi: Sometimes he became grumpy, other times he preferred to philosophize; wanting to explain the situation, justify himself, when things got too complicated, for example.
tr: Like the other night.
es: Like last night.

en: The problem wasn't only with the women, he says.
vi: It's not just women who face issues on those days, he said, the bigger problem is with men.
tr: The problem wasn't just about women, he says.
es: The problem was not only for the women, he says.

en: The main problem was with the men.
vi: It's not just women who face issues on those days, he said, the bigger problem is with men.
tr: The main issue was with men.
es: The main problem was for the men.

en: There was nothing for them anymore.
vi: They have nothing left.
tr: There was nothing left for them anymore.
es: There was nothing left for them.

en: Nothing?
vi: Nothing left?
tr: Nothing at all?
es: Nothing?, I ask him.

en: I say.
vi: I asked.
tr: I ask.
es: Nothing?, I ask him.

en: But they had
vi: But they already had...
tr: But what they have...
es: But they had...

en: There was nothing for them to do, he says.
vi: They have nothing to do, he said.
tr: There was nothing to be done for them, he says.
es: They had nothing to do, he points out.

en: They could make money, I say, a little nastily.
vi: They can go earn money, I said, somewhat insolently.
tr: They could make money, I say, a bit shamelessly.
es: They could make money, he replied in a somewhat brusque tone.

en: Right now I'm not afraid of him.
vi: At this moment, I did not feel afraid of him.
tr: Right now, I'm not afraid of him.
es: Now I don't fear him.

en: It's hard to be afraid of a man who is sitting watching you put on hand lotion.
vi: It's hard to be afraid of a man who is sitting and watching himself apply lotion.
tr: It's hard to be afraid of a man sitting and watching you while you apply lotion to your hands.
es: It's hard to fear a man who is sitting watching you put lotion on your hands.

en: This lack of fear is dangerous.
vi: This state of fearlessness is truly dangerous.
tr: This lack of fear is dangerous.
es: This lack of fear is dangerous.

en: It's not enough, he says.
vi: That's not enough, he said.
tr: This was not enough, he says.
es: It's not enough, he says.

en: It's too abstract.
vi: That's too abstract.
tr: This is a very abstract thing.
es: It's something too abstract.

en: I mean there was nothing for them to do with women.
vi: I mean they have nothing to do with women anymore.
tr: What I mean is, they had nothing left to do with women.
es: I mean, they had nothing to do with the women.

en: What do you mean?
vi: "What do you mean by that?" I said.
tr: What do you mean?
es: "What do you mean?" I ask him.

en: I say.
vi: "What do you mean by that?" I said.
tr: I say.
es: "And the Porncorners?"

en: What about all the Pornycorners, it was all over the place, they even had it motorized.
vi: "What about the whole Pig Alley, it's everywhere, even mechanized."
tr: What about all those porn corners, they were everywhere, they even made them mobile.
es: They were everywhere, they had even motorized them.

en: I'm not talking about sex, he says.
vi: I'm not talking about sex, he said.
tr: I'm not talking about sex, he says.
es: I'm not talking about sex, he clarifies.

en: That was part of it, the sex was too
vi: That's part of it too, sex is too easy to get.
tr: That's just one aspect of it, sex was very easy.
es: Sex was a part of it, and something too accessible.

en: easy.
vi: That's part of it too, sex is too easy to get.
tr: That's just one aspect of it, sex was very easy.
es: Sex was a part of it, and something too accessible.

en: Anyone could just buy it.
vi: Anyone can go out and buy it.
tr: Everyone could buy it.
es: Anyone could buy it.

en: There was nothing to work for, nothing to fight for.
vi: There's nothing to strive for, nothing to struggle for anymore.
tr: There was nothing to strive for, nothing to fight for.
es: There was nothing to work for, nothing to fight for.

en: We have the stats from that time.
vi: We still have data from that time.
tr: We have the statistics from that time.
es: We have the statements from that time.

en: You know what they were complaining about the most?
vi: Do you know what they complained about the most?
tr: Do you know what they complained about the most?
es: Do you know what most people complained about?

en: Inability to feel.
vi: No more feelings.
tr: A lack of feeling.
es: Inability to feel.

en: Men were turning off on sex, even.
vi: Men started turning their backs on sex, that's how far it went.
tr: Men had even started to turn their backs on sex.
es: Men even disconnected from sex.

en: They were turning off on marriage.
vi: They turned their backs on marriage.
tr: And on marriage too.
es: The desire to get married was taken away from them.

en: Do they feel now?
vi: So now they have feelings?
tr: Do they feel it now?
es: And now do you feel?, I asked.

en: I say.
vi: I said.
tr: I ask.
es: And now do you feel?, I asked.

en: Yes, he says, looking at me.
vi: Yes, he said, looking at me.
tr: Yes, he says, looking at me.
es: Yes, he affirms, looking at me.

en: They do.
vi: Of course.
tr: They feel it.
es: Of course they feel.

en: He stands up, comes around the desk to the chair where I'm sitting.
vi: He stood up, walked around the table to my chair.
tr: He stands up, comes to the chair I'm sitting on from around the table.
es: He stands up and walks around the desk until he is next to my chair, behind me.

en: He puts his hands on my shoulders, from behind.
vi: He placed his hands on my shoulders, from behind.
tr: He puts his hands on my shoulders, from behind.
es: He places his hands on my shoulders.

en: I can't see him.
vi: I couldn't see him.
tr: I can't see him.
es: I can't see him.

en: I like to know what you think, his voice says, from behind me.
vi: I hope to know what you think, his voice rose, behind me.
tr: I want to know what you're thinking, says the voice, from behind me.
es: I would like to know what you think, says her voice behind me.

en: I don't think a lot, I say lightly.
vi: I didn't think much, I spoke lightly.
tr: I don't think much, I say softly.
es: I don't think much, I respond weakly.

en: What he wants is intimacy, but I can't give him that.
vi: He wants affection, but I can't give it.
tr: What she wants is closeness, but I can't give it to her.
es: What he wants are intimate relationships, but that is something I cannot give him.

en: There's hardly any point in my thinking, is there?
vi: Even if I think about it, does it mean anything, right?
tr: There's not much point in thinking, is there?
es: What I think doesn't matter much, does it?, I imply.

en: I say.
vi: I said.
tr: I say.
es: What I think doesn't matter much, does it?, I imply.

en: What I think doesn't matter.
vi: What I think doesn't matter.
tr: What I think doesn't matter.
es: What I think doesn't count.

en: Which is the only reason he can tell me things.
vi: It is also the only reason he could confide in me.
tr: And that's why he can tell me things.
es: That is the only reason why they tell me things.

en: Come now, he says, pressing a little with his hands.
vi: Come on, come on, he said, pressing down slightly with his hand.
tr: Come on, he says, squeezing my shoulders with his hands, I'm interested in your opinion.
es: Come on, encourage me, lightly pressing my shoulders.

en: I'm interested in your opinion.
vi: I am very interested in your opinion.
tr: Come on, he says, squeezing my shoulders with his hands, I'm interested in your opinion.
es: I'm interested in your opinion.

en: You're intelligent enough, you must have an opinion.
vi: You are smart, you must have an opinion.
tr: You're smart enough, you must have an opinion.
es: You are intelligent, you must have an opinion.

en: About what?
vi: About what?
tr: What about?
es: About what?, I ask.

en: I say.
vi: I asked.
tr: I ask.
es: About what?, I ask.

en: What we've done, he says.
vi: The things we have done, he said.
tr: About what we are doing, he says.
es: About what we have done, specify.

en: How things have worked out.
vi: About the current situation.
tr: About how things are going.
es: About how things have turned out.

en: I hold myself very still.
vi: I kept myself very still.
tr: I'm straining myself.
es: I stay very still.

en: I try to empty my mind.
vi: I cleared my mind.
tr: I'm trying to clear my mind.
es: I try to empty my mind.

en: I think about the sky, at night, when there's no moon.
vi: I thought of the sky, a moonless night.
tr: I'm thinking of the sky, at night, when there is no moon.
es: I think about the sky, at night, when there is no moon.

en: I have no opinion, I say.
vi: I have no opinion, I said.
tr: I have no idea, I say.
es: I have no opinion, I affirm.

en: He sighs, relaxes his hands, but leaves them on my shoulders.
vi: He sighed, his hand relaxed, but still rested on my shoulder.
tr: He sighs, relaxes his hands, but still leaves them on my shoulders.
es: He sighs, loosens his hands but leaves them on my shoulders.

en: He knows what I think, all right.
vi: He knew what I was thinking, alright.
tr: He knows what I'm thinking, anyway.
es: He knows what I’m thinking.

en: You can't make an omelette without breaking eggs, is what he says.
vi: If you don't break eggs, what will you use to fry? That's all he said.
tr: You can't make an omelet without breaking eggs, he says.
es: You can't swim and keep your clothes dry, he declares.

en: We thought we could do better.
vi: We thought we could make it better.
tr: We thought we could do better.
es: We thought we could make everything better.

en: Better?
vi: Better?
tr: "Better than this?" I say, in a low voice.
es: Better?, I repeat in a low voice.

en: I say, in a small voice.
vi: I said, very softly.
tr: "Better than this?" I say, in a low voice.
es: Better?, I repeat in a low voice.

en: How can he think this is better?
vi: How can he think this is better?
tr: How can he think this is better?
es: How can he believe that this is better?

en: Better never means better for everyone, he says.
vi: Better never means better for everyone, he said.
tr: Better never means better for everyone, he says.
es: Better never means better for everyone, he comments.

en: It always means worse, for some.
vi: It always means worse, for some.
tr: It always means worse, for some.
es: For some, it is always worse.

en: I lie flat, the damp air above me like a lid.
vi: I lie on my back, the humid air covering me like a lid.
tr: I am lying flat, the humid air above me like a blanket.
es: I lie down; the humid air covers me as if it were a lid.

en: Like earth.
vi: Like the earth.
tr: Like the earth.
es: Like the earth.

en: I wish it would rain.
vi: I hope it will rain.
tr: I wish it would rain.
es: I wish it would rain.

en: Better still, a thunderstorm, black clouds, lightning, car-splitting sound.
vi: Even better if a storm comes, dark clouds, lightning strikes, ear-splitting noises.
tr: Even better, a storm, dark clouds, lightning, a noise that makes your eardrums shine.
es: Better yet, that a storm would break out with lightning, black clouds, and deafening noises.

en: Theelectricity might go off.
vi: Who knows, the power might go out.
tr: The electricity could go out.
es: And that the power would go out.

en: I could go down to the kitchen then, say I'm afraid, sit with Rita and Cora around the
vi: I will go down to the kitchen, say I'm scared, sit beside Rita and Cora around the table, they will forgive me because it's a common fear, they will welcome me in.
tr: Then I could go down to the kitchen, say that I am scared, and sit in the kitchen with Rita and Cora; they would allow me to be scared because it is something they share, they would include me among them.
es: Then I would go down to the kitchen, say that I am scared, and sit with Rita and Cora by the table, and they would understand my fear because it is the same one they feel, and they would let me stay.

en: kitchen table, they would permit my fear because it's one they share, they'd let me in.
vi: I will go down to the kitchen, say I'm scared, sit beside Rita and Cora around the table, they will forgive me because it's a common fear, they will welcome me in.
tr: Then I could go down to the kitchen, say that I am scared, and sit in the kitchen with Rita and Cora; they would allow me to be scared because it is something they share, they would include me among them.
es: Then I would go down to the kitchen, say that I am scared, and sit with Rita and Cora by the table, and they would understand my fear because it is the same one they feel, and they would let me stay.

en: There would be candles burning, we would watch each other's faces come and go in the flickering, in the white flashes of jagged light from outside the windows.
vi: There will be candles, we will see each other's faces flickering thanks to the dim light, thanks to the blinding white flashes outside the door.
tr: There would be burning candles, we would watch our faces come and go in the sharp light vibrations, the white flashes coming from outside the windows.
es: There would be some lit candles, and we would watch our faces come and go under the flicker and flashes of the jagged light coming through the window.

en: Oh Lord, Cora would say.
vi: Oh Lord, Cora will say.
tr: Oh my God, Cora would say.
es: Oh Lord, Cora would say.

en: Oh Lord save us.
vi: Oh Lord, save us.
tr: God, protect us.
es: Oh Lord, protect us.

en: The air would be clear after that, and lighter.
vi: The air will be clearer and more open afterwards.
tr: The air would be cleaner and lighter from now on.
es: After that, the air would clear up and be more transparent.

en: I look up at the ceiling, the round circle of plaster flowers.
