vi: I look up at the ceiling, a circle of plaster flowers.
tr: I'm looking up at the ceiling, at the circle of plaster flowers.
es: I look at the flat ceiling, the circle of plaster flowers.

en: Draw a circle, step into it, it will protect you.
vi: Draw a circle, step inside, it will protect you.
tr: Draw a circle, step inside, it will protect you.
es: Draw a circle and get inside it, it will protect you.

en: From the center was the chandelier, and from the chandelier a twisted strip of sheet was hanging down.
vi: Descending from the center is a lamp, descending from the lamp is a twisted bedsheet.
tr: From the center hung a chandelier, and from the chandelier dangled a twisted piece of sheet.
es: In the center was the chandelier, and from the chandelier hung a piece of twisted sheet.

en: That's where she was swinging, just lightly, like a pendulum; the way you could swing as a child, hanging by your hands from a tree branch.
vi: She swayed there, gently, like a pendulum; like everyone used to sway as a child, hands gripping a tree branch.
tr: It was the place where the woman swung, very lightly, like a pendulum; like a child might swing, hanging from a tree branch.
es: That’s where she was swinging, slightly, like a pendulum; in the same way a child would swing from a tree branch.

en: She was safe then, protected altogether, by the time Cora opened the door.
vi: So she was safe, wrapped in the protective circle, when Cora stepped in.
tr: Then she was safe, completely protected. When Cora opened the door.
es: When Cora opened the door, she was safe, completely protected.

en: Sometimes I think she's still in here, with me.
vi: Sometimes I think she is still here, around me.
tr: Sometimes I still think she's here, with me.
es: Sometimes I think she is still here, with me.

en: I feel buried.
vi: I feel like I'm in a grave.
tr: I feel buried.
es: I feel like I am buried.
CHAPTER 33

en: Late afternoon, the sky hazy, the sunlight diffuse but heavy and everywhere, like bronze dust.
vi: Late afternoon, the sky is misty, the sunlight is scattered but dense, like gold dust.
tr: Late in the afternoon, the sky is hazy, yet the sun finds its way through and spreads everywhere with all its might, like bronze-colored dust.
es: At the last hour of the afternoon, the sky is covered with clouds and the sunlight diffuses heavily, like powdered bronze.

en: I glide with Ofglen along the sidewalk; the pair of us, and in front of us another pair, and across the street another.
vi: I walk with Ofglen on the sidewalk; a pair side by side, another pair ahead, yet another pair across the street.
tr: Glen and I are gliding along the street; we are a pair, another pair in front of us, and another pair across the way.
es: I slide along the sidewalk, with Deglen; the two of us, and in front of us another pair, and on the opposite sidewalk, another one.

en: We must look good from a distance: picturesque, like Dutch milkmaids on a wallpaper frieze, like a shelf full of period-costume ceramic salt and pepper shakers, like a flotilla of swans or anything that repeats itself with at least minimum grace and without variation.
vi: From a distance, it must look very nice, very beautiful, like Dutch milkmaids embossed on a wall, like a shelf filled with antique ceramic salt and pepper shakers, like a flock of swans, like multiple replicas of something with a touch of grace, however slight.
tr: We must look good from a distance: picturesque, like German milkmaids in a wallpaper motif, like a shelf full of ceramic salt and pepper shakers adorned with figures in old-time clothing, like a small fleet of swans or anything that repeats itself with at least a touch of elegance, despite the lack of variety.
es: Seen from a distance, we must form a pretty picture: a pictorial image, like Dutch milkmaids from a wallpaper border, like a shelf full of ceramic salt and pepper shakers with period costume designs, like a flotilla of swans, or any other thing that repeats with a minimum of grace and without variation.

en: Soothing to the eye, the eyes, the Eyes, for that's who this show is for.
vi: A pleasing sight, before all eyes, before all Eyes, for that is the true audience of this performance.
tr: To dazzle the eyes, For the Eyes, after all, this show is for them.
es: Relaxing for the sight, for the eyes, for the Eyes, because this demonstration is for them.

en: We're off to the Prayvaganza, to demonstrate how obedient and pious we are.
vi: We are on our way to the Prayvaganza, to display our obedience and piety.
tr: We are being sent to the Prayer Ceremony, to show how obedient and devout we are.
es: We go out on Pilgrimage, to demonstrate how obedient and pious we are.

en: Not a dandelion in sight here, the lawns are picked clean.
vi: Looking around, I couldn't see a single dandelion; every lawn was meticulously trimmed.
tr: There isn't a single dandelion in sight, the lawns have been meticulously cleaned.
es: Not a single dandelion can be seen, the lawns have been carefully cleaned.

en: I long for one, just one, rubbishy and insolently random and hard to get rid of and perennially yellow as the sun.
vi: I longed to see just one, just one, growing wildly and stubbornly like a weed, perennial and golden like the sun.
tr: I want one, just one, worthless and brazenly random, hard to dismiss and yellow like the sun all year round.
es: I wish there were one, just one, insignificant and brazenly loose, hard to get rid of and perpetually yellow, like the sun.

en: Cheerful and plebeian, shining for all alike.
vi: Cheerful and simple, radiant without needing anyone's gaze.
tr: Cheerful and ordinary, shining equally for everyone.
es: Cheerful and common, shining equally for everyone.

en: Rings, we would make from them, and crowns and necklaces, stains from the bitter milk on our fingers.
vi: With Nhan by my side, we often picked them to weave into garlands, bracelets, and crowns, the sap sticking to our fingers.
tr: We used to make rings from them, crowns and necklaces, and we would stain our fingers with their bitter milk.
es: With them, we made rings, crowns, and necklaces, sour milk stains on our fingers.

en: Or I'd hold one
vi: Or I would hold one up to my child's chin: "As pretty as a fairy, isn't it?"
tr: Or I would hold one under my daughter's chin:
es: Or held it under her chin:

en: under her chin:
vi: Or I would hold one up to my child's chin: "As pretty as a fairy, isn't it?"
tr: Or I would hold one under my daughter's chin:
es: Or held it under her chin:

en: Do you like butter?
vi: Or I would hold one up to my child's chin: "As pretty as a fairy, isn't it?"
tr: Do you like weddings?
es: Do you like butter?

en: Smelling them, she'd get pollen on her nose.
vi: Sniffing it, your nose would be dusted with pollen.
tr: When we smelled them, pollen would get on our noses.
es: And when she smelled them, the pollen would get into her nose.

en: Or was that buttercups?
vi: Or is it golden hair?
tr: (Or was it buttercups?)
es: (Or was it the fluff?)

en: Or gone to seed: I cansee her, running across the lawn, that lawn there just in front of me, at two, three years old, waving one like a sparkler, a small wand of white fire, the air filling with tiny parachutes.
vi: Or has it shed its petals and gone to seed: I see you, running across the lawn, the lawn right in front of me, when you were two or three years old, holding the flower like a sparkler, a magic wand flickering with white sparks, the air filled with tiny parachutes.
tr: Or we would go to plant seeds: I can picture her running around the lawn, right here in front of me, three or four years old, holding one, waving it like a sparkler, a small stick of white fire, the air filled with tiny parachutes.
es: I see her running on the grass, that grass that is exactly in front of me, at two or three years old, shaking it as if it were a sparkler, a small rod of white fire, and the air was filled with tiny parachutes.

en: Blow, and you tell the time.
vi: Blow on it, and you'll know the time.
tr: Blow and tell the time.
es: She blows and looks at the time.

en: All that time, blowing away in the summer breeze.
vi: Thousands of minutes, carried away by the gentle summer breeze.
tr: All that time, drifting away in the summer breeze.
es: All the time carried away by the summer breeze.

en: It was daisies for love though, and we did that too.
vi: But it’s the white daisies that can tell love fortunes, we played that game too.
tr: Though there were daisies for love, we played with those too.
es: But they were daisies, and we plucked their petals.

en: We line up to get processed through the checkpoint, standing in our twos and twos and twos, like a private girls' school that went for a walk and stayed out too long.
vi: We lined up at the checkpoint, in pairs, one pair after another, like an entire private girls' school returning from an outing too late.
tr: We line up at the checkpoint to get our procedures done, in pairs and pairs and pairs, like students from a special girls' school who have been out on a walk and stayed outside for too long.
es: We formed a line in front of the checkpoint, to be processed, always in pairs, like girls from a private school who have gone out for a walk and have been away too long, years and years, and everything has grown too much for them, their legs, their bodies, and along with these, their dresses.

en: Years and years too long, so that everything has become overgrown, legs, bodies, dresses all together.
vi: Late, unbearably late, to the point where everything had grown too big, our feet, our bodies, our clothes grew along with us.
tr: We have stayed outside so long it feels like years have passed, so everything seems too big; legs, bodies, and along with them, clothes.
es: We formed a line in front of the checkpoint, to be processed, always in pairs, like girls from a private school who have gone out for a walk and have been away too long, years and years, and everything has grown too much for them, their legs, their bodies, and along with these, their dresses.

en: As if enchanted.
vi: As if enchanted.
tr: We are like we are enchanted.
es: As if they were enchanted.

en: A fairy tale, I'd like to believe.
vi: This is a fairy tale, I want to believe so.
tr: I would like to believe it is a fairy tale.
es: As if it were a fairy tale, I would like to believe it.

en: Instead we are checked through, in our twos, and continue walking.
vi: But we were let through, in pairs, and continued on our way.
tr: Yet we continue to be checked and keep walking in pairs.
es: Instead, we are searched, in pairs, and we continue walking.

en: After a while we turn right, heading past Lilies and down towards the river.
vi: After a while, turn right, go past the lilies towards the river.
tr: After a while, we pass the Lilies and turn right, heading down towards the river.
es: A while later, we turned right, passed by Azucenas, and went down towards the river.

en: I wish I could go that far, to where the wide banks are, where we used to lie in the sun, where the bridges arch over.
vi: If only I could go all the way there, the garlic by the vast riverbank, where we used to lie in the sun, under the curved bridges.
tr: I wish I could go to the wide clearings by the riverbank, where we used to lie under the sun and where the bridges arched.
es: I would like to get there, to its wide banks, where we used to lie down to sunbathe, where the bridges rise.

en: If you went down the river long enough, along its sinewy windings, you'd reach the sea; but what could you do there?
vi: If you are willing to walk along the riverbank, following the winding paths, you will eventually reach the sea; but what is there to do when you get there?
tr: If you follow the river far enough along its meandering curves, you will reach the sea; but really, what could one do there now?
es: If you went down the river far enough, through its winding curves, you would reach the sea; and what could you do there?

en: Gather shells, loll on the oily stones.
vi: Pick up seashells, bask on the slippery rocks.
tr: Collect shells, wander on slippery stones.
es: Collecting shells and lying down on the smooth stones.

en: We aren't going to the river though, we won't see the little cupolas on the buildings down that way, white with blue and gold trim, such chaste gaiety.
vi: But we will not go to the river, will not see the dome-shaped houses along the road, the moonlight glistening with golden or blue hues, fresh and pure.
tr: We are not going towards the river, though, we will not see the small domes of the buildings on that side, white with blue and gold embroideries, such a simple ornamentation.
es: However, we are not going to the river, we will not see the small domes of the buildings along the way, white with blue and a golden ornament, a sober expression of joy.

en: We turn in at a more modern building, a huge banner draped over its doorWOMEN'S PRAYVAGANZA TODAY.
vi: Instead, we turn into a more modern building, with a large banner stretched across the entrance: DAY OF WOMEN'S CHARITY.
tr: We are entering a more modern building, they have hung a massive cloth banner above its door - TODAY WOMEN'S PRAYER CEREMONY.
es: We turn into a more modern building, which above the door has a huge decorated flag, on which it reads: TODAY, PILGRIMAGE OF WOMEN.

en: The banner covers the building's former name, some dead president they shot.
vi: The banner obscures the old name of the building, some former president who took a lead bullet.
tr: The banner covers the building's old name, the name of an assassinated President.
es: The flag covers the original name of the building, that of some president who was shot to death.

en: Below the red writing there's a line of smaller print, in black, with the outline of a winged eye on either side of it: God Is a National Resource.
vi: Below the red letters, there is a smaller line in black, flanked by two winged eye drawings: God is a national resource.
tr: Under the red writing, there is another line in smaller letters, black, with the outlines of a winged eye on either side: GOD IS A NATIONAL RESOURCE.
es: Beneath the red letters, there is a line of smaller letters, in black, with the profile of a winged eye at each end, and it reads: GOD IT IS A NATIONAL RESERVE.

en: On either side of the doorway stand the inevitable Guardians, two pairs, four in all, arms at their sides, eyes front.
vi: The door is flanked by ever-present Guards: two pairs, four people, guns at their hips, eyes straight ahead.
tr: On either side of the door, there are those inevitable Guards, two pairs, a total of four, with their weapons at their sides, eyes looking forward.
es: On each side of the entrance are the inevitable Guardians, two pairs, four in total, with their arms at their sides and their gaze straight ahead.

en: They're like store mannequins almost, with their neat hair and pressed uniforms and plaster-hard young faces.
vi: Almost like fashion models, hair neatly combed, uniforms crisply ironed, faces young and hard as plaster.
tr: They are almost like store mannequins, with their straight hair and pressed uniforms and plaster-like stiff young faces.
es: They almost look like mannequins, with clean hair, ironed uniforms, and their young plaster-like faces.

en: No pimply ones today.
vi: But none of them had pimples.
tr: No pimply ones today.
es: These ones don't have pimples on their faces.

en: Each has a submachine gun slung ready, for whatever
vi: Each one had an automatic rifle within reach, ready to counter any dangerous or rebellious actions we might cause inside.
tr: Each of them has light machine guns ready to fire for any dangerous or destructive action they think you might do inside.
es: Each one carries a machine gun ready for any dangerous or subversive act we might commit inside.

en: dangerous or subversive acts they think we might commit inside.
vi: Each one had an automatic rifle within reach, ready to counter any dangerous or rebellious actions we might cause inside.
tr: Each of them has light machine guns ready to fire for any dangerous or destructive action they think you might do inside.
es: Each one carries a machine gun ready for any dangerous or subversive act we might commit inside.

en: The Prayvaganza is to be held in the covered courtyard, where there's an oblong space, a skylight roof.
vi: The ceremony will be held in a covered courtyard, a rectangular space with a glass roof.
tr: The Prayer Ceremony that needs to be held in the covered courtyard with a rectangular area and a dormer window.
es: The Pilgrimage ceremony will be held in a covered courtyard that has a rectangular space and a roof with a skylight.

en: It isn't a citywide Prayvaganza, that would be on the football field; it's only for this district.
vi: This time it’s not at the city level, that would be in a stadium; today it’s just within this district.
tr: This is not a Prayer Ceremony that encompasses the whole city; if it were, it would be held in a football stadium; it's just for this region.
es: It is not a Pilgrimage for the whole city; in that case, it would be held in the football field. It is only for this district.

en: Ranks of folding wooden chairs have been placed along the right side, for the Wives and daughers of high-ranking officials or officers, there's not that much difference.
vi: Rows of wooden folding chairs have been arranged on the right side of the courtyard, reserved for the wives and daughters of officers or high-ranking officials, not much different from each other.
tr: Rows of folding wooden chairs have been placed to the right, for the wives and daughters of high-ranking officials or officers, there isn't much difference between them.
es: Along the right side, rows of wooden folding chairs have been placed for the Wives and the daughters of high-ranking officers or officials; there is not much difference.

en: The galleries above, with their concrete railings, are for the lower-ranking women, the Marthas, the Econowives in their multicolored stripes.
vi: The higher stands, with concrete railings, are for lower-ranking women, Marthas, and the thrifty Wives in multi-colored striped dresses.
tr: The upper galleries with concrete railings are for women of lower status; the Marthas, the Econowives in their multicolored striped dresses.
es: The upper galleries, with their concrete railings, are for the women of lower rank, the Marthas, the Econowives with their multicolored stripes.

en: Attendance at Prayvaganzas isn't compulsory for them, especially if they're on duty or have young children, but the galleries seem to be filling up anyway.
vi: They are not required to attend the ceremony, especially if they are working or have small children, but the stands still seem crowded.
tr: It's not mandatory for them to attend the Prayer Ceremony, especially if they are on duty or have small children, yet it seems like the galleries will still be filled.
es: Attendance at the Pilgrimage is not mandatory for them, especially if they are on duty or have small children, but nonetheless, the galleries are crowded.

en: I suppose it's a form of entertainment, like a show or a circus.
vi: I guess it’s also a form of entertainment, like watching a play or a circus.
tr: Like a show or a circus, I suppose this is a form of entertainment.
es: I suppose it is a form of distraction like a show or a circus.

en: A number of the Wives are already seated, in their best embroi dered blue.
vi: Some ladies were already seated, wearing their finest embroidered blue dresses.
tr: Some of the spouses have already taken their places in their best embroidered blue dresses.
es: There are already many Wives seated, dressed in their best embroidered blue dresses.

en: We can feel their eyes on us as we walk in our red dresses two by two across to the side opposite them.
vi: You could feel their eyes on us as we walked past with our red couplets, heading to the opposite side.
tr: As we walk two by two in our red dresses towards the places opposite them, we can feel their gazes on us.
es: As we walk in our red dresses, two by two, to the opposite side, we can feel their eyes fixed on us.

en: We are being looked at, assessed, whispered about; we can feel it, like tiny ants running on our bare skins.
vi: We were the subjects of scrutiny, appraisal, whispered judgments; it felt like a line of ants crawling on bare skin.
tr: We are being watched, measured, and whispered about; we can feel this, just as we can feel ants running on our bare skin.
es: We are observed, evaluated, they make comments about us; and we notice it as if they were tiny ants crawling over our bare skin.

en: Here there are no chairs.
vi: This side has no chairs.
tr: There are no chairs here.
es: There are no chairs here.

en: Our area is cordoned off with a silky twisted scarlet rope, like the kind theyused to have in movie theaters to restrain the customers.
vi: The area for us is cordoned off with a twisted red silk rope, like in old cinemas to keep customers out.
tr: Our area is separated by a silky, braided, reddish cord, the kind that used to exist in cinemas to restrain customers.
es: Our area is cordoned off with twisted silk rope, scarlet in color, like the kind they used to put in cinemas to prevent the public from passing.

en: This rope segregates us, marks us off, keeps the others from contamination by us, makes for us a corral or pen; so into it we go, arranging ourselves in rows, which we know very well how to do, kneeling then on the cement floor.
vi: That rope isolates us, marking quarantine, preventing infection from spreading to others, creating a sort of pen or cage; we just flow in, automatically forming lines, a habit we are very used to, and kneel down to sit on the cement floor.
tr: This cord separates and gathers us together, defines our boundaries, prevents us from spreading anything to others, and functions as a pen or coop for us; thus, we enter it, line up looking straight ahead, something we know very well how to do, then kneel on the concrete floor.
es: This rope isolates us, distinguishes us, prevents others from being contaminated by us, forms a corral, a pigsty in which we enter and distribute ourselves in rows, kneeling on the cement floor.

en: "Head for the back," Ofglen murmurs at my side.
vi: “Get down to the end,” Ofglen murmured beside me.
tr: “Head to the back,” murmurs Gleninki.
es: —Come to the back —murmurs Deglen beside me—.

en: "We can talk better."
vi: “It's easier to talk that way.”
tr: “We can talk more comfortably there.”
es: We can talk better there.

en: And when we are kneeling, heads bowed slightly, I can hear from all around us a susurration, like the rustling of insects in tall dry grass: a cloud of whispers.
vi: And while kneeling, head slightly bowed, I could hear a rustling all around, like the sound of insects chirping in tall dry grass: a dense whispering.
tr: With heads slightly bowed, as we kneel, I can hear a rustling sound coming from all around us, like the chirps of insects among the tall and dry grasses: a cloud of whispers.
es: We kneel and slightly bow our heads; I hear a whisper around me, like the whisper of insects over dry grass: a cloud of murmurs.

en: This is one of the places where we can exchange news more freely, pass it from one to the next.
vi: This is one of the places where we can exchange freely, spreading news throughout the crowd.
tr: This is one of the places where we can exchange news more freely, passing it from one to another, making it difficult for them to identify who is speaking or to hear what is being said.
es: This is one of the places where we can exchange news more freely, passing it from one to another.

en: It's hard for them to single out any one of us or hear what's being said.
vi: It’s hard for them to single out anyone in the group, or to hear what is being said.
tr: This is one of the places where we can exchange news more freely, passing it from one to another, making it difficult for them to identify who is speaking or to hear what is being said.
es: It is difficult for them to single us out or hear what we say.

en: And they wouldn't want to interrupt the ceremony, not in front of the
vi: Moreover, they don’t want to interrupt the ceremony, especially in front of the television cameras.
tr: Moreover, it doesn't suit them to interrupt the ceremony in front of the television cameras.
es: And they are not interested in interrupting the ceremony, especially not in front of the television cameras.

en: television cameras.
vi: Moreover, they don’t want to interrupt the ceremony, especially in front of the television cameras.
tr: Moreover, it doesn't suit them to interrupt the ceremony in front of the television cameras.
es: And they are not interested in interrupting the ceremony, especially not in front of the television cameras.

en: Ofglen digs me in the side with her elbow, to call my attention, and I look up, slowly and stealthily.
vi: Ofglen nudged my side, alerting me, and I looked up, very slowly and stealthily.
tr: Gleninki nudges me with his elbow to get my attention, I lift my head, slowly and discreetly.
es: Deglen elbows me to get my attention, and I look up, slowly and cautiously.

en: From where we're kneeling we have a good view of the entrance to the courtyard, where people are steadily coming in.
vi: From this spot, the entrance to the yard was quite clear, where everyone was steadily gathering.
tr: From where we are kneeling, we can see the courtyard entrance where people are constantly streaming in very well.
es: From where we are kneeling, we have a good view of the entrance to the courtyard, where people keep arriving.

en: It must be Janine she meant me to see, because there she is, paired with a new woman, not the former one; someone I don't recognize.
vi: She must have noticed Janine, because there she was, with a new pair, not the previous one, someone I had never seen before.
tr: The person he wants me to see must be Janine, because there she is, paired with a new woman, the old one is gone; someone I don't recognize.
es: Deglen must want me to look at Janine, who is paired with a woman who is not the usual one; she is someone I don't recognize.

en: Janine must have been transferred then, to a new household, a new posting.
vi: So Janine had been transferred, to a new household, a new assignment.
tr: Janine must have been assigned to a new house, a new duty in this case.
es: So Janine must have been transferred to a new house, a new assignment.

en: It's early for that, has something gone wrong with her breast milk?
vi: Too soon, or perhaps her milk had gone bad?
tr: Actually, it's still early for this, could there have been a problem with the breast milk?
es: It's very soon for that, or could something have gone wrong with the milk from her breasts?

en: Thatwould be the only reason they'd move her, unless there's been a fight over the baby; which happens more than you'd think.
vi: That was the only possibility, unless there was a dispute over the baby, which was not as uncommon as one might think.
tr: If there wasn't a fight over the child, this could be the only reason for her reassignment; these kinds of fights happen more often than thought.
es: That would be the only reason for her to be transferred, unless there had been some fight over the baby, which happens more often than one might imagine.

en: Once she had it, she may have resisted giving it up.
vi: Once she had given birth, she might resist giving it away.
tr: Once she gave birth to the child, she might have resisted giving it up.
es: After having it, she might have refused to give it up.

en: I can see that.
vi: That I could understand.
tr: I can understand that.
es: It's understandable.

en: Her body under the red dress looks very thin, skinny almost, and she's lost that pregnant glow.
vi: Her body under the red fabric looked very thin, almost emaciated, the glow of pregnancy no longer there.
tr: Her body under the red dress looks very thin, almost skeletal, moreover, she has lost that pregnancy glow.
es: Under the red dress, her body looks very thin, almost gaunt, and has lost the glow of pregnancy.

en: Her face is white and peaked, as if the juice is being sucked out of her.
vi: Her face was pale and pointed, as if all the life had been drained out.
tr: Her face is white and emaciated as if her vital essence has been drained.
es: Her face is white and gaunt, as if all the fluid had been drained from her body.

en: "It was no good, you know," Ofglen says near the side of my head.
vi: "It’s not pleasant at all, you know," Ofglen said close to my ear.
tr: “It was of no use, you know,” says Gleninki, from beside my head.
es: —It didn't go well, you know? —Deglen tells me, bringing his head closer to mine—.

en: "It was a shredder after all."
vi: "It turned into a shredder."
tr: “In the end, it was just a meat grinder.”
es: It was like a rag.

en: She means Janine's baby, the baby that passed throughJanine on its way to somewhere else.
vi: She was talking about Janine's child, the one who had passed by Janine on the way to somewhere else.
tr: She means Janine's baby, the one Janine felt inside her while going somewhere else.
es: It refers to Janine's baby, the baby that passed through Janine's life on its way to somewhere else.

en: The baby Angela.
vi: The child's name was Angela.
tr: Angela baby.
es: Baby Angela.

en: It was wrong, to name her too soon.
vi: In the end, it was still a mistake, naming her so hastily.
tr: It was wrong to name her so quickly.
es: It was a mistake to give it a name so soon.

en: I feel an illness, in the pit of my stomach.
vi: I felt a gnawing sensation in my stomach.
tr: I feel a discomfort in the pit of my stomach.
es: I feel a pain in the pit of my stomach.

en: Not an illness, an emptiness.
vi: Not gnawing, but empty.
tr: Not discomfort, but an emptiness.
es: It's not a pain, it's an emptiness.

en: I don't want to know what was wrong with it.
vi: I didn't want to know what had gone wrong.
tr: I don't want to know what's wrong with her.
es: I don't want to know what went wrong.

en: "My God," I say.
vi: "Oh God," I said.
tr: "My God," I say.
es: —My God —I exclaimed.

en: To go through all that, fornothing.
vi: After going through all that, and ending up with nothing.
tr: Enduring all this for nothing.
es: Going through all that for nothing.

en: Worse than nothing.
vi: Worse than nothing.
tr: Worse than nothing.
es: Worse than nothing.

en: "It's her second," Ofglen says.
vi: “That's the second one already,” said Ofglen.
tr: “The second baby,” says Gleninki.
es: —It's the second one —Deglen explains to me—.

en: "Not counting her own, before.
vi: “Not counting the stepchild from before.
tr: “If we don't count her own.
es: Not counting the one he had before.

en: She had an eighth-month miscarriage, didn't you know?"
vi: She had a miscarriage at eight months, didn't you know?”
tr: She had a miscarriage at eight months, didn't you know?”
es: She had a miscarriage at eight months, did you know?

en: We watch as Janine enters the roped-off enclosure, in her veil of untouchability, of bad luck.
vi: We watched intently as Janine walked into the middle of the circle, wrapped in misfortune, an untouchable veil.
tr: We are watching Janine, shrouded in untouchability and bad luck, enter the cordoned-off area.
es: We observe Janine, who crosses the cordoned-off area, dressed in her veil of untouchable bad luck.

en: She sees me, she must see me, but she looks right through me.
vi: She saw me, she must have seen me, but she looked right through me.
tr: She sees me, she must see me, but her gaze seems to pass right through me.
es: She looks at me, she must be looking at me, but she doesn't see me.

en: No smile of triumph this time.
vi: This time, no triumphant smile.
tr: No triumphant smile this time.
es: She no longer smiles triumphantly.

en: She turns, kneels, and all I can see now is her back and the thin bowed shoulders.
vi: She turned away, knelt down, and now I could only see her back and her slender, slanted shoulders.
tr: She turns and kneels, now all I can see is her back and her slender, curved shoulders.
es: She turns and kneels, now all I see is her back and her thin, slumped shoulders.

en: "She thinks it's her fault," Ofglen whispers.
vi: “She thinks it's her fault,” Ofglen whispered.
tr: “She thinks it's her fault,” whispers Gleninki.
es: —She thinks it's her fault —whispers Deglen—.

en: "Two in a row.
vi: “Two times in a row.
tr: “Two in a row.
es: Two in a row.

en: For being sinful.
vi: For committing a crime.
tr: Because she is a sinner.
es: For having sinned.

en: She used a doctor, they say, it wasn't her Commander's at all."
vi: She used the doctor, it's rumored, not the Commander of this house.”
tr: They say she used a doctor, the baby wasn't from the Commander.”
es: They say she did it with a doctor, who wasn't her Commander’s.

en: I can't say I do know or Ofglen will wonder how.
vi: I can't say I already knew, otherwise Ofglen would be surprised.
tr: I can't say I know, otherwise Glen would wonder how I knew.
es: I can't tell Deglen that I know, because she would ask me how I found out.

en: As far as she's
vi: As far as she knows, she herself is my only source of information on these kinds of things; things she understands astonishingly well.
tr: As long as she has her ear to the ground, she's my only source for this kind of information; she has an astonishing amount of it.
es: As far as she knows, she is my only source for this kind of information; and it's surprising how much she knows.

en: aware, she herself is my only source, for this kind of information; of which she has a surprising amount.
vi: As far as she knows, she herself is my only source of information on these kinds of things; things she understands astonishingly well.
tr: As long as she has her ear to the ground, she's my only source for this kind of information; she has an astonishing amount of it.
es: As far as she knows, she is my only source for this kind of information; and it's surprising how much she knows.

en: How would she have found out about Janine?
vi: How does she know about Janine?
tr: How did she find out about what happened to Janine?
es: How did she find out about Janine?

en: The Marthas?
vi: Through the Marthas?
tr: From the Marthas?
es: From the Marthas?

en: Janine's shopping partner?
vi: The person paired with Janine for shopping?
tr: Or from Janine's shopping partner?
es: From Janine's shopping partner?

en: Listening at closed doors, to the Wives over their tea and wine, spinning their webs.
vi: Eavesdropping behind doors, now the Ladies' tea and liquor hours, while setting traps.
tr: By listening to the Wives knitting behind closed doors while drinking tea and wine?
es: Or by listening behind doors, when the Wives gather to drink tea or wine and weave their fabrics.

en: Will Serena
vi: Would Serena
tr: If I do what she wants, would Serena Joy talk about me like that too?
es: Will Serena

en: Joy talk about me like that, if I do as she wants?
vi: Joy talk about me like that, if I were to follow her wishes?
tr: If I do what she wants, would Serena Joy talk about me like that too?
es: Joy talk about me like that, if I do what she wants?

en: Agreed to it right away, really she didn't care, anything with two legs and a good you-know-what was fine with her.
vi: Instant nod, indeed she doesn't need to, just having two legs and a usable thing is more than enough.
tr: She agreed immediately, she didn't actually care, she was okay with anyone who had two legs and something good.
es: She agreed right away, she really didn't care, anything with two legs and a good you-know-what is fine with them.

en: They aren't squeamish, they don't have the same feelings we do.
vi: They don't know disgust, they don't have emotions like we do.
tr: They don't know what disgust is, they don't have our feelings.
es: They have no scruples, they don't have the same feelings as we do.

en: And the rest of them leaning forward in their chairs, My dear, all horror and prurience.
vi: And the rest of them on the bench craning their necks, oh my, how horrified and greedy they are.
tr: And the guests lean forward from their chairs, Oh my God, with horror and lust.
es: And the others, sitting in their chairs, leaning forward, my God, all horror and lust.

en: How could she?
vi: How?
tr: How could she do it?
es: How could it?

en: Where?
vi: When?
tr: Where?
es: Where?

en: When?
vi: Where?
tr: When?
es: When?

en: As they did no doubt with Janine.
vi: How Janine must have endured.
tr: Undoubtedly, just like what they did for Janine.
es: As they undoubtedly did with Janine.

en: "That's terrible," I say.
vi: "It's terrible," I said.
tr: "This is a terrible thing," I say.
es: —It's terrible —I say.

en: It's like Janine, though, to take it upon herself, to decide the baby's flaws were due to her alone.
vi: But it is also true that Janine, indeed, has a habit of taking things upon herself, considering the child's disability to be her own fault.
tr: However, blaming herself for everything and deciding that the child's disabilities are her own fault is exactly the kind of behavior typical of Janine.
es: Anyway, it is very typical of Janine to take on the responsibility, to decide that the baby's defect was solely her fault.

en: But people will do anything rather than admit that their lives have no meaning.
vi: But people are willing to do anything to avoid admitting that their lives have no meaning.
tr: But people will do anything rather than admit that their lives have no significance.
es: But people are capable of anything rather than admitting that their lives are meaningless.

en: No use, that is.
vi: Useless, rather.
tr: Rather than saying they are useless, I mean.
es: It's useless.

en: No plot.
vi: No direction.
tr: Unscripted.
es: There is no conspiracy that matters.

en: One morning while we were getting dressed, I noticed that Janine was still in her white cotton nightgown.
vi: One morning, while changing clothes, I noticed that Janine was still wearing her white nightgown.
tr: One morning, while we were getting dressed, I noticed that Janine was still standing in her white cotton nightgown.
es: One morning, while we were getting dressed, I noticed that Janine still had her nightgown on.

en: She was just sitting there on the edge of her bed.
vi: She just sat there on the edge of the bed.
tr: She was just sitting on the edge of her bed.
es: She had remained sitting on the edge of her bed.

en: I looked over towards the double doors of the gymnasium, where the Aunt usually stood, to see if she'd noticed, but the Aunt wasn't there.
vi: I looked out towards the double doors of the gymnasium, where the duty aunt usually stood, to see if she had noticed, but she wasn't there.
tr: I looked towards the place where the Aunts usually stood, at the double doors of the gym, to see if he noticed it too, but the Aunt was not there.
es: I glanced at the double doors of the gym, where there used to be an Aunt, to see if she had noticed, but there was no Aunt.

en: By that time they were more confident about us; sometimes they left us unsupervised in the classroom and even the cafeteria for minutes at a time.
vi: By this time, they trusted us more, sometimes leaving us unsupervised in the classroom or even in the canteen for several minutes.
tr: By then, they had come to trust us quite a bit; sometimes they would leave us alone in the classroom, and occasionally, even for a few minutes, in the cafeteria.
es: At that time they trusted us more, and occasionally left us unsupervised in class, and even in the cafeteria, for a few minutes.

en: Probably she'd ducked out for a smoke or a cup of coffee.
vi: She must have sneaked out for a cigarette or a cup of coffee.
tr: She had slipped away for a cigarette or a cup of coffee.
es: They probably disappeared to smoke a cigarette or have a cup of coffee.

en: Look, I said to Alma, who had the bed next to mine.
vi: Look, I told Alma, next to my bed.
tr: Look, I said to Alma, the owner of the bed next to mine.
es: Look, I said to Alma, whose bed was next to mine.

en: Alma looked at Janine.
vi: Alma looked over at Janine.
tr: Alma looked at Janine.
es: Alma looked at Janine.

en: Then we both walked over to her.
vi: Then both of us went over there.
tr: Then we both walked towards her.
es: Then the two of us approached her.

en: Get your clothes on, Janine, Alma said, to Janine's white back.
vi: Put your clothes on, Janine, Alma said to the white back.
tr: Put on your clothes, Janine, said Alma, to Janine's white back.
es: Get dressed, Janine, Alma said to her back.

en: We don't want extra prayers on account of you.
vi: We don't want to have to pray more because of you.
tr: We don't want to get extra prayer punishment because of you.
es: We don't want to pray twice because of you.

en: But Janine didn't move.
vi: But Janine didn't move.
tr: But Janine did not move.
es: But Janine didn't move.

en: By that time Moira had come over too.
vi: At this moment, Moira had also arrived.
tr: By that time, Moira had also arrived.
es: Moira had also approached.

en: It was before she'd broken free, the second time.
vi: That was before she escaped, the next time.
tr: This was before she broke the beam for the second time.
es: It was before she escaped for the second time.

en: She was still limping from what they'd done to her feet.
vi: She was still limping, a consequence of the foot massage.
tr: She was still limping because of what they did to her feet.
es: He was still limping because of what they had done to his feet.

es: The Commander looked at me with his frank and childlike gaze.

en: Oh yes, he said.
vi: Ah right, he said.
tr: Ah, yes, he said.
es: Oh yes, he said.

en: I've read the magazines, that's what they were pushing, wasn't it?
vi: I do read the magazine, that's exactly what they keep pushing all day, isn't it?
tr: I had read the magazines, this is what they were putting forward, right?
es: I have read the magazines, it is what they promoted, right?

en: But look at the stats, my dear.
vi: But look at the data, young lady.
tr: And look at these statistics, dear.
es: But consider the testimonies, dear.

en: Was it really worth it, falling in love?
vi: Is it really worth it, that whole thing?
tr: Was it really worth it, to fall in love?
es: Was it really worth falling in love?

en: Arranged marriages have always worked out just as well, if not better.
vi: Arranged marriages always yield just as good results, if not better.
tr: Arranged marriages, if not better, work at least as well as the previous ones.
es: Arranged marriages have always worked perfectly well, at the very least.

en: Love, said Aunt Lydia with distaste.
vi: Love, Aunt Lydia said with disgust.
tr: Love, said Aunt Lydia, with disgust.
es: Love, said Aunt Lydia in a disgusted tone.

en: Don't let me catch you at it.
vi: Don't let me catch you in the act.
tr: Don't let me catch you messing with this nonsense.
es: Don't let me catch you in that.

en: No mooning and June-ing around here, girls.
vi: Hey girls, this is not the place for dreamy flirtations.
tr: No wandering around aimlessly here, girls.
es: No daydreaming, girls.

en: Wagging her finger at us.
vi: A finger raised in admonishment.
tr: She wagged her finger at us.
es: Waving her finger in front of us.

en: Love is not the point.
vi: The issue is not love.
tr: Love is not what matters.
es: Love doesn't count.

en: Those years were just an anomaly, historically speaking, the Commander said.
vi: Those years were merely off course, historically speaking, the Commander replied.
tr: Speaking in a historical context, those years were a complete anomaly, said the Commander.
es: Historically speaking, those years were simply an anomaly, argued the Commander.

en: Just a fluke.
vi: They were just disasters.
tr: They only happened by accident; all we did was align everything with Nature's norms.
es: A fiasco.

en: All we've done is return things to Nature's norm.
vi: We only did the job of restoring the standards of Great Nature.
tr: They only happened by accident; all we did was align everything with Nature's norms.
es: All we have done is return things to the course of Nature.

en: Women's Prayvaganzas are for group weddings like this, usually.
vi: The wishes of women usually gather for collective weddings like this, often so.
tr: The Women's Prayer Ceremony is generally organized for such group marriages.
es: The Women's Pilgrimage is generally organized for group weddings, like this one.

en: The men's are for military victories.
vi: Men, on the other hand, gather for military victories.
tr: The men's ceremony is for military victories.
es: The men's pilgrimages are for military victories.

en: These are the things we are supposed to rejoice in the most, respectively.
vi: These are the events we should celebrate the most, in order of importance.
tr: These were, respectively, the things we should be most happy about.
es: This is one of the things that should rejoice us the most.

en: Sometimes though, for the women, they're for a nun who recants.
vi: However, sometimes women's gatherings are organized on the occasion of a nun leaving the convent.
tr: However, sometimes this ceremony was also held for a nun who had renounced her faith.
es: However, on occasions, and in the case of women, they are organized when a nun decides to retract.

en: Most of that happened earlier, when they were rounding them up, but they still unearth a few these days, dredge them up from underground, wherethey've been hiding, like moles.
vi: Most of these occurred long ago, during times when they were being hunted, but even now, a few are still unearthed, dug out from the underground world where they were hiding, like moles.
tr: Most of these happened earlier, during the period when they were gathering the nuns, but even today they still find one or two, digging up the underground where they hide like moles.
es: Most of these cases took place at the beginning, when they were cornered; but even in these times, some are discovered, and they are made to leave hiding, where they have been burrowing like moles.

en: They have that look about them too: weak-eyed, stunned by too much light.
vi: They somewhat resemble that: squinting eyes, bewildered by the excess of light.
tr: They don't exactly give a different impression: they are dazed by the bright light with their myopic eyes.
es: And they look the same: weakened eyes, a dazed look from the excess of light.

en: The old ones they send off to the Colonies right away, but the young fertile ones they try to convert, and when they succeed we all come here to watch them go through the ceremony, renounce their celibacy, sacrifice it to the common good.
vi: The old women are immediately sent to the Colonies, but the younger ones who are still fertile are persuaded to convert, and if successful, we witness them at the ceremony, swearing to renounce their celibate life and dedicate themselves to the community's benefit.
tr: The elderly nuns are sent to the Colonies without delay, but they try to convert the young and fertile ones from their faith, and when they succeed, we all gather to watch them go through this ceremony, renouncing their vows of celibacy and sacrificing it for the benefit of society.
es: The older ones are sent directly to the Colonies, but the young and fertile ones are attempted to be converted and, when they succeed, we all come here to see them celebrate the ceremony of renouncing celibacy and sacrificing themselves for the common good.

en: They kneel and the Commander prays and then they take the red veil, as the rest
vi: They kneel down, the Commander reads a prayer, and they receive the red veil, just like all of us did before.
tr: They kneel and the Commander prays and they take the red veil, just as we have done.
es: They kneel and the Commander prays and then they take the red veil, just as all of us have done.

en: of us have done.
vi: They kneel down, the Commander reads a prayer, and they receive the red veil, just like all of us did before.
tr: They kneel and the Commander prays and they take the red veil, just as we have done.
es: They kneel and the Commander prays and then they take the red veil, just as all of us have done.

en: They aren't allowed to become Wives though; they're considered, still, too dangerous for positions of such power.
vi: However, they are not allowed to become Wives; at this point, they are still considered too dangerous to be placed in such a position of power.
tr: Still, they are not allowed to become Wives; they are considered too dangerous for such a powerful position.
es: However, they are not allowed to become Wives. They are still considered too dangerous to access such positions of power.

en: There's an odor of witch about them, something mysterious and exotic; it remains despite the scrubbing and the welts on their feet and the time they've spent in Solitary.
vi: They exude a witch-like aura, a strange mystical feeling, despite having been scrubbed, bearing the marks on their feet, and having spent some time in solitary confinement.
tr: The scent of witchcraft clings to them, the scent of something mysterious and exotic; despite their scrubbing and the marks of the rods on their soles and the time spent in the cell, this scent remains.
es: They seem surrounded by a witch's aura, something mysterious and exotic; something that remains in them despite the scrubbing and the sores on their feet, and the time they have spent isolated.

en: They always have those welts, they've always done that time, so rumor goes: they don't let go easily.
vi: They always receive those lash marks, always have to sit in confinement, according to rumors: they do not give up easily.
tr: These marks always remain on their soles, they have always done this, the rumor goes: they don't let go of a person easily.
es: They always have sores, they had them back then, or so it is rumored: they do not go away easily.

en: Many of them choose the Colonies instead.
vi: Many would rather choose the Colonies.
tr: Most of the nuns choose the Colonies instead, none of us want to end up with one of them as a shopping partner.
es: Anyway, many of them choose the Colonies.

en: None of us likes to draw one for a shopping partner.
vi: None of us want to pair up for daily shopping with them.
tr: Most of the nuns choose the Colonies instead, none of us want to end up with one of them as a shopping partner.
es: None of us likes having them as shopping companions.

en: They are more broken than the rest of us; it's hard to feel comfortable with them.
vi: They are more prone to breakdowns than the rest of us; being with them is never comfortable.
tr: They are more broken than we are; it is hard to feel comfortable around them.
es: They are more broken than the rest of us; it is difficult to feel comfortable with them.

en: The mothers have stood the white-veiled girls in place and have returned to their chairs.
vi: The mothers have arranged the daughters, veiled in white, into rows and returned to their seats.
tr: The mothers had taken their daughters with white veils to their places and now had returned to their chairs.
es: The mothers have placed the girls adorned with white veils in their spots, and have returned to their seats.

en: There's a little crying going on among them, some mutual patting and hand-holding, the ostentatious use of handkerchiefs.
vi: There were small sobs among them, hands patting and holding each other, handkerchiefs being pulled out and used noisily.
tr: There were light sobs among them, mutual arm nudges and hand holdings, using handkerchiefs just for show.
es: Among them, there is a brief whimpering, mutual pats and handshakes, and the ostentatious use of handkerchiefs.

en: The Commander continues with the service:
vi: The leader continued the ceremony:
tr: The commander continues with the ceremony:
es: The Commander continues with the service:

en: "I will that women adorn themselves in modest apparel," he says,
vi: “I want women to dress modestly,” he said, “with decency and propriety; not with elaborate hairstyles, gold, pearls, or expensive clothes;
tr: “I desire that women adorn themselves with modest clothing,” he says.
es: —I desire that women adorn themselves with modest apparel —he says—, with decency and propriety; not with braided hair, or gold, or pearls, or expensive clothes;

en: "with shamefacedness and sobriety; not with braided hair, or gold, or pearls, or costly array;
vi: “I want women to dress modestly,” he said, “with decency and propriety; not with elaborate hairstyles, gold, pearls, or expensive clothes;
tr: “With shamefacedness and sobriety; not with braided hair, gold, pearls, or expensive costumes; but (for they have become women professing godliness) with good works.
es: —I desire that women adorn themselves with modest apparel —he says—, with decency and propriety; not with braided hair, or gold, or pearls, or expensive clothes;

en: "But (which becometh women professing godliness) with good works.
vi: "But rather good deeds, as is proper for women who profess to worship God."
tr: “With shamefacedness and sobriety; not with braided hair, gold, pearls, or expensive costumes; but (for they have become women professing godliness) with good works.
es: "But (which applies to women who declare themselves devout) good works."

en: "Let the woman learn in silence with all subjection."
vi: “When listening to teachings, women must be silent and completely submissive.”
tr: “Let a woman learn quietly with full submission.”
es: "Let the woman learn in silence, with complete submission —at this point, he gives us a look—.

en: Here he looks us over.
vi: Then he looked around at all of us.
tr: Here, he scans us with his eyes.
es: "Let the woman learn in silence, with complete submission —at this point, he gives us a look—.

en: "All," he repeats.
vi: “Completely,” he repeated.
tr: “Completely,” he repeats.
es: Complete —he repeats.

en: "But I suffer not a woman to teach, nor to usurp authority over the man, but to be in silence.
vi: “I do not permit a woman to teach or to assume authority over a man; she must be quiet.
tr: “However, I do not permit a woman to teach or to assume authority over a man; she must be quiet.
es: "I do not permit a woman to teach or to assume authority over a man; she must be quiet."

en: "For Adam was first formed, then Eve.
vi: "For Adam was formed first, then Eve."
tr: For Adam was formed first, then Eve.
es: "For Adam was formed first, then Eve."

en: "And Adam was not deceived, but the woman being deceived was in the transgression.
vi: “It was not Adam who was deceived, but the woman who was deceived and became a sinner.”
tr: And Adam was not deceived, but the woman being deceived was in transgression.
es: »And Adam was not deceived, but the woman, being deceived, committed a transgression.

en: "Notwithstanding she shall be saved by childbearing, if they continue in faith and charity and holiness with sobriety."
vi: “However, the woman will be saved through childbearing, if they continue in faith, love, and holiness with propriety.”
tr: However, she will be saved through childbearing, if they continue in faith, love, and holiness with propriety.”
es: »Nevertheless, she will be saved through childbearing if she continues in faith and love and holiness with sobriety.

en: Saved by childbearing, I think.
vi: Saved by having children, I thought.
tr: I'm thinking that having a child is a way to be saved.
es: To be saved through childbirth, I think.

en: What did we suppose would save us, in the time before?
vi: So what did we think would save us, back then?
tr: In the previous period, I wonder what we thought would save us?
es: And what saved us before?

en: "He should tell that to the Wives," Ofglen murmurs, "when they're into the sherry."
vi: “He should preach that to the Wives,” Ofglen whispered, “while they’re busy guzzling cherry wine.”
tr: “The Wives should have told them,” Gleninki murmurs. “While swimming in Sherry.”
es: —You should tell that to the Wives —murmurs Deglen—, when they indulge in drinking —she refers to the paragraph about sobriety.

en: She means the part about sobriety.
vi: She was referring to the “temperance” part.
tr: She means the part about moderation.
es: —You should tell that to the Wives —murmurs Deglen—, when they indulge in drinking —she refers to the paragraph about sobriety.

en: It's safe to talk again, the Commander has finished the main ritual and they're doing
vi: It was safe to talk now, the Commander had finished the main ceremony and was now moving on to the ring and veil part.
tr: It’s safe to talk again; the Commander has finished the main part of the ceremony; now, they’re putting on the rings and lifting the veils.
es: Now we can speak again, the Commander has concluded the main ritual and they put on the rings and lift the veils.

en: the rings, lifting the veils.
vi: It was safe to talk now, the Commander had finished the main ceremony and was now moving on to the ring and veil part.
tr: It’s safe to talk again; the Commander has finished the main part of the ceremony; now, they’re putting on the rings and lifting the veils.
es: Now we can speak again, the Commander has concluded the main ritual and they put on the rings and lift the veils.

en: Boo, I think in my head.
vi: Wow, I thought.
tr: Ugh, I think to myself.
es: Tongo, I say mentally.

en: Take a good look, because it'stoo late now.
vi: Look closely, because it’s too late already.
tr: Look well, because now it’s too late.
es: Pay close attention, because now it is too late.

en: The Angels will qualify for Handmaids, later, especially if their new Wives can't produce.
vi: The Angels will be eligible for Handmaids later, especially if the new Wives can’t conceive.
tr: Later, the Angels will be entitled to Handmaids, especially if their new Wives can’t produce children.
es: The Angels will have rights to the Handmaids, later on, especially if their new Wives cannot reproduce.

en: But you girls are stuck.
vi: But you girls are stuck.
tr: However, girls, you’re nailed to where you are.
es: But you, girls, have been swindled.

en: What you see is what you get, zits and all.
vi: Take what you get, from sores onwards.
tr: What you get is limited to what you see.
es: What you get is what you see, with all its consequences.

en: But you aren't expected to love him.
vi: But no one demands you to love him.
tr: But you’re not expected to love them.
es: But no one expects you to love it.

en: You'll find that out soon enough.
vi: You’ll understand soon enough.
tr: You’ll understand this soon enough.
es: You will discover it very soon.

en: Just do your duty in silence.
vi: Just perform your duty in silence.
tr: Just perform your duty silently.
es: Simply fulfill your duty in silence.

en: When in doubt, when flat on your back, you can look at the ceiling.
vi: Whenever in doubt, lying flat on the bed, you can still look up at the high ceiling.
tr: When in doubt, when you lie on your back, you’re allowed to look at the ceiling.
es: When you doubt, when you lie on your backs, you can look at the ceiling.

en: Who knows what you may sec, up there?
vi: Who knows what you might see up there?
tr: Who knows what you’ll see up there?
es: Who knows what you will see up there.

en: Funeral wreaths and angels, constellations of dust, stellar or otherwise, the puzzles left by spiders.
vi: Funeral wreaths and angels, constellations of dust, nebulae or non-nebulae, the forgotten patterns of spiders.
tr: Funeral wreaths and angels, constellations of dust, stars or others, puzzles left by spiders.
es: Funeral wreaths and angels, constellations of dust, stellar or otherwise, the puzzles left by spiders.

en: There's always something to occupy the inquiring mind.
vi: There’s always something for a curious mind.
tr: There’s always something to occupy an inquisitive mind.
es: An unsettled mind always has something to occupy itself with.

en: Is anything wrong, dear?
vi: What's going on, my dear?
tr: Is there something, dear?
es: Is something wrong, dear?, an old joke used to say.

en: the old joke went.
vi: The joke is old.
tr: the old joke continues.
es: Is something wrong, dear?, an old joke used to say.

en: No, why?
vi: No, why?
tr: Hey, why?
es: No, why?

en: You moved.
vi: You just moved.
tr: You moved.
es: You have moved.

en: Just don't move.
vi: Don't move, that's all.
tr: Don't move.
es: Don't move.

en: What we're aiming for, says Aunt Lydia, is a spirit of camaraderie among women.
vi: What we aim for, Aunt Lydia said, is the spirit of camaraderie among women.
tr: The goal we aim for, says Aunt Lydia, is to create a spirit of camaraderie among women.
es: What we aim to achieve, says Aunt Lydia, is a spirit of camaraderie among women.

en: We must all pull together.
vi: We all must unite.
tr: We must all strive together.
es: We must all act in unison.

en: Camaraderie, shit, says Moira through the hole in the toilet cubicle.
vi: Teammate the Mercedes, Moira said through the wall hole.
tr: To hell with your camaraderie, says Moira, from the hole in the toilet stall.
es: Camaraderie, bullshit, says Moira through the toilet hole.

en: Right fucking on, Aunt Lydia, as they used to say.
vi: Talks like a charm, Aunt Lydia, as people often say.
tr: Keep pushing, Aunt Lydia, as they used to say.
es: Aunt Lydia can go to hell, as they used to say.

en: How much you want to bet she's got Janine down on her knees?
vi: How much do you bet she makes Janine kneel on the floor?
tr: How much would you bet that she made Janine kneel?
es: What do you bet she gets Janine to kneel?

en: What you think they get up to in that office of hers?
vi: What do you think they do in that office?
tr: Why do you think they go to her office?
es: What do you think they're plotting in her office?

en: I bet she's got her working away on that dried-up old withered.
vi: I bet her shriveled, dried-up thing has been used by that girl to do the trick...
tr: I bet Aunt Lydia is constantly working on her, that scrawny, old, withered—
es: I bet she makes her work on that dried-up, hairy, old and withered thing...

en: Moira!
vi: Moira!
tr: Moira!
es: Moira!, he exclaimed.

en: I say.
vi: I said.
tr: I say.
es: Moira!, he exclaimed.

en: Moira what?
vi: Moira what Moira?
tr: What about Moira?
es: "Moira, what?" she whispers.

en: she whispers.
vi: she whispered.
tr: she whispers.
es: "Moira, what?" she whispers.

en: You know you've thought it.
vi: You thought so too, you know it.
tr: I know you're thinking about it.
es: "You know you've thought about it too."

en: It doesn't do any good to talk like that, I say, feeling nevertheless the impulse to giggle.
vi: Speaking like that isn't good at all, I said, but you still had to stifle your laughter.
tr: It's not right to talk like this at all, I say, still feeling the urge to giggle.
es: It is not good to talk that way, I asserted, though I felt the urge to laugh.

en: But I still pretended to myself, then, that we should try to preserve something resembling dignity.
vi: But I was still deceiving myself at that moment, thinking that I had to try to maintain something roughly like dignity.
tr: But back then, I was pretending to myself that we still needed to maintain something resembling dignity.
es: But back then, I imagined that we had to try to preserve something akin to dignity.

en: You were always such a wimp, Moira says, but with affection.
vi: You're always such a coward, Moira said, but with affection.
tr: You have always been a coward, says Moira, lovingly though.
es: "You were always such a prude," says Moira in an affected tone.

en: It does so do good.
vi: There's a big difference.
tr: It feels so good.
es: "Of course it's good."

en: It does.
vi: There is.
tr: Really.
es: It is.

en: And she's right, I know that now, as I kneel on this undeniably hard floor, listening to the ceremony drone on.
vi: And she was right, now I understand, as I kneel on the hard ground that strikes my senses, listening to the tedious ceremony.
tr: You were right, now I understand this as I kneel on this undeniably hard ground, listening to the ceremony that continues in a low and monotonous voice.
es: And he is right, I know it now, while I am kneeling on this irredeemably hard ground, listening to the hum of the ceremony.

en: There is something powerful in the whispering of obscenities, about those in power.
vi: There is something powerful in the whispered obscenities, aimed at the strong.
tr: There is something empowering about whispering the explicit remarks about the rulers from ear to ear.
es: There is something compelling about whispering obscenities about those in power.

en: There's something delightful about it, something naughty, secretive, forbidden, thrilling.
vi: There is something joyful, mischievous, hidden, forbidden, that makes one tremble with excitement.
tr: Moreover, there is something pleasant, mischievous, mysterious, forbidden, and exciting.
es: There is something delicious, something daring, stealthy, forbidden, exciting.

en: It's like a spell, of sorts.
vi: Just like a spell.
tr: Like magic, so to speak.
es: It's like a curse, in a way.

en: It deflates them, reduces
vi: It deflates them, brings them down to a manageable level.
tr: It brings them down, reduces them to a common denominator that can be dealt with.
es: It lowers them, reduces them to the common denominator in which they can be framed.

en: them to the common denominator where they can be dealt with.
vi: It deflates them, brings them down to a manageable level.
tr: It brings them down, reduces them to a common denominator that can be dealt with.
es: It lowers them, reduces them to the common denominator in which they can be framed.

en: In the paint of the washroom cubicle someone unknown had scratched: Aunt Lydia sucks.
vi: On the plaster wall of the restroom, an anonymous person had scrawled: Aunt Lydia sucks.
tr: Someone unknown had scratched on the wall of the shower cabin: Aunt Lydia is sulking.
es: On the paint of the toilet, someone unknown had scribbled: Aunt Lydia sucks.

en: It was like a flag waved from a hilltop in rebellion.
vi: It was the flag raised on the hill of rebellion.
tr: It was like a flag waving from the top of a hill in rebellion.
es: It was like a flag waved from a hill during a rebellion.

en: The mere idea of Aunt Lydia doing such a thing was in itself heartening.
vi: Just thinking about Aunt Lydia doing that is enough to warm the heart.
tr: Even the mere idea that Aunt Lydia did something was encouraging in itself.
es: The mere idea that Aunt Lydia would do such a thing was encouraging.

en: So now I imagine, among these Angels and their drained white brides, momentous grunts and sweating, damp furry encounters; or, better, ignominious failures, cocks like three-week-old carrots, anguished fumblings upon flesh cold and unresponding as uncooked fish.
vi: So I imagine the angels and those exhausted brides in their white dresses, amidst the glorious panting and sweat pouring down like a shower, the wet and hairy clashes; or even better, the miserable failures, with a penis like a three-week-old carrot, struggling to find its way on cold, unresponsive flesh like uncooked fish.
tr: Therefore, now I bring to my mind the ultimate serious grumblings and sweatings that will take place among these Angels and dried white brides, facing them with their damp hairs; or, better yet, their disgraceful failures, tools turned into three-week-old carrots, painful, clumsy writhings on cold and unresponsive flesh like uncooked fish.
es: So now, between these Angels and their white, desiccated wives, I imagine transcendental grunts and sweats, wet and hairy encounters; or, better yet, ignominious failures, cocks resembling overripe carrots, anguished groping of flesh, cold and unfeeling like raw fish.

en: When it's over at last and we are walking out, Ofglen says to me in her light, penetrating whisper: "We know you're seeing him alone."
vi: On the way out when the ceremony finally ended, Ofglen whispered in her usual light and sharp voice: "We know you still meet him in private."
tr: At the end of the ceremony, as we were leaving, Gleninki says in that soft, penetrating whisper of hers: "We know you met with him alone."
es: When the ceremony finally concludes and we leave, Deglen says to me in a faint but piercing whisper: —We know you see him alone.

en: "Who?" I say, resisting the urge to look at her.
vi: "Who?" I said, trying to muster the strength to look at her.
tr: “With whom?” I say, resisting the urge to look at him.
es: —To whom? —I ask her, resisting the urge to look at her.

en: I know who.
vi: I know who it is.
tr: I know who it is.
es: I know who she is referring to.

en: "Your Commander," she says.
vi: "Your commander," she said.
tr: "With your Commander," he says.
es: —To your Commander —he clarifies—.

en: "We know you have been."
vi: "We've known for a long time."
tr: "We have known from the very beginning."
es: We know you've been seeing him —I ask how—.

en: I ask her how.
vi: I asked how she knew.
tr: I ask how they found out.
es: We know you've been seeing him —I ask how—.

en: "We just know," she says.
vi: "We know, that's all," she said.
tr: “We learned it, didn't we,” he says.
es: We simply know —he responds—.

en: "What does he want?
vi: "What does he want?
tr: “What does he want?
es: What is he looking for?

en: Kinky sex?"
vi: Sadism, masochism?"
tr: A perverted love?”
es: Sexual perversions?

en: It would be hard to explain to her what he does want, because I still have no name for it.
vi: It's not easy to explain to her what he wants, because I myself haven't been able to name it yet.
tr: It would be difficult to explain what she wanted, because I still hadn't found a name for it.
es: It would be difficult to explain to him what he wants, because I still don't know how to name it.

en: How can I describe what really goes on between us?
vi: How can I recount what really happened?
tr: How can I explain what is really going on between us?
es: How to describe to her what really happens between us?

en: She would laugh, for one thing.
vi: She will laugh, at the very least.
tr: She would laugh, for one.
es: First of all, she would laugh.

en: It's easier for me to say, "In a way."
vi: It's simpler to say it like this, "Something like that."
tr: For me, saying "In a way," is easier.
es: It's easier for me to say:

en: That at least has the dignity of coercion.
vi: At least it sounds dignified for someone being coerced.
tr: In this, at least, there is the weight of trying.
es: —In a certain way —this response has, at least, the dignity of coercion.

en: She thinks about this.
vi: She pondered over this matter.
tr: He is thinking about this.
es: She reflects.

en: "You'd be surprised," she says, "how many of them do."
vi: "You would be surprised," she said, "if you knew how many people enjoy that."
tr: "If you knew how many wanted it," he says, "you would be surprised."
es: —You'd be surprised —he comments— to know how many do it.

en: "I can't help it," I say.
vi: “There's nothing I can do,” I said.
tr: “There is nothing I can do,” I say.
es: —I can't help it —I justify myself—.

en: "I can't say I won't go."
vi: “I can't say I don't want to go.”
tr: “I can't say I won't come.”
es: I can't tell her that I won't go —she should know that.

en: She ought to know that.
vi: You should know that.
tr: He must know this.
es: I can't tell her that I won't go —she should know that.

en: We're on the sidewalk now and it's not safe to talk, we're too close to the others and the protective whispering of the crowd is gone.
vi: We had reached the sidewalk and talking was no longer safe, others were too close and the murmuring crowd no longer provided cover.
tr: Now we are on the sidewalk and it is not safe to talk, we are both too close to the others and the protective murmur of the crowd has ceased.
es: We are already on the sidewalk and it is not convenient to talk, we are very close to the rest and we no longer have the protection of the crowd's murmur.

en: We walk in silence, lagging behind, until finally she judges she can say,
vi: We walked in silence, lagging behind, until she deemed it safe to say, "Of course, it's not possible."
tr: We walk quietly, lingering at the back, until finally, "Of course you can't say that.
es: We walk in silence, lagging behind, until she thinks it is prudent to say:

en: "Of course you can't.
vi: We walked in silence, lagging behind, until she deemed it safe to say, "Of course, it's not possible."
tr: We walk quietly, lingering at the back, until finally, "Of course you can't say that.
es: —Of course you can't.

en: But find out and tell us."
vi: "But find out and tell us."
tr: Still, find out and tell us," until we are convinced that you can say.
es: But find out and tell us.

en: "Find out what?" I say.
vi: “What are you trying to find out?” I said.
tr: "What will I find?" I say.
es: —Find out what? —I asked, puzzled.

en: I feel rather than see the slight turning of her head.
vi: I felt rather than saw her gently turn her head.
tr: I feel it more than I see her slightly turning her head.
es: I almost seem to perceive the slight movement of his head.

en: "Anything you can."
vi: "Anything that works."
tr: "Everything you can find."
es: —Everything you can.
CHAPTER 35

en: Now there's a space to be filled, in the too-warm air of my room, and a time also; a space-time, between here and now and there and then, punctuated by dinner.
vi: Now there is an empty space to fill, amidst the overly warm atmosphere in the room, and time as well; a space-time, between Here and now and there then, ending with dinner.
tr: Now there is a space that needs to be filled in the very warm air of my room, and also a time; a space-time, between here and now and there and then, culminating with dinner.
es: Now, in the warm atmosphere of my room, I have a space to fill, and also a time; a space-time, between the here and now, the there and later, interrupted by dinner.

en: The arrival of the tray, carried up the stairs as if for an invalid.
vi: When the food tray arrives, carried up the stairs as if for an invalid.
tr: The tray being carried up the stairs as if for a bedridden patient.
es: The arrival of the tray, carried up the stairs as if I were an invalid.

en: An invalid, one who has been invalidated.
vi: A waste product, something that has become useless.
tr: A bedridden person, someone invalidated.
es: An invalid, someone who has been invalidated.

en: No valid passport.
vi: Worthless like a passport, with no way out.
tr: No valid passport.
es: Without a valid passport.

en: No exit.
vi: Worthless like a passport, with no way out.
tr: No exit.
es: No way out.

en: That was what happened, the day we tried to cross at the border, with our fresh passports that said we were not who we were: that Luke, for instance, had never been divorced, that we were therefore lawful, under the law.
vi: That was what happened, the day we planned to escape, carrying brand new passports that indicated we were not who we used to be: that Luke, for instance, had never been divorced, that therefore we were legal, according to the law.
tr: This is what happened on the day we tried to cross the border, with our new passports that claimed we were not who we were: for example, Luke had never been divorced, so according to the new laws, our union was legal.
es: That was what happened the day we tried to cross the border, with our brand-new passports that showed we were not who we were: that Luke, for example, had never been divorced, and therefore it was legal, according to the new law.

en: The man went inside with our passports, after we'd explained about the picnic and he'd glanced into the car and seen our daughter asleep, in her zoo of mangy animals.
vi: The police officer took the two passports inside, after hearing our explanation about going on a picnic and seeing our daughter sleeping in the car, amidst her tattered zoo.
tr: After we explained the picnic situation and he himself peeked inside the car and saw our daughter sleeping among the old fabric animals, the man went inside with our passports.
es: After we explained to him that we were going on a picnic and after he took a look inside the car and saw our daughter asleep, surrounded by her zoo of dirty animals, the man went inside with our passports; Luke patted my arm and got out of the car pretending to stretch his legs, and watched the man through the window of the immigration building.

en: Luke patted my arm and got out of the car as if to stretch his legs and watched the man through the window of the immigration building.
vi: Luke gently patted my hand and went outside the car, pretending to stretch his legs, observing the other person through the immigration office window.
tr: Luke tapped my arm and, as if wanting to get some air, stepped out of the car and watched the man through the immigration office window.
es: After we explained to him that we were going on a picnic and after he took a look inside the car and saw our daughter asleep, surrounded by her zoo of dirty animals, the man went inside with our passports; Luke patted my arm and got out of the car pretending to stretch his legs, and watched the man through the window of the immigration building.

en: I stayed in the car.
vi: I stayed in the car.
tr: I stayed in the car.
es: I stayed in the car.

en: I lit a cigarette, to steady myself, and drew the smoke in, a long breath of counterfeit relaxation.
vi: I lit a cigarette, to calm myself, and took a long drag, feigning relaxation.
tr: To calm myself, I lit a cigarette and took a deep drag, a long breath that provided artificial relief.
es: I lit a cigarette to calm myself and inhaled the smoke, a long puff of false relaxation.

en: I was watching two soldiers in the unfamiliar uniforms that were beginning, by then, to be familiar; they were standing idly beside the yellow-and-black-striped lift-up barrier.
vi: I was observing two soldiers in unfamiliar uniforms, which by now had gradually become familiar; they were idly standing by the yellow and black striped barrier.
tr: By that time, I was watching two soldiers in unusual uniforms, who were starting to become familiar; they were idly standing in front of the yellow-black striped lift-and-lower barrier.
es: I busied myself watching the soldiers dressed in those unfamiliar uniforms that, by then, were starting to become familiar; they were idly standing next to the yellow and black striped barrier, which was raised.

en: They weren't doing much.
vi: They weren't doing much.
tr: They weren't doing much.
es: They weren't doing much.

en: One of them was watching a flock of birds, gulls, lifting and eddying and landing on the bridge railing beyond.
vi: One of them was watching a flock of birds, seagulls, circling and landing, then flying over the barrier behind.
tr: One was watching a flock of birds, seagulls, that flew up, turned, and then landed again on the railings of the bridge on the other side.
es: One of them was watching a flock of birds that took flight, swirled, and perched on the railing of the bridge, on the other side.

en: Watching him, I watched themtoo.
vi: Watching him, I also looked at the flock of birds.
tr: While watching him, I also watched the birds.
es: I watched him, and at the same time, them.

en: Every-thing was the color it usually is, only brighter.
vi: Everything was still the same colors as before, only brighter.
tr: Everything was in its usual color, just brighter.
