es: Everything had the same color as always, only brighter.

en: It's going to be all right, I said, prayed in my head.
vi: It will be alright, I told myself, silently praying.
tr: Everything will go well, I said, I prayed silently.
es: Everything will be fine, I told myself, praying mentally.

en: Oh let it.
vi: Oh please.
tr: Oh, please let it go well.
es: Oh, allow it.

en: Let us cross, let us across.
vi: Let us through, let us through.
tr: Let's cross over, let's go to the other side.
es: Allow us to cross, allow us to cross.

en: Just this once and I'll do anything.
vi: Just this once, I will do anything.
tr: Just this time, then I'll do whatever it takes.
es: Just this once, and then I'll do anything.

en: What I thought I could do for whoever was listening that would be of the least use or even interest I'll never know.
vi: I thought of what I would do for anyone who was listening and could make any sense or even had any meaning, I would never know.
tr: For the one listening to this, whoever it may be, I will never know if what I think I can do will be of any use, or even if it will attract any interest.
es: It wouldn't make any sense, and not even be of interest, to know what I thought I could do for whoever was listening to me.

en: Then Luke got back into the car, too fast, and turned the key and reversed.
vi: Then Luke got back into the car, in a hurry, turned the key, and reversed.
tr: Then Luke got into the car, hastily, started the engine and put it in reverse.
es: Then Luke got back into the car very quickly, put the key in the ignition, and backed up.

en: He was picking up the phone,he said.
vi: He's on the phone, he said.
tr: He was making a phone call, he said.
es: He was going to make a phone call, he said.

en: And then he began to drive very quickly, and after that there was the dirt road and the woods and we jumped out of the car and began to run.
vi: Then he sped off, and soon we saw the dirt road with the forest, and we jumped out of the car and ran.
tr: And then he started driving very fast, then we entered that dirt road and the forest, and we jumped out of the car and started running.
es: And he started driving in a hurry, then a dirt road, the forest, and we jumped out of the car and started running.

en: A cottage, to hide in, a boat, I don't know what we thought.
vi: A hut, to hide, a boat, we didn't even know what we were praying for anymore.
tr: A cabin, to hide, a boat, I don't know what we were thinking.
es: A house to hide in, a boat, I don't know what we were thinking.

en: He said the passports
vi: He said the passports were perfectly secure, and we didn't have much time to prepare.
tr: He said the passports were perfect and we had very little time to make a plan.
es: He said the passports were safe, and we had very little time to plan it.

en: were foolproof, and we had so little time to plan.
vi: He said the passports were perfectly secure, and we didn't have much time to prepare.
tr: He said the passports were perfect and we had very little time to make a plan.
es: He said the passports were safe, and we had very little time to plan it.

en: Maybe he had a plan, a map of some kind in his head.
vi: Maybe he had prepared, had a kind of map in his head.
tr: Maybe he had a plan, some kind of map in his mind.
es: Maybe he had a plan, some kind of mental map.

en: As for me, I was only running: away, away.
vi: As for me, I just had to run: run far, as far as possible.
tr: As for me, I was just running: further, further away.
es: As for me, I just kept running and running.

en: I don't want to be telling this story.
vi: I don't want to tell this story.
tr: I don't want to be telling this story.
es: I don't want to tell this story.

en: I don't have to tell it.
vi: I don't necessarily have to tell.
tr: I don't actually have to explain.
es: I don't have to tell it.

en: I don't have to tell anything, to myself or to anyone else.
vi: I don't have to tell anything, to myself or anyone else.
tr: I don't have to explain anything, neither to myself nor to anyone else.
es: I don't have to tell anything, neither to myself nor to anyone else.

en: I could just sit here, peacefully.
vi: I can sit right here, quietly.
tr: I can just sit here, in peace.
es: I could simply sit here, in peace.

en: I could withdraw.
vi: I can withdraw.
tr: I can withdraw.
es: I could step aside.

en: It's possible to go so far in, so far down and back, they could never get you out.
vi: I have the right to retreat deep inside, dive deep to the bottom, where they can never find me.
tr: A person can go so far within themselves, so far down and back, that they can never be brought out again.
es: It is possible to go very far, inward, downward, and backward, they might never find you.

en: Nolite te bastardes carborundorum.
vi: Don't let the bastards grind you down.
tr: Don't let the bastards grind you down.
es: Don't let the bastards grind you down.

en: Fat lot of good it did her.
vi: How useful it would be for her to know.
tr: It didn't help her at all.
es: Boy, did he mess it up.

en: Why fight?
vi: What is the point of struggling?
tr: Why struggle?
es: Why fight?

en: That will never do.
vi: It's not a big deal.
tr: It will never work.
es: It will never work.

en: lx>ve? said the Commander.
vi: Love, huh? The commander has spoken.
tr: Love? said the Commander.
es: "Love?" said the Commander.

en: That's better.
vi: This one is better.
tr: This is better.
es: That's better.

en: That's something I know about.
vi: At least I am familiar with this one.
tr: Something I know.
es: It's something I know.

en: We can talk about that.
vi: Then we will talk about it.
tr: We can talk about this.
es: We can talk about it.

en: Falling in love, I said.
vi: When the moment came, I answered.
tr: To fall in love, I said.
es: Falling in love, I repeated.

en: Falling into it, we all did then, one way or another.
vi: Falling into it, all of us back then, no matter how.
tr: To fall into love, we all used to do it back then, in one way or another.
es: Falling into the clutches of love, it happened to all of us, in one way or another.

en: How could he have made such light of it?
vi: How could he take it so lightly?
tr: How could she have taken it so lightly?
es: How could he have turned it into something so empty?

en: Sneered even.
vi: And even sneer.
tr: Had she even belittled it?
es: Even sarcastic.

en: As if it was trivial for us, a frill, a whim.
vi: As if we were clinging to something trivial, a petty ornament, a whimsical fancy.
tr: As if it were insignificant to us, a show, a whim.
es: As if for us it were something trivial, a pose, a whim.

en: It was, on the contrary, heavy going.
vi: In reality, on the contrary, it was very difficult.
tr: On the contrary, it was laborious.
es: On the contrary, it was a difficult path.

en: It was the central thing; it was the way you understood yourself; if it never happened to you, not ever, you would be like a mutant, a creature from outer space.
vi: That was the key thing, the path through which one understands oneself; if one has never, ever encountered it, one would only be a monstrosity, a creature from outer space.
tr: It was the fundamental thing; it was the way to understand yourself; if it never happened to you, not even once, it meant you were mutated, a creature from the outside world.
es: It was the central problem, the way to understand oneself; if it never happened to you, ever, you could end up like a mutant, a creature from another galaxy.

en: Everyone knew that.
vi: Everyone knows this.
tr: Everyone knew this.
es: Anyone knew it.

en: Falling in love, we said; I fell for him.
vi: Fall, we say so; I make him fall. Fall, drop, descend, tumble.
tr: We used to say, falling in love; my heart fell for him.
es: To fall into the clutches of love, we said; I fell into his arms.

en: We were falling women.
vi: We are fallen women.
tr: We were the women who fell.
es: We were fallen women.

en: We believed in it, this downward motion: so lovely, like flying, and yet at the same time so dire, so extreme, so unlikely.
vi: We believe in it, in this downward motion: how lovely it is, like flying, yet how terrifying, extreme, and illusory it is.
tr: We believed in this downward movement: so affectionate, like flying, but at the same time so frightening, so extraordinary, so unexpected.
es: We believed in it, in this downward movement: as beautiful as flying, and yet, at the same time, so terrible, so extreme, so improbable.

en: God is love, they once said, but we reversed that, and love, like heaven, was always just around the corner.
vi: God is love, they used to say, but we have reversed it, and love, like bliss, is within reach.
tr: They used to say God is love, but we had reversed this, and love, like Heaven, was right within our reach.
es: God is love, they once said, but we turned the phrase upside down and love, like Heaven, was always just around the corner.

en: The more difficult it was to love the particular man beside us, the more we believed in Love, abstract and total.
vi: How difficult it is to love the person beside us, the more we believe in Love, an abstract and complete love.
tr: The harder it was to love that special man next to us, the more we believed in Love, abstract and whole.
es: The more we believed in abstract and total Love, the harder it was for us to love the man beside us.

en: We were waiting, always, for the incarnation.
vi: We wait, endlessly, longing for incarnation.
tr: We were always waiting for its embodiment.
es: We were always waiting for an incarnation.

en: That word, made flesh.
vi: The word becomes flesh.
tr: For this word to take on flesh and blood.
es: That word, made flesh.

en: And sometimes it happened, for a time.
vi: And sometimes you also encounter it, for a moment.
tr: Sometimes this would happen, for a while.
es: And sometimes it happened, for once.

en: That kind of love comes and goes and is hard to remember afterwards, like pain.
vi: That love comes and goes, and later it's hard to remember, like a pain.
tr: This kind of love comes and goes and later it is hard to remember, like pain.
es: That kind of love comes and goes and then it's hard to remember, like pain.

en: You would look at the man one day and you would think, / loved you, and the tense would be past, and you would be filled with a sense of wonder, because it was such an amazing and precarious and dumb thing to
vi: Then one day, people will look at that person and think, I once loved him, and there is a word "once" there, which is utterly surprising, because such a thing "once" happened is truly astonishing and precarious and foolish; and people will also understand why their friends avoided them, back then.
tr: One day you look at that man and think, I loved you, but the sentence is in the past tense and a sense of curiosity fills you, because what you did was surprising, doubtful, and foolish.
es: One day you looked at that man and thought I loved you, and you thought it in the past tense, and you felt amazed because having done so was foolish, something surprising and precarious; and you also understood why at that moment your friends had been evasive.

en: have done; and you would know too why your friends had been evasive about it, at the time.
vi: Then one day, people will look at that person and think, I once loved him, and there is a word "once" there, which is utterly surprising, because such a thing "once" happened is truly astonishing and precarious and foolish; and people will also understand why their friends avoided them, back then.
tr: Moreover, you understand why your friends, back then, avoided this topic.
es: One day you looked at that man and thought I loved you, and you thought it in the past tense, and you felt amazed because having done so was foolish, something surprising and precarious; and you also understood why at that moment your friends had been evasive.

en: There is a good deal of comfort, now, in remembering this.
vi: What a relief it is now, when I think back on it.
tr: Remembering this is quite comforting now.
es: Now, when I remember this, I feel great comfort.

en: Or sometimes, even when you were still loving, still falling, you'd wake up in the middle of the night, when the moonlight was coming through the window onto his sleeping face, making the shadows in the sockets of his eyes darker and more cavernous than in daytime, and you'd think, Who knows what they do, on their own or with other men?
vi: Or sometimes, right in the midst of still loving, still falling, one wakes up in the middle of the night, when the moonlight through the window floods his sleeping face, making the eye sockets even darker and deeper than during the day, and one thinks, Who knows what they do, when alone or among a group of men?
tr: On the other hand, sometimes, while still in love, while still falling in love, you would wake up in the middle of the night, moonlight seeping through the window and hitting their sleeping face, making the shadows in their eye sockets more hollow and deep than in daylight, and you would think.
es: Or sometimes, even when you were still in love, you would wake up in the middle of the night, when the moon came through the window and illuminated their sleeping face, darkening the shadows of their eye sockets and making them more cavernous than during the day, and you would think:

en: Who knows what they say or where they are likely to go?
vi: Who knows what they say or where they most often go?
tr: Who knows what they are doing, on their own or with other men? Who can know what they are saying or where they might possibly go?
es: Who knows what they do when they're alone, or with other men? Who knows what they say, or where they go?

en: Who can tell what they really are?
vi: Who can tell who they really are?
tr: Who can truly tell what they are?
es: Who can tell what they really are?

en: Under their daily-ness.
vi: Beneath the everyday exterior.
tr: When they are in their everyday appearance.
es: In everyday life.

en: Likely you would think at those times:
vi: And maybe at those times, people will think, What if he doesn't love me?
tr: Back then, you might have thought:
es: Probably, at those moments you would think:

en: What if he doesn't love me?
vi: And maybe at those times, people will think, What if he doesn't love me?
tr: What if they don't love me?
es: What if they don't love me?

en: Or you'd remember stories you'd read, in the newspapers, about women who had been foundoften women but sometimes they would be men, or children, that was the worstin ditches or forests or refrigerators in abandoned rented rooms, with their clothes on or off, sexually abused or not; at any rate killed.
vi: Or people will recall the stories they've read in the newspapers about missing women - usually women but sometimes men, or children, which is the worst - found in parks or forests, or in the refrigerators of abandoned apartments, either clothed or unclothed, violated or not; but all killed in the same way.
tr: Or you would remember the stories you read in the newspapers, about women found in ditches or forests or in abandoned rental rooms' refrigerators -often women, but sometimes men or, worst of all, children- with their clothes on or naked, sexually assaulted or not; but in any case, murdered.
es: Or you would remember stories you had read in the newspapers about women who had appeared —often they were women, but sometimes also men, or children, which is terrible— in ditches, or in forests, or in refrigerators of rented and abandoned rooms, with their clothes on or not, sexually abused or not; but in any case, murdered.

en: There were places you didn't want to walk, precautions you took that had to do with locks on windows and doors, drawing the curtains, leaving on lights.
vi: There are areas people don't want to walk through, rooms where precautions are followed - locking windows or doors, drawing curtains, leaving lights on.
tr: There were places you didn't want to walk, precautions you took with window or door locks, drawing the curtains and leaving the lights on.
es: There were places you didn't want to walk through, precautions you took that had to do with the locks on windows and doors, with drawing the curtains and leaving the lights on.

en: These things you did were like prayers; you did them and you hoped they would save you.
vi: People perform these actions like reciting prayers, doing them and hoping they will save themselves.
tr: These things you did were like prayers; you did them and thought they would protect you.
es: These things you did were like prayers; you did them and hoped they would save you.

en: And for the most part they did.
vi: And generally, they do save them.
tr: And most of the time, they did protect you.
es: And for the most part, they did.

en: Or something did; you could tell by the fact that you were still alive.
vi: Or something has saved them; the fact that they are still alive is the immediate proof.
tr: Or something had protected you; you could infer this from the fact that you were still alive.
es: Or something was doing it; you could tell by the fact that you were still alive.

en: But all of that was pertinent only in the night, and had nothing to do with the man you loved, at least in daylight.
vi: But those things only become evident when night falls, having nothing to do with the man one loves, at least in the daylight, because for that man, one would accept to train oneself, putting in the effort to practice.
tr: However, all of this was valid for the night and had nothing to do with the man you loved, at least during the day.
es: But all that was only relevant at night and had nothing to do with the man you loved, at least in the light of day.

en: With that man you wanted it to work, to work out.
vi: But those things only become evident when night falls, having nothing to do with the man one loves, at least in the daylight, because for that man, one would accept to train oneself, putting in the effort to practice.
tr: You wanted it to work out with this man, to reach a solution.
es: With that man, you wanted to work, to make things function so you wouldn't get out of practice.

en: Working out was also something you did to keep your body in shape, for the man.
vi: Also practicing to have a beautiful body, one does it for the man one loves.
tr: The solution was also something you did to maintain the shape of your body, for that man.
es: And the training was something you did to keep your body in shape for that man.

en: If you worked out enough, maybe the man would too.
vi: If one is willing to train oneself diligently, who knows, maybe he will too.
tr: If you found enough solutions, maybe the man would do the same.
es: If you trained enough, maybe the man did too.

en: Maybe you would be able to work it out together, as if the two of you were a puzzle that could be solved; otherwise, one of you, most likely theman, would go wandering off on a trajectory of his own, taking his addictive body with him and leaving you with bad withdrawal, which you could counteract by exercise.
vi: Who knows, maybe both will be able to train each other, like solving a puzzle together; otherwise, one of the two, often him, will drift away on his own path, leaving the other in a state of post-withdrawal struggle, wanting to cope by only increasing the training.
tr: Maybe, you could reach a conclusion together, as if you both were a solvable puzzle; otherwise, one of you, most likely the man, would take his drug-addicted body along and pull away in his own orbit, leaving you to face a bad withdrawal; the only thing you could do to lessen its effect is to exercise.
es: Maybe you were capable of training together, as if both of you were a puzzle that could be solved; otherwise, one of you—most likely the man—would walk away, taking his addicted body with him and leaving you with an abandonment anguish that you could counteract through exercise.

en: If you didn't work it out it was because one of you had the
vi: If practicing endlessly yields no results, it is because both have the wrong attitude.
tr: If you didn't reach a conclusion with him, it was because one of your attitudes was wrong.
es: If things didn't work out, it was because one of you adopted an incorrect attitude.

en: wrong attitude.
vi: If practicing endlessly yields no results, it is because both have the wrong attitude.
tr: If you didn't reach a conclusion with him, it was because one of your attitudes was wrong.
es: If things didn't work out, it was because one of you adopted an incorrect attitude.

en: Everythingthat went on in your life was thought to be due to some positive or negative power emanating from inside your head.
vi: Everything in life, one thinks, follows a certain positive or negative force originating from one's own mind.
tr: It was believed that everything happening in your life stemmed from a positive or negative force emanating from your mind.
es: It was thought that everything that happened in your lives was due to some positive or negative force emanating from within your minds.

en: If you don't like it, change it, we said, to each other and to ourselves.
vi: If you don't like it, then change it, we say that, telling each other as well as telling ourselves.
tr: If you don't like it, change it, we would say to each other and to ourselves.
es: If you don't like it, change it, we would say to each other and to ourselves.

en: And so we would change the man, for another one.
vi: And so we change the man, taking another one.
tr: And so we would change that man, with another.
es: And so, we would swap that man for another.

en: Change, we were sure, was for the better always.
vi: Change, we firmly believe, always brings better results.
tr: We were sure that change was always for the better.
es: We were sure that the change was always for the better.

en: We were revisionists; what we revised was ourselves.
vi: We are the ones who reconsider, we reconsider ourselves.
tr: We were revisionists; what we revised was ourselves.
es: We were revisionists; we would examine ourselves.

en: It's strange to remember how we used to think, as if everything were available to us, as if there were no contingencies, no boundaries; as if we were free to shape and reshape forever the ever-expanding perimeters of our lives.
vi: How strange it is to recall what we used to think in the past, as if everything was ready before our eyes, as if luck did not exist, no boundaries; as if we had the right to erase and redraw endlessly the ever-expanding circumference of our lives.
tr: It's strange to remember how we used to think, as if everything was at our command, as if there was no contingency, no limits; as if we were free to shape and reshape the ever-expanding parameters of our lives forever.
es: It seems strange to remember what we used to think, as if we had everything within reach, as if there were no contingencies, no limits; as if we were free to eternally shape and reshape the ever-expandable perimeters of our lives.

en: I was like that too, I did that too.
vi: I was like that too, I did the same.
tr: I was like that too, I did the same.
es: I was like that too, I did it too.

en: Luke was not the first man for me, and he might not have been the last.
vi: Luke was not the first man for me, and he might not have been the last.
tr: Luke was not the first man for me, moreover, he might not have been the last either.
es: Luke was not the first man in my life, and he might not have been the last.

en: If he hadn't been frozen that way.
vi: If you had not been so paralyzed.
tr: If it hadn't been frozen this way.
es: If he hadn't been frozen in that way.

en: Stopped dead in time, in midair, among the trees back there, in the act of falling.
vi: Frozen in time, in midair, among the forest canopy there, in the midst of the fall.
tr: In time, in the middle of the air, among those trees of the past, in the act of falling, if it hadn't been motionlessly stopped.
es: Stopped dead in time, in the air, among the trees, in the middle of the fall.

en: In former times they would send you a little package, of the belongings: what he had with him when he died.
vi: In the past, people would receive a small package, personal belongings: the things left with them when they died.
tr: In the past, they used to send a small package containing belongings: the things that were with the person when they died.
es: In the past, they would send you a small package with their belongings: what they had with them at the moment of death.

en: That's what they would do, in wartime, my mother said.
vi: They often did so, during wartime, my mother said.
tr: This is what they did during wartime, my mother would say.'
es: According to my mother, that's what they did in times of war.

en: How long were you supposed to mourn, and what did they say?
vi: How long should one mourn, and what did they say?
tr: I wonder how long you were expected to mourn, and what would they say?
es: How long were you supposed to mourn, what did they say?

en: Makeyour life a tribute to the loved one.
vi: Dedicate your life to remembering your loved ones.
tr: Dedicate your existence to the beloved.
es: Make your life a tribute to the beloved.

en: And he was, the loved.
vi: The old days.
tr: And it was so, the beloved.
es: And it was, the beloved.

en: One.
vi: Beloved ones.
tr: One.
es: Him.

en: Is, I say.
vi: You are my beloved, I said loudly.
tr: It is, I say.
es: It is, I tell myself.

en: Is, is, only two letters, you stupid shit, can't you manage to remember it, even a short word like that?
vi: Is, is, just two letters, you fool, can't you remember it, such a short word?
tr: It is, it is, just three letters, you stupid idiot, can't you manage to remember, even such a short word?
es: It is, it is, only two letters, stupid, are you not capable of remembering a word as short as that?

en: I wipe my sleeve across my face.
vi: I wiped my face with my sleeve.
tr: I wipe my face with the sleeve of my dress.
es: I dry my face with my sleeve.

en: Once I wouldn't have done that, for fear of smearing, but now nothing comes off.
vi: There was a time I wouldn't dare do that, afraid it would smear, but now there's nothing left to smudge.
tr: Once, I wouldn't do this for fear of staining it, but now nothing happens.
es: Before, I wouldn't have done it for fear of staining myself, but now it's impossible for that to happen.

en: Whatever expression is there, unseen by me, is real.
vi: If there is any expression on my face, even if I can't see it, it's genuine.
tr: The expression on my face, whatever it is that I cannot see, is real.
es: Any expression that exists, invisible to me, is real.

en: You'll have to forgive me.
vi: You will have to forgive me.
tr: You will have to forgive me.
es: You will have to forgive me.

en: I'm a refugee from the past, and like other refugees I go over the customs and habits of being I've left or been forced to leave behindme, and it all seems just as quaint, from here, and I am just as obsessive about it.
vi: I am a refugee from the past, and like all refugees in the world, I scrutinize the habits and customs of the lifestyle left behind, or forced to leave behind, and like them, I see how strange everything is when looking back from here, and just like that, they bewilder me.
tr: I am a refugee from the past, going over the traditions and customs of the existence I left behind or was forced to leave behind, like other refugees. And from here, it looks entirely extraordinary and pleasant, and I am just as obsessed with this existence.
es: I am a refugee from the past and, like other refugees, I follow the customs and habits that I abandoned or was forced to abandon, and all this seems very quaint, and I am very obsessive about it.

en: Like a White Russian drinking tea in Paris, marooned in the twentieth century, I wander back, try to regain those distant pathways; I become too maudlin, lose myself.
vi: Like a White Russian sipping tea in the heart of Paris, abandoned in the twentieth century, I turn back, trying to find the distant paths; I become sentimental, losing myself.
tr: Like a White Russian drinking tea in Paris, left alone on a deserted island in the twentieth century, I steer backward, trying to rediscover those distant paths; I become overly sentimental, I lose myself.
es: Like a White Russian having tea in Paris, isolated in the twentieth century, I retreat trying to recover those distant paths; I become too sentimental, I get lost.

en: Weep.
vi: Sobbing.
tr: I let my tears flow.
es: I lament.

en: Weeping is what it is, not crying.
vi: Sobbing is the right word, not crying.
tr: This is what happens, not crying.
es: Lamenting is what it is, it's not crying.

en: I sit in this chair and ooze
vi: I sit here on the chair, drenched like a piece of sea foam.
tr: Sitting in this chair, I leak water like a sponge.
es: I sit in this chair and ooze, like a sponge.

en: like a sponge.
vi: I sit here on the chair, drenched like a piece of sea foam.
tr: Sitting in this chair, I leak water like a sponge.
es: I sit in this chair and ooze, like a sponge.

en: So.
vi: So.
tr: So.
es: Then.

en: More waiting.
vi: Wait again, towards the future.
tr: Waiting longer.
es: More waiting.

en: Lady in waiting: that's what they used to call (hose stores where you could buy maternity clothes.
vi: Future mother: the welcoming call when entering a maternity store.
tr: The Waiting Woman: that's what they used to call those stores where you could buy maternity dresses.
es: The sweet wait: that's what they used to call the stores where you could buy maternity clothes.

en: Woman in waiting sounds more like someone in a train station.
vi: The soon-to-be mother sounds like a call to give up a seat on the subway.
tr: The waiting woman is more like someone researching a person waiting at a train station.
es: Plain waiting seems more appropriate for someone at a train station.

en: Waiting is also a place: it is wherever you wait.
vi: Waiting is also a location, between two journeys.
tr: Waiting is also a place: it is where you wait.
es: Waiting is also a place: it's where you wait.

en: For me it's this room.
vi: For me, it's this room.
tr: For me, waiting is this room.
es: For me, it is this room.

en: I am a blank, here, between parentheses.
vi: I am the empty space, here, between two parentheses.
tr: I am a void, here, between parentheses.
es: I am a space between parentheses.

en: Between other people
vi: Among others.
tr: Among other people.
es: Among other people.

en: The knock comes at my door.
vi: There is the sound of the door wood.
tr: Someone is knocking on my door.
es: They knock on my door.

en: Cora, with the tray.
vi: Cora and the tray.
tr: It must be Cora with the tray.
es: It's Cora, with the tray.

en: But it isn't Cora.
vi: But not Cora.
tr: But no, it's not that.
es: But it is not Cora.

en: "I've brought it for you," says Serena Joy.
vi: "I brought it for you," Serena Joy said.
tr: "I brought this for you," says Serena Joy.
es: —I have brought you this —says Serena Joy.

en: And then I look up and around, and get out of my chair and come towards her.
vi: Then I looked around, got up from the chair, and walked over to her.
tr: Then I lift my head and look around, and I get up from my chair and approach her.
es: Then I look up, look around, get up from my chair, and walk towards her.

en: She's holding it, a Polaroid print, square and glossy.
vi: She was holding it, the instant photo, square and glossy.
tr: She is holding a Polaroid picture, square and shiny.
es: She holds it in her hands, it's a copy of a Polaroid, square and shiny.

en: So they still make them, cameras like that.
vi: So they still manufacture those cameras.
tr: So they still make them, these kinds of cameras.
es: So they still make those cameras.

en: And there will be family albums, too, with all the children in them; no Handmaids though.
vi: And there will still be family photo albums, with all the kids; but not the maids.
tr: Moreover, there will be family albums, with all the children in them; though there will never be a Handmaid.
es: And there will also be family albums, full of children; however, not a single Handmaid.

en: From the point of view of future history, this kind, we'll be invisible.
vi: From the perspective of future history, at this rate, we will be invisible.
tr: From the perspective of future history, this kind, that is, we will be invisible.
es: From the perspective of future history, we will be invisible.

en: But the children will be in them all right, something for the Wives to look at, downstairs, nibbling at the buffet and waiting for the Birth.
vi: But the kids will certainly be there, so the Wives have something to look at, downstairs, while nibbling on the buffet waiting for the Birth.
tr: Still, there will indeed be children in them, downstairs, rummaging in the sideboard and waiting to be born for the Wives to look at.
es: But the children will exist, they will be something for the Wives to look at downstairs while they wait for the birth, nibbling at the bar.

en: "You can only have it for a minute," Serena Joy says, her voice low and conspiratorial.
vi: “You can only hold it for a minute,” Serena Joy whispered conspiratorially.
tr: “It can only stay with you for a minute,” says Serena Joy, her voice low and as if sharing a crime.
es: —You can only have her for five minutes —Serena Joy tells me in a low, conspiratorial tone.

en: "I have to return it, before they know it's missing."
vi: “I have to put it back before they notice.”
tr: “I must take it back before they notice it's missing.”
es: I have to return her before they notice she's gone.

en: It must have been a Martha who got it for her.
vi: He is someone Martha got for her.
tr: It must have been a Martha who obtained this for him.
es: It must have been a Martha who got it for her.

en: There's a network of the Marthas, then, with something in it for them.
vi: So there is a network of Martha connections, they also earned something from it.
tr: In this case, it means there is a network among the Marthas, with something in it for them as well.
es: They form a network from which they obtain something.

en: That's nice to know.
vi: It's good to know.
tr: It's nice to learn this.
es: It's good to know.

en: I take it from her, turn it around so I can see it right-side-up.
vi: I took it from her hand, turning it back towards myself.
tr: I take the picture from him, and I turn it to see it properly.
es: I take her by the hands and turn her around to see her right side.

en: Is this her, is this what she's like?
vi: Is this me, is this my appearance?
tr: Is that really him, could he really be like this?
es: It's her, is this what she looks like?

en: My treasure.
vi: My precious.
tr: My treasure.
es: My treasure.

en: So tall and changed.
vi: Tall and very different.
tr: It has grown very long and changed.
es: So tall and changed.

en: Smiling a little now, so soon, and in her white dress as if for an olden-days First Communion.
vi: Already smiled a little, so quickly, wearing a white dress like the first communion, in the old days.
tr: Now she is smiling a little, how quickly, as if dressed in her white dress for an old-time First Communion.
es: Smiling a little, in her white dress, as if she were dressed for her first communion, like in the old days.

en: Time has not stood still.
vi: Time does not stop.
tr: Time hasn't just stood still.
es: Time has not stood still.

en: It has washed over me, washed me away, as if I'm nothing more than a woman of sand, left by a careless child too near the water.
vi: It has pushed me, pushed me away, I am merely a sand woman left too close to the water's edge by a careless child.
tr: It washed over me and carried me away, as if I were a woman made of sand left too close to the water by a careless child.
es: It has soaked me, eroded me, as if I were nothing more than a woman of sand abandoned by a careless child near the water.

en: I have been obliterated for her.
vi: I have been cast aside for the sake of my child.
tr: In his eyes, I was a silhouette.
es: For her, I have been erased.

en: I am only a shadow now, far back behind the glib shiny surface of this photograph.
vi: I am nothing but a shadow, far behind the glossy surface of this photo.
tr: Now I am merely a shadow, far behind the bright surface of this photograph.
es: Now I am only a distant shadow in time, behind the smooth and shiny surface of this photograph.

en: A shadow of a shadow, as dead mothers become.
vi: A shadow of a shadow, like all the mothers who have passed away.
tr: Like the shadows of dead mothers, a shadow of a shadow.
es: The shadow of a shadow, which is what dead mothers end up being.

en: You can see it in her eyes: I am not there.
vi: Just look into my child's eyes: I am not there.
tr: You can see it in his eyes: I am not there.
es: It can be seen in her eyes: I am not there.

en: But she exists, in her white dress.
vi: But you exist, in a white dress.
tr: But there it is, with its white dress.
es: But she exists, with her white dress.

en: She grows and lives.
vi: Growing up and living.
tr: It grows and lives.
es: She grows and lives.

en: Isn't that a
vi: Isn't that good?
tr: Isn't this a beautiful thing?
es: Isn't that something good?

en: good thing?
vi: Isn't that good?
tr: Isn't this a beautiful thing?
es: Isn't that something good?

en: A blessing?
vi: Isn't that a blessing?
tr: A blessing?
es: Isn't it a blessing?

en: Still, I can't bear it, to have been erased like that.
vi: Anyway, I can't stand it, being erased like that.
tr: Still, I can't stand this, being erased like this.
es: However, I cannot bear having been erased in that manner.

en: Better she'd brought me nothing.
vi: I'd rather she didn't bring anything at all.
tr: It would have been better if it had brought me nothing.
es: It would have been better if he had not brought me anything.

en: I sit at the little table, eating creamed corn with a fork.
vi: I sit at a tiny table, using a fork to eat creamed corn soup.
tr: I am sitting at the small table eating creamy cornflakes with a fork.
es: I sit at the small table to eat flakes with cream with a fork.

en: I have a fork and a spoon, but never a knife.
vi: I have a fork, a spoon, but never a knife.
tr: I have a fork and a spoon, but never a knife.
es: They give me a fork and spoon, but never a knife.

en: When there's meat they cut it up for me ahead of time, as if I'm lacking manual skills or teeth.
vi: When there's meat, they cut it up for me beforehand, as if I lack teeth or don't know how to use my hands.
tr: When meat is served, they cut it for me as if I have no hand skills or teeth.
es: When there is meat, they cut it in advance, as if I didn't know how to use my hands, or didn't have teeth.

en: I have both, however.
vi: But I have everything.
tr: However, I have both.
es: But I lack neither of those things.

en: That's why I'm not allowed a knife.
vi: That's why the knife never comes to me.
tr: That's precisely why I am not given a knife.
es: That's why they don't allow me to use a knife.
CHAPTER 36

en: I knock on his door, hear his voice, adjust my face, go in.
vi: I knocked on his door, waited for a response, adjusted my expression, and walked in.
tr: Knocking on the door, I hear his voice, adjust my face, and enter.
es: I knock on his door, hear his voice, fix my face, and enter.

en: He's standing by the fireplace; in his hand he's got an almost-empty drink.
vi: He was standing by the fireplace, holding a nearly empty glass of wine.
tr: He is standing by the fireplace; he has an almost empty drink glass in his hand.
es: He is standing by the fireplace; in his hand, he has an almost empty glass.

en: He usually waits till I get here to start on the hard liquor, though I know they have wine with dinner.
vi: He usually waited for me to arrive before pouring strong liquor, even though I knew they had wine with dinner.
tr: He usually waits for me to arrive before starting on the hard liquor; although I know they had wine with dinner.
es: He usually waits for me to arrive before starting to drink alcohol, although I know they drink wine with dinner.

en: His face is a little flushed.
vi: His face was slightly red.
tr: His face is a bit flushed.
es: His face is slightly flushed.

en: I try to estimate how many he's had.
vi: I tried to estimate how much he had drunk.
tr: I'm trying to figure out how much he has drunk.
es: I try to calculate how much he has drunk.

en: "Greetings," he says.
vi: "Hats off to you!" he said.
tr: “Hello,” he says.
es: —Welcome —she greets me—.

en: "How is the fair little one this evening?"
vi: "How is my little sister?"
tr: “Let's see how our sweet little one is doing this evening?”
es: How is the little one tonight?

en: A few, I can tell by the elaborateness of the smile he composes and aims.
vi: Probably a few glasses, I guessed, thanks to the very skillfully crafted smile meant for me.
tr: I can say that I drank a few sips of the care with which he created and directed his smile.
es: From the elaborate smile she gives me, I estimate not much.

en: He's in the courtly phase.
vi: He was still at the stage of refinement.
tr: His politeness is evident.
es: She is in the courtesy phase.

en: "I'm fine," I say.
vi: "I'm still fine," I said.
tr: “I’m fine,” I say.
es: —I'm fine —I reply.

en: "Up for a little excitement?"
vi: "Are you ready for a little fun trip?"
tr: “Are you ready for a little excitement?”
es: —Ready for a little excitement?

en: "Pardon?" I say.
vi: "I don't understand?" I asked again.
tr: “Pardon?” I say.
es: —How? —I ask him.

en: Behind this act of his I sense embarrassment, an uncertainty about how far he can go with me, and in what direction.
vi: Behind those antics, I sensed his embarrassment, hesitating, unsure of how far I would let him go, and in which direction.
tr: I sense the shyness behind this move, an uncertainty about how far and in which direction to go with me.
es: Behind his words, I sense a discomfort, an uncertainty about how far he can go with me, and in what direction.

en: "Tonight I have a little surprise for you," he says.
vi: “I have a little surprise for you tonight,” he said.
tr: “I have a little surprise for you tonight,” he says.
es: —Tonight I have a little surprise for you —he announces and bursts into laughter.

en: He laughs; it's more like a snigger.
vi: He laughed, but it sounded more like a snort.
tr: He laughs; it's more of an uncontrollable laughter.
es: It's more of a giggle.

en: I notice that everything this evening is little.
vi: I noticed that everything tonight was small.
tr: This evening, I realize that everything is small.
es: I notice that tonight everything is small.

en: He wishes to diminish things, myself included.
vi: He wanted to shrink everything, including me.
tr: He wants to make things smaller, including me.
es: He wants to diminish things, even me—.

en: "Something you'll like."
vi: “You'll like it, just wait and see.”
tr: “Something you'll like.”
es: Something you will like.

en: "What's that?" I say.
vi: “What is this?” I said.
tr: “What is it?” I say.
es: —What is it? —I ask—.

en: "Chinese checkers?"
vi: “Chinese checkers?” I allowed myself to speak like that; he seemed to enjoy this kind of rudeness, especially after a few drinks.
tr: “Chinese checkers?” I can show this much audacity; he seems to like these, especially after a drink or two.
es: Chinese paintings?

en: I can take these liber-ties; he appears to enjoy them, especially after a couple of drinks.
vi: “Chinese checkers?” I allowed myself to speak like that; he seemed to enjoy this kind of rudeness, especially after a few drinks.
tr: “Chinese checkers?” I can show this much audacity; he seems to like these, especially after a drink or two.
es: —I can take these liberties; he seems to enjoy them, especially after a couple of drinks.

en: I le prefers me frivolous.
vi: He liked to see me being unrestrained.
tr: He prefers me to be flying.
es: He prefers me to be frivolous.

en: "Something better," he says, attempting to be tantalizing.
vi: "Even better," he said, trying to drive me crazy.
tr: "Something better," he says, trying to create suspense.
es: —Something better —he specifies, trying to seem seductive.

en: "I can hardly wait."
vi: "I'm very anxious already."
tr: “I am getting impatient.”
es: —I'm impatient.

en: "Good," he says.
vi: "That's good," he said.
tr: “Good,” he says.
es: —Alright —he says.

en: He goes to his desk, fumbles with a drawer.
vi: He went to the table and rummaged through the drawer.
tr: He goes to his desk and rummages through a drawer.
es: He goes to his desk and rummages through a drawer.

en: Then he conies towards me, one hand behind his back.
vi: Then he turned back to me, one hand hidden behind his back.
tr: Then, holding one hand behind his back, he comes towards me.
es: Then he approaches me, with one hand behind his back.

en: "Guess," he says.
vi: "Guess what," he said.
tr: “Guess,” he says.
es: —Guess —he suggests.

en: "Animal, vegetable, or mineral?"
vi: “Animal, plant, or mineral?” I asked.
tr: "Is it animal, vegetable, or mineral?"
es: —Animal, vegetable, or mineral?

en: I say.
vi: “Animal, plant, or mineral?” I asked.
tr: I ask.
es: —I ask.

en: "Oh, animal," he says with mock gravity.
vi: "Oh, animals," he said, pretending to be serious.
tr: “Ah, animal,” he says with mocking seriousness.
es: —Oh, animal —he states with mocking seriousness—.

en: "Definitely animal, I'd say."
vi: "And different animals too, I promise."
tr: “I would definitely call it an animal if it were up to me.”
es: Definitely an animal, I would say

en: He brings his hand out from behind his back.
vi: He extended his hidden hand.
tr: He extends his hand behind him.
es: —he moves his hand away from behind his back.

en: He's holding a handful, it seems, of feathers, mauve and pink.
vi: In his hand, at first glance, was a handful of feathers, pinkish and purplish.
tr: Judging by the appearance, he is holding a handful of lilac and pink feathers.
es: He is holding something resembling a handful of mauve and pink feathers.

en: Now he shakes this out.
vi: Then he shook it out.
tr: Now he shakes and opens them.
es: He spreads them out.

en: It's a garment, apparently, and for awoman: there are the cups for the breasts, covered in purple sequins.
vi: A costume, clearly for women: two round pieces covering the chest, adorned with purple sequins.
tr: It is a garment, actually, a woman's garment: It even has a bra for the breasts, covered with purple glitter.
es: It appears to be a garment, and a woman's at that: you can see the two cups for the breasts, covered in purple sequins.

en: The sequins are tiny stars.
vi: Each sequin was a tiny star.
tr: The glitter I mean are small stars.
es: Sequins are tiny stars.

en: The feathers are around the thigh holes, and along the top.
vi: Feathers were attached around the thighs, around the chest.
tr: The feathers are around and above the hips.
es: The feathers are placed around the leg hole and along the top part.

en: So I wasn't that wrong about the girdle, after all.
vi: So I wasn't too far off about the corset.
tr: So my guess about the corset was not wrong.
es: So, after all, I wasn't wrong about the sash.

en: I wonder where he found it.
vi: I wonder where he got this thing from.
tr: I wonder where you found it.
es: I wonder where she found it.

en: All such clothingwas supposed to have been destroyed.
vi: Those kinds of clothes should have been destroyed.
tr: All clothes of this kind should have been destroyed.
es: It is supposed that all clothes of that type have been destroyed.

en: I remember seeing that on television, in news clips filmed in one city after another.
vi: I still remember watching on TV, news clips from one city to another.
tr: I remember seeing this on television, in the new clips shot from one city to another.
es: I remember seeing it on television, in clips filmed in various cities.

en: In New York it was called the Manhattan Cleanup.
vi: In New York, the Great Manhattan Cleanup took place.
tr: In New York, this was called the Manhattan Representation.
es: In New York, it was called the Manhattan Cleanup.

en: There were bonfires in Times Square, crowds chanting around them, women throwing their arms up thankfully into the air when they felt the cameras on them, clean-cut stony-faced young men tossing things onto the flames, armfuls of silk and nylon and fake fur, lime-green, red, violet; black satin, gold lame glittering silver; bikini underpants, see-through brassieres with pink satin hearts sewn on to cover the nipples.
vi: Pyres sprung up in the middle of Times Square, crowds gathered around shouting, women raising their hands to the sky in gratitude whenever they felt the camera pointed at them, young men with bright and cold faces, constantly throwing armfuls of silk, nylon, and fake fur into the fire, in green, red, and purple; black satin, glittering silver fabric; two-piece lingerie, transparent bras embroidered with pink satin hearts covering the nipples.
tr: Bonfires were lit in Times Square, with crowds singing around them, women raising their arms to the sky in gratitude when they felt the cameras were on them, young men with well-chiseled stone faces throwing things into the flames, armfuls of silk and nylon and faux fur, lime green, red, violet; black satin, gold lamé, shiny silver; bikini panties, see-through bras with pink satin hearts sewn to cover the nipples.
es: In Times Square, there were bonfires and crowds singing around them, women raising their arms, grateful, every time they felt the cameras focusing on them, young men with stony and clean-shaven faces throwing objects into the flames: silk garments, nylon and imitation leather, green, red, and violet garters, black satin, golden lamé, shiny silver; bikini panties, transparent bras with pink satin hearts sewn to cover the nipples.

en: And the manufacturers and importers and salesmen down on their knees, repenting in public, conical paper hats like dunce hats on their heads, SHAME printed on them in red.
vi: And the manufacturers, importers, and distributors knelt down, repenting before the public, wearing rolled-up paper hats like naughty children, with the words "Shame" printed in red.
tr: And the manufacturers and importers and sellers were kneeling, repenting in front of the public, their funny paper hats resembling student dunce caps, with SHAME written on them in red.
es: And the manufacturers, importers, and sellers kneeling, repenting in public, with their heads covered with paper hats, conical in shape —like donkey ears— with the word SHAME painted in red.

en: But some items must have survived the burning, they couldn't possibly have got it all.
vi: But surely a few items escaped the fire, they couldn't track them all down.
tr: However, some items must have escaped burning; it was unlikely they could seize everything.
es: But some things must have been saved from the flames; most likely, they didn't find them all.

en: He must have come by this in the same way he came by the magazines, not honestly: it reeks of black market.
vi: He probably got this from the same source as the pile of magazines, not through legitimate means: it reeks of the black market.
tr: He must have found this the same way he obtained the magazines, not honestly: it reeks of the black market.
es: He must have gotten it the same way he got the magazines: dishonestly; it reeks of the black market.

en: And it's not new, it's been worn before, the cloth under the arms is crumpled and slightly stained, with some other woman's sweat.
vi: And it's not new either, someone has worn it before, the fabric under the arms is creased and slightly stained, by the sweat of an unfamiliar woman.
tr: Moreover, it's not even new, previously worn, with the fabric under the armpits wrinkled and slightly stained, with another woman's sweat.
es: And it's not new, it has been used before; under the arms, the garment is wrinkled and slightly stained with the sweat of some other woman.

en: "I had to guess the size," he says.
vi: “I have to guess the size,” he said.
tr: “I had to guess the measurement,” he says.
es: —I had to guess the size —he warns me—.

en: "I hope it fits."
vi: “Hopefully it fits.”
tr: “I hope it fits.”
es: I hope it fits you well.

en: "You expect me to put that on?" I say.
vi: "Do you think I would wear that thing?" I said.
tr: “You expect me to wear this?” I say.
es: —Do you expect me to wear this? —I am astonished.

en: I know my voice sounds prudish, disapproving.
vi: I knew my voice was very righteous, very indignant.
tr: I know my voice comes out prudish and disapproving.
es: I know my voice sounds prudish and disapproving.

en: Still there is something attractive in the idea.
vi: But the prospect was indeed alluring.
tr: There is something alluring about this idea.
es: However, there is something appealing about the idea.

en: I've never worn anything remotely like this, so glittering and theatrical, and that's what it must be, an old theater costume, or
vi: I had never worn anything even remotely like this, so glamorous and theatrical, and it must be, this must be theater costume, or from some performance at a long-dead nightclub; until now, the closest I had come was touching swimwear, with a tight cream-colored lace nightgown, once bought for me by Luke.
tr: I have never worn anything so outrageous, bright, and theatrical; theatrical, that's the right word; it must be an old theater costume or something from a now-defunct nightclub show; the closest thing I've worn to this was a swimsuit and a peach-colored lace camisole set that Luke once bought for me.
es: I have never worn anything even remotely similar, so bright and theatrical, and that must be what it is, an old theater costume, or something from a long-gone nightclub act; the closest thing I ever wore were swimsuits and a peach-colored lace bustier set that Luke bought me once.

en: something from a vanished nightclub act; the closest I ever came were bathing suits, and a camisole set, peach lace, that Luke bought for me once.
vi: I had never worn anything even remotely like this, so glamorous and theatrical, and it must be, this must be theater costume, or from some performance at a long-dead nightclub; until now, the closest I had come was touching swimwear, with a tight cream-colored lace nightgown, once bought for me by Luke.
tr: I have never worn anything so outrageous, bright, and theatrical; theatrical, that's the right word; it must be an old theater costume or something from a now-defunct nightclub show; the closest thing I've worn to this was a swimsuit and a peach-colored lace camisole set that Luke once bought for me.
es: I have never worn anything even remotely similar, so bright and theatrical, and that must be what it is, an old theater costume, or something from a long-gone nightclub act; the closest thing I ever wore were swimsuits and a peach-colored lace bustier set that Luke bought me once.

en: Yet there's an enticement in this thing, it carries with it the childish allure of dressing up.
vi: But this outfit radiated a seductive charm, it held an allure like children being dressed up.
tr: Still, there is a seductiveness in this, it carries the charm of childish dressing up.
es: However, there is something seductive about this garment, it holds the childish allure of dressing up.

en: And it would be so flaunting, such a sneer at the Aunts, so sinful, so free.
vi: How proud it would be to wear it, how it would mock the aunts, how sinful, how free.
tr: Besides, it would be quite flashy, an insult to the Aunts, quite sinful, quite free.
es: And it would be so ostentatious, like mocking the Aunts, so sinful, so free...

en: Freedom, like everything else, is relative.
vi: Freedom, like everything, is only relative.
tr: Freedom, like everything else, is relative.
es: Freedom, like everything else, is relative.

en: "Well," I say, not wishing to seem too eager.
vi: "Um," I said, not wanting to appear too eager.
tr: "Okay," I say, trying not to look too eager.
es: —Alright —I accept, trying not to seem too eager.

en: 1 want him to feel I'm doing him a favor.
vi: I wanted him to feel like he was receiving a favor from me.
tr: I want to make him feel like I'm doing him a favor.
es: I want him to feel like I'm doing him a favor.

en: Now we may come to it, his deep-down real desire.
vi: Now it's time, here comes the deep desire.
tr: Now we can get to the point, to his deep-seated true desire.
es: Maybe we've reached his true and deep desire.

en: Does he have a pony whip, hidden behind the door?
vi: Does he have a riding crop hidden behind that door?
tr: Does he have a small whip hidden behind the door?
es: Does he have a whip hidden behind the door?

en: Will he produce boots, bend himself or me over the desk?
vi: Will he pull out boots, or make himself or me bend over the table?
tr: Will he ask me to take off my torture boots and bend over the table, or will he bend over himself?
es: Will he take off his boots and throw himself or throw me onto the desk?

en: "It's a disguise," he says.
vi: “This is a disguise outfit,” he said.
tr: “This is a disguise,” he says.
es: —It's a disguise —he explains to me—.

en: "You'll need to paint your face too; I've got the stuff for it.
vi: “You also have to put on makeup; I have the stuff here.
tr: “You will also need to put on makeup; I got some things for that.
es: You will also have to paint your face; I brought everything you need.

en: You'll never get in without it."
vi: Otherwise, you'll never get in.”
tr: You can never get in without it.”
es: You couldn't get in without this.

en: "In where?" I ask.
vi: "Where to?" I asked.
tr: "Where to?" I ask.
es: —Where? —I ask.

en: "Tonight I'm taking you out."
vi: "Tonight, I will take you out."
tr: “I'm taking you out tonight.”
es: —Tonight I am going to take you out.

en: "Out?"
vi: "Play?"
tr: “Outside?”
es: —Outside? —it's an archaic expression.

en: It's an archaic phrase.
vi: The word is too outdated.
tr: This is an archaic expression.
es: —Outside? —it's an archaic expression.

en: Surely there is nowhere, anymore, where a man can take a woman, out.
vi: Obviously, there is no place, no longer, for a man to take a woman - to play.
tr: There is absolutely no place anymore for a man to take a woman out.
es: Surely there is no longer any place to take a woman.

en: "Out of here," he says.
vi: "Playing very far," he said.
tr: “Out of here,” he says.
es: —Get out of here —he asserts.

en: I know without being told that what he's proposing is risky, for him but especially for me; but I want to go anyway.
vi: I immediately understood that this proposal was dangerous, for him, but above all for me, but despite everything, I still wanted to go.
tr: I know without saying that what he suggests is risky, for him, but especially for me; still, I want to go out.
es: I know, without needing to be told, that what he proposes is risky for him, but especially for me; nevertheless, I want to go.

en: I want anything that breaks the monotony, subverts the perceived respectable order of things.
vi: I wanted anything that would break the daily monotony, overturn the accepted and respected order.
tr: I want anything that will break the monotony, that can reverse the perceived respectable order of things.
es: I want anything that breaks the monotony, that subverts the respectable order of things.

en: I tell him I don't want him to watch me while I put this thing on; I'm still shy in front of him, about my body.
vi: I said I didn't want to be watched while putting this on; I was still embarrassed in front of him, because of my body.
tr: I tell him that I don't want him to watch me while I'm wearing this thing; I'm still shy in front of him about showing my body.
es: I tell him that I don't want him to look at me while I put on the garment; in front of him, I am still ashamed of my body.

en: He says he will turn his back, and does so, and I take off my shoes and stockings and my cotton underpants and slide the feathers on, under the tent of my dress.
vi: He said he would turn his back, and he did just that, and I took off the shoes and socks and the pile of cotton underwear, and slipped into the feathers, under the loose petticoat.
tr: He says he'll turn around and he does, I take off my shoes, socks, and cotton underwear and put on the furry ones, under my dress.
es: He says he will turn his back, and he does; I take off my shoes and socks, the cotton tights, and put on the feathers under the protection of the dress.

en: Then I take off the dress itself and slip the thin se-quined straps over my shoulders.
vi: Then I took off the dress, pulling the delicate beaded straps over my shoulders.
tr: Then I take off the dress itself and throw the thin gilded fabric straps over my shoulders.
es: Then I take off the dress and slide the thin sequined straps over my shoulders.

en: There are shoes, too, mauve ones with absurdly high heels.
vi: There were shoes too, peach-colored, with unusually high heels.
tr: There are also shoes, oddly high-heeled, lilac-colored.
es: There is also a pair of mauve shoes with absurdly high heels.

en: Nothing quite fits; the shoes are a little too big, the waist on the costume is too tight, but it will do.
vi: Nothing fit quite right; the shoes were a bit too big, the waist a bit too tight, but it was all fine.
tr: None of them fit perfectly, the shoes are a bit big, the chest of the dress is too tight, but it will do.
es: Nothing fits me perfectly: the shoes are a bit big and the waist of the outfit is too tight, but they will do.

en: "There," I say, and he turns around.
vi: "Done," I said, and he turned around.
tr: “Here,” I say, and he turns around.
es: —It's done —I announce, and he turns around.

en: I feel stupid; I want to see myself in a mirror.
vi: I felt awkward, I wanted to look in the mirror.
tr: I feel like an idiot; I want to see myself in a mirror.
es: I feel stupid; I want to see myself in a mirror.

en: "Charming," he says.
vi: “Unparalleled in the world,” he said.
tr: “Nice,” he says.
es: —Charming —he comments—.

en: "Now for the face."
vi: “Now for the face.”
tr: “Now your face too.”
es: And now your face.

en: All he has is a lipstick, old and runny and smelling of artificial grapes, and some eyeliner and mascara.
vi: The entire makeup kit he had consisted of an old, melted lipstick with a chemical grape smell, along with a bit of eyeliner and mascara.
tr: All that’s in the drawer are an old, melted lipstick that smells like artificial grapes, a few eyeliners, and mascara.
es: All she has is an old, soft lipstick with an artificial grape scent, an eyeliner, and makeup.

en: No eye shadow, no blusher.
vi: No eyeshadow, no blush.
tr: There’s no eyeshadow or blush.
es: No eyeshadow, no blush.

en: For a moment I think I won't remember how to do any of this, and my first try with the eyeliner leaves me with a smudged black lid, as if I've been in a fight; but I wipe it off with the vegetable-oil hand lotion and try again.
vi: For a moment, I thought I had forgotten what to do with them and initially ended up with a black smudge like soot, as if I had just been in a fight, but I wiped it off with some cheap lotion and tried again.
tr: For a moment, I think I won’t remember how to do it; my first attempt with the eyeliner leaves a black sooty smudge on my eyelids, as if I’ve been in a fight; but I wipe it off with some hand lotion from vegetable oil and try again.
es: For a moment, I think I won't remember how to do it, and my first attempt with the eyeliner leaves one eyelid stained black, as if I had done it in a fight; but I clean it off with the vegetable oil hand lotion and try again.

en: I rub some of the lipstick along my cheekbones, blending it in.
vi: I dabbed a bit of lipstick on my cheeks and blended it evenly.
tr: I dab a little lipstick on my cheekbones and blend it with my fingers.
es: I lightly rub my cheekbones with the lipstick and blend it out.

en: While I do all this, he holds a large silver-backed hand mirror for me.
vi: From start to finish, he held a large silver-framed mirror in front of me.
tr: While I’m doing all this, he holds a large silver hand mirror for me.
es: While I perform the operation, he holds a huge silver-backed hand mirror for me.

en: I recognize it as Serena Joy's.
vi: I realized it belonged to Serena Joy.
tr: I realize it belongs to Serena Joy.
es: I recognize Serena Joy's mirror.

en: He must have borrowed it from her room.
vi: He must have borrowed it from her room.
tr: He must have borrowed it from her room.
es: He must have taken it from her room.

en: Nothing can be done about my hair.
vi: My hair can't do anything.
tr: There’s nothing I can do with my hair.
es: I can't do anything with my hair.

en: "Terrific," he says.
vi: "Perfect," he said.
tr: “Extraordinary,” he says.
es: —Great —he states.

en: By this time he is quite excited; it's as if we're dressing for a party.
vi: By this time, he was already very excited; it was just like getting ready for a party.
tr: When everything is over, he looks quite excited; as if we are preparing for a party.
es: At this point, he is quite excited; it's as if we were getting dressed to go to a party.

en: He goes to the cupboard and gets out a cloak, with a hood.
vi: He went to the closet to get the cloak, which had a hood.
tr: He goes to the wardrobe and takes out a cloak, hooded.
es: Go to the closet and take out a cloak with a hood.

en: It's light blue, the color for Wives.
vi: Bright blue, the color of the Wives.
tr: Light blue, the color of the Wives.
es: It is light blue, the color of the Wives.

en: This too must be Serena's.
vi: This too must have belonged to Serena.
tr: This must be Serena's.
es: It must also belong to Serena.

en: "Pull the hood down over your face," he says.
vi: “Pull the hat down to cover your face,” he said.
tr: “Pull the hood down to your face,” he says.
es: —Put the hood over your face —he instructs—.

en: "Try not to smear the make-up.
vi: “Remember not to smudge the makeup.
tr: “Be careful not to smudge your makeup.
es: Try not to mess up the makeup.

en: It's for getting through the checkpoints."
vi: This is to get through the checkpoint.”
tr: This is to pass through the checkpoints.”
es: It is to go through the controls.

en: "But what about my pass?" I say.
vi: “But what about the pass?” I asked.
tr: “But what about my access card?” I say.
es: —And my pass? —I ask.

en: "Don't worry about that," he says.
vi: "Don't worry," he said.
tr: “Don't worry about it,” he says.
es: —Don't worry about that —he reassures me—.

en: "I've got one for you."
vi: "I found it for you."
tr: “I got one for you.””
es: I've got one for you.

en: And so we set out.
vi: And so, we set off.
tr: And so, we set off.
es: And we are getting ready to leave.

en: We glide together through the darkening streets.
vi: We crossed the street together as darkness fell.
tr: Together, we slip through the streets that are beginning to darken.
es: We slid together through the streets shrouded in shadows.

en: The Commander has hold of my right hand, as if we're teenagers at the movies.
vi: The Commander held my right hand, like two teenagers going to the movies.
tr: Commander is holding my right hand as if we were teenagers in the cinema.
es: The Commander has taken my right hand, like teenagers in the movies.

en: I clutch the sky-blue cape tightly about me, as a good Wife should.
vi: I clutched my sky-blue coat tightly around me, like a dignified Lady.
tr: I wrap the sky-blue cloak tightly around my body, as a good Wife should.
es: I close my light blue cloak tightly, as a good Wife would do.

en: Through the tunnel made by the hood I can see the back of Nick's head.
vi: Through the gap in my hat, I could see Nick's nape.
tr: Through the tunnel formed by the hood, I can see the back of Nick's head.
es: Through the tunnel formed by the hood, I can see the back of Nick's neck.

en: His hat is on straight, he's sitting up straight, his neck is straight, he is all very straight.
vi: His hat was straight, his back was straight, his nape was straight, his whole body was rigid.
tr: His hat is straight, he sits upright, his neck straight, entirely erect.
es: He wears his cap in the correct position, sits upright with his neck stretched, his whole body is erect.

en: His posture disapproves of me, or am I imagining it?
vi: Was his posture showing discontent towards me, or was I imagining it?
tr: His posture does not acknowledge my existence, or is it just my impression?
es: Does his posture disapprove of my behavior, or am I imagining it?

en: Does he know what I've got on under this cloak, did he procure it?
vi: Did he know what I was wearing under this coat, or did he turn it out himself?
tr: Does he know what's under this cloak, did he provide it?
es: Does he know what I'm wearing under the cloak, did he get it himself?

en: And if so, does this make him angry or lustful or envious or anything at all?
vi: And if so, would he be angry or lustful or jealous, or feel anything at all because of it?
tr: If he provided it, does it make him angry, desirous, jealous, or at least affected?
es: If so, is he angry, does he feel any desire, envy, or something else?

en: We do have something in common: both of us are supposedto be invisible, both of us are functionaries.
vi: We had one thing in common: we both needed to be invisible, existing only within our duties.
tr: We have something in common with him; we are both considered invisible, we are both servants.
es: We have one thing in common: we both must be invisible, we are both officials.

en: I wonder if he knows this.
vi: I didn't know if he understood.
tr: I wonder if he knows this.
es: I wonder if he knows that.

en: When he opened the door of the car for the Commander, and, by
vi: When he opened the car door for the Commander, and incidentally for me, I tried to catch his eye, to make him look at me, but he acted as if he didn't see me there.
tr: When he opened the door for the Commander and then for me, I tried to catch his gaze, to make him look at me, but he acted as if he hadn't seen me.
es: When he opened the car door for the Commander, and by extension for me, I tried to catch his eye, make him look at me, but he acted as if he didn't see me.

en: extension, for me, I tried to catch his eye, make him look at me, but he acted as if he didn't see me.
vi: When he opened the car door for the Commander, and incidentally for me, I tried to catch his eye, to make him look at me, but he acted as if he didn't see me there.
tr: When he opened the door for the Commander and then for me, I tried to catch his gaze, to make him look at me, but he acted as if he hadn't seen me.
es: When he opened the car door for the Commander, and by extension for me, I tried to catch his eye, make him look at me, but he acted as if he didn't see me.

en: Why not?
vi: Why?
tr: Why not?
es: Why not?

en: It's a soft job for him, running little errands, doing little favors, and there's no way he'd want to jeopardize it.
vi: His job was too light, just running errands, assisting with trivial matters, there's no way he wanted to cause trouble for it.
tr: It's an easy task for him, carrying small messages, doing small favors; well, there's no point in risking that, really.
es: For him, it's an easy job: small errands, favors, and I don't think he wants to risk his situation.

en: The checkpoints are no problem, everything goes as smoothly as the Commander said it would, despite the heavy pounding, the pressure of blood in my head.
vi: The checkpoint was easy to pass through, everything went smoothly just as the Commander said, even though my heart was pounding and the blood in my head was rushing.
tr: Checkpoints are not a problem at all, everything is going as smoothly as the Commander said it would, despite my rapid heartbeat and throbbing head.
es: At the checkpoints, no problems arise; everything goes as smoothly as the Commander said, despite the heavy pounding and the pressure of the blood in my head.

en: Chickenshit, Moira would say.
vi: Moira would definitely call me a scaredy-cat.
tr: Scared rabbit, Moira would say.
es: Shitty chicken, Moira would say.

en: Past the second checkpoint, Nick says, "Here, sir?" and the
vi: Passing the second checkpoint, Nick said, "Here, sir?" and the Commander nodded.
tr: After passing the second checkpoint, Nick asks, "Is this the place, Sir?" and the Commander replies, "Yes."
es: When we passed the second checkpoint, Nick asks: —Here, sir?

en: Commander says yes.
vi: Passing the second checkpoint, Nick said, "Here, sir?" and the Commander nodded.
tr: After passing the second checkpoint, Nick asks, "Is this the place, Sir?" and the Commander replies, "Yes."
es: —Yes —replies the Commander.

en: The car pulls over and the Commander says, "Now I'll have to ask you to get down onto the floor of the car."
vi: The car pulled over to the side and the Commander said, "Now I need you to get down on the floor of the car."
tr: The car stops and the Commander says, "Now I have to ask you to lie down on the ground."
es: The car moves forward and the Commander warns me —: Now I will have to ask you to settle down on the floor of the car.

en: "Down?" I say.
vi: "Down to the floor of the car?" I asked.
tr: “To the ground?” I say.'
es: —On the ground? —I am astonished.

en: "We have to go through the gateway," he says, as if this means something to me.
vi: “We are about to go through the gate,” he said, as if that was enough explanation.
tr: “We need to pass through the garden gate,” he says, as if that means something to me.
es: —We have to go through the door —he explains to me, as if that meant something to me.

en: I tried to ask him where we were going, but he said he wanted to surprise me.
vi: I tried to ask where we were going, but he said he wanted to surprise me.
tr: I tried to ask where we were going, but he said he wanted to surprise me.
es: I tried to ask him where we were going, but he said he wanted to surprise me.

en: "Wives aren't allowed."
vi: “Wives are not allowed through.”
tr: “Wives are not allowed to enter.”
es: —. Wives are not allowed to enter.

en: So I flatten myself and the car starts again, and for the next few minutes I see nothing.
vi: So I lay flat and the car continued to move, then for a few minutes I saw nothing.
tr: Thus, I flatten myself and the car starts moving again, for the next few minutes I see nothing.
es: So I press myself against the ground and the car starts again, and for a few minutes I see nothing.

en: Under the cloak it's stifling hot.
vi: The coat was suffocatingly hot.
tr: It's suffocatingly hot under the cloak.
es: Under the coat, it's unbearably hot.

en: It's a winter cloak, not a cotton summer one, and it smells of mothballs.
vi: It was a winter coat, not a summer cotton coat, reeking of mothballs.
tr: It's a winter cloak, not a summer cotton one, and it smells of mothballs.
es: It's a winter coat, not made of cotton like the summer ones, and it smells of mothballs.

en: He must have borrowed it from storage, knowing she wouldn't notice.
vi: He must have borrowed it from the storage, knowing she wouldn't notice.
tr: He must have borrowed it from the storeroom, knowing Serena wouldn't notice.
es: He must have taken it from the winter clothes closet, knowing she wouldn't notice.

en: He has considerately moved his feet to give me room.
vi: He had carefully moved his feet to make room for me, but my forehead still pressed against his shoes.
tr: He has respectfully pulled his feet back to make room for me.
es: He was kind enough to move his feet to make room for me.

en: Nevertheless my foreheadis against his shoes.
vi: He had carefully moved his feet to make room for me, but my forehead still pressed against his shoes.
tr: Nevertheless, my forehead touches his shoes.
es: Even so, my forehead is against his shoes.

en: I have never been this close to his shoes before.
vi: I had never seen his shoes so close before.
tr: I've never been this close to his shoes before.
es: I've never been so close to his shoes before.

en: They feel hard, unwinking, like the shells of beetles: black, polished, inscrutable.
vi: The shoes were stiff, without a crease, like beetle shells: black, polished, impenetrable.
tr: They're hard and matte, like insect shells: black, painted, mysterious.
es: They seem hard, impenetrable like the shell of cockroaches: black, polished, unyielding.

en: They seem to have nothing to do with feet.
vi: They seemed to have nothing to do with feet.
tr: They seem to have nothing to do with feet.
es: It's as if they had nothing to do with the feet.

en: We pass through another checkpoint.
vi: Passing through another checkpoint.
tr: We are passing through another checkpoint.
es: We passed through another checkpoint.

en: I hear the voices, impersonal, deferential, and the window rolling electrically down and up for the passes to be shown.
vi: I hear a voice, respectful, and the electric door opens down and up to present the pass.
tr: I hear official, respectful voices and the electric window going up and down to show the transit papers.
es: I hear the impersonal and respectful voices, and the window that goes down and up electrically so that he can present the passes.

en: This time he won't show mine, the one that's supposed to be mine, as I'm no longer in official existence, for now.
vi: This time, there is no paper of mine, the paper considered to be mine, because I no longer officially exist, at this moment.
tr: This time, they won't show mine, the one that is supposed to be mine, since I officially don't exist anymore.
es: This time he doesn't show mine, the one that is supposed to be mine, because officially I don't exist, for now.

en: Then the car starts and then it stops again, and the Commander is helping me up.
vi: Then the car moved again, stopped again, and I saw the Commander help me up.
tr: Then the car moves and stops again, and the Commander helps me to stand up.
es: Then the car starts and stops again, and the commander helps me to get up.

en: "We'll have to be fast," he says.
vi: “We have to hurry,” he said.
tr: “We must act quickly,” he says.
es: —We will have to be quick —he comments—.

en: "This is a back entrance.
vi: “This is the back door.
tr: “This is the back entrance.
es: This is a back entrance.

en: You should leave the cloak with Nick.
vi: You can leave the coat for Nick.
tr: You must leave the cloak with Nick.
es: You will leave the cloak with Nick.

en: On the hour, as usual," he says to Nick.
vi: Same time, as always,” he said to Nick.
tr: At the usual time,” he says to Nick finally.
es: At the usual time —he says to Nick.

en: So
vi: So this had happened before as well.
tr: So, this is something he has done before.
es: So this is also something he has done before.

en: this too is something he's done before.
vi: So this had happened before as well.
tr: So, this is something he has done before.
es: So this is also something he has done before.

en: He helps me out of the cloak; the car door is opened.
vi: He helped me take off my cloak; the car door was left open.
tr: He is helping me take off the pilgrims; the car door is open now.
es: He helps me take off my coat; the car door is open.

en: I feel air on my almost-bare skin, and realize I've been sweating.
vi: I felt the air on my nearly bare skin and realized I had been sweating.
tr: I almost feel the air on my bare skin and realize that I am sweating.
es: I feel the air on my almost bare skin and realize that I have been sweating.
