en: As I turn to shut the car door behind me I can see Nick looking at me through the glass.
vi: When I turned back to close the car door, I saw Nick looking straight at me through the window.
tr: As I turn to close the car door, I can see Nick looking at me through the mirror.
es: When I turn to close the car door, I see Nick looking at me through the glass.

en: He sees me now.
vi: Now he had seen me.
tr: Now he sees me.
es: Now he sees me.

en: Is it contempt I read, or indifference, is this merely what he expected of me?
vi: Was that contempt or indifference? Did he expect nothing more from me?
tr: The meaning I read in his eyes—is it contempt, indifference, or is this just what he expects from me?
es: What I see is disdain, or indifference, is it simply what he expected from me?

en: We're in an alleyway behind a building, red brick and fairly modern.
vi: We are in the alley behind a building, built with red bricks, relatively modern.
tr: We are in the alley behind a red brick and quite modern building.
es: We are in an alley, behind a fairly modern red brick building.

en: A bank of trash cans is set out beside the door, and there's a smell of fried chicken, going bad.
vi: A row of trash cans is placed by the door, with a faint smell of fried chicken, going stale, the leader has the key, opens the bare, gray door, level with the wall and - I think - made of iron.
tr: A pile of empty tin cans is placed outside, next to the door; there is a smell of rotting fried chicken in the air.
es: Next to the door, there is a row of garbage bins that smell like decomposing fried chicken.

en: The Commander has a key to the door, which is plain and gray and flush with the wall and, I think, made of steel.
vi: A row of trash cans is placed by the door, with a faint smell of fried chicken, going stale, the leader has the key, opens the bare, gray door, level with the wall and - I think - made of iron.
tr: The Commander has the key to the flat, gray, and wall-flush door, which I think is made of steel.
es: The Commander inserts the key into the door, which is flat and gray and level with the wall and, it seems to me, is made of steel.

en: Inside it there's a concrete-block corridor lit with fluorescent overhead lights; some kind of functional tunnel.
vi: Inside is a bare concrete corridor lit by neon lights, a kind of specialized tunnel.
tr: Inside, there is a concrete block corridor illuminated by fluorescent overhead lights; a kind of functional tunnel.
es: Inside, there is a concrete hallway illuminated with fluorescent lamps; a sort of functional tunnel.

en: "Here," the Commander says.
vi: "Come here," the Commander said.
tr: “Here,” says the Commander.
es: —It's here —the Commander tells me.

en: He slips around my wrist a tag, purple, on an elastic band, like the tags for airport luggage.
vi: He looped a tag around my wrist, purple in color, with an elastic band, like an airport luggage tag.
tr: He attaches a purple tag to my wrist with an elastic band, like the tags used for luggage at the airport.
es: He places a purple tag with an elastic band on my wrist, like the tags they give at airports for luggage—.

en: "If anyone asks you, say you're an evening rental," he says.
vi: "If anyone asks, tell them you were hired for one night," he instructed.
tr: “If anyone asks, you say you’ve been rented for the evening,” he says.
es: If anyone asks, say you are rented for tonight —

en: He takes me by the bare upper arm and steers me forward.
vi: He grabbed my bare upper arm and pushed me forward.
tr: He grabs me by the upper part of my bare arm and directs me forward.
es: advises me. Takes me by the arm to guide me.

en: What I want is a mirror, to see if my lipstick is all right, whether the feathers are too ridiculous, too frowzy.
vi: I just wanted a mirror to see if my lipstick was in place, if the feathers were too gaudy, too disheveled.
tr: What I want is a mirror; I wonder if my lipstick is appropriate, if my hair looks too silly, too messy.
es: What I want is a mirror to see if my lips are well painted or if the feathers are too ridiculous and very disordered.

en: Inthis light I must look lurid.
vi: Under this light, I must look quite ghostly.
tr: I must look terrible under a light.
es: With this light, I must look very pale.

en: Though it's too late now.
vi: Though it was already too late.
tr: Though it’s too late now.
es: But it is already too late.

en: Idiot, says Moira.
vi: You fool, Moira said.
tr: Fool, says Moira.
es: Idiot, says Moira.
CHAPTER 37

en: We go along the corridor and through another flat gray door and along another corridor, softly lit and carpeted this time, in a mushroom color, browny pink.
vi: We followed the corridor through another gray round door and then another corridor, this time dimly lit and carpeted, pinkish-brown, mushroom-colored.
tr: We walk along the corridor, pass through another dull gray door, and this time walk along another corridor that is slightly lit and carpeted in a mushroom-colored, brownish-pink hue.
es: We walked down the hallway, went through another flat, gray door, and proceeded down another hallway, this time illuminated and covered with a mushroom-colored, dusky pink carpet.

en: Doors open off it, with numbers on them: a hundred and one, a hundred and two, the way you count during a thunderstorm, to see how close you are to being struck.
vi: Doors opened on both sides, each numbered: one hundred and one, one hundred and two, like people counting in a storm to see how close the lightning has struck.
tr: There are numbered doors opening into this hall: one hundred one, one hundred two, like counting in a storm to understand how close the lightning is to you.
es: The doors open outward and are numbered: one hundred one, one hundred two, like one counts during a storm to know how far away it is.

en: It's a hotel then.
vi: So it turned out to be a hotel.
tr: So, this is a hotel.
es: So, it's a hotel.

en: From behind one of the doors comes laughter, a man's and also a woman's.
vi: From behind one of the doors came laughter, the voices of both men and women.
tr: Laughter is coming from behind one of the doors, from a man and a woman.
es: From behind one of the doors, laughter can be heard, that of a man and a woman.

en: It's a long time since I've heard that.
vi: It had been a long time since I had heard that.
tr: It's been a long time since I heard these sounds.
es: It had been a long time since I heard laughter.

en: We emerge into a central courtyard.
vi: Stepping out of the hallway, we found ourselves in the central courtyard.
tr: We step into a central courtyard.
es: We stepped out into a central courtyard.

en: It's wide and also high: it goes up several stories to a skylight at the top.
vi: The courtyard was very spacious and tall too: extending up several floors to the glass dome above.
tr: It is spacious and also high: it rises several stories up to the skylight at the top.
es: It is spacious and tall, with several floors leading up to the skylight at the top.

en: There's a fountain in the middle of it, a round fountain spraying water in the shape of a dandelion goneto seed.
vi: In the middle, a round fountain sprayed water in all directions like a dandelion in seed.
tr: In the middle, there is a fountain, a round fountain spraying water in the shape of a dandelion gone to seed.
es: In the center, there is a fountain, a round fountain that sprays water in the shape of a dandelion that is beginning to seed.

en: Potted plants and trees sprout here and there,
vi: Trees in the planters and on the courtyard sprouted everywhere, with vines hanging down from the balconies.
tr: Here and there, flowers in pots and budding trees, vines hanging from balconies.
es: Plants in pots and tree saplings here and there, vines hanging from the balconies.

en: vines hang down from the balconies.
vi: Trees in the planters and on the courtyard sprouted everywhere, with vines hanging down from the balconies.
tr: Here and there, flowers in pots and budding trees, vines hanging from balconies.
es: Plants in pots and tree saplings here and there, vines hanging from the balconies.

en: Oval-sided glass elevators slide up and down the walls like giant mollusks.
vi: Oval-shaped glass-walled elevators crawled along the walls like giant naked snails.
tr: Oval-shaped glass elevators glide up and down the walls like giant snails.
es: Elevators with oval glass panels glide up and down like giant mollusks.

en: I know where I am.
vi: I know where this is.
tr: I know where I am.
es: I know where I am.

en: I've been here before: with Luke, in the afternoons, a long time ago.
vi: I have been here before: with Luke, in the afternoons, from a long time ago.
tr: I had been here before: with Luke, in the evenings, a long time ago.
es: I've been here before: with Luke, in the afternoons, a long time ago.

en: It was a hotel, then.
vi: This was a hotel, back then.
tr: It was a hotel, that evening.
es: It used to be a hotel.

en: Now it's full of women.
vi: Now there are only women.
tr: Now it is full of women.
es: Now it's full of women.

en: I stand still and stare at them.
vi: I stood still in one place and watched them.
tr: I stand still and watch them.
es: I stay still and watch them.

en: I can stare, here, look around me, there are no white wings to keep me from it.
vi: I could look to my heart's content, here, all around, with no white wings to block my view.
tr: I can watch, here, I can look around, there are no white wings to block me.
es: Here I can stare, look around, I no longer have the wimple that prevents me from doing so.

en: My head, shorn of them, feels curiously light; as if a weight has been removed from it, or substance.
vi: My head, having its wings clipped, became unusually light, as if a heavy mass, a chunk of matter, had been cut away.
tr: My head, freed from them, feels unusually light to me; as if a burden or a weight has been lifted from it.
es: My head, stripped of it, feels strangely light, as if a weight or part of its substance has been removed.

en: The women are sitting, lounging, strolling, leaning against one another.
vi: The women were sitting, lounging around, or walking, leaning against each other.
tr: The women are sitting, lying down, walking around, leaning on each other.
es: The women are sitting, lounging, walking around, or leaning against each other.

en: There are men mingled with them, a lot of men, but in their dark uniforms or suits, so similar to one another, they form only a kind of background.
vi: There were also men with them, many men, but dressed in military uniforms or black suits, looking identical, they just formed a background.
tr: There are men mixed among them, many men, but with their dark uniforms or clothes, they resemble each other so much that they only form a kind of background.
es: Mixed with them are some men, heaps of men who, dressed in their uniforms or dark suits, so similar to each other, form an undifferentiated background.

en: The women on the other hand are tropical, they are dressed in all kinds of bright festive gear.
vi: In contrast, the women were vibrant in tropical colors, wearing countless festive and dazzling outfits.
tr: On the other hand, the women are dressed in tropical, bright, festival outfits of all kinds.
es: The women, for their part, have a tropical look, dressed in all kinds of festive and bright clothes.

en: Some of them have on outfits like mine, feathers and glister, cut high up the thighs, low over the breasts.
vi: Some dressed like me, with bright feathers and beads, high-slit skirts, and deeply cut necklines.
tr: Some are dressed like me, feathered and glittery, with dresses that have stripes from the hips and end just above the breasts.
es: Some of them wear outfits like mine, with feathers and shiny decorations, low-cut at the thighs and breasts.

en: Some are in olden-days lingerie, shor-tie nightgowns, baby-doll pajamas, the occasional see-through negligee.
vi: Some wore vintage-style lingerie, thigh-length nightgowns, baby doll dresses, and a few in sheer lace dresses.
tr: Some are wearing old-fashioned lingerie, short nightgowns, fantasy pajamas, familiar sheer robes.
es: Some are wearing underwear like what used to be worn before, short nightgowns, short pajamas, and the occasional transparent negligee.

en: Some are in bathing suits, one piece or bikini; one, I see, is wearing a crocheted affair, with big scallop shells covering the tits.
vi: Some were in swimsuits, one-piece or two-piece; one person, I noticed, wore crocheted yarn, with two large shells covering her nipples.
tr: Some are in swimsuits, one-piece or bikinis; I see someone wearing a lacy thing made of large comb-like shells covering her nipples.
es: Others are wearing swimsuits, either one-piece or bikinis; there's one with a garment made of crochet and huge scallop shells covering her breasts.

en: Some are in jogging shorts and sun halters, some in exercise costumes like the ones they used to show on television, body-tight, with knitted pastel leg warmers.
vi: Some wore running shorts and backless tops, some in exercise outfits often seen on TV in the past, tight-fitting, with light-colored knitted leg warmers.
tr: Some are in running shorts and sun visors, and some are in exercise leotards with pastel-colored knitted leggings, similar to those shown on TV in the past.
es: Some are dressed in sports shorts and open-back blouses, others in gym leotards like those seen on TV, tight, and pastel-colored knitted leg warmers.

en: There are even a few in cheerleaders' outfits, little pleated skirts, outsized letters across the chest.
vi: There were even some dressed like cheerleaders, in short plaid skirts, with large letters across their chests.
tr: There are even a few dressed in cheerleader costumes, with small pleated skirts and large letters on the chest.
es: You can even see some in cheerleader outfits, short pleated skirts, and huge letters on their chests.

en: I guess they've had to fall back on a melange, whatever they could scrounge or salvage.
vi: They probably had to accept this eclectic collection, whatever could still be scavenged.
tr: I think they had to make do with a mix of what they could steal or save.
es: I imagine they had to resort to this mix, to whatever they could swipe or salvage.

en: All wear make-up, and I realize how unaccustomed I've become to seeing it, on women, because their eyes look too big to me, too dark and shimmering, their mouths too red, too wet, blood-dipped and glistening; or, on the other hand, too clownish.
vi: Everyone was made up, and now I realized how unaccustomed I had become to seeing makeup, because their eyes seemed too big, too deep, and too sparkling, their mouths too red, too wet, glistening with bright blood; or thinking another way, too much like clowns.
tr: They all have makeup on, and I realize how much I've lost the habit of seeing it on women, because their eyes seem very large, very dark and shiny, their mouths very red, very wet, blood-stained and glittery to me; or, on the other hand, very clownish.
es: They are all made up, and I realize how strange it is for me to see women with makeup, because their eyes seem too big, too dark and shiny, their mouths too red, too wet, as if bathed in blood; or, on the other hand, clownish.

en: At first glance there's a cheerfulness to this scene.
vi: At first glance, the whole scene looks so cheerful.
tr: At first glance, this scene is almost festive.
es: At first glance, there is a certain joy in the scene.

en: It's like a masquerade party; they are like oversize children, dressed up in togs they've rummaged from trunks.
vi: Like a masquerade party; there are oversized children, dressed up in costumes dug out from the bottom of chests and trunks.
tr: Like a masquerade ball; they are like big children, in the clothes they rummaged out of the chests.
es: It's like a costume dance; they are like children too grown-up for their age, dressed in outfits they found rummaging through a trunk.

en: Is there joy in this?
vi: Is it fun?
tr: Is there joy in this?
es: Is there something pleasurable in all this?

en: There could be,
vi: Perhaps, but is it their choice?
tr: Maybe, but is this their own choice?
es: It could be, but did they choose it?

en: but have they chosen it?
vi: Perhaps, but is it their choice?
tr: Maybe, but is this their own choice?
es: It could be, but did they choose it?

en: You can't tell by looking.
vi: How can one know just by looking?
tr: This cannot be understood by appearances.
es: It cannot be deduced at first sight.

en: There are a great many buttocks in this room.
vi: In the room, there were countless butts on display.
tr: A parade of butts is swaying in this room.
es: In this room, there is a large number of butts.

en: I am no longer used to them.
vi: I am no longer familiar with them.
tr: I'm not very used to them anymore.
es: I'm not used to them anymore.

en: "It's like walking into the past," says the Commander.
vi: “It's like stepping into the past,” the Commander said.
tr: “It's like walking into the past,” says the Commander.
es: —It's like traveling to the past —comments the Commander in a satisfied, even delighted tone—

en: His voice sounds pleased, delighted even.
vi: He seemed pleased, even delighted.
tr: His voice sounds pleased, even joyful.
es: —It's like traveling to the past —comments the Commander in a satisfied, even delighted tone—

en: "Don't you think?"
vi: “Isn't it?”
tr: “Don't you think so?”
es: Don't you think?

en: I try to remember if the past was exactly like this.
vi: I try to remember if the past was really like this.
tr: I'm trying to remember if the past was exactly like this.
es: I try to remember if the past was exactly like this.

en: I'm not sure, now.
vi: I'm not sure anymore.
tr: I'm not quite sure, now.
es: Now I'm not sure.

en: I know it contained these things, but somehow the mix is different.
vi: I know all these things were in it, but the proportions have somehow changed.
tr: I know it contained things like this, but this mixture is somehow different.
es: I know it contained these things, but somehow the mix is different.

en: A movie about the past is not the same as the past.
vi: A film about the past is still not the past.
tr: A film about the past is not the same as the past.
es: A movie about the past is not the same as the past.

en: "Yes," I say.
vi: "Yes," I said.
tr: “Yes,” I say.
es: —Yes —I affirm.

en: What I feel is not one simple thing.
vi: My feelings were not a singular thing.
tr: It's not just one thing I feel.
es: What I feel is not a simple thing.

en: Certainly I am not dismayed by these women, not shocked by them.
vi: Of course, I was not bewildered by those women, not horrified.
tr: Of course, these women do not scare me, nor do they astonish me.
es: Certainly, these women do not scare me, they do not impress me.

en: I recognize them as truants.
vi: I considered them deserters.
tr: I look at them as school dropouts.
es: I recognize in them the type of idle woman.

en: The official creed denies them, denies their very existence, yet here they are.
vi: The official doctrine denied them, denied the very fact of their existence, but they were still here.
tr: The official view denies them, denies even their existence, yet here they are.
es: The official creed rejects them, denies their very existence, and yet, here they are.

en: That is at least something.
vi: At least that meant something.
tr: At the very least, it's something.
es: At least that is something.

en: "Don't gawk," says the Commander.
vi: “Don't stare like that,” the Commander said.
tr: “Stop looking around,” says the Commander.
es: —Don't just stand there staring stupidly —the Commander advises me, or you'll give yourself away.

en: "You'll give yourself away.
vi: “You'll give yourself away.
tr: “You will give yourself away.
es: —Don't just stand there staring stupidly —the Commander advises me, or you'll give yourself away.

en: Just act natural."
vi: Just act natural.”
tr: Act naturally.”
es: Act naturally

en: Again he leads me forward.
vi: Once again, he pulled me along.
tr: He directs me forward again.
es: —guide me again.

en: Another man has spotted him, has greeted him and set himself in motion towards us.
vi: Someone had noticed him, greeted him, and started walking towards us.
tr: Another man salutes him and starts moving towards us.
es: A man has recognized him, greeted him, and started walking towards us.

en: The Commander's grip tightens on my upper arm.
vi: The Commander's hand tightened around my arm.
tr: The Commander's hand tightens on my arm.
es: The Commander grabs my arm more firmly.

en: "Steady," he whispers.
vi: “Stay still,” he whispered.
tr: “Stay calm,” he whispers.
es: —. Calm down —he whispers—.

en: "Don't lose your nerve."
vi: “Don't panic.”
tr: “Don't lose yourself.”
es: Don't lose your composure.

en: All you have to do, I tell myself, is keep your mouth shut and look stupid.
vi: All your task, I told myself, is to keep your mouth shut tightly and put on a dumb face.
tr: All you have to do, I tell myself, is keep your mouth shut and look stupid.
es: All you have to do, I tell myself, is keep your mouth shut and look stupid.

en: It shouldn't be that hard.
vi: It's not that hard.
tr: That shouldn't be so hard.
es: It's not that hard.

en: The Commander does the talking for me, to this man and to the others who follow him.
vi: The commander took over the conversation for me, with this person and the ones that followed.
tr: The Commander does the talking on my behalf, with this man and the others who follow him.
es: The Commander speaks for me, with this man and with the others who come with him.

en: He doesn't say much about me, he doesn't need to.
vi: He didn't say much about me, as there wasn't much to say.
tr: He doesn't say much about me, there's no need for that.
es: He doesn't say much about me, he doesn't need to.

en: He says I'm new, and they look at me and dismiss me and confer together about other things.
vi: He just mentioned that I was new, and they looked at me and then moved on to discuss other matters.
tr: He says that I am new, they look at me and then leave me to talk about other things.
es: He explains that I am new and they look at me, dismiss me, and proceed to talk about other things.

en: My disguise performs its function.
vi: The disguise had done its job.
tr: My disguise serves its purpose.
es: My disguise has fulfilled its function.

en: He retains hold of my arm, and as he talks his spine straightens imperceptibly, his chest expands, his voice assumes more and more the sprightliness and jocularity of youth.
vi: He still held my hand, and as we talked, his back straightened almost imperceptibly, his chest expanded, and his voice grew increasingly lively and youthful.
tr: He grabs my arm again and while talking, his spine subtly straightens, his chest expands, his voice gradually takes on the vitality and playfulness of youth.
es: He keeps holding my arm and, as he speaks, his spine becomes imperceptibly rigid, his chest expands, his voice adopts more and more the vivacity and jocularity of youth.

en: It occurs to me he is showing off.
vi: I suddenly realized he was showing off.
tr: It seems to me that he is showing off.
es: It occurs to me that he is showing off.

en: He is showing me off, to them, and they understand that, they are decorous enough, they keep their hands to themselves, but they review my breasts, my legs, as if there's no reason why they shouldn't.
vi: He was showing me off, in front of them, and they understood, they were also quite formal, their hands and feet still, but they were still appraising my chest, my thighs, as if there was no reason to do otherwise.
tr: He is showing off to them with me, and they understand it, they are polite enough, they keep their hands to themselves, but they scrutinize my chest, my legs, as if there is no reason not to.
es: He is showing me off to them, and they understand and are decorous enough, keeping their hands still but observing my breasts and legs as if there were no reason not to.

en: But also he is showing off to me.
vi: But he was also showing off to me.
tr: But he is also showing off to me.
es: But he is also showing off to me.

en: He is demonstrating, to
vi: But he was also showing off to me.
tr: But he is also showing off to me.
es: But he is also showing off to me.

en: me, his mastery of the world.
vi: He was performing, showing me how he dominated the world.
tr: He is showing me his dominance over the world.
es: He is demonstrating his mastery of the world to me.

en: He's breaking the rules, under their noses, thumbing his nose at them, getting away with it.
vi: He was breaking the rules, right under their noses, sticking his tongue out at them, without facing any consequences.
tr: He breaks the rules right under their noses, mocks them, evades them.
es: He is breaking the rules right under their noses, mocking them.

en: Perhaps he's reached that state of intoxication which power is said to inspire, the state in which you believe you are indispensable and can therefore do anything, absolutely anything you feel like, anything at all.
vi: Perhaps he had reached that state of delusion that is said to arise from power, believing himself to be an indispensable figure who could do anything, everything he wanted, anything at all.
tr: Perhaps he has reached the state of intoxication said to be inspired by power, the state where you believe you are indispensable and therefore can do everything, absolutely everything, just as you wish.
es: Perhaps he has reached that state of intoxication that, it is said, power inspires, that state that makes some feel indispensable and believe they can do anything, absolutely anything they please.

en: Twice, when he thinks no one is looking, he winks at me.
vi: Twice, thinking no one saw, he winked at me.
tr: Twice, when he thinks no one is looking, he winks at me.
es: For the second time, when he thinks no one is looking, he winks at me.

en: It's a juvenile display, the whole act, and pathetic; but it's something
vi: This performance is so childish, and pitiful too; but I understand it.
tr: This is a childish display, all this action, pathetic; but something I understand.
es: All this is childish ostentation, and a pathetic situation; but it is something I understand.

en: I understand.
vi: This performance is so childish, and pitiful too; but I understand it.
tr: This is a childish display, all this action, pathetic; but something I understand.
es: All this is childish ostentation, and a pathetic situation; but it is something I understand.

en: When he's done enough of this he leads me away again, to a puffy flowered sofa of the kind they once had in hotel lobbies; in this lobby, in fact, it's a floral design I remember, dark blue background, pink art nouveau flowers.

es: When she gets tired of the conversation, she takes me by the arm again, this time to a soft, flowered sofa, like the ones that used to be in hotel lobbies; in fact, in this lobby, there is a floral pattern that I still remember, a dark blue background with pink art nouveau style flowers.

tr: By this time, it was around five o'clock.
es: At that moment it was around five o'clock.

en: I was tired of walking, especially that Aunt's way like a goddamn soldier, poker up the ass, and I hadn't had anything to eat since breakfast.
vi: It was nearly five in the afternoon, I was tired from walking, especially in that damned soldier's gait, straight as a stick, and I hadn't eaten anything since morning.
tr: I was tired from walking, especially because of the style of the Aunts who walked like damned soldiers with a prod hanging from their rear, and I hadn't eaten anything since breakfast.
es: She was exhausted from so much walking, especially in the way the Aunts did it, like a damn soldier, with their butt sticking out; besides, she hadn't eaten anything since breakfast time.

en: "What I didn't know of course was that in those early days the Aunts and even the Center were hardly common knowledge.
vi: “What I obviously didn't know was that in those early days, few people knew about the aunts and even the Center itself.
tr: Undoubtedly, what I didn't know was that in those early days, the Aunts, even the Center, were not well known.
es: »What, logically, they didn't know was that in those days the existence of the Aunts, and even the Center, were not public knowledge.

en: It was all secret at first, behind barbed wire.
vi: At first, it was an absolute secret, behind the barbed wire fence.
tr: At first, everything was a secret; what they did behind the barbed wire could be opposed, even then.
es: At first, everything that happened behind the wire fences was kept secret.

en: There might have been objections to what they were doing, even then.
vi: There might have been some opposition to what they were doing, even at that time.
tr: At first, everything was a secret; what they did behind the barbed wire could be opposed, even then.
es: Even then, there might have been objections to what they were doing.

en: So although people had seen the odd Aunt around, they weren't really aware of what they were for.
vi: So even if people saw those strange aunts wandering around, they still didn't know exactly what those women were up to.
tr: Thus, although people saw the strange Aunts around, they were not really aware of what they were actually doing.
es: So although some people might have seen the strange Aunt, they really didn't know who she was.

en: They must have thought they were some kind of army nurse.
vi: Everyone probably thought they were some kind of military nurses.
tr: They must have thought they were some sort of army nurses.
es: They might have thought she was some kind of army nurse.

en: Already they'd stopped asking questions, unless they had to.
vi: By now, people had learned to stop asking questions, unless absolutely necessary.
tr: They had long since stopped asking questions unless they had to.
es: People no longer asked questions, unless they had no other choice.

en: "So these people let me in right away.
vi: “So the homeowner let me in right away.
tr: Thus, these people immediately let me inside.
es: »So these people let me in right away.

en: It was the woman who came to the door.
vi: The one who opened the door was the wife.
tr: The person who came to the door was a woman.
es: It was the woman who came to open the door.

en: I told her I was doing a questionnaire.
vi: I told her I was conducting a survey.
tr: I told her that I was conducting a survey.
es: I told her I was conducting a survey.

en: I did that so she wouldn't look surprised, in case anyone was watching.
vi: I said that so she wouldn't be too surprised, in case someone was watching.
tr: I said this so that if someone was watching, they wouldn't look surprised.
es: I did it so that, in case someone saw us, they wouldn't notice her astonishment.

en: Bui as soon as I was inside the door, I took off the headgear and told them who I was.
vi: But as soon as I got inside, I took off the scarf and revealed who I really was.
tr: But as soon as I stepped inside, I took off my hood and told them who I was.
es: But as soon as I was inside the house, I took off the headpiece and explained who I was.

en: They could have phoned thepolice or whatever, I know I was taking a chance, but like I say there wasn't any choice.
vi: They could very well have called the police or something, I knew I was taking a risk, but I had no choice.
tr: They could have called the police or someone else, I know, I was taking a risk, but as I said, I had no other choice.
es: They could have called the police, or something like that, I know I was taking that risk, but as I said, I had no other choice.

en: Anyway they didn't.
vi: But in any case, they didn't call.
tr: Anyway, they didn't call.
es: Anyway, they didn't do it.

en: They gave me some clothes, a dress of hers, and burned the Aunt's outfit and the pass in their furnace; they knew that had to be done right away.
vi: They gave me clothes, the wife's dress, and burned the maid's uniform and my ID in the fireplace; they knew this couldn't be delayed.
tr: They gave me some clothes, one of the woman's dresses, Aunt's clothes, and they burned her identity in their stove; they knew this had to be done immediately.
es: They provided me with some clothes, one of her dresses, and burned the Aunt's suit and the pass in the fireplace; they knew it was the first thing to do.

en: They didn't like having me there, that much was clear, it made them very nervous.
vi: They didn't want me there, that was obvious, they were extremely tense.
tr: They didn't like having me there, that much was clear, it made them quite nervous.
es: It was evident that they didn't like having me in their house, it made them nervous.

en: They had two little kids, both under seven.
vi: They had two children, both under seven years old.
tr: They had two small children, both under the age of seven.
es: They had two small children, both under seven years old.

en: I could see their point.
vi: I understood their feelings.
tr: I could understand their reasons.
es: I understood their situation.

en: "I went to the can, what a relief that was.
vi: “I went to the bathroom, oh how relieved I felt.
tr: I went to the bathroom, what a great relief.
es: "I went to the bathroom, what a relief."

en: Bathtub full of plastic fish and so on.
vi: The bathtub was filled with plastic fish and other things.
tr: The tub was filled with plastic fish and so on.
es: "And then the bathtub full of plastic fish, etcetera."

en: Then I sat upstairs in the kids' room and played with them and their plastic blocks while their parents stayed downstairs and
vi: Then I went upstairs, sat in the children's room, and played with the kids and a puzzle set while their parents were downstairs discussing what to do with me.
tr: While the parents stayed downstairs and decided what to do with me, I sat in the children's room upstairs, playing with them and their plastic blocks.
es: Afterwards, I stayed upstairs in the children's room and played with them and their plastic blocks while their parents were downstairs, deciding what they would do with me.

en: decided what to do about me.
vi: Then I went upstairs, sat in the children's room, and played with the kids and a puzzle set while their parents were downstairs discussing what to do with me.
tr: While the parents stayed downstairs and decided what to do with me, I sat in the children's room upstairs, playing with them and their plastic blocks.
es: Afterwards, I stayed upstairs in the children's room and played with them and their plastic blocks while their parents were downstairs, deciding what they would do with me.

en: I didn't feel scared by then, in fact I felt quite good.
vi: At that time, I didn't feel panicked; on the contrary, I felt very happy.
tr: At that time, I wasn't scared; in fact, I felt very good.
es: I wasn't scared; in fact, I felt quite good.

en: Fatalistic, you could say.
vi: The thought of fate, you could say.
tr: You could say I was fatalistic.
es: Fatalistic, you would say.

en: Then the woman made me a sandwich and a cup of coffee and the man said he'd take me to another house.
vi: Then the wife made me a sandwich with a cup of coffee while the husband said he would take me to another house.
tr: Then the woman made me a sandwich and a cup of coffee, and the man told me he would take me to another house.
es: Then the woman made me a sandwich and a cup of coffee, and the man told me that he was going to take me to another house.

en: They hadn't risked phoning.
vi: They didn't dare to pick up the phone.
tr: They hadn't dared to make a phone call.
es: They hadn't risked calling on the phone.

en: "The other house was Quakers too, and they were pay dirt, because they were a station on the Underground Femaleroad.
vi: “That house was also Quaker, and I turned out to strike gold, because they were a station on the Women's Underground Railroad.
tr: The other house belonged to the Quakers, and it was just the right place because it was a station on the Underground Female Road.
es: "The people in the other house were also Quakers and represented an interesting resource because they were one of the stations of the Women's Metropolitan Train."

en: After the first man left, they said they'd tryto get me out of the country.
vi: When the other person returned, they said they would take me abroad.
tr: After the first man left, they told me they would try to get me out of the country.
es: When the first couple left, they told me they would try to get me out of the country.

en: I won't tell you how, because some of the stations may still be operating.
vi: I won't give you the details, because some stations might still be operational.
tr: I'm not going to tell you how, because some stations might still be operational.
es: I won't say how, because maybe some of the stations still work.

en: Each one of them was in contact with only one other one, always the next one along.
vi: Each station only connects with one other station, which is the next one in line.
tr: Each station was only in contact with another, always with the next one.
es: Each of these was in contact with only one of the others, always with the next one.

en: There were advantages to thatit was better if you were caughtbutdisadvantages too, because if one station got busted the entire chain backed up until they could make contact with one of their couriers, who could set up an alternate route.
vi: This has its advantages - when caught in a net for example - but also disadvantages, because if one station is raided, the whole line is halted until contact is made with a courier capable of establishing a new route.
tr: This system had its advantages—it worked when caught—but also disadvantages, because when one station was dismantled, the entire chain broke until contact was made with one of the couriers who could establish another route.
es: It had several advantages... it was better if you got caught, but also disadvantages, because if they wiped out one station, the whole chain was dismantled until they managed to establish contact with one of their couriers, who designed a new itinerary.

en: They were better organized than you'd think, though.
vi: However, they are better organized than you might imagine.
tr: They were better organized than you might think, nonetheless.
es: However, they were better organized than anyone could suppose.

en: They'd infiltrated a coupleof useful places; one of them was the post office.
vi: They have managed to infiltrate some useful places; among them is the post office.
tr: They had infiltrated a few key places; one was the post office.
es: They were infiltrated in a couple of useful places; one of them was the post office.

en: They had a driver there with one of those handy little trucks.
vi: There, they have a driver with a quite handy small truck.
tr: There, they had a driver with that handy little truck.
es: There they had a driver who drove one of those handy carts.

en: I made it over the bridge and into the city proper in a mail sack.
vi: I got through the gate into the inner city in a mail sack.
tr: I went to the city from the bridge in a mailbag.
es: I managed to cross the bridge and enter the city itself inside a mail sack.

en: I can tell you that now because they got him, soon after that.
vi: I can tell you this because they caught him a little while later.
tr: I can tell you this because they caught him shortly after this job.
es: Now I can tell you, because shortly afterward they caught him.

en: He ended up on the Wall.
vi: He eventually ended up on the Wall.
tr: The poor man faced the Wall.
es: He ended up hanging on the Wall.

en: You hear about these things; you hear a lot in here, you'd be surprised.
vi: You hear all about these things; in here you hear a lot, surprisingly so.
tr: You hear such things; so much is heard here that you would be amazed.
es: You always find out about these things; you would be surprised to know the number of things you find out here.

en: The Commanders tell us themselves, I guess they figure why not, there's no one we can pass it on to, except each other, and that doesn't count.
vi: The Commanders themselves say it, I guess they think it doesn't matter, we wouldn't bother to go anywhere, except to each other, and that doesn't count.
tr: The Commanders themselves tell these stories, I guess they think why not, there's no one we can convey it to except each other, and it doesn't matter.
es: The Commanders themselves tell you, I imagine they must wonder why they wouldn't, there's no one we can pass the information to, except to the rest of us, and that doesn't matter.

en: "I'm making this sound easy but it wasn't.
vi: "I said it sounded easy, but it really wasn't.
tr: I'm trying to make it look easy, but it wasn't.
es: »As I tell it, it seems easy, but it wasn't.

en: I nearly shat bricks the whole time.
vi: From start to finish, I almost crapped my pants.
tr: I was extremely anxious the whole time.
es: I was scared shitless the whole time.

en: One of the hardest things was knowing that these other people were risking their lives for you when they didn't have to.
vi: One of the hardest things was understanding that these strangers were risking their lives for me when they didn't have to.
tr: The hardest part was knowing that these people were risking their lives for you, even though they didn't have to.
es: One of the worst things was knowing that these people were risking their necks for me without any obligation.

en: But they said they were doing it for religious reasons and I shouldn't take it personally.
vi: But they said they were doing it for religious reasons and I shouldn't take it personally.
tr: But they said they were doing it for religious reasons and that I shouldn't take it personally.
es: But they said they were doing it for religious reasons and that I shouldn't take it personally.

en: That helped some.
vi: That made it a bit easier.
tr: That helped a bit.
es: That helped me in a way.

en: They had silent prayers every evening.
vi: Every night they would pray silently.
tr: Every evening, they prayed quietly.
es: Every night they organized a session of silent prayers.

en: I found that hard to get used to at first, because it reminded me too much of that shit at the Center.
vi: At first, it was hard for me to get used to that because it was too much like the crap at the Center.
tr: At first, I had a hard time getting used to it because it reminded me too much of the filth at the Center.
es: At first, it was hard for me to get used to it, as it reminded me too much of the same crap from the Center.

en: It made me feel sick to my stomach, to tell you the truth.
vi: It made me want to puke, to be honest with you.
tr: To be honest, it made me sick.
es: To be honest, it gave me a stomachache.

en: I had to make an effort, tell myself that this was a whole other thing.
vi: I had to try really hard, reminding myself that this was completely different.
tr: I had to make an effort, tell myself that this was something entirely different.
es: I had to make an effort and tell myself that this was something completely different.

en: I hated it at first.
vi: At first, I hated it intensely.
tr: At first, I hated it.
es: At first, I hated it.

en: But I figure it was
vi: But I think that's what supported them.
tr: But I understand that this was what kept them going.
es: But I suppose that is what allowed them to keep going.

en: what kept them going.
vi: But I think that's what supported them.
tr: But I understand that this was what kept them going.
es: But I suppose that is what allowed them to keep going.

en: They knew more or less what would happen to them if they got caught.
vi: They also had a rough idea of what would happen if they got caught.
tr: If they got caught, they had a rough idea of what would happen to them.
es: They more or less knew what would happen to them if they were discovered.

en: Not in detail, but they knew.
vi: Not in detail, but they knew.
tr: Not in detail, but they knew.
es: Not in detail, but they knew.

en: By that time they'd started putting some of it on (he TV, the trials and so forth.
vi: By that time, TV had started showing some things, trials and so on.
tr: Around that time, they had started showing some of this on television, the trials and other things.
es: At that time, they had started to put some of that on television, the trials, and things like that.

en: "It was before the sectarian roundups began in earnest.
vi: “That was before the official crackdown on heretical sects began.
tr: It was before the serious commencement of sectarian pursuits.
es: “This was before they seriously started the raids against the sects.

en: As long as you said you were some sort of a Christian and you were married, for the first time that is, they were still leaving you pretty much alone.
vi: As for declaring yourself a bit Christian and married, meaning at the beginning, you would still be relatively left alone by them.
tr: As long as you said you were a kind of Christian and married, meaning in your first marriage, they didn't bother you much yet.
es: At first, as long as you said you were some kind of Christian and that you were married, they left you alone.

en: They were concentrating first on the others.
vi: At first, they focused on the fringe group.
tr: They were primarily dealing with others.
es: They first focused on the others; but before starting with the rest, they more or less put the first ones under control.

en: They got them more or less under control before they started in on everybody else.
vi: They didn't realize that after dealing with that group, they would eventually look at everyone else.
tr: They had more or less brought them under control before starting to deal with everyone else.
es: They first focused on the others; but before starting with the rest, they more or less put the first ones under control.

en: "I was underground it must have been eight or nine months.
vi: "I had to hide for about eight or nine months."
tr: I was underground, it must have been eight or nine months.
es: "I must have been in hiding for about eight or nine months."

en: I was taken from one safe house to another, there were more of those then.
vi: "I was moved from place to place, to different safe houses, there were still many of those back then."
tr: I was being taken from one safe house to another, there were many of these houses back then.
es: "They moved me from one safe house to another, there were more back then."

en: They weren't all Quakers, some of them weren't even religious.
vi: "Not all of them were Quakers, some didn't even believe in religion."
tr: Not all of them were Quakers, some weren't even religious.
es: "Not all of them were Quakers, some of them weren't even religious."

en: They were just people who didn't like the way things were going.
vi: "They were just people who didn't want to see things like that happening, that's all."
tr: They were just people who didn't like the way things were going.
es: "They were simply people who didn't like the direction things were taking."

en: "I almost made it out.
vi: “We almost succeeded.
tr: I almost succeeded.
es: »I was about to make it.

en: They got me up as far as Salem, then in a truck full of chickens to Maine.
vi: They took me all the way to Salem, then hid in a chicken truck to Maine.
tr: They took me as far as Salem, and then with a truck full of chickens to Maine.
es: They took me to Salem, and then they moved me in a truck full of chickens to Maine.

en: I almost puked from the smell; you ever thought what it would be like to be shat on by a truckload of chickens, all of them carsick?
vi: The smell almost made me puke; have you ever imagined being crapped on by a whole truckload of chickens, each one getting carsick?
tr: I almost threw up from the smell. Have you ever thought about what it would be like to be covered in shit by a truckload of carsick chickens?
es: I was about to vomit because of the smell. Have you ever thought about what it could mean to have an entire truckload of chickens poop on you?

en: They were planning to get me across the border there; not by car or truck, that was already too difficult, but by boat, up the coast.
vi: They planned to get me across the border there, not by car or truck, which had become too difficult, but by boat, following the coastline up.
tr: They planned to get me across the border there; not by car or truck, that had already become too difficult, but by boat, up from the beach.
es: They were planning to make me cross the border there; not by car or truck, because it had become very difficult, but by boat, along the coast.

en: I didn't know that until the actual night, they never told you the next step until right before it was happening.
vi: I didn't know until the night of the operation, they never said what they were going to do next until right before it started.
tr: I didn't know this until that night; they wouldn't tell me the next step until just before.
es: I didn't know until that very night, they never told you what the next step was until the last minute.

en: They were careful that way.
vi: They were that cautious.
tr: They were so careful.
es: They were that careful.

en: "So I don't know what happened.
vi: "So I don't know what happened.
tr: So, I have no idea what's going on.
es: "So I don't know what happened."

en: Maybe somebody got cold feet about it, or somebody outside got suspicious.
vi: Maybe someone suddenly felt a chill, or some outsider suddenly became suspicious.
tr: Maybe someone got scared or someone from outside got suspicious.
es: Maybe someone chickened out, or some outsider started to get suspicious.

en: Or maybe it was the boat, maybe they thought the guy was out in his boat at night too much.
vi: Or maybe it's because of the boat; perhaps they thought the boatman was going out too often at night.
tr: Or maybe it was the boat that drew attention, maybe they thought the man stayed out too long with his boat at night.
es: Or maybe it was the boat itself, maybe they thought that guy was going out too many times with his boat at night.

en: By that time it must have been crawling with Eyes up there, and everywhere else close to the border.
vi: At that hour, there were probably Eyes everywhere, on the boat, as well as anywhere near the border.
tr: At that time, those places and everywhere near the border must have been swarming with Eyes.
es: At that time, that place must have been swarming with Eyes, like any place near the border.

en: Whatever it was, they picked us up just as we were coming out the back door to go down to the dock.
vi: Whatever the reason, they caught us just as we were leaving through the back door to the boat dock.
tr: Whatever it was, they caught us just as we were going out the back door to head to the dock.
es: Whatever it was, they caught us just as we were leaving through the back door to go down to the dock.

en: Me and the guy, and his wife too.
vi: Me and the boatman, and his wife too.
tr: Me, the man, and his wife.
es: Me and the uncle, and also his wife.

en: They were an older couple, in their fifties.
vi: They were an old couple, around fifty years old.
tr: They were an elderly couple, around fifty years old.
es: They were an older couple, around fifty years old.

en: He'd been in the lobster business, back before all that happened to the shore fishing there.
vi: He worked in the shrimp industry, that was before the fishing industry here ran into these troubles.
tr: The man was in the lobster business, before all that stuff happened to the coastal fishing there.
es: He had been in the lobster business before the whole fishing issue on the coasts happened.

en: I don't know what became of them after that, because they took me in a separate van.
vi: I don't know what happened to them afterward, because they took me away in a separate vehicle.
tr: I don't know what happened to them after that, because they put me in a separate van.
es: I don't know what happened to them after that, because they took me in a separate van.

en: "I thought it might be the end, for me.
vi: "I think it's over for me."
tr: I thought my end had come, for me.
es: “I thought it was the end for me.”

en: Or back to the Center and the
vi: "Either go back to the Center under Aunt Lydia's supervision and the steel cable."
tr: Or that I would return to the Center, to Aunt Lydia and her compassionate care with steel wires.
es: “Or that they would take me back to the Center, under Aunt Lydia’s care and her steel cable.”

en: attentions of Aunt Lydia and her steel cable.
vi: "Either go back to the Center under Aunt Lydia's supervision and the steel cable."
tr: Or that I would return to the Center, to Aunt Lydia and her compassionate care with steel wires.
es: “Or that they would take me back to the Center, under Aunt Lydia’s care and her steel cable.”

en: She enjoyed that, you know.
vi: "She loves it, you know."
tr: Your wife liked this, you know.
es: “You know how she liked it.”

en: She pretended to do all that love-the-sinner, hate-the-sin stuff, but she enjoyed it.
vi: "She pretends to love the sinner but hate the sin, but she loves it."
tr: She seemed to be doing all that love-the-sinner, hate-the-sin nonsense, but she also liked it.
es: “She pretended all that love-the-sinner, hate-the-sin crap but she enjoyed it.”

en: I did consider offing myself, and maybe I would have if there'd been any way.
vi: "I've also thought about ending it myself, and if there was a way, I probably would have done it."
tr: I thought about killing myself, maybe I would have, if I found a way.
es: “I considered the possibility of escaping, and maybe I would have if I had any chance.”

en: But they had two of them in the back of the van with me, watching me like a hawk; didn't say a hell of a lot, just sat and watched me in that walleyed way they have.
vi: "But there were two people sitting in the truck with me, watching me like hawks; not saying a word, just sitting there glaring at me."
tr: But they had given me two Eyes in the back of the van, they were burying me like a hawk; they didn't say a single word, just sat there and watched me with their cross-eyed looks.
es: “But in the back of the van, there were two of them with me, watching me like vultures; they hardly said anything, just sat there and observed me with that cross-eyed look they usually have.”

en: So it was no go.
vi: "So it's hopeless."
tr: That's why it didn't happen.
es: “So it was useless.”

en: "We didn't end up at the Center though, we went somewhere else.
vi: “But the car did not go back to the Center, it went somewhere else.
tr: Still, instead of going to the center, we went somewhere else.
es: "However, we did not go to the Center but to another place."

en: I won't go into what happened after that.
vi: I will not tell what happened next.
tr: I will not go into the details of what happened next.
es: "I will not go into details about what happened afterward."

en: I'd rather not talk about it.
vi: I do not want to talk about it.
tr: I prefer not to speak.
es: "It is better that I do not mention it."

en: All I can say is they didn't leave any marks.
vi: I can only say that they left no trace.
tr: All I can say is that they left no trace.
es: "All I can say is that they did not leave any mark on me."

en: "When that was over they showed me a movie.
vi: “When it was all done, they showed me a movie.
tr: When this job was done, they showed me a movie.
es: "When it was all over, they made me watch a movie."

en: Know what it was about?
vi: Do you know what movie?
tr: Do you know what it was about?
es: "Do you know what it was about?"

en: It was about life in the Colonies.
vi: A movie about life in the Ghetto area.
tr: About life in the Colonies.
es: "About life in the Colonies."

en: In the Colonies, they spend their time cleaning up.
vi: In the Ghetto area, people just scrub all day long.
tr: In the Colonies, they spend their time cleaning.
es: "In the Colonies, they spent their time cleaning."

en: They're very clean-minded these days.
vi: Lately, their minds are really focused on cleaning.
tr: These days, they are very keen on cleaning.
es: "These days, they are very concerned about cleanliness."

en: Sometimes it's just bodies, after a battle.
vi: Sometimes it's just corpses, after some fighting.
tr: Sometimes, the only thing being cleaned is the bodies, left over from a clash.
es: "Sometimes it's just about corpses, after a battle."

en: The ones in city ghettos are the worst, they're left around longer, they get rottener.
vi: Coming out of the ghettos is the worst, they are left there longer, they decompose more horribly.
tr: The ones in the outskirts of the city are the worst, left out for a longer time, they are more decayed.
es: "The worst part is what happens in the urban ghettos, because they leave them lying around for a long time and they decompose."

en: This bunch doesn't like dead bodies lying around, they're afraid of a plague or something.
vi: These guys don't like scattered corpses, they fear disease or something.
tr: This team doesn't like bodies scattered around, they fear an epidemic or something similar.
es: "These people don't like having corpses lying around because they are afraid there might be an epidemic, or something like that."

en: So the women in the Colonies there do the burning.
vi: So the women in that Ghetto area handle the cremation.
tr: Therefore, women in the Colonies do the corpse burning.
es: "So the women in the Colonies take care of burning them."

en: The other Colonies are worse, though, the toxic dumps and the radiation spills.
vi: Other areas are even worse, with toxic waste dumps or radioactive leaks.
tr: The other Colonies are even worse, due to toxic waste and radiation leaks, they estimate you have at most three years before your nose falls off and your skin peels like deep rubber gloves.
es: "Anyway, the other Colonies are worse because of the toxic waste dumping and the spread of radiation."

en: They figure you've got three years maximum, at those, before your nose falls off and your skin pulls away like rubber gloves.
vi: They calculate that you only get three years at most in those places, then your nose will fall off and your skin will peel like rubber gloves.
tr: The other Colonies are even worse, due to toxic waste and radiation leaks, they estimate you have at most three years before your nose falls off and your skin peels like deep rubber gloves.
es: "They estimate that at most you can survive three years of all this, before your nose falls apart and your skin peels off like taking off a pair of rubber gloves."

en: They don't bother to feed you much, or give you protective clothing or anything, it's cheaper not to.
vi: They don't even bother to feed you enough, or provide protective clothing or anything, it's cheaper not to.
tr: They don't bother to feed, clothe, or provide protective gear or anything else, it's cheaper not to.
es: "They don't bother to feed them much or give them protective clothing or anything like that, it's cheaper not to."

en: Anyway they're mostly people they want to get rid of.
vi: But anyway, it's all people they want to get rid of.
tr: Besides, these are mostly the people they want to get rid of anyway.
es: "Besides, it's mostly people they want to get rid of."

en: Theysay there're other Colonies, not so bad, where they do agriculture: cotton and tomatoes and all that.
vi: They say there are other areas, not too bad, where people do farming: growing cotton or tomatoes and so on.
tr: They say there are other Colonies too, not as bad, where people engage in agriculture: cotton, tomatoes, and other vegetables.
es: They say there are other Colonies, not so terrible, where they engage in agriculture: cotton, tomatoes, and all that.

en: But those weren't the ones they showed me the movie about.
vi: But not in the movie I watched.
tr: But the movie they showed wasn't about these.
es: But those were not the ones that appeared in the movie they showed me.

en: "It's old womenI bet you've been wondering why you haven't seen too many of those around anymoreand Handmaids who've screwed up their three chances, and incorrigibles like me.
vi: “Those are middle-aged women - I bet you were wondering why you haven't seen any old ladies around lately - and the Handmaids who have failed three times, and the unruly ones like me.
tr: The women were old, I bet you're wondering why you don't see many of them around anymore; also, there were the Handmaids who had used up their three chances and the incorrigibles like me.
es: »They are older women, I bet you've been wondering why you don't see older women around anymore; and Maids who have wasted their three chances, or incorrigibles like me.

en: Discards, all of us.
vi: The whole lot of them, all rejects.
tr: We were all cast aside.
es: All of us who are considered waste.

en: They're sterile, of course.
vi: They're all infertile, of course.
tr: Of course, they were all sterile.
es: They are sterile, of course.

en: If they aren't that way to begin with, they are after they've been there for a while.
vi: If they weren't like that from the start, they'd become that way after being there for a while.
tr: If they weren't at first, it was inevitable after staying there for a while.
es: And if they weren't at the beginning, they are after spending some time there.

en: When they're unsure, they do a little operation on you, so there won't be any mistakes.
vi: Whenever there's any doubt, they put you on the operating table, so no one is wasted.
tr: If they weren't sure, they would perform a small operation to ensure there were no mistakes.
es: When they are not sure, they perform a small operation on you to make sure there is no mistake.

en: I'd say it's
vi: It's also worth mentioning that there are about a handful of men in the Colonies too.
tr: I can say that a quarter of those in the Colonies were men.
es: I also estimate that in the Colonies, a quarter of them are men.

en: about a quarter men in the Colonies, too.
vi: It's also worth mentioning that there are about a handful of men in the Colonies too.
tr: I can say that a quarter of those in the Colonies were men.
es: I also estimate that in the Colonies, a quarter of them are men.

en: Not all of those Gender
vi: Not every traitor ends up on the Wall.
tr: Not all Sexual Traitors end up hanging on the Wall.
es: Not all those they call Traitors to the Gender end their days at the Wall.

en: Traitors end up on the Wall.
vi: Not every traitor ends up on the Wall.
tr: Not all Sexual Traitors end up hanging on the Wall.
es: Not all those they call Traitors to the Gender end their days at the Wall.

en: "All of them wear long dresses, like the ones at the Center, only gray.
vi: “Everyone was wearing the traditional long dress, like at the Center, except it was gray.
tr: They all wear long dresses, just like those at the Center, except theirs are gray.
es: »Everyone wears long dresses, like those from the Center, but gray.

en: Women and the men too, judging from the group shots.
vi: Both women and men, in several group scenes.
tr: From what I gathered from the group shots, men are also in dresses, just like the women.
es: The women, and the men too, judging by the shots in the movie.

en: I guess it's supposed to demoralize the men, having to wear a dress.
vi: I guess it was meant to mock the men, because they had to wear women's clothes.
tr: I think this is done to break the men's resistance, that is, to force them to wear dresses.
es: I suppose that making the men wear dresses is meant to degrade them.

en: Shit, it would demoralize me enough.
vi: For me, that alone is already quite mocking.
tr: Damn, it would certainly break my resistance enough.
es: Damn, it demoralizes me quite a bit.

en: How do you stand it?
vi: How can anyone tolerate that?
tr: How do you endure this?
es: And how do you put up with it?

en: Everything considered, I like this outfit better.
vi: In every aspect, I prefer this outfit more.
tr: Considering all this, I like these clothes even more.
es: On second thought, I prefer this suit.

en: "So after that, they said I was too dangerous to be allowed the privilege of returning to the Red Center.
vi: “So then, they told me I was too dangerous to be given the honor of returning to the Red Center.
tr: After that, they told me I was too dangerous to be granted the privilege of returning to the Red Center.
es: "After that, they told me it was too dangerous to grant me the privilege of returning to the Red Center."

en: They said I would be a corrupting influence.
vi: They said I would spread depravity.
tr: They said I would have a destructive effect.
es: "They said I would be a corrupting influence."

en: I had my choice, they said, this or the Colonies.
vi: I was given a choice, they said, this or the Colonies.
tr: They also told me I had a choice, here or the Colonies.
es: I could choose: this, or the Colonies.

en: Well, shit, nobody but a nun would pick the Colonies.
vi: Well, heck, only a nun would choose the Colonies.
tr: Yes, damn it, no one but a nun would choose the Colonies.
es: Well, shit, only a fool would choose the Colonies.

en: I mean, I'm not a martyr.
vi: You understand, I wasn't planning on being a martyr.
tr: I mean, I'm not a martyr of faith.
es: I mean, I'm no martyr.

en: If I'd had my tubes tied years ago, I wouldn't even have needed the operation.
vi: If I had been sterilized long ago, I wouldn't even need surgery anymore.
tr: I had my tubes tied years ago, so I didn't need this surgery.
es: I had my tubes tied years ago, so I didn't even need the operation.

en: Nobody in here with viable ovaries either, you can see what kind of problems it would cause.
vi: No one here has functioning ovaries anyway, you can see how that would be troublesome.
tr: None of the workers here have ovaries anyway, you can understand what kind of problems that might cause.
es: Besides, no one here has fertile ovaries, imagine the kind of problems that could cause.

en: "So here I am.
vi: “So I came here.
tr: Here I am.
es: "And here I am."

en: They even give you face cream.
vi: They even give out face cream.
tr: They even give you face cream.
es: "They even provide you with face cream."

en: You should figure out some way of getting in here.
vi: You’ll have to find some way to get in here.
tr: You must find a way to get in here.
es: "You should find a way to come here."

en: You'd have three or four good years before your snatch wears out and they send you to the bone-yard.
vi: You’ll have three or four years of happiness before it wears you down and you get thrown out to the cemetery.
tr: Before this short period ends and they scrap you, you would live well for three or four years.
es: "You'd be fine for two or three years until your opportunity passed and they sent you to the common grave."

en: The food's not bad and there's drink and drugs, if you want it, and we only work nights."
vi: The food is decent and you can indulge in drinking or injecting, if you like, and you only have to work at night.”
tr: The food isn't bad, if you want, there are also drinks and drugs, plus we only work at night.”
es: "The food isn't bad and if you feel like it, they give you drinks and drugs, and we only work at night."

en: "Moira," I say.
vi: “Moira,” I said.
tr: “Moira,” I say.
es: —Moira —I gasp—.

en: "You don't mean that."
vi: “You didn't mean that.”
tr: “You can't be serious.”
es: You're not serious —it starts to scare me because what I perceive in her voice is indifference, a lack of will.

en: She is frightening me now, because what I hear in her voice is indifference, a lack of volition.
vi: She really frightened me, her tone so indifferent, so devoid of will.
tr: She frightens me now, because what I hear in her voice is indifference, a lack of will.
es: You're not serious —it starts to scare me because what I perceive in her voice is indifference, a lack of will.

en: Have they really done it to her then, taken away somethingwhat?
vi: So they had actually done it, taken away something - what?
tr: Have they really done it, taken away something so fundamental in her -what?- or not?
es: Have they really done this to her, taken away something —what?— that used to be so essential to her?

en: that used to be so central to her?
vi: - that used to be her essence?
tr: Have they really done it, taken away something so fundamental in her -what?- or not?
es: Have they really done this to her, taken away something —what?— that used to be so essential to her?

en: And how can I expect her to go on, with my idea of her courage, live it through, act it out, when I myself do not?
vi: And how could I demand that she move forward, according to my own image of her courage, live by it, embody it, when I myself could not?
tr: How can I expect her to continue, to live on with the thought of her courage in me, when I myself do not do this?
es: How can I expect her to succeed, to still live up to my idea of her as a brave person, to survive, if I myself am not capable of doing so?

en: I don't want her to be like me.
vi: I don't want you to become like me.
tr: I don't want him to be like me.
es: I don't want her to be like me: to give up, to resign, to save her skin.

en: Give in, go along, save her skin.
vi: Giving up, going with the flow, saving your own life.
tr: To surrender, to compromise, to cowardly worry about his own life.
es: I don't want her to be like me: to give up, to resign, to save her skin.

en: That is what it comes down to.
vi: As you can see, it is an inevitable outcome.
tr: In the end, it all comes down to this.
es: That's what we've been reduced to.

en: I want gallantry from her, swashbuckling, heroism, single-handed combat.
vi: I want you to be resilient, brave, heroic, and fight valiantly.
tr: I want courage, pride, heroism, a one-man war from him.
es: But from her, I expect courage, bravado, heroism, self-sufficiency: all that I lack.

en: Something I lack.
vi: Which I couldn't do.
tr: Something that I lack.
es: But from her, I expect courage, bravado, heroism, self-sufficiency: all that I lack.

en: "Don't worry about me," she says.
vi: “Don't worry about me,” she said.
tr: “Don't worry about me,” she says.
es: —Don't worry about me —he reassures me.

en: She must know some of what I'm thinking.
vi: She must have guessed a little of what I was thinking.
tr: She must have understood some of my thoughts.
es: He must imagine what I'm thinking—.

en: "I'm still here, you can see it's me.
vi: “I'm still here, you see, it's really me.
tr: “I am still here, you can see that it's me.
es: I'm still here, you see it's me.

en: Anyway, look at it this way: it's not so bad, there's lots of women around.
vi: But anyway, let's consider this: it's not bad, surrounded by so many women.
tr: Anyway, look at it this way: It's not that bad, there are plenty of women around.
es: Anyway, consider it this way: it's not so bad, I'm surrounded by a bunch of women.

en: Butch paradise,
vi: It's a paradise of lesbians, what else could it be.”
tr: You could call it a lesbian paradise.”
es: We could call it the lost paradise.

en: you might call it."
vi: It's a paradise of lesbians, what else could it be.”
tr: You could call it a lesbian paradise.”
es: We could call it the lost paradise.

en: Now she's teasing, showing some energy, and I feel better.
vi: Now she is teasing, appearing cheerful, I feel relieved.
tr: He started to mock, showing signs of liveliness, I feel better.
es: Now he is joking, showing me that he still has energy, and I feel better.

en: "Do they let you?" I say.
vi: "Did they approve?" I asked. “Approval, huh?
tr: "Do they allow this?" I say. “Allow it?
es: —Do they allow it? —I ask her. —If they allow us?

en: "Let, hell, they encourage it.
vi: Damn them, it's more like encouragement.
tr: Damn it, they even encourage it.
es: Damn, they incite us.

en: Know what they call this place among themselves?
vi: Do you know what they call this place among themselves?
tr: Do you know what they call this place among themselves?
es: Do you know what they call this place?

en: Jezebel's.
vi: Jezebel's Palace.
tr: Jezebel's Place.
es: Jezebel’s.

en: The Aunts figure we're all damned anyway, they've given up on us, so it doesn't matter what sort of vice we get up to, and the Commanders don't give a piss what wedo in our off time.
vi: They say that since we're all going to hell anyway, they've given up. No matter what sinful games we play, it's all the same. And the Commanders don't care what we do during our breaks.
tr: The Aunts think that we are all cursed in some way, they have given up on us, so it doesn't matter what kind of sin we commit, the Commanders don't even care what we do in our spare time.
es: The Aunts suppose that we are condemned anyway, they have given up on us, so it doesn't matter what kind of vice we take up, and the Commanders couldn't care less about what we do in our free time.

en: Anyway, women on women sort of turns them on."
vi: Anyway, whether it's the girls upstairs or downstairs, it gets those guys pretty excited.”
tr: Anyway, they get excited by women loving womena”
es: Besides, it seems that seeing a woman with another excites them.

en: "What about the others?" I say.
vi: “What about those people?”
tr: “What about the others?” I say.
es: —And the others? —I asked.

en: "Put it this way," she says, "they're not too fond of men."
vi: “Let me put it this way,” she said, “they are not too crazy about men.”
tr: “Let's put it this way,” he says, “they don't really like men.”
es: —Let's say —he responds— that they are not very fond of men.

en: She shrugs again.
vi: She shrugged again.
tr: He shrugs again.
es: —He shrugs again.

en: It might be resignation.
vi: It could also be resignation.
tr: This could be resignation.
es: It must be resignation.

en: Here is what I'd like to tell.
vi: Here are the stories I want to tell.
tr: I would like to tell this: I would like to tell a story about how Moira escaped, this time for good.
es: This is what I would like to tell.

en: I'd like to tell a story about how Moira escaped, for good this time.
vi: I want to tell how Moira escaped, this time for good.
tr: I would like to tell this: I would like to tell a story about how Moira escaped, this time for good.
es: I would like to tell how Moira escaped, this time successfully.

en: Or if I couldn't tell that, I'd like to say she blew up Jezebel's, with fifty Commanders inside it.
vi: Or if not that, I want to say she blew up Jezebel's, with fifty Commanders inside.
tr: Or if I can't do that, I would like to tell that she blew up Jezebel's Place along with fifty Commanders inside.
es: And if I can't tell that, I would like to say that she blew up Jezebel’s, with fifty Commanders inside.

en: I'd like her to end with something daring and spectacular, some outrage, something that would befit her.
vi: I want her to end with a daring and spectacular act, a frenzy, a gesture worthy of her.
tr: I would like her end to come with something daring and flamboyant, destructive, something that suits her.
es: I would like her to end with something daring and spectacular, some attack, something appropriate to her.

en: But as far as I know that didn't happen.
vi: But as far as I know, nothing of the sort happened.
tr: But as far as I know, that didn't happen.
es: But, as far as I know, none of that happened.

en: I don't know how she ended, or even if she did, because I never saw her again.
vi: I don't know what her fate was, or if it even came, because I never saw her again.
tr: I don't know how her end came, or even if it did, because I never saw her again.
es: I don't know how it ended, not even if it ended in any way, because I never saw her again.
CHAPTER 39

en: The Commander has a room key.
vi: The commander has the key to the private room.
tr: The Commander has a room key.
es: The Commander has the key to a room.

en: He got it from the front desk, while I waited on the flowered sofa.
vi: He got it from the reception desk while I sat on the sofa waiting.
tr: While I was waiting on the floral couch, he went and got it from the reception.
es: He took it from the desk in front, while I waited on the flowered sofa.

en: He shows it to me, slyly.
vi: He showed it to me, cunningly.
tr: He's showing it to me, cunningly.
es: He shows it to me with a timid gesture.

en: I am to understand.
vi: I had to understand on my own.
tr: So I should understand.
es: I'm supposed to understand.

en: We ascend in the glass half egg of the elevator, past the vine-draped balconies.
vi: We followed the half-glass egg upwards, past the balconies covered in vines.
tr: We ascend in a semi-egg-shaped glass elevator, passing by balconies enveloped in vines.
es: We went up in the glass half-egg of the elevator and passed by the balconies adorned with vines.

en: I am to understand also that I am on display.
vi: I had to understand that I was being exhibited.
tr: I must also realize that I am being shown around.
es: I must also understand that I am on display.

en: He unlocks the door of the room.
vi: He opened the door to the room.
tr: He opens the door of the room.
es: Open the room's door with the key.

en: Everything is the same, the very same as it was, once upon a time.
vi: Everything was still the same, just like back then, a long, long time ago.
tr: Everything is the same, just like it used to be.
es: Everything is the same, exactly the same as centuries ago.

en: The drapes are the same, the heavy flowered ones that match the bedspread, orange poppies on royal blue, and the thin white ones to draw against the sun; the bureau and bedside tables, square-cornered, impersonal; the lamps; the pictures on the walls: fruit in a bowl, stylized apples, flowers in a vase, buttercups and devil's paintbrushes keyed to the drapes.
vi: The curtains were still the same, thick with floral patterns to match the bedspread, orange poppies on a dark blue background, with a thin white layer outside for blocking the sun when needed; a small wardrobe, a nightstand, square and impersonal; a few lamps; a few paintings on the wall: fruit in a bowl, stylized apples, flowers in a vase, buttercups and purple dandelions matching the curtains.
tr: The curtains are the same, the ones with large flowers matching the bedspread, poppies in orange on a royal blue background, and the thin white ones used as sunshades; the writing desk and nightstands are angular, impersonal; the lamps; the pictures on the wall: fruits in a bowl, stylized apples, flowers in a vase, buttercups matching the curtains, and Devil's paintbrushes.
es: The curtains are the same, the thickest ones with a floral pattern —orange poppies on a blue background— matching the bedspread, and the thin white ones to filter the sunlight; the dresser and the corner nightstands, impersonal; the lamps and the paintings on the walls: a bowl with fruit, stylized apples, flowers in a vase, ranunculus and gladiolus matching the curtains.

en: All is the
vi: Everything was still the same.
tr: Everything is the same.
es: Everything remains the same.

en: same.
vi: Everything was still the same.
tr: Everything is the same.
es: Everything remains the same.

en: I tell the Commander just a minute, and go into the bathroom.
vi: I told the Commander to wait a moment, then went into the bathroom.
tr: I ask the Commander for a minute's leave and enter the bathroom.
es: I tell the Commander to wait a minute and I enter the bathroom.
