en: My ears are ringing from the smoke, the gin has filled me with lassitude.
vi: My ears were ringing because of the smoke, and the glass of wine made me feel weak.
tr: My ears are ringing because of the cigarette, the gin has numbed me, I'm tired.
es: My ears are buzzing because of the cigarette and the gin has completely relaxed me.

en: I wet a washcloth and press it to my forehead.
vi: I soaked a bath towel in water and pressed it to my forehead for a while.
tr: I wet a small towel and press it to my forehead.
es: I moisten a small towel and place it on my forehead.

en: After a while I look to see if there are any little bars of soap in individual wrappers.
vi: Then I looked around to see if there was a small bar of soap in any of the packages.
tr: After a while, I search to see if there are any individually wrapped small soaps.
es: A moment later, I check if there is any small individually wrapped soap.

en: There are.
vi: There were a few.
tr: Yes, there are.
es: Yes, there is, and they are the ones that come from Spain, with the drawing of a gypsy woman.

en: The kind with the gypsy on them, from Spain.
vi: The kind with a picture of a gypsy girl, Spanish-made.
tr: They are the kind with a gypsy on them, made in Spain.
es: Yes, there is, and they are the ones that come from Spain, with the drawing of a gypsy woman.

en: I breathe in the soap smell, the disinfectant smell, and stand in the white bathroom, listening to the distant sounds of water running, toilets being flushed.
vi: I deeply inhaled the scent of soap into my lungs, that disinfectant scent, and stood in the white-tiled room listening to the distant sound of flushing water, the toilet just flushed.
tr: I inhale the scent of soap, the smell of disinfectant; listening to the distant sounds of running water, the flushing toilets, I stand in the white bathroom.
es: I inhale the smell of soap, a disinfectant smell, and I stay in the bathroom, listening to the distant sounds of running water, of toilet chains.

en: In a strange way I feel comforted, at home.
vi: Strangely, I felt calm, as if I were at home.
tr: In a strange way, I feel comfortable here, like at home.
es: It's strange, but I feel comfortable, like at home.

en: There is something reassuring about the toilets.
vi: The toilet brought a sense of reassurance.
tr: There is something reassuring about toilets.
es: There is something reassuring about bathrooms.

en: Bodily functions at least remain democratic.
vi: Bodily functions are at least still democratic.
tr: At the very least, bodily functions remain democratic.
es: At least physical functions are still democratic.

en: Everybody shits, as Moira would say.
vi: Everyone shits, as Moira would say.
tr: Everyone shits, as Moira would say.
es: Everyone shits, Moira would say.

en: I sit on the edge of the bathtub, gazing at the blank towels.
vi: I sat on the edge of the bathtub, looking at the plain white rolls of towels.
tr: I am sitting by the edge of the bathtub, looking at the clean towels.
es: I sit on the edge of the bathtub and observe the white towels.

en: Once they would have excited me.
vi: At one time, they would have excited me.
tr: They used to excite me once.
es: At one time, they had seemed exciting to me.

en: They would have meant the aftermath, of love.
vi: They once symbolized the aftershocks of love.
tr: They used to signify post-love.
es: They represented the aftermath of love.

en: I saw your mother, Moira said.
vi: I saw your mother, Moira said.
tr: I saw your mother, said Moira.
es: I saw your mother, Moira told me.

en: Where?
vi: Where?
tr: Where?
es: Where?, I asked her.

en: I said.
vi: I asked.
tr: I said.
es: Where?, I asked her.

en: I felt jolted, thrown off.
vi: My stomach tightened, dizzy.
tr: I felt shaken, like a ship that had lost its course.
es: I felt myself shudder and realized that I had been thinking of her as if she were dead.

en: I realized I'd been thinking of her as dead.
vi: I realized I still considered my mother to be dead.
tr: I realized that I had thought he was dead.
es: I felt myself shudder and realized that I had been thinking of her as if she were dead.

en: Not in person, it was in that film they showed us, about the Colonies.
vi: It's not outside, it's in the movie they are showing, that immigrant area.
tr: It wasn't about him, it was in that film about the Colonies that he showed us.
es: Not in person, but in the movie they showed me about the Colonies.

en: There was a close-up, it was her all right.
vi: There is a close-up shot, it really looks like you.
tr: There was a close-up shot, it was definitely him.
es: There was a close-up in which she appeared.

en: She was wrapped up in one of those gray things but I know it was her.
vi: You are trapped in that gray thing but I recognized you.
tr: He was wearing one of those gray things, but I'm sure it was him.
es: She was wrapped in one of those gray things, but I know it was her.

en: Thank God, I said.
vi: Thank God, I said. What, thank God?
tr: Thank God, I said.
es: Thank God, I said.

en: Why, thank God? said Moira.
vi: Moira said.
tr: Why, thank God? said Moira.
es: Thank God for what?, Moira wondered.

en: I thought she was dead.
vi: I think mom is dead.
tr: I thought you were dead.
es: I thought she was dead.

en: She might as well be, said Moira.
vi: Sometimes dying is even better, Moira said.
tr: He might be dead, said Moira.
es: It would be better if he were, Moira stated.

en: You should wish it for her.
vi: You should pray for that for your uncle.
tr: You should wish for his death, for his own good.
es: That is what you should wish for him.

en: I can't remember the last time I saw her.
vi: I don't remember what the last time I saw my mother was like.
tr: I can't remember the last time I saw her.
es: I can't remember when was the last time I saw her.

en: It blends in with all the others; it was some trivial occasion.
vi: That day blended into all the other days, just another trivial occasion.
tr: It blends with all the others; it was an insignificant event.
es: It blends together with all the others; it was some unimportant occasion.

en: She must have dropped by; she did that, she breezed in and out of my house as if I were the mother and she were the child.
vi: Probably, my mother stopped by the house; she was always like that, rushing in and out of my house, as if I were the mother and she were the child.
tr: She must have just dropped by; she would do that as if I were the mother and she the child, breezing in and out of my home.
es: She must have dropped by my house; she used to do that, coming and going carelessly from my house as if I were the mother and she the daughter.

en: She still had that jauntiness.
vi: She was still as enthusiastic as before.
tr: She still had that carefreeness.
es: She still retained all her liveliness.

en: Sometimes, when she was between apartments, just moving into one or just moving out, she'd use my washer-dryer for her laundry.
vi: Many times, during the transition between apartments, either moving in or moving out, she would bring clothes to use my washer-dryer combo.
tr: Sometimes, when she was between homes, that is, moving from one to another, she would use my machine for her laundry.
es: Sometimes, while moving from one apartment to another, she would bring her dirty clothes to wash them in my washer-dryer.

en: Maybe she'd come over to borrow something, from me: a pot, a hair dryer.
vi: Maybe that day she came to borrow something from me: pots, a hairdryer.
tr: Maybe she had come to borrow something from me: a pot, a hairdryer.
es: Maybe she stopped by the house to borrow something: a pot, the hair dryer.

en: That
vi: That was another habit of hers.
tr: This was also one of her habits.
es: This was also one of her habits.

en: too was a habit of hers.
vi: That was another habit of hers.
tr: This was also one of her habits.
es: This was also one of her habits.

en: I didn't know it would be the last time or else I would have remembered it better.
vi: I didn't know it was the last time, otherwise I would have remembered it better.
tr: I didn't know this would be the last time, otherwise I would have remembered it better.
es: I didn't know it would be the last time we would see each other; otherwise, I would have remembered it better.

en: I can't even remember what we said.
vi: I don't even remember what we talked about.
tr: I can't even remember what we talked about.
es: I don't even remember what we said.

en: A week later, two weeks, three weeks, when things had become suddenly so much worse, I tried to call her.
vi: A week later, two weeks, then three weeks, when the situation suddenly worsened, I tried calling my mother.
tr: A week later, two weeks, three weeks later, when things suddenly got this bad, I tried to reach him by phone.
es: A week later, two weeks, three, when suddenly things got even worse, I tried to call her.

en: But there was no answer, and no answer when I tried again.
vi: But no one answered, even when I called again.
tr: But there was no answer, and there was still no answer when I tried again.
es: But I got no answer, and later, when I tried again, neither.

en: She hadn't told me she was going anywhere, but then maybe she wouldn't have; she didn't always.
vi: Mom didn't say where she was planning to go, but there have been times like this before: she doesn't always inform us.
tr: He hadn't mentioned to me that he was going somewhere, but maybe he wouldn't have; he didn't always tell me.
es: He hadn't told me that he was thinking of going anywhere, but maybe he had left without telling me; he didn't always do so.

en: She had her own car and she wasn't too old to drive.
vi: Mom has her own car and isn't too old to drive.
tr: He had his own car and he wasn't too old to drive it.
es: He had his own car, and he wasn't too old to drive.

en: Finally I got the apartment superintendent on the phone.
vi: Finally, I was able to call the building manager.
tr: Finally, I caught the apartment manager on the phone.
es: Finally, I managed to speak on the phone with the building's security guard.

en: He said he hadn't seen her lately.
vi: He said he hadn't seen my mother in a long time.
tr: He said he hadn't seen him around.
es: He said that he hadn't seen her lately.

en: I was worried.
vi: I panicked.
tr: I was worried.
es: I was worried.

en: I thought maybe she'd had a heart attack or a stroke, it wasn't out of the question, though she hadn't been sick that I knew of.
vi: I thought maybe mom had a heart attack or a stroke, something fatal, even though as far as I knew she hadn't been ill lately.
tr: I thought maybe he had a heart attack or a stroke, which wasn't impossible, although as far as I knew, he had no illness.
es: I thought that maybe she had had a heart attack or a stroke, although it was unlikely because, as far as I knew, she had not been sick.

en: She was always so healthy.
vi: Mom was always strong and healthy.
tr: He was always so healthy.
es: She was always in very good health.

en: She still worked out at
vi: She still worked out at Nautilus and went swimming twice a week.
tr: He was always so healthy.
es: She was always in very good health.

en: Nautilus and went swimming every two weeks.
vi: She still worked out at Nautilus and went swimming twice a week.
tr: He still exercised at Nautilus and went for a swim twice a week.
es: She still worked at Nautilus and went swimming every two weeks.

en: I used to tell my friends she was healthier than I was and maybe it was true.
vi: I often told my friends that she was healthier than me, and I might not be wrong.
tr: I used to always tell my friends that he was healthier than me, and maybe it was true.
es: I used to tell my friends that she was healthier than me, and maybe it was true.

en: Luke and I drove across into the city and Luke bullied the superintendent into opening up the apartment.
vi: Luke drove me into the city and intimidated the manager to the point of opening the apartment door.
tr: We went down to the city with Luke, and Luke forced the manager to open the apartment.
es: Luke and I drove to the city, and Luke forced the guard to open the apartment.

en: She could be dead, on the floor, Luke said.
vi: She could be dead on the floor, Luke said.
tr: He might be dead, lying on the floor, Luke said.
es: She could be lying on the floor, dead, insisted Luke.

en: The longer you leave it the worse it'll be.
vi: The longer you wait, the worse it will get.
tr: The longer you leave him there, the worse it will be.
es: The longer you leave her, the worse it will be.

en: You thought of the smell?
vi: Don't you think it will start to smell?
tr: Have you ever thought about the smell?
es: Can you imagine the smell?

en: The superintendent said something about needing a permit, but Luke could be persuasive.
vi: The manager said something about needing a permit, but Luke can be very persuasive at times.
tr: The manager said something about needing permission, but Luke was always good at being persuasive.
es: The guard said something about needing a permit, but Luke knew how to be persuasive.

en: He made it clear we weren't going to wait or go away.
vi: He made him understand that we had no intention of waiting or leaving.
tr: He made it clear that we wouldn't wait or leave.
es: He made it clear that we weren't planning to wait or leave.

en: I started to cry.
vi: And I cried.
tr: I started to cry.
es: I started to cry.

en: Maybe that was what finally did it.
vi: Perhaps that was the deciding factor.
tr: Maybe that was what finally convinced him.
es: Maybe this was what finally convinced him.

en: When the man got the door open what we found was chaos.
vi: When the door opened, a scene of chaos unfolded before our eyes.
tr: When Adam opened the door, what we saw was complete chaos.
es: When the man opened the door, what we found was utter chaos.

en: There was furniture overturned, the mattress was ripped open, bureau drawers upside-down on the floor, their contents strewn and mounded.
vi: Chairs and tables were overturned, cushions were ripped apart, drawers were upended on the floor, and belongings were scattered in piles.
tr: The furniture was overturned, mattresses were torn, the desk drawers were turned inside out, and their contents were scattered and piled up in one corner.
es: There were furniture pieces turned upside down, the mattress was torn, the drawers of the dresser were thrown on the floor, face down, and their contents scattered and piled up.

en: But my mother wasn't there.
vi: But my mother was nowhere to be seen.
tr: But my mother was not there.
es: But my mother was not there.

en: I'm going to call the police, I said.
vi: I'm calling the police, I said.
tr: I will call the police, I said.
es: I'm going to call the police, I said.

en: I'd stopped crying; I felt cold from head to foot, my teeth were chattering.
vi: I wasn't crying anymore; I was cold from head to toe, my teeth chattering.
tr: I had stopped crying; I was frozen from head to toe, my teeth were chattering.
es: I had stopped crying; I felt a shiver run through my body from head to toe, and my teeth were chattering.

en: Don't, said Luke.
vi: Don't, Luke said.
tr: Don't, said Luke.
es: Don't do it, Luke advised me.

en: Why not?
vi: Why?
tr: Why is that?
es: Why not?, I asked him, staring at him intently; now I was furious.

en: I said.
vi: I said.
tr: I said.
es: Why not?, I asked him, staring at him intently; now I was furious.

en: I was glaring at him, I was angry now.
vi: I stared at him, I was furious.
tr: I was glaring at him, I was already angry.
es: Why not?, I asked him, staring at him intently; now I was furious.

en: He stood
vi: He stood amidst the wreckage in the living room, just looking at me.
tr: He was standing among the ruins of the living room, just looking at me.
es: He stood in the middle of the remnants of the room and just looked at me.

en: there in the wreck of the living room, just looking at me.
vi: He stood amidst the wreckage in the living room, just looking at me.
tr: He was standing among the ruins of the living room, just looking at me.
es: He stood in the middle of the remnants of the room and just looked at me.

en: He put his hands into his pockets, one of those aimless gestures people make when they don't know what else to do.
vi: He put his hands in his pockets, one of those meaningless gestures people make when they don't know what else to do.
tr: He put his hands in his pockets; one of those pointless actions people resort to when they don't know what else to do.
es: He put his hands in his pockets, one of those unintended gestures people adopt when they don't know what to do.

en: Just don't, is what he said.
vi: That's enough, I only said that.
tr: Don't do it, that's what he said.
es: Just don't do it, he said.

en: Your mother's neat, Moira would say, when we were at college.
vi: Your mom is fierce, Moira often said, back in college.
tr: Another strange woman, Moira used to say, back in college.
es: Your mother is very clean, Moira told me when we were going to university.

en: Later:
vi: Later: you are really fiery.
tr: Later: she has charm.
es: Some time later: she is shameless.

en: she's got pizzazz.
vi: Then later: you are really lovely.
tr: Later: she has charm.
es: Even later: she is cunning.

en: Later still: she's cute.
vi: Then later: you are really lovely.
tr: Then: she is friendly.
es: Even later: she is cunning.

en: She's not cute, I would say.
vi: My mom doesn't "love," I said.
tr: It's not close to Cana, I'd say.
es: She is not cunning, I replied.

en: She's my mother.
vi: My mom is my mom.
tr: She's my mother.
es: She is my mother.

en: Jeez, said Moira, you ought to see mine.
vi: Oh my, Moira said, you haven't seen my old lady.
tr: Eeeh, said Moira, you should see mine.
es: Yeah, Moira laughed, you should see mine.

en: I think of my mother, sweeping up deadly toxins; the way they used to use up old women, in Russia, sweeping dirt.
vi: I think of my mother, sweeping away deadly toxins; just like people used to make old women in Eastern Europe sweep the ground.
tr: I'm thinking of my mother, cleaning deadly poisons like they used to make old women clean filth in Russia.
es: I think of my mother collecting lethal toxins; that's how old women in Russia used to end their days, sweeping up filth.

en: Only this dirt will kill her.
vi: Except this ground will kill my mother.
tr: But this filth will kill her.
es: Only this filth will kill her.

en: I can't quite believe it.
vi: I can't believe it.
tr: Actually, I don't really believe that.
es: I can't believe it.

en: Surely her cockiness, her optimism and energy, her pizzazz, will get her out of this.
vi: Surely my mother's stubbornness, optimism, and enthusiasm, her fire, will help her get out.
tr: I'm sure her confidence, optimism, and energy, her charm will help her overcome this.
es: Surely her boldness, her optimism and energy, her cunning, will get her out of it.

en: She will think of something.
vi: She will figure out a way.
tr: She will find a way.
es: She will come up with something.

en: But I know this isn't true.
vi: But I know it's not like that.
tr: But I know that this is not true.
es: But I know this is not true.

en: It is just passing the buck, as children do, to mothers.
vi: It's just shifting the burden, as children often do, onto the mother.
tr: As children always do, this is just placing the responsibility on mothers.
es: It's simply passing the buck, like children do with their mothers.

en: I've mourned for her already.
vi: I had time to mourn my mother.
tr: I had already mourned for him.
es: I have already mourned their death.

en: But I will do it again, and again.
vi: But I will mourn again, and again.
tr: But I will do it again, and then again.
es: But I will do it again, over and over.

en: 1 bring myself back, to the here, to the hotel.
vi: I call myself back, here, this hotel.
tr: I am returning myself, here, to this hotel.
es: Return to the present, to the hotel.

en: This is where I need to be.
vi: This is where I need to be.
tr: This is where I am supposed to be.
es: This is where I need to be.

en: Now, in this ample mirror under the white light, I take a look at myself.
vi: Now, in the wide mirror under the white light, I look at how I appear.
tr: Now, in this large mirror under the white light, I am looking at myself.
es: I take a look at myself in this huge mirror, under the white light.

en: It's a good look, slow and level.
vi: I examine myself very carefully, slowly, and balanced.
tr: I look carefully, slow and measured.
es: She looked at me intently and penetratingly.

en: I'm a wreck.
vi: I look really miserable.
tr: I am a wreck.
es: I am a wreck.

en: The mascara has smudged again, despite Moira's repairs, the purplish lipstick has bled, hair trails aimlessly.
vi: The mascara has clumped again, despite Moira fixing it, the purplish lipstick is smudged, and my hair is a mess.
tr: Despite Moira's corrections, the mascara has run again, the purple lipstick is smudged, and the hair hangs aimlessly.
es: The makeup has smeared again despite Moira's touch-ups, the purple lipstick has faded, and my hair is disheveled.

en: The molting pink feathers are tawdry as carnival dolls and some of the starry sequins have come off.
vi: The outfit is overdue for a change, looking gaudy like a costume party puppet, with some sequins missing.
tr: The pink tassels with shedding feathers are vulgar like carnival dolls, and a few of the gilded sequins have fallen off.
es: The pink feathers look gaudy like those of a carnival doll, and some of the star-shaped sequins have fallen off.

en: Probably they were off to begin with and I didn't notice.
vi: It's very likely they were gone from the start and I didn't notice.
tr: Maybe they had fallen off from the very beginning, and I hadn't noticed.
es: They were probably missing from the beginning, and I didn't notice.

en: I ama travesty, in bad make-up and someone else's clothes, used glitz.
vi: I'm like a theatrical performer, crudely made up in borrowed clothes, dazzling but cheap.
tr: I am a transvestite, with bad makeup and other people's clothes, a used sparkle.
es: I look like a badly made-up transvestite wearing someone else's clothes.

en: I wish I had a toothbrush.
vi: If only there were a toothbrush.
tr: I wish I had a toothbrush.
es: I would like to have a toothbrush.

en: I could stand here and think about it, but time is passing.
vi: I could just stand here thinking about it, but time is passing.
tr: I could stand here and ponder over this, but time is slipping away.
es: I could stay here, thinking about all of this, but time passes.

en: I must be back at the house before midnight; otherwise I'll turn into a pumpkin, or was that the coach?
vi: I have to be home before midnight, otherwise I'll turn into a pumpkin, or was it a carriage?
tr: I must return home before midnight; otherwise, I will turn into a pumpkin, or was it the carriage that turned?
es: I must be back at the house before midnight; otherwise, I will turn into a pumpkin... Or was that what happened to the carriage?

en: Tomorrow's the Ceremony, according to the calendar, so tonight Serena wants me serviced, and if I'm not there she'll find out why, and then what?
vi: Tomorrow is the Monthly Ceremony, according to the calendar, so Serena wants me to serve tonight, and if I'm not there, she'll find out the reason, then what?
tr: Tomorrow is the Night of the Ceremony, according to the calendar, Serena wants me to prepare tonight; moreover, if I am not there, she will investigate the reason, and then what?
es: According to the calendar, the Ceremony is celebrated tomorrow, so Serena wants me to be mounted tonight, and if I'm not there, she will find out the reason, and then what?

en: And the Commander, for a change, is waiting; I can hear him pacing in the main room.
vi: And the Commander is waiting, to change the atmosphere, I hear footsteps moving around the room.
tr: This time the Commander is waiting; I can hear him pacing up and down in the room.
es: And the Commander is waiting, for a change; I hear him pacing in the main room.

en: Now he pauses outside the bathroom door, clears his throat, a stagy ahem.
vi: Now he stops by the bathroom door, clears his throat, skillfully lets out a gentle cough.
tr: Now he pauses outside the bathroom door, clears his throat, an actor-like ahem.
es: Now he stops on the other side of the bathroom door and clears his throat with a theatrical ahem.

en: I turn on the hot water tap, to signify readiness or something approaching it.
vi: I turn on the hot water faucet, showing that I am ready or almost ready.
tr: I turn on the hot water tap, to imply that I am ready or something similar.
es: I turn on the hot water tap to indicate that I am ready, or something like that.

en: I should get this over with.
vi: This matter must be finished.
tr: I turn on the hot water tap, to imply that I am ready or something similar.
es: I have to get this over with.

en: I wash my hands.
vi: I wash my hands.
tr: I wash my hands.
es: I wash my hands.

en: I must beware of inertia.
vi: Must be cautious of the risk of stagnation.
tr: I must avoid standing still.
es: I have to be careful of inertia.

en: When I come out he's lying down on the king-size bed, with, I note, his shoes off.
vi: When I came out, he was already lying on the oversized bed, shoes off, I noticed.
tr: When I go outside, I find him lying in the big bed, and I notice that he has taken off his shoes.
es: When I go out, I find him lying on the huge bed and notice that he has taken off his shoes.

en: I lie down beside him, I don't have to be told.
vi: I lay down beside him, without needing to be told.
tr: I lie down next to him, it doesn't need to be said.
es: I lie down next to him, he doesn't have to tell me.

en: 1 would rather not; but it's good to lie down, I am so tired.
vi: I didn't want this; but lying down was good, I was extremely tired.
tr: If it were up to me, I wouldn't want to; but lying down feels good, I'm so tired.
es: I would prefer not to do it, but it's good to stretch out, I am very tired.

en: Alone at last, I think.
vi: In the end, it's just the two of us, I thought, the problem is I don't want to be alone with him at all, especially not in bed.
tr: In the end, we are alone, I think.
es: Finally alone, I think.

en: The fact is that I don't want to be alone with him, not on a bed.
vi: In the end, it's just the two of us, I thought, the problem is I don't want to be alone with him at all, especially not in bed.
tr: The truth is, I don't want to be alone with him, not in a bed.
es: The thing is, I don't want to be alone with him, not on the bed.

en: I'd rather have Serena there too.
vi: I'd rather have Serena here.
tr: I would have preferred Serena to be here too.
es: I would prefer Serena to be present as well.

en: I'd rather play Scrabble.
vi: I'd rather play Scrabble.
tr: I would have preferred to play Scrabble.
es: I would prefer to play Intelect.

en: But my silence does not deter him.
vi: But I remained silent, not making him hesitate.
tr: But my silence doesn't deter him.
es: But my silence does not discourage him.

en: "Tomorrow, isn't it?" he says softly.
vi: "Tomorrow, isn't it?" he whispered.
tr: "Tomorrow, right?" he says softly.
es: —It's tomorrow, right? —he asks softly—.

en: "I thought we could jump the gun."
vi: "I was thinking we could play a little before the bell."
tr: "It seems to me we could act a bit early."
es: I thought we could get ahead of it —he turns to me.

en: He turns towards me.
vi: He turned to me.
tr: He turns to me.
es: I thought we could get ahead of it —he turns to me.

en: "Why did you bring me here?"
vi: “Why did you bring me here?” I said coldly.
tr: “Why did you bring me here?” I ask coldly.
es: —Why have you brought me here?

en: I say coldly.
vi: “Why did you bring me here?” I said coldly.
tr: “Why did you bring me here?” I ask coldly.
es: —I say to him coldly.

en: He's stroking my body now, from stem as they say to stern, cat stroke along the left flank, down the left leg.
vi: At this moment, he is caressing my body, from head to toe as they say, a cat's stroke along the left side, down the left leg.
tr: Now, as they said, they are caressing my body from head to toe, light caresses from the left side to the left leg.
es: Now it caresses my body; from bow to stern, as they used to say, with feline caresses along the left side, going down the left leg.

en: He stops at the foot, his fingers encircling the ankle, briefly, like a bracelet, where the tattoo is, a Braille he can read, a cattle brand.
vi: When he reaches the foot, he stops, his fingers encircle the ankle, for a moment, like a shake, embracing the tattoo, a Braille letter he can read, a cattle brand mark.
tr: When they reach the foot, they stop, their fingers encircle the ankle, briefly, like a bracelet, the place where the tattoo is, readable like Braille, a cattle brand.
es: It stops upon reaching the foot and encircles my ankle with its fingers, briefly, like a bracelet, where the tattoo is, as if reading the Braille system, as if it were a cattle brand.

en: Itmeans ownership.
vi: That letter means ownership.
tr: This signifies ownership.
es: It means ownership.

en: I remind myself that he is not an unkind man; that, under other circumstances, I even like him.
vi: I remind myself that he is not unkind; remind that, in different circumstances, I might even like him.
tr: I remind myself that he is not a rude man; under different circumstances, I also liked him.
es: I remind myself that he is not an unpleasant man; that, under different circumstances, I might even like him.

en: His hand pauses.
vi: The hand paused.
tr: Eli hesitates.
es: His hands stop.

en: "I thought you might enjoy it for a change."
vi: “I thought maybe you would like a change of pace.”
tr: “I thought you might like this as a change.”
es: —I thought you might like a change —knowing that isn't enough—.

en: He knows that isn't enough.
vi: He also knew that wasn't enough.
tr: He knows it's not enough.
es: —I thought you might like a change —knowing that isn't enough—.

en: "I guess it was a sort of experiment."
vi: “I think it's also a kind of experiment.”
tr: “I guess it was some kind of experiment.”
es: I supposed it was some kind of experiment —that's not enough either.

en: That isn't enough either.
vi: That still wasn't enough.
tr: That’s not enough either.
es: I supposed it was some kind of experiment —that's not enough either.

en: "You said you wanted to know."
vi: “You said you wanted to know.”
tr: “You said you wanted to know.”
es: You said you wanted to know.

en: He sits up, begins to unbutton.
vi: He sat up and began to unbutton.
tr: Sitting down, he starts to unbutton.
es: He sits up and starts unbuttoning his clothes.

en: Will this be worse, to have him denuded, of all his cloth power?
vi: Would it be worse when he was stripped, all that silk-like authority?
tr: Will it get worse, stripping him of all this clothing power?
es: Will it be worse to see him stripped of the power that his clothes confer?

en: He's down to the shirt; then, under it, sadly, a little belly.
vi: Now he had gotten down to his shirt, and, sadly, beneath it, a very small belly.
tr: He reached the shirt; then, underneath, a sad, small belly.
es: He has taken off his shirt, and underneath it appears a sad and small belly.

en: Wisps of hair.
vi: A few strands of hair fluttering.
tr: A few tufts of hair.
es: And some tufts of hair.

en: He pulls down one of my straps, slideshis other hand in among the feathers, but it's no good, I lie there like a dead bird.
vi: He slipped one strap of my shirt off, slid his other hand into the feathers, but it was useless, I lay there stiff as a bird struck by an arrow.
tr: He pulls down one of my straps, slides his other hand among the feathers, but it doesn't work, I lie there like a dead bird.
es: He lowers one of my straps and slides the other hand between the feathers; but it's useless, there I stay like a dead bird.

en: He is not a monster, I think.
vi: He is not a demon, I thought.
tr: He's not a monster, I think.
es: He is not a monster, I think.

en: I can't afford pride or aversion, there are all kinds of things that have to be discarded, under the circumstances.
vi: I couldn't maintain pride or disgust, there were a hundred things that needed to be let go of, in this situation.
tr: I can't afford pride or hatred, there are things that must be given up, under certain conditions.
es: I cannot afford the luxury of feeling pride or aversion, there are many things one must give up under certain circumstances.

en: "Maybe I should turn the lights out," says the Commander, dismayed
vi: “Perhaps I should turn off the light,” the Commander said, troubled and clearly offended.
tr: “Maybe I should turn off the lights,” says the Commander, in a weary and undoubtedly disappointed manner.
es: —Maybe it would be better if I turned off the light —says the Commander, dismayed and undoubtedly disappointed.

en: and no doubt disappointed.
vi: “Perhaps I should turn off the light,” the Commander said, troubled and clearly offended.
tr: “Maybe I should turn off the lights,” says the Commander, in a weary and undoubtedly disappointed manner.
es: —Maybe it would be better if I turned off the light —says the Commander, dismayed and undoubtedly disappointed.

en: I see him for a moment before he does this.
vi: I caught a glimpse of him before the light went out.
tr: Before he does that, I see him for a moment.
es: Before he turns off the light, I see him.

en: Without his uniform he looks smaller, older, like something being dried.
vi: Without the uniform, he looked thin, old, as if dried out.
tr: Without his uniform, he looks smaller, older, like something dried up.
es: Without the uniform, he looks smaller, older, as if he were starting to dry up.

en: The trouble is that I can't be, with him, any different from the way I usually am with him.
vi: The trouble is, I cannot do anything different beside him than I usually do.
tr: The problem is, I can't be with him in a different way than ever before.
es: The problem is that I can't behave with him in a way different from the usual.

en: Usually I'm inert.
vi: Usually, I just sit idly.
tr: Usually, the situation I am in is one of immobility.
es: And usually, I show myself as inert.

en: Surely there must be something here for us, other than this futility and bathos.
vi: There must be something more here, not just awkwardness and uselessness.
tr: Of course, there must be something here for us, something different from this uselessness and baseness.
es: Surely there is something more for us here, something that isn't this futility and sentimentality.

en: Fake it, I scream at myself inside my head.
vi: Pretend, I shouted in my head.
tr: Pose, I shout to myself inside my mind.
es: Pretend, I screamed mentally to myself.

en: You must remember how.
vi: You have to remember how to do it.
tr: You must remember how to do it.
es: You must remember how to do it.

en: Let's get this over with or you'll be here all night.
vi: If you don't finish this, you'll be here all night.
tr: Let's finish this, or you'll stay here all night.
es: Finish this once and for all or you'll spend the whole night here.

en: Bestir yourself.
vi: Move, damn it.
tr: Get yourself moving.
es: Move.

en: Move your flesh around, breathe audibly.
vi: Shift your body, breathe loudly.
tr: Twist your body, breathe audibly.
es: Breathe heavily.

en: It's the least you can do.
vi: At least you have to do that.
tr: At least you can do this.
es: It's the least you can do.

en: XIII
vi: XIII - Night
tr: Thirteen
es: Thirteen

en: Night
vi: XIII - Night
tr: Night
es: THE NIGHT

vi: XIII - Night
tr: Night
es: THE NIGHT
CHAPTER 40

en: The heat at night is worse than the heat in daytime.
vi: The nighttime heat is more unbearable than the daytime heat.
tr: The night heat is worse than the daytime heat.
es: At night, the heat is worse than during the day.

en: Even with the fan on, nothing moves, and the walls store up warmth, give it out like a used oven.
vi: Even with the fan on, nothing moves, the four walls accumulate heat, sweltering like an old oven.
tr: Even if the fan is running, nothing stirs, the walls store the heat and give it back like a used oven.
es: Despite the fan being on, everything remains still; the walls accumulate heat and release it as if they were a lit oven.

en: Surely it will rain soon.
vi: It will probably rain soon.
tr: It's certain that it will rain soon.
es: Surely it will rain soon.

en: Why do I want it?
vi: What do I want rain for?
tr: Why do I want it to rain?
es: Why do I wish for it?

en: It will only mean more dampness.
vi: Rain will only add more humidity.
tr: It will only mean more humidity.
es: It will only mean more humidity.

en: There's lightning far away but no thunder.
vi: There is distant lightning but no thunder.
tr: Lightning flashes in the distance, but there's no thunder.
es: In the distance, a lightning bolt can be seen, but no thunder is heard.

en: Looking out the window I can see it, a glimmer, like the phosphorescence you get in stirred seawater, behind the sky, which is overcast and too low and a dull gray infrared.
vi: I see the lightning when I look out the window, faintly flickering, like phosphorescence in a stormy sea, the other side of the sky filled with low-hanging clouds, emitting a dull infrared glow.
tr: When I look out the window, I can see it like phosphorescence on a wavy sea, a glimmer behind the cloud-covered, very low and dull gray infrared-colored sky.
es: I can see it from the window, a flickering light —like the phosphorescence perceived in a choppy sea— behind the cloudy sky, very low and of a dull infrared gray color.

en: The searchlights are off, which is not usual.
vi: The floodlights have gone out, an unusual occurrence, a power cut.
tr: The spotlights are off, this is unusual.
es: The spotlights are off, which is unusual.

en: A power failure.
vi: The floodlights have gone out, an unusual occurrence, a power cut.
tr: A power outage.
es: A power outage.

en: Or else Serena Joy has arranged it.
vi: Or Serena Joy's arrangement.
tr: Or Serena Joy arranged this.
es: Or Serena Joy might have arranged it that way.

en: I sit in the darkness; no point in having the light on, to advertise the fact that I'm still awake.
vi: I sit in the dark; turning on the light is useless, announcing that I am still awake.
tr: I'm sitting in the dark; there's no point in turning on the light, in announcing the fact that I'm still awake.
es: I sit in the darkness; there's no point in leaving the light on, they would realize that I'm still awake.

en: I'm fully dressed in my red habit again, having shed the spangles, scraped off the lipstick with toilet paper.
vi: I have again finished dressing in my red attire, the beads have been poured out, the lipstick has been wiped clean with toilet paper, then hoping nothing is revealed, no smell of it, or his smell remains.
tr: I put on my entirely red clothes again, after removing the sequins and wiping off the lipstick with toilet paper.
es: I am fully dressed, once again in my red habit, after having removed the sequins and wiped off the lipstick with toilet paper.

en: I hope nothing shows, I hope I don't smell of it, or of him either.
vi: I have again finished dressing in my red attire, the beads have been poured out, the lipstick has been wiped clean with toilet paper, then hoping nothing is revealed, no smell of it, or his smell remains.
tr: I hope nothing is noticeable, I hope neither his nor the Commander's scent has clung to me.
es: I hope nothing is noticeable, I hope I don't smell like makeup, nor like him.

en: She's here at midnight, as she said she'd be.
vi: She arrived at midnight, as announced.
tr: As she said, Serena is here at midnight.
es: She will be here at midnight, just as she said.

en: I can hear her, a faint tapping, a faint shuffling on the muffling rug of the corridor, before her light knock comes.
vi: I heard the sound, the cane tapping lightly, feet shuffling softly on the thick carpet lining the hallway, before the faint knocking on the door came.
tr: I can hear her, a faint rustle before she softly taps on the door, a slight scraping sound on the suffocating carpet of the corridor.
es: I can hear her, a faint tapping, a faint shuffling of feet on the thick carpet of the hallway, and then a soft knock on the door.

en: I don't say anything, but follow her back along the hall and down the stairs.
vi: I didn't say a word, following her back down the hallway to the stairs.
tr: I don't say anything, but I follow her down the hall and the stairs.
es: I say nothing, but I follow her down the hallway and then downstairs.

en: She can walk faster, she's stronger than I thought.
vi: She could move faster, she was stronger than I thought.
tr: She can walk faster, stronger than I thought.
es: She walks quickly, she is stronger than I thought.

en: Her left hand clamps the banister, in pain maybe but holding on, steadying her.
vi: Her hand gripped the stair railing, enduring the pain, perhaps, but still holding tight, helping her stand straight.
tr: Her left hand grips the banister, perhaps with pain but enduring it, supporting herself.
es: She grips the banister with her left hand, perhaps because of the pain and also to steady herself.

en: I think: she's biting her lip, she's suffering.
vi: I thought: she is biting her lip, she is in pain.
tr: She bites her lip, she's in pain, I think.
es: I think: she is biting her lips, she is suffering.

en: She wants it all right, that baby.
vi: She really needs it, this child.
tr: Yes, she really wants this baby.
es: There is no doubt that she wants the baby.

en: I see the two of us, a blue shape, a red shape, in the brief glass eye of the mirror as we descend.
vi: I saw the two of us, one blue shadow, one red shadow, in the reflection of the glasses as we passed by.
tr: As we go down, I see the two of us in the short glass of the mirror, one blue and one red figure.
es: In the glass eye that forms the mirror, as we descend, I see us both, a blue silhouette, a red silhouette.

en: Myself, my obverse.
vi: Me and my counterpart.
tr: As we go down, I see the two of us in the short glass of the mirror, one blue and one red figure.
es: Me and my reverse.

en: We go out through the kitchen.
vi: We passed through the kitchen and went outside.
tr: We are leaving the kitchen and going outside.
es: Let's go to the kitchen.

en: It's empty, a dim night-light's left on; it has the calm of empty kitchens at night.
vi: The kitchen was empty, still lit by a dim night light, peaceful like every empty kitchen at night.
tr: The kitchen is empty, a night light has been left on; it has that silence peculiar to empty kitchens at night.
es: It is deserted and a small lamp has been left on; you can feel the calm that reigns during the night in empty kitchens.

en: The bowls on the counter, the canisters and stoneware jars loom round and heavy through the shadowy light.
vi: Bowls lay on the rack, iron boxes and porcelain jars formed plump round shapes casting shadows from the light.
tr: The containers, boxes, and earthenware bowls on the counter look round and heavy due to the shadowy light.
es: The bowls on the shelf, the cans, and the clay containers looming menacingly under the dim light.

en: The knives are put away into their wooden rack.
vi: Knives were neatly arranged on the wooden shelf.
tr: The knives have been put away on the wooden shelves.
es: The knives are stored in their wooden holder.

en: "I won't go outside with you," she whispers.
vi: “I will not go outside with you,” she whispered.
tr: “I will not come outside with you,” she whispers.
es: —I won't go out with you —she whispers.

en: Odd, to hear her whispering, as if she is one of us.
vi: Strangely, she whispered, as if she were one of us.
tr: It's strange to hear her whispering as if she were one of us.
es: It's strange to hear her whisper, as if she were one of us.

en: Usually Wives do not lower their voices.
vi: The Ladies rarely lower their voices.
tr: Usually, the Wives do not lower their voices.
es: Normally, Wives don't lower their voices—.

en: "You go out through the door and turn right.
vi: “You go out the door and turn right.
tr: “You will go out the door and turn right.
es: Go out the door and turn right.

en: There's another door, it's open.
vi: There is another door, which is open.
tr: There is another door there, open.
es: You'll find another door; it's open.

en: Go up the stairs and knock, he's expecting you.
vi: Go up the stairs and knock on the door, he is waiting.
tr: Go up the stairs and knock on the door, they are waiting for you.
es: Go up the stairs and knock, he's waiting for you.

en: No one will see you.
vi: No one will see you.
tr: Nobody will see you.
es: No one will see you.

en: I'll sit here."
vi: I will sit here.”
tr: I will sit here.”
es: I'll stay here —then she'll wait for me, in case any problem arises.

en: She'll wait for me then, in case there's trouble; in case Cora and Rita wake up, no one knows why, come in from their room at the back of the kitchen.
vi: So she would wait for me, in case something happened; in case Cora and Rita woke up, who knows why, and came in here from the bedroom behind the kitchen.
tr: So she will wait for me, in case something goes wrong; if Cora and Rita, for some unknown reason, wake up and come into the kitchen from their rooms at the back.
es: In case Cora or Rita get up, who knows why, and come to the back of the kitchen.

en: What will she say to them?
vi: What would she say?
tr: What will she tell them?
es: What will she tell them?

en: That she couldn't sleep.
vi: Say she couldn't sleep.
tr: That she couldn't sleep.
es: That she couldn't sleep.

en: That she wanted some hot milk.
vi: Say she wanted to drink hot milk.
tr: That she wanted some warm milk.
es: That she wanted some warm milk.

en: She'll be adroit enough to lie well, I can see that.
vi: She was quick-witted enough for a lie, that I had seen already.
tr: I can tell she will be good at making up lies.
es: She'll be skillful enough to tell them a lie, that I already know—.

en: "The Commander's in his bedroom upstairs," she says.
vi: “The master is in the upstairs bedroom,” she said.
tr: “Commander, upstairs, in the bedroom,” he says.
es: The Commander is upstairs, in his room —she explains to me—.

en: "He won't come down this late, he never does."
vi: “At this late hour, he won't come down, no way.”
tr: “He wouldn't come down this late, he never does this.”
es: He won't come down at this time of night.

en: That's what she thinks.
vi: That's what she thought.
tr: That's what he thinks.
es: He never does —that's what she believes.

en: I open the kitchen door, step out, wait a moment for vision.
vi: I opened the kitchen door, took a step out, and waited a moment for my eyes to adjust.
tr: I open the kitchen door, step out, and wait for my eyes to adjust.
es: I open the kitchen door, step outside, and wait a moment for my eyes to adjust to the darkness.

en: It's so long since I've been outside, alone, at night.
vi: It had been a long time since I went outside, alone, at night.
tr: It's been such a long time since I went out alone at night.
es: It's been a long time since I've been out alone at night.

en: Now there's thunder, the storm's moving closer.
vi: There was already thunder, the storm was getting closer.
tr: The thunder is now audible, the storm is approaching.
es: Now a thunder is heard, the storm is approaching.

en: What has she done about the Guardians?
vi: What did she do with the Guards?
tr: I wonder how he dealt with the guards?
es: What will he have done regarding the Guardians?

en: I could be shot for a prowler.
vi: If not, I could have been shot like a prowler.
tr: I could be shot as a thief.
es: They could shoot me thinking I'm a prowler.

en: Paid them off somehow, I hope: cigarettes, whiskey, or maybe they know all about it, her stud farm, maybe if this doesn't work she'll try them next.
vi: She must have bribed them somehow, I hope: cigarettes, whisky, or maybe they knew everything, her pigsty, who knows if it doesn't work out this time, she will use them next time.
tr: I hope he bribed them with something: cigarettes, whiskey, or maybe they know everything, the breeding farm, maybe if that doesn't work, he'll try them next time.
es: He must have paid them with something, or so I hope: cigarettes, whiskey, or maybe they know everything, this whole stallion business, maybe if this doesn't work, he'll make me try with them next.

en: The door to the garage is only steps away.
vi: The garage door was just a few steps away.
tr: The door to the garage is just a few steps away.
es: The door leading to the garage is just a few steps away.

en: I cross, feet noiseless on the grass, and open it quickly, slip inside.
vi: I rushed over, my feet silently treading on the grass, and quickly opened it, slipping inside.
tr: I walk, my feet silent on the grass, quickly open the door and slip inside.
es: I walk on the grass with silent steps and slip inside.

en: The stairway is dark, darker than I can see.
vi: The staircase was dark, so dark that I couldn't see the way.
tr: The stair landing is dark, too dark to see.
es: The staircase is in darkness, so much so that I can't see anything.

en: I feel my way up, stairby stair: carpet here, I think of it as mushroom-colored.
vi: I groped my way up, step by step: there was carpet, I imagined it to be the color of mushroom caps.
tr: Upwards, feeling my way, step by step, I find my way. There's a carpet here, I think, it's cork-colored.
es: I climb up groping, step by step: there is a carpet, I imagine it is mushroom-colored.

en: This must have been an apartment once, for a student, a young single person with a job.
vi: This must have once been a rental room, for students, for young people living alone who had started working.
tr: This must have once been an apartment; for a student, a young bachelor with a job.
es: Once, this must have been an apartment for a student, a young and single person with a job.

en: A lot of the big houses around here had them.
vi: Many large houses around here have them.
tr: Many of the large houses around had these.
es: There used to be a lot of big houses around here where they lived.

en: A bachelor, a studio, those were the names for that kind of apartment.
vi: Studio apartments, single rooms, as they are commonly called.
tr: Bachelor room, studio; these were the names of such apartments.
es: A bachelor pad, that's what they called this type of apartment.

en: It pleases me to be able to
vi: I was quite pleased to remember this.
tr: I like being able to remember this.
es: I like to check that I am able to remember it.

en: remember this.
vi: I was quite pleased to remember this.
tr: I like being able to remember this.
es: I like to check that I am able to remember it.

en: Separate entrance, it would say in the ads, and that meant you could have sex, unobserved.
vi: Private entrance, as stated in the advertisement, meaning a path to satisfy one's instincts, without anyone peeking in.
tr: Separate entrance, the ads would say, and this meant you could have sex without being watched.
es: Private entrance, they put in the ads, which meant they could bring a little friend without anyone noticing.

en: I reach the top of the stairs, knock on the door there.
vi: I climbed all the stairs and knocked on the door in front of me.
tr: Reaching the end of the stairs, I knock on the door there.
es: I reach the end of the stairs and knock on the door.

en: He opens it himself, who else was I expecting?
vi: It was him who opened the door, who else could I expect?
tr: He opens the door himself, who else was I expecting?
es: He himself opens it, who else?

en: There's a lamp on, only one but enough light to make me blink.
vi: A single light was on, just one but enough to make my eyes blink.
tr: A lamp is on, just one, but there's enough light to make me blink.
es: There is a lamp on, only one but powerful enough to make me blink.

en: I look past him, not wanting to meet his eyes.
vi: I looked away behind him, not wanting to meet his eyes.
tr: I look beyond him, hoping not to meet his eyes.
es: I look inside the room, I don't want to look him in the eyes.

en: It's a single room, with a fold-out bed, made up, and a kitchenette counter at the far end, and another door that must lead to the bathroom.
vi: The room was a single room, with a folding bed, the bedding already arranged, a small kitchenette somewhere, and another door probably leading to the bathroom.
tr: It's a single room, with a pull-out couch, opened; in the far corner, there's a small kitchen counter and another door that should lead to the bathroom.
es: It is a single room with a folding bed, which is already prepared, and a small built-in kitchen at the other end and another door that must lead to the bathroom.

en: This room is stripped down, military, mini
vi: The room was a single room, with a folding bed, the bedding already arranged, a small kitchenette somewhere, and another door probably leading to the bathroom.
tr: This room is bare, military, minimal.
es: A dismantled room, military style and tiny.

en: I I
vi: A bare, military-like, extremely simple room.
tr: This room is bare, military, minimal.
es: A dismantled room, military style and tiny.

en: mal.
vi: A bare, military-like, extremely simple room.
tr: This room is bare, military, minimal.
es: A dismantled room, military style and tiny.

en: No pictures on the walls, no plants.
vi: No pictures on the walls, no plants on the floor.
tr: No pictures on the walls. No flowers.
es: There are no pictures on the walls, nor plants.

en: He's camping out.
vi: He was living in a makeshift manner.
tr: It's as if he's camping.
es: He camps here.

en: The blanket on the bed is gray and says U. S.
vi: The blanket on the bed was gray, marked with a U. S.
tr: The blanket on the bed is gray and has U. S. written on it.
es: The blanket on the bed is gray and bears the inscription U. S.

en: He steps back and aside to let me pass.
vi: He stepped aside to make room for me to pass.
tr: He steps back to let me pass, turning slightly to the side.
es: He takes a step back and lets me in.

en: He's in his shirt sleeves, and is holding a cigarette, lit.
vi: He was only wearing a shirt, holding a lit cigarette.
tr: His shirt on his back, a burning cigarette in his hand.
es: He is in shirt sleeves and has a lit cigarette in his hand.

en: I smell the smoke on him, in the warm air of the room, all over.
vi: I smelled the scent of tobacco on him, mingling with the warm air, filling the room.
tr: I smell the smoke on him, in the warm air of the room and everywhere.
es: I perceive the smell of smoke, on him, in the hot air of the room, everywhere.

en: I'd like to take off my clothes, bathe in it, rub it over my skin.
vi: I wanted to strip off my clothes and bathe in that smoke, letting it seep into my skin.
tr: I wish I could take off my clothes, bathe in this scent, rub it on my skin.
es: I would like to take off my clothes and bathe in this smell, rub my skin with it.

en: No preliminaries; he knows why I'm here.
vi: Don't start anything; you know why I'm here.
tr: There is no prior affection; he knows why I am here.
es: No preliminaries; he knows why I am here.

en: He doesn't even say anything, why fool around, it's an assignment.
vi: You don't say a word, what are you doing, this is serious.
tr: He does not utter a single word, why waste time, this is a duty.
es: He doesn't even say anything, why waste time on nonsense, this is about a job.

en: He moves away from me, turns off thelamp.
vi: You move away from me, turn off the light.
tr: He moves away from me and turns off the lamp.
es: He moves away from me and turns off the lamp.

en: Outside, like punctuation, there's a flash of lightning; almost no pause and then the thunder.
vi: Outside, like a beat, a flash of lightning bursts; almost immediately thunder roars.
tr: Outside, like a punctuation mark, a flash of lightning; almost without a pause, thunder is heard afterward.
es: Outside, like punctuation, a flash of lightning is seen; almost immediately the thunder is heard.

en: He's undoing my dress, a man made of darkness, I can't see his face, and I can hardly breathe, hardly stand, and I'm not standing.
vi: You are taking off my clothes, a man made of darkness, I can't see your face, I can hardly breathe, can hardly stand, I am no longer standing.
tr: He undresses me, a man made of darkness, I cannot see his face, I am barely breathing, barely standing, and I am no longer standing.
es: He is taking off my dress, he is a man made of darkness, I can't see his face, I can barely breathe, I can barely endure it, and I am not resisting.

en: His mouth is on me, his hands, I can't wait and he's moving, already, love, it's been so long, I'm alive in my skin, again, arms around him, falling and water softly everywhere, never-ending.
vi: Your mouth presses against me, your hands, I can't wait but you are moving, so fast, the passion, it's been so long, my skin comes alive again, resurrects, arms embracing you, falling and soft water everywhere, bottomless.
tr: His mouth on me, his hands, I cannot wait and he moves, already, love, it has been so long, I am alive within my skin, again, my arms wrap around him, a fall and water softly covering everything, unending.
es: I feel his mouth on me, his hands, I can't wait and he is already moving, love, it's been so long, I feel life pulsing in my skin, again, arms around him, as if falling into water softly, without finding the end.

en: I knew it might only be once.
vi: I understand it might be just once.
tr: I know that such a thing can only happen once.
es: I knew it could be just once.

en: I made that up.
vi: I made it up.
tr: I made this up.
es: I made it up.

en: It didn't happen that way.
vi: That's not how it is.
tr: It didn't happen this way.
es: It didn't happen that way.

en: Here is what happened.
vi: It's like this.
tr: Here is what happened:
es: It didn't happen that way.

en: I reach the top of the stairs, knock on the door.
vi: I climbed all the way up the stairs and knocked on the door.
tr: I reach the top of the stairs and knock on the door.
es: What happened is the following: I reach the end of the stairs and knock on the door..

en: He opens it himself.
vi: He himself opened the door.
tr: He opens the door himself.
es: He himself is the one who opens it.

en: There's a lamp on; I blink.
vi: A light was on, and I blinked my eyes.
tr: A lamp turns on, and I blink my eyes.
es: There is a lamp on; I blink.

en: I look past his eyes, it's a single room, the bed's made up, stripped down, military.
vi: I avoided looking at him; this was a single room, the bed was made, bare, and military-like.
tr: I look beyond his eyes; this is a single-person room, bare, with a military-made bed.
es: I look inside the room, it is a single room, dismantled, military-style, the bed is already made.

en: No pictures but the blanket says U. S. He's in his shirt sleeves, he's holding a cigarette.
vi: There were no pictures, but the blanket had a U mark. He was only wearing a shirt, holding a cigarette in his hand.
tr: No pictures, but the blanket has U. S. written on it. He's in his shirt, holding a cigarette.
es: There are no pictures, but the blanket has the inscription U. S. He is in his shirt sleeves and has a cigarette.

en: "Here," he says to me, "have a drag."
vi: “Hey,” he told me, “take a puff.”
tr: “Al,” he says to me, “take a puff.”
es: —Ten —he tells me—, take a puff —no preliminaries, he knows why I'm here.

en: No preliminaries, he knows why
vi: No preamble, he knew why I was there.
tr: No small talk, he knows why I'm here.
es: —Ten —he tells me—, take a puff —no preliminaries, he knows why I'm here.

en: I'm here.
vi: No preamble, he knew why I was there.
tr: No small talk, he knows why I'm here.
es: —Ten —he tells me—, take a puff —no preliminaries, he knows why I'm here.

en: To get knocked up, to get in trouble, up the pole, those were all names for it once.
vi: To puff out my chest, to bring trouble upon myself, to check my backpack in reverse, those names from a distant past.
tr: Being loaded, having problems, being heavily pregnant; it was always called like this once upon a time.
es: To get pregnant, to get into trouble, in over my head, as they used to say.

en: I take the cigarette from him, draw deeply in, hand it back.
vi: I took the cigarette, inhaled deeply, and handed it back.
tr: I take the cigarette from him, take a deep puff, and give it back.
es: I take the cigarette from his hands, take a deep puff, and give it back to him.

en: Our fingers hardly touch.
vi: Our fingers barely touched.
tr: Our fingers barely touch.
es: Our fingers barely touch.

en: Even that much smoke makes me dizzy.
vi: Even a bit of smoke made my head ache.
tr: Even this little bit of smoke makes my head spin.
es: Even that puff makes me dizzy.

en: He says nothing, just looks at me, unsmiling.
vi: He didn't say anything, just looked at me, not smiling.
tr: He doesn't say anything, just looks at me, without smiling.
es: He doesn't say anything, he just looks at me with a serious expression.

en: It would be better, more friendly, if he would touch me.
vi: It would be better, friendlier, if he touched me.
tr: If he had touched me, it would have been better, more friendly.
es: It would be better and more pleasant if he touched me.

en: I feel stupid and ugly, although I know I am not either.
vi: I felt stupid and ugly, even though I knew both of those things were not true.
tr: I feel stupid and ugly, even though I know I'm neither.
es: I feel stupid and horrible, although I know I'm not.

en: Still, what does he think, why doesn't he say something?
vi: But then, what is he thinking, why doesn't he say anything?
tr: Still, what is he thinking, why doesn't he say anything?
es: However, what does he think, why doesn't he say anything?

en: Maybe he thinks I've been slutting around, at Jezebel's, with the Commander or more.
vi: Maybe he thinks I was just busy whoring around, at Jezebel's, with the Commander or a few other guys.
tr: Maybe he thinks I'm fooling around, at Jezebel's Place, with the Commander or others.
es: Maybe he thinks that at Jezebel's I've been fooling around with the Commander.

en: It annoys me that I'm even worrying about what he thinks.
vi: I was annoyed to find myself worrying about what he thought.
tr: It even angers me to worry about what they think.
es: It bothers me that I still care about what he thinks.

en: Let's be practical.
vi: Let's be realistic.
tr: Let's be practical.
es: Let's be practical.

en: "I don't have much time," I say.
vi: “I don't have much time,” I said.
tr: “I don't have much time,” I say. I acted rudely and clumsily, that wasn't what I meant. "I can empty into a bottle and you can pour into it," he says. He doesn't smile. “There’s no need to be rude,” I say. Maybe she feels used. Maybe she wants something from me, a bit of emotion, an acknowledgment that she’s human too, that she’s more than just a seed envelope. “I know it’s hard for you,” I try. He shrugs his shoulders. “I get what I deserve,” he says, with an empty retort. But he still doesn't move. I'm getting my due, I'm laying you down, I rhyme in my mind. So, this is how we will do it. She didn't like the makeup and sequins. We will be strict. "Do you come here often?" “What is a good girl like me doing in a place like this?” I reply, and we both smile: this is better. This is to confirm that we are pretending, because what else can we do in such a situation? “Abstinence spurs desire.” We are quoting from old movies belonging to a previous era. Those movies belonged to an even earlier time: Such conversations correspond to a date long before our own era. Even my mother wouldn't speak like that, at least not as long as I've known her. Maybe no one ever spoke like that in real life, it was all a lie from the beginning. Still, how surprising it is that it comes to mind so easily, I understand now what purpose this stereotypical and artificial joke, peculiar to homos, served, what it has always served: to keep one's essence distant; closed, protected. Now I am sad, the way we speak is extremely melancholic: lost music, faded paper flowers, worn satin, an echo of an echo. Everything is gone, now impossible. I start crying out of the blue. Finally, he moves towards me, wraps his arms around me, strokes my back, holds me in this way, to comfort me. “Come on,” he says. “We don't have much time.” With his arm around my shoulder, he takes me to the pull-out couch and lays me down. He even opens the blanket first. He starts undressing me, then caressing me, kissing my ear. “No romance,” he says. “Okay?” It had a different meaning once, a long time ago.
es: —I don't have much time —I warn him.

en: This is awkward and clumsy, it isn't what I mean.
vi: An awkward and clumsy sentence, I didn't mean it that way at all.
tr: The meaning back then: no restrictions. The current meaning: no exaggerations. The meaning: don't risk yourself for me, if it comes to that. And so it goes. And so. I knew it could only happen once. Goodbye, I thought, even then, goodbye. There was no thunder either, I had added this. To cover up the sounds I was ashamed to make. It didn't happen like that. I'm not sure exactly how it happened. My only hope is in a revival: feeling love is always just an approximation. Halfway, I thought of Serena Joy, sitting downstairs in the kitchen. Thinking: cheap. They spread their legs for everyone. The only thing you need to give them is a cigarette. And then I thought: This is a betrayal. Not the act itself, but my reaction. If I knew for certain that he was dead, would it matter? I wish I were shameless. I wish I were unashamed.
es: It sounds awkward and untimely, it's not what I meant to say.

en: "I could just squirt it into a bottle and you could pour it in," he says.
vi: "I can squeeze it into a bottle, and you can just pour it in," he said. Not laughing. “There's no need to be so cruel,” I said. Maybe he felt used. Maybe he also wanted something from me, like emotions, like acknowledging that he is also human, not just a seed pod. “I know you have your own difficulties,” I ventured. He shrugged. "I get paid," he said, looking irritable. But he still didn't move. I get paid, she gets beaten, I recite in my head. So we will do it like that. He doesn't like makeup, flashy stuff. We will play it cool. “Do you come here often?” “What can a good girl like me do in a place like this,” I replied.
tr: I wish I were ignorant.
es: —I could squirt some into a bottle and then you could stick it in yourself —he replies.

en: He doesn't smile.
vi: Both of them smiled: that's better.
tr: That way, I wouldn't know how ignorant I am.
es: He doesn't smile. —There is no need for you to be cruel —I tell him. Maybe he feels used. Perhaps he expects something from me, some emotion, some recognition that he is also human, that he is something more than just a mere seed—. I know it is difficult for you — I suggest. He shrugs. —I get paid —he says in a grumpy tone. But he still doesn't move. I get paid, you go to bed, I hum to myself, So that's how we'll do it. He doesn't like makeup or sequins. We're going to be tough. —Do you come here often? —And what is a girl like me doing in a place like this? —I respond. We both smile: that's better.

en: XIV Salvaging
vi: That was an acknowledgment that we were acting, for what else could we do with such a setup? "The longer the abstinence, the deeper the love." We are quoting late-night movies from a very long time ago. And those movies used even older language: this manner of speaking originates from an era millions of years before us. Even my mother didn't speak like that when I lived with her. Perhaps no one has ever spoken like that in real life; it was made up from the start. Anyway, it's still surprising how quickly it has come back, this old-fashioned, falsely cheerful way of asking for favors. Now I know what the real meaning is, returning after millions of years: to keep one's core truly distant, truly hidden, untouchable by anyone. I'm sad again, talking like this leads to endless sorrow: the music fades, the paper flowers lose their color, the satin frays, echoes within echoes. Everything is lost, never to return. Suddenly, I burst into tears. Finally, he came forward, wrapped his arms around me, gently rubbed my back, just holding me like that, comforting me.
es: It's an acknowledgment that we are acting because, What else can we do in such a situation? —Abstinence softens the heart —we are quoting lines from old movies, from other times. And even back then, they were old movies: that way of speaking belongs to a time quite earlier than ours. Not even my mother spoke like that, as far as I can remember. Perhaps no one ever spoke like that in real life and it was all something fabricated from the beginning. However, it is astonishing how easily these clichéd and falsely cheerful sexual jokes come to mind. Now I understand what they mean, what they have always meant: to keep the essence of each person out of danger, enclosed, protected. I am sad, the way both of them speak is infinitely sad: a music that fades away, paper flowers that wither, worn-out satin, the echo of an echo. Everything is over, nothing is possible anymore. Suddenly, I burst into tears. Finally, he moves, wraps his arms around me, caresses my back, comforts me.

vi: “Come on,” he said. “We don't have much time.” Still holding my shoulder, he led me to the folding bed and laid me down. He remembered to pull the blanket back first. He started unbuttoning, then caressing, kissing my ear. “No playing romantic games,” he said. “Agreed?” That sentence used to have a different implication, in the past. In the past, it used to mean: unbound. Now it means: no hero.
tr: Salvation
es: —Come on —he says—.

vi: It means: don't risk your life for me, if it comes to that.
es: We don't have much time —without removing his arm from my shoulders, he leads me to the folding bed and lays me down, first pulling back the sheet. He starts to unbutton himself, then he caresses me and kisses my ear—.

en: I wish this story were different.
vi: And then it was like that. And just like that. I know it might be just once. Farewell, I thought, right at that moment, farewell. But there was no thunder, I added that. To drown out the sounds that made me ashamed. It's not like that anymore either. I'm not sure what happened, not exactly. I just hope to reconstruct some part of it: the feeling of love is always just approximate. In the middle, I thought about Serena Joy, sitting down there in the kitchen. Thinking: how cheap. They would spread their legs for any man. It only costs a cigarette. And I thought again, later: that was betrayal. Not the event itself, but my reaction. If I knew for sure he was dead, would it make any difference? I wish I were not ashamed. I wish I did not know shame. I wish I were ignorant. That way, I wouldn't have to know how ignorant I am. XIV - Redemption 41 I wish this story were different.
tr: I wish this story were different.
es: No romantic fantasies —he tells me—. Agreed? Once, this would have meant something else. Once, it would have meant: no strings attached. Now it means: no heroics. It means: if it comes to it, don't risk yourself for me. And that's how it happened. I knew it could be just once. Goodbye, I even thought at that moment, goodbye. However, no thunder sounded, I added. To cover the noises that embarrass me to make. It didn't happen that way either. I'm not sure how it happened, not exactly. All I can do is a reconstruction: the way love feels is always approximate. In the midst of all this, I thought of Serena Joy, who was sitting in the kitchen, thinking in turn: it turned out to be easy. They would spread their legs for anyone. All you have to do is give them a cigarette. And then I thought: this is a betrayal. Not the fact itself, but my reaction. If I were sure that he is dead, would there be any difference? I wish I didn't feel shame. I would like to be shameless. I would like to be ignorant. Then I wouldn't know how ignorant I am. 14 THE RESCUE CHAPTER 41 I would like this story to be different.

en: I wish it were more civilized.
vi: I wish it were more civilized.
tr: I wish it were more civilized.
es: I would like it to be more civilized.

en: I wish it showed me in a better light, if not happier, then at least more active, less hesitant, less distracted by trivia.
vi: I wish I appeared in it better, if not happy, then at least more energetic, less hesitant, less distracted by trivial matters.
tr: I wish it, if not happier, at least showed me in a better light, then at least more active, less hesitant, less hindered by trivial things.
es: I would like it to give a better impression of me, if not as a happy person, at least more active, less hesitant, less distracted by trivialities.

en: I wish it had more shape.
vi: I wish it had a clearer beginning and end.
tr: I wish it were more structured.
es: I would like it to have a more defined form.

en: I wish it were about love, or about sudden realizations important to one's life, or even about sunsets, birds, rainstorms, or snow.
vi: I wish it were about love, or sudden realizations that mark a lifetime, or even about sunsets, birds, storms, snowfall, anything.
tr: And I wish it were about love or significant sudden realizations in human life, even about sunsets, birds, storms, or snow.
es: I would like it to be about love, or significant achievements in life, or about sunsets, or birds, storms, or snow.

en: Maybe it is about those things, in a way; but in the meantime there is so much else getting in the way, so much whispering, so much speculation about others, so much gossip that cannot be verified,so many unsaid words, so much creeping about and secrecy.
vi: It could also be about those very things, somehow; but at present, there are too many obstacles, too many whispers, too many assumptions about others, too many unverified rumors, too many unspoken words, too much groping and secrecy.
tr: Perhaps it is about all these things, in a way; but meanwhile, there are many other things happening, a bunch of whispers, a bunch of speculations about others, a bunch of rumors that cannot be proven true, a bunch of unspoken words, sneaky movements around, and a bunch of secrecy.
es: Perhaps, in a certain sense, it is a story about all of this; but in the meantime, there are many things that cross the path, many whispers, many speculations about other people, much gossip that cannot be verified, many unspoken words, much stealth and secrets.

en: And there is so much time to be endured, time heavy as fried food or thick fog; and then all at once these red events, like explosions, on streets otherwise decorous and matronly and somnambulent.
vi: And again, too much time to endure, time thick as fried food or dense fog, and then suddenly those events, like bombs exploding, amidst the usually courteous streets of sleepwalking ladies.
tr: Moreover, there is a bunch of time to endure, a time as heavy as fried foods or a thick fog; and then, in otherwise familiar, maternal, and somnolent streets, anarchic events that suddenly appear like explosions.
es: And there is much time to endure, a time as heavy as fried food or thick fog; and, suddenly, these bloody events, like explosions, in streets that would otherwise be decorous, serene, and somnolent.

en: I'm sorry there is so much pain in this story.
vi: Forgive me for this, as it brings so much sorrow.
tr: I'm sorry that there is so much pain in this story.
es: I lament that in this story there is so much pain.

en: I'm sorry it's in
vi: Forgive me for this, as it brings so much sorrow.
tr: I'm sorry that there is so much pain in this story.
es: I lament that in this story there is so much pain.

en: fragments, like a body caught in crossfire or pulled apart by force.
vi: Forgive me, it is fragmented into pieces, like a body trapped between the crossfire of sparrows or being torn apart by five horses.
tr: I'm also sorry that it is fragmented, like a body caught in crossfire or forcibly torn apart.
es: And I lament that it is in fragments, like someone caught between two fires or shattered by force.

en: But there is nothing I can do to change it.
vi: But there is nothing I can do to fix it.
tr: Unfortunately, there is nothing I can do to change it.
es: But I can do nothing to change it.

en: I've tried to put some of the good things in as well.
vi: I also tried to include a few good things.
tr: I tried to put good things inside as well, though.
es: I have also tried to show some of the good things.

en: Flowers, for instance, because where would we be without them?
vi: Flowers, for example, because what would we be without flowers?
tr: Flowers, for example, because without them, where would we be?
es: For example, the flowers, because where would we have gotten without them?

en: Nevertheless it hurts me to tell it over, over again.
vi: However, I still feel pain when I have to recount it from the beginning, once more.
tr: Despite everything, telling it over and over again hurts me.
es: Anyway, it hurts me to tell it over and over again.

en: Once was enough: wasn't once enough for me at the time?
vi: Once is enough: wasn't once enough for me, back then?
tr: Once was enough: Wasn't once enough back then?
es: Once was enough: wasn't it enough for me at the time?

en: But I keep on going with this sad and hungry and sordid, this limping and mutilated story, because after all I want you to hear it, as I will hear yours too if I ever get the chance, if I meet you or if you escape, in the future or in heaven or in prison or underground, some other place.
vi: But I still continue this sad, hungry, wretched story, this limping and crippled tale, because after all, I want someone to hear it, just as I would listen to someone else's story if I ever had the chance, if I met them or if they escaped, in the future, in heaven, in prison, or in the underground, somewhere other than here.
tr: Yet I continue to live with this sorrowful and hungry and miserable, this limping and crippled story, because I want you to listen, after all, just as I will listen to yours, if I get the chance, that is, if I meet you or if you run away, in the future or in Heaven or underground, somewhere else.
es: That's why I continue with this sad, eager, sordid, lame, and mutilated story, because after all I want you to hear it, just as I would like to hear yours if the opportunity ever arises, if I find you or if you escape, in the future, or in Heaven, in prison or in hiding, anywhere else.

en: What they have in common is that they're not here.
vi: They all share one thing in common: they are not here.
tr: The common point is that they are not here.
es: What they have in common is that they are not here.

en: By telling you anything at all I'm at least believing in you, I believe you're there, I believe you into being.
vi: By telling someone anything, at the very least, I believe there is someone, I believe someone exists, I believe someone will come into existence.
tr: By telling you something out of nothing, at least I believe in you, I believe that you are there, by believing I create you.
es: By telling you something, anything, at least I am believing in you, believing that you are there, I believe in your existence.
