en: Because I'm telling you this story I will your existence.
vi: Because by telling this story to someone, I affirm their presence.
tr: By telling you this story, I also determine your existence.
es: Because by telling you this story, I make you exist.

en: I tell, therefore you are.
vi: I tell it, therefore they exist.
tr: I tell, therefore you are.
es: I tell, therefore you exist.

en: So I will go on.
vi: So I decided to continue.
tr: That's why I will continue.
es: So I will continue.

en: So I will myself to go on.
vi: So I decided that I must continue.
tr: That's why I will push myself to keep going.
es: I will force myself to continue.

en: I am coming to a part you will not like at all, because in it I did not behave well, but I will try nonetheless to leave nothing out.
vi: I am about to tell the part that people won't like, because in it I behaved really badly, but anyway I will try not to hide anything.
tr: I'm coming to a part you won't like at all, you won't like it because in this section, without behaving appropriately, I will try not to skip anything no matter what.
es: We have reached a part that you will not like at all because I did not behave well, but nevertheless I will try not to leave anything out.

en: After all you've been through, you deserve whatever I have left, which is not much but includes the truth.
vi: For those who have gone through all that, you deserve everything I have left, not much, but it includes the truth.
tr: After all, you've come this far, you have the right to hear whatever is left of this story; there's not much left, but it contains the truth.
es: After all you have been through, you deserve what remains, which is not much but contains the truth.

en: This is the story, then.
vi: So the story goes like this.
tr: So, here is the story.
es: So this is the story.

en: I went back to Nick.
vi: I turned back to Nick.
tr: I went to Nick again.
es: I met with Nick again.

en: Time after time, on my own, without Serena knowing.
vi: Time and again, by myself, Scrcna doesn't know.
tr: Again and again, on my own, without Serena knowing.
es: Time and time again, on my own, without Serena knowing.

en: It wasn't called for, there was no excuse.
vi: It's not because of orders, there's no reason.
tr: It wasn't wanted, there was no excuse.
es: No one asked me to, there were no excuses.

en: I did not do it for him, but for myself entirely.
vi: It's not because of him, entirely just for myself.
tr: I did it not for him, but entirely for myself.
es: I didn't do it for him, but only for myself.

en: I didn't even think of it as giving myself to him, because what did I have to give?
vi: I don't even consider it dedicating myself to him, because what do I have left to give?
tr: I didn't even think of it as giving myself to him, because what did I have to give?
es: I didn't even think I was giving myself to him because, what did I have to give?

en: I did not feel munificent, but thankful, each time he would let me in.
vi: I don't feel like I'm giving, but rather grateful, every time he lets me in.
tr: Every time he let me in, I didn't feel generous, but grateful.
es: I didn't feel generous but grateful every time he received me.

en: He didn't have to.
vi: He isn't obligated to anything.
tr: He didn't have to do it.
es: He had no obligation.

en: In order to do this I became reckless, I took stupid chances.
vi: To do that, I became reckless, I jumped at every foolish opportunity.
tr: I became reckless to do this, I took advantage of unlikely opportunities.
es: Because of this, I became reckless, I made stupid choices.

en: After being with the Commander I would go upstairs in the usual way, but then I would go along the hall and down the Marthas' stairs at the back and through the kitchen.
vi: At the Commander's place, I went upstairs as usual, but then went all the way down the hallway to the back stairs for the Marthas, then through the kitchen.
tr: After being with the Commander, I would go upstairs as usual, but then I would go down the back stairs of the Marthas by following the corridor and go to him through the kitchen.
es: After being with the Commander, I would climb the stairs as usual, but then I would sneak down the hallway and go down the Marthas' staircase and exit through the kitchen.

en: Each time I would hear the kitchen door click shut behind me and I would almost turn back, it sounded so metallic, like a mousetrap or a weapon, but I would not turn back.
vi: Each time, I would hear the kitchen door click shut behind me and almost turn back, the cold metallic sound, like a mouse trap or a weapon, but I didn't turn back.
tr: Each time, I would almost turn back when I heard the click of the kitchen door closing behind me, it sounded very metallic to my ears, like a mouse trap or a gunshot, but I wouldn't turn back.
es: Every time I heard the click of the kitchen door behind me —so metallic, like a mousetrap or a weapon— I thought about turning back, but I didn't.

en: I would hurry across the few feet of illuminated lawnthe searchlights were back on again, expecting at any moment to feel the bullets rip through me even in advance of their sound.
vi: I would rush a few steps across the brightly lit lawn - the floodlights were back, watching out for bullets hitting me at any moment before even hearing the shot.
tr: At any moment, expecting to feel the bullets piercing me even before their sounds, I would hurriedly cross the few meters of illuminated lawn, the spotlights had been turned on again.
es: I hurried across the few meters of illuminated grass; the spotlight would pass again and I waited to feel the bullets piercing me at any moment, even before hearing the shots.

en: I would make my way by touch up the dark staircase and come to rest against the door, the thud of blood in my ears.
vi: I would find my way up the dark stairs and lean against the door, breathing, blood pounding in my ears.
tr: I would find my way by touch on the dark stairs and lean against the door to rest, the thumping of my blood in my ears.
es: I groped my way up the stairs and leaned against the door; the blood rushed to my head.

en: Fear is a powerful stimulant.
vi: There's no stimulant like fear.
tr: Fear is a powerful stimulant.
es: Fear is a powerful stimulant.

en: Then I would knock softly, a beggar's knock.
vi: Then I would knock very lightly, like a beggar.
tr: Then I would knock on the door slowly, like a beggar knocking.
es: Then I would knock on the door softly, like a beggar would.

en: Each time I would expect him to be gone; or worse, I would expect him to say I could not come in.
vi: Every time, I would be wary that he wasn't there, or worse, that he would tell me not to come in.
tr: Each time I would expect him to be gone; or, worse, to tell me I couldn't come in.
es: Every time I did it, I feared that he had left; or, worse yet, that he would tell me I couldn't come in.

en: He might say he wasn't going to break any more rules, put his neck in the noose, for my sake.
vi: He might say he didn't want to break the rules any more, stick his neck out any more, for me.
tr: He could tell me that he would no longer break the rules, that he would no longer play with fire.
es: He could tell me that he didn't want to keep breaking the rules, that he didn't want to have his neck on the line because of me.

en: Or even worse, tell me he was no longer interested.
vi: Or worse, say he wasn't interested in me anymore.
tr: Or, even worse, he could tell me that he was no longer interested.
es: Or, even worse, that he would tell me he was no longer interested.

en: His failure to do any of these things I experienced as the most incredible benevolence and luck.
vi: The fact that he couldn't do any of those things to me was as much kindness as it was unbelievable luck.
tr: His ineptitude at doing any of these things was the most incredible experience of benevolence and luck I had ever lived through.
es: The fact that he didn't tell me any of these things seemed like an incredible stroke of luck to me.

en: I told you it was bad.
vi: I told you it was really bad.
tr: I told you it was bad.
es: I told you it was terrible.

en: Here is how it goes.
vi: The specific story is as follows.
tr: Here's how the story goes.
es: And this is what happens.

en: He opens the door.
vi: He opened the door.
tr: He is opening the door.
es: He opens the door.

en: He's in his shirt sleeves, his shirt untucked, hanging loose; he's holding a toothbrush, or a cigarette, or a glass with something in it.
vi: Sleeves rolled up, shirt untucked, hanging loosely; holding a brush, a cigarette, or a cup containing something.
tr: He is only wearing a shirt, not tucked in, its tails hanging freely; he has a toothbrush in his hand or a cigarette or a glass with something to drink in it.
es: He is in shirt sleeves, with his shirt untucked, loose; in his hand, he carries a toothbrush, or a cigarette, or a glass with some drink.

en: He has his own little stash up here, black-market stuff I suppose.
vi: He also had his own stash up there, black market goods, I guessed.
tr: He has a small, mysterious storage here, I think it's for black market goods.
es: Here he has his own hideout, I suppose for things from the black market.

en: He's always got something in his hand, as if he's been going about his life as usual, not expecting me, not waiting.
vi: His hands always held something, as if he was going about his usual routine, not waiting for me, not anticipating.
tr: He always has something in his hand, as if continuing his life as usual, not expecting my arrival, not waiting for me.
es: She always carries something in her hand, as if she were busy with her usual tasks, as if she weren't waiting for me.

en: Maybe he doesn't expect me, or wait.
vi: Perhaps he wasn't waiting, not anticipating.
tr: Maybe he really isn't expecting or waiting.
es: And maybe she isn't waiting for me.

en: Maybe he has no notion of the future, or does not bother or dare to imagine it.
vi: Maybe he had no concept of the future, or didn't bother or dare to imagine it.
tr: Maybe he doesn't have a concept of the future or doesn't bother to imagine it or doesn't dare to.
es: Perhaps she has no idea about the future, or she doesn't bother or doesn't dare to imagine it.

en: "Is it too late?" I say.
vi: "Is it too late?"
tr: "Is it too late?" I say.
es: —Am I too late? —I ask him.

en: He shakes his head for no.
vi: He shook his head no.
tr: He shakes his head to say no.
es: He shakes his head no.

en: It is understood between us by now that it is never too late, but I go through the ritual politeness of asking.
vi: Now we implicitly understand that it is never too late, but I still politely ask as a formality.
tr: So far, there has been an agreement between us that it is never too late, yet I still show the courtesy of asking.
es: Between us, it is already understood that it is never too late, but I fulfill the ritual courtesy of asking him.

en: It makes me feel more in control, as if there is a choice, a decision that could be made one way or the other.
vi: Thanks to that, I feel like I am in control of the situation, having the right to choose, the right to decide this way or that.
tr: It gives me the feeling of being more in control of the situation, as if there is a choice that can be made, a decision that can be taken, one way or another.
es: That makes me feel calmer, as if there were some alternative, a decision that could be made one way or another.

en: He steps aside and I move past him and he closes the door.
vi: He stepped aside, I walked through, and he closed the door.
tr: He steps aside, I pass by him and enter inside, and he closes the door.
es: He steps aside, I enter, and he closes the door.

en: Then he crosses the room and closes the window.
vi: Then he went to the other end of the room to close the window.
tr: He steps aside, I pass by him and enter inside, and he closes the door.
es: Then he crosses the room and closes the window; afterwards, he turns off the light.

en: After that he turns out the light.
vi: After that, he turned off the light.
tr: Then he turns off the light.
es: Then he crosses the room and closes the window; afterwards, he turns off the light.

en: There is not much talking between us anymore, not at this stage.
vi: There was no more back and forth between us, at this stage.
tr: We don't talk much anymore, at least at this stage.
es: At this stage, there is no conversation between us anymore; I am already half-naked.

en: Already I am half out of my clothes.
vi: I had managed to undress halfway.
tr: I'm already half undressed.
es: At this stage, there is no conversation between us anymore; I am already half-naked.

en: We save the talking for later.
vi: Talking would be saved for later.
tr: We leave the conversation for later.
es: We save the conversation for later.

en: With the Commander I close my eyes, even when I am only kissing him good-night.
vi: By the Commander, I close my eyes, even when saying goodbye.
tr: When I'm with the Commander, I close my eyes, even when giving a goodnight kiss.
es: When I am with the Commander, I close my eyes, even when it is just the goodnight kiss.

en: I do not want to see him up close.
vi: I don't want to look at him too closely.
tr: I don't want to see him that close.
es: I don't want to see him so close.

en: But now, here,
vi: But now, here, every time, my eyes are wide open.
tr: But now, here, every time, I keep my eyes open.
es: But here I always keep my eyes open.

en: each time, I keep my eyes open.
vi: But now, here, every time, my eyes are wide open.
tr: But now, here, every time, I keep my eyes open.
es: But here I always keep my eyes open.

en: I would like a light on somewhere, a candle perhaps, stuck into a bottle, some echo of college, but anything like that would be too great a risk; so I have to make do withthe searchlight, the glow of it from the grounds below, filtered through his white curtains which are the same as mine.
vi: If only there were a light source, like a candle, placed in a bottle neck, reminiscent of college days, but that would be too risky; I have to make do with the headlights, shining up from the yard, piercing through the white curtains similar to those in my room.
tr: I wish there was a light somewhere, maybe a candle, placed on top of a bottle, something echoing the college, but such a thing would be too risky; so I have to make do with the projector light, the glow of the projector light filtering through the same white curtains as mine.
es: I wish there were some light on, maybe a candle stuck in a bottle, some reminiscence of school days, but it wouldn't be worth the risk; so I have to settle for the spotlight and the glow that comes from below, filtered through the white curtains, which are the same as mine.

en: I want to see what can be seen, of him, take him in, memorize him, save him up so I can live on the image, later: the lines of his body,the texture of his flesh, the glisten of sweat on his pelt, his long sardonic unrevealing face.
vi: I want to see as much as possible, in you, perceive you, memorize you, keep you as an image to savor later: the contours of your body, the smoothness of your flesh, the glistening sweat on your hair, the long, mocking, inscrutable face.
tr: I want to see the things that can be seen, about him, to take him in, to memorize him, to keep him inside me, so I can make do with that image later: the contours of his body, the texture of his skin, the sheen of sweat on his skin, his long, mocking, and inscrutable face.
es: I want to see as much of him as I can, take him in, memorize him, keep him in my mind so I can live off his image later: the lines of his body, the texture of his skin, the shine of sweat on his skin, his long, sardonic, and unrevealing face.

en: I ought to have done that with Luke, paid more attention, to the details, the moles and scars, the singular creases; I didn't and he's fading.
vi: I should have done that with Luke before, paid more attention, to every detail, moles and scars, to every wrinkle; I didn't know and you faded away.
tr: I should have done this with Luke too, paying more attention to the details, the moles and spots, the odd lines; but I didn't, and now he's fading away.
es: I should have done the same with Luke, paid more attention to the details, the moles and scars, his wrinkles; I didn't, and now his image is starting to fade.

en: Day by day, night by night he recedes, and I become more faithless.
vi: Day by day, night by night you withdrew, and I became more distrustful.
tr: Day by day, night by night, he's disappearing, and I am becoming more unfaithful.
es: It fades day by day, night by night, and I become more unfaithful.

en: For this one I'd wear pink feathers, purple stars, if that were what he wanted; or anything else, even the tail of a rabbit.
vi: For this person, I would wear pink feathers, purple star beads, if you asked; anything, even a rabbit's tail.
tr: I would wear pink feathers, purple stars, if that was what he wanted; or anything else, even a rabbit's tail.
es: For this man, I would put on pink feathers, purple stars, if he wanted; or anything else, even a rabbit's tail.

en: But he does not require such trimmings.
vi: But he doesn't care for such frills.
tr: However, he doesn't need such decorations.
es: But he does not demand those adornments from me.

en: We make love each time as if we know beyond the shadow of a doubt that there will never be any more, for either of us, with anyone, ever.
vi: We make love each time as if there were no doubt that there would never be another time, for him or me, with anyone else, forever.
tr: Every time we make love, it's as if we both know, without the slightest doubt, that there will never be another time with anyone else, ever again.
es: We make love each time as if we knew without the slightest shadow of a doubt that there would be no other occasion, for either of us, with anyone, ever.

en: And then when there is, that too is always a surprise, extra, a gift.
vi: And when the next time comes, it is always a surprise, an extra gift, a present.
tr: And then, when a new time comes, it is always a surprise, an extra, a blessing for us.
es: And when the next occasion arrives, it is always a surprise, an extra thing, a gift.

en: Being here with him is safety; it's a cave, where we huddle together while the storm goes on outside.
vi: Here with you is a safe haven, a dark cave, for us to curl up together while the storm rages outside.
tr: It's safe to be here with him; while the storm rages outside, we huddle together in a nook.
es: Being here with him is being safe; it’s like a cave where we huddle while the storm rages outside.

en: This is a delusion, of course.
vi: This is self-deception, of course.
tr: This is an illusion, no doubt.
es: It’s an illusion, of course.

en: This room is one of the most dangerous places I could be.
vi: This room is the most dangerous place in the world for me.
tr: One of the most dangerous places I could be is this room.
es: This room is one of the most dangerous places I could be.

en: If I were caught there would be no quarter, but I'm beyond caring.
vi: If caught, don't expect any mercy, but now I don't care.
tr: If I were caught there, they would show no mercy, but I've already crossed the threshold of caring.
es: If they caught me, they wouldn’t give me any quarter, but I don’t care.

en: And how have I come to trust him like this, which is foolhardy in itself?
vi: But how did I come to trust you so much, even that is foolish?
tr: And how did I come to trust him so much, isn't this a kind of wild bravery in itself?
es: And how have I come to trust him in this way, which is reckless in itself?

en: How can I assume I know him, or the least thing about him and what he really does?
vi: How could I think I understand you, understand anything about you or your true actions?
tr: How can I pretend to know him or the slightest thing about him and what he really does?
es: How can I assume that I know him, even minimally, and that I know what he’s really doing?

en: I dismiss these uneasy whispers.
vi: I chase away those restless whispers.
tr: I dispel these restless whispers.
es: I overlook these annoying whispers.

en: I talk too much.
vi: I talk too much.
tr: I talk too much.
es: I talk too much.

en: I tell him things I shouldn't.
vi: I tell everything that shouldn't be told.
tr: I tell him things I shouldn't tell.
es: I tell him things I shouldn't tell him.

en: I tell him about Moira, about Ofglen; not about Luke though.
vi: I talk about Moira, about Ofglen; though I don't mention Luke.
tr: I talk about Moira, about the one from Glen; though I don't talk about Luke.
es: I talk to him about Moira, about Deglen; but never about Luke.

en: I want to tell him about the woman in my room, the one who was there before me, but I don't.
vi: I want to talk about the woman in the room too, my predecessor, but I don't.
tr: I want to mention the woman in my room to him, the woman who was there before me, but I don't.
es: I want to tell him about the woman in my room, the one who was here before me, but I don't.

en: I'm jealous of her.
vi: I am jealous of her.
tr: I am jealous of that woman.
es: I'm jealous of her.

en: If she's been here before me too, in this bed, I don't want to hear about it.
vi: If she also preceded me here, on this bed, I don't want to know about it.
tr: If she was here before me, in this bed, I don't want to hear it.
es: If she was here before me, in this bed, I don't want to know.

en: I tell him my real name, and feel that therefore I am known.
vi: I even revealed my real name, feeling that I was known because of it.
tr: I tell her my real name and from then on, I feel known.
es: I tell him my real name and from that moment on, I feel recognized.

en: I act like
vi: I acted like a fool.
tr: I am acting like a fool.
es: I act like a fool and I know I shouldn't do it.

en: a dunce.
vi: I acted like a fool.
tr: I am acting like a fool.
es: I act like a fool and I know I shouldn't do it.

en: I should know better.
vi: I should have been wiser.
tr: I should have acted more wisely.
es: I act like a fool and I know I shouldn't do it.

en: I make of him an idol, a cardboard cutout.
vi: I turned him into a god statue, into a shadow cutout.
tr: I am turning her into an idol, a cardboard silhouette.
es: I've turned him into an idol, a cardboard cutout.

en: He on the other hand talks little: no more hedging or jokes.
vi: On the contrary, he spoke very little: no more beating around the bush or joking.
tr: But he speaks little: he no longer makes convoluted remarks or jokes.
es: He, for his part, speaks little: neither evasive answers nor jokes.

en: He barely asks questions.
vi: He hardly asked anything.
tr: He barely asks questions.
es: He barely asks questions.

en: He seems indifferent to most of what I have to say, alive only to the possibilities of my body, though he watches me while I'm speaking.
vi: He seemed indifferent to most of what I said, only becoming animated at the potential of my body, although he did observe when I spoke.
tr: He seems indifferent to most of what I have to say, as if only sensitive to the possibilities my body offers, yet he watches me while I speak.
es: He seems indifferent to most of the things I tell him and only shows interest in the possibilities of my body, although when I speak he looks at me.

en: He watches my face.
vi: He observed my facial expressions.
tr: He watches my face.
es: Looks me in the face.

en: Impossible to think that anyone for whom I feel such gratitude could betray me.
vi: It is unimaginable that someone I know so well could betray me.
tr: It is not possible to think that someone for whom I have such a feeling of gratitude could betray me.
es: It is impossible for me to think that someone for whom I feel so much gratitude could betray me.

en: Neither of us says the word love, not once.
vi: Neither of them mentioned the word love, not even once.
tr: Neither of us utters the word love, not even once.
es: Neither of them utters the word love, not even once.

en: It would be tempting fate;
vi: It would be tempting fate; it would be playing a romantic game, courting bad luck.
tr: It would be defying fate: it would be romance, bad luck.
es: It would be tempting fate; it would mean romance, and misfortune.

en: it would be romance, bad luck.
vi: It would be tempting fate; it would be playing a romantic game, courting bad luck.
tr: It would be defying fate: it would be romance, bad luck.
es: It would be tempting fate; it would mean romance, and misfortune.

en: Today there are different flowers, drier, more denned, the flowers of high summer: daisies, black-eyed Susans, starting us on the long downward slope to fall.
vi: Today there are different flowers, drier, sharper, summer's peak flowers: white daisies, coneflowers - the black-eyed Susans, marking the beginning of the long slope down to autumn.
tr: Today there are different flowers, drier, more distinct, warm summer flowers: daisies, yellow daisies similar to ox-eye daisies, surprising us on the long and sloping road going downwards.
es: Today there are different flowers, drier, more defined, they are the flowers of midsummer: daisies and rudbeckias, which grow along the descending slope.

en: I see them in the gardens, as I walk with Ofglen, to and fro.
vi: I see through the gardens, while walking beside Ofglen, going and coming back.
tr: I see them in the gardens, while walking up and down with Gleninki.
es: I see them in the gardens as I walk back and forth with Deglen.

en: I hardly listen to her, I no longer credit her.
vi: I almost don't hear her, I don't trust her anymore.
tr: I don't pay much attention to what they say, I don't trust them anymore.
es: I barely listen to her; I no longer believe her.

en: The things she whispers seem to me unreal.
vi: Her whispered words seem unreal.
tr: The things they whisper to me seem unreal.
es: The things she tells me seem unreal.

en: What use are they, for me, now?
vi: What use are they, to me, now?
tr: What use are they to me now?
es: What meaning do they have for me now?

en: You could go into his room at night, she says.
vi: She can enter his room at night, she said.
tr: You can enter his room at night, he says.
es: You could enter his room at night, whisper.

en: Look through his desk.
vi: Search the desk thoroughly.
tr: Rummage through his desk.
es: And look at his desk.

en: There must be papers, notations.
vi: There must be documents, records.
tr: There should be documents, notes.
es: There must be papers, notes.

en: The door is locked, I murmur.
vi: The door is locked, I muttered.
tr: The door is locked, I mutter.
es: The door is locked, I explain to him.

en: We could get you a key, she says.
vi: We found the key, she said.
tr: We can find you a key, he says.
es: We can get you a key, he says.

en: Don't you want to know who he is, what he does?
vi: Don't you want to know who he is, what he does?
tr: Don't you want to know who he is, what he does?
es: Don't you want to know who it is, what they do?

en: But the Commander is no longer of immediate interest to me.
vi: But the Commander-in-Chief no longer holds my primary interest.
tr: However, the Commander is no longer a source of false interest for me.
es: But the Commander no longer represents an immediate interest to me.

en: I have to make an effort to keep my indifference towards him from showing.
vi: I struggled to avoid revealing that I was no longer interested in him.
tr: I have to make an effort not to show my indifference towards him.
es: I have to make an effort so that my indifference towards him is not noticeable.

en: Keep on doing everything exactly the way you were before, Nick says.
vi: Just act the same as before, in everything, Nick said.
tr: Continue doing everything exactly as you did before, says Nick.
es: Keep doing everything exactly as you have been, Nick advises me.

en: Don't change anything.
vi: Don't change anything at all.
tr: Don't change anything.
es: Don't change anything; otherwise, they would notice.

en: Otherwise they'll know.
vi: Otherwise, they will know.
tr: Otherwise, they will understand.
es: Don't change anything; otherwise, they would notice.

en: He kisses me.
vi: He kissed me, looking at me the whole time.
tr: He kisses me, constantly watching me.
es: He kisses me, looking at me the whole time.

en: watching me all the time.
vi: He kissed me, looking at me the whole time.
tr: He kisses me, constantly watching me.
es: He kisses me, looking at me the whole time.

en: Promise?
vi: Promise?
tr: Promise?
es: Promised?

en: Don't slip up.
vi: No slip-ups.
tr: Don't make a mistake.
es: Don't mess it up.

en: I
vi: I placed his hand on my belly.
tr: I place my hand on my belly.
es: He placed his hand on my belly.

en: I put his hand on my belly.
vi: I placed his hand on my belly.
tr: I place my hand on my belly.
es: He placed his hand on my belly.

en: It's happened, I say.
vi: It's there, I said.
tr: It's done, I say.
es: It has happened, I announce.

en: I feel it has.
vi: I can feel it.
tr: I feel that it's done.
es: I can feel it.

en: A couple of weeks and I'll be certain.
vi: In a few more weeks, it will be certain.
tr: In two weeks, I will be sure.
es: A couple more weeks and I will be sure.

en: This I know is wishful thinking.
vi: This I know is just trying to believe in what I hope for.
tr: I am aware that this is my own wishful thinking.
es: I know it is an illusion.

en: He'll love you to death, he says.
vi: He will love her to death, he said.
tr: The commander will love you until he dies, he says.
es: He will be delighted with you, she tells me, And so will she.

en: So will she.
vi: She will too.
tr: So will Serena.
es: He will be delighted with you, she tells me, And so will she.

en: But it's yours, I say.
vi: But it is your child, I said.
tr: But I say, it's you.
es: But it's yours, I tell him.

en: It will be yours, really.
vi: It will be your child, really.
tr: It will be from you, truly.
es: It will be yours, truly.

en: I want it to be.
vi: I want that.
tr: I want it to be that way.
es: I want it to be.

en: We don't pursue this, however.
vi: However, we do not discuss further.
tr: We are not after this, though.
es: In any case, it is not our aspiration.

en: I can't, I say to Ofglen.
vi: I give up, I tell Ofglen.
tr: I can't do it, I tell Gleninki.
es: I can't, I tell Deglen.

en: I'm too afraid.
vi: I'm very scared.
tr: I'm very scared.
es: I'm very scared.

en: Anyway I'd be no good at that, I'd get caught.
vi: Anyway, I'm not good at this, I'll get caught.
tr: Besides, I wouldn't be able to do it; I'd get caught.
es: Besides, I wouldn't do it well, they would catch me.

en: I scarcely take the trouble to sound regretful, so lazy have I become.
vi: I don't even bother to put on a suit of regret anymore, I've become too lazy.
tr: I'm not really bothering to look unhappy; I've become that lazy.
es: I don't even bother to look distressed, that's how far my laziness goes.

en: We could get you out, she says.
vi: We will rescue you, she said.
tr: We can take you outside, he says.
es: We could get you out, he insists.

en: We can get people out if we really have to, if they're in danger.
vi: We can rescue if we must, if someone is in danger.
tr: If we are really obligated, we can take people outside, if they are in danger.
es: We can get people out if it's really necessary, if they are in danger, in imminent danger.

en: Immediate danger.
vi: That urgent danger.
tr: In imminent danger.
es: We can get people out if it's really necessary, if they are in danger, in imminent danger.

en: The fact is that I no longer want to leave, escape, cross the border to freedom.
vi: The fact is that I no longer want to leave, escape, or cross the border to freedom.
tr: The truth is, I no longer want to leave, escape, or cross the border to freedom.
es: The thing is that I no longer want to leave, nor escape, nor cross the border towards freedom.

en: I want to be here, with Nick, where I can get at him.
vi: I want to stay here, with Nick, in the place where he is still by my side.
tr: Here, where I can reach him, I want to be with Nick.
es: I want to stay here, with Nick, where I can be with him.

en: Telling this, I'm ashamed of myself.
vi: Talking about this, I feel ashamed.
tr: I feel ashamed of myself while telling this.
es: When I say this, I am ashamed of myself.

en: But there's more to it than that.
vi: But that's not all.
tr: But there is more to it than that.
es: But that is not all.

en: Even now, I can recognize this admission as a kind of boasting.
vi: Up until now, I still realize that admitting it is also a form of bragging.
tr: Even now, I realize that this acceptance is a kind of boasting.
es: Even now, I acknowledge that this confession is a kind of boast.

en: There's pride in it, because it demonstrates how extreme and therefore justified it was, for me.
vi: It is also a form of pride, as it shows how serious that connection is and how justified it is to me.
tr: There is pride in it because it reveals how extreme and justified it is for me.
es: There is something of pride in it, because it shows the extremity of the situation and, therefore, justifies it.

en: How well worth it.
vi: How much it is worth exchanging for.
tr: How much it was worth it.
es: It is well worth it.

en: It's like stories of illness and near-death, from which you have recovered; like stories of war.
vi: Just like when people talk about a near-death illness they recovered from; or about a battle.
tr: It resembles stories about the diseases you have recovered from and the deadly situations you have escaped; war stories.
es: It is like the story of an illness from which you have recovered after being on the brink of death; like war stories.

en: They demonstrate seriousness.
vi: Affirming the gravity of the situation.
tr: These kinds of stories exhibit seriousness.
es: They demonstrate a certain gravity.

en: Such seriousness, about a man, then, had not seemed possible to me before.
vi: Considered as important as that, a man, I had never imagined before, would exist.
tr: In that case, such seriousness in a man had never seemed possible to me before.
es: It had not seemed possible to me such seriousness regarding a man.

en: Some days I was more rational.
vi: There are days when I am more rational.
tr: Some days I was more rational.
es: Sometimes it was more rational.

en: I did not put it, to myself, in terms of love.
vi: I do not describe myself in terms of love.
tr: I wasn't putting it into words of love, for my own sake.
es: I never thought of it in terms of love.

en: I said, I have made a life for myself, here, of a sort.
vi: I say, I have created a life for myself here, almost like this.
tr: I was telling myself that I was building a life for myself here, a kind of life.
es: I thought: here, in a way, I have made my life on my own.

en: That must have been what the settlers' wives thought, and women who survived wars, if they had a man.
vi: Surely this thought must have come to the wives of pioneers, and women escaping from war, if they found a man.
tr: This must have been the thought of immigrant blood and of women who survived wars, if they still had a man, of course.
es: That must have been what the wives of the colonizers thought, and the women who survived the wars, if they still had a man.

en: Humanity is so adaptable, my mother would say.
vi: Humanity is incredibly adaptable, my mother would surely say.
tr: Human beings get used to everything, my mother used to say.
es: Humanity is very adaptable, my mother used to say.

en: Truly amazing, what people can get used to, as long as there are a few compensations.
vi: How astonishing it is to see what people can get used to, as long as there is some compensation.
tr: As long as there are a few things to fill the void, it’s truly surprising what people can get used to.
es: It is truly surprising how many things people can get used to as long as there is some compensation.

en: It won't be long now, says Cora, doling out my monthly stack of sanitary napkins.
vi: It won't be long now, Cora said, on the day of the monthly sanitary pad distribution.
tr: It won't take very long, says Cora, while giving me my monthly sanitary pad ration.
es: It won't be long now, comments Cora, arranging my sanitary cloths for this month into a pile.

en: Not long now, smiling at me shyly but also knowingly.
vi: Not long now, she smiled at me shyly but knowingly.
tr: It won't take long, she says, smiling shyly but understandingly.
es: Not long, and she smiles at me with a shy yet cunning expression.

en: Does she know?
vi: Do you know?
tr: Does she know?
es: Does she know?

en: Do she and Rita know what I'm up to, creeping down their stairs at night?
vi: Do you and Rita know what I do, sneaking up their stairs every night?
tr: Are she and Rita aware of what I do, sneaking down the stairs at night?
es: Do she and Rita know what I do, know that at night I go down the stairs they use?

en: Do I give myself away, daydreaming, smiling at nothing, touching my face lightly when 1 think they aren't watching?
vi: Have I exposed myself, when daydreaming, when smiling aimlessly, when lightly touching my lips thinking they wouldn't see?
tr: Am I giving myself away, smiling lost in dreams, lightly touching my face when I think they aren't looking?
es: Could I have given myself away daydreaming, smiling at any little thing, touching my face gently when I think they aren't looking?

en: Ofglen is giving up on me.
vi: Ofglen has let me go.
tr: Gleninki is also losing hope in me.
es: Deglen is starting to give up on me.

en: She whispers less, talks more about the weather.
vi: She whispers less, talks more about the weather.
tr: She whispers less and talks more about trivial things.
es: She whispers less and talks more about the weather.

en: I do not feel regret about this.
vi: I don't feel regret.
tr: That's why I don't feel regret.
es: I don't regret it.

en: I feel relief.
vi: I feel light.
tr: What I feel is relief.
es: I feel relieved.
CHAPTER 42

en: The bell is tolling; we can hear it from a long way off.
vi: The bell tolled; from afar we could also hear it.
tr: The bell is ringing, we can hear its sound from quite a distance.
es: The bells are tolling; they sound quite far away.

en: It's morning, and today we've had no breakfast.
vi: It was morning, and we hadn't been given breakfast this morning.
tr: It's morning, we haven't had breakfast yet.
es: It's morning, and today we haven't had breakfast.

en: When we reach the main gate we file through it, two by two.
vi: At the main gate, we lined up in pairs to pass through.
tr: When we reach the main gate, we walk in line, two by two.
es: Upon reaching the main door, we went out in rows of two.

en: There's a heavy contingent of guards, special-detail Angels, with riot gearthe helmets with the bulging dark Plexiglas visors that make them look like beetles, the long clubs, the gas-canister gunsin cordon around the outside of the Wall.
vi: A whole crowded guard squad, the Special Angel unit, in riot gear - protective helmets, black acrylic face shields that made them look like beetles, long batons, air guns - stood blocking the outer perimeter of the Wall.
tr: There is a regiment of guards and special-duty Angels, equipped for riot control - helmets with dark visors that make them look like insects, long batons, tear gas launchers - they have formed a cordon outside the Wall.
es: There is a thick contingent of guards, specially appointed Angels, with riot gear —helmets with dark plexiglass visors that give them the appearance of beetles, long batons, gas canisters— forming a cordon around the outside of the Wall.

en: That's in case of hysteria.
vi: The room went mad.
tr: This is for a riot situation.
es: All this is in case of any instances of hysteria.

en: The hooks on the Wall are empty.
vi: The hooks on the Wall were all empty.
tr: The hooks on the Wall are empty.
es: The hooks on the Wall are empty.

en: This is a district Salvaging, for women only.
vi: Today's redemption is at the district level, only women attend.
tr: This is a regional Liberation Ritual, only for women.
es: This is a local Salvaging, only for women.

en: Salvagings are always segregated.
vi: Redemption always has boundaries.
tr: Liberation Rituals are always conducted separately.
es: The Salvagings are always separate.

en: It was announced yesterday.
vi: It was just announced yesterday.
tr: It was reported yesterday.
es: This one was announced yesterday.

en: They tell you only the day before.
vi: They only announce one day in advance.
tr: They announce it just one day before.
es: They don't announce it until a day before.

en: It's not enough time, to get used to it.
vi: Not enough time to get used to it.
tr: There isn't enough time to get accustomed to it.
es: It's little time to get used to it.

en: To the tolling of the bell we walk along the paths once used by students, past buildings that were once lecture halls and dormitories.
vi: Following the sound of the bell, we walked along the path marked by the footprints of students, past the buildings that once were lecture halls and dormitories.
tr: Walking towards the sound of the bell, we pass by the buildings that once housed lecture halls and dormitories, along the paths once used by students.
es: We advance towards where the bells are ringing, along the paths that were once used by students, and pass by buildings that were once classrooms and dormitories.

en: It's very strange to be in here again.
vi: Being here again feels truly strange.
tr: It's very strange to be here again.
es: It feels very strange to be here again.

en: From the outside you can't tell that anything's changed, except that the blinds on most of the windows are drawn down.
vi: From the outside, you can't tell anything has changed, except that almost all the windows have their blinds drawn.
tr: From the outside, you couldn't say this or that has changed, except for the shutters being down on most of the windows.
es: Seen from the outside, anyone would say that nothing has changed, except that the blinds on most of the windows are down.

en: These buildings belong to the Eyes now.
vi: Those buildings now belong to the Eye.
tr: These buildings now belong to the Eyes.
es: Now, these buildings belong to the Eyes.

en: We file onto the wide lawn in front of what used to be the library.
vi: We followed in line onto the wide lawn in front of the building that used to be a library.
tr: We walk in a line towards the wide lawn in front of the building that used to be a library.
es: We march in a line across the wide meadow, in front of what used to be the library.

en: The white steps going up are still the same, the main entrance is unaltered.
vi: The white steps leading up were still intact, the main door unchanged.
tr: The white stairs leading up are still the same, the main entrance has not been closed.
es: The white staircase remains the same, and the main entrance remains unchanged.

en: There's a wooden stage erected on the lawn, something like the one they used every spring, for commencement, in the time before.
vi: A wooden stage had sprung up on the grass, just as it did every spring, for the graduation ceremonies of the past.
tr: There is a wooden stage set up on the lawn, similar to what they used to use for the Graduation Ceremony every spring in the previous era.
es: On the grass, they have erected a wooden platform, similar to the one they used to set up every spring for the Diploma Award Ceremony, years ago.

en: I think of hats, pastel hats worn by some of the mothers, and of the black gowns the students would put on, and the red ones.
vi: I remembered the hats, the light-colored hats on the heads of some mothers, the black gowns for the students to wear, and the red ones too.
tr: Hats come to mind, pastel-colored hats worn by some mothers, black capes worn by students, and red capes.
es: I think about the hats that some of the mothers wore and the black gowns the students put on, and the red ones.

en: But this stage is not the same after all, because of the three wooden posts that stand on it, with the loops of rope.
vi: But this stage, in the end, was not the same as before, because of the addition of three wooden columns with loops of rope.
tr: However, this stage is not the same at all, because of the three wooden poles standing on it with nooses hanging from them.
es: But after all, this platform is not the same; the difference lies in the three wooden posts on top, and the rope loops.

en: At the front of the stage there is a microphone; the television camera is discreetly off to the side.
vi: In front of the stage is a microphone, with the television camera modestly set aside.
tr: There is a microphone in front of the cream; the television camera is cautiously turned to another side.
es: At the front of the stage, there is a microphone; the television camera is discreetly placed to one side.

en: I've only been to one of these before, two years ago.
vi: I've only attended this event once, two years ago.
tr: I had attended only one of these, two years ago.
es: So far, I have only been to one of these events, two years ago.

en: Women's Salvagings are not frequent.
vi: Redeeming women is not seen very often.
tr: The Women's Liberation Ceremony is not held frequently.
es: Women's Salvations are not frequent.

en: There is less need for them.
vi: It's needed less now.
tr: There is less and less need for them.
es: They are not so necessary.

en: These days we are so well behaved.
vi: These days, we are so well-behaved.
tr: These days we are very well-behaved.
es: In these times, we behave very well.

en: I don't want to be telling this story.
vi: I don't want to tell this story.
tr: I do not want to tell this story.
es: I don't want to tell this story.

en: We take our places in the standard order: Wives and daughters on
vi: We took our places in the usual order:
tr: We take our places in the standard arrangement: Wives and daughters sit on foldable wooden chairs placed towards the back, Econowives and Marthas are in the corners and on the library stairs, while Handmaids are at the front, in a place where everyone can observe us.
es: We take our places in the usual order: the Wives and daughters on the wooden folding chairs set up at the back, the Econowives and the Marthas on the sides and on the steps of the library, and the Handmaids at the front, where everyone can keep an eye on us.

en: the folding wooden chairs placed towards the back, Econowives and Marthas around the edges and on the library steps, and Handmaids at the front, where everyone can keep an eye on us.
vi: The Lady and her daughter, folding wooden chairs at the back, The Frugal Wife and Martha around the edge of the grass and on the steps, and The Maidservant in the front row, for all to see.
tr: We take our places in the standard arrangement: Wives and daughters sit on foldable wooden chairs placed towards the back, Econowives and Marthas are in the corners and on the library stairs, while Handmaids are at the front, in a place where everyone can observe us.
es: We take our places in the usual order: the Wives and daughters on the wooden folding chairs set up at the back, the Econowives and the Marthas on the sides and on the steps of the library, and the Handmaids at the front, where everyone can keep an eye on us.

en: We don't sit on chairs, but kneel, and this time we have cushions, small red velvet ones with nothing written on them, not even Faith.
vi: We had no seats, had to kneel, and this time there were cushions, tiny ones made of red velvet, with nothing written on them, not even Faith.
tr: We do not sit on chairs but kneel, though this time we have cushions, small red velvet cushions with nothing written on them, not even Faith.
es: We do not sit on chairs but kneel, and this time we have small cushions, made of red velvet, without any inscription, not even the word Faith.

en: Luckily the weather is all right: not too hot, cloudy bright.
vi: Maybe the weather is quite nice: not too hot, cloudy but bright.
tr: By chance, the weather is good: not very hot, partly cloudy.
es: Fortunately, the weather is good: it's not too hot and the sky is clear.

en: It would be miserable kneeling here in the rain.
vi: Kneeling here in the rain would be miserable.
tr: Kneeling in the rain here would have been bad.
es: It would be unfortunate to have to be here on our knees in the rain.

en: Maybe that's why they leave it so late to tell us: so they'll know what the weather will be like.
vi: Perhaps that's why they announced it so late: to be sure about the weather.
tr: Maybe that's why they delay telling us so much: so they understand what the weather will be like.
es: Maybe that's why they announce it so late, to predict what the weather will be like.

en: That's as good a reason as any.
vi: It's as reasonable as any other reason.
tr: It's as good a reason as any that could be proposed.
es: It's as good a reason as any.

en: I kneel on my red velvet cushion.
vi: I knelt on my red velvet knees.
tr: I kneel on my red velvet cushion.
es: I kneel on my red velvet cushion.

en: I try to think about tonight, about making love, in the dark, in the light reflected off the white walls.
vi: I thought about tonight, about love, in the shadows, in the reflections on the white lime walls.
tr: I try to think about tonight, the lovemaking, in the dark, in the light reflected on the white walls.
es: I try to think about tonight, about making love in the dark while the light reflects off the white walls.

en: I remember being held.
vi: I remembered the embrace.
tr: I remember being embraced.
es: I remember doing it.

en: There's a long piece of rope that winds like a snake in front of the first row of cushions, along the second, and back through the lines of chairs, bending like a very old, very slow river viewed from the air, down to the back.
vi: A rope twisted like a snake in front of the top row of seats, running along the second row, winding back through the rows of seats, meandering like a river, very ancient, very slow, seen from the plane above, all the way to the end.
tr: There is a long rope coiling like a snake in front of the first row of cushions, passing the second row and extending between the rows of chairs at the back; it curls backward like a very old, very slow-flowing river seen from above.
es: There is a long piece of rope that sways like a snake in front of the first row of cushions, over the second, and reaches the rows of chairs, curving like a slow river seen from the air.

en: The rope is thick and brown and smells of tar.
vi: The thick brown rope emitted a strong tar odor.
tr: The rope is thick, brown, and smells of tar.
es: The rope is thick, brown in color, and smells of tar.

en: The front end of the rope runs up onto the stage.
vi: The other end extended all the way to the stage.
tr: The front end of the rope goes towards the stage.
es: The other end of the rope is on top of the stage.

en: It's like a fuse, or the string of a balloon.
vi: Like a slow-burning fuse, or a mooring line for a hot air balloon.
tr: It resembles a fuse or the ties of a balloon.
es: It looks like a fuse, or the string of a balloon.

en: On the stage, to the left, are those who are to be salvaged: two Handmaids, one Wife.
vi: On the platform, to the left, those who are redeemed today: two Maidservants, one Lady.
tr: On the stage, to the left, stand those who are to be rescued: two Handmaids and a Wife.
es: To the left of the stage are those who are going to be saved: two Handmaids and a Wife.

en: Wives are unusual, and despite myself I look at this one with interest.
vi: Having a Lady is unusual, and I couldn't stop myself from looking up in curiosity.
tr: It's not very common to see Wives, and I can't help but look at her with interest.
es: It is not common for there to be Wives, and much to my regret, I look at this one with interest.

en: I want to know what she has done.
vi: I really wanted to know what she had done.
tr: I want to know what she is doing.
es: I want to know what he has done.

en: They have been placed here before the gates were opened.
vi: They had been here before the gate opened.
tr: They were placed here before the doors were opened.
es: They have been placed here before the doors were opened.

en: All of them sit on folding wooden chairs, like graduating students who are about to be given prizes.
vi: All three sat on folding chairs, like graduates waiting to receive their awards.
tr: They are all sitting on folding wooden chairs, like students about to receive their graduation awards.
es: They are all sitting on wooden folding chairs, as if they were graduate students about to receive an award.

en: Their hands rest in their laps, looking as if they are folded sedately.
vi: Hands resting in their laps, looking as if they were clasped in serenity.
tr: Their hands rest in their laps, as if calmly clasped together.
es: They have their hands on their laps, as if they were crossed.

en: They sway a little, they've probably been given injections or pills, so they won't make a fuss.
vi: Slightly swaying, probably injected or given medication, to prevent causing a disturbance.
tr: They sway a little, perhaps they have been given an injection or a pill, so they won't cause a commotion.
es: They sway a little, probably they have been given injections or pills, so they don't cause trouble.

en: It's better if things go smoothly.
vi: Everything is better if it remains calm.
tr: It's better if everything goes smoothly.
es: It's better for things to proceed calmly.

en: Are they attached to their chairs?
vi: Were they tied to the chairs?
tr: Are they tied to their chairs, I wonder?
es: Are they tied to the chairs?

en: Impossible to say, under all that drapery.
vi: Can't tell, with all those flowing dresses.
tr: It's hard to tell while they're in all this pile of fabric.
es: With all the clothes they are wearing, it's impossible to know.

en: Now the official procession is approaching the stage, mounting the steps at the right: three women, one Aunt in front, two Salvagers in their black hoods and cloaks a pace behind her.
vi: At this moment, the delegation of officials is ascending the stage, climbing each step on the right: three women, one Aunt leading, two black-clad Redeemers following a step behind.
tr: Now the official procession is approaching the stage, they are climbing the stairs on the right side: three women, an Aunt in front, and two Guardians in black hoods and cloaks a step behind her.
es: Now the official entourage approaches the stage and climbs the steps on the right; there are three women: an Aunt who goes ahead and, one step behind, two Guardians dressed in black cloaks and hoods.

en: Behind them are the
vi: At this moment, the delegation of officials is ascending the stage, climbing each step on the right: three women, one Aunt leading, two black-clad Redeemers following a step behind.
tr: Other Aunts are coming behind them.
es: Behind them are the other Aunts.

en: other Aunts.
vi: Next are the remaining Aunts.
tr: Other Aunts are coming behind them.
es: Behind them are the other Aunts.

en: The whisperings among us hush.
vi: The murmuring among us ceases completely.
tr: The whispers among us cease.
es: The murmurs cease.

en: The three arrange themselves, turn towards us, the Aunt flanked by the two black-robed Salvagers.
vi: The trio lines up, facing us, the Aunt flanked by the two dark figures.
tr: The leading trio lines up and turns towards us, the two Guardians in black clothing flank the Aunt on either side.
es: The three women settle down and turn towards us; the Aunt is flanked by the two Guardians dressed in black.

en: It's Aunt Lydia.
vi: It's Aunt Lydia.
tr: This is Aunt Lydia.
es: It's Aunt Lydia.

en: How many years since I've seen her?
vi: How many years has it been since I last saw her?
tr: How many years has it been since I last saw her?
es: How many years had it been since I last saw her?

en: I'd begun to think she existed only in my head, but here she is, a little older.
vi: I had started to think she only existed in my mind, but here she is, looking a bit older.
tr: I had started to think she existed only in my mind, but there she is, a little older, that's all.
es: I had started to think she only existed in my imagination, but here she is, a bit older.

en: I have a good view, I can see the deepening furrows to either side of her nose, the engraved frown.
vi: From here, I can see very clearly; I notice the lines forming on either side of her nose, the frown etched into her face.
tr: My vision is good; I can see the deepening wrinkles on either side of her nose, the frown etched into her face.
es: From here I can see her perfectly, I see the deep wrinkles on the sides of her nose, the mark between her eyebrows.

en: Her eyes blink, she smiles nervously, peering to left and right, checking out the audience, and lifts a hand to fidget with her headdress.
vi: Her eyes blink, she smiles nervously, glancing left and right, gauging the audience, then raises her hand to touch the scarf on her head.
tr: She blinks her eyes, smiles nervously, glances around, assessing the audience; she raises her hand to adjust her headpiece.
es: She blinks, smiles nervously, looks attentively to the right and left examining the audience, raises a hand and fiddles with her headdress.

en: An odd strangling sound comes over the PA system: she is clearing her throat.
vi: A very strange, muffled sound escapes through the amplification system: she just cleared her throat.
tr: A strange sound comes from the Public Address system, a sound like someone being strangled: she clears her throat.
es: Through the speaker system, a strange and strangled sound reaches us: she is clearing her throat.

en: I've begun to shiver.
vi: My whole body was trembling.
tr: I started to tremble.
es: I have started to shiver.

en: Hatred fills my mouth like spit.
vi: Hatred filled my mouth like saliva.
tr: Hatred fills my mouth like saliva.
es: Hatred fills my mouth with saliva.

en: The sun comes out, and the stage and its occupants light up like a Christmas creche.
vi: The sun emerged, the stage and the crowd on it lit up like a Christmas scene.
tr: The sun is rising, the stage and those on it are bathed in light like a Christmas scene.
es: The sun rises and the stage and its occupants light up like a nativity scene.

en: I can see the wrinkles under Aunt Lydia's eyes, the pallor of the seated women, the hairs on the rope in front of me on the grass, the blades of grass.
vi: I saw the wrinkles under Aunt Lydia's eyes, the pale complexion of the three people on the chair, the strands of rope in front of me on the grass, I saw each blade of grass.
tr: I can make out the wrinkles under Aunt Lydia's eyes, the pallor of the seated women, the fringes of the rope on the grass in front of me, the blades of grass.
es: I see the wrinkles under Aunt Lydia's eyes, the pallor of the women who are sitting, the strands of the rope in front of me, the blades of grass.

en: There is a dandelion, right in front of me, the color of egg yolk.
vi: There was a dandelion, right in front of me, yolk-yellow in color.
tr: There is a dandelion flower right in front of me, the color of egg yolk.
es: Directly in front of me is a dandelion the color of an egg yolk.

en: I feel hungry.
vi: I felt hungry.
tr: I feel hunger.
es: I am hungry.

en: The bell stops tolling.
vi: The bell rang.
tr: The sound of the bell stops.
es: The bells stop ringing.

en: Aunt Lydia stands up, smooths down her skirt with both hands, and steps forward to the mike.
vi: Aunt Lydia stood up straight, smoothed her skirt with both hands, and stepped up to the microphone.
tr: Aunt Lydia stands up, straightens her skirts with both hands, and steps forward to the microphone.
es: Aunt Lydia stands up, smooths her skirt with both hands, and approaches the microphone.

en: "Good afternoon, ladies," she says, and there is an instant and earsplitting feedback whine from the PA system.
vi: “Good afternoon, ladies,” she said, and immediately the sound system responded with an ear-piercing screech.
tr: “Good afternoon, ladies,” she says, and a simultaneous and ear-piercing static comes from the Public Address system.
es: —Good afternoon, ladies —he greets, and the instant and deafening buzz of the speaker system is heard.

en: From among us, incredibly, there is laughter.
vi: Among us, unable to hold it in, laughter erupted.
tr: Amazingly, there is laughter among us.
es: It seems incredible, but among us, some laughter arises.

en: It's hard not to laugh, it's the tension, and the look of irritation on Aunt Lydia's face as she adjusts the sound.
vi: It was hard to suppress, given the tension and Aunt Lydia's furious expression as she adjusted the sound.
tr: It's hard not to laugh, caused by the tense and uncomfortable expression that appears on Aunt Lydia's face as she adjusts her voice.
es: It's hard not to laugh; it's the tension and Aunt Lydia's irritated expression while adjusting the sound.

en: This is supposed to be dignified.
vi: This was supposed to be a solemn moment.
tr: She is supposed to be dignified, though.
es: This is supposed to be something solemn—.

en: "Good afternoon, ladies," she says again, her voice now tinny and flattened.
vi: “Good afternoon, ladies,” she repeated, her voice now sharp and grating.
tr: “Good afternoon, ladies,” he says again, his voice now tinny and dull.
es: Good afternoon, ladies —she repeats, this time in a metallic and dull tone.

en: It's ladies instead of girlsbecause of the Wives.
vi: Ladies, instead of the girl, because of the Ladies.
tr: Since there are also spouses present, he says ladies instead of girls.
es: The fact that she says ladies, instead of girls, is due to the presence of the Wives—.

en: "I'm sure we are all aware of the unfortunate circumstances that bring us all here together on this beautiful morning, when I am certain we would all rather be doing something else, at least I speak for myself, but duty is a hard taskmaster, or may I say on this occasion taskmistress, and it is in the name of duty that we are here today."
vi: “I am sure we are all well aware of the unfortunate circumstances that have brought us together on this beautiful morning, at a time when I am certain we would all rather be doing something else, at least I speak for myself, but duty is a harsh taskmaster, or perhaps I should say in this case a harsh taskmistress, and it is in the name of duty that we are all here today.”
tr: “We are all, undoubtedly, aware of the unfortunate circumstances that have brought us together here on this beautiful morning, when I am sure all of us, myself included, would prefer to be doing something else. However, duty is a harsh taskmaster, or perhaps I should say taskmistress in this case, and we are here today in the name of duty.”
es: I'm sure we are all aware of the unfortunate circumstances that bring us together on this beautiful morning, and I have no doubt that we would all prefer to be doing something else, at least that's the case for me; but duty is a true tyrant, perhaps in this case, I should say tyrantess, and it is in the name of duty that we are here today.

en: She goes on like this for some minutes, but I don't listen.
vi: It continued like that for minutes, but I didn't listen.
tr: It continues like this for a few minutes, but I'm not listening.
es: She continues in this tone for a few minutes, but I don't listen to her.

en: I've heard this speech, or one like it, often enough before: the same platitudes,
vi: I had heard this play, or similar ones, too many times already: the same clichés, the same slogans, the same words: the torch lighting the future, the cradle of the race, the duty before us.
tr: I've heard enough of these or similar talks before: the same bland words, the same slogans, the same expressions: the torch of the future, the preservation of the race, the duty ahead, and so on.
es: I've heard this speech, or one like it, quite a few times: the same clichés, the same slogans, the same phrases about the torch of the future, the cradle of the race, the duty that awaits us.

en: the same slogans, the same phrases: the torch of the future, the cradle of the race, the task before us.
vi: I had heard this play, or similar ones, too many times already: the same clichés, the same slogans, the same words: the torch lighting the future, the cradle of the race, the duty before us.
tr: I've heard enough of these or similar talks before: the same bland words, the same slogans, the same expressions: the torch of the future, the preservation of the race, the duty ahead, and so on.
es: I've heard this speech, or one like it, quite a few times: the same clichés, the same slogans, the same phrases about the torch of the future, the cradle of the race, the duty that awaits us.

en: It's hard to believe there will not be polite clapping after this speech, and tea and cookies served on the lawn.
vi: It's hard to believe that after this speech there wouldn't be polite applause, and tea with biscuits served on the grass.
tr: After this speech, it's hard to believe that tea and cookies won't be served on the lawn following a light applause.
es: It's hard to believe that after this speech there won't be polite applause and tea and pastries won't be served in the garden.

en: That was the prologue, I think.
vi: This is just the prelude, I thought.
tr: This was the introduction, I think.
es: I think that was the prologue.

en: Now she'll get down to it.
vi: Now she will get to the point.
tr: Now he will get to the point.
es: Now it will get to the point.

en: Aunt Lydia rummages in her pocket, produces a crumpled piece of paper.
vi: Aunt Lydia rummaged through her bag and pulled out a crumpled piece of paper.
tr: Aunt Lydia reaches into her pocket and rummages around, pulling out a crumpled piece of paper.
es: Aunt Lydia rummages in her pocket and takes out a crumpled piece of paper.

en: This she takes an undue length of time to unfold and scan.
vi: It took her an absurdly long time to open it and skim through.
tr: Straightening it out and glancing at it takes longer than necessary.
es: It takes her an excessive amount of time to unfold it and glance at it.

en: She's rubbing our noses in it, letting us know exactly who she is, making us watch her as she silently reads, flaunting her prerogative.
vi: The piece of paper was shoved under our noses, making us understand exactly who she was, forcing us to look while she silently read, flaunting her privilege.
tr: In this way, she shoves it in our faces, making sure we understand exactly who she is, forcing us to watch her silently as she reads, flaunting her privileges.
es: It's as if she's rubbing it in our faces, letting us know exactly who she is, forcing us to watch her as she reads silently, flaunting her prerogatives.

en: Obscene, I think.
vi: Crude, I thought.
tr: Disgusting, I think.
es: This is an obscenity, I think.

en: Let's get this over with.
vi: Let's get this over with.
tr: Let's just get this over with.
es: Let's finish this once and for all.

en: "In the past," says Aunt Lydia, "it has been the custom to precede the actual Salvagings with a detailed account of the crimes of which the prisoners stand convicted.
vi: “In previous occasions,” Aunt Lydia continued, “it was customary before the main Redemption ceremony to detail the charges against these prisoners.
tr: “In the past,” says Aunt Lydia, “it became customary for a detailed account of the crimes to precede the Salvaging after the convicts were found guilty.
es: —In the past —he says— there was a custom of beginning the Salvations with a detailed report of the crimes for which the prisoners were condemned.

en: However, we have found that such a public account, especially when televised, is invariably followed by a rash, if I may call it that, an outbreak I should say, of exactly similar crimes.
vi: However, we have concluded that such public announcements, especially when broadcasted, would inevitably lead to a series of, if I may say so, more like an outbreak, of imitative sins.
tr: However, we found that such a narration in front of everyone, especially when shown on television, invariably led to a boldness, if the term is correct, actually an explosion, in committing exactly the same crimes.
es: However, we have considered that a public report of this type, especially when it is a televised event, is invariably followed by an outbreak, if I may call it that, almost a wave, I would say, of exactly the same crimes.

en: So we have decided in the best interests of all to discontinue this practice.
vi: Therefore, we have decided in the interest of all to put an end to this practice.
tr: Therefore, we decided to put an end to this practice for the good of everyone.
es: So we have decided, for the good of all, to break with this practice.

en: The Salvagings will proceed without further ado."
vi: The Redemption ceremony will proceed without any further embellishments.”
tr: The Salvaging will be conducted without further ado.”
es: The Salvations will proceed without further explanations.

en: A collective murmur goes up from us.
vi: The collective murmuring rose again.
tr: A collective murmur rises from our side.
es: A collective murmur is heard.

en: The crimes of others are a secret language among us.
vi: We considered the sins of others as a secret common language.
tr: The crimes committed by others are a secret language among us.
es: The crimes of others are a secret language among us.

en: Through them we show ourselves what we might be capable of, after all.
vi: Through that, we showed ourselves what we could still do, at least.
tr: After all, we show ourselves what we are capable of through them.
es: Through them, we show each other that, after all, we would be capable of committing them.

en: This is not a popular announcement.
vi: This announcement was not received well.
tr: It means there won't be an explanation in front of everyone.
es: It is not a popular statement.

en: But you would never know it from Aunt Lydia, who smiles and blinks as if washed in applause.
vi: But no one could tell just by looking at Aunt Lydia, smiling and blinking as if she were basking in applause.
tr: On the other hand, nothing can be understood from Aunt Lydia's stance, smiling and blinking as if being washed with applause.
es: But no one would know by looking at Aunt Lydia, who smiles and blinks, as if overwhelmed by the applause.

en: Now we are left to our own devices, our own speculations.
vi: Now we were left to our own schemes and guesses.
tr: Now we are left to our own devices, to our own speculations.
es: Now they let us fend for ourselves, to make our own speculations.

en: The first one, the one they're now raising from her chair, black-gloved hands on her upper arms: Reading?
vi: The first person, they were pulling her up from her chair, gloved hands grabbing her: Reading?
tr: The first woman, now lifted from her chair, black-gloved hands clinging to her arm: reading?
es: The first one, the one they are now lifting from her chair, hands with black gloves on the upper part of her arms: for reading?

en: No, that'sonly a hand cut off, on the third conviction.
vi: No, that would only cut off a hand, for a third offense.
tr: No, the punishment for that is cutting off hands, and that on the third offense.
es: No, it's just an amputated hand, on the third conviction.

en: Unchastity, or an attempt on the life of her Commander?
vi: Adultery, or an attempt to kill her Commander?
tr: Indecency, or an attempt on the Commander's life?
es: Infidelity, or an attempt on the life of her Commander?

en: Or the Commander's Wife, more likely.
vi: Or the Commander's Wife, more likely.
tr: Or, more precisely, on the Commander's Wife's life.
es: Or, more likely, on the life of the Commander's Wife.

en: That's what we're thinking.
vi: At least that's what we thought.
tr: These are what come to our minds.
es: That's what we are thinking.

en: As for the Wife, there's mostly just one thing they get salvaged for.
vi: As for that Wife, she almost only had one task to bring them to Redemption.
tr: As for the Wife; there is usually only one thing they are saved from.
es: As for the Wife, there is generally only one reason why they might subject her to Salvaging.

en: They can do almost anything to us, but they aren't allowed to kill us, not legally.
vi: They could treat us in almost any way, but they were not allowed to kill us. Not according to the law.
tr: Although they can do almost anything to us, they are not allowed to kill us, at least not legally.
es: They can do almost anything to us, but they are not authorized to kill us, at least not legally.

en: Not with knitting needles or garden shears, or knives purloined from the kitchen, and especially not when we are pregnant.
vi: Especially not with knitting needles or garden shears, or knives stolen from the kitchen, and especially not when we were pregnant.
tr: With a knitting needle or garden shears, if not that, a knife stolen from the kitchen, especially when we are pregnant, it is strictly forbidden for them to do this job.
es: Not with knitting needles, nor with garden shears, nor with knives stolen from the kitchen, and even less so if we are pregnant.

en: It could
vi: It could be adultery, of course.
tr: It could also be adultery, of course.
es: It could be adultery, of course.

en: be-adultery, of course.
vi: It could be adultery, of course.
tr: It could also be adultery, of course.
es: It could be adultery, of course.

en: It could always be that.
vi: There was always that possibility.
tr: It could always be that.
es: It could always be that.

en: Or attempted escape.
vi: Or plotting to escape.
tr: Or maybe he had tried to escape.
es: The escape attempt.

en: "Ofcharles," Aunt Lydia announces.
vi: "Ofcharles," Lydia said.
tr: “Charlesinki,” Aunt Lydia announces.
es: —Decharles —announces Aunt Lydia.

en: No one I know.
vi: Among the familiar faces.
tr: Not someone I know.
es: I don't know her.

en: The woman is brought forward; she walks as if she's really concentrating on it, one foot, the other foot, she's definitely drugged.
vi: The woman was brought out, she walked as if only focusing on stepping correctly, one foot after the other, a hundred percent drugged.
tr: The woman is brought forward; she walks as if she is really concentrating on the task, one step, then another: it is obvious she is sedated.
es: They make her move forward; she walks as if she is really concentrating on the task, one foot, then the other, there is no doubt that she is drugged.

en: There's a groggy off-center smile on her mouth.
vi: The corner of her mouth twisted into a dazed smile.
tr: She has a crooked drunken smile on her mouth.
es: A lopsided and weak smile forms on her mouth and she contracts one side of her face in an uncoordinated wink directed at the camera.

en: One side of her face contracts, an uncoordinated wink, aimed at the camera.
vi: One side of her face twitched, blinking involuntarily, directly at the camera.
tr: One side of her face is twitching, an irregular blink, directed at the camera.
es: A lopsided and weak smile forms on her mouth and she contracts one side of her face in an uncoordinated wink directed at the camera.

en: They'll never show it of course, this isn't live.
vi: They won't show this scene, of course, this isn't broadcast live.
tr: They will certainly never show this, it's not live broadcast.
es: Of course, they won't show it, this is not live.

en: The two Salvagers tie her hands, behind her back.
vi: Two Redeemers tied her hands behind her back.
tr: Two Guardians are tying her hands, behind her.
es: The two Guardians tie her hands behind her back.

en: From behind me there's a sound of retching.
vi: There is the sound of retching behind me.
tr: I hear retching sounds coming from somewhere behind me.
es: Someone behind me is feeling nauseous.

en: That's why we don't get breakfast.
vi: Not having breakfast is because of that.
tr: That's why we don't have breakfast.
es: That's why they don't give us breakfast.

en: "Janine, most likely," Ofglen whispers.
vi: "Janine, who else could it be," Ofglen whispered.
tr: “It's most likely Janine,” Gleninki whispers.
es: —It's probably Janine —whispers Deglen.

en: I've seen it before, the white bag placed over the head, the woman helped up onto the high stool as if she's being helped up the steps of a bus, steadied there, the noose adjusted delicately around the neck, like a vestment, the stool kicked away.
vi: I had seen beforehand, a white bag pulled over the head, the body lifted onto a high chair as if onto a bus step, held steady, the noose skillfully adjusted around the neck, like a sacrificial robe, the stone boat kicked away.
tr: I've seen this before, a white bag placed over the head, the woman is helped onto a high stool as if climbing the steps of a bus, she is fixed there, the noose is carefully adjusted around her neck like a robe, the stool is kicked away.
es: I have seen this before, the white bag placed over the head, the woman being helped to climb the high stool as if she were being helped to climb the steps of a bus, held up there, the noose delicately adjusted around her neck like a garment, and then a kick to the stool to knock it away.

en: I've heard the long sigh go up, from around me, the sigh like air coming out of an air mattress, I've seen Aunt Lydia place her hand over the mike, to stifle the other sounds coming from behind her, I've leaned forward to touch the rope in front of me, in time with the others, both hands on it, the rope hairy, sticky with tar in the hot sun, then placed my hand on my heart to show my unity with the Salvagers and my consent, and my complicity in the death of this woman.
vi: I had heard the sound of sighs rising up from all sides, like air escaping from an air mattress, I had seen Aunt Lydia place her hand over the microphone, hiding the sounds coming from behind her, I had once leaned forward to touch the rope in front of me, along with everyone else, with both hands, the rope full of fur, sticky with tar in the hot sun, had placed my hand on my left chest to show my unity with the Redeemer and my consent, and the complicity in this person's death.
tr: I hear the long sigh surrounding me, a sigh like the air escaping from an air mattress, I notice Aunt Lydia pressing her hand against the microphone to prevent the other sounds from being heard, I lean forward to touch the rope in front of me, at the same time as the others, touching it with both hands, sticky with tar melting in the hot air, the frayed rope, then I place one hand over my heart to show my unity and approval with the Rescuers, my complicity in this woman's death.
es: I have heard the prolonged sigh that rises around me, a sigh like the air from an inflatable mattress, I have seen Aunt Lydia place her hand over the microphone to muffle the sounds coming from behind her, I have leaned forward to touch along with the other women, with both hands, the rope in front of me, that hairy and sticky rope from tar because of the sun, and then I have placed my hand on my heart to show my unity with the Salvagers, my consent and my complicity in the death of this woman.

en: I have seen the kicking feet and the two in black who now seize hold of them and drag downward with all their weight.
