vi: I had seen the legs kicking, the two men in black grabbing and holding down with all their might.
tr: I see her legs kicking the air and the pair in black grabbing them and pulling down with all their strength.
es: I have seen the feet kicking and the two dressed in black grabbing them and pulling down with all their might.

en: I don't want to see it anymore.
vi: I did not want to look again.
tr: I don't want to see anymore.
es: I don't want to see it anymore.

en: I look at the grass instead.
vi: I looked at the grass.
tr: I look at the grass instead.
es: Instead, I look at the grass.

en: I describe the rope.
vi: I described the rope.
tr: I describe the rope.
es: I describe the rope.
CHAPTER 43

en: The three bodies hang there, even with the white sacks over their heads looking curiously stretched, like chickens strung up by the necks in a meatshop window; like birds with their wings clipped, like flightless birds, wrecked angels.
vi: Those three bodies hanging there, even though their heads were covered with bags, still looked strangely tense, like plucked chickens with their necks tied up in a butcher's shop, like birds with clipped wings, like birds that cannot fly, fallen angels.
tr: Three bodies are hanging there, with white bags pulled over their heads that seem oddly spread out, like chickens hanging by their necks in a butcher's window; like clipped-wing birds, flightless birds, like angels accidentally fallen to earth.
es: The three bodies hang there; with the white sacks over their heads, they seem strangely stretched, like chickens hanging by the neck in a butcher's shop window, like birds with clipped wings, like birds incapable of flying, like destroyed angels.

en: It's hard to take your eyes off them.
vi: It was impossible to take my eyes off them.
tr: It's hard to take one's eyes off them.
es: It's hard to take your eyes off them.

en: Beneath the hems of the dresses the feet dangle, two pairs of red shoes, one pair of blue.
vi: Under the hems of their skirts, their feet dangled, two pairs of red shoes, one pair blue.
tr: Feet dangle beneath the folds of the clothes, two pairs of red shoes, and one pair of blue shoes.
es: The feet dangle below the hems of the dresses, two pairs of red shoes, one pair of blue.

en: If it weren't for the ropes and the sacks it could be a kind of dance, a ballet, caught by flash-camera: midair.
vi: Remove the rope and the bags, and this could be a dance, a ballet, a snapshot caught mid-fall.
tr: If it weren't for the ropes and bags, it could be likened to a kind of dance, a ballet, caught in the flash of a camera: suspended in the air.
es: If it weren't for the ropes and the sacks, it could be some kind of dance, a ballet captured in the air by a camera.

en: They look arranged.
vi: It looked very orderly.
tr: They look as if they have been specially arranged.
es: They seem to be arranged in order.

en: They look like show biz.
vi: It looked very showbiz.
tr: They look as if they belong to the world of spectacle.
es: As if they were part of a show.

en: It must have been Aunt Lydia who put the blue one in the middle.
vi: Aunt Lydia must have placed the blue in the middle.
tr: It must be Aunt Lydia who put the one in blue there.
es: It must have been Aunt Lydia who put the one in blue in the middle.

en: "Today's Salvaging is now concluded," Aunt Lydia announces into the mike.
vi: “Today's Redemption Ceremony is now over,” Aunt Lydia announced with the microphone.
tr: “Today's Salvation Ceremony has ended,” Aunt Lydia announces from the microphone.
es: —Today's Salvaging is concluded —announces Aunt Lydia through the microphone—.

en: "But?
tr: “However...”
es: But...

en: We turn to her, listen to her, watch her.
vi: We turned to look at Aunt, listened to Aunt, admired Aunt.
tr: We turn towards her, we listen to her, we watch her.
es: We turn towards her, we listen to her, we observe her.

en: She has always known how to space her pauses.
vi: Aunt always knew how to time the moments of silence.
tr: She has always known how to use pauses.
es: She always knew where to make the pauses.

en: A ripple runs over us, a stir.
vi: A tremor passed through us, unsettling.
tr: There is a ripple among us, a commotion.
es: A murmur and a movement arise among us.

en: Something else, perhaps, is going to happen.
vi: Something else, surely, was about to happen.
tr: Maybe something else will happen.
es: Perhaps something else is going to happen.

en: "But you may stand up, and form a circle."
vi: "You girls can stand up and form a circle."
tr: “But you can stand up and form a circle.”
es: —But you must get up and form a circle —she smiles at us with a generous and munificent expression.

en: She smiles down upon us, generous, munificent.
vi: Aunt smiled at us, generously, magnanimously.
tr: He smiles at us, noble, extremely generous.
es: —But you must get up and form a circle —she smiles at us with a generous and munificent expression.

en: She is about to give us something.
vi: Aunt has something to give us.
tr: About to give us something.
es: She is about to give us something.

en: Bestow.
vi: Distribute.
tr: About to bestow a favor.
es: To grant us something—.

en: "Orderly, now."
vi: "Order, now."
tr: “Come on, be orderly.”
es: In order.

en: She is talking to us, to the Handmaids.
vi: Auntie is talking to us, the group of maidservants.
tr: He is addressing us, the Handmaids.
es: He is speaking to us, to the Handmaids.

en: Some of the Wives are leaving now, some of the daughters.
vi: Some of the ladies have left, along with a few daughters.
tr: Some Wives are leaving now, and some girls too.
es: Some of the Wives start to leave, as well as some of the daughters.

en: Most of them stay, but they stay behind, out of the way, they watch merely.
vi: Most of them stayed, but far behind, on the sidelines, just watching.
tr: Most are staying, but they stay behind, far away, merely watching.
es: Most of them stay, but in the back, apart, simply watching.

en: They are not part of the circle.
vi: They are not in the circle.
tr: They are not part of the circle.
es: They are not part of the circle.

en: Two Guardians have moved forward and are coiling up the thick rope, getting it out of the way.
vi: Two Guards have come out, now rolling up the thick rope, storing it away.
tr: Two guards stepped forward, gathering the thick rope and pulling it out from underfoot.
es: Two Guardians have advanced and are winding up the thick rope, removing it from the way.

en: Others move the cushions.
vi: A few people are gathering the pile of cushions.
tr: The others are taking the cushions.
es: Others are removing the cushions.

en: We are milling around now, on the grass space in front of the stage, some jockeying for position at the front, next to the center, many pushing just as hard to work their way to the middle where they will be shielded.
vi: We are bustling about, moving on the grass in front of the stage, some people jostling to get to the front row, right in the center, while others are pushing just as aggressively to get to the middle, shielded on all sides.
tr: Now, we are huddling together like sheep in the grassy area in front of the stage, some racing to secure a spot close to the center, while many others are making equal efforts to reach a place in the middle where they will be obscured.
es: We huddle on the grass, in front of the stage, some of us try to find a spot at the front, near the center, a few push hard enough to make their way to the center, where they will be protected.

en: It's a mistake to hang back too obviously in any group like this; it stamps you as lukewarm, lacking in zeal.
vi: Being too conspicuous in such groups is a mistake; you will be lumped in with the lukewarm, lacking fervent devotion.
tr: In any group like this, it is a clear mistake to stay at the back; it causes you to be labeled as lacking enthusiasm and uninterested.
es: It's a mistake to hesitate too much in a group like this; they label you as an unenthusiastic person lacking zeal.

en: There's an energy building here, a murmur, a tremor of readiness and anger.
vi: The heat is accumulating here, a murmur, a trembling on the verge of erupting into anger.
tr: There is a concentrated energy here, a murmur, a thrill of alertness and anger.
es: Here, there is a display of energy, a murmur, a shiver of speed and fury.

en: The bodies tense, the eyes are brighter, as if aiming.
vi: Bodies tense, eyes blazing, as if on the prowl.
tr: Bodies are tense, eyes brighter; just like taking aim.
es: Bodies tense, eyes become brighter, as if aiming at something.

en: I don't want to be at the front, or at the back either.
vi: I don't want to go to the front, nor to the back.
tr: I neither want to be in the front nor stay behind.
es: I don't want to be in front, nor behind.

en: I'm not sure what's coming, though I sense it won't be anything I want to see up close.
vi: I'm not sure what's coming, though I understand it's not something I want to see up close.
tr: I'm not sure what's ahead in line, though I sense it's not something I'd want to see up close.
es: I'm not sure what will happen, although I sense it will be something I don't want to see up close.

en: But Ofglen has hold of my arm, she tugs me with her, and now we're in the second line, with only a thin hedge of bodies in front of us.
vi: But Ofglen is holding my hand, she pulls me along with her, and now we're up to the second row, with only a small crowd in front of us.
tr: However, Glen is pulling me by the arm, and now we're in the second row, with only a thin pair of bodies in front of us.
es: But Deglen grabs me by the arm and drags me along; we position ourselves in the second line, barely protected by a thin row of bodies.

en: I don't want to see, yet I don't pull back either.
vi: I don't want to look, but I don't pull back either.
tr: I don't want to see, yet I can't pull back either.
es: I don't want to see but I don't retreat either.

en: I've heard rumors, which I only half believed.
vi: I've heard many rumors, though I only believe half of them.
tr: I had heard rumors that I half-believed.
es: I've heard rumors, but I only half believe them.

en: Despite everything I already know, I say to
vi: Despite everything I've seen, I still tell myself: they wouldn't go that far.
tr: Despite everything I've learned so far, I tell myself: they wouldn't go this far.
es: Despite everything I know, I tell myself: they won't go to that extreme.

en: myself: they wouldn't go that far.
vi: Despite everything I've seen, I still tell myself: they wouldn't go that far.
tr: Despite everything I've learned so far, I tell myself: they wouldn't go this far.
es: Despite everything I know, I tell myself: they won't go to that extreme.

en: "You know the rules for a Particicution," Aunt Lydia says.
vi: “You know the Pre-Trial rules,” Aunt Lydia said.
tr: “You know the Joint-Execution rules,” says Aunt Lydia.
es: —You know the rules of a Particicution —says Aunt Lydia—.

en: "You will wait until I blow the whistle.
vi: “You wait until I blow the whistle.
tr: “You will wait until I blow the whistle.
es: You will wait until I blow the whistle.

en: After that, what you do is up to you, until I blow the whistle again.
vi: After that, you can do whatever you want until I blow it a second time.
tr: What you do after that is up to you, until I blow the whistle again, of course.
es: After that, what you do is your business, until I blow the whistle again.

en: Understood?"
vi: Understand?”
tr: Understood?”
es: Understood?

en: A noise comes from among us, a formless assent.
vi: There was a sound from us in response, a wordless assent.
tr: A murmur arises from us, a shapeless approval.
es: A general murmur arises, a shapeless assent.

en: "Well then," says Aunt Lydia.
vi: “Here we go,” Aunt Lydia said.
tr: “Well then,” says Aunt Lydia.
es: —Well then —says Aunt Lydia.

en: She nods.
vi: She nodded.
tr: She nods, and two guards, not the ones lifting the rope, this time come out from behind the stage.
es: She nods her head and two Guardians, who are not the ones who removed the rope, approach from behind the stage.

en: Two Guardians, not the same ones that have taken away the rope, come forward now from behind the stage.
vi: Two Guardians, not the ones who had just put away the rope, came forward from behind the stage.
tr: She nods, and two guards, not the ones lifting the rope, this time come out from behind the stage.
es: She nods her head and two Guardians, who are not the ones who removed the rope, approach from behind the stage.

en: Between them they half carry, half drag a third man.
vi: They half carried, half dragged a person between them.
tr: Between them, they are half carrying, half dragging a third man.
es: Between the two of them, they almost drag another man.

en: He too is in a Guardian's uniform, but he has no hat on and the uniform is dirty and torn.
vi: This person was also wearing a Guardian’s uniform, but had lost his hat, and his clothes were torn and dirty.
tr: He is also wearing a guard's uniform, but he has no hat, and his uniform is dirty and torn.
es: This one is also dressed in a Guardian's uniform, but he is not wearing the cap and his uniform is dirty and torn.

en: His face is cut and bruised, deep reddish-brown bruises; the flesh is swollen and knobby, stubbled with unshaven beard.
vi: His face was full of cuts and bruises, the deep bruises had turned a reddish-brown; his flesh was swollen in lumps, and his unshaven beard was scraggly.
tr: His face is full of cuts and bruises, dark brick-colored bruises; his flesh is swollen and lumpy, his beard unshaven and long.
es: His face is cut and bruised, and full of reddish-purple welts; it is swollen and lumpy, and his beard is beginning to grow.

en: This doesn't look like a face but like an unknown vegetable, a mangled bulb or tuber, something that's grown wrong.
vi: It didn’t look like a face but rather some strange vegetable, a scarred root or tuber, damaged while it was growing.
tr: He looks more like an unknown vegetable than a face, a bruised onion or a gnarled root, something that grew imperfectly.
es: It doesn't look like a face, but some unknown vegetable, a shattered bulb or a tuber, something deformed.

en: Even from where I'm standing I can smell him: he smells of shit and vomit.
vi: Even from here I could smell him: the stench of feces and vomit.
tr: Even from where I am standing, I can smell him: the stench of feces and vomit.
es: Even from where I am, I can smell him: he smells of shit and vomit.

en: His hair is blond and falls over his face, spiky with what?
vi: His blond hair hung over his face, matted with something.
tr: His hair is blond and falls over his face; what could have made it so matted?
es: Some strands of blond hair fall over his face, as if something had made them stand on end.

en: Dried sweat?
vi: Dried sweat?
tr: Dried sweat?
es: Could it be dried sweat?

en: I stare at him with revulsion.
vi: I looked at him with utter disgust.
tr: I look at him with a start.
es: I stare at him fixedly, with disgust.

en: He looks drunk.
vi: He looked like a drunk.
tr: He looks like he's drunk.
es: He looks drunk.

en: He looks like a drunk that's been in a fight.
vi: He looked like a drunk who had just been in a fight.
tr: He looks like a drunk who just came out of a fight.
es: He looks like a drunk who has been in a fight.

en: Why have they brought a drunk in here?
vi: What was the point of bringing a drunk here?
tr: Why did they bring a drunk here?
es: Why would they have brought a drunk here?

en: "This man," says Aunt Lydia, "has been convicted of rape."
vi: “This man,” Aunt Lydia said, “has been convicted of rape.”
tr: “This man,” says Aunt Lydia, “has been found guilty of rape.”
es: —This man —Aunt Lydia clarifies— has been convicted of rape —her voice trembles with anger and reveals a triumphant tone—.

en: Her voice trembles with rage, and a kind of triumph.
vi: Her voice trembled with rage, and also with a sense of triumph.
tr: Her voice trembles with anger, a kind of triumph.
es: —This man —Aunt Lydia clarifies— has been convicted of rape —her voice trembles with anger and reveals a triumphant tone—.

en: "He was once a Guardian.
vi: “He was once a Guardian.
tr: “He was once a Guardian.
es: He was a Guardian.

en: He has disgraced his uniform.
vi: He has sullied his uniform.
tr: He stained his uniform.
es: He dishonored his uniform.

en: He has abused his position of trust.
vi: He has violated a position of trust.
tr: He betrayed the trust placed in him.
es: He abused his position of trust.

en: His partner in viciousness has already been shot.
vi: His accomplice in this heinous crime has been shot.
tr: His accomplice was shot dead beforehand.
es: His accomplice has already been executed.

en: The penalty for rape, as you know, is death.
vi: The punishment for rape, as you all know, is death.
tr: The penalty for rape, as you all know, is death.
es: As you know, rape is punished by death.

en: Deuteronomy 22:23-29.
vi: Deuteronomy chapter 22, verses 23 to 29.
tr: Deuteronomy, Chapter 22:23 - 2921.
es: Deuteronomy, twenty-two; verses twenty-three and twenty-nine.

en: I might add that this crime involved two of you and took place atgunpoint.
vi: I should add that this crime involved two of you and involved the use of a weapon.
tr: I can also add that this crime targeted two of you and was carried out under the threat of a weapon.
es: I must add that this crime involved two of you and was carried out at gunpoint.

en: It was also brutal.
vi: Thus, it was even more brutal.
tr: This is also something inhuman.
es: And it was brutal.

en: I will not offend your ears with any details, except to say that one woman was pregnant and the baby died."
vi: I will not go into further details to sully your ears, except to inform you that one of the two is pregnant and the child has died.”
tr: I will not hurt your ears with the details, I will only say that one of the women was pregnant and the baby died.”
es: I will not offend your ears with more details, except to say that one woman was pregnant and the baby died.

en: A sigh goes up from us; despite myself I feel my hands clench.
vi: The sighs of us prisoners rose up; unconsciously, I clenched my fist.
tr: A murmur is coming from us; I feel that I can't stop myself from clenching my fists.
es: A moan is heard among us; despite myself, I clasp my hands.

en: It is too much, this violation.
vi: This is truly outrageous, this act of coercion.
tr: This is too much, this violation.
es: This violation is excessive.

en: The baby too, after what we go through.
vi: A child too, after everything we had to go through.
tr: To also eliminate the baby, after all we've endured!
es: The baby too, after all that we endure.

en: It's true, there is a bloodlust; I want to tear, gouge, rend.
vi: Indeed, the bloodlust surged; I wanted to tear apart, smash, and shred to pieces.
tr: To be honest, there is such a thing as bloodlust; I want to tear apart, gouge out eyes, rip apart.
es: It's true, there is a craving for blood; I feel the urge to break, to tear, to destroy.

en: We jostle forward, our heads turn from side to side, our nostrils flare, sniffing death, we look at one another, seeing the hatred.
vi: We jostled each other, pushing forward, our heads turning from side to side, nostrils flaring, smelling the scent of death, we looked at each other's faces, seeing the anger.
tr: We are pushing and shoving each other forward, our heads turning this way and that, our nostrils flaring like bellows, smelling the scent of death as we look at each other, what we see is hatred.
es: We push forward, our heads turning from side to side, our nostrils flaring as we sniff out death, we look at each other to see our hatred.

en: Shooting was too good.
vi: Shooting is still humane.
tr: To hit would be a mercy.
es: He deserved something worse than death.

en: The man's head swivels groggily around: has he even
vi: The man's head sluggishly turned around: could he hear what we were saying?
tr: The man's head is spinning like a drunkard's: did he hear it?
es: The man turns his head, dazed.

en: heard her?
vi: The man's head sluggishly turned around: could he hear what we were saying?
tr: The man's head is spinning like a drunkard's: did he hear it?
es: Did he even hear it?

en: Aunt Lydia waits a moment; then she gives a little smile and raises her whistle to her lips.
vi: Aunt Lydia waited for a moment, then gave a small smile and brought the whistle to her lips.
tr: Aunt Lydia waits for a moment; then she smiles slightly and brings her whistle to her lips.
es: Aunt Lydia waits a moment; then she smiles slightly and brings the whistle to her lips.

en: We hear it, shrill and silver, an echo from a volleyball game of long ago.
vi: We all heard it, shrill as silver, echoing back from a volleyball game of years gone by.
tr: We hear its sound, sharp and silvery, an echo from a volleyball game of the distant past.
es: We hear it, shrill and pristine, an echo from a volleyball game of bygone times.

en: The two Guardians let go of the third man's arms and step back.
vi: The two guards released the man and stepped back.
tr: The two guards release the third man's arms and step back.
es: The two Guardians release the arms of the third man and step back.

en: He staggersis he drugged?
vi: He staggered - drugged, perhaps?
tr: He staggers -drugged?- and falls to his knees.
es: The man staggers —is he drugged?— and falls to his knees.

en: and falls to his knees.
vi: - then collapsed.
tr: He staggers -drugged?- and falls to his knees.
es: The man staggers —is he drugged?— and falls to his knees.

en: His eyes are shriveled up inside the puffy flesh of his face, as if the light is too bright for him.
vi: His eyes squinted within the swollen flesh on his face, as if blinded.
tr: His eyes, as if the light is too bright for him, have dried and shriveled in the swollen flesh of his face.
es: His eyes are squinted in the swollen flesh, as if the light is too bright for him.

en: They've kept him in darkness.
vi: He had been imprisoned in darkness.
tr: They have kept him in the dark.
es: They have kept him locked up in the darkness.

en: He raises one hand to his cheek, as though to feel if he is still there.
vi: He raised a hand to his cheek, as if to check if he was still there.
tr: He reaches one hand to his cheek; as if to see if it is still there.
es: He brings a hand to his cheek, as if to check if it is still there.

en: All of this happens quickly, but it seems to be slowly.
vi: Everything happened in a flash, but felt like an eternity.
tr: All of this happens quickly, but it feels slow to a person.
es: All this happens quickly, but it seems slow.

en: Nobody moves forward.
vi: No one stepped forward.
tr: Nobody is moving forward.
es: Nobody moves.

en: The women are looking at him with horror, as if he's a half-dead rat dragging itself across a kitchen floor.
vi: The women looked at him in horror, like a half-dead sewer rat dragging itself across the kitchen floor.
tr: The women are looking at him in horror; as if looking at a half-dead mouse crawling forward in the kitchen.
es: The women look at him with horror, as if he were a half-dead rat crawling across the kitchen floor.

en: He's squinting around at us, the circle of red women.
vi: He squinted his eyes, looking around at the red circle of women.
tr: He is squinting at us surrounding him, at the circle of red women.
es: He looks at us with squinted eyes, observing the circle of red women.

en: One corner of his mouth moves up, incrediblea smile?
vi: One corner of his mouth lifted, in disbelief - a smile?
tr: The corner of his mouth twitches upwards, an unbelievable thing - a smile?
es: Incredibly, one side of his mouth lifts... could it be a smile?

en: I try to look inside him, inside the trashed face, see what he must really look like.
vi: My aunt looked back, behind the shattered face, he looked really miserable.
tr: I'm trying to see inside, to find out what it should really look like inside your battered face.
es: I try to penetrate it with my gaze, to see inside the shattered face, to find out what his real appearance must be.

en: I think he's about thirty.
vi: He was approximately thirty years old.
tr: I think he's in his thirties.
es: I suppose he is around thirty years old.

en: It isn't Luke.
vi: Not Luke.
tr: Not Luke.
es: He is not Luke.

en: But it could have been, I know that.
vi: But it could have been Luke, I know.
tr: Still, it could have happened, I know this.
es: But I know it could have been him.

en: It could be Nick.
vi: It could have been Nick.
tr: It could have been Nick.
es: It could be Nick.

en: I know that whatever he's done I can't touch him.
vi: I understand that I cannot touch him no matter what he has done.
tr: No matter what he has done, I know I won't lay a hand on him.
es: I know that, regardless of what he has done, I cannot touch him.

en: He says something.
vi: He said something.
tr: He is saying something.
es: He says something.

en: It comes out thick, as if his throat is bruised, his tongue huge in his mouth, but I hear it anyway.
vi: The words came out thick, as if his throat was crushed, his tongue swollen in his mouth, but I still understood.
tr: His voice comes out muffled, as if his throat is decayed, his tongue feels too big for his mouth, yet I can still hear him.
es: His words are unclear, as if his throat were bruised, as if his tongue were too large, but I hear him anyway.

en: He says, "I didn't?
vi: He said, "I don't.."
tr: "I didn't do it..." he says.
es: He says: —I don't...

en: There's a surge forward, like a crowd at a rock concert in the former time, when the doors opened, that urgency coming like a wave through us.
vi: The crowd surged forward, like a throng at an old-time rock concert, when the doors opened, the urgent wave swept over us like a tide.
tr: There is a sudden surge forward, like the crowd at an old-time rock concert when the doors open, this necessity comes over us like a wave.
es: A movement occurs forward, as if we were a crowd at a rock concert from another time and we were waiting for the doors to open with that urgency that takes hold of us.

en: The air is bright with adrenaline, we are permitted anything and this is freedom, in my body also, I'm reeling, red spreads everywhere, but before that tide of cloth and bodies hits him Ofglen isshoving through the women in front of us, propelling herself with her elbows, left, right, and running towards him.
vi: The air boiled with blood, we were allowed to do anything and this was freedom, in my whole body, I was spinning like a whirlwind, red surged all around, but before the tide of fabric and flesh could hit him, that Ofglen had already elbowed her way through the crowd in front, thrusting her elbows up, left, right, charging straight at him.
tr: The air is charged with adrenaline, we are allowed to do anything and this is freedom itself, in my body too; I stagger drunkenly, red spreads everywhere, but this dress and body ebb and flow without hitting it, Glen's pushes the women in front of us, advancing by making way with his elbows, left, right, running towards it.
es: The air is filled with adrenaline, everything is allowed to us, this is freedom, I feel it in my body, I feel vertigo, a red stain spreads everywhere, but before the tide of clothes and bodies starts to hit him, Deglen makes her way through the women, elbowing left and right and runs towards him.

en: She pushes him down, sideways, then kicks his head viciously, one, two, three times, sharp painful jabs with the foot, well aimed.
vi: She shoved him down, toppling him over, then savagely kicked his head, once, twice, three times, each kick strong, painful, and precise.
tr: He tackles the man to the ground from the side, then hits his head hard, once, twice, three times, sharp and painful kicks, well-aimed.
es: She makes him fall sideways and furiously kicks his head, once, twice, three times, with dry and precise blows.

en: Now there are sounds, gasps, a low noise like growling, yells, and the red bodies tumble forward and I can no longer see, he's obscured by arms, fists,
vi: The sounds rose, choking sounds, a low murmur like a moan, a howl, and the red mass collapsed forward so I could no longer see, he disappeared under the arms, fists, and feet.
tr: Now there are sounds, gasping breaths, a low-pitched hum like a growl, screams, red bodies rolling forward and I can no longer see him; he disappears among the arms, fists, and feet.
es: Now there are groans, a weak sound similar to a growl, screams, and the red bodies fall forward and I can no longer see anything, he has been hidden by arms, fists, and feet.

en: feet.
vi: The sounds rose, choking sounds, a low murmur like a moan, a howl, and the red mass collapsed forward so I could no longer see, he disappeared under the arms, fists, and feet.
tr: Now there are sounds, gasping breaths, a low-pitched hum like a growl, screams, red bodies rolling forward and I can no longer see him; he disappears among the arms, fists, and feet.
es: Now there are groans, a weak sound similar to a growl, screams, and the red bodies fall forward and I can no longer see anything, he has been hidden by arms, fists, and feet.

en: A high scream comes from somewhere, like a horse in terror.
vi: A high-pitched scream from somewhere, like a frightened horse.
tr: A fierce scream comes from somewhere, the scream of a frightened horse.
es: Somewhere a howl is heard, like the terrified cry of a horse.

en: I keep back, try to stay on my feet.
vi: I stayed behind, trying to stand firm.
tr: I'm falling behind, struggling to stay on my feet.
es: I stay at a certain distance, trying to keep my balance.

en: Something hits me from behind.
vi: Something hit my back, and I staggered.
tr: Something hits me from behind.
es: Something hits me from behind and I stagger.

en: I stagger.
vi: Something hit my back, and I staggered.
tr: I stumble.
es: Something hits me from behind and I stagger.

en: When I regain my balance and look around, I see the Wives and daughters leaning forward in their chairs, the Aunts on the platform gazing down with interest.
vi: When I regained my balance and looked around, I saw the Ladies and daughters leaning forward on their seats, and the aunts on the platform looking down with delight.
tr: When I regain my balance and look around, I see the Wives and girls leaning forward in their chairs, and the Aunts on the platform looking down with interest.
es: When I regain my balance, I look around and see the Wives and daughters leaning forward in their chairs, and the Aunts watching with interest from the platform.

en: They must have a better view from up there.
vi: From up there, everything was clearer.
tr: They must have a better view from up there.
es: From up there, they must have a better perspective.

en: He has become an it.
vi: He has become that.
tr: Adam is now an object.
es: He has become that.

en: Ofglen is back beside me.
vi: Ofglen has returned to my side.
tr: Gleninki is by my side again.
es: Deglen is once again by my side.

en: Her face is tight, expressionless.
vi: Her face is closed, emotionless.
tr: His face is tense, expressionless.
es: His face is tense and expressionless.

en: "I saw what you did," I say to her.
vi: “I saw everything,” I told her.
tr: “I saw what you did,” I say to him.
es: —I saw what you did —I tell him.

en: Now I'm beginning to feel again: shock, outrage, nausea.
vi: Now the feelings are coming back: dizziness, frustration, nausea.
tr: Now I start to feel it again: shock, anger, nausea.
es: I start to feel shock, outrage, nausea again.

en: Barbarism.
vi: Barbaric.
tr: Barbarity.
es: Barbarism—.

en: "Why did you do that?
vi: “Why did you do that?
tr: “Why did you do this?
es: Why did you do it?

en: You!
vi: You!
tr: You!
es: Precisely you!

en: I thought you?
vi: I thought...”
tr: I thought that you...”
es: I thought that...

en: "Don't look at me," she says.
vi: “Don't look at me,” she said.
tr: "Don't look at me," he says.
es: —Don't look at me —he warns me—.

en: "They're watching."
vi: “They are looking.”
tr: "They are watching."
es: They are watching us.

en: "I don't care," I say.
vi: "I don't care," I said.
tr: “I don't care,” I say.
es: —I don't care —I reply.

en: My voice is rising, I can't help it.
vi: My voice rose, I couldn't help it.
tr: The tone of my voice is rising, I can't help it.
es: I'm raising my voice. I can't help it.

en: "Get control of yourself," she says.
vi: “Get a grip,” she said.
tr: “Get a grip,” he says.
es: —Control yourself —he advises me.

en: She pretends to brush me off, my arm and shoulder, bringing her face close to my ear.
vi: She pretended to brush me off, first my hands then my shoulders, leaning close to my ear.
tr: He acts like he's brushing off my clothes, brings his face close to my ear.
es: He pretends to push me away by grabbing my arm and shoulder and brings his face close to my ear—.

en: "Don't be stupid.
vi: “Don't do anything foolish.
tr: “Don't be stupid.
es: Don't be stupid.

en: He wasn't a rapist at all, he was a political.
vi: He is not a rapist, he is involved in politics.
tr: He wasn't raped or anything, he was a political prisoner.
es: He wasn't a rapist, he was a politician.

en: He was one of ours.
vi: He is a comrade.
tr: He was one of us.
es: He was one of ours.

en: I knocked him out.
vi: I will knock you out.
tr: I knocked him out.
es: I left him unconscious.

en: Put him out of his misery.
vi: Free you from this torment.
tr: I saved him from his suffering.
es: I spared him the pain.

en: Don't you know what they're doing to him?"
vi: Don't you see what they are doing to him?”
tr: Don't you know what they did to him?”
es: Don't you see what they are doing to him?

en: One of ours, I think.
vi: Comrades, I think.
tr: I think, one of us.
es: One of ours, I think.

en: A Guardian.
vi: A Guard.
tr: A guard.
es: A Guardian.

en: It seems impossible.
vi: It seems like something from the sky.
tr: This seems impossible to me.
es: It seems impossible.

en: Aunt Lydia blows her whistle again, but they don't stop at once.
vi: Aunt Lydia blew the whistle again, but they did not stop immediately.
tr: Aunt Lydia blows her whistle again, but they don't stop immediately.
es: Aunt Lydia blows the whistle again, but the women do not stop immediately.

en: The two Guardians move in, pullingthem off, from what's left.
vi: Two Guardians intervened, pulling them away from what was left.
tr: Two guards step in between them and pull them apart, whatever is left of the man, some lie on the grass where they were accidentally hit or kicked.
es: The two Guardians intervene to separate them from what remains of the man.

en: Some lie on the grass where they've been hit or kicked by accident.
vi: Some lay on the grass from the moment they were accidentally hit or kicked.
tr: Two guards step in between them and pull them apart, whatever is left of the man, some lie on the grass where they were accidentally hit or kicked.
es: Some lie on the grass as they have been hit or kicked by mistake.

en: Some have fainted.
vi: Some had fainted.
tr: Some have fainted.
es: Others have fainted.

en: They straggle away, in twos and threes or by themselves.
vi: They staggered away, in groups of two or three or alone.
tr: They scatter away from the herd, in pairs, threes, or alone.
es: The rest scatter in pairs, threes, or alone.

en: They seem dazed.
vi: All seemed dazed.
tr: They look mesmerized.
es: They seem dazed.

en: "You will find your partners and re-form your line," Aunt Lydia says into the mike.
vi: “You will find your partners and straighten up into pairs,” Aunt Lydia said into the microphone.
tr: “Find your partners and form a line again,” says Aunt Lydia through the microphone.
es: —Find your partner and form a line —orders Aunt Lydia through the microphone.

en: Few pay attention to her.
vi: Hardly anyone paid attention.
tr: Very few people pay attention to her.
es: A few obey her.

en: A woman comes towards us, walking as if she's feeling her way with her feet, in the dark: Janine.
vi: Someone walked towards me, stepping as if feeling their way in the dark: Janine.
tr: One of the women is coming towards us, as if finding her way in the dark by feeling with her feet: Janine.
es: A woman approaches us, walking as if groping in the dark: it is Janine.

en: There's a smear of blood across her cheek, and more of it on the white of her headdress.
vi: A bloodstain on her cheek, more blood on the white cloth.
tr: There is a bloodstain along her chin, and even more on her headdress.
es: She has a bloodstain on her face and some more on the white part of her headdress.

en: She's smiling, a bright diminutive smile.
vi: She was smiling, a bright and fresh smile.
tr: She smiles, a bright little smile.
es: She gives us a tiny smile.

en: Her eyes have come loose.
vi: Her eyes were vacant.
tr: Her eyes are glazed over.
es: Her gaze is lost.

en: "Hi there," she says.
vi: "Hello," she said.
tr: “Hello,” he says.
es: —Hello —he greets—.

en: "How are you doing?"
vi: "How are you all?"
tr: “How are you?”
es: How are you?

en: She's holding something,
vi: She was holding something very tightly in her right hand.
tr: He is holding something tightly in his right hand.
es: —he holds something with his right hand.

en: tightly, in her right hand.
vi: She was holding something very tightly in her right hand.
tr: He is holding something tightly in his right hand.
es: —he holds something with his right hand.

en: It's a clump of blond hair.
vi: A tuft of blonde hair.
tr: It is a tuft of yellow hair.
es: It's a lock of blonde hair.

en: She gives a small giggle.
vi: She giggled.
tr: He giggles softly.
es: He laughs foolishly.

en: "Janine," I say.
vi: "Janine," I said.
tr: “Janine,” I say.
es: —Janine —I say to her.

en: But she's let go, totally now, she's in free fall, she's in withdrawal.
vi: But she had given up, completely, she was in free fall, she had retreated.
tr: However, she has let herself go, now entirely, in free fall, retreating into her shell.
es: But now she lets herself go completely, as if in free fall, in an attitude of abandonment.

en: "You have a nice day," she says, and walks on past us, towards the gate.
vi: “Have a nice day,” she said, and left us, heading towards the gate.
tr: “I wish you a good day,” he says and walks past us, towards the door.
es: —Have a good time —she says and walks past us, heading towards the entrance.

en: I look after her.
vi: I watched her.
tr: Then I look back.
es: I watch her.

en: Easy out, is what I think.
vi: Escaping was too easy, I thought so.
tr: The thing I thought was that it was an easy way out.
es: Be careful, I think.

en: I don't even feel sorry for her, although I should.
vi: I didn't even feel pity, though I should have.
tr: Even though it was necessary, I don't even feel sadness for him.
es: I don't even feel sorry for her, although I should.

en: I feel angry.
vi: I was angry.
tr: I feel anger.
es: I feel rage.

en: I'm not proud of myself for this, or for any of it.
vi: I'm not proud of this, or anything today.
tr: I'm not proud of myself for this, or for other things.
es: I'm not proud of it, nor of any of this.

en: But then, that's the point.
vi: Oh but, that's the main thing.
tr: However, that was the situation at the time.
es: But that's what matters.

en: My hands smell of warm tar.
vi: My hand smells of tar.
tr: My hands smell of hot tar.
es: My hands smell like hot tar.

en: I want to go back to the house and up to the bathroom and scrub and scrub, with the harsh soap and the pumice, to get every trace of this smell off my skin.
vi: I want to go back to that house, straight to the bathroom to scrub and rub, using pumice stone and coarse soap, to completely remove this smell from my skin.
tr: I want to go back home, go up to the bathroom, and scrub, scrub, scrub my body with hard soap and pumice stone to remove every trace of this smell from my skin.
es: I want to go back home and go up to the bathroom and scrub myself over and over again with the hard soap and pumice stone to remove any trace of this smell from my skin that makes me feel sick.

en: The smell makes me feel sick.
vi: The smell makes me want to vomit.
tr: This smell makes me sick.
es: I want to go back home and go up to the bathroom and scrub myself over and over again with the hard soap and pumice stone to remove any trace of this smell from my skin that makes me feel sick.

en: But also I'm hungry.
vi: But I am still hungry.
tr: At the same time, I am hungry.
es: And I am also hungry.

en: This is monstrous, but nevertheless it's true.
vi: It's disgusting, but it's the truth.
tr: This is a disgusting thing, but nevertheless, it is true.
es: It seems monstrous, but nevertheless it is true.

en: Death makes me hungry.
vi: Death makes me hungry.
tr: Death makes me hungry.
es: Death makes me feel hungry.

en: Maybe it's because I've been emptied; or maybe it's the body's way of seeing to it that I remain alive, continue to repeat its bedrock prayer: I am, I am.
vi: Maybe because I have been drained, or maybe in this way my body confirms that it is still alive, continuing to repeat the cradle prayer: I live, I live.
tr: Maybe it's because I am emptied; or it is the body's way of dealing with my survival, continuing to repeat its fundamental prayer: I exist, I exist.
es: Maybe it's because I have been left empty; or maybe it's my body's way of proving that I am alive, and I keep repeating like a prayer: I am, I am.

en: I am, still.
vi: I am, still, alive.
tr: I exist, still.
es: I am still here.

en: I want to go to bed, make love, right now.
vi: I want to go to bed, make love, immediately.
tr: I want to get into bed, make love, right now.
es: I want to go to bed and make love, right now.

en: I think of the word relish.
vi: I think of the word delicious.
tr: Appetite, the word sticks in my mind.
es: I think about the word fruition.

en: I could eat a horse.
vi: I can swallow an entire elephant.
tr: I can even sweep away a horse.
es: I could eat a horse.
CHAPTER 44

en: Things are back to normal.
vi: Everything has returned to normal.
tr: Things have returned to normal.
es: Things have returned to normal.

en: How can I call this normal?
vi: How can this be called normal?
tr: How can I call it normal?
es: How can I call this normality?

en: But compared with this morning, it is normal.
vi: But compared to this morning, this is very normal.
tr: Still, compared to this morning, it's normal.
es: Although compared to this morning, it is normal.

en: For lunch there was a cheese sandwich, on brown bread, a glass of milk, celery sticks, canned pears.
vi: Lunch consists of a cheese sandwich, made with brown bread, a cup of milk, chopped celery, and canned pears.
tr: For lunch, there was a cheese sandwich made with brown bread, a glass of milk, celery, and canned pears.
es: For lunch, they gave me a sandwich with brown bread and cheese, a glass of milk, some celery stalks, and canned pears.

en: A schoolchild's lunch.
vi: Lunch is a packed meal at school.
tr: A student's meal.
es: A school lunch.

en: I ate everything up, not quickly, but reveling in the taste, the flavors lush on my tongue.
vi: I eat everything, not in a hurry, but savoring each item, the flavors rising on my tongue.
tr: I finished eating everything, not quickly, but savoring the taste, a medley of flavors on my tongue.
es: I ate it all, not very quickly, but savoring the abundance of flavors with my tongue.

en: Now I am going shopping, the same as usual.
vi: Now it's time to go shopping, as usual.
tr: Now I'm going shopping, the usual task.
es: Now I will go shopping, as usual.

en: I even look forward to it.
vi: I'm actually looking forward to it.
tr: I'm even looking forward to it.
es: I almost look forward to that moment eagerly.

en: There's a certain consolation to be taken from routine.
vi: Daily routines are somewhat comforting.
tr: There is a certain comfort to be taken from routine.
es: In a way, it is a comfort to break the routine.

en: I go out the back door, along the path.
vi: I went out the back door, following the path for cars.
tr: I'm exiting through the back door, along the path.
es: I go out the back door and walk along the path.

en: Nick is washing the car, his hat
vi: Nick was washing the car, his hat tilted to one side.
tr: Nick is washing the car, his hat tilted to one side.
es: Nick is washing the car and wearing his cap sideways.

en: on sideways.
vi: Nick was washing the car, his hat tilted to one side.
tr: Nick is washing the car, his hat tilted to one side.
es: Nick is washing the car and wearing his cap sideways.

en: He doesn't look at me.
vi: He did not look at me.
tr: He's not looking at me.
es: He doesn't look at me.

en: We avoid looking at each other, these days.
vi: We avoid looking at each other these days.
tr: These days, we avoid looking at each other.
es: Now we try not to look at each other.

en: Surely we'd give something away by it, even out here in the open, with no one to see.
vi: If not, it would surely reveal something, even in the middle of an empty space, with no one looking.
tr: Surely, we could reveal something, here, in the open, even when there's no one to see.
es: Surely we would be discovered, even here in the open air, where no one sees us.

en: I wait at the corner for Ofglen.
vi: I arrive at the corner of the street to wait for Ofglen.
tr: I'm waiting for Gleninki at the corner.
es: I stop at the corner to wait for Deglen.

en: She's late.
vi: Today she is late.
tr: He's late.
es: She is running late.

en: At last I see her coming, a red and white shape of cloth, like a kite, walking at the steady pace we've all learned to keep.
vi: Finally, I see her, a figure in red and white cloth, like a kite, walking steadily as we have all been taught.
tr: Finally, I see him coming, in the form of a red and white dress, like a kite, walking with the orderly steps we've all learned to follow.
es: Finally, I see her coming, a silhouette of red and white clothing, like a kite, walking with a steady pace, just as we have been taught.

en: Isee her and notice nothing at first.
vi: I look at her, at first noticing nothing.
tr: I see him and at first, I don't notice anything.
es: I see her and at first, I don't notice anything.

en: Then, as she comes nearer, I think that there must be something wrong with her.
vi: Then, as she gets closer, I think something seems off about her.
tr: Then, as he gets closer, I think there must be something strange about him.
es: But as she gets closer, I realize that something is not right.

en: She looks wrong.
vi: Her shape is off.
tr: He looks wrong.
es: She looks strange.

en: She is altered in some indefinable way; she's not injured, she's not limping.
vi: She has changed, in a way that can't be named; she is not injured, not limping.
tr: Transformed in an indescribable way; not injured, not limping either.
es: She has changed in an undefined way; she is not hurt nor limping.

en: It's as if she has shrunk.
vi: It looks like she has shrunk.
tr: As if he were shriveled.
es: It's as if she had shrunk.

en: Then when she's nearer still I see what it is.
vi: Then, as I got closer, I understood what it was.
tr: Then, when it gets really close, I understand what it is.
es: When I have her closer, I realize.

en: She isn't Ofglen.
vi: She was not Ofglcn.
tr: This is not Glen's.
es: It's not Deglen.

en: She's the same height, but thinner, and her face is beige, not pink.
vi: She was just as tall, but thinner, and her face was more yellow, not rosy.
tr: It's the same height but thinner, and its face is not pink but straw-colored.
es: She has the same height, but she is thinner, and her face is beige instead of pink.

en: She comes up to me, stops.
vi: She came to me and stopped.
tr: It comes towards me and stops.
es: She approaches me and stops.

en: "Blessed be the fruit," she says.
vi: “Bless the fruits,” she said.
tr: “May God bless the fruit,” he says.
es: —Blessed be the fruit —she greets me.

en: Straight-faced, straight-laced.
vi: Stern and upright.
tr: Face-wall, lace-upright.
es: Unflappable. Sanctimonious.

en: "May the Lord open," I reply.
vi: “Pray for the Blessed One to grant birth,” I replied.
tr: “May God clear your way,” I reply.
es: —And may the Lord allow it to open —I replied.

en: I try not to show surprise.
vi: My aunt did not show any surprise.
tr: I try to show surprise.
es: I try not to reveal my astonishment.

en: "You must be Offred," she says.
vi: “You must be Offred,” she said.
tr: “You must be Fredinki,” he says.
es: —You must be Offred —he says to me.

en: I say yes, and we begin our walk.
vi: I said yes, and we started walking.
tr: Yes, I say, and we start walking.
es: I respond affirmatively and we start walking.

en: Now what, I think.
vi: What now, I thought.
tr: What will happen now, I wonder.
es: And now?, I think.

en: My head is churning, this is not good news, what has become of her, how do I find out without showing too much concern?
vi: My head was spinning, not a good sign, how was she, how to know dipc085 without appearing overly concerned?
tr: My head is spinning. This is not good news, what happened to him, how can I find out without seeming too interested?
es: My head is spinning, this doesn't mean anything good, what could have happened to her, how to find out without showing too much of my concern?

en: We aren't supposed to form friendships, loyalties, among one another.
vi: People did not expect us to form bonds of friendship, loyalty.
tr: We must not form friendships or attachments with each other.
es: We cannot create friendships or loyalties among us.

en: I try to remember how much time Ofglen has to go at her present posting.
vi: I tried to remember how much longer Ofglen had in her current term.
tr: I'm trying to remember how much longer Gleninki needs to stay in his current assignment.
es: I try to remember how long Deglen had to stay in her current assignment.

en: "We've been sent good weather," I say.
vi: “We have been blessed with beautiful weather,” I said.
tr: “God has sent us beautiful weather,” I say.
es: —We have very good weather —I commented.

en: "Which I receive with joy."
vi: “I am immensely grateful.”
tr: “I welcome it with happiness.”
es: —What fills me with joy —it is a calm, monotonous, expressionless voice.

en: The voice placid, flat, unrevealing.
vi: The voice was calm, steady, and restrained.
tr: His voice is gentle, flat, non-revealing.
es: —What fills me with joy —it is a calm, monotonous, expressionless voice.

en: We pass the first checkpoint without saying anything further.
vi: We passed the first checkpoint without saying anything more.
tr: Without saying anything else, we pass the first checkpoint.
es: We passed through the first checkpoint without saying anything more.

en: She's taciturn, but so am I.
vi: She was sparing with her words, but so was I.
tr: He remains silent, but so do I.
es: She appears taciturn, but so do I.

en: Is she waiting for me to start something, reveal myself, or is she a believer, engrossed in inner meditation?
vi: Was she waiting for me to start, to reveal myself, or was she a devotee, immersed in prayer?
tr: Is he waiting for me to start something, to reveal myself, or is he a believer, someone lost in inner contemplation?
es: Is she waiting for me to start talking, to reveal myself, or is she a believer absorbed in meditation?

en: "Has Ofglen been transferred, so soon?"
vi: "Has Ofglen moved away already, so soon?"
tr: “Was Gleninki transferred this quickly?” I ask, knowing well that it wasn't so.
es: —Has Deglen been transferred? So soon?

en: I ask.
vi: I asked.
tr: “Was Gleninki transferred this quickly?” I ask, knowing well that it wasn't so.
es: —I ask, knowing she hasn't been transferred.

en: But I know she hasn't.
vi: But I knew it wasn't true.
tr: “Was Gleninki transferred this quickly?” I ask, knowing well that it wasn't so.
es: —I ask, knowing she hasn't been transferred.

en: I saw her only this morning.
vi: I just saw her this morning.
tr: I saw him just this morning.
es: I saw her this morning.

en: She would have said.
vi: If there was, she would have said.
tr: If that were the case, he would have told me.
es: She would have told me.

en: "I am Ofglen," the woman says.
vi: “I am Ofglen,” the other said.
tr: “Gleninki is mine,” says the woman.
es: —I am Deglen —the woman replies.

en: Word perfect.
vi: Perfectly word for word.
tr: The expression is flawless.
es: I know it perfectly well.

en: And of course she is, the new one, and Ofglen, wherever she is, is no longer Ofglen.
vi: And of course, that is her name, while Ofglen, wherever she is, is no longer Olglen.
tr: And undoubtedly she is right, the new one, Gleninki, wherever it is, is no longer Gleninki.
es: Of course she is, she's the new one; and Deglen, wherever she is, is no longer Deglen.

en: I never did know her real name.
vi: I never knew her real name.
tr: I had never learned its real name.
es: I never knew her real name.

en: That is how you can get lost, in a sea of names.
vi: One can disappear like that, amidst a sea of names.
tr: This is how you get lost, in the sea of names.
es: This is how you can lose yourself in a sea of names.

en: It wouldn't be easy to find her, now.
vi: It's no longer easy to find her.
tr: It is not easy to find it now.
es: Now it wouldn't be easy to find her.

en: We go to Milk and Honey, and to All Flesh, where I buy chicken and the new Ofglen gets three pounds of hamburger.
vi: We went to Milk and Honey, then to Flesh and Bone, I bought chicken and the new Ofglen got ground beef, one and a half pounds, still the same long lines as always.
tr: We stop by Milk and Honey and All Kinds of Meats, I get chicken, the new Gleninki gets a kilo and a half of hamburger.
es: We go to Milk and Honey, and to All Meat, where I buy a chicken and the new Deglen gets a kilo of hamburgers.

en: There are the usual lines.
vi: We went to Milk and Honey, then to Flesh and Bone, I bought chicken and the new Ofglen got ground beef, one and a half pounds, still the same long lines as always.
tr: The usual lines are there.
es: There's a line, as usual.

en: I see several women I recognize, exchange with them the infinitesimal nods with which we show each otherwe are known, at least to someone, we still exist.
vi: I met a few acquaintances, exchanged minimal nods to signal to each other that we are still known, at least to one or two people, that we still exist.
tr: I see a few women I know, we nod our heads at each other with the vaguest of movements, thus showing that we recognize each other, that we still exist, at least to someone.
es: I see several women I recognize and exchange with them the infinitesimal nods with which we mutually show that we know each other, at least to someone, that we still exist.

en: Outside All Flesh I say to the new Ofglen, "We should go to the Wall."
vi: Coming out of Flesh and Bone, I said to the new Ofglen, “We should go by the Wall.”
tr: Outside All Kinds of Meats, I say to the new Gleninki, "We should go to the Wall."
es: When we leave All Meat, I say to the new Deglen:

en: I don't know what I expect from this; some way of testing her reaction, perhaps.
vi: I don't know why I said that; perhaps as a way to test her reaction.
tr: I don't know what I'm expecting from this; possibly, a way to gauge her reaction.
es: —We should go to the Wall —I don't know what I'm trying to achieve with this; maybe to find a way to test her reaction.

en: I need to know whether or not she is one of us.
vi: I needed to know if she was one of us.
tr: I feel the need to find out if she is one of us.
es: I need to know if she is one of us or not.

en: If she is, if I can establish that, perhaps she'll be able to tell me what has really happened to Ofglen.
vi: If she was, if I could confirm it, maybe she could tell me what really happened to Ofglen.
tr: If so, and if I can determine this, maybe she can tell me what really happened to Gleninki.
es: If it is, if I can prove it, maybe she can tell me what really happened to Deglen.

en: "As you like," she says.
vi: “Up to you,” she said.
tr: "As you wish," he says.
es: —As you wish —he/she accepts.

en: Is that indifference, or caution?
vi: Was that indifference, or caution?
tr: Is this indifference or caution?
es: Is it indifference or caution?

en: On the Wall hang the three women from this morning, still in their dresses, still in their shoes, still with the white bags over their heads.
vi: On the Wall of Shame this morning, the three women were still in the same clothes, still the same shoes, still with white bags over their heads.
tr: This morning, three women are hanging on the Wall, still in their clothes, with white bags still and still placed over their heads.
es: On the Wall hang the three women from this morning, still wearing their dresses and with white bags on their heads.

en: Their arms have been untied and are stiff and proper at their sides.
vi: Their hands had been untied, hanging stiffly and properly by their sides.
tr: Their arms untied, hanging stiffly and neatly at their sides.
es: Their arms have been untied, now hanging stiffly at the sides of their bodies.

en: The blue one is in the middle, the two red ones on either side, though the colors are no longer as bright; they seem to have faded, grown dingy, like dead butterflies or tropical fish drying on land.
vi: The middle one was blue, the ones on either side were red, though no longer bright; it seemed they had faded, dulled, like dead butterflies, or tropical fish dried up on land.
tr: The one in blue in the middle, the two in red on either side, although the colors are no longer that bright; they look faded, dull, like dead butterflies or tropical fish drying on the ground.
es: The one in blue is in the middle and the two in red are on the sides, but the colors are no longer so bright; they seem to have faded, dulled, like dead butterflies or like a tropical fish that starts to dry out on the sand.

en: The gloss is off them.
vi: Their glossy sheen was gone.
tr: Their gilding has worn off.
es: They have lost their shine.

en: We stand and look at them in silence.
vi: We stood silently watching.
tr: We stand and watch them silently.
es: We observe them in silence.

en: "Let that be a reminder to us," says the new Ofglen finally.
vi: "Let's look at that and remember," finally said Ofglen.
tr: "Let this be a lesson to us," says the new Gleninki at last.
es: —Let this serve as a warning to us —pronounces the new Deglen finally.

en: I say nothing at first, because I am trying to make out what she means.
vi: At first, I did not respond, as I had not yet figured out what she meant.
tr: At first, I say nothing; because I am trying to understand what he means.
es: At first, I say nothing because I try to decipher what she means.

en: She could mean that this is a reminder to us of the unjust-ness and brutality of the regime.
vi: It could mean to remember the injustice and cruelty of this regime.
tr: For us, he might have wanted to say that this regime's injustice and brutality serve as a lesson.
es: She could mean that it is a warning about the injustice and brutality of the regime.

en: In that case I ought to say yes.
vi: If so, I should say yes.
tr: In that case, yes, it needs to be said.
es: In that case, I would have to answer yes.

en: Or she could mean the opposite, that we should remember to do what we are told and not get into trouble, because if we do we will be rightfully punished.
vi: Or it could be the opposite, she might be saying that we need to remember to comply with the commandments and avoid trouble, otherwise we will be duly punished.
tr: On the other hand, he might have meant the opposite; that is, we should remember what we were told and not get ourselves into trouble, because if we do, we will be rightfully punished.
es: Or she could mean the opposite, that we should do what we are told and not get into trouble, because if we don't, we will receive just punishment.

en: If she means that, I should say praise be.
vi: If that is her intention, I should say amen.
tr: If that is what he means, what I need to say is, thank goodness.
es: If she means this, I should answer "praised be".

en: Her voice was bland, toneless, no clues there.
vi: Her voice was smooth, without tone, without clues.
tr: His voice is soft and toneless, no clues at all.
es: But her voice was soft, expressionless, it did not provide me with any clues.

en: I take a chance.
vi: I took a risk.
tr: I'm trying my luck.
es: I take the risk and respond to him:

en: "Yes," I say.
vi: "Yes," I said.
tr: “Yes,” I say.
es: —Yes.

en: To this she does not respond, although I sense a flicker of white at the edge of my vision, as if she's looked quickly at me.
vi: There was no reply, though I noticed a flicker of white in the corner of my eye, as if she had glanced quickly over.
tr: It doesn't respond to this, but I feel a white flicker at the corner of my eye, as if it had quickly looked at me.
es: She doesn't answer me, but I perceive a white flash, as if she had quickly turned to look at me.

en: After a moment we turn away and begin the long walk back, matching our steps in the approved way, so that we seem to be in unison.
vi: A moment later, we turned back and began the long journey home, matching our steps in unison to show uniformity.
tr: A moment later, we turn around and start walking the long way back; we synchronize our steps accordingly, so we appear united.
es: A moment later, we set out on the long journey back, coordinating our steps as established so that it appears we are acting in unison.

en: I think maybe I should wait before attempting anything further.
vi: I think maybe we should wait before going any further.
tr: Before going any further, I think I might need to wait.
es: I think that maybe it would be better to wait before making a new attempt.

en: It's too soonto push, to probe.
vi: It's still not the time to question or investigate.
tr: It's too early to push, to probe.
es: It is too soon to insist, to probe.

en: I should give it a week, two weeks, maybe longer, watch her carefully, listen for tones in her voice, unguarded words, the way Ofglen listened to me.
vi: I need to spend a week, two weeks, maybe longer, observing her carefully, listening to her tone, her careless words, like Ofglen listened to me before.
tr: I should give it a week, two weeks, maybe even more, I should watch him carefully, listen to the tones in his voice, the unguarded words, just like Gleninki listened to me.
es: I should wait a week, two weeks maybe more and observe her closely, listen to the tones of her voice, the imprudent words, just as Deglen listened to me.

en: Now that Ofglen is gone I am alert again, my sluggishness has fallen away, my body isno longer for pleasure only but senses its jeopardy.
vi: Now that Ofglen is gone, I am cautious again, the lethargy has vanished, my body no longer serves for pleasure but senses danger within it.
tr: Now that Gleninki is gone, I'm on alert again, my laziness has vanished, my body is no longer just for pleasure, it also senses the dangers that might come.
es: Now that Deglen is gone, I am alert again, my laziness has disappeared, my body no longer just experiences pleasure, but I perceive the danger it entails.

en: I should not be rash, I should not take unnecessary risks.
vi: I must not be hasty, must not take risks unless necessary.
tr: I shouldn't be hasty, I shouldn't take unnecessary risks.
es: I must not rush or take unnecessary risks.

en: But I need to know.
vi: But I have to know.
tr: However, I need to know.
es: But I need to know.

en: I hold back until we're past the final checkpoint and there are only blocks to go, but then I can no longer control myself.
vi: I restrained myself through the last checkpoint and only a few blocks remained, but then I couldn't control myself anymore.
tr: I hold myself back until I pass the last checkpoint, and with only a few blocks left to go, that's when I can no longer control myself.
es: I hold myself back until we pass the last checkpoint, only a few blocks remain, and then I lose my temper.

en: "I didn't know Ofglen very well," I say.
vi: "I don't know Ofglen very well," I said.
tr: "I didn't know Gleninki very well," I say.
es: —I didn't know Deglen very well —I comment—.

en: "I mean the former one."
vi: "She relied on me before."
tr: "I mean the one before you."
es: I mean the first one.

en: "Oh?" she says.
vi: "Really?" she replied.
tr: “Yes?” he says.
es: —No? —he asks.

en: The fact that she's said anything, however guarded, encourages me.
vi: She had opened her mouth to answer, no matter how guarded, which emboldened me.
tr: The fact that he has said something, no matter how cautiously, encourages me.
es: The fact that he has responded, albeit cautiously, encourages me.

en: "I've only known her since May," I say.
vi: “I just met her in May,” I said.
tr: “I’ve only known him since May,” I say.
es: —I've only known her since May —I continued.

en: I can feel my skin growing hot, my heart speeding up.
vi: I felt my skin heat up, my heart pounding.
tr: I can feel my skin tightening and my heart racing.
es: I feel my skin burning and my heart racing.

en: This is tricky.
vi: This matter is somewhat tricky.
tr: This is deceitful.
es: This is delicate.

en: For one thing, it's a lie.
vi: First of all, it’s a lie.
tr: For one, it's a lie.
es: On one hand, it is a lie.

en: And how do I get from there to the next vital word?
vi: Then how to get from there to the next crucial word?
tr: Besides, how will I transition to the next crucial point from here?
es: And now how do I get to the vital word?—.

en: "Around the first of May I think it was.
vi: “Around the first of May, I think.
tr: “I think it was around the first of May.
es: I think it was around the first of May.

en: What they used to call May Day."
vi: It used to be called May Day.”
tr: What they used to call May Day.”
es: What they used to call May Day.

en: "Did they?" she says, light, indifferent, menacing.
vi: “Really?” she said, lightly, indifferently, threateningly.
tr: “Is that what they used to say?” he says, lightly, indifferently, threateningly.
es: —Oh, really? —he responds in a weak, indifferent, threatening tone—.

en: "That isn't a term I remember.
vi: “I don't remember that word.
tr: “It's not an expression I remember.
es: I don't remember that expression.

en: I'm surprised you do.
vi: It's surprising that you remember it.
tr: I'm actually surprised you remember it.
es: I'm surprised you remember it.

en: You ought to make an effort?
vi: You should put in the effort...” she paused.
tr: You must have made an effort...”
es: You should make an effort... —he pauses— ... to eliminate such... —another pause— ... resonances from your mind.

en: She pauses.
vi: You should put in the effort...” she paused.
tr: He pauses.
es: You should make an effort... —he pauses— ... to eliminate such... —another pause— ... resonances from your mind.

en: "To clear your mind of such?
vi: “To clear your mind of all sorts of...”
tr: “To clear your mind...”
es: You should make an effort... —he pauses— ... to eliminate such... —another pause— ... resonances from your mind.

en: She pauses again.
vi: She paused again.
tr: He pauses again.
es: You should make an effort... —he pauses— ... to eliminate such... —another pause— ... resonances from your mind.

en: "Echoes."
vi: “Echoes.”
tr: “Of such reflections.”
es: You should make an effort... —he pauses— ... to eliminate such... —another pause— ... resonances from your mind.

en: Now I feel cold, seeping over my skin like water.
vi: The cold came, spreading across my skin like water.
tr: I feel the cold seeping through my skin like water now.
es: I feel the cold springing up on my skin as if it were water.

en: What she is doing is warning me.
vi: It was her warning me.
tr: What it does is warn me.
es: What he says is a warning.

en: She isn't one of us.
vi: She does not belong to the group.
tr: Not one of us.
es: She is not one of ours.

en: But she knows.
vi: But she knows.
tr: But knows.
es: But she knows.

en: I walk the last blocks in terror.
vi: I walked to the end of the row of houses in horror.
tr: I am walking the last blocks in terror.
es: I walk the last blocks dominated by terror.

en: I've been stupid, again.
vi: I did something foolish again.
tr: I did something stupid again.
es: Once again, I have acted like a fool.

en: More than stupid.
vi: Not just foolish.
tr: Even worse.
es: More than a fool.

en: It hasn't occurred to me before, but now I see: if Of-glen's been caught, Ofglen may talk, about me among others.
vi: This is something I had never realized before, but now I see: if Ofglen has been caught, Ofglen might talk, about me as well as others.
tr: It hadn't occurred to me before, but now it hits me: if Glen's been caught, he might talk, in front of others, about me too.
es: It didn't occur to me before, but now I realize: if Deglen has been discovered, she might talk about other people and also about me.

en: She will talk.
vi: She will talk.
tr: He will talk.
es: And she will talk.

en: She won't be able to help it.
vi: She won't be able to bear it.
tr: He can't do otherwise.
es: She won't be able to avoid it.

en: But I haven't done anything, I tell myself, not really.
vi: But I haven't done anything yet, I told myself, nothing really.
tr: But I didn't do anything, I say to myself, in the true sense.
es: But in reality, I haven't done anything, I tell myself.

en: All I did was know.
vi: It's all just what I know.
tr: All I did was know.
es: All I have done is know.

en: All I did was not tell.
vi: It's all just what I don't say.
tr: All I did was not inform.
es: All I have done is not speak.

en: They know where my child is.
vi: They know where my child is.
tr: They know where my child is.
es: They know where my little one is.

en: What if they bring her, threaten something to her, in front of me?
vi: What if they bring the child, threaten to do something to them, right in front of me?
tr: But what if they bring them and threaten to do something, right in front of me?
es: And if they bring her and threaten her in my presence?

en: Or do it.
vi: Or actually do it.
tr: But what if they do?
es: And if they do something to her?

en: I can't bear to think what they might do.
vi: I don't dare to think what could happen next.
tr: I can't bear to think about what they might do.
es: I can't bear to think what they could do to her.

en: Or Luke, what if they have Luke.
vi: Or Luke, if they already have Luke.
tr: And what if Luke, if Luke is in their hands?
es: Or Luke, what if they have Luke?

en: Or my mother or
vi: Or my mother or Moira or almost anyone.
tr: And what about my mother, Moira, or anyone else, for that matter?
es: Or my mother, or Moira, or anyone.

en: Moira or almost anyone.
vi: Or my mother or Moira or almost anyone.
tr: And what about my mother, Moira, or anyone else, for that matter?
es: Or my mother, or Moira, or anyone.

en: Dear God, don't make me choose.
vi: God, don't make me choose.
tr: Oh God, don't make me choose.
es: My God, don't make me choose.

en: I would not be able to stand it, I know that; Moira was right about me.
vi: I wouldn't be able to face it, I know that; Moira was right about me.
tr: I couldn't endure it, I know; Moira was right.
es: I know I couldn't bear it; Moira was right about me.

en: I'll say anything they like, I'll incriminate anyone.
vi: I would say whatever they want, I would accuse anyone.
tr: I'll say whatever they want, I'll blame everyone.
es: I'll say whatever they want, I'll betray anyone.

en: It's true, the first scream, whimper even, and I'll turn to jelly, I'll confess to any crime, I'll end up hanging from a hook on the Wall.
vi: Indeed, just one scream, one uncontrollable sob, I would crumble, I would confess to every crime, I would go up dangling on the Wall's hook.
tr: That's the truth, at the first scream, even the first moan, I'll turn to jelly, I'll confess to any crime, my end will be hanging on a hook on the Wall.
es: It's true, at the first scream, even at the first moan, I'll be shattered, I'll confess to any crime and end up hanging from a hook on the Wall.

en: Keep your head down, I used to tell myself, and see it through.
vi: Keep your head down, I often tell myself, and endure to the end.
tr: Keep your head down, I used to tell myself, and don't get caught.
es: Keep your head down, I used to tell myself, and understand it.

en: It's no use.
vi: It's useless.
tr: It's no use.
es: It doesn't make sense.

en: This is the way I talk to myself, on the way home.
vi: I kept discussing with myself like that, along the way home.
tr: I was talking to myself like this, on the way home.
es: This is what I tell myself as we return home.

en: At the corner we turn to one another in the usual way.
vi: At the corner of the street, we turned to each other as usual.
tr: In the corner, we turn to each other in a familiar way.
es: Upon reaching the corner, we positioned ourselves face to face, as usual.

en: "Under His Eye," says the new, treacherous Ofglen.
vi: "In His eyes," the new, uncertain Ofglen said.
tr: “God protect us,” says the new, unreliable Gleninki.
es: —May His Gaze accompany you —says the new and treacherous Deglen in farewell.

en: "Under His Eye," I say, trying to sound fervent.
vi: "In his eyes," I said, she appeared enthusiastic.
tr: "God bless," I say, trying to appear enthusiastic.
es: —May His Gaze accompany you —I respond, trying to appear devout.

en: As if such playacting could help, now that we've come this far.
vi: As if acting would make a difference, when we had reached this point.
tr: As if acting so pretentiously would work, we had come to this point now.
es: As if, now that we've reached this point, this comedy would serve any purpose.

en: Then she does an odd thing.
vi: Then she did something strange.
tr: Then she does something very strange.
es: Then he does something strange.

en: She leans forward, so that the stiff white blinkers on our heads are almost touching, so that I can see her pale beige eyes up close, the delicate web of lines across her cheeks, and whispers, very quickly, her voice faint as dry leaves.
vi: She reached out, making the stiff blindfolds on our heads almost touch, making me look closely at her pale yellow eyes, the lines across her cheeks, and whispered, quickly, lightly like dry leaves.
tr: She leans forward, so much that the stiff white visors on our heads almost touch, I can see her pale beige eyes up close, the fine web of lines on her cheeks, she whispers, in one breath, her voice dry like leaves.
es: He leans forward —in such a way that the rigid blinders on our heads are about to touch and I can see up close the pale beige color of his eyes, and the delicate network of lines that crisscross his cheeks— and whispers very quickly and in a muted tone, as if his voice were a dry leaf:

en: "She hanged herself," she says.
vi: "She hanged herself," she said.
tr: “She hanged herself,” she says.
es: —She hanged herself.

en: "After the Salvaging.
vi: "After the Redemption ceremony.
tr: “After the Salvaging Ceremony.
es: After the Salvage.

en: She saw the van coming for her.
vi: She saw the van coming for her.
tr: She saw the van that came for her.
es: She saw the van coming to take her away.

en: It was better."
vi: It was better that way."
tr: This was better.”
es: It's better this way.

en: Then she's walking away from me down the street.
vi: In an instant, she had stepped away on the sidewalk.
tr: Then, he walks away from me and down the street.
es: And he walks away from me, down the street.
CHAPTER 45

en: I stand a moment, emptied of air, as if I've been kicked.
vi: I stood for a moment, completely out of breath, as if I had just been kicked.
tr: As if kicked, my breath is taken away, I stand still for a moment.
es: Wait a moment; I'm out of breath, as if I had been kicked.

en: So she's dead, and I am safe, after all.
vi: So she is dead, and I am safe, finally.
tr: So, he is dead, and I am safe now.
es: Then she is dead and I am safe.

en: She did it before they came.
vi: She did it before they came.
tr: He did it before they arrived.
es: She did it before they arrived.

en: I feel a great relief.
vi: I feel incredibly relieved.
tr: I feel a great sense of relief.
es: I feel an enormous relief.

en: I feel thankful to her.
vi: I feel truly grateful.
tr: I feel gratitude towards him.
es: I am grateful to him/her.

en: She has died that I may live.
vi: She died so that I could live.
tr: He died so that I could live.
es: He/She has died so that I can live.

en: I will mourn later.
vi: Mourning can wait.
tr: I am postponing mourning.
es: I will regret it.

en: Unless this woman is lying.
vi: Unless this person is lying.
tr: Of course, if this woman is not lying.
es: Unless this woman is lying.

en: There's always that.
vi: There is always a possibility.
tr: This possibility always exists.
es: The possibility always exists.

en: I breathe in, deeply, breathe out, giving myself oxygen.
vi: I inhale deeply, exhale, taking in more oxygen.
tr: I breathe in deeply, then exhale, nourishing myself with oxygen.
es: I breathe deeply and release the air, providing oxygen.

en: The space in front of me blackens, then clears.
vi: The space in front of me becomes clearer, brighter.
tr: The area in front of me darkens, then clears up again.
es: Everything darkens and then clears up.

en: I can see my way.
vi: I can see the way.
tr: I can see my path.
es: Now I see where I'm walking.

en: I turn, open the gate, keeping my hand on it a moment to steady myself, walk in.
vi: I turned around, opened the gate, steadied myself for a moment, and stepped in.
tr: I turn back, holding my hand on it for a moment to gather myself, then I open the door and go inside.
es: I turn, open the door, leave my hand resting for a moment to calm myself, and enter.

en: Nick is there, still washing the car, whistling a little.
vi: There was Nick, washing the car, whistling softly.
tr: Nick is there, still washing the car, whistling softly.
es: There is Nick, still washing the car, and whistling.

en: He seems very far away.
vi: He seemed so far away.
tr: He seems very far away.
es: I have the feeling that he is very far away.

en: Dear
vi: Oh Lord, I think, I will do everything you want.
tr: Oh Great God; I think, I will do everything you want.
es: My God, I think, I will do whatever you want.

en: God, I think, I will do anything you like.
vi: Oh Lord, I think, I will do everything you want.
tr: Oh Great God; I think, I will do everything you want.
es: My God, I think, I will do whatever you want.

en: Now that you've let me off, I'll obliterate myself, if that's what you really want; I'll empty
vi: You have spared me, I will forsake myself, if you truly want that; I will empty myself, completely, will become the holy chalice.
tr: You, who have left me now, I will erase myself, if this is truly your wish; I will empty myself, truly, I will be as clean as a ritual chalice.
es: Now that you have forgiven me, I will destroy myself if that is what you truly desire; I will truly empty myself, I will become a chalice.

en: myself, truly, become a chalice.
vi: You have spared me, I will forsake myself, if you truly want that; I will empty myself, completely, will become the holy chalice.
tr: You, who have left me now, I will erase myself, if this is truly your wish; I will empty myself, truly, I will be as clean as a ritual chalice.
