es: Now that you have forgiven me, I will destroy myself if that is what you truly desire; I will truly empty myself, I will become a chalice.

en: I'll give up Nick, I'll forget about the others, I'll stop complaining.
vi: I will abandon Nick, I will forget those others, I will cease lamenting.
tr: I will give up on Nick, I will let go of the others, I will stop complaining.
es: I will give up Nick, I will forget about the others, I will stop lamenting.

en: I'll accept my lot.
vi: I will accept my fate.
tr: I will accept my fate.
es: I will accept my fate.

en: I'll sacrifice.
vi: I will dedicate myself.
tr: I will sacrifice myself.
es: I will sacrifice myself.

en: I'll repent.
vi: I will repent.
tr: I will repent.
es: I will repent.

en: I'll abdicate.
vi: I will surrender.
tr: I will leave everything.
es: I will abdicate.

en: I'll renounce.
vi: I will renounce.
tr: I will withdraw from everything.
es: I will renounce.

en: I know this can't be right but I think it anyway.
vi: I know it's really not right, but that's what I thought.
tr: I know this cannot be true, but it still crosses my mind.
es: I know this isn't fair, but I think it anyway.

en: Everything they taught at the Red Center, everything I've resisted, comes flooding in.
vi: Everything taught at the Red Center, everything I still resisted, came flooding back.
tr: Everything they taught at the Red Center, everything I resisted, is closing in on me.
es: Everything they taught us at the Red Center, everything I have resisted comes back to me like a torrent.

en: I don't want pain.
vi: I don't want to.
tr: I don't want to suffer.
es: I don't want to feel pain, I don't want to be a dancer nor have my feet in the air and my head turned into a faceless white rectangle of cloth.

en: I don't want to be a dancer, my feet in the air, my head a faceless oblong of white cloth.
vi: I don't want to be a dancer, kicking my legs up to the sky, my head wrapped in a long, faceless white cloth.
tr: I don't want to be a dancer, feet pounding the air, head a faceless rectangle of white cloth.
es: I don't want to feel pain, I don't want to be a dancer nor have my feet in the air and my head turned into a faceless white rectangle of cloth.

en: I don't want to be a doll hung up on the Wall, I don't want to be a wingless angel.
vi: I don't want to be a doll pinned to the Wall, I don't want to be a fallen angel.
tr: I don't want to be a puppet hung on the Wall, I don't want to be a wingless angel.
es: I don't want to be a doll hanging from the Wall, I don't want to be an angel without wings.

en: I want to keep on living, in any form.
vi: I want to keep living, in any form.
tr: I want to continue living, in whatever form it may be.
es: I want to keep living, no matter what.

en: I resign my body freely, to the uses of others.
vi: I voluntarily surrender my body, for others to use.
tr: I willingly give up my body, for the use of others.
es: I freely give my body for others to use.

en: They can do what they like with me.
vi: They can do whatever they want with me.
tr: They can do whatever they please with me.
es: They can do whatever they want with me.

en: I am abject.
vi: I am insignificant.
tr: I am a wretch.
es: I am an object.

en: I feel, for the first time, their true power.
vi: I felt, for the first time, their full power.
tr: I am feeling their true strength for the first time.
es: For the first time, I feel the true power that they have.

en: I go along past the flower beds, the willow tree, aiming for the back door.
vi: I moved forward through the flower beds, the willows, aiming for the back door.
tr: Heading towards the back door, I pass by the flower beds and the willow tree.
es: I walk past the flower beds and the willow tree, heading towards the back door.

en: I will go in, I will be safe.
vi: I will go in, I will be safe.
tr: I will go inside, I will be safe.
es: I will enter, I will be safe.

en: I will fall on my knees, in my room, gratefully breathe in lungfuls of the stale air, smelling of furniture polish.
vi: I will collapse to my knees, in my room, inhaling deeply the blessed foul air, faintly smelling of wood polish.
tr: I will kneel down in my room, gratefully inhaling the stale air until my lungs burst, smelling the furniture polish.
es: I will fall to my knees in my room, and I will breathe gratefully, filling my lungs with the stale air and smelling the scent of polished furniture.

en: Serena
vi: Serena
tr: Serena
es: Serena

en: Joy has come out of the front door; she's standing on the steps.
vi: Joy has gone out the front door, now she is standing on the steps.
tr: Joy has stepped out the front door; she is standing on the steps.
es: Joy is waiting on the front door steps.

en: She calls to me.
vi: She calls me.
tr: She is calling me.
es: She calls me.

en: What is it she wants?
vi: What does she want?
tr: What does she want?
es: What does she want?

en: Does she want me to go into the sitting room and help her wind gray wool?
vi: Does she want me to help roll the gray yarn in the sitting room?
tr: Does she want me to go to the living room and help wind the gray yarn?
es: Does she want me to go to the living room and help her wind the gray wool?

en: I won't be able to hold my hands steady, she'll notice something.
vi: I won't be able to keep my hands steady, she will notice.
tr: I won't be able to keep my hands steady, she will notice something.
es: I won't be able to keep my hands steady, she will notice something.

en: But I walk over to her anyway, since I have no choice.
vi: But I still walk over to her, because there is no other way.
tr: Still, I walk towards her, as I have no other choice.
es: But anyway, I approach her, I have no other choice.

en: On the top step she towers above me.
vi: At the top step, she stood, towering over me.
tr: On the upper step, he looks far superior to me.
es: He stands before me, on the last step.

en: Her eyes flare, hot blue against the shriveled white of her skin.
vi: Her eyes blazing, the blue burning brightly against the shriveled white of her skin.
tr: His eyes are blazing, a core blue against the shriveled white of his skin.
es: His eyes shine, a vivid blue in contrast with the white of his wrinkled skin.

en: I look away from her face, down at the ground; at her feet, the tip of her cane.
vi: I averted my gaze from her face, looking down at the ground; her feet, the tip of her cane.
tr: I avert my gaze from his face, directing it to the ground; to his feet, to the tip of his cane.
es: I look away from his face and gaze at the ground; next to his feet, I see the tip of the cane.

en: "I trusted you," she says.
vi: “I trusted you,” she said.
tr: “I trusted you,” he says.
es: —I trusted you —he tells me—.

en: "I tried to help you."
vi: “I tried to help you.”
tr: “I tried to help you.”
es: I tried to help you.

en: Still I don't look up at her.
vi: I still did not look up at her.
tr: I still don't lift my head to look at him.
es: I still don't look at her.

en: Guilt pervades me,I've been found out, but for what?
vi: A feeling of guilt invaded me, I had been discovered, but what for?
tr: A feeling of guilt spreads through my body, I was caught, but for what?
es: A feeling of guilt overwhelms me. They have discovered me, but what have they discovered?

en: For which of my many sins am I accused?
vi: Among my countless misdeeds, which one was being accused?
tr: For which of my countless sins was I being accused?
es: Which of my many sins am I being accused of?

en: The only way to find out is to keep silent.
vi: The only way to find out was to remain silent.
tr: The only way to understand is to remain silent.
es: The only way to find out is to remain silent.

en: To start excusing myself now, for this or that, would be a blunder.
vi: Opening my mouth to explain, this and that, would only make things worse.
tr: Now making an excuse, about this or that, would be a foolish mistake.
es: Starting to make excuses now for this or that would be a mistake.

en: I could give away something she hasn't even guessed.
vi: I might reveal something she hadn't yet guessed.
tr: I could let slip something he hadn't even thought of.
es: I might reveal something that she doesn't even imagine.

en: It might be nothing.
vi: It might be nothing.
tr: Nothing might have happened either.
es: It might not be anything important.

en: It might be the match hidden in my bed.
vi: It could be a matchstick hidden in the bed.
tr: Maybe it was the match hidden in my bed.
es: It might be about the match I hid in the mattress.

en: I hang my head.
vi: I let my head drop down.
tr: I hold my head down in shame.
es: I lower my head.

en: "Well?" she asks.
vi: “What?” she asked.
tr: “Huh?” he asks.
es: —Well? —he urges me—.

en: "Nothing to say for yourself?"
vi: “No excuses at all?”
tr: “Aren't you going to say something for yourself?”
es: Don't you have anything to say?

en: I look up at her.
vi: I looked up at her.
tr: I lift my head and look at him.
es: I look at her.

en: "About what?" I manage to stammer.
vi: "About what?" I stammered.
tr: “About what?” I manage to stammer.
es: —About what? —I manage to stammer.

en: As soon as it's out it sounds impudent.
vi: As soon as the words left my mouth, they sounded insolent.
tr: As soon as it leaves my mouth, it sounds insolent-
es: As soon as I say it, it seems insolent to me.

en: "Look," she says.
vi: “Look here,” she said.
tr: “Look,” he says.
es: —Look —he indicates to me.

en: She brings her free hand from behind her back.
vi: She raised her other hand from behind her back.
tr: He pulls his free hand from behind his back and shows it.
es: He removes his hand from behind his back.

en: It's her cloak she's holding, the winter one.
vi: In her hand was a cloak, the winter one.
tr: In his hand is the winter cloak he was holding.
es: What he is holding is his cloak, the winter one—.

en: "There was lipstick on it," she says.
vi: “There's a lipstick stain on it,” she said.
tr: “There was a lipstick stain on it,” he says.
es: It was stained with lipstick —he says—.

en: "How could you be so vulgar?
vi: “How could you be so vulgar?
tr: “How could you be so rude?
es: How could you be so vulgar?

en: I told him"
vi: I told him...”
tr: I told her too...”
es: I told him... —he lets the cloak fall and I see that there is something else in his bony hand.

en: She drops the cloak, she's holding something else, her hand all bone.
vi: She dropped the cloak, still holding something else, her hands bony and skeletal.
tr: He drops the cloak, now there's something else in his hand, a hand made entirely of bone.
es: I told him... —he lets the cloak fall and I see that there is something else in his bony hand.

en: She throws that down as well.
vi: She threw that down as well.
tr: He throws this to the ground as well, a purple sequin dress falls, sliding down the stairs like snake skin, sparkling in the sunlight.
es: He also throws it to the ground.

en: The purple sequins fall, slithering down over the step like snakeskin, glittering in the sunlight.
vi: Purple sequins scattered, sliding down the steps like snake skin, glittering in the sunlight.
tr: He throws this to the ground as well, a purple sequin dress falls, sliding down the stairs like snake skin, sparkling in the sunlight.
es: The purple sequins slide down the steps like snake skin, glistening under the sunlight.

en: "Behind my back," she says.
vi: “Right behind my back,” she said.
tr: “And behind my back,” he says.
es: —. Behind my back —he continues—.

en: "You could have left me something."
vi: “You could have at least left something for me.”
tr: “You could have left something for me too.”
es: You could have left me something —so does he love her?

en: Does she love him, after all?
vi: Did she love him, after all?
tr: Despite everything, does he love her?
es: You could have left me something —so does he love her?

en: She raises her cane.
vi: She raised her cane.
tr: He raises his cane.
es: Raise the cane.

en: I think she is going to hit me, but she doesn't.
vi: I thought she was going to hit me, but she didn't.
tr: I think he’s going to hit me, but he doesn’t.
es: I think he's going to hit me, but he doesn't—.

en: "Pick up that disgusting thing and get to your room.
vi: “Pick up that disgusting thing and go to your room immediately.
tr: “Take that disgusting thing and go to your room.
es: Pick up this trash and go to your room.

en: Just like the other one.
vi: Just like the one before you.
tr: You’re just like the other one.
es: Exactly the same as the other one.

en: A slut.
vi: Filthy whore.
tr: A slut.
es: A bitch.

en: You'll end up the same."
vi: In the end, it’s all the same.”
tr: Your end will be the same too.”
es: And you'll end up the same way.

en: I stoop, gather.
vi: I bent down, picked it up.
tr: I bend down and pick up.
es: I bend down and pick it up.

en: Behind my back Nick has stopped whistling.
vi: Behind me, Nick was already whistling.
tr: Behind me, Nick has stopped whistling.
es: Nick, who is behind me, has stopped whistling.

en: I want to turn, run to him, throw my arms around him.
vi: I want to turn around, run to him, and hug him.
tr: I want to turn back, run towards him, and wrap my arms around his neck.
es: I want to turn around, run towards him, and hug him.

en: This would be foolish.
vi: That would be foolish.
tr: That would be foolish.
es: But it would be foolish.

en: There is nothing he can do to help.
vi: He can't help at all.
tr: There is nothing he can do to help.
es: He can't do anything to help me.

en: He too would drown.
vi: He would drown too.
tr: He would also be dragged into the mire.
es: He would fall with me.

en: I walk to the back door, into the kitchen, set down my basket, go upstairs.
vi: I went to the back door, into the kitchen, put down the basket, and went upstairs.
tr: I walk towards the back door, enter the kitchen and leave my basket, then go upstairs.
es: I walk towards the back door, enter the kitchen, leave the basket, and go up the stairs.

en: I am orderly and calm.
vi: I am orderly and calm.
tr: I am obedient and calm.
es: I am calm.

en: XV Night
vi: Chapter XV - Night
tr: Fifteen
es: XV

vi: Chapter XV - Night
tr: Night
es: THE NIGHT
CHAPTER 46

en: I sit in my room, at the window, waiting.
vi: I sit in my room, by the window, waiting.
tr: I am sitting in my room, by the window, waiting.
es: I sit in my room, next to the window, and wait.

en: In my lap is a handful of crumpled stars.
vi: In my heart, a crumpled handful of stars.
tr: In my lap, a handful of bruised stars.
es: In my lap, I have a handful of crushed stars.

en: This could be the last time I have to wait.
vi: Perhaps this is the last time I have to wait.
tr: This could have been the last time I had to wait.
es: This could be the last time I have to wait.

en: But I don't know what I'm waiting for.
vi: But I don't know what I'm still waiting for.
tr: But I don't know what I'm waiting for.
es: But I don't know what I'm waiting for.

en: What are you waiting for?
vi: What else are you waiting for?
tr: What are you waiting for?
es: What are you waiting for?, it used to be said.

en: they used to say.
vi: people often say.
tr: they used to say.
es: What are you waiting for?, it used to be said.

en: That meant hurry up.
vi: That means hurry up.
tr: It meant hurry up.
es: Which meant Hurry up.

en: No answer was expected.
vi: No need for an answer.
tr: So, no answer was expected.
es: An answer was not expected.

en: For what are you waiting is a different question, and I have no answer for that one either.
vi: What are you waiting for is a different question, and I don't have an answer for that either.
tr: What are you waiting for, is a different question, and I have no answer to give to this question.
es: What are you waiting for is a different question, and for this one, I also have no answer.

en: Yet it isn't waiting, exactly.
vi: But this is not waiting, not exactly.
tr: Still, it's not exactly waiting.
es: Although it is not exactly waiting.

en: It's more like a form of suspension.
vi: It's more like a form of stagnation.
tr: It's more like being in a state of suspension.
es: It is more like a form of suspension.

en: Without suspense.
vi: Not waiting to untie the knot.
tr: Without any hesitation.
es: Without suspending anything.

en: At last there is no time.
vi: In the end, there wasn't enough time.
tr: There is no time in the end.
es: There is no time.

en: I am in disgrace, which is the opposite of grace.
vi: I have fallen out of favor, which means losing grace.
tr: I am in an embarrassing situation, which is the opposite of being virtuous.
es: I have fallen from grace, which is the opposite of grace.

en: I ought to feel worse
vi: I should have been suffering more than this.
tr: I should feel worse about this.
es: Because of this, I should feel worse.

en: about it.
vi: I should have been suffering more than this.
tr: I should feel worse about this.
es: Because of this, I should feel worse.

en: But I feel serene, at peace, pervaded with indifference.
vi: But I felt serene, peaceful, immersed in indifference.
tr: Yet I feel peaceful, calm, filled with indifference.
es: But I feel calm, at peace, imbued with indifference.

en: Don't let the bastards grind you down.
vi: Don't let the bastards crush your home.
tr: Don't let those bastards tear you apart.
es: Don't let the bastards burn you out.

en: I repeat this to myself but it conveys nothing.
vi: I reminded myself that those words no longer had any meaning.
tr: I keep repeating this to myself, but it holds no meaning.
es: I repeat it to myself, but it doesn't mean anything to me.

en: You might as well say, Don't let there be air; or, Don't be.
vi: It's no different from saying, Don't have air; or, Don't exist.
tr: Well, it could also mean Don't let it breathe or Exist.
es: One could also say Don't let the air pass; or No.

en: I suppose you could say that.
vi: I guess one could say that.
tr: I think this could be said.
es: I suppose you could say that.

en: There's nobody in the garden.
vi: There is no one in the garden.
tr: There is no one in the garden.
es: There is no one in the garden.

en: I wonder if it will rain.
vi: I don't know if it's going to rain.
tr: I wonder if it will rain.
es: I wonder if it will rain.

en: Outside, the light is fading.
vi: Outside, the sun is setting.
tr: Outside, the weather is getting dark.
es: Outside, the day begins to fade.

en: It's reddish already.
vi: The sky is already glowing.
tr: It's already turning red.
es: The sky is already reddish.

en: Soon it will be dark.
vi: It will be dark soon.
tr: Soon it will be dark.
es: Soon it will be dark.

en: Right now it's darker.
vi: It's already darker now.
tr: It's already darker now.
es: It's already darker.

en: That didn't take long.
vi: It won't take long.
tr: This didn't take long.
es: It didn't take much time.

en: There are a number of things I could do.
vi: There are still some things I can do.
tr: There were actually a few things I could do.
es: There are a lot of things I could do.

en: I could set fire to the house, for instance.
vi: I could set the house on fire, for example.
tr: For example, I could set the house on fire.
es: For example, I could set the house on fire.

en: I could bundle up some of my clothes, and the sheets, and strike my one hidden match.
vi: I could gather the clothes and bed sheets into a bundle and strike a stored match.
tr: I could bundle up some of my clothes and sheets and strike my only hidden match.
es: I could make a bundle with some of my clothes and the sheets and light the match I have saved.

en: If it didn't catch, that would be that.
vi: If the match doesn't light, then that's it.
tr: If it didn't burn, it wouldn't burn.
es: If it didn't catch fire, nothing would happen.

en: But if it did, there would at least be an event, a signal of some kind to mark my exit.
vi: But if it does light, at least there would be an event, a kind of sign to remember the day I left.
tr: On the other hand, if it did burn, at least there would be an event, a kind of sign marking my exit.
es: But if it did catch fire, at least there would be some kind of signal marking my departure.

en: A few flames, easily put out.
vi: Just a little fire, very easy to put out.
tr: A few flames that could be easily extinguished.
es: A few flames that would easily go out.

en: In the meantime I could let loose clouds of smoke and die by suffocation.
vi: While waiting, I could smoke myself to suffocation.
tr: Meanwhile, releasing clouds of smoke into the air, I could die from suffocation.
es: In the meantime, I could let out some clouds of smoke and die of suffocation.

en: I could tear my bedsheet into strips and twist it into a rope of sorts and tie one end to the leg of my bed and try to break the window.
vi: You can tear the bed sheet into strips and twist them into a type of rope, tying one end to the bed leg to break the door.
tr: I could cut the bed sheet into strips, twist them into a makeshift rope, tie one end to the foot of my bed, and try to break the window.
es: I could tear the sheet into strips, twist them like a rope, tie one end to the leg of my bed, and try to break the window glass.

en: Which is shatterproof.
vi: With unbreakable glass.
tr: That unbreakable window.
es: Which is shatterproof.

en: I could go to the Commander, fall on the floor, my hair disheveled, as they say, grab him around the knees, confess, weep, implore.
vi: Maybe go find the Commander, collapse to the floor, hair disheveled, as they say, clutching his knees, confessing, sobbing, pleading.
tr: I could go to the Commander, as they used to say, with my hair disheveled, kneel on the ground, wrap my arms around his knees, confess, lament, and beg for my forgiveness.
es: I could turn to the Commander, throw myself on the ground completely disheveled, cling to his knees, confess, cry, implore.

en: Nolite te bastardes carborundorum, I could say.
vi: Nolite te bastardes carborundorum, I will say.
tr: I could say, "Nolite te bastardes carborundorum."
es: Nolite te bastardes carborundorum, I could say.

en: Not a prayer.
vi: It's not a prayer.
tr: Not a prayer.
es: Not as a prayer.

en: I visualize his shoes, black, well shined, impenetrable, keeping their own counsel.
vi: I imagine his shoes, black, shiny, seamless, harboring their own private intentions.
tr: I bring his shoes to my mind, black, well-polished, unattainable, revealing nothing.
es: I see his shoes, black, polished, impenetrable, keeping silent.

en: Instead I could noose the bedsheet round my neck, hook myself up in the closet, throw my weight forward, choke myself off.
vi: Otherwise, one could put their head through the bed frame, hook it onto the closet handle, lean forward, and strangle themselves to death.
tr: Instead, I could wrap the bed sheet around my neck, tie myself to the hook in the bathroom, and lean forward to strangle myself.
es: I could also tie the sheet around my neck, hang myself from the wardrobe, let my body fall forward, and strangle myself.

en: I could hide behind the door, wait until she comes, hobbles along the hall, bearing whatever sentence, penance, punishment, jump out at her, knock her down, kick her sharply and accurately in the head.
vi: Could hide behind the door, wait for her to come, hobbling through the hallway, with any sentence, crime, punishment, jump at her, knock her down, kick her in the head hard and precisely.
tr: I could have hidden behind the door and waited until Serena arrived, limping down the corridor, bringing with her the judgment, whether it was the atonement for my sin or the punishment, whatever it was, I could have pounced on her, knocked her to the ground, and hit her on the head, sharply and perfectly.
es: I could hide behind the door, wait for her to come limping down the hallway bringing some sentence, a penance, a punishment, pounce on her, knock her down, and kick her head with a swift and precise blow.

en: To put her out of her misery, and myself as well.
vi: Free her from the torment, and myself too.
tr: To save her from her misery, and of course, from mine as well.
es: To spare her the pain, just like me.

en: To put her out of our misery.
vi: Free her from the torment for both of us.
tr: To save her from our misery.
es: To spare her our pain.

en: It would save time.
vi: Will make up for lost time.
tr: This would save time.
es: That way, he would gain time.

en: I could walk at a steady pace down the stairs and out the front door and along the street, trying to look as if I knew where I was going,
vi: It is possible to calmly go downstairs through the front door to the main road, trying to act as if you know exactly where you are going, to see how far you can go.
tr: I could walk down the stairs with steady steps, exit through the door, and walk along the street, trying to look like I knew where I was going and seeing how far I could go.
es: I could go down the stairs with a steady step, exit through the front door to the street, trying to give the impression that I know where I'm going, and see how far I can get.

en: and see how far I could get.
vi: It is possible to calmly go downstairs through the front door to the main road, trying to act as if you know exactly where you are going, to see how far you can go.
tr: I could walk down the stairs with steady steps, exit through the door, and walk along the street, trying to look like I knew where I was going and seeing how far I could go.
es: I could go down the stairs with a steady step, exit through the front door to the street, trying to give the impression that I know where I'm going, and see how far I can get.

en: Red is so visible.
vi: The red color is too striking.
tr: Red is a very conspicuous color.
es: Red is a very visible color.

en: I could go to Nick's room, over the garage, as we have done before.
vi: Could go up to Nick's room, up above the garage, like before.
tr: I could go to Nick's room, the one above the garage, like we did before.
es: I could go to Nick's room, above the garage, as I have done until now.

en: I could wonder whether or not he would let me in, give me shelter.
vi: Could wonder if he would let her in, give her shelter.
tr: I could satisfy my curiosity about whether he would let me in, whether he would protect me.
es: I could wonder if he would let me in or not, if he would give me shelter.

en: Now that the need is real.
vi: Because now is the time she really needs it.
tr: Now that this need is real.
es: Now that it is really necessary.

en: I consider these things idly.
vi: I absentmindedly think about these things.
tr: I am reviewing all of this lazily.
es: I think about all this absentmindedly.

en: Each one of them seems the same size as all the others.
vi: All possibilities seem to be approximately the same.
tr: Each one looks the same as the others.
es: Each of the possibilities seems as important as the rest.

en: Not one seems preferable.
vi: None is more valuable than the other.
tr: None is preferable to the other.
es: None seems preferable to another.

en: Fatigue is here, in my body, in my legs and eyes.
vi: Weakness has come here, into my body, seeping into my legs and eyelids.
tr: Exhaustion descends upon me, my body, my legs, and my eyes.
es: Fatigue takes hold of me, my body, my legs, and my eyes.

en: That is what gets you in the end.
vi: That is the state one will eventually fall into.
tr: In the end, this is what takes hold of you.
es: This is what happens in the end.

en: Faith is only a word, embroidered.
vi: Faith is also just a word, embroidered with thread.
tr: Faith is just a word, a fancy word.
es: Faith is nothing more than an embroidered word.

en: I look out at the dusk and think about its being winter.
vi: I look out at the twilight and think it's winter now.
tr: I am looking outside at twilight and thinking that the season is winter.
es: I look at the sunset and imagine that we are in winter.

en: The snow falling, gently, effortlessly, covering everything in soft crystal, the mist of moonlight before a rain, blurring the outlines, obliterating color.
vi: Snowfall, gently, almost imperceptibly, burying everything in fine crystal, the moonlit mist before the rain, blurring outlines, erasing colors.
tr: The falling snow, gently, effortlessly, covering everything with soft crystals, a moonlight haze before the rain, blurring the outlines, erasing the color.
es: The snow falls gently, easily, covering everything with soft crystals, the fog that covers the moon before it rains, blurring the outlines, erasing the colors.

en: Freezing to death is painless, they say, after the first chill.
vi: Freezing to death is said to be painless, once the initial chill has passed.
tr: They say freezing to death doesn't hurt, after the initial chill.
es: They say that death by freezing is painless.

en: You lie back in the snow like an angel made by children and go to sleep.
vi: People lie like angels imprinted on the snow when the children have left and fallen asleep.
tr: You lie down like an angel made by children and drift off to sleep in the snow.
es: You lie down on the snow like an angel made by some children and fall asleep.

en: Behind me I feel her presence, my ancestress, my double, turning in midair under the chandelier, in her costume of stars and feathers, a bird stopped in flight, a woman made into an angel, waiting to be found.
vi: I feel her presence behind me, my grandmother, my version, hovering and spinning under the chandelier, body wrapped in star scales and feathers, wings halted mid-flight, the woman transformed into an angel, waiting to be discovered.
tr: I feel her presence behind me, my ancestral woman, my twin, spinning in the air under the chandelier, with her costume made of gilding and feathers, a bird halted in flight, a woman turned into an angel, waiting to be found.
es: I feel her presence behind me, that of my ancestor, my double, who appears suspended in the air, beneath the chandelier, with her dress of stars and feathers like a bird halted in mid-flight, a woman turned into an angel, waiting to be found.

en: By me this time.
vi: This time, that person is me.
tr: This time by me.
es: This time by me.

en: How could I have believed I was alone in here?
vi: How did I think I was alone here?
tr: How could I have believed I was alone here?
es: How could I believe that I was alone?

en: There were always two of us.
vi: There are always two.
tr: We were always both here.
es: We were always two.

en: Get it over, she says.
vi: Finish it, she said.
tr: Finish this job, she says.
es: End it once and for all, she tells me.

en: I'm tired of this melodrama, I'm tired of keeping silent.
vi: I'm tired of this play, tired of the silence.
tr: I'm tired of this melodrama, tired of staying silent.
es: I am tired of this melodrama, I am tired of keeping silent.

en: There's no one you can protect, your life has value to no one.
vi: You can't protect anyone, your life is useless to anyone.
tr: There's no one you can protect, your life has no value for anyone.
es: There is no one you can protect, your life has no value to anyone.

en: I want it finished.
vi: I want it to end.
tr: I want this to end.
es: I want this to end.

en: As I'm standing up I hear the black van.
vi: As I stood up, I heard the van.
tr: As I stand up, I hear the black minibus arriving.
es: As I get up, I hear the black van.

en: I hear it before I see it; blended with the twilight, it appears out of its own sound like a solidification, a clotting of the night.
vi: I heard it before I saw it; mingling in the twilight, it emerged from its own sound like a solid noise, like a block of winter night.
tr: Before I see it, I hear its sound; adorned with twilight, it seems like the embodiment of its own sound, the coagulation of the night.
es: I hear it before I see it; it emerges from its own sound mixed with the twilight, like a solidification, a clot of the night.

en: It turns into the driveway, stops.
vi: It drove up the driveway and stopped.
tr: The car turns onto the driveway and stops.
es: It turns into the driveway and stops.

en: I can just make out the white eye, the two wings.
vi: I only saw the white eye, two flapping wings.
tr: I can only see its white eye, those two wings.
es: I barely make out the white eye and the two wings.

en: The paint must be phosphorescent.
vi: Probably using fluorescent paint.
tr: Its paint must be phosphorescent.
es: The paint must be phosphorescent.

en: Two men detach themselves from the shape of it, come up the front steps, ring the bell.
vi: Two people separated from the black mass, stepped onto the front porch, and rang the bell.
tr: Two men emerge from the shape of the vehicle, climb the front steps, and ring the bell.
es: Two men detach from it as if from a mold, climb the entrance steps, ring the doorbell.

en: I hear the bell toll, ding-dong, like the ghost of a cosmetics woman, down in the hall.
vi: I heard the bell chime, downstairs, ding dong, like the ghost of a cosmetics consultant.
tr: I hear the sound of the bell, ding-dong, like the ghost of a woman selling cosmetics, down in the hall.
es: I hear the sound of the doorbell, ding-dong, like the ghost of a cosmetics saleswoman.

en: Worse is coming, then.
vi: It gets even worse.
tr: It means worse is coming.
es: Now comes the worst.

en: I've been wasting my time.
vi: I have wasted time.
tr: I was wasting my time.
es: I have been wasting time.

en: I should have taken things into my own hands while I had the chance.
vi: I should have seized everything when I had the chance.
tr: I should take control of the course of events while I still have a chance.
es: I should have taken care of it when I still had the chance to do so.

en: I should have stolen a knife from the kitchen, found some way to the sewing scissors.
vi: I should have stolen the kitchen knife, found a way to get the sewing scissors.
tr: I should steal a knife from the kitchen, find a way to reach the sewing scissors.
es: I should have stolen a knife from the kitchen, found a way to get the scissors from the sewing kit.

en: There were the
vi: I should have stolen the kitchen knife, found a way to get the sewing scissors.
tr: There were garden shears, knitting needles; if you look for them, the world is full of weapons.
es: There were also the garden shears, the knitting needles.

en: garden shears, the knitting needles; the world is full of weapons if you're looking for them.
vi: Also the garden shears, the knitting needles; there are weapons all around if one needs them.
tr: There were garden shears, knitting needles; if you look for them, the world is full of weapons.
es: The world is full of weapons if one looks for them.

en: I should have paid attention.
vi: I should have paid attention.
tr: I should be careful.
es: I should have paid attention.

en: But it's too late to think about that now, already their feet are on the dusty-rose carpeting of the stairs; a heavy muted tread, pulse in the forehead.
vi: But now it's too late to think, their feet have already tapped on the peach-pink ash-colored carpet of the stairs; their thudding footsteps swallowed the sound, veins on their foreheads throbbing.
tr: But it is too late to think about this now, his feet are already on the dusty-rose-colored carpet of the stairs; a heavy, silent walk, a throbbing vein on the forehead.
es: But now it is too late to think about that, their footsteps already sound on the ash-pink carpet of the stairs; the mute and heavy steps resound in my forehead; I am with my back to the window.

en: My back's to the window.
vi: My back turned to the window.
tr: My back is turned to the window.
es: But now it is too late to think about that, their footsteps already sound on the ash-pink carpet of the stairs; the mute and heavy steps resound in my forehead; I am with my back to the window.

en: I expect a stranger, but it's Nick who pushes open the door, flicks on the light.
vi: I thought I would meet a stranger, but no one other than Nick pushed the door open and turned on the room light.
tr: I am expecting a stranger, but it is Nick who pushes the door open and flicks on the light.
es: I hope to see a stranger, but it is Nick who suddenly opens the door and turns on the light.

en: I can't place that, unless he's one of them.
vi: I couldn't understand, unless he belonged to them.
tr: I can't find a place for this in my mind, unless he is one of them, of course.
es: I don't understand, unless he is one of them.

en: There was always that possibility.
vi: A possibility that was always left open.
tr: This possibility always existed.
es: That possibility always existed.

en: Nick, the private Eye.
vi: Nick, The secret eye.
tr: Nick, the special Eye.
es: Nick, the secret Eye.

en: Dirty work is done by dirty people.
vi: Dirty work needs dirty people.
tr: Dirty work is done by dirty people.
es: Dirty work is done by dirty people.

en: You shit, I think.
vi: Rotten scum, I thought.
tr: You piece of shit, I think.
es: You are a piece of shit, I think.

en: I open my mouth to say it, but he comes over, close to me, whispers.
vi: I opened my mouth to say it, but he moved closer, very close to me, and whispered.
tr: I open my mouth to say it, but he comes towards me, close, and whispers.
es: I open my mouth to say it, but he comes closer to me and whispers:

en: "It's all right.
vi: "It's okay.
tr: “Everything is fine.
es: —Everything is fine.

en: It's Mayday.
vi: This is Mayday.
tr: This is Mayday.
es: It's Mayday.

en: Go with them."
vi: Just go with them."
tr: Go with them.”
es: Go with them —he calls me by my real name.

en: He calls me by my real name.
vi: He called me by my real name.
tr: He calls me by my real name.
es: Go with them —he calls me by my real name.

en: Why should this mean anything?
vi: But does that necessarily mean anything?
tr: Why should this have any meaning?
es: Why would this mean anything?

en: "Them?" I say.
vi: “Them?” I said.
tr: “With them?” I say.
es: —Them? —I ask him.

en: I see the two men standing behind him, the overhead light in the hallway making skulls of their heads.
vi: I saw two people behind him, the hallway ceiling light shining on their heads, making them look like skulls.
tr: I see the two men standing behind him, the corridor's ceiling light turning their heads into skulls.
es: I see the two men standing behind him; the hallway light turns their heads into skulls—.

en: "You must be crazy."
vi: “You’re crazy.”
tr: “You must be crazy.”
es: You must be crazy —my suspicion hangs in the air, a dark angel sends me a warning.

en: My suspicion hovers in the air above him, a dark angel warning me away.
vi: My pot of doubt hovered above him, an angel I haunted warned me to refuse.
tr: My doubt hovers above him, like a mysterious angel warning me.
es: You must be crazy —my suspicion hangs in the air, a dark angel sends me a warning.

en: I can almost see it.
vi: I almost saw it.
tr: I can almost see it.
es: I can almost see it.

en: Why shouldn't he know about Mayday?
vi: So what if he knew Mavday?
tr: Why would the Mayday talk never end?
es: Why wouldn't he know about Mayday?

en: All the Eyes must know about it; they'll have squeezed it, crushed it, twisted it out of enough bodies, enough mouths by now.
vi: Every Eye must have known; they had been squeezed out, ground out, wrung out from so many bodies, so many throats already.
tr: All the Eyes must know this; they must have extracted it by squeezing, crushing, twisting it out of enough bodies, enough mouths by now.
es: All the Eyes must know; it has been squeezed, wrung, and drained from too many bodies, from too many mouths.

en: "Trust me," he says; which in itself has never been a talisman, carries no guarantee.
vi: "Trust me," he said; a phrase that has never been enough as a talisman, guaranteeing nothing.
tr: "Trust me," he says; this phrase has never had a charm of its own, there's never any guarantee.
es: —Trust me —he insists; although that was never a talisman, it does not represent any guarantee.

en: But I snatch at it, this offer.
vi: But I seized that offer.
tr: Still, I cling tightly to this, to this suggestion.
es: But I cling to this offer.

en: It's all I'm left with.
vi: Besides it, I had nothing else.
tr: This is the only thing left to me.
es: It's all I have left.

en: One in front, one behind, they escort me down the stairs.
vi: One in front, one behind, they escorted me downstairs.
tr: One in front, one behind, they are accompanying me down the stairs.
es: They escort me down the stairs, one in front and one behind.

en: The pace is leisurely, the lights are on.
vi: Their steps were steady, the lights all bright.
tr: The steps are calm, the lights are on.
es: We move at a slow pace; the lights are on.

en: Despite the fear, how ordinary it is.
vi: Apart from the fear, how normal it all seemed.
tr: Despite the fear, how ordinary it is.
es: Despite the fear, everything seems normal to me.

en: From here I can see the clock.
vi: From here, I could see the clock.
tr: I can see the clock from here.
es: From where I am, I can see the clock.

en: It's no time in particular.
vi: What time it was, I couldn't tell.
tr: It's not a special time.
es: It's not any particular time.

en: Nick is no longer with us.
vi: Nick is no longer coming along.
tr: Nick is no longer with us.
es: Nick is no longer with us.

en: He may have gone down the back stairs, not wishing to be seen.
vi: He probably went down the back stairs, not wanting to be seen.
tr: He might have gone down the back stairs to avoid being seen.
es: He must have gone down the back stairs so that no one would see him.

en: Serena
vi: Serena
tr: Serena
es: Serena

en: Joy stands in the hallway, under the mirror, looking up, incredulous.
vi: Joy stood in the hall, right under the mirror, looking up, in disbelief.
tr: Joy is standing in the hallway, under the mirror, looking up, suspicious.
es: Joy is in the hallway, beneath the mirror, watching us with an incredulous look.

en: The Commander is behind her, the sitting room door is open.
vi: The Commander was behind her, the door to the sitting room ajar.
tr: The Commander is behind her, the living room door open.
es: Behind her, next to the open door of the living room, is the Commander.

en: His hair is very gray.
vi: His hair was strangely gray.
tr: Her hair is very gray.
es: His hair is very gray.

en: He looks worried and helpless, but already withdrawingfrom me, distancing himself.
vi: He looked worried and helpless, but had managed to step back from me, keeping his distance.
tr: She looks anxious and desperate, at the same time avoiding me, keeping her distance.
es: He looks worried and powerless, but he is starting to pull away from me, to distance himself.

en: Whatever else I am to him, I am also at this point a disaster.
vi: No matter what I was to him, at this moment, I was a disaster.
tr: Whatever else I am to her, at this point I am also a plague.
es: Apart from what it meant to him, we have reached a point where I also represent a failure.

en: No doubt they've been
vi: It was obvious they had just had a fight, because of me; it was obvious she had just scolded him.
tr: There is no doubt they had a fight about me; no doubt Serena gave him hell.
es: They have undoubtedly argued about me; she has undoubtedly given him a hard time.

en: having a fight, about me; no doubt she's been giving him hell.
vi: It was obvious they had just had a fight, because of me; it was obvious she had just scolded him.
tr: There is no doubt they had a fight about me; no doubt Serena gave him hell.
es: They have undoubtedly argued about me; she has undoubtedly given him a hard time.

en: I still have it in me to feel sorry for him.
vi: I still had enough strength to feel sorry for him.
tr: I still carry enough emotion inside me to feel sorry for him.
es: I'm still having a hard time, I can't feel sorry for him.

en: Moira is right, I am a wimp.
vi: Moira was right, I am a coward.
tr: Moira was right, I'm a soft-hearted person.
es: Moira is right, I am a prude.

en: "What has she done?" says Serena Joy.
vi: “What did it do?” Serena Jov asked.
tr: “What has she done?” asks Serena Joy.
es: —What has she done? —asks Serena Joy.

en: She wasn't the one who called them, then.
vi: So it wasn't her who called.
tr: So, it wasn't her who called them.
es: So it wasn't her who called them.

en: Whatever she had in store for me, it was more private.
vi: If there was something saved for me, it wouldn't be this noisy.
tr: Whatever she has planned for me, it's something more special.
es: I don't know what was in store for me, but it was something more private.

en: "We can't say, ma'am," says the one in front of me.
vi: “We cannot speak, madam,” the person in front of me said.
tr: “We can't say, sir,” says the one in front of me.
es: —We can't say, ma'am —says the one in front of me—.

en: "Sorry."
vi: “Please forgive us.”
tr: “I'm sorry.”
es: I'm sorry.

en: "I need to see your authorization," says the Commander.
vi: “I need a certificate of authority,” the Commander said.
tr: "I need to see your authorization document," says the Commander.
es: —I want to see the authorization —says the Commander—.

en: "You have a warrant?"
vi: “Do you have a subpoena?”
tr: "Do you have an arrest warrant?"
es: Do you have legal authorization?

en: I could scream now, cling to the banister, relinquish dignity.
vi: Now I can scream, hold tightly to the stair railing, and throw away all dignity.
tr: I could grab the railing and scream without any regard for politeness now.
es: Now I could start screaming, grab onto the railing, give up all dignity.

en: I could stop them, at least for a moment.
vi: I will block their way, even if just for a minute.
tr: I could stop them, at least for a while.
es: I could stop them, at least for a moment.

en: If they're real they'll stay, if not they'll run away.
vi: If it's real, they will stay, if not, they will run away.
tr: If they are real, they will stay; if not, they will run away.
es: If they are the real ones, they will stay, otherwise they will run away.

en: Leaving me here.
vi: Leaving me behind.
tr: Leaving me here.
es: And they will leave me here.

en: "Not that we need one, sir, but all is in order," says the first one again.
vi: "It seems we don't need to, sir, but this is being done according to the law," the other person replied.
tr: “We don't need it, sir, but everything is in accordance with the orders,” says the first one again.
es: —We don't need it, sir, but everything is in order —says the same man—.

en: "Violation of state secrets."
vi: "The crime of infringing on national secrets."
tr: “Betrayal of national secrets.”
es: Violation of state secrets.

en: The Commander puts his hand to his head.
vi: The commander put his hands on his head.
tr: The Commander puts his hand on his head.
es: The Commander puts a hand to his head.

en: What have I been saying, and to whom, and which one of his enemies has found out?
vi: What did I say, to whom, which of the enemies did you sense?
tr: What was I explaining and to whom, moreover, which of his enemies revealed this?
es: What have I been saying, and to whom, and which of his enemies has discovered it?

en: Possibly he will be a security risk, now.
vi: It's very likely that by now you have become a security threat.
tr: Now the Commander will pose a potential security risk.
es: His security is probably in danger now.

en: I am above him, looking down; he is shrinking.
vi: I stand above you, looking down; you are shrinking.
tr: I'm above him, looking down from there; he shrinks and diminishes.
es: I am above him, looking at him; and he is shrinking.

en: There have already been purges among them, there will be more.
vi: There has been purification, and there will be more.
tr: There had been a purge among the Commanders before, and there will be more in the future.
es: There have already been purges among them, and there will be more.

en: Serena
vi: Serena
tr: Serena
es: Serena

en: Joy goes white.
vi: Joy's face was pale.
tr: Joy turns completely pale.
es: Joy turns pale.

en: "Bitch," she says.
vi: "You promiscuous woman," she said.
tr: "Whore," he says.
es: —Slut —he insults me—.

en: "After all he did for you."
vi: "He treats you like that."
tr: "After all the things he did for you."”
es: After everything he did for you.

en: Cora and Rita press through from the kitchen.
vi: Cora and Rita pushed and ran out of the kitchen.
tr: Cora and Rita come out of the kitchen shoving each other.
es: Cora and Rita come running from the kitchen.

en: Cora has begun to cry.
vi: Cora was already crying.
tr: Cora has started crying.
es: Cora is in tears.

en: I was her hope, I've failed her.
vi: I was her hope, I let her down.
tr: I was her hope, I let her down.
es: I was her hope, and I have let her down.

en: Now she will always be childless.
vi: Now she will never have children.
tr: From now on, she will always be childless.
es: She will never have children.

en: The van waits in the driveway, its double doors stand open.
vi: The van waited by the entrance, both doors wide open.
tr: The minibus is waiting on the driveway, its double doors open.
es: The van waits in the driveway, with the double doors open.

en: The two of them, one on either side now, take me by the elbows to help me in.
vi: The two of them, one on each side, grabbed my elbows and helped me in.
tr: Now the two of them, each on one side of me, are helping me get inside by holding my elbows.
es: The two men—now one on each side—grab me by the arms and help me up.

en: Whether this is my end or a new beginning I have no way of knowing: I have given myself over into the hands of strangers, because it can't be helped.
vi: Whether this was the end or a new beginning, I couldn't tell: I had entrusted myself to strangers, as there was no other way.
tr: There is no way to know if this is my end or a new beginning: I have surrendered myself to strangers because there is no other way.
es: I have no way of knowing if this is my end or a new beginning: I have surrendered to strangers because it is inevitable.

en: And so I step up, into the darkness within; or else the light.
vi: And so I stepped forward, into the darkness inside; or perhaps the light.
tr: And so I climb, into the darkness inside; or into the light.
es: I ascend and penetrate into the darkness within; or into the light.

en: Keynote Speaker: Professor James Darcy Pieixoto, Director, Twentieth and Twenty-first-Century Archives, Cambridge University, England.

es: Inaugural Speaker: Professor James Darcy Pieixoto, Director of the Twentieth and Twenty-First Century Archives, University of Cambridge, England.

en: CRESCENT MOON: I am delighted to welcome you all here this morning, and I'm pleased to see that so many of you have turned out lor Professor Pieixoto's, I am sure, fascinating and worthwhile talk.
vi: New Moon: I am honored to welcome all of you here this morning, and I am very pleased to see so many people have come to listen to Professor Pieixoto's talk, which I am sure will be fascinating and very valuable.
tr: CRESCENTMOON: I am pleased to welcome you all here this morning. Furthermore, I am delighted to see that many of you have gathered for what I am sure will be an interesting and valuable talk by Professor Pieixoto.
es: CRESCENT MOON: I am delighted to welcome you all, and pleased to see that many of you are attending the undoubtedly fascinating and beneficial lecture by Professor Pieixoto.

en: We of the Gileadean Research Association believe that this period well repays further study, responsible as it ultimately was for redrawing the map of the world, especially in this hemisphere.
vi: We at the Gilead Research Association believe that this period in history promises many rewards for in-depth research, as it ultimately plays a major role in the redrawing of the world map, particularly in this hemisphere.
tr: As the Gilead Studies Association, we believe that this period, especially in this hemisphere, will ultimately be responsible for redrawing the map of the world, and that further studies will be rewarding.
es: The members of the Gileadean Research Association believe that this period deserves more thorough study, as it was responsible for altering the world map, especially in this hemisphere.

en: But before we proceed, a few announcements.
vi: But before we continue, there are a few small announcements.
tr: I need to make a few announcements before we proceed further.
es: But before moving on to that, I would like to make some announcements.

en: The fishing expedition will go forward tomorrow as planned, and for those of you who have not brought suitable rain gear and insect repellent, these are available for a nominal charge at the Registration Desk.
vi: Tomorrow's fishing trip will proceed as planned, and those who have not brought enough rain gear and insect repellent can purchase them for a nominal fee at the reception desk.
tr: The fishing trip will take place tomorrow as planned; therefore, for those of you who haven't brought rain-appropriate clothing and insect repellent, it is possible to obtain these at the Registration Desk for a small fee.
es: The fishing expedition will depart tomorrow, as scheduled, and for those who have not brought adequate rain gear and insect repellent, I inform you that you can obtain them charged to your account at the reception.

en: The nature walk and Outdoor Period-Costume Sing-Song have been rescheduled for the day after tomorrow, as we are assured by our own infallible Professor Johnny Running Dog of a break in the weather at that time.
vi: The field trip and outdoor historical reenactment have been postponed to the day after tomorrow, as our infallible Professor Johnny Running Dog has confirmed that the weather will clear up by then.
tr: The Nature Hike and Outdoor Historical Costume Singing activities have been rescheduled for the day after tomorrow, as our infallible Professor Johnny Running Dog has guaranteed good weather during this period.
es: The Nature Walk and the Outdoor Historical Costume Parade have been postponed to the day after tomorrow since our infallible Professor Johnny Running Dog has informed us that there will be a change in the weather by then.

en: Let meremind you of the other events sponsored by the Gilead ean Research Association that are available to you at this convention, as part of our Twelfth Symposium.
vi: I would also like to review other events hosted by the Gilead Research Association at this congress, which are also part of the seminar program.
tr: At this congress, as part of the Twelfth Symposium, allow me to remind you of other activities supported and offered by the Gilead Research Association.
es: Allow me to remind you of the rest of the activities sponsored by the Gileadian Research Association that you can participate in during this congress as part of the programming for this Twelfth Symposium.

en: Tomorrow afternoon, Professor Gopal Chatterjee, of the Department of Western Philosophy, University of Baroda, India, will speak on "Krishna and Kali Elements in the State Religion of the Early Gilead Period," and there is a morning presentation on Thursday by Professor Sieg-linda Van Buren from the Department of Military History at the University of
vi: Tomorrow afternoon, Professor Gopal Chatterjee from the Department of Western Philosophy, Baroda University, India, will speak on "Krishna-Kali Elements in Early Gilead State Religion," and on Thursday morning, there will be a presentation by Professor Sieglinda Van Buren from the Department of Military History at San Antonio University, Republic of Texas.
tr: Tomorrow afternoon, Professor Gopal Chatterjee from the Department of Western Philosophy at Baroda University in India will speak on "Krishna and Kali Elements in Early Gilead State Religion."
es: Tomorrow afternoon, Professor Gopal Chatterjee, from the Department of Western Philosophy at the University of Baroda in India, will lecture on "The Krishna and Kali Elements in the State Religion of the Early Gileadian Period," and on Thursday morning, Professor Sieglinda Van Buren, from the Department of Military History at the University of San Antonio, Republic of Texas, will speak.

en: San Antonio, Republic of Texas.
vi: Tomorrow afternoon, Professor Gopal Chatterjee from the Department of Western Philosophy, Baroda University, India, will speak on "Krishna-Kali Elements in Early Gilead State Religion," and on Thursday morning, there will be a presentation by Professor Sieglinda Van Buren from the Department of Military History at San Antonio University, Republic of Texas.
tr: Additionally, on Thursday morning, there will be a presentation by Professor Sieglinda Van Buren from the Department of Military History at the University of San Antonio, Republic of Texas.
es: Tomorrow afternoon, Professor Gopal Chatterjee, from the Department of Western Philosophy at the University of Baroda in India, will lecture on "The Krishna and Kali Elements in the State Religion of the Early Gileadian Period," and on Thursday morning, Professor Sieglinda Van Buren, from the Department of Military History at the University of San Antonio, Republic of Texas, will speak.

en: Professor Van Buren will give what I am sure will be a fascinating illustrated lecture on "The Warsaw Tactic: Policies of Urban Core Encirclement in the Gileadean Civil Wars."
vi: Professor Van Buren will deliver a lecture that I am sure will be captivating, with many illustrations, on "Warsaw Tactics: Urban Isolation Policies during the Gilead Civil War."
tr: Professor Van Buren will give a lecture, which I am sure will be fascinating, on "Warsaw Tactics: Siege Policies in City Centers during the Gilead Civil War."
es: Professor Van Buren will offer what will undoubtedly be a fascinating illustrated lecture on "The Warsaw Tactic: The Urban Core Encirclement Policy in the Gileadian Civil Wars."

en: I am sure all of us will wish to attend these.
vi: I am certain all of us will want to attend these sessions.
tr: Undoubtedly, we will all desire to attend these.
es: I am sure we will all want to attend.

en: I must also remind our keynote speakeralthough I am sure it is not necessaryto keep within his time period, as we wish to leave space for questions, and I expect none of us wants to miss lunch, as happened yesterday.
vi: I also have to remind our keynote speaker - although I'm sure this isn't necessary - not to exceed the allotted time, as we still want to have time for questions, and I believe none of us want to miss lunch, as happened yesterday.
tr: On the other hand, I must remind our keynote speaker -although, I am sure this is not necessary- not to exceed the allotted time, so that we can allocate time for questions, and I believe none of us want to miss lunch like we did yesterday.
es: I must also remind our keynote speaker, although I am sure it is not necessary, to stick to the time that has been assigned to him, because we want to dedicate a part to questions, and I suppose no one will want to miss lunch, as happened yesterday.

en: (Laughter.)
vi: [The audience bursts into laughter.]
tr: (Laughter)
es: (Laughter.)

en: Professor Pieixoto scarcely needs any introduction, as he is well known to all of us, if not personally then through his extensive publications.
vi: Professor Pieixoto needs no introduction, as we are all familiar with him, if not directly then through his extensive works.
tr: Since Professor Pieixoto is very well known to all of us through his numerous publications, if not personally, there is little need for further introduction.
es: Professor Pieixoto practically needs no introduction as he is well known to all of us, if not personally, at least through his numerous publications.

en: These include "Sumptuary Laws Through the Ages: An Analysis of Documents" and the well-known study "Iran and Gilead: Two Late-Twentieth-Century Monotheocracies, as Seen Through Diaries."
vi: Among them are "Regulation of Expenditure Through the Ages: An Analysis Based on Data" and the widely known study "Iran and Gilead: Two Theocracies of the Late 20th Century, Through Personal Diaries".
tr: These publications include "Laws Aimed at Preventing the Supply of Money Through the Ages: An Analysis of Documents" and his well-known work "Irene and Gilead: Two Late Twentieth Century Monotheocracies as Seen Through Diaries."
es: Among them are "Sumptuary Laws Through the Ages: An Analysis of Documents," and the well-known study "Iran and Gilead: Two Late Twentieth-Century Monotheocracies Seen Through Diaries."

en: As you all know, he is the co-editor, with Professor Knotly Wade, also of Cambridge, of the manuscript under consideration today, and was instrumental in its transcription, annotation, and publication.
vi: As everyone knows, he is the co-editor, along with Professor Knotly Wade, also from Cambridge, of the manuscript being discussed today, and provided significant support in its transcription, annotation, and publication.
tr: As you all know, he is the co-publisher, along with Professor Knotly Wade from Cambridge, of the tape recordings being examined today, and thus has played a role in their transcription, interpretation, and publication.
es: As you all know, he is the co-director, along with Professor Knotly Wade (Knotted Duck), also from Cambridge, of the manuscript we are discussing today and collaborated in its transcription, commentary, and publication.

en: The title of his talk is "Problems of Authentication in Reference to The Handmaid's Tale."
vi: The title of the talk is: "Issues in Authenticating 'The Handmaid's Tale'."
tr: The title of his speech is "Problems of Authentication and Authorship in Relation to The Handmaid's Tale."
es: The title of this talk is "Authentication Issues Related to The Handmaid's Tale."

en: Professor Pieixoto.
vi: Welcome, professor.
tr: Professor Pieixoto.
es: Professor Pieixoto.

en: Applause.
vi: [ Applause.]
tr: Applause.
es: (Applause.)

en: PIEIXOTO: Thank you.
vi: Pielxoto: Thank you very much.
tr: PIEIXOTO: Thank you.
es: PIEIXOTO: PIEIXOTO: Thank you.

en: I am sure we all enjoyed our charming Arctic Char last night at dinner, and now we are enjoying an equally charming Arctic Chair.
vi: I trust we are all satisfied with the extremely delightful Arctic char we had for dinner last night, and now we are equally satisfied with an Arctic chairwoman who is no less delightful.
tr: I am sure we all enjoyed our lovely Arctic Char23 at last night's dinner, and now we are enjoying an equally lovely Arctic Chair24."
es: I am sure that we all enjoyed the iced tea at dinner last night and that we are now equally enjoying our fiery president.

en: I use the word "enjoy" in two distinct senses, precluding, of course, the obsolete third.
vi: I use the word "satisfied" in two different senses, leaving out, of course, the third, outdated one.
tr: I am using the expression "enjoy" in two different senses, of course excluding the outdated third one.
es: I use the word "enjoy" in two senses, excluding, of course, the third, now obsolete.

en: (Laughter.)
vi: [Loud laughter.]
tr: (Laughter.)
es: (Laughter.)

en: But let me be serious.
vi: But let us discuss serious matters.
tr: Now, with your permission, let me get a bit serious.
es: But let's be serious.

en: I wish, as the title of my little chat implies, to consider some of the problems associated with the soi-disant manuscript which is well known to all of you by now, and which goes by the title of The Handmaid's Tale.
vi: I hope, as the title of today's casual conversation suggests, to consider a few issues related to what we might temporarily call the manuscript that everyone now knows well, known as The Handmaid's Tale.
tr: As the title of my little chat suggests, I would like to address some issues related to the soi-disant tape recordings, now very well known to all of you under the title "The Handmaid's Tale."
es: I would like, as the title of this small talk indicates, to consider some of the problems associated with the supposed manuscript that is already well known to all of you and is titled The Handmaid's Tale.

en: I say soi-disant because what we have before us is not the item in its original form.
vi: I say 'temporarily call' because what we have in our hands is not that item in its original form.
tr: I say soi-disant because what we have before us is not the material in its original form.
es: I say supposed because what we have before us is not the article in its original form.

en: Strictly speaking, it was not a manuscript at all when first discovered and bore no title.
vi: To be precise, when it was first discovered, it was not at all a manuscript, nor did it have a title.
tr: To be more specific, when it was discovered, it did not have the characteristics of an orderly recording and did not have a title either.
es: In strict terms, when we discovered it, it was not a manuscript at all, and it did not have a title.

en: The superscription "The Handmaid's Tale" was ap pended to it by
vi: The phrase "The Handmaid's Tale" was added much later by Professor Wade, partly to pay homage to the great Geoffrey Chaucer; but those who are well acquainted with Professor Wade, like myself, will understand when I say that I am certain every wordplay was intentional, specifically relating to the old colloquial meaning of the word "tail" - tail; which is the bone that everyone fights over, in the period of Gilead society that our epic refers to.
tr: The title "The Handmaid's Tale" was given by Professor Wade, partly out of respect for the great Geoffrey Chaucer; however, those who know Professor Wade as closely as I do will understand what I mean when I say that I am certain all wordplays are done with a specific purpose.
es: The inscription "The Handmaid's Tale" was added by Professor Wade, partly as a tribute to the great Geoffrey Chaucer; but those of you who, like me, know Professor Wade more closely, will understand when I say that I am sure all the puns were intentional, especially the one related to the vulgar meaning of the word "tale" being to some extent the foundation of that phase of Gileadean society that our saga deals with.

en: Professor Wade, partly inhomage to the great Geoffrey Chaucer; but those of you who know Professor Wade in-formally, as I do, will understand when I say hat i am sure allpuns were intentional, particularly that having to do with the ar-chaic vulgar signification of the word tail; that being, In some extent, the bone, as it were, of contention, in that phase of Gileadean society of which our saga treats.
vi: The phrase "The Handmaid's Tale" was added much later by Professor Wade, partly to pay homage to the great Geoffrey Chaucer; but those who are well acquainted with Professor Wade, like myself, will understand when I say that I am certain every wordplay was intentional, specifically relating to the old colloquial meaning of the word "tail" - tail; which is the bone that everyone fights over, in the period of Gilead society that our epic refers to.
tr: Especially when it comes to the wordplay involving the archaic and coarse meaning of the word "tail"; to some extent, it seems to be the very cause of the discord in the Gilead society of our story's period.
es: The inscription "The Handmaid's Tale" was added by Professor Wade, partly as a tribute to the great Geoffrey Chaucer; but those of you who, like me, know Professor Wade more closely, will understand when I say that I am sure all the puns were intentional, especially the one related to the vulgar meaning of the word "tale" being to some extent the foundation of that phase of Gileadean society that our saga deals with.

en: (Laughter, applause.)
vi: [Laughter, applause.]
tr: (Laughter, applause.)
es: (Laughter, applause.)

en: This itemI hesitate to use the word documentwas uncurl hod on the site of what was once the city of Bangor, in what, at the time prior to the inception of the Gileadean regime, would have been the state of Maine.
vi: This item - I am careful not to use the word "document" - was found at a location that was once the city of Bangor, in the region that, before the events leading to the establishment of the Gilead regime, was the state of Maine.
tr: This piece - I hesitate to use the word document - was unearthed in what was once the city of Bangor, in the area formerly known as the State of Maine before the onset of the Gilead regime.
es: This article, I dare not use the word document, was discovered at the site of what was once the city of Bangor, in what, in the time before the beginning of the Gileadean regime, had been the state of Maine.

en: We know that this city was a prominentway station on what our author refers to as "The Underground Fe-maleroad," since dubbed by some of our historical wags "The Underground Frailroad."
vi: We know that this city was an important station on what our female author calls the "Underground Femaleroad," which some joking historians have now dubbed the "Chicken Run."  [Laughter, jeers.]
tr: We know this city as an important way station on what our author has designated the "Underground Femaleroad," which is why our more facetious historians later dubbed it the "Underground Frailroad."
es: We know that this city was an important stopover of what our author calls "the Women's Metropolitan Train," as some of our humorous historians gave it the nickname "the Chicks' Metropolitan Train."

en: (Laughter, groans.)
vi: We know that this city was an important station on what our female author calls the "Underground Femaleroad," which some joking historians have now dubbed the "Chicken Run."  [Laughter, jeers.]
tr: (Laughter, murmurs.)
es: (Laughter and whistles.)

en: For this reason, our association has taken a particular interest in it.
vi: It is because of this that our association has paid special attention to it.
tr: This is why our Union has taken a special interest in it.
es: For this reason, our Association has taken a special interest in it.

en: The item in itspristine state consisted of a metal footlocker, U. S. Army issue, circa perhaps 1955.
vi: The origin of this item includes a personal iron chest, American military supplies, probably around 1955.
tr: In its original form, this piece is a U. S. army item, possibly from around (circa) 1955, consisting of a metal box.
es: The article in its original state consisted of a metal shoebox, for use by the United States Army, perhaps around nineteen fifty-five.

en: This fact of itself need have no significance, as it is known that such footlockers were frequently sold as "army surplus" and must therefore have been widespread.
vi: This fact itself doesn't hold much significance, as we know that such chests were often sold as "surplus military supplies" and thus must have been quite common.
tr: This fact may not be very significant in itself, as it is known that such small boxes are often sold as “army surplus,” and therefore should be easily found.
es: This fact in itself does not have to be significant, as it is known that these shoeboxes were frequently sold as "army surplus," and therefore may have been scattered.

en: Within this footlocker, which was sealed with tape of the kind once used on packages to be sent by post, were approximately thirty tape cassettes, of the type that became obsolete sometime in the eighties or nineties with the advent of the compact disc.
vi: The chest was sealed with tape commonly used for parcels, containing about thirty cassette tapes, which became obsolete around the 80s or 90s when CDs became popular.
tr: Inside this box, there were about thirty tape cassettes, sealed with a type of tape once used for packages sent by mail; these cassettes had become outdated somewhere in the eighties or nineties with the advent of compact discs.
es: Inside this shoebox, sealed with adhesive tape like the kind used in the past for postal packages, there were approximately thirty cassettes, of the type that became obsolete around the eighties or nineties, with the advent of compact discs.

en: I remindyou that this was not the first such discovery.
vi: I would like to reiterate that this is not the first discovery of its kind.
tr: I would like to remind you that this is not the first of such findings.
es: I remind you that this is not the first discovery of this kind.

en: You are doubtless familiar, for instance, with the item known as "The A. B. Memoirs," located in a garage in a suburb of Seattle, and with the Diary of P.," excavated by accident during the erection of a newmeeting house in the vicinity of what was once Syracuse, New York.
vi: Everyone is certainly familiar with, for example, the item known as "Memoir A. B," which appeared in a suburban garage in Seattle, and "Diary of P," accidentally unearthed during the construction of a new apartment building on the outskirts of what used to be Syracuse, New York.
tr: For example, you are undoubtedly familiar with the piece known as "A. B. Memories," discovered in a garage in one of Seattle's existences, and "P.'s Diary," accidentally unearthed during the construction of a new meeting house in the area once known as Syracuse, that is, New York.
es: Without a doubt, you are familiar with the article known as "The Memoirs of A. B.," found in a garage in a suburb of Seattle, and "The Diary of P.," accidentally unearthed during the construction of a new temple near what was once Syracuse, in New York.

en: Professor Wade and I were very excited by this new discovery.
vi: Professor Wade and I were very excited about this discovery.
tr: Professor Wade and I were filled with great excitement when we encountered this new finding.
es: Professor Wade and I were very excited about this new discovery.

en: Luckily we had, several years before, with the aid of our excellent
vi: Fortunately, a few years earlier, with the help of an outstanding archaeological technician residing at the school, we had successfully reconstructed a machine capable of playing these types of tapes, and immediately set to work on the arduous task of decoding them.
tr: Fortunately, a few years ago, with the help of our excellent assistant technician who is an antique enthusiast, we had managed to recreate a machine that could play such tapes, and we immediately set to the arduous task of copying.
es: Fortunately, several years earlier, with the help of our resident antique technician, we had reconstructed a device capable of playing such cassettes, and we immediately undertook the careful task of transcription.

en: resident antiquarian technician, reconstructed a machine capable of playing such tapes, and we immediately set about the painstaking work of transcription.
vi: Fortunately, a few years earlier, with the help of an outstanding archaeological technician residing at the school, we had successfully reconstructed a machine capable of playing these types of tapes, and immediately set to work on the arduous task of decoding them.
tr: Fortunately, a few years ago, with the help of our excellent assistant technician who is an antique enthusiast, we had managed to recreate a machine that could play such tapes, and we immediately set to the arduous task of copying.
es: Fortunately, several years earlier, with the help of our resident antique technician, we had reconstructed a device capable of playing such cassettes, and we immediately undertook the careful task of transcription.

en: There were some thirty tapes in the collection altogether, with varying proportions of music to spoken word.
vi: There are about thirty tapes in total, mixing music and narration in varying proportions.
tr: In our collection, we had about thirty tapes that, despite the conversations, also contained varying amounts of music.
es: In the collection, there were a total of about thirty cassettes, with varying proportions of music and words.

en: In general, each tape begins with two or three songs, as camouflage no doubt; then the music is broken off and the speaking voice takes over.
vi: Generally, each tape would start with about two or three songs, obviously as a disguise, then the music would be interrupted by the narration.
tr: Each tape, undoubtedly for camouflage purposes, usually starts with two or three songs: then the music suddenly stops and the conversation begins.
es: Generally, each cassette begins with two or three songs, undoubtedly used as camouflage: then the music stops and a voice is heard.

en: The voice is a woman's, and, according to our voice-print experts, the same one throughout.
vi: It is a woman's voice and, according to our voice analysis experts, consistent from beginning to end.
tr: The voice belongs to a woman, and according to our sound-recording experts, it is always the same voice speaking.
es: It is the voice of a woman and, according to our phonetics experts, it is the same from beginning to end.

en: The labels on the cassettes were authentic period labels, dating, of course, from some time before the inception of the early Gilead era, as all such secular music was banned under the regime.
vi: The labels on the tapes are authentic contemporary labels, existing long before the events that marked the beginning of Gilead, of course, since such secular music was banned under the regime.
tr: The labels on the tapes were the actual labels from that period, of course, dating back to a time before the early Gilead era, because such worldly music was banned under that regime.
es: The cassette labels were authentic labels that dated, of course, from a time before the beginning of the first Gileadean era since, under this regime, all that profane music was banned.

en: There were, for instance, four tapes entitled "Elvis Presley's Golden Years," three of "Folk Songs of Lithuania," three of "Boy GeorgeTakes It Off," and two of "Mantovani's Mellow Strings," as well as some titles that sported a mere single tape each: "Twisted Sisters at Carnegie Hall" is one of which I am particularly fond.
vi: For example, there are four tapes labeled "Elvis Presley - The Golden Years," three tapes labeled "Lithuanian Folk Songs," three tapes labeled "Boy George Unplugged," and two labeled "Mantovani, Soft Strings," as well as several other tapes not part of any set: "Twisted Sisters at Carnegie Hall" was a particularly favored one.
tr: For example, there were four tapes under the title "The Golden Years of Elvis Presley," three titled "Lithuanian Folk Songs," another three titled "Boy George Lifts It Up," and two titled "Mantovani's Soft Strings." Additionally, there were titles found on a single tape: "Twisted Sister at Carnegie Hall" was one of my personal favorites.
es: For example, there were four cassettes titled "The Golden Years of Elvis Presley," three of "Popular Songs of Lithuania," three from "Boy George Takes It Off" and two from "The Melodious Violins of Mantovani," as well as some titles for which there was only one cassette: "The Twin Sisters at Carnegie Hall," is one of my favorites.

en: Although the labels were authentic, they were not always appended to the tape with the corresponding songs.
